Ramaricium flavomarginatum.habitat: in crevices of the rough bark of large branches of Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), (Burt), on Quercus garryana; bark of large dead branches; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)

Repetobasidium mirificum.habitat: on very decayed conifer wood, like other very thin corticioid fungi mostly found during wet conditions, (Eriksson)

Resinicium bicolor.habitat: on rotten barkless conifer wood, more rarely also on wood of hardwoods, (Breitenbach), on barked or more common barkless wood, causing an intense white decay; common on slash in lumbered forests, (Eriksson), on a variety of conifers and hardwoods; causes a root and butt rot in Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir) and Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), root rot in Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir) and Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), and trunk rot in Abies balsamea and young Abies grandis (Grand Fir), (Ginns), all year; including worked timber, (Buczacki)

Rhizochaete sulphurina.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to sulphur', indicating the color
Rhizochaete sulphurina.habitat: on decayed wood (logs etc.) on conifers and also reported on hardwood, (Eriksson), Picea sp. (spruce), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), (Ginns)

Rhizoctonia fusispora.habitat: normally on hardwood, but now and then also found on coniferous remnants, and more rarely on herbaceous plants and on ferns, (Hjortstam), Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), A. magnifica (California Red Fir), Acer negundo (Boxelder), A. spicatum (Mountain Maple), Betula sp. (birch), Carpinus caroliniana (American Hornbeam), Carya sp. (hickory), Juglans cinerea (Butternut), Phytolacca decandra (poke root), Picea glauca (White Spruce), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), P. tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Salix sp. (willow), Ulmus americana (American Elm), Kretzschmaria deusta (carbon-cushion, Xylariales); rotten wood; decaying wood, (Ginns), on rotten hardwood (Breitenbach), on "rotting wood, soil, herbaceous debris, old grass stalks, decaying fungal fruit bodies and other organic substrates"; all year, (Buczacki)

Rhizoctonia ochracea.habitat: on dead wood of Picea (spruce), according to the literature on rotten wood; fall, (Breitenbach), on decaying wood (Julich), on bark and dead wood; Picea glauca (white spruce), (Ginns)

Rhizoctonia solani.habitat: on "bare earth, wood and bark lying on the ground, and on living stems of potatoes, beans, rhubarb, horseradish, tomatoes, Amaranthus etc. at or near the ground", (Burt, genus name italicized), causes a variety of diseases, including Rhizoctonia root rot, brown patch of turf, web blight of seedlings of Aleurites fordii, Catalpa spp., and Ficus sp.; fruiting bodies typically produced on live stems; also on wood and bark lying on the ground; over 400 genera of host plants, (Ginns), mainly growing on stems of Solanum tuberosum (potato) but also collected on leaves of other herbaceous plants (Hjortstam), on rotting herbaceous and vegetable debris, woody remains, litter, soil and living stems and leaves; all year, (Buczacki)

Schizopora flavipora.habitat: annual, on dead hardwoods, associated with white rot of dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), on dead wood or hardwood trees, also sometimes on shrubs, conifers and structural timbers in buildings; late summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Schizopora paradoxa.habitat: collections examined from Corylus (Hallenberg), Alnus (alder), Araucaria, Betula (birch), Carpinus (hornbeam), Eucalyptus, Fagus (beech), Laurus, Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), Syringa, Sorbus (mountain-ash), Taxus (yew), (Langer), on dead wood of hardwoods causing white soft rot, occasionally on conifers, shrubs and herbaceous plants and old polypore fruitbodies; all year, (Buczacki)

Schizopora radula.habitat: collections examined from Abies (fir), Alnus (alder), Castanea (chestnut), Fraxinus (ash), Quercus (oak), (Hallenberg), on Eucalyptus, Populus, Sorbus (mountain-ash), Quercus, (Langer), all year (Buczacki)

Scopuloides hydnoides.habitat: on both barked and barkless wood of hardwoods, rarely seen on coniferous wood, (Eriksson), on rotten wood of hardwoods, especially on the underside of small trunks and branches of Fagus (beech) lying on the ground, (Breitenbach), on Acer (maple), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Nyssa (tupelo), Populus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Tilia (basswood), Ulmus (elm); bark and wood; charred wood; dead branches; rotten trunks; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), especially Alnus and Salix in wet habitats; spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Scytinostroma galactinum.habitat: found on a variety of conifers and hardwoods; causes a root and butt rot of woody plants; fruitbodies produced on slash, rotten logs, stumps, wood and roots, old conk; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), associated with a white rot of conifer wood and occasionally of hardwood throughout North America, (Nakasone)

Scytinostroma jacksonii.nameOrigin: in honor of Professor H.S. Jackson
Scytinostroma jacksonii.habitat: on Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Tsuga sp. (hemlock); associated with a white rot, (Ginns)

Scytinostroma ochroleucum.habitat: on Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock); on bark; on decaying wood, (Ginns), on hardwoods and conifers (Julich), on yew in United Kingdom; probably all year, (Buczacki)

Scytinostroma portentosum.habitat: on Acacia, Acer (maple), Aleurites, Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Bouganvillea, Carya (hickory), Crossosoma (rockflower), Gleditsia (locust), Juniperus (juniper), Mortonia, Prosopis, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Sambucus (elderberry), Sapindus (soapberry), (Ginns), on Hedera helix (ivy), according to literature on Salix (willow) as well as other hardwoods and shrubs; spring to fall, (Breitenbach), usually on underside of fallen branches or trunks; probably all year, (Buczacki)

Scytinostroma protrusum.habitat: subspecies protrusum is often associated with a root rot of various hardwoods, especially apple, subspecies septentrionale is found typically on hardwoods such as Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), and Populus, (Nakasone)

Scytinostromella arachnoidea.habitat: Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce), P. rubens (Red Spruce), P. sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock); rotted log; log; associated with a white rot, (Ginns(5))

Scytinostromella heterogenea.habitat: on bark and barkless wood of hardwoods and conifers, Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Pinus (pine), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns(24)), on decayed wood in humid forests, many from much decayed wood of Picea (spruce), but also on Alnus (alder), Pinus, and Salix (willow), (Eriksson)

Scytinostromella humifaciens.habitat: on the "underside of 1) a very rotten stick on ground, 2) rotted log and 3) charred and rotted wood of conifers"; Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Ginns(24))

Sebacina epigaea.habitat: on hardwood, rarely conifer wood; Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Elaeagnus, Fraxinus (ash), Juniperus (juniper), Mimosa, Populus, Quercus (oak); rotten wood; branches; old hard heart of branch; bark at bases of live trees; underside of logs; fallen leaves and debris; underside of very old cow dung; soil, (Ginns), "on plant remains lying on the ground, also commonly growing over soil, rocks, etc.", summer to fall, (Breitenbach), "on soil, bases of living trees, and the lower sides of very rotten logs", (Martin)

Serpula himantioides.habitat: on litter and decaying wood of conifers and hardwoods, (Cooke); on litter and rotten wood; dead trees; associated with a brown rot; conifers and hardwoods; causes significant butt rot in Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), trunk rot in Chamaecyparis nootkatensis (Alaska cedar), and heart rot in Picea glauca (White Spruce) and P. rubens (Red Spruce), (Ginns(5)), fall (Buczacki)

Serpula lacrimans.habitat: "serious pest of structural wood in old houses, buildings, ships, etc., usually developing indoors or in poorly ventilated situations, often hiding under floorboards"; bulging wood and musty odor are signs of its presence, (Arora), on "conifer wood used in construction, more rarely on hardwood, commonly in old cellars, staircases, and other poorly ventilated rooms, grows over wood, walls, carpets, etc."; throughout the year, (Breitenbach); associated with a brown rot; wood of Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Abies magnifica [California Red Fir], Pinus contorta [Lodgepole Pine], Pinus ponderosa [Ponderosa Pine], Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata [Western Red Cedar], Tsuga mertensiana [Mountain Hemlock], (Ginns(5)), on conifer logs in woods, but more often encountered on indoor wood; June to January, but year-round indoors, (Lincoff)

Sistotrema adnatum.nameOrigin: means 'adnate' referring to adnate (firm) attachment to substrate

Sistotrema brinkmannii.habitat: both in hardwood and coniferous forests, in gardens etc.; mostly "on much decayed wood, but may be found on all kinds of debris as well as on peat, soil, old paper, dead fruitbodies of Aphyllophorales", etc.; early spring to late fall, (Eriksson), on rotting wood and bark, herbaceous and fern debris, old leather articles, old fungal fruitbodies, and other organic substrates; all year, (Buczacki)

Sistotrema confluens.nameOrigin: means 'confluent', referring to the tendency of fruitbodies to intergrow
Sistotrema confluens.odour: 'distinct and characteristic, described by some people as vanilla, by others as "disagreeable" ', (Eriksson), faint (Coker)
Sistotrema confluens.habitat: on ground "among mosses and fallen leaves and other litter in hardwood or conifer forests, less often in open fields", (Eriksson), needles and wood on the ground, hosts Pinus sp., P. contorta, Populus sp., (Ginns), our collections occurring "in mats of pine straw" [pine needle beds], (Coker), gregarious, forming colonies more or less spread out on the soil among plants and mosses in forests that are coniferous, mixed, or hardwood; fruiting in summer and fall, (McNeil)

Sistotrema coroniferum.nameOrigin: means 'bearing a crown', perhaps referring to the basidia
Sistotrema coroniferum.habitat: on "much decayed, moist wood of conifers", especially Picea (spruce), but also of hardwoods such as Fagus (beech), Betula (birch), Populus, and Salix (willow), (Eriksson), on dead, barkless wood; throughout the year, (Breitenbach); on fallen cones and dead wood; decaying, charred wood; associated with a white rot; Acer (maple), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Quercus (oak), Ulmus (elm), (Ginns), on rotting wood, dead bramble stems, and old fungal fruitbodies; all year, (Buczacki)

Sistotrema diademiferum.nameOrigin: means 'bearing a diadem', likely referring to the appearance of the basidia
Sistotrema diademiferum.habitat: on coniferous and hardwood wood and bark, "mostly seen on fallen twigs and branches, less often on trunks", (Eriksson), Gossypium barbadense (creole cotton), Picea sp. (spruce), Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), Populus sp., Pyrus malus (Apple), Quercus sp. (oak); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), spring to fall (Bourdot), on rotting wood, litter, and old herbaceous and fern debris; probably all year, (Buczacki)

Sistotrema farinaceum.habitat: type on a fallen log of Populus (Hallenberg)

Sistotrema hirschii.habitat: Betula sp. (birch), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Populus grandidentata (Bigtooth Aspen), Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), Salix gooddingii (Goodding Willow), (Ginns), on debarked wood of Populus grandidentata and Quercus garryana, (Rogers)

Sistotrema oblongisporum.habitat: on smooth bark of only slightly decayed, fallen or hanging branches of hardwoods; some collections on conifer branches (Picea, Pinus) also seem to belong here, (Eriksson), fallen branch of Alnus (alder); stump of Pinus radiata (Monterey Pine); fallen or hanging branches of hardwood trees, (Hallenberg), on rotting wood and litter of hardwood trees and old herbaceous and fern debris; probably all year, (Buczacki)

Sistotrema porulosum.habitat: type on fallen branch of Acer (maple), paratype on fallen branch, second paratype on Populus, (Hallenberg)

Sistotrema raduloides.habitat: on very decayed wood of hardwoods with a preference for Populus tremula [European Aspen] but also on other hardwoods (e.g. Betula, Quercus, Malus), rarely on coniferous wood (Picea), seen from North America on Populus spp. and coniferous wood, (Eriksson), on bark; decayed barkless wood; logs; associated with a white rot; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Picea (spruce), Populus, Tilia (basswood), Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns)

Sistotrema resinicystidium.habitat: on decayed hardwood and coniferous wood, (Eriksson), on brown-rotted wood of Quercus (oak) (Hallenberg)

Sistotremastrum niveocremeum.habitat: on decayed wood of hardwoods (e.g. Quercus, Corylus, Alnus) and sometimes on Picea (spruce), (Eriksson), "on the underside of dead, barkless hardwood"; fall to winter, (Breitenbach), on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Populus, Quercus (oak), Sassafras, (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)

Sistotremastrum suecicum.habitat: Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Juniperus (juniper), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja, (Ginns), mostly on conifer wood, especially of Pinus (pine), but not rare on Picea (spruce), a few collections on Juniperus (juniper) and on hardwood, also on old fallen fences, (Eriksson)

Skvortzovia furfuracea.habitat: on decayed, mostly barkless coniferous wood, (Eriksson), on decaying wood of logs; moss-covered bark; charred wood; associated with a white rot; Abies (fir), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Juniperus (juniper), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns)

Sphaerobasidium minutum.habitat: on old, barkless, conifer wood (Pinus, Picea, Abies), also on wooden fences, (Eriksson), on decayed hardwood, and wood or bark of Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), and stems of Pteridium aquilinum (bracken fern), (Liberta)

Sphaeronaemella helvellae.nameOrigin: means 'on Helvella', an older genus name for the Gyromitra host species
Sphaeronaemella helvellae.habitat: on fruitbodies of Gyromitra infula, Gyromitra ambigua

Steccherinum bourdotii.habitat: found on wood of Quercus (oak) and Carpinus betulus (European hornbeam), (Bernicchia(2)), on host trees of 14 genera, only one occurrence on conifer wood, (Piatek)

Steccherinum ciliolatum.habitat: on decayed wood; slash; logs; associated with a white rot; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Malus, Picea (spruce), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), (Ginns)

Steccherinum fimbriatum.habitat: on bark and barkless wood, slash; logs; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Amelanchier (serviceberry), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Juniperus (juniper), Liriodendron (Tuliptree), Notholithocarpus (Tanoak), Ostrya (hophornbeam), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prunus, Quercus (oak), Rhus, Salix (willow), Umbellularia, (Ginns), associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on bark as well as on barkless hardwood, more rarely on Juniperus and other coniferous substrates, (Eriksson), on rotten hardwood, more rarely conifer wood, usually on underside; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on fallen branches and decaying wood of hardwoods and conifers, (Maas Geesteranus), all year (Buczacki)

Steccherinum laeticolor.habitat: on Acer (maple), Celtis (hackberry), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Prunus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Ulmus (elm); on dead wood; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on hardwood (Fagus, Fraxinus, Prunus, Quercus, Ulmus), (Maas Geesteranus)

Steccherinum ochraceum.habitat: on fallen branches and decaying wood of hardwoods and conifers, (Maas Geesteranus), on hardwood, Corylus (hazel), Fagus (beech), Quercus (oak), Tilia (basswood), Ulmus (elm), (Eriksson), on dead hardwood (especially Fagus), more rarely conifer wood, with or without bark, "resupinate forms principally on trunks and branches lying on the ground", capped forms on standing trunks; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on a variety of hardwoods, also Cupressus macrocarpa (Monterey Cypress), Juniperus virginiana (Eastern Juniper), Picea pungens (Blue Spruce), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Ginns), June to October, sometimes year-round, (Lincoff(2))

Steccherinum queletii.habitat: Acer rubrum (Red Maple), A. saccharinum (Silver Maple); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on branches of Abies alba (European Silver Fir), both on still attached and fallen branches, (Eriksson)

Steccherinum subcrinale.habitat: on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock); on rotting logs; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on fallen trunks and branches of Picea (spruce), Fagus (beech), and Betula (birch), (Eriksson)

Stereum complicatum.nameOrigin: means 'complicate' (bent upon itself), indicating its pattern of cap folding
Stereum complicatum.habitat: "in overlapping or laterally fused groups on dead twigs and stumps of hardwoods, especially oak"; July to January, fruitbody overwinters, (Phillips), fruiting year round (Miller), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Juniperus (juniper), Nyssa (tupelo), Picea (spruce), Populus, Prunus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Thuja, Weigelia; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)

Stereum gausapatum.nameOrigin: from 'gausapa', meaning 'shaggy, woolen cloth or garment'
Stereum gausapatum.habitat: restricted to Quercus (oak), (Chamuris(4)), on dead wood of Quercus with and without bark, on standing and fallen trunks, and attached or fallen branches, often covering entire trunks and branches for meters; according to the literature also occurring rarely on other hardwoods, (Breitenbach), restricted to Quercus in Scandinavia, usually on standing trunks and still attached branches, more rarely on fallen branches and other debris of oak, (Eriksson), reported on 16 species of oak and on a variety of hardwoods, also reported on Pseudotsuga menziesii, (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)

Stereum hirsutum.habitat: often covering entire trunks and branches for meters; on dead wood of hardwoods with and without bark, on standing and fallen trunks, and on attached and fallen branches; throughout the year, (Breitenbach) |on hardwood but occasionally also on Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), (Eriksson) |on many genera of hardwoods, also reported on Abies (fir), Juniperus (juniper), Larix (larch), Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga (hemlock); associated with a white rot, (Ginns) |all year (Buczacki)

Stereum ochraceoflavum.habitat: on dead branches and twigs of hardwoods, especially Quercus (oak), still with bark, occasionally massively covering branches lying on the ground; throughout the year, (Breitenbach) on a variety of hardwoods, reported on Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce) and isolated from decay in utility poles of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), associated with a white rot, (Ginns)

Stereum ostrea.habitat: on logs and stumps of hardwoods, especially oak; all year, (Phillips), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Carpinus (hornbeam), Carya (hickory), Castanea (chestnut), Catalpa, Celtis laevigata (Sugarberry), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Juglans (walnut), Liquidambar styraciflua (Sweetgum), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Myrica (bayberry), Nyssa (tupelo), Picea (spruce), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Sequoia (redwood), Tilia (basswood), Tsuga (hemlock), Ulmus (elm), (Ginns)

Stereum rugosum.habitat: on dead, standing or fallen wood of hardwoods, with and without bark; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on hardwood of many kinds, especially on standing dead trunks where it can cover large areas, (Eriksson), on various hardwoods, also reported from Abies (fir), Picea (spruce) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Ginns)

Stereum sanguinolentum.nameOrigin: from 'sanguis', Latin for 'blood' and '-lentus', Latin for 'full of, prone to'
Stereum sanguinolentum.habitat: on dead wood of conifers, with and without bark; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on coniferous wood, (Eriksson), Abies (fir), Alnus (alder), Amelanchier (serviceberry), Fagus (beech), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on conifers, especially Tsuga, Pinus, and Picea; July to March, (Lincoff)

Stereum subtomentosum.habitat: annual, on Alnus (alder) and other hardwoods, (Eriksson), gregarious, sometimes covering entire branches, on dead wood of various hardwoods; annual, sometimes also perennial, (Breitenbach), all year (Buczacki)

Stypella dubia.habitat: on rotten coniferous wood and hardwood, (Martin), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Fagus grandifolia (American Beech), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), Populus, Ulmus (elm), (Ginns), fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)

Stypella grilletii.habitat: appears to be restricted to hardwood (Roberts), on barkless hardwood or rarely conifer wood, (Martin for Sebacina podlachica), dead wood; twigs and dead branches; Alnus sp. (alder), Pinus sp. (pine), Pseudotsuga sp. (Douglas-fir), Quercus sp. (oak), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Ulmus sp. (elm), (Ginns for Myxarium grilletii), Amelanchier sp. (serviceberry) Elaeagnus commutata (silverberry), Lyonothamnus floribundus (Catalina Ironwood), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), Prunus sp., P. serotina (Black Cherry), Quercus sp. (oak), Ulmus sp. (elm), (Ginns for Sebacina podlachica), probably all year; on rotting hardwood, rarely on conifer wood, dead herbaceous material and dead pyrenomycete fruitbodies, (Buczacki)

Stypella subgelatinosa.habitat: on fallen hardwood and conifer wood, (Roberts), on Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Quercus (oak), Pinus (pine), (Reid), dead hardwood, (or coniferous wood?), (Martin), probably all year (Buczacki)

Stypella subhyalina.habitat: on fallen hardwood, occasionally on old polypore fruitbodies, (Roberts), on rotten, barkless wood; on limb; thelephoraceous fungus, Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Populus sp., Prunus sp., Quercus sp. (oak), Salix sp. (willow), Tilia sp. (basswood), Ulmus sp. (elm), (Ginns), on Fagus (beech), (Reid), probably all year; on rotting hardwood, rarely on rotting polypore fruitbodies, (Buczacki)

Subulicium lautum.habitat: mostly on coniferous wood, also on dead or decaying ferns, (Eriksson), Thuja occidentalis, Tsuga canadensis, (Ginns), both on coniferous wood and hardwood, also collected on lumber, (Hjortstam)

Subulicystidium longisporum.habitat: on hardwood, rarely conifer wood, on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fraxinus (ash), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Picea (spruce), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Ulmus (elm); bark and decaying wood; barkless wood; bark of rotten limb; slash; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on decayed wood of hardwoods and other debris on the ground, also collected on herbs (Aconitum), (Eriksson), on dead barkless conifer wood, according to the literature also on hardwood; fall, (Breitenbach), on rather rotten wood (Julich)

Syzygospora subsolida.habitat: on surface of hypertrophied caps of Pseudomarasmius pallidocephalus, sometimes completely obscuring the cap

Thujacorticium mirabile.habitat: on old, barkless, decayed logs of Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), but 2 collections on unidentified logs were presumably on T. plicata, (Ginns(14))

Tomentella asperula.habitat: Juniperus virginiana (Eastern Juniper), Populus balsamifera (Balsam Poplar), Thuja sp., (Ginns), the Idaho collection "lignicolous", (Larsen)

Tomentella avellanea.habitat: on wood or humus (Larsen), Abies sp. (fir), Picea sp. (spruce), Pinus sp. (pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Ginns)

Tomentella badia.habitat: on a variety of woody substrates, of both angiosperms and gymnosperms, (Larsen), Alnus tenuifolia (Thinleaf Alder), Betula alleghaniensis (Yellow Birch), Fagus sp. (beech), Picea glauca (White Spruce), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus sp., P. tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), (Ginns(5)), early summer to fall; also rarely on soil, (Buczacki)

Tomentella bryophila.habitat: on the underside of rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, summer-fall, (Breitenbach), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Amelanchier (serviceberry), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking aspen), Quercus (oak), Robinia (locust), Thuja sp., Tsuga (hemlock), Fomes sp. (polypore), (Ginns), in Belgium, recorded on moss, and in France lapidicolous [on rock], (Larsen), on rotting wood and bark of hardwoods, "rarely on other organic materials such as old leather"; summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Tomentella calcicola.nameOrigin: means 'living on stone': Bourdot and Galzin collection was lapidicolous
Tomentella calcicola.habitat: Acer sp. (maple), Alnus sp. (alder), A. incana (Speckled Alder), A. tenuifolia (Thinleaf Alder), Picea sp. (spruce), Populus sp., P. tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), P. trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), (Ginns), in Europe also on Juniperus (juniper) and lapidicolous [on rock], (Larsen)

Tomentella cinerascens.habitat: Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Picea (spruce), Populus, Tilia (basswood), Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns), also Phragmites (reed), Salix (willow), Aesculus, moss, (Larsen, in Europe), summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Tomentella coerulea.habitat: Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Alnus sp. (alder), Betula sp. (birch), Fraxinus nigra (Black Ash), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Prosopis juliflora (Mesquite), Quercus gambelii (Gambel's Oak), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), Tsuga sp. (hemlock), (Ginns), noted with some collections in Europe to be terricolous as well as lignicolous, (Larsen), on rotting wood and occasionally on soil; fall (Buczacki)

Tomentella crinalis.habitat: on rotten wood of conifers and hardwoods, fall-spring, (Breitenbach), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fraxinus (ash), Pinus (pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Quercus (oak), Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns)

Tomentella ellisii.habitat: on wood, also humicolous [on humus] and terricolous [on ground], (Larsen), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Spiraea, Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns), on rotting wood of hardwoods and conifers, "also recorded on debris of bulrush and common reed"; summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Tomentella ferruginea.habitat: usually on wood, also recorded as "humicolous, lignicolous", as "on angiospermous wood, terricolous", and as "lignicolous, leather scraps", (Larsen), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Juglans (walnut), Juniperus (juniper), Liriodendron, Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Tilia (basswood), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga (hemlock), Yucca, (Ginns), on rotting hardwood, also recorded on rush debris; summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Tomentella fibrosa.habitat: on rotten wood, as well as bark of hardwoods and conifers, (Breitenbach), Betula (birch), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock); decayed leaves; organic debris, (Ginns(5)), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Tomentella fuscoferruginosa.habitat: Abies sp. (fir), Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Acer sp. (maple), Betula sp. (birch), Pinus sp. (pine), Populus sp., Quercus sp. (oak), (Ginns), in Poland on Alnus (alder), (Larsen)

Tomentella kootenaiensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Kootenay', referring to Kootenay National Park, where type was found
Tomentella kootenaiensis.habitat: on Populus sp., also on coniferous wood, (Larsen)

Tomentella lilacinogrisea.habitat: Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Carpinus (hornbeam), Fagus (beech), Larix (larch), Pinus (pine), Populus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Thuja, Tilia (basswood), Tsuga (hemlock), Polyporus (polypore), (Ginns), also in Europe on Castanea (chestnut), Cerasus, Crataegus (hawthorn), Juniperus (juniper), Picea (spruce), in France on coniferous wood, lapidicolous [on rock], (Larsen), fall; also on fern debris, (Buczacki)

Tomentella nitellina.habitat: in Washington on Picea (spruce), in France lapidicolous [on rock], (Larsen), Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Picea sp. (spruce), Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Populus sp., Populus balsamifera (Balsam Poplar), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), Thuja plicata (Western Red-Cedar); on twig (Ginns)

Tomentella pilosa.habitat: on dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, commonly on the underside of rotten branches, (Breitenbach), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Liriodendron, Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Tilia (basswood), Ulmus (elm), (Ginns), also Alnus (alder), Carpinus (hornbeam), Fagus (beech), Thymus (thyme), moss, (Larsen, in Europe), fall (Buczacki)

Tomentella ramosissima.habitat: Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Thuja, Tilia (basswood), (Ginns), also Cedrus (cedar), Carpinus (hornbeam), (Larsen), fall (Buczacki)

Tomentella rubiginosa.habitat: Carya (= Hicoria) sp., Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Liriodendron, Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prunus, Quercus (oak), Thuja, Tilia (basswood), Rhododendron, Carex (sedge), Cymophyllus fraseri (Fraser's sedge); dead leaves and wood, (Ginns), also in Europe Carpinus (hornbeam), Crataegus (hawthorn), Sorbus, leaves of Juniperus (juniper) and of Quercus, (Larsen), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Tomentella stuposa.habitat: associated with conifers and hardwoods, (Stalpers), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Magnolia, Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Thuja, Tilia (basswood), Tsuga (hemlock), Polyporus sp. (polypore), (Ginns), also in Czechoslovakia Carpinus (hornbeam), Cornus (dogwood), Quercus (oak), Rubus (berry cane), Salix (willow), Sorbus (mountain-ash), Trametes, (polypore), (Larsen), late summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Tomentella sublilacina.habitat: Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Juglans (walnut), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Prunus, Quercus (oak), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), Fomes (polypore), Ganoderma (polypore), Polyporus (polypore), Hypoxylon, Lycopodium, moss, (Ginns), also in Europe Carpinus (hornbeam), Cornus (dogwood), Juniperus (juniper), Juncus (rush), lapidicolous [on rock], (Larsen, M.J.(9)), on "rotting wood, leaves, litter and on soil" in wet habitats "in woodland, marshes, pond margins and similar sites especially when the soil is drying out"; late summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Tomentella subvinosa.habitat: Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Picea (spruce), Populus, Sassafras, Tilia (basswood), (Ginns)

Tomentella terrestris.habitat: on the underside of very rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, "also growing over the soil"; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), Abies sp. (fir), Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Acer sp. (maple), Betula sp. (birch), Castanea sp. (chestnut), Picea sp. (spruce), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), Pinus sp. (pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus sp., Populus balsamifera (Balsam Poplar), Quercus sp. (oak), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-cedar), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga (hemlock), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), (Ginns), also in Europe on Sorbus (mountain-ash), Diatrype (a pyrenomycete), lapidicolous [on rock], (Larsen)

Tomentellopsis echinospora.habitat: on the underside of very rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, according to the literature also on the underside of mosses, leaves, and rocks; winter half of the year, (Breitenbach); Carya sp. (hickory), Pinus sp. (pine), Pinus banksiana (Jack Pine), Populus spp.; on bark, (Ginns(5)), fall; also recorded on old horse dung, (Buczacki)

Trechispora farinacea.habitat: on well decayed wood of both hardwoods and conifers, (Hjortstam), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Celtis (hackberry), Fraxinus (ash), Juniperus (juniper), Liquidambar, Malus, Phoenix canariensis (Dwarf Date Palm), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Platanus (sycamore), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Rhododendron, Tsuga (hemlock), Ulmus (elm); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on a variety of substrates, including decayed stems, wood and bark of hardwoods and conifers, Typha latifolia (cat-tail), Viburnum, humus, leaves, moss, and fruitbodies of Ganoderma, (Liberta), on rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, "on the undersides of fallen branches, as well as in cavities in rotten stumps"; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on rotting wood, old polypore fruitbodies, and occasionally herbaceous debris; summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Trechispora microspora.habitat: on both hardwood and coniferous wood, and also collected on fern remains, (Hjortstam), on hardwood, conifer wood, moss, and leaf debris, (Liberta), on very rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), on woody plant debris, also occasionally on rotting fronds of male fern; summer, fall, winter, (Buczacki)

Trechispora mollusca.habitat: annual, on dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, associated with a white rot of conifer and hardwood logs and slash, (Gilbertson), usually growing in well sheltered places on strongly decayed trunks and branches, (Hjortstam), on the underside of rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, also on leaves and other plant remains, (Breitenbach), also on Fomes fomentarius (Liberta)

Tubulicium vermiferum.nameOrigin: means 'bearing worms', presumably referring to the spores or cystidia
Tubulicium vermiferum.habitat: on dicotyledonous wood (Weresub), Antidesma, Calluna, Cibotium, Citharexylum, Cocos, Dysoxylum, Erica, Eugenia, Gaultheria, Livistonia, Metrosideros, Olearia, Osmaronia, Pseudopanax, Salix cinerea, Senecio, Vaccinium, Vitex, (Ginns), usually on bark of living trees and bushes of Salix and Corylus (Hjortstam), late summer to winter (Buczacki)

Tubulicrinis accedens.habitat: on decayed wood; Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), (Ginns), especially on Pinus (pine), but often on Picea (spruce), Juniperus (juniper), and fencing, very occasionally on hardwood, (Hjortstam), on rotten conifer wood, especially Picea; fall, (Breitenbach), fall (Buczacki)

Tubulicrinis angustus.habitat: on decayed conifer wood, mostly on Pinus (pine), sometimes on fencing and occasionally on hardwood, (Hjortstam), on rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on Fagus (beech), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Tubulicrinis borealis.habitat: on all kinds of barkless conifer wood, "often on fencing and other timber lying on the ground", (Hjortstam), on rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, as well as old resupinate polypores; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Ginns)

Tubulicrinis calothrix.habitat: on all kinds of coniferous wood, scattered on fencing and other barkless timber, (Hjortstam), usually on coniferous wood (Weresub(3)), on Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Tsuga (hemlock); slash; logs; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)

Tubulicrinis chaetophorus.habitat: on coniferous wood, but also reported on Alnus (alder), (Hjortstam), Abies magnifica (California Red Fir), Picea sp. (spruce), Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock); on rotting wood, (Ginns)

Tubulicrinis globisporus.habitat: on fallen branches and trunks of coniferous wood, mostly on Pinus (pine) but also on Picea (spruce) and Abies (fir), (Hjortstam(4)), mostly on Pinus, (Hjortstam(6)), in BC on fallen trunk of Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), (Ginns)

Tubulicrinis gracillimus.habitat: on hardwood and conifer wood, (Hjortstam), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Juniperus (juniper), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prunus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Salix (willow), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock); "Bark; rarely bark; decaying wood; twig; slash; bark or between loose bark and wood of logs; associated with a white rot", (Ginns), on rotten conifer wood, especially of Picea and Pinus; fall, (Breitenbach)

Tubulicrinis inornatus.habitat: on well decayed and barkless wood of both Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), (Hjortstam), on Abies balsamea (Subalpine Fir), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), P. strobus (Eastern White Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Ginns)

Tubulicrinis juniperinus.habitat: on coniferous wood (Weresub(3)), on Picea sp. (spruce), conifer, (Ginns)

Tubulicrinis prominens.habitat: on Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine); on rotting wood, (Ginns)

Tubulicrinis regificus.habitat: on bark and barkless wood of conifers, (Hjortstam), type on coniferous wood, (Jackson)

Tubulicrinis subulatus.nameOrigin: means 'subulate' referring to the shape of the cystidia
Tubulicrinis subulatus.habitat: on all kinds of coniferous wood and occasionally on hardwood, (Hjortstam), on rotten wood of conifers; spring to fall, (Breitenbach), on wood of Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), and Pinus (pine); associated with a white rot, (Ginns), probably all year (Buczacki)

Tulasnella allantospora.habitat: bark and debarked wood of hardwoods, rarely on coniferous wood, (Martin, G.W.), on Pinus ponderosus (Gilbertson, who is writing about species that grow on that host)

Tulasnella bifrons.habitat: on barkless wood of Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), and Ulmus (elm), (Martin), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Pinus, Quercus, Ulmus; underside of moist rotten wood; fertile surface of decaying shelf fungus, (Ginns)

Tulasnella calospora.habitat: on decayed hardwood and conifer wood, (Martin), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Quercus (oak), Calopogon sp., Goodyera sp., Habenaria sp., Platanthera obtusata, Pogonia sp., Spiranthes sp.; mycorrhizal with species of Orchidaceae; on old shelf fungi; on dead mosses, (Ginns)

Tulasnella eichleriana.habitat: on rotting wood and bark, Betula sp. (birch), Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch), Populus sp., Quercus sp. (oak), Salix sp. (willow), (Ginns), also Alnus (alder), Corylus (hazel), Fagus (beech), Nothofagus (southern beech), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), (Roberts)

Tulasnella fuscoviolacea.habitat: mainly on coniferous wood, (Martin), Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock), hardwood; bark; rotten wood; pine cone, (Ginns)

Tulasnella pinicola.habitat: bark and barkless wood of coniferous and hardwood species, and on old fruitbodies of tough or woody hymenomycetes, (Martin, G.W.), Betula nigra (River Birch), Carya sp. (hickory), Cytisus sp. (broom), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tulip-poplar), Mimosa sp., Quercus sp., Quercus rubra (Northern Red Oak), (Ginns), barked and debarked hardwood (oak, tulip poplar, river birch, hickory, and Mimosa), fall to spring, (Olive(3) for GA)

Tulasnella pruinosa.habitat: hardwood without bark, (Martin), Acer sp. (maple), Betula nigra (River Birch), Carpinus caroliniana (American Hornbeam), Castanea sp. (chestnut), Fagus sp. (beech), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), Quercus sp. (oak), Salix sp. (willow), Ulmus sp. (elm), (Ginns)

Tulasnella violea.habitat: on "branches of conifers and hardwoods with and without bark and lying on the ground, as well as on old polypores"; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), dead wood, bark, lichens, old shelf polypores, (Martin), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Carya (hickory), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Holodiscus discolor (Ocean-spray), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Nyssa (tupelo), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Quercus (oak), Salix (willow); bark; very rotten wood, limb; fallen branches, old polypores, (Ginns)

Tylospora asterophora.habitat: mostly on well decayed wood but found on all kinds of debris on the ground, (Hjortstam), on the underside of very rotten conifer branches lying on the ground and overgrown with moss, according to the literature also on dead leaves, mosses and bare earth; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), on soil, conifer needle litter and other debris in plantations, especially with Picea (spruce) "but probably only on acidic sites", also with Sphagnum in wet woodland, (Buczacki)

Vararia investiens.habitat: on fallen wood (Welden); fallen twigs and branches; logs; Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Carya (hickory), Larix (larch), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Paxistima myrsinites (Falsebox), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prunus, Quercus (oak), Rhododendron, Tsuga (hemlock); associated with a white rot, (Ginns)

Vararia phyllophila.habitat: on fallen hardwood and conifer wood, (Welden), on Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), Populus sp., Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Quercus sp. (oak); on dried leaves; on fallen leaves and limbs; on wood on ground, (Ginns)

Vararia racemosa.nameOrigin: means 'full of clusters', Burt refers to the paraphyses "with tips branched sometimes racemosely"
Vararia racemosa.habitat: on bark and wood of decaying logs; July to September, (Burt), on Abies (fir), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar); decaying wood and bark; slash; logs; associated with a white rot, (Ginns)

Veluticeps abietina.habitat: Abies (fir), Larix (larch), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock); on bark; wood and logs; debarked log; fence timber; associated with a brown rot, (Ginns), on wood and bark of coniferous logs and stumps, especially Abies and Picea; associated with a brown rot, (Nakasone), on "logs and branches of conifers, in North Europe usually on Picea abies", (Eriksson, Latin name italicized), on stumps and the ends of fallen trunks of Picea (spruce), more rarely on branches, according to literature also on Abies (fir); throughout the year, (Breitenbach)

Veluticeps ambigua.habitat: on conifer wood, especially Picea [spruce] and Abies [fir], (Nakasone); Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock); bark; moss-covered wood; cut wood; butt; log; associated with a brown rot, (Ginns), on rotten stumps of Picea (spruce) and according to literature also on rotten spruce beams, (Breitenbach)

Veluticeps fimbriata.habitat: on barkless coniferous logs, especially Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce); associated with a brown rot, (Nakasone); Abies, Larix (larch), Picea, Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock), (Ginns)

Waitea circinata.nameOrigin: means 'coiled, curled away from an apex'
Waitea circinata.habitat: Agrostis palustris (creeping bentgrass), A. stolonifera (redtop), Avena sativa (oats), Beta vulgaris (beet), Bromus tectorum (cheatgrass), Cucumis sativus (cucumber), Daucus carota (carrot), Festuca arundinacea (tall fescue), Glycine max (soybean), Helianthus annuus (common sunflower), Hordeum vulgare (barley), Oryza sativa (rice), Pennisetum glaucum (pearl millet), Phaseolus lunatus (lima bean), Pinus banksiana (Jack Pine), Raphanus sativus (radish), Schizachyrium scoparium (little bluestem), Stenotaphrum secundatum (St. Augustine grass), Triticum aestivum (wheat), Zea mays (maize), (Ginns)

Xenasma rimicola.habitat: on deciduous wood, (Hjortstam), Acer sp., (maple), Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Alnus sp. (alder), Fraxinus sp. (ash), Picea sp. (spruce), Populus sp., Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), Rubus sp., Salix sp. (willow), Ulmus sp. (elm), Phellinus conchatus (polypore), (Ginns)

Xenasma tulasnelloideum.habitat: on dead hardwood, "on the underside of trunks and branches still with bark and lying on the ground"; fall, (Breitenbach), mostly on barkless hardwood, more rarely on coniferous wood such as Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), (Hjortstam), Acer (maple), Betula (birch), Liquidambar, Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak); bark and wood of dead limbs; barkless wood, decayed wood and bark; vegetable debris, (Ginns), probably all year (Buczacki)

Xenasmatella vaga.nameOrigin: means 'of sulphur', referring to yellow color
Xenasmatella vaga.habitat: from conifer wood and hardwood (Hjortstam), Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Arbutus (madrone), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Juglans (walnut), Juniperus (juniper), Liquidambar, Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock); bark; moss-covered wood; rotten wood; branch; slash; logs; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on the undersides of dead branches and trunks of Fagus (beech) and other hardwoods and conifers (Larix among others), lying on the ground; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), summer to fall; also on other plant debris, (Buczacki)

Xenosperma ludibundum.habitat: on barkless hardwood, (Hjortstam), on decayed wood of Chamaecyparis thyoides (Atlantic White-cedar), bark of Quercus sp. (oak), (Liberta)

Xylobolus frustulatus.habitat: on debarked wood of Quercus (oak), "occurring on branches and trunks lying on the ground", more rarely on still attached branches; the sporulation is presumed to take place mostly in the summer as most specimens from fall and early spring are sterile, with the hymenium consisting only of acanthocystidia, (Hjortstam), Betula (birch), Carya (hickory), Castanea (chestnut), Liriodendron tulipifera (Tuliptree), Pinus (pine) Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Quercus (oak); "on dead wood; logs and stumps, trunk; associated with a white rot or a white pocket rot", (Ginns), on dry, hard, oak logs; year-round, (Lincoff)

Xylobolus subpileatus.habitat: Castanea (chestnut), Celtis occidentalis (Hackberry), Fagus (beech), Liquidambar sp., Malus, Platanus (sycamore), Quercus (oak), Taxodium (baldcypress), Ulmus (elm); "on bark; old logs; underside of rotten log; trunks; dead stump", (Ginns), on several species of Quercus (oak), (Burt)

Xylodon brevisetus.habitat: on bark or lignum of decayed conifer wood, less often on hardwood, in such cases in conifer forests mixed with hardwoods, e.g. Salix (willow) and Betula (birch); "mostly on lying logs but is also often collected on slash, dead branches etc. on the ground", (Eriksson), on dead wood of conifers, according to the literature also on hardwoods; typically on dead but still attached branches, "as well as dead, standing trunks"; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), Abies (fir), Arbutus (madrone), Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Mortonia scabrella (sandpaper bush), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Rhododendron, Thuja; barkless wood and bark; "moss-covered wood and bark; twig; branch; tree base; stump; exposed root; uprooted bottom; log; associated with a white rot", (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)

Xylodon sambuci.nameOrigin: means 'of Sambucus' (elder, one of its hosts)
Xylodon sambuci.habitat: on hardwood of all sorts but most often in hedges, garden bushes, thickets, etc.: even though not restricted to Sambucus (elderberry), occurs with striking regularity on that substrate; rare on conifers in Scandinavia, (Eriksson), on dead hardwoods, especially shrubs, but usually on attached branches and trunks, with and without bark, of Sambucus nigra (Black Elderberry); throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on Abies (fir), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Carex (sedge), Chrysanthemum, Cytisus (broom), Fouquieria splendens (Ocotillo), Fraxinus (ash), Juglans (walnut), Juniperus (juniper), Maclura (Osage Orange), Morus (mulberry), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Populus, Prosopis (mesquite), Quercus (oak), Robinia (locust), Salix (willow), Sambucus callicarpa (Coast Red Elderberry), Sambucus glauca (Blue Elderberry), Sambucus racemosa (Red Elderberry), Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), Typha (cat-tail); bark and wood; dead branches; trunks; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), associated with a white rot of dead branches of mesquite, (Gilbertson), all year (Buczacki)

Dissingia crassitunicata.habitat: single, gregarious, or subcespitose [somewhat tufted] on soil under conifers, May to October, (Abbott), scattered to gregarious on soil, especially along trails, in montane regions with Abies spp. (fir), August to October, (Castellano), gregarious to scattered under conifers on bare soil, often along trails, later summer and fall, (Weber)

Dissingia leucomelaena.habitat: single, gregarious, subcespitose [somewhat tufted], or scattered and numerous on bare soil, moss, or litter in coniferous woods, April to September, (Abbott), gregarious in forests and meadows, commonly on pathsides and roadsides, in stony, sandy, humus-poor places, April to June, (Breitenbach), scattered to densely gregarious or clustered, occasionally single, on ground, usually near or under pine or other conifers, favoring bare, grassy or hard-packed soil along roads and paths; in spring and early summer, or in California in winter and early spring, (Arora)

Gyromitra ambigua.edibility: poisonous (Harmaja(8), who discusses a case in which the consumption of the water used in boiling along with the mushroom apparently was associated with a poisonous reaction)
Gyromitra ambigua.habitat: single, gregarious, or scattered in soil or duff or on rotted wood under conifers, from July 23 in AK to February 7 in BC, (November through February collections only known from southern coastal regions), (Abbott), single or in groups on barren sandy soil along roads and paths near pine, (Phillips), single or in groups, always near pines (Pinus sylvestris), "almost always on barren sandy soil, very often along roads and paths (rarely on burnt areas, among charcoal, in decaying wood or on the margins of pine bogs), from late July to the end of October", mostly in northern parts and at higher elevations up to the limit of Pinus sylvestris (Scotch pine), (Harmaja(6) for Fennoscandia)

Gyromitra ancilis.edibility: not recommended: some eat it but care must be taken to cook it thoroughly and identify it correctly, (Arora)
Gyromitra ancilis.habitat: single to gregarious or clustered, "on ground or around old stumps or occasionally on rotten wood in forests", mainly in spring or early summer under conifers, a characteristic snowbank fungus, (Arora), single, gregarious or subcespitose and numerous, scattered on soil, litter, or woody debris, less often on rotted wood or burnt debris, under conifers or rarely under hardwoods or in mixed woods, March to July, (Abbott), single to gregarious, on rotting wood, especially conifer stumps, buried remains of wood, etc., (Breitenbach), "on wet soil or rotting wood in the mountains in spring", often as a snowbank fungus, (Trudell)

Gyromitra californica.habitat: single to gregarious "on soil, duff, or woody debris, rarely on rotted logs, in coniferous woods", "from April 24 in BC to August 6 in ID and interior BC, June and July collections are common", (Abbott), on or adjacent to well-rotted stumps or logs of coniferous trees or on soil rich in brown rotted wood, (Castellano), single, scattered, or gregarious "in woods and at their edges, along streams, or often in somewhat disturbed soil", mainly late spring and summer, but sometimes in fall or even winter, (Arora)

Gyromitra columbiana.habitat: type at 1500m altitude in "upper oroboreal zone", cut-over area in Abies lasiocarpa-Picea engelmannii forest, by temporary logging road

Gyromitra esculenta.edibility: dangerously poisonous (Arora), has caused serious acute poisonings in Washington, Montana and British Columbia resulting in severe liver damage, (M. Beug, pers. comm.)
Gyromitra esculenta.habitat: single, gregarious, subcespitose [somewhat tufted], or scattered on ground in soil, litter, woody debris, occasionally on well-rotted wood or burnt debris, under conifers or in mixed woods, in spring, (Abbott), typically found with conifers, especially pine, but has also been reported with aspen, (Ammirati(11)), March to May, (Phillips), on ground in disturbed or undisturbed mixed conifer and hardwood forests and occasionally in urban lawns, (Castellano), "associated with conifers and hardwoods and may be found on soil or rotten wood"; spring or early summer, (Trudell)

Gyromitra gigas.edibility: not recommended, G. gigas suspected of causing monomethylhydrazine poisoning (see Gyromitra esculenta), (Benjamin)
Gyromitra gigas.habitat: single to gregarious "on litter and woody debris in coniferous or mixed woods, often near melting snow", from April 3 in WA to July 13 in AK, with June the most common

Gyromitra infula.nameOrigin: "from Latin term describing a turbanlike headdress worn by Catholic priests and vestal virgins", (Lincoff(1))
Gyromitra infula.spores: white to pale cream (Abbott), slightly yellowish (Harmaja(6))
Gyromitra infula.habitat: single, gregarious, subcespitose [somewhat tufted], or scattered on ground or more often on rotted coniferous wood or hardwood in coniferous or mixed woods, rarely in hardwood woods, from July 15 to Feb 17 in BC, with the majority of collections in August, September, and October, (Abbott), single to scattered on humus and rotting wood or debris, (Phillips), in most locations fruits in late summer and fall, but in CA winter and early spring, (Arora), July to October in the east, November to April in the west, (Lincoff(2)), single or in groups near conifers (spruce almost always present) "from grass-herb rich forests to dry heath forests, very often in decaying wood" (mostly of Picea, rarely Pinus or Betula), otherwise especially on bare soil, "sometimes on burnt areas, very rarely even among charcoal", often where the ground has been disturbed, for example by roads and paths, mostly below 200m and not above 500m, from latter half of August to mid-November, (Harmaja(6) for Fennoscandia), also occurs before July in BC and WA

Gyromitra korfii.nameOrigin: "named for Dr. R.P. Korf of Cornell University, a respected mycologist whose specialty is the cup-fungi"
Gyromitra korfii.edibility: uncertain: spots for hydrazines have been negative, and some have eaten it without obvious ill effect, but safety has not been proven, (Weber)
Gyromitra korfii.habitat: mid-April to late May, sometimes in large clusters

Gyromitra leucoxantha.habitat: single to gregarious on soil, litter, or woody debris in coniferous woods, May 10 to June 8 in BC, (Abbott), single to gregarious under larch and spruce, shortly after snowmelt, (Breitenbach), on soil in woods of mixed hardwood and coniferous species, in May and early June, (Ginns)

Gyromitra melaleucoides.habitat: single, gregarious, subcespitose, or scattered "on soil, litter, or rotted wood in coniferous or mixed forests", April 11 in BC to July 22 in ID, (Abbott), on or adjacent to well-decayed (brown cubical-rotted) wood in moist coniferous forests, spring, (Castellano)

Gyromitra montana.habitat: common in the mountains of western North America, generally in spring, often around melting snowbanks, (Weber), spring and early summer (Trudell)

Gyromitra olympiana.nameOrigin: after Olympic National Park, where the type collection was found (Kanouse)
Gyromitra olympiana.habitat: single, gregarious or scattered on soil or duff in coniferous forests or mixed woods, in spring, frequently near melting snow, (Abbot)

Gyromitra sphaerospora.habitat: single to gregarious or scattered and numerous on very rotted hardwood (or rarely coniferous) logs or woody debris, in hardwood or mixed woods, from June 3 to July 6 in AB, (Abbott)

Helvella acetabulum.nameOrigin: means 'a vinegar cup, any cup-shaped vessel'
Helvella acetabulum.edibility: poisonous (Phillips), sometimes reported as edible with caution, (McKnight), fair when cooked, especially after being boiled, poisonous raw, (Lincoff(1))
Helvella acetabulum.habitat: single to gregarious on soil or litter in coniferous, mixed or hardwood woods, March to July, (Abbott), single to gregarious in hardwood and coniferous forests, in pastures, commonly on pathsides and roadsides, on sandy chalky soil, April to June, (Breitenbach), single to gregarious on ground in woods and at their edges, spring and summer, but in CA may fruit in winter and early spring, (Arora), May to June (December to April in southwest), (Phillips)

Helvella albella.habitat: single to gregarious on ground in coniferous or mixed woods, from July 17 in AK to December 6 in WA

Helvella atra.habitat: gregarious to scattered and numerous on ground or rotted wood in deciduous or mixed woods, from July 14 in MT to September 2 in AB, (Abbott), single, scattered, or in small groups on ground or rotten wood under both hardwoods and conifers, mainly summer and fall, (Arora)

Helvella compressa.habitat: single, gregarious, subcespitose [somewhat tufted], or scattered and numerous "on soil or litter, rarely with burnt woody debris, in coniferous or infrequently in mixed or deciduous woods", March 9 to December 25 in coastal WA, April to June collections common, (Abbott), single to gregarious "on ground in woods and at their edges, under trees, etc.", (Arora), on soil in low to mid-elevation, mixed woods often including Pseudotsuga menziesii or Quercus spp. and which may be subject to low levels of occasional disturbance, March through July, (Castellano), scattered to gregarious in duff under redwoods, oaks and various pines, in spring, (Weber)

Helvella corium.habitat: single or typically gregarious to numerous and scattered, often on bare soil, typically with willows in deciduous or mixed woods or tundra, typically June to August, but from May to September, (Abbott)

Helvella costifera.habitat: single to gregarious on soil in coniferous or mixed woods, June to August, (Abbott), gregarious in coniferous and hardwood forests on humusy, lime-rich soils, (Breitenbach)

Helvella crispa.edibility: to be avoided (Arora), edible but causes gastric upset in some people (Phillips)
Helvella crispa.habitat: single, gregarious, or scattered on soil and litter in hardwood or mixed woods, from July 11 in AB to November 15 in WA, (Abbott), single to gregarious on ground or very rotten wood under both hardwoods and conifers, (Arora), July to October, (December to April in CA), (Phillips), on ground in both hardwood and coniferous forests, (or in late-summer lawns near planted conifers), late July to mid-October in East, December-April in Southwest, September-October in Northwest, (Lincoff(2))

Helvella cupuliformis.habitat: gregarious on clay soil under Arbutus menziesii and Arctostaphylos sp., March in OR, (Abbott), single to gregarious on path embankments on loamy-sandy soil in hardwood and coniferous forests, (Breitenbach)

Helvella dryophila.habitat: mainly in small groups, rarely single, terrestrial, ectomycorrhizal with Quercus spp. (Q. agrifolia - California Live Oak, Q. douglasii - Blue Oak, Q. kelloggii - California Black Oak, Q. wislizenii - Interior Live Oak), also as a root tip on Arbutus menziesii in a pure Arbutus stand; fruiting mid-December through the end of May at higher elevations, (Nguyen), found also in a mixed fruit and nut tree orchard in Washington State, and also identified on root tips of Arbutus menziesii, (Beug(3)), fruits also under apple and likely other hardwoods (M. Beug, pers. comm.)

Helvella elastica.nameOrigin: from Greek, "pushing" or "elastic", referring to flesh texture, (Lincoff(1)), from Greek meaning "stretched" or "slimmed", (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Helvella elastica.edibility: unknown (Arora), not recommended (Lincoff(2)), fair when cooked, never eat raw, (Lincoff(1))
Helvella elastica.habitat: single to gregarious on soil, litter, moss, or rarely rotted wood, in coniferous or mixed woods, from June 5 in ID to December 25 in coastal WA, (Abbott), single to widely scattered or gregarious "in woods or at their edges, particularly near streams and paths", (Arora), typically gregarious on soil under conifers in damp areas, May through December, (Castellano), July to early November; December to April in Southwest, (Lincoff(2)), in both conifer and hardwood forests (Trudell)

Helvella fibrosa.habitat: single to gregarious or scattered and numerous on litter in hardwood, mixed, or coniferous woods, April to October, (Abbott), single to gregarious on pathsides and roadsides on sandy bare soil in spruce forest, according to literature also under hardwoods and on humusy and loamy ground, (Breitenbach)

Helvella lactea.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to milk', referring to color
Helvella lactea.habitat: single to gregarious "on soil or litter in coniferous or mixed woods", from July in MB to December 25 in WA

Helvella latispora.habitat: gregarious on soil or litter in hardwood, mixed, or coniferous woods, from June 27 in ID to August 29 in MB

Helvella macropus.nameOrigin: from Greek meaning "large-footed" (Lincoff(1)), or "with a long leg" (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Helvella macropus.habitat: single to gregarious on litter or soil, infrequently on rotted wood, in hardwood, mixed, or coniferous woods, July to October, (Abbott), often single, sometimes in coniferous forests but primarily in hardwood forests, on bare ground or moss-covered places, July to October, (Breitenbach), single, scattered, or gregarious "on ground or rotten wood under both hardwoods and conifers", summer, winter, and spring, (Arora), June to November, (December to January on the west coast), (Phillips)

Helvella maculata.habitat: single, gregarious or scattered "on soil or duff in coniferous or mixed woods", from August 1 in AB to November 30 in coastal WA, but typically in fall, (Abbott), single to gregarious in mixed woods and under conifers, (Arora), scattered to gregarious under conifers, late summer and fall, (Weber), "normally appearing late summer through fall but can appear early spring in coastal areas", (Beug)

Helvella pezizoides.habitat: single to gregarious on soil, humus, or rotted wood in woodland, bog or tundra habitats, (Abbott)

Helvella solitaria.habitat: single or often gregarious to numerous and scattered on ground in soil or litter in coniferous, mixed, or occasionally hardwood woods, April to October, (Abbott), single, scattered or in small groups in forest humus or occasionally on rotting wood, usually under hardwoods, late spring and summer, but in California may fruit in winter and early spring, (Arora)

Helvella vespertina.nameOrigin: Latin for western, where the sun sets (Vellinga)
Helvella vespertina.edibility: yes, do not eat if affected by whitish to pinkish Hypomyces cervinigenus, (Arora), edible, but exercise great caution in identifying or sampling, (Lincoff(1)), not recommended (McKnight)
Helvella vespertina.habitat: in groups and clusters, "terrestrial in forests and grassy verges", ectomycorrhizal with Pinus (P. muricata - Bishop Pine, P. lambertiana - Sugar Pine, P. ponderosa - Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and possibly Abies concolor (White fir) and Arbutus menziesii (Pacific madrone); fruiting OctoberMarch (rarely in April), (Nguyen), single to gregarious, subcespitose [somewhat tufted], or scattered "on soil or litter, rarely on rotted or burnt wood, in coniferous or mixed woods", from June in MB to April 15 in coastal southern BC, November through April fruitings only from southern area [of Pacific Northwest], June to August fruiting only Canada and Alaska, (Abbott), single, scattered, or in groups in woods and under trees, (Arora)

Morchella americana.edibility: edible, but the usual precautions for morels must be followed, there are reports of adverse reactions, (Weber)
Morchella americana.habitat: in western North America "under hardwoods in river bottoms or in urban settings in association with apple trees or ornamental ash plantings", in the east of North America common, often found under living and dead hardwoods, especially living Fraxinus americana (White Ash) and dead or dying Ulmus americana (American Elm), and occasionally in association with conifers; fruiting in spring, (Kuo(6)), single to gregarious or clustered, "in a wide variety of habitats, including hardwood forests", "under mature to old fruit trees (especially apples), around dead American elms, under white pines, on sand dunes and many other places", (Weber), M. claviformis under Acer (maple), and M. populina under Populus (cottonwood etc.) are considered synonyms (Richard(1)), in North America it is found "in a variety of habitats, often associated with white ash but also found near dead elms, in old apple orchards, riparian areas, burned areas, or mixed hardwood forests, sometimes under conifers, often on steep slopes or along old railroad beds", in spring and early summer, (Beug(3))

Morchella brunnea.habitat: under hardwoods, including Arbutus menziesii and Quercus spp., probably to be expected in non-burned conifer forests; April, (Kuo(6)), also found in landscape bark and an adjacent lawn in a residential yard in Pullman, WA, (McCotter(1), referring to Carris et al. 2015 in press at Mycologia)

Morchella eximia.habitat: primarily associated with burned soils, appearing in the spring following a fire the previous summer or fall, often after Morchella anthracophila; associated with conifers, principally Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Clowez for M. carbonaria), only collected the first year after a fire; under Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce), Pinus contorta var. latifolia (Lodgepole Pine), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), A. grandis (Grand Fir), and Larix occidentalis (Western Larch), seeming never to appear under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Clowez(1) for M. anthracophila, using information from Pilz(2)), collection in Washington under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Richard(1))

Morchella exuberans.nameOrigin: In describing Morchella exuberans as a new species, Clowez(1) says, "Forme exubrante, c'est--dire arrondie, avec de multiples replis du stipe et des alvoles qui se mlent pour former un ascome vaguement subglobuleux" which could be translated as 'exuberant form, that is rounded, with multiple folds in the stipe and pits that merge to form a vaguely subglobose fruitbody'. The Latin word 'exuberans', according to Brown, R.W.(1), means 'abounding, overflowing', and the French word 'exuberance' is used for 'superabundance' as well as exuberance.
Morchella exuberans.habitat: appearing at approximately 1200m in lightly burned spruce and fir forests, in the year following summer forest fires, August

Morchella importuna.nameOrigin: means "assertive" or "inconsiderate" in character - "the species often is the cause of consternation and distress among gardeners and homeowners whose territory has been invaded"
Morchella importuna.habitat: appearing "in gardens, planters, woodchip beds and urban landscaping settings", March to May, (Kuo), a Morchella that occurs in forests with thinned logging is likely to be this species as well (Michael Beug, pers. comm.)

Morchella norvegiensis.habitat: "Samples were found in a wide range of manmade or human-disturbed sites. Some collections are from calcareous ground, some from nitrogen-rich habitats, and some from flower beds with or without bark; gravely road-sides and borders of logged coniferous forests also seem favorable for the species. Old burnt remnants were present in the site where the type was collected. On a few occasions it was collected in sites that may have natural, undisturbed vegetation. Voitk et al. (2016) wrote that the majority of the collections of their M. eohespera in Canada and USA were found in natural vegetation where soil, gravel, and sand periodically shifted because of wind and cryogenic cycles.", (Weholt(1)), found at one site in Washington under Picea engelmannii, (Engelmann Spruce), mid-June to late June, 1100m above sea level "in a spruce bottom composed of small meadows and open woods" with old growth Engelmann spruce and nearby boggy areas with mixed spruce and Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), (Beug(5)), growing singly under conifers, (M. Beug, pers. comm.)

Morchella populiphila.nameOrigin: refers to the association with Populus
Morchella populiphila.habitat: under Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood) in river bottoms, March and April, (Kuo(6)), collected where Populus was not present, from a residential yard and a city park in Pullman, WA, (McCotter)

Morchella prava.nameOrigin: "means crooked, irregular or deformed" and reflects the contorted cap, (Kuo)
Morchella prava.habitat: the ecology of the seven collections studied was not consistent, apart from fruiting from April to early June

Morchella rufobrunnea.habitat: type with Quercus, Liquidambar, Clethra, and Alnus in sandy soil on a recently disturbed roadside embankment with tree trunks, mid-May to mid-July, (Guzman), along a roadbed and in a garden (original Mexico collections), in California and Oregon from landscaping and similar disturbed-ground sites, (Kuo)

Morchella septimelata.nameOrigin: "The epithet reflects the fact that the species is the seventh phylogenetic species (Mel-7) in the M. elata Clade" enumerated in O'Donnell(1) in 2011
Morchella septimelata.habitat: emerging at 1000-2000 m "in lightly to moderately burned conifer forests, often near creek beds, springs and seeps"; found "primarily in years immediately following forest fires but often appearing in dwindling numbers for several seasons thereafter"; April-July

Morchella sextelata.nameOrigin: from the fact that this is the sixth species (Mel-6) in the M. elata clade study in O'Donnell(1)
Morchella sextelata.habitat: appearing at 1000-1500m "in lightly to moderately burned conifer forests", including forests dominated by Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine); found "primarily in years immediately following forest fires but often appearing in dwindling numbers for several seasons thereafter"

Morchella snyderi.nameOrigin: honors Leon Carlton Snyder (1908-1987), who named M. hotsonii and M. crassistipa from WA in the 1930s
Morchella snyderi.habitat: under non-burned, montane conifers, including Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), and Abies concolor (White Fir); April, May, and early June, (Kuo(6)), found also in landscape bark mulch (McCotter), typically in clusters of 2-20 (M. Beug, pers. comm.)

Morchella tomentosa.nameOrigin: means 'tomentose', 'chosen in part to reflect potential continuity with Moser's invalid taxon' [atrotomentosa] 'while also acknowledging that the North American species, while always tomentose, is not always black-tomentose' (Kuo(3))
Morchella tomentosa.habitat: at altitudes of 1000-3400 meters "in lightly to moderately burned conifer forests" including forests dominated by Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) on the West Coast and forests dominated by Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce) and Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir) or Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine) in the Rocky Mountains; "primarily in years following forest fires, but often appearing in dwindling numbers for several seasons thereafter"; May through August, (Kuo), sometimes appearing "as late as August or even September at high elevations when there has been sufficient moisture", (Beug)

Morchella tridentina.habitat: "appearing at various altitudes in mixed forests dominated by various trees", including Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), Quercus spp. (oak), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pinus lambertiana (Sugar Pine), and Abies concolor (White Fir); April, (Kuo(6)), documented "from nonburned soils in living forests or in nonburned areas within the fire perimeter" (Pilz), fruits after Morchella snyderi and M. brunnea (Michael Beug, pers. comm.)

Morchella vulgaris.habitat: none of the plant associates mentioned by Clowez(1) for the type variety are coniferous

Rhizina undulata.habitat: single to gregarious or numerous and scattered "on soil, duff or woody debris, typically in recently burned areas under conifers", March to November; a pathogen of conifer seedlings, (Abbott), gregarious in coniferous forests, "clearcuts, tree farms of young spruces, commonly in or near burned ground, on mossy ground", May to October, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Verpa bohemica.nameOrigin: means "from Bohemia", the area where it was first found, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Verpa bohemica.edibility: eaten by many but can cause severe stomach cramps and loss of muscular co-ordination, particularly when consumed in large quantities on successive days, (Arora), traditionally parboiled, with water discarded prior to final preparation, (Benjamin)
Verpa bohemica.taste: pleasant (Phillips), slightly bitter but not unpleasant (Lincoff(1))
Verpa bohemica.habitat: widely scattered to gregarious in woods, thickets, and forest edges, etc., usually fruiting in early spring, typically appearing 1-3 weeks before Morchella species, (Arora), in damp woods along stream banks, pathsides, March to early May, (Phillips), in leaf litter under hardwoods, especially poplars, (Lincoff(1)), on ground, often along riverbanks under cottonwoods, willows, and aspens, often well hidden under dead leaves, (Ammirati), single to gregarious in open hardwood forest, river meadows, hedges, April-May, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Verpa conica.edibility: edible when cooked (Arora), Verpas are traditionally parboiled, with water discarded prior to final preparation, (Benjamin)
Verpa conica.habitat: single, widely scattered, or gregarious in soil or humus in forests, riparian woodlands [by streams], under shrubbery and fruit trees, etc., usually in spring (Arora), single to gregarious along banks of rivers and streams, hedges, meadows, forest edges, April to May, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), hardwood woods and orchards, April-May, (Phillips), at edge of woods or in hedges, especially under the Rosaceae, (Lincoff(1))

Agaricus abruptibulbus.habitat: gregarious under planted Picea abies (Norway Spruce), 'with some grasses and herbaceous plants present, or solitary in native forest, "in open places in woods" and "along the borders of thin woods" (Peck, 1894)', (Kerrigan(3)), fruiting in September (Kerrigan(3))

Agaricus albolutescens.odour: odor of almonds, (Kerrigan(3)), strongly sweet and anise-like or almondy (Arora)
Agaricus albolutescens.habitat: single to somewhat gregarious under Lithocarpus, Quercus, Arbutus, and conifers, coastal California and Oregon; fruiting from October to January, (Kerrigan(3)), single, scattered or gregarious on ground in woods, (Arora), single or scattered, occasionally clustered, in duff or humus, in a variety of forest habitats, fruiting midfall into early winter, occasionally in spring, (Siegel)

Agaricus albosanguineus.habitat: type on the ground under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) in woods, December, (Hotson), growing "gregariously to singly in coniferous woods in needles or under brush (Holodiscus), frequently at the edge of forests in semi-open places such as balds (Tacoma prairies, San Juan Island)", (Isaacs, Latin underlined)

Agaricus 'altipes'.habitat: low elevation coniferous forest in Washington and Alaska, high elevation coniferous forest in New Mexico; fruiting late August, (Kerrigan), "in grass in mixed woods, mostly conifers", (Phillips)

Agaricus annae.habitat: gregariously in needle duff under Douglas fir, (Isaacs), usually with cypress, found in Hayden Lake ID under mixed conifers, (Chariton), spruce woods (Moser for Europe), mixed woodland (Courtecuisse)

Agaricus arvensis.odour: of almonds (Kerrigan(3)), almond or anise, often musty at maturity (Arora for what may be the same species)
Agaricus arvensis.habitat: gregarious to somewhat cespitose (tufted), often in rings, in meadowland and open areas near or under trees (particularly with cypresses in California) on the West Coast; in Pennsylvania "occurs infrequently on open, sunny lawns, and much more frequently with spruce, with or without grasses"; in California November to March, in Pennsylvania (May) September to October; summer, fall, winter, spring

Agaricus augustus.edibility: yes, one of the best, (Arora), sweet and almondy when young, strong and mushroomy at maturity; occasional people get stomach upset which can be intense
Agaricus augustus.odour: "sweet (like almond extract), especially when young", (Arora), of almonds (Kerrigan(1)), pleasant, of almonds, (Phillips), anise (Hotson), anise or almonds (Miller)
Agaricus augustus.habitat: single or in groups or clumps on ground in woods, but usually near roads and paths, in clearings, and other places where soil disturbed, sometimes in flower beds, composted areas, under trees in towns, in arboretums, etc., (Arora), single to gregarious or cespitose [in tufts], in litter under Sequoia, Picea (spruce), Tsuga (hemlock), or occasionally Quercus (oak), or under planted Cupressus (cypress) or Pinus (pine), usually near roads or paths, or rarely in lawns near trees, fruiting year round, (Kerrigan(1) for California), spring, summer, or fall, (Miller)

Agaricus 'benesii'.odour: soon fruity-spicy when cut, (Kerrigan(1)), mild, indistinct, (Kerrigan(3))
Agaricus 'benesii'.habitat: gregarious "in shallow to moderately deep litter of conifers", (Kerrigan(1)), known from a lawn under Picea in PA, from a botanic garden in Edmonton AB, "with some short-needle conifer nearby", and per information from D. Bojantchev probably occurring under Picea in ID, (Kerrigan(3))

Agaricus bernardii.nameOrigin: probably after G. Bernard, French mycologist
Agaricus bernardii.edibility: yes, choice, (Arora), "full-flavored ... this is a salty mushroom and recipes calling for salt must be adjusted accordingly, or unpalatability may be achieved", (Kerrigan(3))
Agaricus bernardii.odour: mild to pungent or briny, (Arora), strong, pungently briny, (Kerrigan(1)), strongly unpleasant, (Courtecuisse), not marked (Hotson)
Agaricus bernardii.habitat: single or scattered to densely gregarious in sand, sandy soil, disturbed areas, lawns, and saline habitats, grows along coasts, may fruit underground, (Arora), single to abundantly gregarious "in sand near beaches, or near saline tidelands, or in lawns on sandy soils (then frequently in large rings)", or rarely under Cupressus (cypress) or Pinus (pine), (Kerrigan(1) for California), grazing marshes and somewhat saline grassland (Courtecuisse for Europe), fall (Buczacki)
