Agaricus bisporus.nameOrigin: refers to 2-spored basidia, bis = twice (Latin), spora = seed (Greek)
Agaricus bisporus.edibility: the most widely eaten and cultivated mushroom, (Arora)
Agaricus bisporus.odour: mild or faintly fruity (Arora), fruity/spicy after exposure, (Kerrigan(1)), pleasant (Lincoff), fungoid (Isaacs), 'familiar as "mushroom" of the market', (Kerrigan(3))
Agaricus bisporus.habitat: in grocery stores, compost, manure, rich soil, along paths, in gardens, rarely in woods or on lawns, (Arora), gregarious to cespitose [in tufts], or rarely single, "in old manure or manured ground or compost, or in old piles of plant trimmings and sludge, or in litter of trees", especially Cupressus macrocarpa (Monterey cypress), occasionally under Pinus (pine), Eucalyptus, Quercus (oak), and others, (Kerrigan(1) for California), spring, summer, fall (Buczacki)

Agaricus bitorquis.nameOrigin: means "with a double necklace", bis = twice (Latin), torquis = necklace (Latin)
Agaricus bitorquis.odour: mild (Arora, Kerrigan(1)), pleasant (Phillips), pleasant, faintly almond, (Miller)
Agaricus bitorquis.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups or rows "on road shoulders, in hard-packed soil, along sidewalks, around playgrounds, and in other disturbed areas; often fruiting underground", (Arora), single to gregarious "in soil where organic matter has been incorporated, or in hard-packed soils, or along roadsides and foundations etc.", (Kerrigan(1)), "especially along roadsides, paths, in parks and towns, often in bare soil or gravel, even pushing up asphalt", July to October, (Phillips), spring, summer, fall, winter, (Miller)

Agaricus braendlei.nameOrigin: The species is named after F. J. Braendle, who collected the holotype in Washington BC. The subspecies is named "for Annette Louise Kautzer, lifelong friend, companion in adventure, and steward of the type locality"
Agaricus braendlei.habitat: gregarious "in clumps, troops, or arcs in a grassy orchard at 850 m elev." in Calaveras Co. California, also confirmed from Lake Co. and San Francisco Co., November-December

Agaricus buckmacadooi.nameOrigin: "The epithet honors the friendly generosity and the mycological contributions of the collector of the first sequenced specimen, Buck McAdoo, who has collected many specimens of, and extended our knowledge of, Agaricus in Washington State" (Kerrigan(3), Latin italicized)
Agaricus buckmacadooi.habitat: gregarious, along the west coast of North America, most often in coniferous forests with Tsuga and Pseudotsuga in Washington, with Sequoia in California, September-December

Agaricus 'campestris'.odour: mild (Arora), none or slight (Smith), pleasant (Phillips), mild almond (Chariton)
Agaricus 'campestris'.habitat: in groups or fairy rings or occasionally single; in grass, (Arora), scattered to gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] "in meadows, pastures, along roads and in barnyards", (Smith), "spring and fall or during periods of cool moist weather at other times", (Miller), spring, summer, fall, winter

Agaricus cervinifolius.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] in very fertile soil in the margins of coniferous forests where horses had been pastured, (Isaacs)

Agaricus 'chionodermus'.nameOrigin: from 'chion', Greek for snow, and 'derma', Greek for skin
Agaricus 'chionodermus'.spores: presumably a shade of dark brown
Agaricus 'chionodermus'.habitat: fruits gregariously, July-August, in mid-elevation Pinus (pine) and higher-elevation (or high latitude) Picea (spruce) and Abies (true fir) forests, "Rocky Mountains and other Western ranges"

Agaricus 'coepiochraceus'.odour: faintly to distinctly almond, disagreeable on standing, (Isaacs)
Agaricus 'coepiochraceus'.habitat: growing singly or in cespitose [tufted] clusters, on beaches in rocky soil or around drift logs, (Isaacs)

Agaricus comptuloides.nameOrigin: "related to Agaricus comptulus Fr." according to Murrill in original description (with Latin name italicized), 'comptulus' presumably meaning 'comtulus'
Agaricus comptuloides.habitat: gregarious in mixed evergreen litter, (Kerrigan(1) for California collection), gregariously under conifers on needle duff, (Isaacs)

Agaricus comtulus.habitat: single to somewhat gregarious in lawns and grassy places, (Kerrigan(1)), on grazed grassland (Moser for Europe), in grassy areas or open woods, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), always in grass (Chariton), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Agaricus 'crassistipus'.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] in grass under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) or Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Agaricus crocodilinus.odour: of burnt almonds or wet straw, slowly becoming disagreeable
Agaricus crocodilinus.habitat: gregarious in pastures and fields, usually where cattle are located

Agaricus deardorffensis.nameOrigin: prae- means before, clare means 'clear', squamosus means 'scaly'
Agaricus deardorffensis.edibility: poisonous to many, with vomiting and diarrhea (Arora)
Agaricus deardorffensis.taste: unpleasant metallic (Arora), mild, almond, or oily-disagreeable, (Isaacs)
Agaricus deardorffensis.odour: phenolic odor of crushed flesh especially in base of stem, (Arora), mild or phenolic, often strongly so, (Isaacs), phenolic (Kerrigan(1))
Agaricus deardorffensis.habitat: single or in groups or clusters on ground in woods or under trees, especially along roadsides and paths, (Arora), single, gregarious, or in thick fleshy clusters, growing under both conifers and hardwoods, occasionally in lawns, (Isaacs), single or gregarious and often in a row, frequently in compacted soil along roads and paths, most commonly under Sequoia, occasionally under other trees, (Kerrigan(1) for California), summer, fall, winter

Agaricus deserticola.habitat: single, scattered, or gregarious "in poor soil, waste places, irrigated fields, lawns, disturbed areas, etc.", apparently widespread in arid and semi-arid areas, fruiting after rains or artificial watering, (Arora), usually in semiarid, waste places, February to November, (Zeller)

Agaricus devoniensis.nameOrigin: presumably 'from Devon County in the United Kingdom'; the name "bridghamii" "honors Joseph Bridgham, one of 19th century North America's foremost illustrators of fungi and other natural subjects, who illustrated several Agaricus spp. for the Icones Farlowianae (Farlow 1929)" (Kerrigan(4), with Latin name in italics)
Agaricus devoniensis.spores: presumably a shade of dark brown
Agaricus devoniensis.odour: 'familiar as "mushroom" (of the market)', (Kerrigan(3) for subspecies devoniensis), mushroomy, unremarkable, (Kerrigan(3) for subspecies bridghamii)
Agaricus devoniensis.habitat: gregarious or single, near the coast, particularly under Hesperocyparis macrocarpa (Monterey cypress), November to March, (Kerrigan(3) for subspecies devoniensis in California), gregarious in arcs, or single, known only from high elevation Picea (spruce) forests in the Rocky Mountains, July-August, (Kerrigan(3) for subspecies bridghamii), in fairly level valley bottoms, at middle to high elevations in the eastern Rocky Mountains of Alberta (1300 m) and Colorado (2900-3000 m), (Kerrigan(4) for subsp. bridghamii)

Agaricus diminutivus.edibility: avoid because sometimes confused with Inocybes
Agaricus diminutivus.habitat: single, widely scattered, or in small groups on ground in humus in woods

Agaricus dulcidulus.habitat: coniferous and deciduous woods (Moser), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Agaricus 'elwhaensis'.nameOrigin: means 'from Elwha', referring to the Elwha Valley in the Olympic Mountains of Washington
Agaricus 'elwhaensis'.habitat: single in needle duff under a Douglas fir tree

Agaricus excellens.habitat: gregarious in grass and Polytrichum moss near Douglas fir (Isaacs), gregarious in woods under Picea (spruce), occasionally in deciduous woods (Fagus), (Isaacs from Moeller for Europe), in woods (Moser)

Agaricus fissuratus.odour: "usually distinct, of almonds", or when old "musty or urine-like", (Kerrigan(3)), sweet like anise or almond when young, often somewhat musty when old, (Arora for Agaricus arvensis in the former sense used mostly for Agaricus fissuratus)
Agaricus fissuratus.habitat: gregarious, often in rings, "in lawns and other grassy habitats"; fruits September to November (February to April)

Agaricus flavitingens.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on sandy rocky soil under Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Smith)

Agaricus 'fugaciovelus'.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] in needles under Cedrus deodora (deodar cedar)

Agaricus 'gracilifolius'.habitat: single on leaf mold in a dense thicket of Corylus and Holodiscus, October, (Isaacs), fall

Agaricus 'helodes'.habitat: often single or in small groups; under conifers in needle duff

Agaricus hondensis.nameOrigin: refers to La Honda, California where originally described
Agaricus hondensis.edibility: poisonous to many causing vomiting or stomach distress, (Arora)
Agaricus hondensis.odour: crushed flesh mild or faintly phenolic but usually distinctly phenolic in base of stem when crushed, (Arora), phenolic or often indistinct, usually strongly phenolic in base, (Kerrigan(1))
Agaricus hondensis.habitat: single or in groups, troops, or fairy rings in woods on ground, "particularly where there are thick accumulations of fallen twigs and other debris", (Arora), in arcs, subcespitose [more or less in tufts], gregarious, or single, under conifers in needle duff or under brush (Rubus, Holodiscus) in leaves, (Isaacs), gregarious in litter of Sequoia, Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), rarely Cupressus (cypress) and other trees, usually in deep woods, (Kerrigan(1) for California), low elevation, conifer duff (Chariton), one of the relatively few Agaricus species found under redwood, in California also occasionally found with Cupressus macrocarpa (Monterey cypress) and C. abramsii (Santa Cruz cypress), but north of California occurs with other conifers and may occasionally be found under hardwoods, (Kerrigan(2))

Agaricus 'hotsoni'.nameOrigin: after J.W. Hotson who with D. Stuntz described it as A. diminutivus
Agaricus 'hotsoni'.habitat: gregarious in sandy loam in woods (Isaacs)

Agaricus inapertus.edibility: firm specimens said to be edible (Arora)
Agaricus inapertus.odour: "usually sweet (like almond extract or anise) when young but often unpleasant or musty at maturity", (Arora), almonds or anise, the odor of over-mature fruitbodies rather disagreeable, and in dried material distinctly cumarinous, (Singer)
Agaricus inapertus.habitat: single to gregarious or clustered "in duff or soil under conifers (or sometimes aspen)", mountains of western North America, especially late summer and fall, (Arora), underground or subhypogeous [somewhat underground], "growing in clumps, side by side and sometimes one above the other", eventually the upper part of the fruitbody emerging from the ground, found on clay soil near conifers in mountain areas, August, (Singer), fruits in late summer and fall (Smith(4))

Agaricus 'integer'.habitat: found in open grassy places with moss, (Dilly), open grassy places, sometimes in moss, (Chariton)

Agaricus 'involucratus'.edibility: not recommended because of resemblance to poisonous Amanitas (Chariton)

Agaricus kerriganii.edibility: appears to be an edible species (Malloch), edible (Chariton)
Agaricus kerriganii.taste: almonds (weak in some), (Malloch), anise-like when crushed (Isaacs), distinctly anise (Chariton), mild (Miller)
Agaricus kerriganii.odour: almonds (Kerrigan(1)), anise-like when crushed (Isaacs), almonds (weak in some), (Malloch), quite strongly anise (Courtecuisse), distinctly anise (Chariton)
Agaricus kerriganii.habitat: scattered to gregarious, occurring in twos and threes, under conifers or in mixed forests in needles or leaves, (Isaacs), single or more often gregarious in forest litter of many native trees, (Kerrigan(1) for California), on the ground in lawns and fields and in the woods (especially coniferous woods), (Malloch for eastern Canada), coniferous woods (especially spruces), (Moser for Europe), in small groups "in coniferous more rarely deciduous woodland, also in meadows", (Hansen), under conifers or mixed trees, under oak, (Chariton), late summer and fall (Miller)

Agaricus 'lamellodistans'.habitat: in grass under pine (Chariton), gregarious in grass under pine (Isaacs)

Agaricus lilaceps.nameOrigin: presumably means 'lilac head' referring to the color of the cap
Agaricus lilaceps.edibility: yes, choice, requires thorough cooking to make it tender, (Arora)
Agaricus lilaceps.odour: mild to faintly sweet or fruity (Arora), fruity / spicy after exposure (Kerrigan(1))
Agaricus lilaceps.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious or clustered on ground under old cypresses or occasionally other trees, (Arora), gregarious and occasionally very prolific, often in rings, in deep, 3-10cm, accumulations of Cupressus macrocarpa (Monterey cypress) litter (or sawdust), rarely under other trees, (Kerrigan(1))

Agaricus mesocarpus.nameOrigin: "a species with a moderately proportioned basiodiomatal stature"
Agaricus mesocarpus.habitat: gregarious "in high elevation forests of the western interior mountain ranges, with spruce or aspen", July to August

Agaricus micromegethus.nameOrigin: 'megethos' is Greek for 'greatness' - perhaps the name means 'small greatness'
Agaricus micromegethus.odour: almond (Kerrigan(1)), distinctly sweet (anise-like or almondy), (Arora), pleasant (Phillips), pleasant, faintly of anise, (Kibby)
Agaricus micromegethus.habitat: gregarious in lawns, pastures and grassy places, (Kerrigan(1)), single to scattered or gregarious "in lawns, pastures, fields and other grassy or open places", (Arora), prefers short turf especially sandy soils (Kibby)

Agaricus moronii.nameOrigin: indicates a species that like its namesake, the town Moroni, can be seen above Salt Lake City
Agaricus moronii.habitat: single or in pairs, known from 1500 m to 3000 m elevation, with conifers

Agaricus 'parkensis'.habitat: gregarious in grass, associated with Robinia (locust), (Isaacs), gregarious to fascicled in litter of Quercus agrifolia (California live oak) at the margin of open woods along roadside (Kerrigan for California collection)

Agaricus porphyrocephalus.habitat: scattered to gregarious, lawns and meadows

Agaricus 'purpurellus'.edibility: yes, but too easy to confuse with poisonous Inocybe species, (Chariton)
Agaricus 'purpurellus'.odour: faintly fragrant anise (Chariton), sweet, almond-like, (Isaacs), of bitter almonds (Courtecuisse)
Agaricus 'purpurellus'.habitat: open woods(Chariton), gregarious "on needle duff under conifers in open woods", (Isaacs), coniferous woods (Moser), grassy conifer woods (Courtecuisse)

Agaricus sandianus.nameOrigin: "A species of the Sandia Mountains of New Mexico; the name originates with Sandia Pueblo and its people"
Agaricus sandianus.habitat: the holotype was gregarious in Picea (spruce) forest habitat, near the summit of the Sandia Mountains of New Mexico, fruiting in August

Agaricus smithii.habitat: single to gregarious under mixed conifers, (Kerrigan(1)), gregarious "in the coastal region of Northern California and southern Oregon, often with or near Picea sitchensis, sometimes Pinus spp. October-November (-January)" (Kerrigan(3) with Latin names italicized)

Agaricus subrufescens.taste: strong of almond extract (Arora), of green nuts (Isaacs), like almonds or not distinctive (Bessette)
Agaricus subrufescens.odour: strong sweet like almond extract, especially when young, (Arora), strongly almond (Kerrigan(1)), when crushed, strong of almonds, (Isaacs)
Agaricus subrufescens.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious or clustered "in compost, manure, and rich soil", (Arora), densely gregarious to cespitose [in tufts], "on soil incorporating manure or composted vegetable matter, as in gardens", May to December in California, (Kerrigan(1)), gregarious to mass-cespitose, "most typically in disturbed habitats: with manure or compost, or heaps of leaves, sometime lawns", (Kerrigan(3)), cespitose, on masses of decaying fallen leaves in deciduous woods and in richly manured hothouse beds, (Isaacs), spring, summer, fall, winter

Agaricus subrufescentoides.habitat: solitary on the ground in woods near Seattle, Washington, October 20-November 1, 1911, also collected near Tacoma, Washington, October 26, 1911, (Murrill)

Agaricus subrutilescens.edibility: yes, but severe gastric upsets in some (Arora)
Agaricus subrutilescens.odour: mild or slightly fruity (Arora), fruity / spicy after exposure (Kerrigan(1)), pleasant (Phillips)
Agaricus subrutilescens.habitat: single, scattered, or in small groups in woods, usually under conifers, (Arora), single, scattered, or gregarious under conifers in duff or under brush (Rubus) in leafy humus, (Isaacs), single to gregarious in various forest communities, (Alnus, Sequoia, Pseudotsuga, Cupressus, Quercus), (Kerrigan(1) for California), fall and winter (Miller)

Agaricus 'subsolidipes'.habitat: based on collection in a lawn

Agaricus summensis.nameOrigin: "summensis" refers to the habitat along the crest of the Santa Cruz Mountains, where it was originally found
Agaricus summensis.habitat: single or in pairs, in litter of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) with or without Quercus (oak), apparently also under Sequoia, probably also under Picea (spruce); (December-) January in California, July-August around the Rockies

Agaricus sylvaticus.habitat: type of A. sylvaticus subsp. occidentalis under Picea glauca (White Spruce) at 2500 m in Utah, also collected from 3000 m in Colorado, July-August; other collections possibly assignable to this subspecies under Hesperocyparis and other vegetation in San Francisco Bay area of California, December, (Kerrigan(3)), growing singly, gregariously or cespitosely under Douglas-fir or other conifers in humus, usually in older, mature stands, (Isaacs)

Agaricus sylvicola.odour: "odor of almonds", (Kerrigan(3)), anise or almond (Bessette), Trudell(4) gives "pleasant (though sometimes very faint) anise" for Agaricus silvicola (Vittadini) Saccardo
Agaricus sylvicola.habitat: scattered to gregarious in litter of mixed hardwood and coastal coniferous forests in California, fruiting October-January (-March), (Kerrigan(3))

Agaricus thiersii.nameOrigin: "The epithet honours Harry D. Thiers, the collector of the type, and his contributions to mycology, his generosity, his friendship, and his genial mentoring."
Agaricus thiersii.odour: "astringent fungoid, strong" for one E. Vellinga collection
Agaricus thiersii.habitat: often single, usually under pine (Pinus ponderosus, P. radiata, P. muricata), fruits November-January in California

Agaricus thujae.nameOrigin: means 'of Thuja' the genus of Western Redcedar (Thuja plicata)
Agaricus thujae.odour: similar to Agaricus bisporus, or slightly unpleasant
Agaricus thujae.habitat: gregarious in sandy soil under Thuja plicata (Western Redcedar) "in a predominantly mixed conifer woods" with some Alnus (alder) nearby; November

Agaricus xanthodermus.edibility: poisonous to many, headaches, vomiting, diarrhea, (Arora), causes "sweating, nausea, and severe stomach cramps, though some people are unaffected", (Phillips)
Agaricus xanthodermus.taste: strongly almond-like and disagreeable (Isaacs), similar to odor (Phillips)
Agaricus xanthodermus.odour: unpleasant, phenolic, (Arora), phenolic (Kerrigan(1)), strong, inky or phenolic (Phillips), iodoform or ink (Courtecuisse)
Agaricus xanthodermus.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious "under trees and hedges, in yards, on lawns, along roads and paths, also in woods, pastures, and under cypress", (Arora), subcespitose under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa pine) in grass and needles (Isaacs for Oregon specimen), gregarious to densely gregarious under Cupressus (cypress), Pinus (pine), Cedrus (true cedar), Acacia, Quercus (oak), Olea (olive), and occasionally other woody plants, or in lawns, (Kerrigan(1) for California), summer and fall (Miller)

Agrocybe acericola.spores: dull rust brown (Phillips), cinnamon to rust (Lincoff), cinnamon brown (Bessette)
Agrocybe acericola.habitat: "on decaying logs and woody debris in hardwoods", July to September, (Phillips), single to scattered on decaying hardwood logs and wood chips, especially Acer (maple), April to June and August to September, (Lincoff), scattered, in groups or clusters on decaying hardwood logs, stumps, and wood chips, April to September, (Bessette), on decaying poplar wood in the west of North America (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), spring, summer, fall

Agrocybe arvalis.habitat: "on the ground in fields, copses and open woodland" (Watling for Britain), fields and meadows (Moser for Europe), tracks, fields, meadows, (Courtecuisse for Europe), amongst grass in pastures, in stubble fields, on roadsides and in gardens, (Hansen for Europe), spring, summer, fall (Buczacki)

Agrocybe columbiana.habitat: scattered to gregarious on soil or grassy areas, spring and fall

Agrocybe molesta.spores: dull brown (Phillips), light brown (Hermanson), dark tobacco-brown (Breitenbach)
Agrocybe molesta.taste: a little bitter, unpleasant, (Phillips), slightly bitter (Hermanson), mild, with a farinaceous hint, (Breitenbach), mild with an aftertaste (Miller)
Agrocybe molesta.odour: not distinctive (Phillips), mushroomy, (Hermanson), pleasant, barely farinaceous, (Breitenbach)
Agrocybe molesta.habitat: in fields, pastures, and wastelands, shrub borders, May to July, (Phillips), scattered to gregarious on lawns, waste grassland, pastures, gardens, shrub borders, roadsides, spring to fall, (Hermanson), gregarious to clustered, more rarely single "outside of forests, in gardens, fields, vineyards, dry and semi-dry lawns, on soil", spring-fall, (Breitenbach for Europe), cultivated and disturbed ground (Arora(1)), spring, summer, fall

Agrocybe pediades.spores: snuff brown (Watling), brown (Arora), dark brown (Hermanson), rusty brown (Miller), dark tobacco-brown (Miller)
Agrocybe pediades.edibility: not recommended, too easy to confuse, (Arora)
Agrocybe pediades.taste: very mealy (Watling), mild or farinaceous (Arora), farinaceous (Hermanson), farinaceous and disagreeable (Miller)
Agrocybe pediades.habitat: scattered to gregarious in grass, cultivated ground, dung, manure, sand, (Arora), grasslands, pastures, May to June, (Phillips), scattered to gregarious, "grassy areas, waste land, poor pastures, and sand dunes", (Hermanson), "amongst grass in sandy areas in gardens and fields", (Watling for Britain), spring, summer, or fall, (Miller)

Agrocybe praecox.spores: snuff brown (Watling), dark brown (Phillips, Hermanson), dark rich brown (Miller)
Agrocybe praecox.edibility: no (Phillips), yes but taste often poor and variants have unknown edibility, (Arora)
Agrocybe praecox.taste: mealy (Watling), farinaceous-mealy (Phillips) farinaceous (Hermanson), often has a somewhat bitter taste (Trudell)
Agrocybe praecox.odour: pleasant (Watling), farinaceous-mealy (Phillips) farinaceous (Hermanson), mild to fungoid (Miller)
Agrocybe praecox.habitat: "on the ground in grassy or bare places, margins of fields and woods", spring and summer, often cespitose [in tufts] or in small troops, (Watling for Britain), "in wood chips, humus, and grass, in fields and woodlands", May to July, (Phillips) cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious or scattered, on humus, chip dirt, lawns, fields, roadsides, open woods, spring to early fall, (Hermanson), "very common in newly landscaped areas containing mulch or wood chips", occurring in spring or early summer, (Trudell), spring, summer, fall

Agrocybe putaminum.taste: "weakly to strongly farinaceous, often with weak to strong, bitter aftertaste", (Noordeloos), bitter-farinaceous (Watling referencing Bas 1958), bitter, with a cucumber aftertaste, (Wikipedia article referencing Pegler(5))
Agrocybe putaminum.odour: indistinct to aromatic, farinaceous when cut, (Noordeloos), farinaceous, fungal, (Wikipedia article referencing Pegler(5))
Agrocybe putaminum.habitat: gregarious, sometimes fasciculate, "on buried wood or wood-chips in roadside verges, in gardens, on ruderal places", June to December, (Noordeloos), seen on wood chips, has been reported in garden soil, in garden soil rich in plum pits, (Vellinga), on woody debris, in garden soil intermixed with straw and manure, attached to fruits of members of the Rosaceae family, (Watling), spring, summer, fall

Agrocybe semiorbicularis.habitat: scattered or in groups in grass, in sand, or along roadside, (Phillips), "amongst grass at edges of pastures, roadsides, on lawns etc.", (Watling for Britain)

Agrocybe smithii.spores: dull gray brown (Hermanson), "Prout's brown", "bister", "Verona brown", "warm sepia", (Watling)
Agrocybe smithii.odour: farinaceous, (Hermanson), rather fragrant-fungoid or farinaceous when crushed, +/- rancid when old, (Watling)
Agrocybe smithii.habitat: gregarious in fairy rings or troops on mulch beds, spring to summer, (Hermanson), single, gregarious, or scattered-cespitose on and among woodchips under Elaeagnus angustifolia (Russian olive) or on manured soil, (Watling)

Agrocybe subpediades.habitat: appears commonly in spring and summer scattered to gregarious in sandy areas of semiarid steppe habitat; frequent in the Similkameen, Okanagan and other areas with sagebrush, bunchgrass, and Antelope brush, (P. Kroeger, pers. comm.)

Albogymnopilus nanus.habitat: scattered in troops, "on small woody debris (sometimes buried), or on wood chips, often in disturbed areas, rarely on rotting logs or in spruce and hemlock duff"; late fall into spring

Alboleptonia ochracea.odour: indistinct to at most radish-like or pungent
Alboleptonia ochracea.habitat: scattered to gregarious in grass or in needle humus or branchlet humus near trees especially Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), in Pacific Northwest September to October, (Largent), fall

Alboleptonia sericella.odour: mild, at times fungoid to slightly pungent, (Largent)
Alboleptonia sericella.habitat: scattered to gregarious "in damp soil in woods, thickets, along trails, etc.", (Arora), single, scattered, or gregarious in mossy humus, grassy areas, leafy humus, cedar branchlet humus, or needle humus under or near various conifers and hardwoods, devil's club, or ferns, in Pacific Northwest late June through mid-December, (Largent), summer, fall, winter

Amanita 'alba'.habitat: single to gregarious in mixed woods

Amanita alpinicola.edibility: unknown (Lindgren(2)), likely toxic, with one report of poisoning, closely related to Amanitas such as A. muscaria that contain ibotenic acid and muscimol, (Cripps)
Amanita alpinicola.odour: not distinctive, (Lindgren), "indistinct or unpleasant to slightly fruity", (Cripps)
Amanita alpinicola.habitat: scattered with Pinus albicaulis or P. monticola at higher elevations, fruiting in summer, (Lindgren), in high, dry habitats mostly half-buried in soil (sometimes fully opened fruitbodies buried); in Montana fruiting in late spring to early summer, soon after snow melt; ectomycorrhizal with five needle western pines including at least Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine) and possibly P. monticola (Western White Pine), and also with three-needle Pinus jeffreyi (Jeffrey Pine), (Cripps)

Amanita aprica.nameOrigin: means "growing in the sunshine, exposed to the sun, sunny", because it is found most often in places exposed to direct sun and because of the bright apricot-like color of the cap, (Tulloss)
Amanita aprica.edibility: one case of poisoning is documented with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, intestinal cramps, muscle spasms, hallucinations, disorientation, and drowsiness, symptoms similar to those of intoxication with Amanita muscaria, (Tulloss), toxic also to dogs, with symptoms similar to humans, (J. Lindgren, pers. comm.), toxins incompletely known and ingestion should definitely be avoided, as Amanitas may be deadly
Amanita aprica.habitat: single to gregarious, most often with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) in exposed areas, fruits just after morels in spring, (Lindgren), single to gregarious, at 600 - 1850 m elevation, often in sunny locations "such as road cuts, along trails, campgrounds, and other breaks in forest canopy"; occurring with conifers, mainly Pseudotsuga menziesii, less often with Pinus (pine), (Tulloss)

Amanita armillariiformis.habitat: single to several in dry areas among sagebrush, mustards, cheat grass and usually near aspen, Douglas fir, or willow, late March to mid-June, (Miller), spring, summer

Amanita augusta.habitat: "common in the mixed coastal woods of California, the Pacific Northwest, and Alaska", primary fruiting season is fall, but may fruit in late summer and fall in the Pacific Northwest and in winter and spring in California; tending to fruit in small numbers, typically 1-3 fruitbodies, rarely more, (Bojantchev), single to scattered or in small groups under both hardwoods and conifers, (Arora), on ground under conifers, in Pacific Northwest fruiting in September to October, (Lincoff), late summer to fall (Buczacki), summer, fall

Amanita aurantisquamosa.nameOrigin: presumably refers to orange scales on stem
Amanita aurantisquamosa.habitat: single to scattered under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Populus tremuloides (aspen) or Juniperus scopulorum (juniper), only the cap showing above the duff when it fruits; fruits late spring to early summer, (Miller)

Amanita breckonii.habitat: described from campus of San Francisco State University where it fruited in a planting of Pinus radiata (Monterey Pine), June, September, (Thiers(5)), also known from Washington state under Abies (spruce) and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine) at 1220 meters elevation, June, (Tulloss(6)), spring, fall

Amanita calyptratoides.odour: "absent to slightly rank, but then over-powered by odor of wet soil" (Tulloss)
Amanita calyptratoides.habitat: in California, single to somewhat gregarious, in "dense, dark, somewhat sandy clay", in open Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak) woods at the edges of chaparral vegetation or under Quercus agrifolia (Tulloss), type under Quercus (oak), (Peck)

Amanita calyptroderma.edibility: good, but be sure of identification (Lindgren), as deadly mushrooms are similar
Amanita calyptroderma.habitat: gregarious; in Pacific Northwest grows with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) "and more commonly with madrone and hardwoods in southern Oregon and California" [fall], (Lindgren), Tulloss(6) gives ecology as the following (Latin names italicized) 'Solitary to gregarious. California: At 90 +/- m elev. Under Quercus or in Abies woods (e.g., holotype) or in mixed forest "where the Bishop Pine [Pinus muricata] start intermingling with" Arbutus menziesii, Lithocarpus densiflorus, and Q. agrifolia. Oregon: Under Pseudotsuga menziesii. Washington: Under P. menziesii in heavy clay soil not watered in summers.', (Tulloss), rich ground "in fir woods or their borders", (Peck)

Amanita ceciliae.habitat: single or scattered on ground, in mixed coniferous and hardwood forests and in open woods, July to October, (Phillips), summer, fall

Amanita constricta.habitat: associated with Pacific coastal species of oak and arbutus as well as Douglas-fir, (Tulloss), in "coastal forests where it occurs mainly under hardwoods such as coastal oaks and madrones, but it has, on occasion, also been found under Douglas fir", (Thiers, for California), fall

Amanita 'farinosa'.habitat: single, with conifers, fall, (Lindgren), in open conifers (Goetz)

Amanita gemmata.habitat: single, scattered or in groups "in woods or along forested paths and roads", (Arora), on ground, "in oak and pine woods, woods and parks in urban areas", June to October, (Lincoff), summer, fall

Amanita magniverrucata.edibility: many Amanitas in subgenus Lepidella are seriously toxic (Siegel(2))
Amanita magniverrucata.odour: strong, pungent, unpleasant, (Thiers(5)), usually indistinct when young, becoming unpleasant when old, (Siegel)
Amanita magniverrucata.habitat: coastal forests of northern and central California, in association with Pinus muricata (Bishop Pine) and probably associated with other closely related pines, (Thiers(5)), single or scattered in small groups with pine and oak, often in fall and early winter "but scattered fruitings continue into spring", (Siegel)

Amanita muscaria.nameOrigin: means "to do with flies" and it is said to have been mixed with milk to stupefy flies
Amanita muscaria.habitat: single or scattered to densely gregarious or in large fairy rings, "in forests and at their edges, also with planted trees", (Arora), on the ground, under Pinus (pine), Picea (spruce), and Betula (birch), also live oak and madrone in California, fruits in June to October, in California during winter, (Lincoff), summer, fall, winter

Amanita novinupta.odour: faintly fungoid (Lindgren), faintly fungoid, "normal agaric", or mild, (Tulloss(2))
Amanita novinupta.habitat: gregarious under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) in landscaped areas and probably with other trees, fruits in April, (Lindgren), single to scattered to gregarious in troops, under various conifers or oak, (Tulloss(2)), spring

Amanita 'ocreata'.edibility: deadly poisonous (Arora), poisoning due to amanitins, symptoms begin after 6-36 hours with vomiting, watery diarrhea, and abdominal cramps for a day or so, then apparent recovery for a day or so, then liver and sometimes kidney failure, brain toxicity, death common, (Benjamin)
Amanita 'ocreata'.habitat: in the Pacific Northwest, found in spring in mixed woods, especially with oak, hazel, and cottonwood, (Trudell), single to widely scattered or in small groups on ground under oaks, winter and spring, (Arora for California), mainly near water in sandy soil with deciduous and possibly coniferous trees, in spring, (Lindgren), grows near streams or wet lands in silt or sandy soil in the Pacific Northwest, at low elevation and not in the high mountains, (J. Lindgren, pers. comm.)

Amanita pachycolea.edibility: yes but be sure of identification, not choice, (Lindgren, Arora)
Amanita pachycolea.taste: mild(Lindgren), mild, may be fishy when old, (Arora), not distinctive (Thiers)
Amanita pachycolea.odour: mild(Lindgren), sometimes unpleasant when old (Arora), not distinctive (Thiers)
Amanita pachycolea.habitat: single to scattered in mixed woods and with conifers, (Lindgren), single, scattered, or in small groups, in mixed woods and under conifers, (Arora), seems to be associated with conifers but has also been found in mixed woods, (Thiers), fall

Amanita 'pantherina'.edibility: poisonous, causing the pantherine syndrome (within 4 hours: nausea, clumsiness, confusion; later, sleep or coma, altered perception, muscle twitching), due to ibotenic acid and muscimol, deaths rare (at most 3 known in the last 50 years), (Benjamin)
Amanita 'pantherina'.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious on ground in woods, (Arora), spring, summer, fall, (Lindgren), January to April, September, (Tulloss)

Amanita pantherinoides.habitat: "originally found under conifers and hardwoods in wet, coastal forests", (Tulloss), type single, collected in woods near Seattle, Washington, October 20 - November 1, 1911, also collected in sandy pine barrens Newport Oregon, "Specimens at Albany sent by Copeland from California and temporarily referred by Peck to Amanitopsis adnata appear to belong here, but I have not examined them microscopically", (Murrill with Latin name italicized), fall

Amanita phalloides.edibility: poisoning due to amanitins, symptoms begin after 6-36 hours with vomiting, watery diarrhea, and abdominal cramps for a day or so, then apparent recovery for a day or so, then liver and sometimes kidney failure, brain toxicity, death common, (Benjamin)
Amanita phalloides.taste: not unpleasant, but do not try it: too poisonous
Amanita phalloides.odour: "at first mild, but later quite pungent or nauseating (like raw potatoes or chlorine)", (Arora), sickening sweet, or like raw potatoes, (Lindgren), sweetish, unpleasant when old, (Breitenbach)
Amanita phalloides.habitat: single, scattered or in groups or troops in woods or on lawns near trees, (Arora), fruits in late summer and fall and into the winter, depending on location and weather, (Ammirati(11)), often growing with Corylus (filbert, hazelnut) or Castanea (sweet chestnut) trees in the Pacific Northwest, (Lindgren), [found in BC under Fagus (beech), Castanea (sweet chestnut), hazelnut (Corylus avellanea), and introduced oak, in California has spread to native oaks]

Amanita populiphila.edibility: edible with caution except for gritty universal veil, but be absolutely sure of species
Amanita populiphila.odour: none or mild and pleasantly fungoid or pungent
Amanita populiphila.habitat: under Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen) or Populus deltoides (Eastern Cottonwood)

Amanita porphyria.odour: often turnip-like when old, (Arora), like raw potatoes (Lindgren), slight (Phillips), potato sprout or raw turnip (Goetz, D.), raw potato or radish (Trudell)
Amanita porphyria.habitat: single, scattered or in small groups under conifers, (Arora), under conifers and in mixed woods, August to October, (Lincoff), summer, fall

Amanita prairiicola.habitat: "Amanita prairiicola is a species of tall grass prairie and high elevation desert. It is frequently found with no nearby woody plant symbiont. It has been found in desert with no living plant in its vicinity." (Tulloss), gregarious in desert areas with sand dunes and in desert range land near or under Sarcobatus vermiculatus (black greasewood), and Chrysothamnus nauseosus (rubber rabbitbush), April to June, (Miller), spring, summer

Amanita protecta.nameOrigin: from "protectus", Latin meaning "protected", "referring to the thick universal veil in this species", (Tulloss)
Amanita protecta.odour: mild at first, fishy when old, (Siegel), slightly sweet, or when old faintly unpleasant, (Tulloss)
Amanita protecta.habitat: in California described as single or in groups, primarily in areas with Salix spp. (willow) and possibly with live oak throughout mushroom season but most abundant in winter, (Siegel), in California, described as being single to gregarious under Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), December to March, in coastal southern California to 800 m elevation, (Tulloss)

Amanita pruittii.nameOrigin: after Ben Pruitt (1888-1993), "farmer, shopkeeper, avid naturalist, founder of historical and nature societies, environmentalist, and amateur mycologist who, at the age of 88 (when the type collection of A. pruittii was made), was actively collecting, photographing, and writing field descriptions of fungi. He is said to have been able to call wild birds to his hand." (Tulloss(7) with Latin name italicized). The name "pruittii" was originally suggested by A. H. Smith in correspondence with Mr. Pruitt and appears with a draft description in unpublished material, (Tulloss(6)).
Amanita pruittii.taste: not distinct when raw, bitter when heated
Amanita pruittii.odour: not distinct when raw, offensive when heated
Amanita pruittii.habitat: gregarious in Sudan grass and possibly other grassy areas (sometimes in standing water J. Lindgren, pers. comm.), in fall

Amanita 'pseudobreckonii'.habitat: single or scattered "in small groups in duff under conifers", especially Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce); often "in large flushes in early fall and spring, with scattered fruitings through winter", [at least in California]

Amanita regalis.edibility: poisonous, containing toxins present in other species similar to A. muscaria, A. pantherina, etc. (Tulloss(6))
Amanita regalis.habitat: "in damp, partly grassy, pine and spruce forests as well as deciduous forests (including birch)" in the mountains of central and northern Europe; in Alaska mostly above treeline

Amanita rubescens.edibility: edible [cooked] but not recommended [too many lookalikes], (Bessette), one or more members of the Amanita rubescens group contain an acidic protein that can destroy red blood cells - it goes by the name rubescenslysin, (Seeger)
Amanita rubescens.taste: mild, rarely bitterish, insipid, faintly nutty (Breitenbach)
Amanita rubescens.habitat: scattered to grouped, on ground in mixed woods or under trees in grassy areas, July to October, (Bessette), single to gregarious or grouped in hardwood and coniferous forest, late spring to fall, (Breitenbach), spring, summer, fall

Amanita silvicola.edibility: unknown, do not eat, especially because of resemblance to poisonous Amanita smithiana
Amanita silvicola.odour: mild or slightly soapy (Arora), fishy when old (Lindgren)
Amanita silvicola.habitat: single or in small groups in coniferous or mixed woods, (Arora), especially under Douglas fir; fruiting September to October, (Phillips), fall

Amanita smithiana.edibility: poisonous, in a number of poisonings A. smithiana has been considered a possible cause with the following picture: after 4-10 or more hours, gastrointestinal symptoms, followed by kidney failure with or without liver failure, (Tulloss(3))
Amanita smithiana.taste: mild to somewhat sweet or lacking; when cooked: radish-like, superb to moderately acidic bitter, (Tulloss(3)), [do not taste]
Amanita smithiana.odour: absent to mild to somewhat faintly pungent or salty or like dust from ground bark of Douglas fir, to yeast-like or with cut surfaces smelling like green tomatoes or tomato plants, very strong and unpleasant when old, almost ham-like with tinges of chlorine, (Tulloss(3))
Amanita smithiana.habitat: single to gregarious, usually under conifers, often amidst or near very rotten wood; fruiting in fall, occasionally summer, winter, spring (September to December, occasionally July, August, or January, once collection in May), (Tulloss(3)), fall, winter, spring, summer

Amanita umbrinidisca.nameOrigin: named for the umbrinous color of the central area of the cap
Amanita umbrinidisca.habitat: "on the ground in a fir forest", October 20 to November 1, 1911, (Murrill)

Amanita 'vaginata'.edibility: not known to be toxic in Pacific Northwest, (Lindgren), yes but be sure of identification, (Arora)
Amanita 'vaginata'.habitat: single to scattered with hardwoods or conifers; usually fruits in fall, (Lindgren), single to scattered or in small groups in woods or under trees, (Arora), summer to fall (Bacon for Europe)

Amanita velosa.spores: white or tinged very slightly pinkish (Arora), white (Siegel)
Amanita velosa.edibility: yes, choice, but too easy to confuse for beginners with poisonous Amanitas, (Arora)
Amanita velosa.habitat: widely scattered to gregarious, with trees especially Quercus (oak) but often grows away from the tree out in the open past the drip line of the oak trees, can be up to 40 feet from host in grass; fruits in winter and spring, (Arora), open areas and lawns, especially near live oak; fruits February to May, (Lincoff), single to scattered in duff, especially in short-grass meadows bordering oak groves, often fairly far from edge of canopy; primarily spring but occasionally in winter, (Siegel)

Amanita vernicoccora.edibility: edible but great care should be taken not to confuse this species with deadly poisonous taxa such as A. ocreata and A. phalloides, (Tulloss(6))
Amanita vernicoccora.taste: mild to pungent, (Bojantchev), mild then faintly peppery when raw, when cooked may be distinctly of fish (Tulloss)
Amanita vernicoccora.odour: mild at first, pungent when old, "frequently interpreted as fishy"
Amanita vernicoccora.habitat: associated with oaks such as Quercus agrifolia, Quercus wislizenii, Quercus douglasii, Quercus kelloggii, Tanoak (Notholithocarpus densiflorus), and likely with Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone) Arctostaphylos manzanita (manzanita); "At higher elevations A. vernicoccora may switch association to conifers but we have not seen it outside of the range of Quercus kelloggii"; late winter and spring, (Bojantchev), in Washington under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Tulloss)

Ampulloclitocybe avellaneialba.habitat: "in groups or clusters on or near rotting logs and debris of alder and conifers", (Phillips), gregarious on very decayed logs and other woody debris (often buried) under conifers, September into December, (Bigelow), fall, winter

Ampulloclitocybe 'clavipes'.edibility: edible (not with alcohol), but not recommended, too easy to confuse, (Arora), not edible (Phillips), some individuals eating this with alcohol have experienced chorine poisoning similar to that caused by eating Coprinopsis atramentaria with alcohol (headache, hot flashes, internal disturbances, rash), (Sept(1))
Ampulloclitocybe 'clavipes'.odour: often fragrant (fruity, like that of grapes), (Bigelow), mild or somewhat fragrant or fruity (Arora), when fresh like grape bubble gum (Trudell)
Ampulloclitocybe 'clavipes'.habitat: single, scattered, gregarious, rarely subcespitose [more or less in tufts], often in arcs, usually under conifers, occasionally in hardwoods or mixed woods, generally August into November, sometimes in July in eastern North America, December into March in California, (Bigelow), summer, fall, winter, spring

Aphroditeola 'olida'.nameOrigin: 'olida' means 'with an odor'; the genus name Aphroditeola is an "allusion to mythical Aphrodite, apropos the pink color and pleasing fragrance"
Aphroditeola 'olida'.taste: mild but obscured by strong odor, (Bigelow), mild (Breitenbach)
Aphroditeola 'olida'.odour: strongly fragrant, reminiscent of bubble gum, (Bessette), fragrant, resembling odor of cinnamon candy, (Bigelow), aromatic, sweetish like fruit bon-bons or flowers, (Breitenbach), fruity (Phillips), fragrant, reminiscent of root beer or cinnamon candy, (Arora), fruit drops (Moser), fruity odor of cinnamon candy or grape soda (Trudell)
Aphroditeola 'olida'.habitat: scattered or gregarious on soil or conifer needles, usually under Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), occasionally Pinus (pine) and Tsuga (hemlock), July to October, (Bigelow), gregarious to almost clustered, the caps often concrescent, in conifer forest, among mosses or needle litter, summer to fall, (Breitenbach), under conifers or in mixed woods (Phillips), summer, fall

Armillaria altimontana.nameOrigin: refers "to its occurrence in the high elevation mountains (alti - high; montana = mountain)"
Armillaria altimontana.habitat: found "on hardwoods and conifers in higher elevation forests", especially in forest types dominated by Abies (true fir) species

Armillaria cepistipes.nameOrigin: means 'with onion-shaped foot', cepa = onion (Latin), pes = foot (Latin)
Armillaria cepistipes.taste: "mild, irritating the throat after being chewed for a rather long time" (Breitenbach)
Armillaria cepistipes.habitat: generally clustered, more rarely single, on hardwoods, "parasitic or saprophytic on trunks, stumps, or roots", summer to fall, (Breitenbach), in groups, parasitic then saprobic on hardwoods, (Courtecuisse)

Armillaria gallica.habitat: single to gregarious, usually on soil, but occasionally "climbing" onto logs or stumps to fruit, almost always found on hardwoods, but occasionally on conifers, (Volk), Garry oak habitat on southern Vancouver Island, (Allen), often occurs singly, parasitic or saprobic; on the ground, but connected to wood by rhizomorphs, (Courtecuisse), rarely grows in clumps but scattered singly over a wide area growing from buried wood or roots, (Kibby), fall (Buczacki)

Armillaria mellea.edibility: yes (use firm caps and discard tough stems), but some forms can cause digestive upsets, (Arora), gastrointestinal symptoms dominate the clinical picture, but hallucinations have been reported in a few cases (Benjamin)
Armillaria mellea.habitat: in small or massive clusters on stumps, logs, and living trees, or scattered to gregarious (occasionally single) on ground, but growing from roots or buried wood

Armillaria nabsnona.nameOrigin: nabsnona stands for North American Biological Species IX: 'Nona' = ninth
Armillaria nabsnona.habitat: primarily on hardwoods in riparian areas, especially Alnus (alder), in gregarious clusters but not cespitose, spring and fall, (Volk(1)), on hardwood, especially Alnus rubra (Red Alder), (Volk(2))

Armillaria ostoyae.edibility: a fine edible if thoroughly cooked (Bessette), has been reported to cause some people some gastrointestinal upset if collected from hemlock, but Volk believes most of the reported upset is due to undercooking (and overeating) of larger collections, (Volk), there are reports of toxic reactions to Armillaria ingestion - gastrointestinal symptoms dominate the clinical picture, but hallucinations have been reported in a few cases (Benjamin)
Armillaria ostoyae.habitat: typically in large clusters but sometimes single on or about stumps or trees, July to November, (Bessette), in BC found from 49 degrees latitude to 53 degrees primarily on conifers, but hardwoods within disease centers in conifer stands were frequently attacked and killed, (Morrison), on the Olympic peninsula in Washington, almost exclusively on conifers, especially Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), but also Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), (Banik), singly but most commonly in large fasciculate groups on decaying wood debris, dead stumps, dead trees, dead roots, declining trees, and healthy roots, hosts include Acer (maple), Betula (birch), and Quercus (oak), (Berube), a serious problem in Malus and Prunus orchards in Michigan (Burdsall), usually in clusters, mostly on conifers, but also on hardwoods and shrubs such as Salix (willow) and Rubus spectabilis (salmonberry), (Trudell), summer, fall

Armillaria sinapina.habitat: singly or in small fasciculate (bundled) groups or two to five on dead stumps and healthy roots, and trees, (hardwood and conifer), (Berube), singly, or sometimes in clusters of two or three; in northeastern North America found mainly on hardwoods and occasionally conifers, but in the Pacific Northwest more common on conifers, (Volk)

Arrhenia 'acerosa'.habitat: on various mosses, especially Dicranum species, "or near mosses and then either terrestrial or on litter close to the soil or mosses, in coniferous forests, burn sites, seepage sites, or moss carpets", (Redhead), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Arrhenia auriscalpium.nameOrigin: perhaps based on resemblance in stature to Auriscalpium
Arrhenia auriscalpium.habitat: sandy or peaty soil with sparse low often pioneering moss cover, in recently deglaciated sites or burn sites as well as tundra or arctic alpine sites

Arrhenia bigelowii.nameOrigin: "bigelowii" honors "the American mycologist Howard Elson Bigelow, the first to publish this entity as a separate taxon"
Arrhenia bigelowii.habitat: in groups of 1-6 separate fruitbodies, attached to living Sphagnum with white mycelial tomentum, open raised Sphagnum bogs; fruiting "June-Sept, most plentiful in July"; may be found "in the same bog at the same time" as Arrhenia gerardiana

Arrhenia chlorocyanea.habitat: scattered or gregarious, in the open on thin soil, sometimes mosses, November to May, (Bigelow(5) for Clitocybe atroviridis), in grass, moss or on lichens (Arora for Clitocybe atroviridis), coniferous woods (Moser for O. chlorocyanea in Europe), fall, winter, spring

Arrhenia 'epichysium'.habitat: "scattered on decayed wood in coniferous and mixed woods", (Bessette), scattered or gregarious, sometimes single, on logs and stumps of conifers or hardwoods, (Bigelow)

Arrhenia gerardiana.taste: slightly farinaceous when young, soon fading, (Bigelow)
Arrhenia gerardiana.odour: unremarkable, (Voitk), slightly farinaceous when young, soon fading, (Bigelow)
Arrhenia gerardiana.habitat: in groups of one to six separate fruitbodies, attached to living Sphagnum "with white mycelial tomentum", in open raised Sphagnum bogs; "JuneSeptember, most plentiful in July"; "may be found in the same bog at the same time" as Arrhenia bigelowii, (Voitk), single, scattered, or gregarious, on sphagnum in bogs, June and July, rarely August, (Bigelow)

Arrhenia hohensis.odour: not distinctive or rarely faintly fragrant
Arrhenia hohensis.habitat: scattered to gregarious on sandy soil, among lichens and mosses at times, May to July, September to November, (Bigelow), spring, summer, fall

Arrhenia lobata.habitat: single to clustered on moss in wet sites, "alpine sites or lowland bogs or fens often around the margins of pools", (Redhead(7)), moss-associated, "often found in fens, along streams, or in association with melting snow", (Trudell)

Arrhenia obscurata.habitat: scattered on sandy soil or sometimes on moss, June to September, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Arrhenia peltigerina.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] in scattered groups on soil and old lichens (Peltigera), May in New York, July in Idaho, (Bigelow), spring, summer

Arrhenia philonotis.habitat: in groups of one to six separate fruitbodies, on barren moors, heaths, fens, raised Sphagnum bogs, either with Sphagnum or other moss; "June-September, most plentiful in August"

Arrhenia pubescentipes.habitat: scattered or gregarious on soil or moss, single in greenhouse pot; June, July, September, (Bigelow), summer

Arrhenia rainierensis.habitat: on soil or moss of wet road banks, September, October, (Bigelow), fall

Arrhenia 'retiruga'.habitat: on mosses, tree trunks, sometimes on twigs or leaves near mosses (Redhead), fall, spring, (Buczacki)

Arrhenia telmatiaea.nameOrigin: 'telma' is Greek for marsh, pool, or standing water, (Brown, R.W.)
Arrhenia telmatiaea.habitat: open, raised Sphagnum bogs in groups of one to six separate fruitbodies, attached to living Sphagnum moss "with white mycelial tomentum", July to September

Aspropaxillus giganteus.edibility: difficult to digest and poor in flavor, (Arora)
Aspropaxillus giganteus.taste: pleasant to slightly disagreeable (Arora), mild or disagreeable, (Bigelow), mild (Singer)
Aspropaxillus giganteus.odour: pleasant to slightly disagreeable (Arora), rather pleasant and somewhat farinaceous, (Bigelow), weak, farinaceous or "mossy" according to Quelet, or "somewhat suggestive of skunk cabbage" according to Murrill, (Singer)
Aspropaxillus giganteus.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious, "in open woods and grassy (but usually wooded) areas", often in fairy rings or arcs, (Arora), single or gregarious, under conifers in Washington, in deep humus in Tennessee, on compost heap in Massachusetts, (Bigelow), gregarious often in large fairy rings; in open mixed woods and in hilly places under spruce and fir, "very often in gardens and parks on grassy soil"; August to October, (Singer), summer, fall

Aspropaxillus septentrionalis.nameOrigin: means "northern" after the seven bright stars of "Septentriones", the big dipper
Aspropaxillus septentrionalis.edibility: not recommended because of disagreeable taste and lack of data
Aspropaxillus septentrionalis.odour: strong and somewhat spermatic, later pungent, (Bigelow), peppery (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Aspropaxillus septentrionalis.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] under conifers, (a Yukon collection under poplars); July, August, November, (Bigelow), under conifers, clustered, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), summer, fall

Asterophora lycoperdoides.habitat: in gregarious clusters on rotting Russula (especially the R. dissimulans-R. nigricans complex) and Lactarius spp., in forests, (Castellano), usually grouped or clustered on dead mushrooms of Russula and Lactarius, (Breitenbach), in colonies on old mushrooms especially species in the Russula densifolia group, (Arora), on rotting mushrooms, especially Russula and Lactarius, (Lincoff), summer and fall (Miller)

Asterophora parasitica.odour: unpleasant, farinaceous, (Castellano), strong, sour, like Polyporus squamosus, (Corner), unpleasant (Bessette), very strongly mealy (Courtecuisse)
Asterophora parasitica.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on rotting Russula (especially the R. dissimulans-R. nigricans complex), and rarely on Lactarius spp., (Castellano), typically gregarious and grouped on decomposing Russula and Lactarius species, sometimes on others, (Bessette), on fruitbodies of Russula and Lactarius species (Corner), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Atheniella 'adonis'.habitat: among grass, moss, on fallen twigs or decayed wood, under conifers or hardwoods, (Maas Geesteranus for Europe), scattered to gregarious on needle beds under spruce and hemlock in west coastal conifer forests, or in the higher mountains, not uncommon in spring and fall, (Smith), early summer to fall (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Atheniella aurantiidisca.habitat: gregarious under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Pinus (pine), spring and fall

Atheniella delectabilis.odour: strong nitrous, sometimes evident only if flesh crushed, or absent, (Smith), strong, unpleasant, acrid, (Buczacki)
Atheniella delectabilis.habitat: scattered to gregarious on needle beds especially under heaps of dead branches or fallen treetops, (Smith), probably all year (spring, summer, fall, winter), (Buczacki)

Atheniella 'flavoalba'.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious on needle beds or humus under oaks; fall, (Smith), among grass and moss, on fallen twigs, in broad-leaved as well as coniferous woods, (Maas Geesteranus), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Atractosporocybe inornata.taste: mild or slightly bitter (Bessette), not distinctive or slightly bitter (Bigelow)
Atractosporocybe inornata.habitat: single, scattered, in groups or clusters on conifer needles or hardwood leaves, July to November, (Bessette), single, scattered, gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts], under hardwoods or conifers, September to November, rarely July or August, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Aureonarius callisteus.odour: locomotive (Moser), distinctive, described variously as scorched linen, heated laundry iron, hotplate, hot metal, or locomotive (Paul Kroeger, pers. comm.), slight (Phillips), sharp, fungus-like, or of potatoes or radish-like, (Thorn), strong, motor oil, model electric trains, ozone, (Buczacki)
Aureonarius callisteus.habitat: conifer woods (Thorn), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Aureonarius infucatus.odour: when smelling from the top of the cap "often faint and like apples, sometimes stronger and like a recently extinguished candle"
Aureonarius infucatus.habitat: in western North America mainly in non-calcareous coniferous forests, but in Europe and eastern North America in mesic coniferous forests, often on rich to calcareous soil; fruiting August-October

Aureonarius kroegeri.nameOrigin: named "for Paul Kroeger, well known Canadian mycologist"
Aureonarius kroegeri.habitat: single to gregarious, "in moist, old growth forests with Abies and Tsuga or Tsuga and Picea, in soil and duff or among mosses, September to mid-October"

Aureonarius limonius.odour: not distinct, (Thorn), +/- radish-like (Courtecuisse), strong, rather rusty [sic] (Phillips)
Aureonarius limonius.habitat: under hardwoods and conifers, more often northern mountains (Courtecuisse for Europe), coniferous woods (Phillips), fall (Buczacki)

Aureonarius neocallisteus.nameOrigin: means 'new callisteus' referring to Aureonarius callisteus
Aureonarius neocallisteus.odour: (notes from fresh fruitbodies) holotype lacking hot-iron smell, (Niskanen), "rather dank and earthy rather than the hot metal smell. Descriptors I find evoke the odour are 'like a concrete basement that had been flooded', 'an earthen-floored cellar' (these are from childhood memories growing up in Alberta; in coastal BC such things just smell mouldy), 'like a walk-in refrigerator' or produce cooler, and Fred Rhoades came up with 'WD-40'. The odour is musty and earthy, but not the strong Actinomycete smell of mouldy soil which resembles green corn", (P. Kroeger, pers. comm.)
Aureonarius neocallisteus.habitat: holotype gregarious in interior cedar-hemlock old-growth forest, moist cold variant, made up of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), on submesic soils with relatively dry and low nutrient status; generally in coniferous forests, fruiting September to October, (Niskanen), fall

Baeospora myosura.taste: not distinctive (Lennox, Bessette, Breitenbach), faint, mushroomy or bitter, (Buczacki)
Baeospora myosura.habitat: scattered to gregarious on cones of Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), very rarely Pinus spp., (June) September-November, (Desjardin for California), single to gregarious on cones of Douglas-fir or spruce, these often buried, (Lennox), on fallen cones of eastern white pine, Norway and Sitka spruce, and probably other conifers, (Lincoff), in groups on conifer cones, especially white pine and Norway spruce, also on magnolia cones, (Bessette, for northeastern North America), single to gregarious, on cones of Pinus and Picea, (Breitenbach for Europe), fall and early winter (Bacon), summer, fall, winter

Baeospora myriadophylla.habitat: scattered to cespitose [in tufts] "on much decayed wood in moist lowland mixed woods, spring or fall", (Lennox), scattered to densely gregarious, lignicolous on decayed Abies logs, "typically buried deep within the logs", (Desjardin), "in small groups or clustered on decaying wood, especially poplar and hemlock"; June - October, (Phillips), on decayed Abies logs, sometimes buried deep within the logs, at higher elevations, (Castellano), typically "on hardwood logs and stumps", "less often on conifer wood and forest floor litter", (Trudell), summer, fall

Bolbitius 'reticulatus'.nameOrigin: means 'reticulate' (covered with a network of interlacing lines, ridges, or folds)
Bolbitius 'reticulatus'.habitat: in California, single or in small troops on well-decayed hardwoods, especially Lithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak) and live oak, fruiting "throughout mushroom season, most common in fall and spring"

Bolbitius titubans.spores: rusty orange to rusty brown (Arora), sienna [an ocher brown] to rust, (Watling)
Bolbitius titubans.habitat: single, scattered or gregarious (or even in tufts) "on dung, manure, straw, lawns, in tall grass, cultivated ground, etc.", (Arora), on dung, straw-bales and piles of rotting vegetable debris, at margins of woods, edges of fields and particularly in farm-yards and gardens, (Watling for Britain), spring, early summer, and fall, (Miller)

Bonomyces 'sinopicus'.nameOrigin: "sinopica" refers to "quartz colored red-brown by iron impurities"
Bonomyces 'sinopicus'.odour: strongly farinaceous (Bigelow), mealy or of cucumber (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), strongly farinaceous-rancid (Breitenbach)
Bonomyces 'sinopicus'.habitat: single, scattered, sometimes gregarious, on sandy soil, frequently in the open along road shoulders and paths, occasionally in open woods, sometimes on recently burned areas, rarely on wood, "April to November but most frequently in June and early July", (Bigelow), "may be found at almost any time of year, often on bare soil", (Trudell), single to gregarious, "Along pathsides, on street embankments, under shrubbery, in coniferous forests on bare ground or among grasses or herbs, also in burned places", spring to summer, (Breitenbach), spring, summer, fall

Britzelmayria multipedata.habitat: cespitose on the ground "but actually coming from buried wood, often abundant on old sawdust piles"

Callistosporium 'luteo-olivaceum'.taste: mild or slightly bitter, (Arora), both North American and European collections often reported as slightly bitter or styptic, (Redhead), farinaceous-bitter (Trudell)
Callistosporium 'luteo-olivaceum'.odour: mild to pungent or slightly fruity, (Arora)
Callistosporium 'luteo-olivaceum'.habitat: single, scattered or in small groups or tufts on rotten wood (often buried), under conifers, (Arora), single, scattered, or in small clusters, on well-rotted, often mossy wood, preferring "conifer logs and stumps (often associated with the bark)"; spring through fall, (Trudell)

Calocybe carnea.edibility: edible but too easy to confuse with poisonous species
Calocybe carnea.habitat: scattered or in groups "in lawns, grassy clearings in woods, or other open places", (Arora), recorded on moss in spruce bog (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Calocybe fallax.habitat: in Montana and Idaho on needles of Abies grandis (Grand Fir), A. lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce), and Pinus contorta, in Alaska on litter, cones and branchlets of Alnus crispa (Green Alder) and on the moss Drepanocladus uncinatus, (Brunner), forests and alpine habitats (at least in Europe, Hansen), coniferous forest (at least in Europe, Moser)

Calocybe onychina.odour: farinaceous, even somewhat cucumber-like, (Bessette), not distinctive (Mitchel)
Calocybe onychina.habitat: several to gregarious under conifers, June and early July, (Bessette), summer

Calonarius adonis.habitat: under oaks (both deciduous and evergreen) and potentially other hardwood hosts, (Bojantchev), single or scattered, in California "under live oak and Tanoak", (Siegel)

Calonarius albidolilacinus.nameOrigin: "The name refers to the white and lilac colors" of the fruitbodies
Calonarius albidolilacinus.habitat: under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak); the type collected in November

Calonarius anetholens.nameOrigin: "The name refers to the anise odor." (Liimatainen), 'anethum' is Latin for 'anise', 'olens' is Latin for 'emitting an odor'
Calonarius anetholens.habitat: under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) or Q. garryana and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine); the type collected in November

Calonarius aureofulvus.odour: not distinctive, fungoid to slightly fragrant, (Moser(2))

Calonarius aurora.nameOrigin: name means 'dawn, morning' (Latin), perhaps referring to the universal veil colors
Calonarius aurora.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts], sometimes in fairy rings, in subalpine conifer forest, [at least in Wyoming]

Calonarius bigelowii.nameOrigin: after Howard E. Bigelow, the collector of the type
Calonarius bigelowii.spores: easily obtained despite underground growth (Smith), dark rusty brown (Miller)
Calonarius bigelowii.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to scattered "under the duff or just breaking through, under conifers", type found in June, (Thiers), tends to grow under duff, (Arora), usually single at the line between the mineral soil and the duff, (i.e. produced underground or occasionally breaking through), white-bark pine region of Idaho, summer and early fall, (Smith), single to several, under the duff or just breaking through when mature, with conifers at high elevations; summer and fall, (Miller)

Calonarius cacodes.odour: "very strong of raw potatoes and radish (potato cellar)"
Calonarius cacodes.habitat: mixed conifer forests, Tsuga (hemlock), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies (fir)

Calonarius callochrous.habitat: in coniferous forests (Brandrud), "in boreo-nemoral, montane and subalpine coniferous forests", associated with Picea abies and Abies alba, on calcareous soil, (Froslev(2) for Europe), with Picea (spruce), rarely Pinus (pine), on calcareous soil, fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe)

Calonarius cedretorum.nameOrigin: means 'of cedars' (habitat in Europe includes Cedrus)
Calonarius cedretorum.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious on ground under conifers, under oak, or in mixed woods, (Arora), under spruce and fir, September to October, later in the South, (Phillips), under Cedrus (true cedar), sometimes hardwoods in warm sites (Courtecuisse for Europe), fall (Buczacki)

Calonarius corrosus.habitat: gregarious in conifer forests near Picea (spruce); summer to fall, (Breitenbach(5))

Calonarius cupreorufus.odour: none (Kauffman), none (Lincoff), none (Smith(22) who mentions that the Cortinarius orichalceus Fr. he is talking about is the one with no odor and white flesh, not the one described by Henry with anise odor and greenish yellow flesh)
Calonarius cupreorufus.habitat: under conifers, in high mountains, 2400 to 3000 meters, (Kauffman), in conifer woods in mountains, late summer and fall, (Lincoff), coniferous and mixed woods, deciduous woods, on chalk, (Moser)

Calonarius elegantio-occidentalis.nameOrigin: 'elegantio' refers to Calonarius elegantior, and 'occidentalis' means 'western'
Calonarius elegantio-occidentalis.habitat: At higher elevations in the Cascade Mountains it is found in mixed conifer forests with Abies (true fir), Pinus (pine), and Picea (spruce); Abies, Pinus, and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir); or Abies, Picea, Pinus, Pseudotsuga, and Larix (larch). At mid-elevations it is found with Abies, Pseudotsuga, and Tsuga (hemlock). In coastal populations it is found with Picea and Tsuga.

Calonarius elegantiomontanus.odour: pungent or not distinctive, (Garnica), not distinctive (Moser)
Calonarius elegantiomontanus.habitat: in mixed conifer forests where Picea (spruce) occurs, often in combination with Abies (true fir) and Pinus (pine), (Garnica), under conifers (Moser)

Calonarius elotoides.odour: somewhat of radish or raw potatoes at least when cut

Calonarius flavipallens.nameOrigin: "The name refers to the colour of the pileus." (Liimatainen(2) who give the colors as pale ochraceous)
Calonarius flavipallens.habitat: in Finland, found in boreal forests dominated by Picea abies (Norway spruce) on calcareous soil

Calonarius flavobulbus.odour: slightly fruity when cut (apples) to not distinctive
Calonarius flavobulbus.habitat: under Quercus vacciniifolia (Huckleberry Oak) and Q. garryana (Oregon White Oak)

Calonarius fulvoarcuatorum.nameOrigin: 'arcuatorum' refers to Cortinarius arcuatorum of Europe; 'fulvo' means fulvous in color
Calonarius fulvoarcuatorum.habitat: the examined collections were from mixed woods that included Quercus (oak), (Garnica(4), who note that the three similar species mentioned here are in general strongly associated with members of the Fagaceae, except for the populations of C. arcuatorum from the eastern Rockies where only conifers occur)

Calonarius luteicolor.nameOrigin: "refers to the yellowish colours of the pileus and lamellae" (Liimatainen)

'Calonarius' magnivelatus^;.habitat: forms fruiting bodies underneath the soil surface associated with roots of conifers above 1500m elevation, May through August, (Castellano), single to gregarious under mountain conifers (especially fir and pine), usually buried in duff, (Arora), April to September, montane with Pinus, Abies, Tsuga, (Trappe, M.(3))

Calonarius metarius.habitat: in mountain forests of spruce and fir (Kauffman), scattered to gregarious under spruce and fir, summer and fall, (Smith(6))

Calonarius mikedavisii.nameOrigin: in honor of Professor Mike Davis
Calonarius mikedavisii.habitat: mixed woods with Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce)

Calonarius napus.taste: mild, slightly astringent or slightly raphanoid, (Garnica), mild, slightly astringent (Moser(2))
Calonarius napus.odour: none or slightly pungent (Garnica), not distinctive (Moser(2))
Calonarius napus.habitat: subalpine coniferous forest, under Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce) and Pinus contorta, (Moser(2)), in Rocky Mountains occurring in conifer forests with Picea where Abies and Pinus may be present, in Cascade Mountains of Washington occurring in mixed conifer forests of Abies, Picea, Pseudotsuga, and Tsuga, in coastal OR and northern CA known from low elevations with Pseudotsuga, Picea, or Pseudotsuga and Tsuga, (Garnica)

Calonarius oliveopetasatus.odour: "weak, when cut of fresh cut grass"

Calonarius olympianus.nameOrigin: first found in the Olympic Mountains of Washington
Calonarius olympianus.habitat: type gregarious under fir, (Smith), scattered to gregarious on ground under conifers

Calonarius piceae.habitat: on "calcareous, dry to seasonally moist soil", "in boreo-nemoral, montane and subalpine coniferous forests", associated with Picea abies (European spruce) and Abies alba (European Silver Fir)

Calonarius pseudocupreorufus.nameOrigin: "refers to the affinity to" Cortinarius cupreorufus [now Calonarius cupreorufus], (Liimatainen)

Calonarius saxamontanus.nameOrigin: from Latin 'saxum' meaning 'rock' and Latin 'montanus' meaning 'pertaining to mountains', may refer to the Rocky Mountains where some collections were found
Calonarius saxamontanus.spores: deposits spores on the inside of the veil
Calonarius saxamontanus.habitat: subemergent, forming humps about 5cm high in the duff where they have failed to emerge, associated with Pinus (pine) and Abies (true fir) species, fruiting from late June to late July at 2500-3500 meters elevation

Calonarius spectabilis.habitat: under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Larix occidentalis (Western Larch)

Calonarius subpurpureophyllus.nameOrigin: means 'close to [Cortinarius] purpureophyllus', a similar species found in Michigan under hardwoods
Calonarius subpurpureophyllus.habitat: under Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Moser(9)), gregarious under spruce (Smith)

Calonarius verrucisporus.habitat: type single in humus under conifers, (Thiers), single to scattered, often found well buried in conifer duff in mountains; occasional in spring, rare in fall, (MykoWeb)

Calonarius viridirubescens.odour: of hot baked, or not distinctive
Calonarius viridirubescens.habitat: under Lithocarpus densiflora (tanoak) or deciduous oaks (Quercus garryana), also in mixed forests of oak and tanoak with conifers

Candolleomyces candolleanus.edibility: yes, but not easy to identify, (Arora)
Candolleomyces candolleanus.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious around old hardwood stumps or buried wood, particularly common around cottonwood and elm, spring and early summer, (Smith), scattered to gregarious or in tufts in lawns, gardens, on or around old hardwood stumps, on buried roots or debris, etc., sometimes also in woods, year-round but most common in late spring, summer, and early fall, (Arora for his area of California), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller)

Candolleomyces typhae.habitat: on dead leaves and stems of Typha (cat-tail) and Carex (sedge), often fruiting near the waterline, late spring and summer, (Smith), "Gregarious, grouped, more rarely solitary on dead stems or leaves of various aquatic plants such as Typha, Phragmites, and others, usually a few centimeters above the water surface", (Breitenbach for Europe, generic names italicized)

Cantharellula oregonensis.habitat: type found on ground in mixed woods in the foothills of the Cascades at 800 and 1200 feet

Cantharellula umbonata.edibility: yes (Phillips), doubtful (Kibby), a fine edible if young and fresh (Bessette)
Cantharellula umbonata.odour: scented (Phillips), faintly of cucumbers, or fragrant or not distinctive, (Redhead(36)), not distinctive (Bessette)
Cantharellula umbonata.habitat: scattered or in groups on hair-cap moss beds; August to November, (Phillips), among mosses, especially Polytrichum, often on peaty or sandy soils, often in disturbed sites, has also been recorded on needle beds but usually where previous moss beds had been shaded out, (Redhead), conifer bogs (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), scattered to gregarious, sometimes in fairy rings, quite exclusively in haircap (Polytrichum) moss; August to November, (Bessette), grows in association with Dicranum, Polytrichum, and other mosses, (Trudell), summer, fall

Cantharellus californicus.nameOrigin: refers to its main location in California
Cantharellus californicus.taste: indistinct (Siegel), "typically mild (but one collection in exceptionally dry conditions was strongly bitter as if impregnated with tannin)", (Arora)
Cantharellus californicus.odour: indistinct "to slightly fruity, most pronounced in dry weather or in very fresh young fruitbodies", (Siegel), "faintly fruity (reminiscent of pumpkin) especially when several are stored together in a paper bag", (Arora)
Cantharellus californicus.habitat: single, in pairs or clumps, "forming arcs and rings", "prefers deep duff of live oaks in open woodland, but also in dark redwood forest with a mixed hardwood understory", also "occurs with Tanoak and deciduous oaks", (Siegel), single to gregarious in leaf litter in association with Quercus agrifolia (Coast Live Oak) or sometimes other oaks, also found with Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak), "usually fruiting between November and April but collections have been made during every month of the year", (Arora)

Cantharellus cascadensis.spores: white to yellowish white (colors from Kelly), (Dunham), whitish to creamy (Siegel)
Cantharellus cascadensis.habitat: single to gregarious or occasionally cespitose, in Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) - Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) forest of variable age and elevation, (Dunham), in small groups "or scattered in large arcs in deep humus of a variety of conifers"; most often with T. heterophylla, Abies nobilis (Grand Fir), and Pseudotsuga menziesii; "fall and early winter", (Siegel), M. Beug (pers. comm. February 28, 2022) has found it in woods that were almost exclusively Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak)

Cantharellus formosus.edibility: idiosyncratic allergic-type reactions to chanterelles have been reported to North American Mycological Association's poison registry (Benjamin), widely consumed however and considered choice (Pilz)
Cantharellus formosus.taste: mild to slightly peppery, (Tylutki), mildly peppery when raw (Pilz)
Cantharellus formosus.odour: none or fragrant of apricots, (Tylutki), faint, fruity, apricot-like, more noticeable in drier fresh collections, (Pilz)
Cantharellus formosus.habitat: single to gregarious, often in small clusters or slight arcs, on bare and mossy needle beds, sometimes near coarse woody debris, in both second growth and old growth western North American forests, most often under hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla) sometimes mixed with Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii), Sitka spruce, (Picea sitchensis) and other associates, once under virtually pure Pinus contorta, (Redhead), under hemlock, Douglas-fir, and spruce, (Pilz)

Cantharellus roseocanus.nameOrigin: 'roseocanus' means 'rose-colored hoary'; the English name is suggested by Redhead because it "sports an array of colors, it occurs in rainforests, and at its end it is golden"
Cantharellus roseocanus.spores: orangish yellow, similar in color to spore-bearing surface, (Redhead), orange yellow (Pilz)
Cantharellus roseocanus.taste: some forms of C. cibarius have subtle peppery taste
Cantharellus roseocanus.odour: fruity apricot-like (slightly stronger than C. formosus), (Pilz)
Cantharellus roseocanus.habitat: single to gregarious, often in small clusters, on bare or mossy or grassy needle beds, in second growth Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis), or under spruce (Picea) with hemlock (Tsuga) and or fir (Abies), (Redhead), associated with Sitka spruce on the coast and Engelmann spruce at higher elevations in the Cascade Range, but not found in pure stands of Douglas-fir or hemlock, also reported from pure stands of lodgepole pine along Oregon coast; generally fruiting from August through October in old forests, (Pilz)

Cantharellus subalbidus.taste: usually peppery when raw (Pilz), not distinctive (Smith), pleasant (Miller)
Cantharellus subalbidus.odour: pleasant, in fresh specimens reminiscent of apricot (contrary to original description by Smith & Morse), (Pilz), mild or slightly fragrant (Arora), not distinctive (Smith), mild (Miller)
