Cantharellus subalbidus.habitat: single, scattered, or gregarious in woods, in the Pacific Northwest and northern California "quite abundant under second-growth conifers", but in his area further south in California it is only occasionally common and the best places to look are "on the high exposed ridges of our coastal mountains under tanoak and madrone or in manzanita thickets mixed with knobcone pine", (Arora), under Douglas-fir and hemlock, commonly late summer and early fall in mature to old forests, (Pilz)

Cantharocybe gruberi.nameOrigin: after Gruber, who found the type specimen
Cantharocybe gruberi.odour: radish-like, somewhat sweetish, or like green pepper, or farinaceous
Cantharocybe gruberi.habitat: single on needle beds and earth under conifers, May in Idaho, July to September in New Mexico, (Bigelow), spring, summer, fall

Catathelasma evanescens.nameOrigin: means 'evanescent' (fleeting) and probably referring to the annulus which is called evanescent in the protologue
Catathelasma evanescens.spores: white (on upper side of upper annulus)
Catathelasma evanescens.odour: "farinaceous when young but mixed farinaceous-antiseptic or unpleasant" when old
Catathelasma evanescens.habitat: isolated fruitbodies "scattered on bare ground in coniferous forests"

Catathelasma imperiale.habitat: associated with boreal or alpine conifers, often found in calcareous soils

Catathelasma ventricosum.edibility: good (Phillips), but note the poisonous Amanita smithiana can be somewhat similar
Catathelasma ventricosum.taste: not distinctive or slightly unpleasant- farinaceous, (Vizzini), mild to unpleasant-farinaceous (Castellano)
Catathelasma ventricosum.odour: not distinctive or slightly unpleasant- farinaceous, (Vizzini), not distinctive or slightly farinaceous, (Castellano), not distinctive (Bessette)
Catathelasma ventricosum.habitat: single, scattered, occurring in deep humus under conifers (primarily Abies (true fir) and Picea (spruce)), (Vizzini), single, scattered, rooting in deep humus under conifers, primarily Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), (Castellano), fruiting late summer and fall (Miller)

Caulorhiza hygrophoroides.nameOrigin: means "like Hygrophorus", so named because "At first sight the young pileus is suggestive of the pileus of Hygrophorus conicus, both in shape and color", (Peck, with Latin name italicized)
Caulorhiza hygrophoroides.habitat: scattered, on buried wood in hardwood forests or at the edge of trails, in May, (Mycoquebec), subcespitose, on decaying half-buried wood, May, (Peck), scattered to gregarious in low hardwoods, late spring, (Smith), referring to WI finds, "All but one time it has been found appearing to arise from bare earth, although it doubtless occurs on buried wood, explaining its appearance in dry years.", (Nelsen)

Cheimonophyllum candidissimum.habitat: decayed and dead wood of conifers and hardwoods; commonly gregarious; fall, (Brown), on decaying wood, July to October, (Lincoff), on dead hardwood branches (Barron), on logs, trunks, stumps of hardwood trees and dead grass and moss under conifers, (Watling for United Kingdom), on rotting wood, dead grass stems and perhaps mosses, (Buczacki), summer, fall

Chlorophyllum agaricoides.edibility: caused hemolytic anemia in a dog, which had eaten a mature fruitbody (DE Desjardin pers. obs. as reported in Vellinga(5)); said to be edible when young (Arora), edible when young and tastes sweet and nutty (Lincoff)
Chlorophyllum agaricoides.odour: like cabbage in mature specimens (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), none (Miller)
Chlorophyllum agaricoides.habitat: single, scattered, in groups, or even in dense clusters on lawns, flower beds, fields, and waste places, (Arora), May to October (Phillips)

Chlorophyllum brunneum.edibility: "Edible and excellent, but can cause serious gastrointestinal upsets (even in people who've eaten them without problems in the past). Use only very fresh caps, cook them thoroughly, and don't eat large quantities. Also, be aware of the habitat in which they were growing - Chlorophyllum are known to accumulate heavy metals.", (Siegel(2), with Latin name italicized), excellent but some have gastric upset, (Phillips(2)), there are reports of severe gastrointestinal reactions to Chlorophyllum from regions where Chlorophyllum molybdites does not occur, (Benjamin), make sure it is not Chlorophyllum molybdites!
Chlorophyllum brunneum.odour: "Often pleasantly savory, then musty in age", (Siegel), pleasant (Phillips)
Chlorophyllum brunneum.habitat: single, "in pairs, or in fused clumps, arcs, or large troops"; largest flushes often in fall and spring, "with scattered fruitings throughout the year", (Siegel(2) for California), on rich soil in gardens and compost heaps, (Phillips(2)), mainly in man-made, nutrient-rich habitats like gardens and compost heaps, (Vellinga(3)), spring, summer, fall

Chlorophyllum molybdites.spores: grayish olive to greenish (Arora), dull light olive-green to grayish green (Siegel)
Chlorophyllum molybdites.edibility: poisonous, may cause severe gastrointestinal distress, (Arora)
Chlorophyllum molybdites.odour: indistinct or strongly like Agaricus bisporus, especially when old, (Siegel)
Chlorophyllum molybdites.habitat: single to scattered or in groups or large fairy rings "on lawns and other grassy places, also in gardens", fruiting in summer or in warm weather, (Arora), summer and early fall (Siegel)

Chlorophyllum olivieri.edibility: edible and good, but Chlorophyllum "can cause gastrointestinal upsets due to allergic reactions, so be sure to eat only fresh specimens, cook them thoroughly, eat only a small amount the first time, and make sure it's not C. molybdites!" (Siegel), edible and choice, but may sicken some people (Sieger), there are reports of severe gastrointestinal reactions to Chlorophyllum from regions where Chlorophyllum molybdites does not occur, (Benjamin), make sure it is not Chlorophyllum molybdites!
Chlorophyllum olivieri.taste: mild (Siegel), mild, nutty, (Breitenbach), pleasant (Phillips), not remarkable (Sieger)
Chlorophyllum olivieri.odour: "mild or pleasantly earthy" (Siegel), faintly like raw potatoes, (Breitenbach), strongly aromatic (Phillips), not remarkable (Sieger)
Chlorophyllum olivieri.habitat: in troops, arcs, and rings (occasionally single), "mostly in rich leaf litter and forest humus in disturbed areas, usually producing large flushes in fall and early winter", (Siegel), single to gregarious "in coniferous forests, more rarely in hardwood forests, sometimes also in parks or gardens", summer to fall, (Breitenbach), "woods and shrubberies of all kinds, often with conifers"; summer to late fall, (Phillips), litter under hardwoods, (Sieger), from oak habitats in the Pacific Northwest, spruce and deciduous woods in Europe, (Vellinga)

Chlorophyllum rhacodes.nameOrigin: As Vittadini did not publish an etymology, we have to guess his meaning - two possible roots for the epithet are the Greek words 'rhakos (rag) and rhachos (bush, quickset hedge); the derivations and transliterations of these can be spelled as 'racodes', 'rhacodes', 'rachodes', and 'rhachodes', (Vellinga(20))
Chlorophyllum rhacodes.edibility: edible and choice, but sickens some people, (Sieger), there are reports of severe gastrointestinal reactions to Chlorophyllum from regions where Chlorophyllum molybdites does not occur, (Benjamin), make sure it is not Chlorophyllum molybdites!
Chlorophyllum rhacodes.odour: not remarkable (Sieger), reminiscent of raw potatoes (Breitenbach)
Chlorophyllum rhacodes.habitat: grows in both natural and man-made habitats, (Vellinga(3)), solitary to gregarious or grouped outside forests, "in gardens, parks, meadows, etc. on humus- and nutrient-rich soils or compost heaps", summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Chromosera citrinopallida.habitat: on tundra-like bank, 5000 foot elevation in Washington, September to October, (Hesler), on soil among short turf and mosses, especially dwarf scrub, and at the edges of bogs, (Buczacki), fall

Chromosera 'cyanophylla'.habitat: single, scattered or cespitose [in tufts] on exposed white-rotted, wet, coniferous wood (often cut ends and sides of logs or branches) on the forest floor, (Redhead), scattered, gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on decaying wood of balsam, fir, or hemlock, spring and fall, (Smith), scattered or in groups on decaying conifer wood, especially balsam fir and hemlock, May to October, (Bessette for northeastern North America), spring, summer, fall

Chroogomphus albipes.habitat: single or scattered to densely gregarious or clustered "in duff under conifers (especially fir and pine)" in mountains, often buried or half-buried in humus layer, summer and early fall, (Arora), single to cespitose under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), (Smith)

Chroogomphus leptocystis.habitat: from 2500-4500 feet, under Pinus monticola (Western White Pine) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), and mixed conifers; generally fruiting from September through late October, (Miller), fall

Chroogomphus loculatus.nameOrigin: means 'loculate', referring to the locules in the spore-bearing surface
Chroogomphus loculatus.habitat: beneath soil surface associated with various Pinaceae species, particularly Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), at 1400 meters elevation, October, (Castellano), type single to mostly cespitose [in tufts] with fused stems, under Tsuga mertensiana at 1400m, (Miller(6))

Chroogomphus ochraceus.taste: pleasant (Miller(14)), mild (Miller(1) as C. rutilus), indistinct (Desjardin)
Chroogomphus ochraceus.odour: not distinctive (Miller(14)), none (Miller(1) as C. rutilus), indistinct (Desjardin)
Chroogomphus ochraceus.habitat: single to abundant, only under conifers, especially pines; summer and fall, (Miller(14)), on ground in needles and moss under conifers, (Miller(1) for C. ochraceus), single to scattered, occasionally gregarious, on ground under conifers especially Pinus (pine), August to November, (Miller(1) as C. rutilus), under pines in association with Suillus fuscotomentosus (Desjardin for California), Chroogomphus spp. are thought to be parasitic on the mycelia of boletes and in the Redwood Coast of California, Chroogomphus ochraceus appears associated with Suillus fuscotomentosus in three-needle pine habitat, (Siegel).

Chroogomphus pseudovinicolor.spores: "greenish to smoky-olive to blackish (occasionally lacking olive tinge)", (Arora), green ("elm green", "roman green", to "dark grayish olive"), (Miller(5)), olive-green to smoky gray-brown with a greenish cast (Bessette)
Chroogomphus pseudovinicolor.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups (often in small clumps) on ground under conifers, (Arora), single to cespitose [in tufts], usually not more than 3 fruiting bodies from a common base, under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine) at 2500-4000 foot elevation, September to October, (Miller(5)), single to commonly cespitose in twos or threes, under Douglas-fir or Ponderosa Pine, (Bessette), fall

Chroogomphus tomentosus.edibility: yes, but better dried than fresh, (Arora)
Chroogomphus tomentosus.habitat: single to widely scattered or gregarious under conifers, late summer through early winter, (Arora), on needles or in deep moss under conifers, late August to late October, (Miller(1)), summer, fall, winter

Chroogomphus vinicolor.spores: "smoky-gray to smoky-black, sometimes with an olive tinge", (Arora)
Chroogomphus vinicolor.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious, under conifers especially Pinus (pine), (Arora), single to gregarious or sometimes cespitose [in tufts], recorded under nine different species of pine, other conifers have also been in many habitats; fruiting August to early October, (Miller(1)), summer, fall

Chrysomphalina aurantiaca.habitat: gregarious on conifer logs; fruiting "usually in September and October, rarely in November and December" (Bigelow), "scattered, in groups or small clusters on decaying conifer wood and adjacent duff", September to December, (Bessette), typically in fall, but can also fruit in spring (Trudell), spring, fall, winter

Chrysomphalina chrysophylla.spores: yellow ("pinkish buff" to "warm buff") in var. chrysophylla but in variety salmonispora light salmon tinted (light "salmon buff", "ochraceous salmon"), unknown in var. hoffmanii, (Bigelow), off-white, buff to pale pinkish buff (Siegel)
Chrysomphalina chrysophylla.odour: not distinctive (Bigelow for var. chrysophylla and var. hoffmanii, Phillips(1)), not distinctive or odor fragrant (Bigelow for var. salmonispora)
Chrysomphalina chrysophylla.habitat: gregarious on conifer logs, usually July and August in eastern North America, but through October in the Pacific Northwest, (Bigelow for var. chrysophylla), scattered or in clusters on rotting coniferous logs and moss, May to September, (Phillips(1)), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller)

Chrysomphalina grossula.nameOrigin: 'grossula' is diminutive form of 'grossa' which means 'big, coarse, thick'; 'wynniae' after Welsh mushroom collector Mrs. Lloyd Wynne
Chrysomphalina grossula.spores: whitish in thin deposits, creamy white on paper, may appear very slightly greenish when deposited on glass
Chrysomphalina grossula.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on water-soaked conifer wood, bark chips, conifer debris (occasionally on hardwood mixed with colonized conifer wood), in mixed forests or parks, (Norvell), fruiting in fall (Castellano), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Claudopus byssisedus.habitat: "scattered to gregarious on various substrates and always in protected and humid areas, on underside of rotting logs of conifer or hardwoods, inside rodent holes", beneath moss-covered banks; fruiting summer to fall (July to November) and in central California January to March, (Largent), on rotten wood or on soil in woodland areas, also recorded as occurring on subterranean fungi and in plant pots, (Watling), summer, fall, winter, spring

Claudopus 'parasiticus'.habitat: collection on Cantharellus subalbidus (Spurr), "on rotten wood, and vegetable debris, naked soil and putrescent fungi", including Polyporus squamosus, Coltricia perennis, and Cantharellus cibarius, (Watling for Britain), similar collection on Cantharellus roseocanus (Aarnaes), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Cleistocybe gomphidioides.nameOrigin: means 'like a nail' or 'like a Gomphidius', gomphos = nail (Greek), eidos = similar (Greek)
Cleistocybe gomphidioides.habitat: single to gregarious under conifers, mixed conifers and Alnus (alder), or gregarious on wet soil under Oplopanax horridus (devil's club), August to October, (Ammirati), summer, fall

Cleistocybe vernalis.habitat: single or clustered "on soil at edge of dirt road and on sloped road bank, in mixed conifer forests", spring (late April to mid-May)

Clitocybe adustiterricola.habitat: type gregarious on burned earth, November, (Bigelow), fall

Clitocybe albidula.habitat: gregarious under pine or in mixed woods, September, October, December, (Bigelow), fall, winter

Clitocybe albirhiza.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious or in clusters or rings, on ground under conifers, especially in spring shortly after snow melts, (Arora), scattered to gregarious or cespitose [in tufts], often in arcs or rings, under Picea (spruce), especially Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce), Larix (larch), and Pinus (pine), June, July, (Bigelow), in groups or dense clusters under conifers on mountains, between 2000m and 3000m, (Phillips), spring, summer

Clitocybe alnicola.habitat: on soil and humus under Alnus (alder)

Clitocybe americana.spores: pale pinkish cream ("pale pinkish buff" in Ridgway(1)), (Bigelow), white (Buczacki)
Clitocybe americana.habitat: usually gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts], sometimes single or scattered, on or near hardwood logs (especially birch, maple, beech), sometimes on buried wood, summer (July and August usually, sometimes in September), (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe angustifolia.habitat: scattered, gregarious, or cespitose [in tufts], under or near conifers, August to October, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe arvalis.habitat: gregarious on ground in cultivated field, October - November, (Bigelow), fall

Clitocybe avellaneifolia.taste: mild or when old sometimes disagreeable
Clitocybe avellaneifolia.odour: mild or when old sometimes nauseous
Clitocybe avellaneifolia.habitat: on moss or needles under conifers, September and October, (Bigelow), fall

Clitocybe badioferruginea.habitat: type gregarious on soil and humus near conifer log in swamp, September, (Bigelow), fall

Clitocybe brunneocephala.spores: pale rosy buff (Ridgway(1) "pale pinkish buff"), (Bigelow), rosy buff or dull pinkish (Arora)
Clitocybe brunneocephala.edibility: edible but "Be sure not confuse with poisonous Entolomas", (Arora), edible and excellent (Desjardin)
Clitocybe brunneocephala.odour: pleasant but not like Clitocybe nuda (Bigelow), "mild or pleasant" (Arora), slightly fragrant (Desjardin)
Clitocybe brunneocephala.habitat: gregarious, "sometimes in rings", "in lawns and pastures"; December to March, (Bigelow), "mainly in lawns and pastures, but also at the edges of woods or under trees", (Arora)

Clitocybe caperata.habitat: type gregarious under conifers, July, (Bigelow), summer

Clitocybe catervata.spores: "pale pinkish buff", "pale vinaceous buff", "pale vinaceous fawn", "pale pinkish cinnamon", (Bigelow, colors from Ridgway(1))
Clitocybe catervata.taste: usually not distinctive (recorded once as disagreeable)
Clitocybe catervata.habitat: single, gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts], often in arcs; under conifers, rarely under hardwoods

Clitocybe cereoceps.nameOrigin: means 'waxy head', referring to waxy appearance of cap
Clitocybe cereoceps.habitat: gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), October, (Bigelow), fall

Clitocybe cerussata.odour: mild (Bigelow(5)), strong, with somewhat floury component (Moser), faint or a bit sweet (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Clitocybe cerussata.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts], in arcs, under Picea (spruce) or Pinus (pine), (Bigelow(5)), coniferous and hardwood forest, woody meadows, (Moser), in coniferous or mixed forest in deep moss (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)

Clitocybe coacta.habitat: type gregarious on humus in mixed woods, July, (Bigelow), summer

Clitocybe concava.nameOrigin: means 'concave' presumably referring to deeply concave cap
Clitocybe concava.habitat: gregarious on needles under conifers, October, (Bigelow), fall

Clitocybe coniferophila.habitat: gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] on needle beds under Pinus (pine) or Picea (spruce)

Clitocybe crassa.habitat: under Picea (spruce), June and July, (Smith), scattered or gregarious, in open stands of spruce, June and July, (Bigelow), summer

Clitocybe crenulata.habitat: gregarious on soil and moss, June and October, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe deceptiva.edibility: yes, best as flavoring agent, make sure each specimen smells like anise, (Arora)
Clitocybe deceptiva.odour: fragrant and anise-like when fresh, (Arora), anise (Bigelow), sweet-scented bedstraw (Gallium triflorum), (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Clitocybe deceptiva.habitat: scattered to gregarious in damp places under conifers, (Arora), gregarious under conifers, most frequently in September and October, in northern California in December, (Bigelow), and on lawns, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), fall, winter

Clitocybe diatreta.spores: cream color to ivory color, thin deposits appear white
Clitocybe diatreta.taste: not distinctive but strongly fungoid at times
Clitocybe diatreta.odour: not distinctive but strongly fungoid at times
Clitocybe diatreta.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts], in arcs, under conifers, frequently pine, rarely under aspen and birch; summer to fall (late August to November), (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe ditopa.taste: farinaceous to nauseous farinaceous, (Bigelow), rancid, floury, (Buczacki)
Clitocybe ditopa.odour: farinaceous to nauseous farinaceous, (Bigelow), unpleasant, markedly mealy-floury but with sweet features, (Buczacki)
Clitocybe ditopa.habitat: on soil under conifers (pine), October, (Bigelow), usually in small groups, often +/- tufted; on needle litter or on soil with grasses and mosses in conifer woods, occasionally with hardwoods; fall, (Buczacki)

Clitocybe epigaea.nameOrigin: means 'on earth', referring to habitat on soil
Clitocybe epigaea.habitat: gregarious on wet soil, July, (Bigelow), summer

Clitocybe fragrans.edibility: yes but avoid due to similar poisonous species, (Phillips)
Clitocybe fragrans.habitat: scattered, in groups or in clusters under hardwoods, (Phillips), scattered or gregarious, sometimes subcespitose [more or less in tufts], under hardwoods or in mixed woods, late July into September usually, December in California, (Bigelow), and on lawns (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), spring, summer, fall, winter, (Buczacki)

Clitocybe gilvaoides.habitat: gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] under conifers (spruce), September and October, (Bigelow), grassy woods, bushes (Moser for Europe), fall

Clitocybe glacialis.habitat: single, scattered or in small groups on ground under conifers (particularly spruce and fir), usually near melting snow, (Arora), "has always been found associated with melting snow along snowbanks", (Miller), cespitose under spruce, near melting snow, April to August, (Phillips), spring, summer

Clitocybe glutiniceps.habitat: on moss or needles under conifers (pine), September and October, (Bigelow), fall

Clitocybe gracilis.habitat: gregarious on moss over rock, August to October, (Bigelow), grassy woods, spruce woods, also old sites of fires (Moser for Europe), summer, fall

Clitocybe griseifolia.habitat: usually single, on humus in woods, October, (Bigelow), fall

Clitocybe leopardina.nameOrigin: means 'like a leopard' referring to the spotted cap margin

Clitocybe leptoloma.nameOrigin: means 'with a delicate margin', lepte = fine, delicate (Greek), loma = margin (Greek)
Clitocybe leptoloma.spores: [unknown, most likely white since gills said to be white]
Clitocybe leptoloma.taste: not distinctive or nutty and pleasant (Bigelow)
Clitocybe leptoloma.habitat: single, gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts], on logs, August, (Bigelow), on decaying wood (Bessette), summer

Clitocybe madefacta.habitat: type gregarious under Tsuga (hemlock) and Pinus (pine)

Clitocybe martiorum.nameOrigin: refers to Mr. and Mrs. Marti who collected the species in Switzerland
Clitocybe martiorum.taste: farinaceous or rancid farinaceous when crushed or cut; disagreeable in old caps
Clitocybe martiorum.odour: farinaceous to rancid farinaceous when crushed or cut; pungent or sometimes fragrant in intact caps
Clitocybe martiorum.habitat: scattered to gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on needle beds under conifers (pine, spruce, yew, hemlock)

Clitocybe maxima.taste: usually not distinctive, occasionally slightly farinaceous, (Bigelow)
Clitocybe maxima.odour: "mild or rather unpleasant" (Arora), usually not distinctive, occasionally rather rancid, (Bigelow)
Clitocybe maxima.habitat: single or in groups or fairy rings on ground in woods or clearings, especially in mountains, (Arora), single, scattered, gregarious, occasionally subcespitose [more or less in tufts], on leaves and humus under hardwoods (beech, birch, maple) in eastern North America, "under aspen, alder, or sometimes conifers in western North America"; August and September, sometimes July or October, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe metachroa.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts], on needles under conifers (pine) usually (one collection on debris under Robinia), (Bigelow), fall to winter (Buczacki)

Clitocybe mitis.habitat: single to scattered, gregarious, or subcespitose [more or less in tufts], on needle beds under spruce or larch; July and August, (Bigelow), summer

Clitocybe multicarpa.spores: white or (one collection) pale pinkish buff
Clitocybe multicarpa.habitat: scattered, gregarious, or cespitose [in tufts], on conifer needles (spruce, pine, hemlock), once on sand; July and August, (Bigelow), summer

Clitocybe murina.habitat: type on needle bed under conifers, September, (Bigelow), fall

Clitocybe mutabilis.habitat: scattered to gregarious on soil and needles under conifers, occasionally in mountains meadows or at edges of snow banks, May-July, September, October, (Bigelow), spring, summer, fall

Clitocybe nebularis.spores: pale buff to yellowish, (Arora), pale yellow (Bigelow)
Clitocybe nebularis.edibility: yes if thoroughly cooked, flavor poor, (Arora), may cause allergic upset, (Lincoff(1)), take care to distinguish from Entoloma species
Clitocybe nebularis.taste: usually disagreeable, sometimes sour or slightly farinaceous, rarely mild, (Bigelow)
Clitocybe nebularis.odour: rancid and disagreeable, likened to rancid flour, rotting cucumbers, skunk cabbage, mice cages, beer barf, (Arora), usually disagreeable, sometimes sour or slightly farinaceous, rarely mild, at times recalling skunk, (Bigelow)
Clitocybe nebularis.habitat: scattered to gregarious under trees, often in rings, (Arora), single, scattered or gregarious on ground under coniferous trees, (Bigelow), summer and fall (Miller), may be parasitized by Volvariella surrecta in some areas (Lincoff(2)), late fall and winter (Bacon for Europe), summer, fall, winter

Clitocybe obsoleta.odour: fragrant and sweet (like Hydnellum suaveolens but not strongly of anise)
Clitocybe obsoleta.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] under conifers, late July to October, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe odora.spores: pinkish cream or buff (Arora), "pale pinkish buff" becoming darker and more ochraceous when old, (Bigelow)
Clitocybe odora.edibility: yes, best used as flavoring agent because of strong taste, (Arora)
Clitocybe odora.odour: strongly fragrant anise-like, at least when fresh, (Arora), anise (Bigelow)
Clitocybe odora.habitat: scattered or in groups in woods, (Arora), gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] under conifers, July into December, (Bigelow), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Clitocybe pallidipes.habitat: type gregarious on wood, late August, (Bigelow), summer

Clitocybe patelliformis.nameOrigin: means 'in the form of a pan'
Clitocybe patelliformis.habitat: gregarious or occasionally cespitose [in tufts], in arcs under conifers, October to December, (Bigelow), fall, winter

Clitocybe payettensis.habitat: gregarious on moss and algae on wet rocks, June, (Bigelow), summer

Clitocybe 'phyllophila'.spores: cream color or pinkish, (Bigelow), pale ochraceous clay, (Phillips)
Clitocybe 'phyllophila'.taste: "mild except in old specimens which become rancid and unpleasant", (Bigelow), mild, becoming unpleasant when old, (Phillips)
Clitocybe 'phyllophila'.odour: "strong, sometimes without crushing flesh", "a pungent or spicy fragrance (not anise)", (Bigelow), strong, sweet, (Phillips)
Clitocybe 'phyllophila'.habitat: gregarious or cespitose [in tufts], often in arcs, in needle beds of pine, less commonly in mixed woods of pine and birch; September and October, (Bigelow), "in groups or dense clusters among leaf litter and pine needles in mixed woods", (Phillips), fall

Clitocybe profundidisca.habitat: on soil in open or under conifers, July, October, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe pseudodicolor.habitat: gregarious on needle beds under conifers, September into late November, (Bigelow), fall

Clitocybe pseudomarginella.habitat: gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] on needles under conifers, once under alders near conifers, July into October, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe pungens.nameOrigin: means 'sharp, acrid, piercing, biting', probably referring to pungent odor
Clitocybe pungens.odour: of green corn husks and pungent
Clitocybe pungens.habitat: gregarious on soil under conifers, late June, July, (Bigelow), summer

Clitocybe ramigena.habitat: single, scattered, or gregarious, on moss, mossy logs and stumps of conifers and hardwoods, sometimes on humus, May through August, (Bigelow), spring, summer

Clitocybe rivulosa.edibility: poisonous and potentially fatal to children (muscarine producing profuse sweating, salivation, diarrhea, etc.), (Arora)
Clitocybe rivulosa.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in rings, in pastures and grassy areas, often with Marasmius oreades, (Arora), scattered or gregarious, sometimes in arcs or rings, in grass in the open (lawns and pastures), August into October, (Bigelow), also in open places in the woods, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), summer, fall

Clitocybe robusta.spores: pale yellow ("ivory yellow", "cartridge buff" Ridgway(1) colors)
Clitocybe robusta.taste: rancid or merely disagreeable, rarely mild
Clitocybe robusta.habitat: scattered, gregarious or sometimes cespitose [in tufts], "on humus, in open hardwoods or under conifers"; August into October, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe salmonilamella.habitat: single "or in small groups of single or paired fruitbodies on small-diameter woody debris, especially on decaying live oak branches buried in duff (also in surrounding humus)"; "fall and early winter", (Siegel(2)), scattered, gregarious, or subcespitose [somewhat tufted], on wood debris, (Bigelow)

Clitocybe sclerotoidea.nameOrigin: refers to the tissue mass (sclerotium) from which it grows
Clitocybe sclerotoidea.habitat: typically in small tight clumps on ground under Pinus (pine), small aborted fruitbodies often present, occasionally large single fruitbodies may be found; winter and spring [for Arora's area of California]; may be parasitic on Helvella lacunosa, since the sclerotium is composed of hyphae from both species, (Arora), cespitose on moss and needles under Pinus; usually in September to December, but recorded in May, June, July, (Bigelow), spring, summer, fall, winter

Clitocybe senilis.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts], usually under conifers, sometimes under hardwoods or in mixed woods, June through August, (Bigelow), summer

Clitocybe smithii.nameOrigin: presumably after Alexander Smith who collected type
Clitocybe smithii.habitat: gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts], on ground under conifers (spruce and fir)

Clitocybe sparsivestita.nameOrigin: means 'sparsely clothed', probably referring to pubescence on stem that is not dense

Clitocybe squamulosa.habitat: scattered, gregarious or cespitose [in tufts], usually on needle beds under conifers, "but at times under alder or in open on road shoulders", frequent from late June through August, rarely in September and October, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe subcanescens.habitat: gregarious on needle beds under conifers (pine, hemlock, cedar), September and October, (Bigelow), fall

Clitocybe subclavipes.habitat: single, scattered or gregarious on humus in hardwoods, rarely on needles under conifers, June into November, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe subditopoda.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts], often in arcs or fairy rings, on needle beds under Pinus (pine) or Picea (spruce), rarely under hardwoods; usually September, (Bigelow), can occur late in to the fall (Trudell)

Clitocybe subsocialis.habitat: gregarious under conifers, June, December, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe tenuissima.taste: not usually distinctive but single collections noted with slight taste ("slightly sour and disagreeable", "like elderberry bark")
Clitocybe tenuissima.odour: not usually distinctive but single collections with slight odors ("slightly penetrating", "like a fresh tomato leaf")
Clitocybe tenuissima.habitat: scattered, gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts], under conifers (pine, spruce), most frequently in September and October but sometimes in late July and August, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe thujana.habitat: gregarious under conifers (Thuja), August, October, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe truncicola.spores: "white usually, rarely faintly cream in heavy deposit" (Bigelow), white (Phillips, Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Clitocybe truncicola.odour: not distinctive (Bigelow, Phillips), faintly or strongly aromatic, like Japanese oranges, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Clitocybe truncicola.habitat: usually scattered or gregarious, rarely single or subcespitose [more or less in tufts], on hardwood logs and stumps (one record on cedar log), (Bigelow), scattered or in groups, on hardwood stumps and fallen trunks, August to September, (Phillips), fall, (Buczacki), summer, fall

Clitocybe umbrinipes.nameOrigin: means 'umbrinous foot', refers to dark gray brown lower stem
Clitocybe umbrinipes.habitat: type gregarious in mixed woods or conifers and aspen, October, (Bigelow), fall

Clitocybe variabilis.habitat: gregarious under conifers (spruce, fir, pine), sometimes in conifer woods mixed with alder, August to early November, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Clitocybe vermicularis.habitat: single or gregarious on needles under conifers, June, (Bigelow), summer

Clitocybe vibecina.odour: farinaceous (Bigelow), aromatic, of sweet scented bedstraw (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), mealy (Courtecuisse)
Clitocybe vibecina.habitat: scattered, gregarious, or cespitose [in tufts], on leaves or needles, under conifers or hardwoods, usually in September and October, but also recorded in July, (Bigelow), coniferous woods (Moser for Europe), under spruce, fall, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), mainly in damp coniferous woods (Courtecuisse), summer, fall

Clitocybe violaceifolia.habitat: the collection found in winter (on decaying wood in January), (Bigelow), winter

Clitocybula abundans.habitat: on logs and stumps of either conifers or hardwoods, August and September, (Bigelow), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller), cespitose [in tufts] on logs or stumps of conifers, (Lennox), summer, fall

Clitocybula familia.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on logs and stumps, usually on conifer wood, but occasionally on hardwood; August and September, rarely October, (Bigelow), in large clusters on coniferous logs, August to October, (Phillips), summer, fall

Clitocybula lacerata.habitat: scattered, gregarious, or subcespitose [more or less in tufts], on logs of conifers (spruce) or hardwood (oak, birch), sometimes on soil or attached to buried wood, (Bigelow), scattered to gregarious on logs or stumps of conifers or hardwoods (oak or birch), (Lennox), generally clustered, more rarely single, primarily on rotten conifer wood, in forests, in places where wood is chopped, along forest edges, on stumps. branches or sawdust, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Clitocybula oculata.habitat: type solitary in low woods, probably attached to buried wood

Clitopaxillus alexandri.habitat: single, scattered or gregarious, on ground under conifers, September and October, (Bigelow), fall

Clitopilus aureicystidiatus.habitat: single or scattered under conifers, October, (Baroni), fall

Clitopilus hobsonii.habitat: on stumps, logs, twigs, old bracket fungi, herbaceous stems and other plant debris, (Watling), rotten wood under hardwoods or conifers, (Courtecuisse), single to gregarious on remains of dead wood or plant materials such as branches, bark, grasses, herbs, etc., spring, summer, fall, (Breitenbach), late summer, fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)

Clitopilus nuciolens.spores: a dingy "light vinaceous-cinnamon", "vinaceous-cinnamon", or light "mikado brown" (colors from Ridgway)
Clitopilus nuciolens.odour: "not distinct or fragrant" [syntax ambiguous, and Baroni describes gills as "not forked or intervenose" so that "neither distinct nor fragrant" would not be expected here if fragrant odor was being excluded: the species name suggests a nutty odor], (Baroni), Murrill(1) says "having the odor of walnuts in dried specimens" and when Singer(18) studied the type in 1942, the odor of walnut was still evident; O. Ceska (pers. comm) says may be slightly farinaceous
Clitopilus nuciolens.habitat: cespitose [in tufts], gregarious, or single "in humus, sandy soil or on decaying wood" under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood), Abies (fir), or Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), summer, fall, winter, (July to February)

Clitopilus prunulus.nameOrigin: means 'little plum', prunulus is diminutive of prunus = plum (Latin)
Clitopilus prunulus.edibility: yes, but not recommended: too easy to confuse with poisonous species, (Arora)
Clitopilus prunulus.odour: "strongly but pleasantly farinaceous (like sweetbread)", (Arora), "strongly mealy, of bread dough or cucumber", (Phillips)
Clitopilus prunulus.habitat: single to scattered or in small groups, "on ground in open woods and grassy places near trees", (Arora), sometimes in rings (Courtecuisse), summer and fall (Miller), in conifer as well as hardwood forests (Trudell)

'Collybia' bakerensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Baker' after Baker National Forest in Washington, where type was collected
'Collybia' bakerensis.odour: not distinctive (Desjardin(3)), aromatic, sweet and pleasant, (Kirkwood), mild (Smith)
'Collybia' bakerensis.habitat: scattered to gregarious on fallen conifer logs, typically on Tsuga (rarely Picea), July-October, in California typically on bark of Abies May-July, (Desjardin(3)), scattered on fallen logs in moist river basins, (Kirkwood), type single on conifer log (Smith), spring, summer, fall

Collybia cirrhata.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "fringed" or "frayed" from the stem base, (Lincoff(1))
Collybia cirrhata.habitat: gregarious on remains of old mushrooms, in woods among dead leaves, summer and fall, (Lincoff), gregarious on blackened fungus remains, on rich humus, or well decayed wood in conifer and hardwood forests, July to September, occasionally November, (Halling), summer, fall

Collybia cookei.nameOrigin: after Cooke, who illustrated it as Collybia cirrhata
Collybia cookei.habitat: gregarious on blackened fungus remains, in rich humus, or on well decayed wood in mixed conifer-hardwood forests, July to early October, (Halling), on much decayed mushroom remains, appearing as a black tarry substrate, gregarious to somewhat cespitose [in tufts], usually abundant, (Lennox), summer, fall

Collybia tuberosa.odour: none (Halling), not distinctive (Phillips), sweet or fungoid, (Lennox)
Collybia tuberosa.habitat: on blackened remains of decaying mushrooms, particularly larger Russula and Lactarius, (Arora), gregarious on blackened fungus remains (agarics, polypores, hydnums and boletes), occasionally on humus of conifers and hardwoods, (Halling), scattered to subcespitose [more or less in tufts], generally abundant, on hard tarry pad of much decayed mushroom, (Lennox), summer and fall (Miller)

Collybiopsis californica.habitat: scattered to gregarious on "on senescent leaves or decayed wood" of Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), in oak woodlands, January to March, (Desjardin(9) but habitat may be extended by other observations); Petersen(31) showed that the fruiting season is longer - the BC collection was 8.X.1992, and California collections were 12.I.1978, 11.XI.2008, and 15.XI.1999.

Collybiopsis confluens.nameOrigin: 'confluens' is Latin for the place 2 streams meet, but probably refers to clustered habitat
Collybiopsis confluens.spores: whitish to cream-colored (Halling), white or tinged yellow (Arora)
Collybiopsis confluens.edibility: with caution: tough and similar species have not been tested, (Arora), edible but worthless (Phillips)
Collybiopsis confluens.odour: mild, rarely with slight alliaceous odor, (Halling), odd, distinctive ?buggy, (Phillips), initially cyanic then garlicky, (Lincoff(1)), curious aromatic odor that is quite pleasant (Kibby)
Collybiopsis confluens.habitat: gregarious but sometimes cespitose [in tufts] "on humus, decayed leaf litter in mixed forests, conifer forests, or hardwood forests", (Halling), gregarious, "often in tufts or clusters, on ground in woods", (Arora), summer and fall (Miller)

Collybiopsis eneficola.nameOrigin: En = N; ef = F (NF = abbreviation for Newfoundland); + -icola = dwelling in, or with a preference for
Collybiopsis eneficola.habitat: single, gregarious, or cespitose; might be inferred as decaying deciduous leaves and small twigs, favoring Betula (birch); collected from Mixed woods, (Betula, Abies balsamea, Picea, Larix; sometimes dominated by Betula, and no record without Betula), "fruiting mid-August through early November" (Petersen), "scattered to caespitose on thick duff, in mixed woods", (Williams, Joanne)

Collybiopsis luxurians.habitat: gregarious, but often cespitose [in tufts], rarely single, "on rotten wood, wood chips, or on lawns (buried wood?)"; June to September, (Halling), occurs in a variety of urban and suburban habitats including flower beds with wood chips and in lawns around the roots of trees; usually in large conspicuous clusters, but can be single or in small groups, (Trudell), summer, fall

Collybiopsis peronata.taste: acrid (peppery), (Halling), +/- burning sharp (Moser), at first mild, then pepper-hot, (Breitenbach, Trudell), bitter (but see NOTES above) (Hansen)
Collybiopsis peronata.odour: none (Moser), of vinegar when rubbed (Courtecuisse), pleasantly spicy (Breitenbach), often pleasantly spicy (Trudell)
Collybiopsis peronata.habitat: in mixed woods on leaf litter and woody debris; early summer to fall, (Trudell), usually in clumps on leaves or conifer needles, (Moser), on dead leaves and needles (Hansen), in woods (Courtecuisse), single to gregarious and cespitose [in tufts] in hardwood and coniferous forests, "on leaves and needles, especially common among beech leaves", (Breitenbach)

Collybiopsis subpruinosa.nameOrigin: means 'somewhat pruinose', probably referring to the cap, which in the Latin description is "sub lente minute pruinoso"
Collybiopsis subpruinosa.odour: indistinct (Desjardin(6)), mild to strongly fungal, like Marasmius oreades, (Desjardin(7))
Collybiopsis subpruinosa.habitat: scattered to clustered "in humus-rich soil and woody debris", "late summer through fall in coastal forests", (Desjardin(6) for California)

Collybiopsis vaillantii.habitat: found on senescent sheaths of Carex (sedge) and on senescent leaves of Juncus (rush), also on twigs of Alnus rubra (Red Alder) and in Ontario on Salix nigra (Black Willow), (Redhead), in southern Appalachian Mountains grows both in wetland environments on leaves of ferns (Osmunda) and grasses (Carex) or on twigs or bark of Alnus and Salix, and in drier forests on twigs or bark of Fagus (beech), Liriodendron (tuliptree), Platanus (sycamore), Pinus (pine), and Tsuga (hemlock), (Desjardin), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Collybiopsis villosipes.habitat: scattered in troops or clusters, occasionally single, "in duff under conifers or in wood chips", often in disturbed areas

Connopus 'acervatus'.nameOrigin: acervatus means "in a bundle or sheaf"
Connopus 'acervatus'.spores: white to pale cream (Halling), white (Arora, Miller)
Connopus 'acervatus'.edibility: not edible: said to bitter when cooked and slightly poisonous to some, (Arora)
Connopus 'acervatus'.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on decaying wood or rich humus in conifer forests or mixed woods, (Halling), in compact bundles or clusters "on rotting conifers (but often appearing terrestrial)", (Arora), late summer and fall (Miller)

Conocybe aberrans.habitat: on rotting conifer logs, June, (Smith), summer

Conocybe apala.spores: ocher-brown (Hallen), reddish brown or cinnamon (Arora), sienna tinged rust (Watling), rust-brown (Breitenbach)
Conocybe apala.habitat: scattered or in troops in grass, (Arora), in grassy areas, parkland, gardens and meadows, (Watling for Britain), late spring, summer, fall (Miller)

Conocybe aurea.habitat: can occur abundantly in commercial compost applied in home landscaping, (Trudell), usually "gregarious in gardens, in flower boxes, on humus- and nutrient-rich soils", summer, (Breitenbach)

Conocybe brunnea.habitat: on rich humus and debris under hardwoods, spring, (Smith), "on base rich soils, amongst herbaceous debris and under herbs" in woodland clearings or wet depressions, by roadsides, etc., (Watling(1) for Britain), typically terrestrial but has been collected on wood, (Watling(6)), fall, (Buczacki)

Conocybe cyanopus.nameOrigin: means "blue foot", kyanos = deep blue (Greek), pous = foot (Greek)
Conocybe cyanopus.edibility: probably moderately to highly hallucinogenic, 0.33-1.01% psilocybin, 0-0.007% psilocin, 0.12-0.20% baeocystin, beware of similar Galerinas that may be poisonous, (Stamets)
Conocybe cyanopus.habitat: scattered in grassy areas in lawns and fields, summer and fall, (Stamets), scattered on moss and in grass (Smith)

Conocybe 'dumetorum'.habitat: single or in small groups "amongst herbaceous debris and calcareous rubble, or in the dykes of limestone pavement", frequently on worm casts or lightly attached to old stems of Mercurialis perennis (dog's mercury) "or small fragments of woody debris in base rich soils", (Watling), on ground in woods, rotting wood, etc., (Moser)

Conocybe fibrillosipes.habitat: type among herbaceous debris in conifer woodland

Conocybe filaris.edibility: poisonous, has been reported to contain the same deadly amanitins as Amanita phalloides and Galerina autumnalis, (Stamets)
Conocybe filaris.habitat: "on rich clayey soil especially in woodlands in limestone areas, edges of paths, in parks etc.", (Watling), scattered to gregarious "in decayed wood substratum, in wood or bark chips, or on newly laid lawns and grassy areas that rest on buried wood", (Stamets), in grass or on wood chips, July to October, (Phillips), summer, fall

Conocybe fimicola.habitat: gregarious on manure in spring, (Smith), gregarious on mature pile of dung, May, (Watling), spring

Conocybe flexipes.habitat: scattered on avalanche debris, fall, (Smith), on "moss, decaying wood and detritus from herbaceous plants and shrubs, site of old avalanche", (Watling)

Conocybe pinguis.habitat: gregarious on rotting logs of alder and maple, spring and early summer, (Smith), gregarious on old rotten logs (Alnus or ?Acer), May, (Watling)

Conocybe rugosa.habitat: "on soil on pathsides in gardens and parks, usually on disturbed soil near human habitation", also from greenhouses, (Watling for Europe), usually fall, sometimes spring, (Buczacki)

Conocybe smithii.edibility: probably hallucinogenic, up to 0.80% baeocystin, beware of Galerinas
Conocybe smithii.habitat: scattered to numerous in moss and about sphagnum bogs, and in damp places, (Stamets), scattered "in various habitats including swampy areas, cool bogs, mossy logs, moist soil, or under dense cover and often associated with mosses", also in lawns; late spring, summer, and perhaps early fall, (Ammirati)

Conocybe stercoraria.habitat: scattered on horse dung, spring and early summer, (Smith), on horse dung in May, on dung in September, (Watling), spring, summer, fall

Conocybe 'tenera'.spores: sienna tinged rust (Watling), rust-brown (Breitenbach), bright yellow or reddish-brown, (Phillips), red-brown (Miller)
Conocybe 'tenera'.edibility: no (Phillips), unknown but similar filaris poisonous (Arora)
Conocybe 'tenera'.habitat: "scattered to numerous in grass in lawns, fields, and woods", May to July, September, (Phillips), in grass, in gardens, parks, etc., and along pathsides in woods and copses, (Watling for Britain), spring and summer, occasionally in fall, (Miller)

Conocybe tenera.spores: rusty brown or cinnamon brown (Arora), yellow- to red-brown (Phillips for Conocybe tenera)
Conocybe tenera.edibility: unknown but similar Conocybe filaris poisonous
Conocybe tenera.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious "on lawns, in gardens, fields, rich soil, dung, and humus"

Contumyces rosellus.nameOrigin: means 'little rose' and implies pink color
Contumyces rosellus.odour: faintly of geraniums or Philadelphus lewisii (mock orange)
Contumyces rosellus.habitat: on soil among mosses, moist shady sites in spring, (Redhead(55)), single or in small groups, on soil "among grass, lawns, pastures, woodland, also dunes", fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Coprinellus disseminatus.edibility: not worthwhile (Arora), reported as edible, but cooks down to almost nothing, can be used as a means of flavoring other dishes, (Smith)
Coprinellus disseminatus.habitat: densely gregarious "on or near decayed wood and debris, or on buried wood", usually in woods or grassy areas, (Arora), crowded, "on or near old stumps or other dead wood", spring, summer, and fall, (Smith), "in large groups (sometimes hundreds) on stumps and debris of deciduous wood and on lawns and grassy areas", May to October (November to March in southern California), (Phillips), spring, summer, fall, winter

Coprinellus domesticus.habitat: scattered in troops or in small clusters, occasionally single, "fruiting on or near rotten hardwood logs, stumps, or woody debris in early fall or spring", on the east coast of North American commonly fruits in wet basements

Coprinellus flocculosus.habitat: scattered in troops, small clusters, or occasionally single, on wood chips; fruiting "throughout wet season, but generally in larger flushes in spring or early fall"

Coprinellus micaceus.habitat: gregarious, usually in clusters, "on wood or woody debris, around stumps, or on roots or buried wood", (Arora), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller), "in large groups and clusters on hardwood stumps, buried roots, and other organic debris", (Trudell), spring, summer, fall, winter, (Buczacki)

Coprinopsis atramentaria.spores: deep brownish black to almost black (Van De Bogart), black (Arora)
Coprinopsis atramentaria.edibility: edible but reacts with alcohol, it "contains a disulfiram-like compound (coprine) that reacts with alcohol in the body to produce acetaldehyde", which in turn produces "reddening of the ears and nose, a metallic taste in the mouth, lightheadedness, rapid heart beat, a throbbing sensation, and sometimes nausea and vomiting", (Arora), symptoms occur 5-10 minutes after alcohol ingestion by a person who has eaten the inky caps a half hour to three days previously: sensation of warmth, flushing, and possible swelling of the face, sensation of tingling in arms and legs, nausea and vomiting, metallic taste in mouth, fast heart beat and palpitations, severe headache, sweating, anxiety, vertigo, confusion, low blood pressure, collapse, (Benjamin)
Coprinopsis atramentaria.habitat: single or in loose groups of several to many or in dense cespitose clusters, usually on soil and frequently near rotting wood, and especially partly buried rotten wood, rarely directly on rotting wood, (Van De Bogart), scattered to densely gregarious or in massive clumps in cultivated areas, lawns, gardens, roadsides, on or around old stumps, etc., (Arora), summer and fall (Miller), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Coprinopsis brunneistragulata.nameOrigin: means 'with brown covering'; '"stragulum' is Latin for "blanket, pall, covering" and 'stragulus' means 'spreading or covering' (Brown, R.W.(1)); the species has been respelled 'brunneistrangulatus" by some authors who perhaps guess that 'strangulatus' was meant, in reference to constricted hyphae in the universal veil
Coprinopsis brunneistragulata.habitat: single, terrestrial, on moist shaded lawns

Coprinopsis canoceps.habitat: scattered "on debris in rich soil under alder and cottonwood"

Coprinopsis cinerea.spores: deep brownish black to soot black
Coprinopsis cinerea.habitat: single or in loose clusters, on wood to seemingly terrestrial (?from buried wood), "on soil, forest litter, wood chips, hardwood sticks, twigs, and stumps", (Van De Bogart), mainly fall (Buczacki)

Coprinopsis depressiceps.habitat: type single or in small clusters, on soil around a willow tree in mixed forest, terrestrial or sublignicolous

Coprinopsis friesii.habitat: in small groups, "a few together, generally on grasses" (Ulje), on leaf litter of Typha and Carex in Ontario, on unspecified monocots in Quebec, in wet fields or temporary pools; in Europe reported on senescent Trifolium, Lupinus, Chenopodium, Arctium, Robinia, Carex and various grasses, from Morocco on Phragmites and Juncus, (Redhead), on dead grass (Hansen, L.), on dead grass stalks, reeds, etc., (Moser), on decaying grass debris, rotting rush culms, rarely on soil among grass, mainly summer, (Buczacki)

Coprinopsis kubickae.habitat: herbaceous material in wetland habitat including salt marsh, the synonymized C. amphibius described from wood in alkaline lakes, (Redhead(13))

Coprinopsis lagopides.habitat: single or in small groups, terrestrial to seemingly wood-dwelling: on soil, woody debris, or most often on rotting stumps of Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple); Orton's European description emphasizes burnt soil, and Van De Bogart's collections of var. trisporus were on burnt soil

Coprinopsis lagopus.habitat: single, scattered, or in dense troops, on woody debris, leaf litter, burned areas, dung, manure, wet straw, etc., (Arora), fall

Coprinopsis marcida.habitat: type single "on a piece of wood buried in a thick moss carpet on the floor of a coniferous forest", September, (Van De Bogart(2)), fall

Coprinopsis nivea.spores: "very dark chocolate brown, almost black", (Ulje), black (Breitenbach)
Coprinopsis nivea.habitat: single or a few together; on dung of horses and cattle, (Ulje), single to gregarious "on manure of various animals, especially on cow pies and horse manure"; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), on old dung, (Hansen, L.), May to November (Bacon), spring, summer, fall

Coprinopsis pachyderma.nameOrigin: means 'thick-skinned', referring to the exceptionally thick walls of most of the cells of the universal veil
Coprinopsis pachyderma.habitat: type in loose groups on an open compost pile of rotting wood chips and sawdust, October, (Van De Bogart), fall

'Coprinopsis' phaeospora.habitat: on plant remains and earth (Moser), on plant debris on soil, (Hansen), on senescent grass leaves in wet pasture (Redhead(9)), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Coprinopsis picacea.nameOrigin: could be from 'pica', Latin for magpie
Coprinopsis picacea.odour: gas-like, similar to Tricholoma inamoenum or like creosote, (Breitenbach), unpleasant (Phillips), strong, unpleasant, naphthalene, halitosis, (Buczacki)
Coprinopsis picacea.habitat: single to gregarious in hardwood forests, "on soil among leaf litter, preferentially on damp, humus-rich, calcareous soils", summer to fall, (Breitenbach), single or in small groups, +/-tufted, (Buczacki)

Coprinopsis pinguispora.nameOrigin: means 'fat-spored' referring to nearly round spores
Coprinopsis pinguispora.habitat: type sublignicolous [somewhat wood-dwelling] on clay soil at the base of alder tree, in large cespitose clumps

Coprinopsis psychromorbida.habitat: on necrotic or senescent parts of herbaceous plants usually in arid areas

Coprinopsis romagnesiana.nameOrigin: presumably after Henri Romagnesi, the French mycologist
Coprinopsis romagnesiana.habitat: cespitose around roots of old trees, (Watling), +/- clustered; occurs "on and around stumps or dying trees, or growing from buried wood", (Laessoe(3))

Coprinopsis stercorea.habitat: single, scattered, or in small troops "on relatively fresh dung", mostly dung of grazing animals, but also bear and dog scat; "throughout wet season, generally soon after soaking rains following a dry period", "fruitbodies can come and go in less than a day"

Coprinopsis striata.habitat: single or in small groups, on duff in conifer forest

Coprinopsis strossmayeri.odour: fungoid; rhizomorphs "with strong unpleasant smell resembling mould"
Coprinopsis strossmayeri.habitat: in very large clusters (up to several dozens of fruitbodies) on rotten wood of hardwoods in forests and parks

Coprinopsis sylvicola.habitat: small, loose groups, "on leaves and debris among chunks of rotten conifer wood lying on the soil in an old second-growth mixed forest", May, (Van De Bogart), spring

Coprinopsis tectispora.habitat: type single or in loose clusters on soil mix in a greenhouse, March, (Van de Bogart), spring

Coprinopsis uliginicola.habitat: single in swampy areas under brush or on decayed aspen wood, especially around beaver ponds

Coprinopsis undulata.habitat: in large clusters, terrestrial or subcoprophilous on prepared compost

'Coprinus' alnivorus.habitat: type on hard, scarcely rotted wood of Alnus sp. in hardwood rainforest

'Coprinus' alutaceivelatus.nameOrigin: means 'leather-like veil', referring to tan veil color
'Coprinus' alutaceivelatus.habitat: type loosely clustered, on soil and conifer needle duff, October, (Van De Bogart), fall

'Coprinus' arachnoideus.nameOrigin: refers to spider and presumably the webby veil
'Coprinus' arachnoideus.habitat: type single, terrestrial, "on prepared soil mixes in a greenhouse"

Coprinus asterophoroides.nameOrigin: means 'like [Coprinus] asterophorus', 'asterophorus' means 'bearing a star' referring to star-shaped universal veil remnant on cap, which also occurs in asterophoroides
Coprinus asterophoroides.habitat: type "terrestrial, on sandy soil in dry open sagebrush area", August, (Van De Bogart), summer

'Coprinus' bubalinus.habitat: type single or in small clusters, on walnut and mulberry slash

Coprinus colosseus.habitat: in large, loose clumps on loose, crumbly soil in dense, brushy, scrub hardwood forest, type found in May, (Van De Bogart), spring

Coprinus comatus.edibility: delicious, may rarely react with alcohol like C. atramentarius, (Arora)
Coprinus comatus.odour: faint odor of mushrooms (Van De Bogart)
Coprinus comatus.habitat: single to clumped or even densely cespitose [in tufts], "terrestrial, on lawns, by roadsides, along trails, near compost heaps, and occasionally in forested areas, always on soil", (Van De Bogart), sometimes single "but more often scattered to densely gregarious or in loose clumps on hard ground and grassy areas, rich or disturbed soil etc.", (Arora), most commonly in early spring and late fall, (Miller), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

'Coprinus' fimetarius.spores: "soot black or deep purplish black or deep brownish black"
'Coprinus' fimetarius.habitat: single to loosely clustered, coprophilous or subcoprophilous, on herbivore dung and rotting hay and straw

Coprinus palmeranus.habitat: type "on clay soil in open grassy maple woods", October, (Van De Bogart(1)), fall

Coprinus roseistipitatus.habitat: on rabbit or deer dung in moist hardwood rainforest, substrate covered with a thin but persistent white felt-like mycelium, type found in October, (Van De Bogart), fall

Coprinus spadiceisporus.habitat: type on deer or rabbit dung

Coprinus umbrinus.habitat: single, on horse dung in open pasture

Coprinus xerophilus.habitat: single or in groups of scattered individuals, "terrestrial, on sandy or gravelly soil in dry to semiarid areas"

Cortinarius aavae.nameOrigin: "This species is named after our daughter Aava." (Niskanen(1))
Cortinarius aavae.habitat: in conifer-dominated forest, the type specimen from Quebec collected under Betula (birch) and Tsuga (hemlock)

Cortinarius absarokensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Absaroka' referring to Absaroka Wilderness in Montana where type found
Cortinarius absarokensis.odour: odorless or with slight fruity smell
Cortinarius absarokensis.habitat: under willow in Montana, (Moser(5)), subalpine in North Cascades (Moser(7))

Cortinarius acutovelatus.habitat: associated with conifers (spruce) in damp areas

Cortinarius acutus.odour: weak, iodoform-like, more distinct on drying, (Brandrud), radish when crushed, (Stuntz), iodine (Miller)
Cortinarius acutus.habitat: coniferous forests (Brandrud for Europe), on the ground in swampy places and mixed woods, (Kauffman for New England), conifer woods (Stuntz), summer and early fall (Miller)

Cortinarius ahsii.nameOrigin: "of A.H.S." being the initials of prominent mycologist Dr. Alexander H. Smith: the species was published with a collection of papers dedicated to him on his seventieth birthday
Cortinarius ahsii.taste: not distinctive, but variant forms occur with acrid [peppery] to radish-like or bitter taste, (McKnight), "not distinctive, fungoid", (Ammirati)
Cortinarius ahsii.odour: "lacking or faint and aromatic", (McKnight), "lacking or faint and aromatic" (Ammirati)
Cortinarius ahsii.habitat: single to subcespitose [more or less in tufts], on soil and forest litter in conifer forests, early spring to summer, does not fruit under snowbanks but begins early in succession that follows snowbank fungi, (McKnight), single to gregarious or cespitose in "soil and litter of conifer forests", fruiting "in early spring and summer, associated with snowbanks, but also found shortly after snow melt", (Ammirati)

Cortinarius alboambitus.nameOrigin: refers to the white edge of the cap (Niskanen)
Cortinarius alboambitus.habitat: fruiting in coniferous forests; found at least in fall

Cortinarius alboglobosus.nameOrigin: "The name refers to the affinity to C. niveoglobosus and to the white color" (Niskanen)
Cortinarius alboglobosus.odour: in gills, "indistinct or somewhat fruity", (Niskanen), slight or penetrating-earthy (Kauffman), varies mild to earthy (Stuntz)
Cortinarius alboglobosus.habitat: "In Europe, Eastern North America, Eastern side of the Rocky Mountains, and in British Columbia in mixed forests, presumably associated with Betula. In Western North America, in Washington in coniferous forests"; fruits in fall, (Niskanen), under pine, spruce, and fir, (Kauffman).

Cortinarius albonigrellus.habitat: associated with dwarf alpine Salix (willow), (Kernaghan), usually gregarious on dwarf-shrub heaths among low mosses and near Salix herbacea (dwarf willow), summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Cortinarius albosericeus.nameOrigin: name base "on white thinly sheathing veil" of stem and cap
Cortinarius albosericeus.habitat: in mixed forests of Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), or of Quercus garryana, Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), late fall

Cortinarius alboviolaceus.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in small clumps in forest humus, associated mainly with hardwoods, (Arora for California), deciduous forests (Brandrud for Europe), often in large numbers under beech and oak (Phillips), under conifers and hardwoods, especially beech and oak, (Bessette), late summer and fall (Miller)

Cortinarius alnetorum.taste: slightly radish-like or of cucumber rind  (Moser), mild (Buczacki)
Cortinarius alnetorum.odour: fungus-like, or freshly cut grass, or herbs (potato leaves), (Moser), when crushed geranium leaves, (Phillips), indistinct (Buczacki)
Cortinarius alnetorum.habitat: under Alnus sinuata (Sitka alder) on sandy soil and among mosses along a stream, (Moser), on soil with alder in carr, wet hardwood woodland and other wet habitats, usually in small groups, trooping or +/- tufted, fall, (Buczacki)

Cortinarius alpinus.habitat: with alpine dwarf willows (Salix reticulata, S. retusa, S. herbacea etc.)

Cortinarius americanus.habitat: mycorrhizal, on the ground under alder, (MycoQuebec), going by the name of the synonym, may be found with Sphagnum moss

Cortinarius ammiratii.habitat: "in conifer dominated forests, presumably associated with Tsuga heterophylla", fruiting in fall

Cortinarius angelesianus.nameOrigin: means 'from Angeles': type found at Mt. Angeles, WA
Cortinarius angelesianus.habitat: scattered to single on very decayed conifer wood

Cortinarius anisatus.odour: in gills "usually with a distinct smell of anise", "sometimes missing and then slightly raphanoid", (Kytovuori)
Cortinarius anisatus.habitat: in loose groups or single, "in submesic spruce forests, often on calcareous ground, but also in ordinary blueberry spruce forests, often in deep moss cover"; it "has predominantly been found in older forests, but it also grows in fairly young stands"; fruiting from early August to late September, (Kytovuori(1) for northern Europe), in mesic conifer forests with Picea (spruce), often on calcareous soil, but also in ordinary Vaccinium myrtillus Picea forests; late summer to fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe)

Cortinarius anomalodelicatus.nameOrigin: 'anomalus' for the section Anomali or the species Cortinarius plus 'delicatus' for the slender fruitbodies
Cortinarius anomalodelicatus.habitat: gregarious under Picea (spruce) "in boreal and subalpine habitats"

Cortinarius anomalovelatus.habitat: scattered or in small groups and clusters "of two to three fruitbodies on ground or on very decayed mossy logs and stumps" under Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) (Siegel)

Cortinarius anomalus.habitat: in coniferous and mixed woods, especially under birch (Phillips), single or a few together under Salix (willow) and Betula nana (dwarf birch) on Alaskan tundra, (Ammirati(10)), usually gregarious, more rarely single, in coniferous and hardwood forests, (Breitenbach), late summer to fall (Bacon)

Cortinarius 'anthracinus'.odour: mild (Kauffman), indistinct to slightly radish-like, (Siegel), none (Hoiland)
Cortinarius 'anthracinus'.habitat: on mosses, under Douglas fir and hemlock, in mountains, (Kauffman), single or scattered "in small groups on ground" in mossy conifer forest, (Siegel), in hardwood and coniferous forests, (Hoiland), often damp woods (Courtecuisse), fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius aptecohaerens.odour: "insignificant or sometimes a distinct raw (somewhat earthy-raphanoid) odor when cut (rapidly disappearing)."
Cortinarius aptecohaerens.habitat: mainly "in dry, sandy pine forests, but also in calcareous pine-spruce forests, and probably also in mesotrophic/semi-rich low-herb spruce forests".

Cortinarius armeniacus.spores: [presumably a shade of brown close to cinnamon brown]
Cortinarius armeniacus.odour: indistinct (to faintly sour), (Brandrud), mild or slightly of radish (Kauffman), slight radish (Stuntz)
Cortinarius armeniacus.habitat: coniferous forests under Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), (Brandrud for Europe), on ground in coniferous mountain forests, (Kauffman), coniferous woods (Moser(1)), in conifer forests in the mountains (Stuntz)

Cortinarius armillatus.edibility: yes, but be very cautious, (Arora), probably poisonous (Phillips)
Cortinarius armillatus.odour: in gills slightly raphanoid (Niskanen), usually slightly radish-like, (Arora)
Cortinarius armillatus.habitat: in loose groups in deciduous and mixed forests with Betula (birch), possibly also with Carpinus (hornbeam), "on damp to fairly dry, usually oligotrophic soil", and it is also common "in coniferous forests under solitary birches and in manmade habitats such as yards, parks, cemeteries and roadsides", "common in hemiboreal to subarctic zones and rare to occasional in the temperate zone"; fruiting late July to mid-October, (Niskanen for northern Europe), single or more often scattered or in groups, on ground, associated with birch (Arora), summer and fall (Miller)

Cortinarius arquatus.habitat: under conifers, in mountain forests, (Kauffman), coniferous woods, (Moser)

Cortinarius athabascus.nameOrigin: in honor of "the Athabascan family of Native American tribes" - "this species can be found throughout its range along the Pacific coast of North America", (Bojantchev)
Cortinarius athabascus.habitat: "mostly scattered, but frequently caespitose", in conifer and mixed woods, collections cited were fruiting in fall, (Bojantchev), single, scattered, or in clusters "on ground in mixed coastal forests" [in California's Redwood Coast, may occur also in Santa Cruz Mountains], fall through early winter [in former location], associated with many different conifers including Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Siegel)

Cortinarius atrocaeruleus.habitat: gregarious "in wet places in mixed forests", primarily near Salix (willow) and Betula (birch) "at montane to subalpine elevations", summer to fall, (Breitenbach(5) for Europe)

Cortinarius atrosquamosus.nameOrigin: named for the dark squamulose cap surface
Cortinarius atrosquamosus.habitat: primarily in conifer forest, but also mixed conifer-hardwood forests, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Notholithocarpus (Tanoak), Pseudotsuga, Tsuga (hemlock) and Betula (birch), "coastal to subalpine"

Cortinarius aurantiobasis.taste: not distinctive (Ammirati), not distinctive or slightly radish-like, (Trudell)
Cortinarius aurantiobasis.odour: not distinctive (Ammirati), not distinctive or slightly radish-like, (Trudell)
Cortinarius aurantiobasis.habitat: gregarious "in rich humus under conifers or on decayed conifer logs", (Ammirati), favors wet habitats with conifers, often near Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) or Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), (Trudell)

Cortinarius aureifolius.spores: [presumably a shade of brown close to rusty cinnamon]
Cortinarius aureifolius.taste: not distinctive (Ammirati(6) for var. aureifolius), slightly radish-like or indistinct (Ammirati(6) for var. hesperius and var. psammophilus)
Cortinarius aureifolius.odour: radish-like or not distinct (Ammirati(6) for all three varieties)
Cortinarius aureifolius.habitat: scattered to gregarious in sandy soil or sand (often partly buried) under pines, (Ammirati(6)), gregarious to scattered or single in sandy soil in pine, pine-hardwood areas, or near Arctostaphylos, fall and winter (September to January), (Matheny)

Cortinarius badioflavidus.nameOrigin: name based on coloration of cap and stem
Cortinarius badioflavidus.odour: "sharply fragrant to that of green corn"
Cortinarius badioflavidus.habitat: found in mixed forests, fruiting in late fall-winter and spring

Cortinarius badiovinaceus.spores: [presumably a shade of brown close to cinnamon or rust brown]
Cortinarius badiovinaceus.habitat: gregarious under conifers (Moser), gregarious under conifers, September, (Smith), fall

Cortinarius badius.habitat: on moist ground, in moss or sphagnum, in coniferous or mixed forests, (Kauffman(3)), in coniferous and mixed woods, especially under birch, September-October, (Phillips), fall

Cortinarius balaustinus.nameOrigin: 'balaustium' is the flower of the wild pomegranate
Cortinarius balaustinus.habitat: in hardwood and mixed forests with Betula (birch) and Fagus (beech), late summer to fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe), in groups, trooping, or tufted, on soil in old hardwood woodland with Betula, Corylus (hazel), and Quercus (oak), late summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Cortinarius barlowensis.nameOrigin: named after Barlow Pass, Washington, where type was found

Cortinarius bibulus.habitat: associated with Alnus (alder) species on moist and often naked soil, or in moss-mats of Mnium species, along brooks and rivers, in swamps, etc., (Brandrud for Europe), in alder bogs (Moser for Europe), under alder (Courtecuisse for Europe), under alder, September-October, (Phillips), fall

Cortinarius biformis.habitat: in small groups, non-fasciculate [not bundled]; in "boreo-nemoral to boreal and montane coniferous forests", foremost with Picea abies (European Spruce), but also under Pinus sylvestris (Scots pine) "on oligotrophic dry to moist ground", especially with blueberry, and especially in mountainous areas of northern Fennoscandia; fruiting August to October, (Lindstrom(1) in Fennoscandia)

Cortinarius birkebakii.habitat: in mixed and coniferous forests, fruiting in fall; one collection mentioned as being in soil and litter

Cortinarius bivelus.nameOrigin: means "with two veils", chosen by Fries to signify a double-annulate stem, but this character can only be observed at most in young fruitbodies, (Breitenbach)
Cortinarius bivelus.habitat: usually gregarious to slightly clustered "in hardwood and coniferous forests", primarily near Betula (birch), summer to fall

Cortinarius boreasensis.odour: "very strong and distinctive, sharp but sweet and somewhat fruity" (but totally different from C. pyriodorus)

Cortinarius boulderensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Boulder': type specimen from Boulder Creek in WA
Cortinarius boulderensis.habitat: gregarious under conifers (Smith), usually in association with the roots of various Pinaceae spp., fruiting in May and from September through November, (Castellano), spring, fall

Cortinarius bovinus.nameOrigin: means 'bovine, pertaining to cattle', bovinus = bovine (Latin)
Cortinarius bovinus.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] in Washington under hemlock in August, (Smith), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius bridgei.nameOrigin: named for William Bridge Cooke (known to mycologists as "Bridge", "who was the first mycologist to study snowbank fungi in western North America")
Cortinarius bridgei.habitat: fruiting with conifers, cespitose [tufted] to gregarious in soil and needles, "spring into early July, depending on elevation and rate of snow melt"

Cortinarius brunneifolius.habitat: mesic to dryish coniferous forests, presumably with Picea (spruce), often deep in mosses

Cortinarius brunneoalbus.nameOrigin: refers to brown and white colors of the fruitbody
Cortinarius brunneoalbus.odour: in stem base flesh "very faintly honey-like"
Cortinarius brunneoalbus.habitat: in "mossy, mesic coniferous forests" (Abies - true fir, Tsuga - hemlock); fruiting in fall

Cortinarius brunneocalcarius.nameOrigin: name refers to brown color of cap and habitat on calcareous ground (Niskanen)
Cortinarius brunneocalcarius.habitat: in conifer forests, Picea (spruce), Tsuga (hemlock), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), on calcareous ground, often in groups

Cortinarius brunneofibrillosus.nameOrigin: refers to the brown fibrillose cap surface
Cortinarius brunneofibrillosus.odour: gills and/or flesh marjoram-like or raphanoid
Cortinarius brunneofibrillosus.habitat: in oak woodland: Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), Q. agrifolia (California Live Oak), or mixed woods: Q. garryana, Abies grandis (Grand Fir) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) or Q. garryana and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine)

Cortinarius brunneotinctus.nameOrigin: "The name refers to the color changes in the fruit body" (Niskanen)
Cortinarius brunneotinctus.habitat: in coniferous forests, often in groups (clusters)

Cortinarius brunneovernus.nameOrigin: refers to brown color ("brunneo-") and fruiting in spring ("vernus")
Cortinarius brunneovernus.habitat: "often densely gregarious to subcaespitose"; in mid-elevation (650-800 meters) dry mountain conifer forests; spring, early to late May

Cortinarius brunneus.odour: not distinctive (Smith), faint, indistinctly radish-like to earth-like, (Brandrud)
Cortinarius brunneus.habitat: gregarious under Douglas-fir in Washington in September, (Smith), coniferous woods (Moser), damp conifer woods, especially Picea (spruce), sometimes hardwoods (Courtecuisse), at times can be abundant in Pacific Northwest forests "with Sitka spruce and other conifers, especially near the coast", (Trudell), fall

Cortinarius bulbosus.odour: earthy, scarcely subnauseous, (Kauffman(3)), slight earthy (Stuntz), none (Breitenbach)
Cortinarius bulbosus.habitat: under maple, birch, and conifers, in mixed forests, (Kauffman(3)), conifer forests, (Stuntz), single to gregarious in conifer forests, summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Cortinarius cacaocolor.odour: "faint but sharp and soon vanishing", (Smith), "strong, resembling rhubarb (?)" (Phillips)
Cortinarius cacaocolor.habitat: single to scattered under conifers, (Smith), September to October (Phillips), fall

Cortinarius caesiifolius.odour: foetid but soon vanishing, (Smith(22)), foetid, but evanescent and easily missed, (Stuntz)
Cortinarius caesiifolius.habitat: type was cespitose [in tufts] along the side of a road, (Smith(22))

Cortinarius caesioarmeniacus.nameOrigin: refers to the bluish tints in the fruitbodies and affinity with Cortinarius armeniacus
Cortinarius caesioarmeniacus.habitat: Mesic to damp coniferous forest (Abies balsamea, Picea) often with some Betula (birch), on calcareous ground, late summer and fall

Cortinarius californicus.taste: not distinctive (Ammirati(16)), not distinctive or slightly fungoid-raphanoid (fungus-like - radish-like), (Ammirati(7))
Cortinarius californicus.odour: not distinctive (Ammirati(16)), not distinctive or slightly fungoid-raphanoid (fungus-like - radish-like), (Ammirati(7))
Cortinarius californicus.habitat: mixed forests of Abies (fir) and Pinus (pine) and mixtures of Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Thuja (Red-cedar), Arbutus (madrone), Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), and Acer (maple) (Ammirati(16)), single or gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] in mixed hardwood-conifer and conifer forests, (Ammirati(7)), scattered under spruce and fir, fall, (Smith)

Cortinarius calopus.nameOrigin: "ionema from Greek iov = violet, nema = fibril, thread"
Cortinarius calopus.odour: fragrant sweetish, like Cortinarius calopus [which is said to be like overripe pears, here Cortinarius venustus] but not as strong, (Moser), very distinctive, fruity (as in Cortinarius pyriodorus), (Smith), strong of over-ripe pears (Stuntz)
Cortinarius calopus.habitat: type under Salix sp. (willow) but Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir) a few meters away, (Moser), scattered to gregarious under conifers (Smith)

Cortinarius camphoratus.odour: of raw potatoes (Bessette), powerful, remarkably raunchy odor of rotting meat or vegetables (Arora), strong and unpleasant, as of burnt flesh or burnt horn, (Brandrud for Europe), cold mashed potatoes and goat's cheese (Courtecuisse for Europe), very strong, unpleasant, nauseous-repulsive, goats, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)
Cortinarius camphoratus.habitat: single, scattered or in groups on ground under conifers and hardwoods, September to October, (Bessette), mainly under spruce and fir in acid, fairly moist forests amongst deep moss, (Brandrud for Europe), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius caninus.habitat: gregarious or in troops "in grassy places in coniferous forests, more rarely in hardwood forests", primarily near young Picea (spruce), summer to fall, (Breitenbach), in coniferous or broad-leaved woods, August to October, (Phillips), Picea (and Betula?) forests, open grassy places, (Hansen, L.), in coniferous and hardwood woods, (Moser), in grassy woodlands (Bon), open grassy conifer woods especially Picea (spruce), (Courtecuisse), summer, fall

Cortinarius caperatus.nameOrigin: means 'wrinkled'; the English name Granny's nightcap is a translation of a Finnish name for the mushroom according to McKnight(1), referring to the night-time hair covering commonly worn by women in the 1800s.
Cortinarius caperatus.spores: rusty brown (Arora), rust-yellow (Breitenbach), dingy-rusty to yellowish brown (Miller), ochraceous brown (Buczacki)
Cortinarius caperatus.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground in woods, (Arora), in coniferous woods, often under blueberries or huckleberries, July to September, (Phillips), summer to early fall (Miller)

Cortinarius cascadensis.nameOrigin: named after Cascade Head Experimental Forest, Lincoln Co., Oregon
Cortinarius cascadensis.habitat: gregarious on humus, on rotten wood, and on moss-covered base of hemlock trees, mixed conifer forest (hemlock, Douglas-fir, and spruce), November, (Ammirati), fall

Cortinarius casimiri.habitat: usually gregarious "in hardwood and coniferous forests as well as under shrubs, primarily near hardwoods but also near Picea" (spruce), fall

Cortinarius ceskae.nameOrigin: named for Adolf and Oluna Ceska who collected the type in the course of a long term survey of Observatory Hill in Victoria, British Columbia; there have been various linguistic opinions on what the species epithet should be according to Latin grammar using a Czech surname

Cortinarius chrysolitus.nameOrigin: Kauffman(6) specified gills as chrysolite green in the original description
