Cortinarius chrysolitus.habitat: gregarious in Sphagnum under conifers, late August to November, (Ammirati), on deep Sphagnum in swamp of balsam trees (Kauffman(6) for New York). summer, fall

Cortinarius chrysomallus.habitat: with dwarf Salix (Lamoure for Europe), shrubby and dwarf Salix (willow) and Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce) in alpine zone, (Kernaghan)

Cortinarius cinnamomeoluteus.odour: slight iodoform, (Hoiland), of radish or not distinctive (Stuntz), iodoform, radish, (Buczacki)
Cortinarius cinnamomeoluteus.habitat: under Salix (willow) or Alnus (alder), often amongst Sphagnum, (Hoiland), always under Salix (willow) on moist ground in mires, swamp forests, shrubs, riverbanks, or snow beds, (Hansen), fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius cinnamomeus.odour: "weak, of radish or iodoform", (Brandrud), slight iodoform (Hoiland)
Cortinarius cinnamomeus.habitat: boreal and montane to nemoral [woodland] zone, rather frequent in oligotrophic. acid forests under Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), but also known from hardwood forests under Betula (birch), Quercus (oak) and Fagus (beech), mainly on bare soil along paths and road borders or amongst low mosses or lichens, (Brandrud for Europe), coniferous, more rarely deciduous woods, (Moser for Europe), in wet spots under conifers (Barron), often fruiting in the spring in western North America but usually in the fall elsewhere, (Miller)

Cortinarius cisqhale.nameOrigin: means "beautiful tree" and is the word for tanoak in the language of the Kashaya/Pomo Native American people
Cortinarius cisqhale.habitat: "scattered to frequently caespitose" with up to a dozen fruitbodies, "appears to be associated solely with" Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak), "and broadly distributed throughout its range"

Cortinarius clackamasensis.odour: "of lamellae and/or context fungoid, indistinct or slightly raphanoid"
Cortinarius clackamasensis.habitat: gregarious "in deep humus under mixed conifers", Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), and Abies (true fir)

Cortinarius clandestinus.odour: "pleasant, raw potatoes, parsley, or raphanoid", (Ammirati), distinctly that of radish or sometimes slight, (Kauffman)
Cortinarius clandestinus.habitat: "from lowland to subalpine and boreal conifer forests", occurring with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Abies (true fir), Picea (spruce) or Pinus (pine), in boreal forests also in mixed forests of conifers with Populus, Betula (birch) and Alnus (alder), fruiting spring through fall, (Ammirati), type among mosses under Pseudotsuga menziesii and Tsuga, (Kauffman)

Cortinarius clarisordidus.nameOrigin: the name refers to the colour of the fruitbodies
Cortinarius clarisordidus.habitat: in boreal, rich grass-herb Picea (spruce) forests, among mosses

Cortinarius clarobrunneus.odour: indistinct or slightly raphanoid, sometimes pleasant and aniseed-like, (Niskanen)
Cortinarius clarobrunneus.habitat: in dry to dryish Pinus (pine) forests, common (Niskanen(12) for northern Europe), in dry forests, often in sandy Pinus (pine) heathland, but also in mesic conifer forests, fall, (Knudsen(1) who also say it is mainly with Pinus), (Knudsen)

Cortinarius clintonianus.habitat: in conifer forests of Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), Pinus (pine) and Thuja (red-cedar) or Pinus (pine) and Abies (true fir), sometimes with Populus and Betula (birch)

Cortinarius collinitus.habitat: coniferous forests (Kauffman), in wet acidic spruce forest, usually in Sphagnum, primarily montane, summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), in some years can be very common in mid-elevation to high elevation coniferous forests, (Trudell)

Cortinarius colymbadinus.habitat: gregarious to cespitose in mixed conifer forests, fruiting from late May into September, [especially in mountains], (Ammirati), coniferous or less often deciduous woods, from May, (Moser for Europe), subalpine forest, fruiting soon after snow-melt, (Kernaghan), spring

Cortinarius comptulus.habitat: gregarious under conifers, (Smith), with Pinus (pine) and Picea (spruce), fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe)

Cortinarius croceus.odour: with a slight smell of iodoform (Hoiland), typically has a radish odor (Trudell)
Cortinarius croceus.habitat: coniferous woods, and less often hardwood woods

Cortinarius cruentiphyllus.nameOrigin: refers to the red gills; 'cruentus' means 'stained or spotted with blood', 'bloody', (Brown, R.W.(1))
Cortinarius cruentiphyllus.habitat: the type found in spruce forest, ecology in "conifer-dominated forests, in hemiboreal and southern boreal zone and in mountain areas", late summer and fall; in North America 3 collections in mixed woods of conifers and hardwoods

Cortinarius 'crystallinus'.nameOrigin: means 'crystalline, resembling crystal in appearance or quality' (Latin)
Cortinarius 'crystallinus'.taste: of cap pellicle bitter (Smith), bitter, also the cuticle, (Breitenbach), bitter in all parts (Moser)
Cortinarius 'crystallinus'.habitat: under conifers (Smith), usually gregarious in hardwood and mixed forests, primarily near Fagus (beech) and Abies (fir), (Breitenbach for Switzerland), deciduous woods (Moser)

Cortinarius cypriacus.habitat: a collection under Picea (spruce) in Washington

Cortinarius davemallochii.nameOrigin: named for Dave Malloch who collected the type in New Brunswick
Cortinarius davemallochii.habitat: in "damp conifer-dominated forests and bogs among Sphagnum, in hemiboreal and boreal zone", fruiting in late summer and fall

Cortinarius deceptivus.habitat: "on moist humus or debris, in hemlock or mixed woods", (Kauffman for eastern North America), under pines in OR (Smith(22))

Cortinarius decipiens.odour: not distinctive (Smith), none (Courtecuisse), "distinct when crushed, radishy(?)" (Phillips)
Cortinarius decipiens.habitat: gregarious under spruce (Smith collection), coniferous and deciduous woods, (Moser for Europe), in conifer woods (Phillips), fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius delibutus.habitat: coniferous and deciduous woods (Phillips, Moser in Ammirati(10)), single in mosses under Salix (willow) and Betula nana (dwarf birch), (Ammirati, from Alaskan tundra), fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius denigratus.nameOrigin: "Name based on blackening of the basidiocarps on drying"
Cortinarius denigratus.habitat: in forests of Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), April 30, and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Arbutus menziesii (Pacific madrone), April 19; spring

Cortinarius depauperatus.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] or gregarious in moist to wet habitats with conifers, including Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock); mid-August to early December, (Castellano), summer, fall, winter

Cortinarius diasemospermus.odour: "pleasant, sour-sweetish and fruity, like lemon balm when dry, not markedly like rubbed Pelargonium leaves"
Cortinarius diasemospermus.habitat: gregarious to cespitose "in hardwood forests in wet places", primarily under Fagus (beech) as well as on alpine dwarf-shrub heaths; fruiting in fall, (Breitenbach(5) for Switzerland)

Cortinarius dilutus.habitat: under pines in mountains (Kauffman), under Picea (spruce) primarily, but also in mixed woods, especially in swampy areas, and reported with other conifers, in Greenland with Salix (willow), (Kernaghan)

Cortinarius diosmus.odour: when first cut radish-like, after a few minutes fruity

Cortinarius distans.nameOrigin: 'distans' probably refers to the distant gills described by Peck
Cortinarius distans.spores: [presumably a shade of brown close to "tawny"]
Cortinarius distans.habitat: on grassy ground in pine woods, Greenbush, June, (Peck), on grassy ground, in hardwood and coniferous woods, (Kauffman)

Cortinarius distortus.habitat: very cespitose [in clusters], type under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), (Kauffman)

Cortinarius duboisensis.nameOrigin: "Named for DuBois Lake, the original name of Roland Lake in Washington, USA"
Cortinarius duboisensis.habitat: collections under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), or a mixture of those and Abies grandis (Grand Fir); fruiting in late fall

Cortinarius duracinus.odour: indistinct (Brandrud), not distinctive (Stuntz), nutty to radish when crushed (Phillips), radish-like in var. raphanicus (Moser), strongly radish-like in var. raphanicus, not striking and hot radish-like in var. duracinus, (Breitenbach)
Cortinarius duracinus.habitat: boreonemoral, boreal and montane coniferous forests, mostly in older forests, on rich, preferentially calcareous soils, mostly under Picea (spruce), but also under Abies (fir) and Pinus (pine) amongst low mosses, herbs and in needle beds; sometimes crowded-fasciculate, (Brandrud for Europe), coniferous and deciduous woods, at least in Europe (Moser), hardwood or mixed woods (Phillips)

Cortinarius elatior.odour: "strong of honey when bruised, especially towards base", (Brandrud for Europe), mild (Kauffman)
Cortinarius elatior.habitat: hardwood forests, rarely pine forests, (Brandrud), under Douglas-fir, cedar and hemlock, in higher mountains, (Kauffman), under hardwoods, (Moser)

Cortinarius eldoradoensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Eldorado', "after the Eldorado National Forest in the Central Sierra Nevada"
Cortinarius eldoradoensis.habitat: scattered to subcespitose [somewhat cespitose] under conifers in foothills and mountains in spring during or soon after snow melt, often right along banks of melting snow

Cortinarius emunctus.habitat: scattered to gregarious under mixed conifers

Cortinarius erythrinus.habitat: gregarious on bare soil in mixed woods, (Kauffman), coniferous woods (Moser), fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius evernius.odour: indistinct (Brandrud), mild (Moser(3) for Washington collection), scented, possibly of radish, (Phillips), slightly that of radish, (Kauffman), radish (Stuntz), not radish-like (Moser(1) who however describes a var. fragrans (ined.) with a radish-like odor)
Cortinarius evernius.habitat: coniferous forests, often in clusters, also recorded in birch forests, (Brandrud for Europe), in conifer woods, especially near boggy areas; August to October, (Phillips), single, scattered, or in groups, under conifers often in moss (Arora), summer, fall

Cortinarius fagetorum.nameOrigin: refers to its habitat on Fagus (beech) wood
Cortinarius fagetorum.habitat: usually gregarious on mossy wood of Fagus (beech), fall, (Breitenbach(5) for Switzerland)

Cortinarius fasciatus.nameOrigin: means 'bundled', probably referring to clustered growth habit
Cortinarius fasciatus.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on soil in trail in Washington

Cortinarius ferrugineovelatus.nameOrigin: "refers to the rusty red universal veil"
Cortinarius ferrugineovelatus.odour: odor of gills indistinct (Liimatainen), cedar wood (notes with BC collection)
Cortinarius ferrugineovelatus.habitat: in Oregon, with Pinus ponderosa, old growth forest; in Fennoscandia fruiting "in hemiboreal to boreal Picea dominated forests on calcareous soil"

Cortinarius ferruginosus.habitat: gregarious "on wet soil under brush, Joyce, Washington, Oct. 2, 1935"

Cortinarius flammeouraceus.nameOrigin: etymology not given in original description, but probably refers to vividly red brown color and the relation to other Telamonia species in Section Uracei
Cortinarius flammeouraceus.odour: odor in gills like cedar wood
Cortinarius flammeouraceus.habitat: in herb rich, mesic Picea (spruce) forests, "often on calcareous soil"

Cortinarius flavobasilis.nameOrigin: based on the "yellow" color of external stem base
Cortinarius flavobasilis.habitat: in mixed conifer forests of Abies (true fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), and/or Tsuga (hemlock), often beginning to fruit 2-3 weeks "after snow melt at higher elevations"

Cortinarius flexipes.odour: usually strong of pelargonium leaves (Brandrud), mild, (Kauffman), without special odor (Stuntz), strong of geraniums (Pelargonium), (Miller)
Cortinarius flexipes.habitat: coniferous and deciduous forests, often fasciculate [bundled], (Brandrud for Europe), among mosses, in coniferous swamps (Kauffman), under conifers, especially spruce, (Stuntz), summer and fall (Miller)

Cortinarius fragrantissimus.habitat: collections from mixed forests of Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) and Abies grandis (Grand Fir) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone); fruiting in late fall

Cortinarius fructuodorus.nameOrigin: refers to fruity odor of gills (Niskanen(3))

Cortinarius fulmineus.odour: "weak, slightly of hot baked", (Moser), mild or radish-like, (Arora)
Cortinarius fulmineus.habitat: under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), (Moser), single to widely scattered or gregarious on ground under hardwoods, (Arora)

Cortinarius fulvescentoideus.nameOrigin: refers to the affinity to C. fulvescens (Hyde(1))
Cortinarius fulvescentoideus.habitat: in mesic to moist coniferous forests with Picea (spruce) and Tsuga (hemlock), often in Sphagnum

Cortinarius fuscodiscus.spores: [presumably a shade of brown close to ochraceous tawny]

Cortinarius fuscoflavidus.nameOrigin: named "for the dark blackish to yellowish colouration"
Cortinarius fuscoflavidus.odour: slightly fungoid in gills and/or flesh
Cortinarius fuscoflavidus.habitat: mixed conifer and conifer hardwood forests, October to December

Cortinarius galerinoides.habitat: under shrubby willows (Moser), a circumpolar and alpine Salix (willow) associate, (Kernaghan)

Cortinarius gentilis.nameOrigin: means 'of the same race' or 'foreign, exotic'
Cortinarius gentilis.edibility: possibly deadly poisonous, caused damage to rat kidneys but exact toxicity not well established (Benjamin), doubtful whether it has orellanine but could be present in small quantities (Joseph Ammirati, pers. comm. 1999)
Cortinarius gentilis.taste: not distinct or fungoid or radish-like (Thorn)
Cortinarius gentilis.odour: not distinct or fungoid or radish-like (Thorn), often strong of raw potatoes (Trudell), radish-like, sometimes rubber-like (Niskanen)
Cortinarius gentilis.habitat: gregarious among mosses under conifers (Thorn), "often fruiting in groups, sometimes from well-rotted woody debris", (Trudell), in dry to mesic conifer forests with Pinus (pine) and Picea (spruce), (Niskanen), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius germanus.habitat: subcespitose [more or less in tufts] or gregarious, in moist mixed woods of pine and beech, at least for eastern North America or Europe

Cortinarius glandicolor.spores: [presumably a shade of brown close to cinnamon-brown]
Cortinarius glandicolor.habitat: gregarious under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) in Washington

Cortinarius glutinosoarmillatus.habitat: under tanoak and live oaks in California, reported from cottonwood and aspen in the Pacific Northwest; fruits in late fall to early spring in California, (Bojantchev), single or scattered "in troops or small clusters under live oak"

Cortinarius griseoviolaceus.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious under conifers

Cortinarius gualalaensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Gualala', "after the coastal city of Gualala in northern California"
Cortinarius gualalaensis.odour: somewhat spicy, especially in young fruitbodies
Cortinarius gualalaensis.habitat: mostly cespitose, of up to a dozen fruitbodies, but frequently scattered; fruits in fall under conifers (Pinus muricata in California and Pinus contorta in Oregon)

Cortinarius guttatus.odour: slightly but distinctly spicy (like marjoram, same odor as Phlegmacium percome but weaker)

Cortinarius hadrocroceus.nameOrigin: refers to the robust fruitbodies and the affinity to Cortinarius croceus, 'hadros' is Greek meaning 'stout, bulky, large'
Cortinarius hadrocroceus.habitat: in coniferous forests dominated by Pinus (pine), but also with Arctostaphylos uva-ursi (kinnikinnick) in subalpine and alpine zones; fruiting in fall

Cortinarius haematochelis.habitat: deciduous and mixed woods, at least in Europe (Moser), under conifers in WA (Smith)

Cortinarius helodes.habitat: marshy land under Alnus incana (Gray Alder), Alnus sinuata (Sitka Alder), and (Argentina) Alnus acuminata; June to October in the United States

Cortinarius helvelloides.habitat: usually gregarious in wet alder groves; summer to fall, (Breitenbach(5) for Europe), marshy land under alder spp. (Moser(13)), among sphagnum with alder, usually in small groups, trooping or +/- tufted, (Buczacki)

Cortinarius hemitrichus.habitat: single or scattered in small groups of clusters "on ground under introduced birch trees", (Siegel)

Cortinarius hinnuleocervinus.nameOrigin: "The name refers to the affinity to C. hinnuleus and to the color of the pileus." (Liimatainen)
Cortinarius hinnuleocervinus.spores: [presumably a shade of brown close to "tawny"]
Cortinarius hinnuleocervinus.habitat: in mixed forests of Picea (spruce), Lithocarpus (stone oak), (Liimatainen), gregarious under conifers (Smith)

Cortinarius hinnuleus.odour: "strongly earthy or green corn in some specimens", in others somewhat sweetish, (Moser), either slight or strong and disgusting (earthy) (Phillips), strong, earthy, (Buczacki)
Cortinarius hinnuleus.habitat: in large groups and often dense clusters with Salix arctica (willow) at 3000 to 3150m, (Moser for Wyoming), also at least some varieties with other hardwoods, conifers, (Breitenbach), fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius humboldtensis.habitat: usually occur in association with the roots of various Pinaceae spp., November and December, (Castellano), gregarious under Pinus (pine), (Ammirati), fall, winter

Cortinarius huronensis.odour: of radish, (Ammirati(9)), faintly radish-like to iodoform-like, (Breitenbach)
Cortinarius huronensis.habitat: scattered to gregarious in Sphagnum, other mosses, or in moist humus under conifers, September through November, (Ammirati(9)), usually gregarious on moors among Sphagnum, primarily near Betula (birch), more rarely near Pinus (pine); summer-fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Cortinarius idahoensis.habitat: gregarious "under conifers on humus or rotted wood, September through November", (Ammirati), single or scattered "on ground or on well-rotted wood under pine, but reported with other conifers as well"; "late fall or winter", (Siegel)

Cortinarius illibatus.habitat: usually gregarious "in coniferous and mixed forests", always near Picea (spruce), summer to fall, (Breitenbach(5) for Switzerland)

Cortinarius immixtus.habitat: type on deep mosses under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas fir) and Tsuga (hemlock) (Kauffman)

Cortinarius impolitus.habitat: under Abies lasiocarpa (Balsam Fir), along a road, often in fascicles [bundles], (Moser), gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on sandy soil among mosses in low, moist places in white pine and beech woods, (Kauffman for Michigan)

Cortinarius incognitus.habitat: scattered to gregarious "in conifer forests, often in sandy pine or pine-hardwood areas, usually September to November, less frequently from May to September", (Ammirati(20)), scattered to gregarious "in conifer and mixed forests, often in drier habitats"; fruiting in spring, summer or fall, (Ammirati(9))

Cortinarius infractiflavus.nameOrigin: refers to the affinity to C. infractus and yellowish cap (Liimatainen(2))
Cortinarius infractiflavus.odour: "very slightly of cedar wood (?) or fungaceous"
Cortinarius infractiflavus.habitat: in conifer forests under Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), (Moser), in boreal and mountainous conifer forests (Picea, Abies), (Liimatainen)

Cortinarius infractus.taste: strongly bitter (Brandrud), "bitter (at least of the skin)", (Arora)
Cortinarius infractus.habitat: hardwood and coniferous forests (Brandrud), scattered to gregarious under both hardwoods and conifers (Arora), fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius inops.habitat: with dwarf alpine Salix (willow) or Dryas (Kernaghan)

Cortinarius iodeoides.taste: of flesh mild, of cap pellicle bitter, (Kauffman)
Cortinarius iodeoides.habitat: subcespitose [more or less in tufts] among leaf-mold, often hidden by leaves, in woods of Acer (maple), Quercus (oak) etc., (Kauffman), under conifers (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)

Cortinarius iodes.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), none (Kauffman), of cuticle mild (Phillips)
Cortinarius iodes.habitat: "scattered, in groups or clusters on the ground under hardwoods: July-September", (Bessette), low woods (Kauffman), scattered under alder and fir (Smith), August to September (Phillips), summer, fall

Cortinarius ionosmus.odour: pleasantly like Viola odorata, (Breitenbach), strong of violets or violet roots (Moser)
Cortinarius ionosmus.habitat: gregarious to clustered "in montane and subalpine spruce forests", summer to fall, (Breitenbach(5) for Switzerland), mountainous and subalpine spruce woods (Moser)

Cortinarius kauffmanianus.habitat: mycorrhizal on soil under conifers (spruce, pine and fir), often on poor and acidic soil, typically in sandy pine forests, September and October

Cortinarius kranabetteri.nameOrigin: "in honor of Marty Kranabetter, fungal ecologist, British Columbia, Canada", (Dima)
Cortinarius kranabetteri.habitat: "in late successional conifer or mixed forests with Populus [genus italicized]"

Cortinarius laetus.habitat: usually gregarious "in montane coniferous forests above chalk"; summer to fall, (Breitenbach(5) for Switzerland), mountain conifer woods (Moser(1)), in Wyoming among Salix arctica (Moser(7))

Cortinarius laniger.odour: "conspicuous, radish-like, strongest when cut", (Brandrud), of geranium or mild (Phillips)
Cortinarius laniger.habitat: under conifers (Brandrud), scattered to gregarious under conifers, (Arora), fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius lapidophilus.habitat: type in New York on rocky soil in woods

Cortinarius largentii.nameOrigin: after D. Largent who collected the type
Cortinarius largentii.habitat: type under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), Q. chrysolepis (Canyon Live Oak) and Lithocarpus densiflora (Tanoak) with scattered Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone)

Cortinarius latiodistributus.nameOrigin: "refers to the wide distribution of the species", (Dima)
Cortinarius latiodistributus.habitat: in "mature and old growth mesic conifer forests", with Tsuga (hemlock) and Abies (true fir) in the Pacific Northwest; elsewhere with Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), sometimes mixed with Betula (birch)

Cortinarius lilacinocolossus.nameOrigin: refers to lilac cap color and 'colossal' size
Cortinarius lilacinocolossus.odour: "strongly of green corn, earthy, when freshly cut somewhat grass-like, but when quite fresh also a sweetish odor can be present"
Cortinarius lilacinocolossus.habitat: smaller to larger clusters in mixed forests with Pinus lambertiana (Sugar Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Lithocarpus (Tanoak), Arbutus (madrone), Arctostaphylos, Castanopsis (chinkapin), and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir)

Cortinarius lindstroemii.nameOrigin: in honor of the late "Hakan Lindstrom, a long-term mycologist with a special interest in small species of Telamonia"
Cortinarius lindstroemii.habitat: "coniferous forests, often on damp and acid habitats"

Cortinarius liquidus.nameOrigin: means 'clear, limpid, pure, unmixed; liquid; flowing, without interruption; smooth' (Latin)
Cortinarius liquidus.habitat: "in a swampy area of conifers, alders, etc.", locally abundant

Cortinarius loringii.nameOrigin: "named for Scot Loring" who collected the holotype
Cortinarius loringii.odour: sweet (fragrant), in dried collection pleasant celery odor
Cortinarius loringii.habitat: holotype in mixed woods, Quercus spp. (oak) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir)

Cortinarius lucorum.odour: "mild to more or less pungent or fungoid/raphanoid", (Matheny), "indistinct or slightly radish-like when cut", (Brandrud)
Cortinarius lucorum.habitat: scattered to gregarious, not clustered, "on soil in mixed, lowland forests", "June and September to October", likely an ectomycorrhizal associate of Populus, (Matheny), "sometimes forming small clusters"; hardwood forests, usually on grassy ground or in leaf litter, (Brandrud), deciduous and coniferous woods (Moser), summer, fall

Cortinarius luteo-ornatus.nameOrigin: means 'yellow - decorated' - "Cortinarius luteo-ornatus originally was described by Moser (1965) as a variety of C. armillatus with yellowish to brownish yellow universal veil, less vivid colors, and shorter, slightly broader spores" (Niskanen(13))
Cortinarius luteo-ornatus.habitat: often growing in groups, rarely single; in mesic to dry coniferous forests with Picea (spruce), possibly with Pinus (pine), and in subalpine Betula (birch) forests, "often on somewhat richer soil", seems to prefer well developed mesic Picea forests with a thick moss cover; fruiting mid-July to late September, (Niskanen(13) for Scandinavia, who say also that it associates with Betula in the subarctic zone)

Cortinarius malachius.odour: indistinct (Brandrud), weak, not distinctive to somewhat radish-like (Breitenbach)
Cortinarius malachius.habitat: boreonemoral to boreal and montane coniferous forests, mainly under Picea (spruce), sometimes under Pinus (pine), frequently in deep needle-bed or on moist places, (Brandrud for Europe), coniferous woods (Moser for Europe), summer to fall (Breitenbach)

Cortinarius malicorius.nameOrigin: means "pertaining to the rind of the pomegranate" (Latin)
Cortinarius malicorius.habitat: scattered to gregarious under conifers, often fruiting in moist areas, sometimes in Sphagnum; late August through November, (Ammirati(9)), summer, fall

Cortinarius mattiae.nameOrigin: in honor of Matti, child of the author

Cortinarius miniatopus.habitat: under spruce (Smith), pine woods (Moser for Europe)

Cortinarius miwok.nameOrigin: in honor "of the Miwok Native American people" - "this species can frequently be found in the Sierra Nevada areas that they inhabited"
Cortinarius miwok.odour: "slightly spicy, or moldy if surrounded by wet soil"
Cortinarius miwok.habitat: scattered to subcespitose, fruiting under conifers in California mountains in late spring and early summer during or soon after snow melt

Cortinarius mucicola.nameOrigin: 'muscicola' would mean 'living in moss': perhaps the meaning is the same here: later in the description he refers to it as musicola
Cortinarius mucicola.habitat: type found gregarious under conifers in deep moss

Cortinarius mucifluus.habitat: swampy wet areas in conifer woods, September to October, (Phillips), margins of swamps (Kauffman), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius mucosus.habitat: coniferous forests, exclusively associated with 2-needle Pinus (pine) in dry, moss or lichen dominated, nutrient poor, often sandy sites, (Brandrud), widely scattered to gregarious "in mixed woods and under conifers (particularly pine and spruce)", in Alaska under birch and willow, (Arora), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius murinascens.nameOrigin: refers to the color change of the cap in drying
Cortinarius murinascens.odour: odor of gills indistinct or slightly radish-like
Cortinarius murinascens.habitat: "in herb-rich, mesic to damp, conifer-dominated forests" presumably with Betula (birch) and Populus on calcareous soil, "more seldom in less eutrophic habitats"; possibly also associated with Quercus (oak); fruiting late summer and fall; in BC from mycorrhizal root tip of Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch) in interior cedar-hemlock forest

Cortinarius nauseosouraceus.nameOrigin: refers to similarity to Cortinarius uraceus but with strong unpleasant odor (Niskanen(3))
Cortinarius nauseosouraceus.odour: strong, unpleasant, earthy or like green corn, present even in dried specimens
Cortinarius nauseosouraceus.habitat: in conifer forests, in a variety of habitats from 200-1500 meters; fruiting in fall (from September to October)

Cortinarius nemorensis.odour: rather faint, earth-like, (Brandrud), weak musty (Moser), "unpleasant, somewhat musty-earthy", (Breitenbach)
Cortinarius nemorensis.habitat: in nemoral, boreonemoral and montane deciduous forests, (Brandrud for Europe), under hardwoods, (Moser for Europe), single to gregarious in hardwood forests, summer to fall, (Breitenbach(5) for Switzerland)

Cortinarius neofurvolaesus.odour: indistinct or slightly raphanoid, (Kytovuori), indistinct or slightly radish-like, (Knudsen)
Cortinarius neofurvolaesus.habitat: often growing in groups, although sometimes single, "common and often abundant in boreal to hemiboreal sandy pine heath forests, but also occurs in pine forests on rocky ground, and sometimes in spruce forests mixed with pines"; fruiting from late August to late October, (Kytovuori(1) for northern Europe), in mesic to dry conifer forests with Pinus (pine) and maybe also with Picea (spruce), also described as being in sandy Pinus heath forests; fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe), (Knudsen)

Cortinarius neosanguineus.nameOrigin: means 'new [Cortinarius] sanguineus', with which it has been confused
Cortinarius neosanguineus.odour: somewhat fragrant, mild or radish-like, (Ammirati), mild or faintly pleasant (Arora)
Cortinarius neosanguineus.habitat: gregarious in mixed woods, mixed conifers, and stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Ammirati), single to widely scattered or in small groups, mainly under conifers and often in beds of moss, (Arora), in coniferous forests (Pseudotsuga, Tsuga, Abies, Picea), September to November, (Niskanen)

Cortinarius nettieae.nameOrigin: named "for the late Nettie Laycock, a well-known Pacific Northwest citizen scientist and mycologist"
Cortinarius nettieae.odour: of gills and/or flesh radish-like or not distinctive
Cortinarius nettieae.habitat: "from coastal Oregon and Washington in conifer forests of Picea, Pinus, Abies, and Tsuga, from Montana in subalpine forest, with Picea, Pinus, and Abies and from Quebec under Betula with Populus, Salix, Abies, and Picea [Latin names italicized]"

Cortinarius nigrocuspidatus.nameOrigin: means 'with a black sharp point', referring to the conic umbo
Cortinarius nigrocuspidatus.habitat: under spruce and fir in mountain forests [but in Petrak's Lists Supplement reproduced in the online Index Fungorum says In silvis Piceae et Pini]

Cortinarius nymphatus.nameOrigin: name bases on the Greek word 'nymphe' meaning 'fairy', "since the species is small and elegant"
Cortinarius nymphatus.habitat: The collections from Finland were in coniferous forests (Pinus, Picea). The BC collection was in temperate coniferous rainforest (Picea sitchensis - Sitka spruce). Collections were found in the fall (September and October).

Cortinarius obtusus.nameOrigin: name means 'blunt', probably referring to umbo
Cortinarius obtusus.odour: usually radish-like or iodine-like but often faint
Cortinarius obtusus.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious on ground under conifers, especially pine and spruce

Cortinarius occidentalisagacitas.nameOrigin: "This is the sister species of C. sagacitas that occurs in western North America" (Niskanen(11)). In the description of C. sagacitas, the etymology is "The name refers to the odour of the lamellae." The odor of the lamellae of the two species is given identically as "parfume-like, somewhat remiscent of cedar wood". The Latin word 'sagacitas' refers to keenness of perception, acuteness of the senses, or shrewdness. 'occidentalis' means 'western'.
Cortinarius occidentalisagacitas.odour: in gills "strong, parfume-like [sic], somewhat remiscent [sic] of cedar wood"

Cortinarius ochropallens.nameOrigin: "The name refers to the color of the pileus." (Liimatainen)
Cortinarius ochropallens.habitat: conifer forests, producing fruitbodies in fall, (Liimatainen)

Cortinarius ochrophyllus.habitat: single to gregarious "in acidic, boggy, predominantly montane coniferous forests", primarily near Picea (spruce) and Betula (birch) among mosses, fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), in conifer forest with Picea (spruce); late summer to fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe)

Cortinarius olivaceofuscus.habitat: in rich hardwood forests, usually on calcareous soil - with Fagus (beech), Quercus (oak), Corylus (hazel), Carpinus (hornbeam), possibly Tilia (lime), more seldom in rich Picea forests (spruce); late summer to fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe), especially under Carpinus, often on calcareous soils, (Courtecuisse for Europe), in small groups, trooping or +/- tufted, on soil in hardwood woodland on acidic sites, usually with Fagus or Quercus but also with Salix (willow), fall, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Cortinarius olivaceoluteus.nameOrigin: refers to the color of the fruitbodies
Cortinarius olivaceoluteus.habitat: in coniferous and mixed forests; fruiting in spring and fall

Cortinarius olivaceopictus.habitat: gregarious to scattered in conifer or mixed woods

Cortinarius ominosus.odour: raphanoid [radish-like] to indistinctive, (Ammirati), raphanoid when cut and then of cedar wood (when enclosed in a box), (Bidaud),
Cortinarius ominosus.habitat: "found across North America with conifers in a variety of habitats, and can be common in sandy areas with Pinus"; often found with the Cortinarius croceus complex, (Ammirati), holotype on needle litter, in a wood of Abies alba with some Picea abies, (Bidaud)

Cortinarius orasericeus.habitat: cespitose, in fir forests, among needles, at high altitude

Cortinarius orichalceus.nameOrigin: presumably named for the color of the cap, 'xanthos' meaning 'yellow' in Greek and 'kephale' meaning 'head' in Greek

Cortinarius oulankaensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Oulanka, Finland', where it was first found
Cortinarius oulankaensis.habitat: "in mesic to fairly damp coniferous forests" with Picea (spruce), on calcareous soil

Cortinarius paludosaniosus.nameOrigin: "The name is derived from the synonym Cortinarius saniosus var. paludophilus."
Cortinarius paludosaniosus.habitat: in mixed forests, associated with hardwoods

Cortinarius paragaudis.odour: odor in gills slightly raphanoid (Niskanen), not distinctive (Smith(22))
Cortinarius paragaudis.habitat: "occurs in a wide range of habitats" from submesic to damp Picea (spruce) forests, dryish coniferous forests (Picea, Pinus (pine)), subalpine Betula (birch) forests and presumably also temperate Quercus (oak) forests. The most characteristic habitat is submesic to damp Picea forest. In oceanic areas it also occurs in dryish Pinus forests mixed with Betula. It is common in boreal zone, common to occasional in hemiboreal zone, occasional in subarctic zone and rare in temperate zone; fruiting late July to early October, (Niskanen, at least from northern Europe) scattered to gregarious under spruce, (Smith(22) for California), coniferous woods (Moser for Europe)

Cortinarius parkeri.nameOrigin: named for Andrew D. Parker of Metaline Falls, Washington, who provided some collections, photographs, and descriptions
Cortinarius parkeri.odour: typically strongly radish-like or rarely earthy garlicky
Cortinarius parkeri.habitat: single, gregarious or cespitose, developing in soil and litter, often partly buried, consistently associated with conifers but found in mixed forests as well, fruiting from March to April at lower elevations (120-270 m. a. s. l.) and from early May to mid-July at higher elevations (up to 1315 m. a. s. l.), (Ammirati), spring, summer

Cortinarius parvannulatus.odour: usually strong, similar to cedar wood but more unpleasant
Cortinarius parvannulatus.habitat: conifer and hardwood forests and with willows in alpine areas

Cortinarius pavelekii.nameOrigin: after Henry Pavelek who found the type, and who is a past president of the Oregon Truffling Society
Cortinarius pavelekii.odour: faint or sometimes musty - radish-like to sweet medicinal (Trappe(2))
Cortinarius pavelekii.habitat: "endemic to mature to old-growth forests or forests with an old-growth legacy of coarse woody debris, usually in mossy places", from sea level to +/- 250 meters elevation, underground in association with the roots of Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce) and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), (Trappe(2)), always underground, rarely breaking soil surface; fruiting March to June, occasionally November, (Trappe, M.(3))

Cortinarius perplexus.habitat: single or scattered "in small troops under both evergreen and deciduous oaks", (Siegel)

Cortinarius pholideus.odour: faint, sometimes distinct reminiscent of nutmeg, (Brandrud), faint, pleasant, (Phillips), not distinctive (Bessette)
Cortinarius pholideus.habitat: in hardwood forest, associated with birch, (Brandrud), in mixed woods, especially under birch, (Phillips), scattered, in groups, or cespitose [in tufts] "on the ground or on very decayed logs in conifer or mixed woods", August to October, (Bessette), summer, fall

Cortinarius piceidisjungendus.nameOrigin: "The name refers to the habitat with coniferous trees and affinity to C. disjungendus"
Cortinarius piceidisjungendus.habitat: in mesic conifer forest, late August to October

Cortinarius pinguis.edibility: unknown (Arora), not edible, it is thought, (Phillips)
Cortinarius pinguis.habitat: single to gregarious in duff under conifers especially under spruce in the mountains, (Arora), single to gregarious, rarely cespitose [clustered] (3-5) under duff or projecting through it in conifer forests in mountain areas, June to September, (Singer), September to November (Phillips), usually found in the mountains under Abies (fir), from summer into fall, (Trudell)

Cortinarius pitkinensis.nameOrigin: "refers to the place where the species was first found" (Pitkin County, Colorado)

Cortinarius politus.habitat: in rather dry mixed coniferous forests at mid-elevations to high elevations; "occurring in small groups of two to three"; fruiting "in late spring, primarily in early to mid-June"

Cortinarius privignatus.nameOrigin: from [Cortinarius] privignus and Latin natus being born from, due to the resemblance to that species
Cortinarius privignatus.habitat: uncommon in spruce forests (Soop(2) for Europe), on the ground in mesic spruce forests and young plantations; fruiting late summer to late fall, mycorrhizal, (Mycoquebec)

Cortinarius privignipallens.nameOrigin: "The name refers to the pale colors of the pileus and affinity with C. privignatus."
Cortinarius privignipallens.habitat: in mesic to damp forests with Picea (spruce) "on rich to calcareous soil", "but also on less eutrophic ground"; fruiting in fall

Cortinarius 'privignus'.habitat: under pine, fir, and hemlock, usually in mountain forests, (Kauffman), coniferous and mixed woods (Moser for Europe), hardwoods (Courtecuisse for Europe), in hemlock and mixed woods (Phillips)

Cortinarius 'psammocephalus'.nameOrigin: means 'sand head' probably referring to the texture of the cap
Cortinarius 'psammocephalus'.habitat: under hardwoods, especially Quercus (oak); late summer to fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe), usually in small groups, trooping or +/- tufted, on soil in hardwood woodland, fall, (Buczacki)

Cortinarius pseudoacutus.nameOrigin: "The species is reminiscent of C. acutus" (Liimatainen(12))
Cortinarius pseudoacutus.odour: at the stem base and in gills iodoform-like, "best observed when slightly dried"
Cortinarius pseudoacutus.habitat: in coniferous forest [presumably on the ground], Tsuga (hemlock), Pinus (pine) and Picea (spruce)

Cortinarius punctatus.habitat: under spruce and firs, in mountain forests, (Kauffman), scattered to gregarious in mixed forests, (Smith(15))

Cortinarius putorius.nameOrigin: "The name refers to the unpleasant smell of the basidiomata"; 'putor' is Latin for 'stench, rottenness'
Cortinarius putorius.habitat: in "mesic coniferous forests" (Tsuga - hemlock, Abies - true fir, Pseudotsuga - Douglas-fir, Picea - spruce)

Cortinarius pyriodorus.odour: moderately strong, penetrating, spicy in fresh specimens, of overripe pears or musty apples, but variable, not truly fetid
Cortinarius pyriodorus.habitat: type collected on deep moss, in forest of Douglas fir and hemlock, Lake Cushman, Washington

Cortinarius raphanoides.taste: acrid or subacrid [somewhat peppery], (Kauffman), slight (Phillips), somewhat acrid [somewhat peppery], (Stuntz)
Cortinarius raphanoides.odour: "slight but penetrating, more or less that of radish", (Kauffman), of radish, especially when crushed, (Phillips), distinct odor of radish (Stuntz), distinct of radish (Brandrud)
Cortinarius raphanoides.habitat: on mosses, under Douglas-fir and hemlock, in forests, (Kauffman), in mixed and conifer woods (Phillips), in Europe deciduous woods, especially birches (Moser), hardwood forest under Betula (Brandrud), fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius rarus.odour: of gills and/or flesh not distinctive or pleasant
Cortinarius rarus.habitat: a spring species in mountain conifer forests of Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), and/or Pinus (pine), sometimes mixed with Quercus (oak)

Cortinarius rigidus.odour: more or less marked (Kauffman(3)), strong, of household geraniums (Phillips), faint, agreeable (Stuntz)
Cortinarius rigidus.habitat: on mossy ground, along streams, in coniferous forests, (Kauffman(3)), coniferous woods, September to October, (Phillips), fall

Cortinarius roseobasilis.habitat: gregarious under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) or in mixed forests of Quercus garryana, Crataegus (hawthorn), and Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen); fruiting in late fall

Cortinarius roseobulbus.habitat: under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) and Lithocarpus densiflora (Tanoak)

Cortinarius roseobulliardioides.nameOrigin: "The name refers to affinity and similar appearance to C. bulliardioides." (Hyde(1) with Latin name italicized)
Cortinarius roseobulliardioides.habitat: in coniferous forests - Abies (true fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock)

Cortinarius rubellus.taste: not distinct (Thorn), slight of radish, (Smith), sweet (Lincoff)
Cortinarius rubellus.odour: "Radish/mild or radish" (Robertson), not distinct (Thorn), radish (Smith), mushroomy or slightly radish-like, (Lincoff), radish (Courtecuisse), radish (Courtecuisse)
Cortinarius rubellus.habitat: gregarious to cespitose, under second generation young to mature Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) with Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) and Acer circinatum (Vine Maple), also on very rotten moss-covered logs under Tsuga heterophylla and Thuja plicata; in BC and Washington from early July to later September, (Robertson), gregarious to cespitose in duff under Abies balsamea in the collection from Nova Scotia, subcespitose in Sphagnum under Larix laricina and Picea mariana in Ontario, and reported from wet, boggy sites in Europe, (Thorn), on humus in coniferous forest, (Smith), summer, fall

Cortinarius rufosanguineus.nameOrigin: refers to rufous-red color of fruitbodies (Adams, S.)
Cortinarius rufosanguineus.habitat: scattered "in moss and soil in alpine heath" with krummholz Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) and Vaccinium and subalpine meadows with scattered conifers - Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Tsuga mertensiana, "and an understory of Vaccinium", fruiting late summer to fall

Cortinarius rusticus.spores: [presumably a shade of brown close to cinnamon]

Cortinarius 'salor'.habitat: with hardwoods or conifers (Brandrud), gregarious in hardwood and coniferous forests, summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Cortinarius saniosus.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to discharge', sanies = pus, bloody matter, ulcer, (Latin)
Cortinarius saniosus.habitat: under Douglas fir, (Smith's record), ruts, muddy alder Alnus carr [carr is wetland site dominated by alder or willow], wood edges, a damp-loving species (Courtecuisse for Europe), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius saturninus.habitat: on ground in hardwood and coniferous forests, (Kauffman(3)), nemoral to boreal (subalpine) and montane hardwood forests, usually under Salix (willow) but also under Corylus and Populus, often clustered in fairy rings and rows, "mostly on grassy ground or on naked, clayey soils", (Brandrud for Europe), copses and coniferous woods, (Moser for Europe), fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius scandens.odour: none or slight (Kauffman), slight, similar to iodine (Phillips), pleasant, not distinctive, (Breitenbach)
Cortinarius scandens.habitat: on ground in deciduous and coniferous forests, (Kauffman), damp coniferous woods and alder bogs (Moser for Europe), under conifers, September to October, (Phillips), usually gregarious in forests or parks under Picea (spruce) in wet places, according to literature also in alder swamps; summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Cortinarius scutulatus.habitat: on sandy ground in woods (Kauffman), single to gregarious "in wet places on moors near hardwoods and conifers", summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Cortinarius seidliae.odour: in stem base flesh "indistinct, faintly iodoform-like or sweet", (Ariyawansa)
Cortinarius seidliae.habitat: in "mesic, mossy coniferous forests" (Pseudotsuga - Douglas-fir, Tsuga - hemlock, Abies - true fir), late summer to late fall, (Ariyawansa)

Cortinarius septentrionalis.nameOrigin: means 'northern' after the seven bright stars of 'Septentriones', the big dipper
Cortinarius septentrionalis.habitat: with Betula (birch) including Betula nana, late summer to fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe)

Cortinarius smithii.nameOrigin: named in honor of A.H. Smith
Cortinarius smithii.odour: none or not distinctive (Ammirati(7)), mild or slightly radish-like (Arora)
Cortinarius smithii.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious or scattered under conifers or in mixed woods, (Ammirati), late summer and fall (Miller)

Cortinarius solis-occasus.habitat: gregarious in montane coniferous forests near Picea (spruce) and Abies (true fir), summer to fall, (Breitenbach(5) for Switzerland)

Cortinarius sommerfeltii.nameOrigin: named in honor of Soren Christian Sommerfelt, "one of the first Norwegian botanists investigating fungi", (Hoiland)
Cortinarius sommerfeltii.habitat: the greater part of 37 Nordic collections occurred in shady, damp Picea (spruce) forests, (Hoiland), usually gregarious "in spruce forests on needle litter or among mosses", fruiting in fall, (Breitenbach)

Cortinarius sordidemaculatus.nameOrigin: means 'with sordid spots' or 'sordid with spots'
Cortinarius sordidemaculatus.odour: indistinct, a little reminiscent of Cortinarius brunneus
Cortinarius sordidemaculatus.habitat: in loose groups or single, usually in older forests, "grows in boreal to hemiboreal, submesic spruce forests, especially on rich or calcareous ground, but also occurs in ordinary blueberry spruce forests"; "late July to early October"

Cortinarius species^.spores: rusty brown to cinnamon brown or ochraceous tawny

Cortinarius sphagnoravus.nameOrigin: "The name refers to the color of the pileus and damp habitat." (Liimatainen), "sphagno-" refers to Sphagnum and "ravus" is Latin for "gray".
Cortinarius sphagnoravus.habitat: in "mesic to damp hemiboreal, boreal and mountainous coniferous forests"

Cortinarius spilomeus.taste: mild, slightly radish-like, (Breitenbach), faint, pleasant or indistinct, (Buczacki)
Cortinarius spilomeus.odour: sweetish, unpleasant, (Breitenbach), faint, pleasant or indistinct, (Buczacki)
Cortinarius spilomeus.habitat: gregarious to almost clustered, in coniferous forests of hills and mountainous areas near Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), and Betula (birch); summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), coniferous woods and with Betula (Moser for Europe), single or trooping and +/- tufted, on soil in hardwood and mixed woodland with Betula, Quercus, or Pinus, summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Cortinarius squarrosus.habitat: among vegetation on the ground, in woods

Cortinarius stemmatus.habitat: under alder and Douglas-fir in Washington, (Smith), usually gregarious in conifer or mixed forest, (Breitenbach)

Cortinarius stuntzii.nameOrigin: after Daniel Stuntz, professor at the University of Washington
Cortinarius stuntzii.habitat: scattered to gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] on sand dunes or occasionally soil with Salix exidua and S. rigida

Cortinarius subacutus.spores: [presumably a shade of brown close to cinnamon]

Cortinarius subbalaustinus.habitat: especially with Betula (birch) (Moser for Europe), gregarious, often in fairy rings at the edge of moors and on heaths on dry soil near Betula, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), on soil with hardwoods, especially Betula and Quercus (oak) on acidic sites, fall, usually in small groups, trooping or +/- tufted, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Cortinarius subcagei.habitat: in coniferous forests, fall, type found in spruce-dominated forest on sandy soil, among mosses

Cortinarius subcuspidatus.nameOrigin: refers to the 'almost cuspidate (sharp or pointed)' cap
Cortinarius subcuspidatus.spores: [presumably a shade of brown to tawny]
Cortinarius subcuspidatus.habitat: gregarious on or around rotting conifer logs (Smith)

Cortinarius suberi.nameOrigin: the species appears to have named in memory of Nils Suber
Cortinarius suberi.habitat: in calcareous Picea (spruce) forests among Vaccinium (in Sweden), (Soop(3)), while var. suberi grows Pinus forests as well, var. brunneogriseus is exclusively encountered with Pinus, (Soop(4)).

Cortinarius subexitiosus.nameOrigin: refers to the affinity with C. exitiosus
Cortinarius subexitiosus.habitat: in "conifer dominated, mixed forests (Tsuga, Picea, Pseudotsuga, Abies, Populus, Salix)"; fruiting in fall

Cortinarius subfloccopus.habitat: in mesic to damp conifer forest with Picea abies (Norway Spruce) or Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), late August to early October, (Niskanen), summer, fall

Cortinarius subnotatus.habitat: on the ground in mixed forest

Cortinarius suboenochelis.nameOrigin: sub- (near) plus -oenochelis, referring to the affinity with Cortinarius paragaudis ssp. oenochelis (a synonym of Cortinarius luteo-ornatus)
Cortinarius suboenochelis.habitat: mesic to dryish coniferous forests mostly with Picea (spruce), but perhaps also with Pinus (pine), "often on somewhat richer soil"; usually grows in groups, but also singly; fairly common (Scandinavia) in the boreal zone, in the hemiboreal zone it seems to be occasional or rare; fruiting September to October

Cortinarius subpurpureus.spores: [presumably a shade of brown close to ochraceous tawny]

Cortinarius subrufulus.nameOrigin: refers to the affinity to Cortinarius rufulus
Cortinarius subrufulus.habitat: in mixed forests - Pinus (pine), Picea (spruce), and Salix (willow); fruiting in fall

Cortinarius substriatus.habitat: type collected on moss, under Douglas-fir and hemlock, (Kauffman)

Cortinarius subtilior.habitat: usually gregarious on dwarf-shrub heaths among Salix herbacea on siliceous soil in alpine areas in summer, (Breitenbach(5) for Switzerland)

Cortinarius subtortus.taste: mild to slightly bitterish or with bitterish aftertaste, (Smith), bitter, unpleasant, (Buczacki)
Cortinarius subtortus.odour: faintly pungent but hardly distinctive, (Smith), incense or cedar wood (Moser for Europe), Russian leather (mixed with pencil wood), (Courtecuisse for Europe), pleasant, incense, cedar wood, (Buczacki)
Cortinarius subtortus.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] "under conifers, especially around very decayed stumps and logs", (Smith), coniferous, more rarely deciduous woods, (Moser for Europe), sphagnum, under conifers, especially Picea (spruce), more often in mountains, (Courtecuisse for Europe), fall (Buczacki)

Cortinarius subvalidus.habitat: spruce woods, at least in Europe

Cortinarius tenebricus.habitat: usually gregarious in dwarf-shrub communities among Salix and Dryas octopetala, alpine, summer

Cortinarius tenuifulvescens.nameOrigin: "The species looks like a slender C. fulvescens" (Hyde(1), Latin name in italics)
Cortinarius tenuifulvescens.habitat: found in "dry to mesic coniferous forests, in northern Europe often on sandy soil, one collection from spruce-hardwood swamp"; in BC found in mossy detritus

Cortinarius testaceofolius.habitat: in coniferous forests, usually with Picea (spruce), sometimes with Pinus (pine), often deep in mosses, late summer to fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe)

Cortinarius thiersii.nameOrigin: after Prof. H.D. Thiers, San Francisco State University, who first collected it from California
Cortinarius thiersii.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious under conifers, June to August, (Ammirati), summer

Cortinarius tillamookensis.nameOrigin: refers to Tillamook County where the species was first found
Cortinarius tillamookensis.habitat: in Pinus (pine) forests, often on sandy soil; in fall

Cortinarius tortuosus.habitat: usually gregarious in wet, moss-rich coniferous forests near Pinus (pine) and Picea (spruce), primarily among Sphagnum; summer to fall

Cortinarius traganus.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to goats', referring to the smell as recorded in Europe
Cortinarius traganus.edibility: poisonous according to one source and indigestible according to another (Arora)
Cortinarius traganus.taste: a touch bitter (Phillips), sweet (Lincoff(1)), not distinctive or slightly bitter (Bessette(2)), bitter (Miller)
Cortinarius traganus.odour: "strong, especially on the gills, fruity and characteristic", (Brandrud), often faintly pungent or sweet, (Arora), strong, of overripe pears, (Phillips), strong, pungent, sometimes faint, described as either pleasant or unpleasant, (Lincoff(2)), strong, penetrating smell of billygoat or acetylene, sometimes fruity, (Lincoff(1)), strongly of acetylene (pear liqueur) (Courtecuisse), pungent and pleasant or disagreeable (Bessette(2), Miller), usually fairly strong, pungent penetrating odor, some forms have spicy or fragrant odor, like overripe pears, (Ammirati(1)), fruity but hard to detect for some people (Trudell), strong, unpleasant, sweet sickly, chemical, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)
Cortinarius traganus.habitat: coniferous forests (Brandrud), single, scattered or gregarious (sometimes in clumps) under conifers, (Arora), summer and fall, (Miller)

Cortinarius transatlanticus.nameOrigin: refers to distribution on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean
Cortinarius transatlanticus.odour: odor in gills not distinctive or somewhat iodoform
Cortinarius transatlanticus.habitat: in coniferous forests but also with Betula (birch) at least in the subalpine areas of Europe; fruiting in fall

Cortinarius trappei.nameOrigin: named for Dr. James Trappe, "noted mycologist and the one who organized the expedition to the area where this species was collected in 1989"
Cortinarius trappei.habitat: in conifer forest, fruiting in late summer and fall

Cortinarius triformis.habitat: gregarious to grouped in hardwood and coniferous forests, (Breitenbach), under conifers especially Picea (spruce), in California with oak; often cespitose (Kernaghan), deciduous and coniferous woods (Moser), coniferous forests (Hansen)

Cortinarius 'trivialis'.edibility: said to be a good edible (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), but avoid due to identification problems
Cortinarius 'trivialis'.taste: mild (Phillips), Lincoff(1) says sweet, but not clear that this is C. trivialis J.E. Lange
Cortinarius 'trivialis'.habitat: under hardwoods, (Brandrud), "in mixed and deciduous woods, especially damp areas", September to October, (Phillips), late summer and fall (Miller), deciduous woods (Moser)

Cortinarius truckeensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Truckee', "after the town of Truckee, California in the vicinity of which this species is abundant"
Cortinarius truckeensis.habitat: "subcespitose to scattered"; fruiting under Pinus jeffreyi (Jeffrey's Pine) in California near Truckee, "under a very thick conifer duff and rarely breaks above the surface of the forest floor", most commonly, "the location of fruiting is marked by a hump that may hide a dozen or more clustered basidiomata"

Cortinarius tubarius.habitat: gregarious in Sphagnum under conifers, from mid-August to November, (Ammirati), usually gregarious on moors or in wet meadows, often among Sphagnum, mostly under Betula (birch), primarily montane; summer-fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), summer, fall

Cortinarius tuolumnensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Tuolumne', after the Tuolumne River and County in the Central Sierra Nevada
Cortinarius tuolumnensis.odour: "distinctly spicy with a hint of fruit", especially in young fruitbodies
Cortinarius tuolumnensis.habitat: often cespitose with up to a dozen fruitbodies; It appears that the preferred habitat in California is "wet montane meadows (soon after snow melt), surrounded by conifers", mostly pines like Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine); late spring and early summer

Cortinarius turgidus.odour: faint fragrant (Smith), faint, pleasant, sweetish when old, (Breitenbach)
Cortinarius turgidus.habitat: gregarious under conifers, (Smith), usually gregarious or in troops or rows, in montane to subalpine hardwood and mixed forests, primarily near Fagus (beech), (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Cortinarius turmalis.habitat: subcespitose [more or less in tufts] under conifers

Cortinarius uliginosus.taste: radish (Ammirati), radish with bitter aftertaste (Smith), not distinct or radish (Thorn), rather unpleasant, slightly astringent, (Breitenbach)
Cortinarius uliginosus.odour: radish (Ammirati), may be non-distinct (Thorn), slightly radish-like (Breitenbach)
Cortinarius uliginosus.habitat: scattered to gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] in moist areas among willows or willows and alders, July through October, (Ammirati), summer, fall

Cortinarius umbrinolens.habitat: usually "gregarious to slightly clustered in hardwood forests", primarily near Betula (birch) and Fagus (beech), also near conifers; summer to fall

Cortinarius umidicola.nameOrigin: means 'living in swamp' or 'living in damp area', umidum = swamp (Latin), umidus = damp, moist, wet, humid, (Latin)
Cortinarius umidicola.odour: not distinctive or slightly pungent to somewhat radish-like

Cortinarius uraceus.habitat: on mosses and humus, in coniferous forests (Kauffman), conifer woods (Stuntz), nemoral to boreal and montane deciduous and coniferous forest, usually under Picea (spruce) or Abies (fir), but also under Fagus (beech), (Brandrud for Europe)

Cortinarius 'valgus'.odour: strongly fungoid to somewhat radish-like (Castellano), "peculiar, gas-like, with an earth-like component" (Brandrud)
Cortinarius 'valgus'.habitat: "solitary, scattered, gregarious or cespitose, sometimes locally abundant under Abies amabilis, Picea sitchensis, Pseudotsuga menziesii, and Tsuga heterophylla", (Castellano, Latin names italicized), subalpine, boreal and boreonemoral forests, normally under Picea (spruce), but also recorded under Betula (birch) and Fagus (beech), (Brandrud for Europe), under birch and beech, (Moser for Europe)

Cortinarius vanduzerensis.nameOrigin: after place found (H.B. van Duzer Forest Wayside on Oregon coast)

Cortinarius vellingae.nameOrigin: "named to honor Else Vellinga, a mentor and inspiration to many in the mycological community", (Siegel)
Cortinarius vellingae.habitat: single or in small groups under live oak, possibly Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak), and likely continuing much further north with Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), (Siegel)

Cortinarius venetus.odour: never strongly radish-like (Moser(1)), faintly radish-like, (Breitenbach), faintly radish-like (Brandrud)
Cortinarius venetus.habitat: under spruce in montane or subalpine habitats (Kernaghan), single to gregarious in coniferous forests, primarily near Picea (spruce), (Breitenbach), boreonemoral, boreal and montane coniferous forests, rarely also in nemoral deciduous forests, associated with spruce, pine, and fir (rarely beech), (Brandrud)

Cortinarius venustus.odour: very distinctive, fruity (as in Cortinarius pyriodorus), (Smith), strong of over-ripe pears (Stuntz), strong and sweetish (Huhtinen), persistently fruity, (Knudsen), characteristic, sweetish fruity, (Laessoe)
Cortinarius venustus.habitat: scattered to gregarious under conifers (Smith for Washington), in lichen woodlands dominated by Picea glauca (white spruce), (Huhtinen from Quebec), in mesic Picea (spruce) forests and in subalpine with Betula (birch); late summer to fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe), mycorrhizal with Betula and Picea on poor soils (Laessoe)

Cortinarius vernicosus.nameOrigin: means "full of spring" (in reference to occurrence of fruiting bodies in spring); also varnished, shiny (in reference to appearance of glutinous veil on fruiting bodies when ambient conditions are dry, as commonly encountered in spring)
Cortinarius vernicosus.spores: dark yellow brown ("snuff brown" Ridgway(1) color)
Cortinarius vernicosus.habitat: single to scattered, on ground often growing in deep moss or areas of thick conifer duff, old growth mixed conifer woods, April to early July, (Seidl), spring, summer

Cortinarius vernus.taste: "mild, pleasant, somewhat astringent after being chewed a rather long time"
Cortinarius vernus.habitat: usually gregarious or in troops in coniferous and hardwood forests of hills and mountainous areas, at the edges of forests or in hedges; usually from April onward, (Breitenbach), spring

Cortinarius vinaceobrunneus.nameOrigin: name based on color of stem
Cortinarius vinaceobrunneus.habitat: under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), late fall

Cortinarius vinaceogrisescens.habitat: collections have been made in mixed forests of Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), fruiting in late fall

Cortinarius violaceus.odour: mild or cedar-like, (Arora), not distinctive (Phillips), "weak but distinct of cedar wood or leather" (Brandrud for both subspecies)
Cortinarius violaceus.habitat: single or in twos or threes under conifers, sometimes next to rotting logs, or mixed woods, in Europe said to favor hardwoods, (Arora), subsp. violaceous favors hardwoods, and subsp. hercynicus favors spruce, (Brandrud), fruiting in fall (Miller), late summer and fall (Bacon)

Cortinarius viridiflavus.nameOrigin: refers to the green and yellow colors of the fruitbodies
Cortinarius viridiflavus.habitat: in coniferous forests, fruiting in fall

Cortinarius wahkiacus.nameOrigin: named for Wahkiacus, Washington, where some of the initial material was found
Cortinarius wahkiacus.habitat: found from forests of Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) or Quercus garryana and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), fruiting in late fall

Cortinarius zakii.nameOrigin: named for Dr. B. Zak of the Pacific Northwest Forest and Range Experiment Station, Corvallis, Oregon, whose studies show that this species forms ectendomycorrhizae with Arbutus menziesii and ectomycorrhizae with Pseudotsuga menziesii and Abies grandis, (Ammirati(2))
Cortinarius zakii.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] in humus or rotten wood in stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Ammirati(2))

Crassisporium funariophilum.spores: cinnamon-brown according to Breitenbach(4), but in the Pacific Northwest reported to have a more reddish cast that the spore deposits of most Pholiota species
Crassisporium funariophilum.habitat: densely gregarious on burned soil, June and July, (Smith), in dense groups on burned soil in summer (Scates)

Craterellus atrocinereus.nameOrigin: "atro-" from the Latin "ater" meaning "dark"; "-cinereus", meaning "gray", referring to the European species Craterellus cinereus, which it resembles, (Frank)
Craterellus atrocinereus.habitat: scattered or in small groups "on ground under hardwoods", especiallyQuercus (oak), but also with Notholithocarpus (Tanoak), (Frank), single to scattered or in groups or clusters "in mixed woods and under oaks", may fruit in the company of Craterellus calicornucopioides, or a few days before it, (Arora for his neighborhood in California, as Craterellus cinereus)

Craterellus calicornucopioides.nameOrigin: "cali-" is anicknameforCalifornia,andalsoGreekfor"beautiful", (Frank),"-cornucopioides" referstothe European species Craterellus cornucopioides; 'cornucopioides' means 'like a horn of plenty'
Craterellus calicornucopioides.spores: whitish to buff or pale yellow, (Arora), yellow / salmon for what has been known as C. fallax, white for C. cornucopioides when distinguished from it, (Pilz)
Craterellus calicornucopioides.habitat: scattered or cespitose (tufted) "on ground or very rotten wood in hardwood forests, fruiting mainly in the winter and spring with Neolithocarpus (tanoak), but also with Quercus, Arctostaphylos, Vaccinium, Arbutus, etc."; in Washington "it grows rarely with Quercus, Vaccinium, and/or Pseudotsuga", (Frank), scattered or in groups or close clusters often arising from a common base in humus or soil, under conifers or hardwoods; beginning in late fall in southern Oregon and continuing on into early winter and late spring in California, (Pilz), June to early winter in Europe (Bacon), spring, summer, fall, winter

Craterellus 'tubaeformis'.spores: white (Phillips), white to creamy white in thick deposits (Smith, but see also SIMILAR), white to creamy white (Castellano), white to buff (Miller)
Craterellus 'tubaeformis'.edibility: good (Phillips), Persson & Karlsson-Stiber reported in 1993 that consuming C. tubaeformis with alcohol might in rare instances cause negative reactions (Pilz)
Craterellus 'tubaeformis'.taste: pleasant (Phillips), not distinctive (Smith), Arora gives mild or bitterish for infundibuliformis group
Craterellus 'tubaeformis'.habitat: often in large groups in wet mossy bogs, (Phillips), cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious, on wet soil, "often along streams or near springs or in bogs under conifers", (Smith), "on wet soil, often along streams or near springs or in bogs under conifers", "also juxtaposed to rotten logs", fall through winter, (Castellano), "usually found scattered to clustered on well-decayed wood", "or sometimes in soil and humus, near the roots of living trees and around stumps"; generally November to May, (Pilz), occurrence in northwestern Oregon is highly correlated with the presence of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) with which it forms mycorrhizae; mycorrhizae also formed with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), but it is encountered only rarely in stands without hemlock component, (Trappe, M.), summer and fall (Miller), spring, summer, fall, winter

Crepidotus amygdalosporus.habitat: on hardwood, rarely on conifer wood

Crepidotus applanatus.spores: "sayal brown" to "cinnamon brown", (Hesler, colors from Ridgway(1)), brown (Phillips), brownish to cinnamon-brown (Lincoff), red-brown (Buczacki)
Crepidotus applanatus.habitat: on hardwood, more rarely on conifers, summer, (Hesler), in overlapping clusters on dead deciduous wood, (Lincoff), abundant, shelving, and sometimes appearing overlapping, "usually on hardwood limbs, logs, and stumps"; spring and fall, (Miller), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Crepidotus calolepis.habitat: usually "in groups or overlapping tiers on the bark of dead hardwoods (or rarely conifers)", (Arora), on bark of hardwood, more rarely coniferous trees, spring, summer and fall, (Hesler), year round (Bacon), spring, summer, fall, winter

Crepidotus circinatus.nameOrigin: means 'coiled' or 'curled away from an apex'

Crepidotus contortus.habitat: on twigs of Acer circinatum [Vine Maple] and Populus, May and September, (Hesler), spring, fall

Crepidotus crocophyllus.taste: mild (Miller), mild or often slowly bitterish (Hesler)
Crepidotus crocophyllus.habitat: scattered to gregarious on debarked hardwoods or woody hardwood litter, rarely on conifer litter; spring to fall, (Miller), on "hardwood sticks, stumps, fallen branches, and logs, more rarely on conifer wood", June to October, (Hesler), summer, fall

Crepidotus ellipsoideus.habitat: on hardwood, rarely on coniferous wood

Crepidotus epibryus.spores: pale yellow-brown, (Arora), pale brownish yellow, pale for Crepidotus, (Hesler), yellow (Bandala), buff (Buczacki)
Crepidotus epibryus.habitat: scattered or in groups "on fallen branches, twigs, herbaceous stems, and debris (usually of hardwoods)", (Arora), on hardwood logs and twigs, and herbaceous stems, (Hesler), somewhat gregarious to gregarious, on fallen leaves or dead herbaceous debris, in Quercus (oak) and mesophytic (subtropical) forests, (Bandala for Mexico), perhaps all year (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter

Crepidotus fraxinicola.habitat: on deciduous wood, June to August, (Hesler), summer

Crepidotus fusisporus.habitat: on hardwood sticks, dead branches, and logs, June to August, (Hesler), summer

Crepidotus lanuginosus.nameOrigin: refers to down on plants or cheeks
Crepidotus lanuginosus.habitat: on conifer sticks and limbs; the type found in July in California, (Hesler), summer

Crepidotus lundellii.habitat: on hardwood, (Hesler), on "wood and bark of (deciduous trees?) and pines", (Moser for Europe)

Crepidotus montanensis.habitat: type found on mossy living birch bark, July, (Hesler), summer

Crepidotus occidentalis.habitat: type on alder in June (Hesler), summer

Crepidotus ochraceus.habitat: type found on alder, November, (Hesler), fall

Crepidotus pallidobrunneus.habitat: on hardwood sticks and logs, July to August, (Hesler), summer

Crepidotus payettensis.habitat: type on barkless lodgepole pine log, July, (Hesler), summer

Crepidotus pseudoflammeus.habitat: type on fallen alder twigs, September, (Hesler), fall

Crepidotus pubescens.habitat: on fallen twigs and leaves of hardwoods and coniferous trees, October-November, (Hesler), fall

Crepidotus rainierensis.habitat: type found on conifer log, September, (Hesler), fall

Crepidotus regularis.nameOrigin: probably refers to regularly shaped cheilocystidia
Crepidotus regularis.taste: not distinctive, in one collection radish-like
Crepidotus regularis.habitat: on hardwood, rarely on conifer wood

Crepidotus stratosus.nameOrigin: means 'having layers', likely referring to duplex cap tissue
Crepidotus stratosus.habitat: on hardwood and coniferous wood or on soil, October and December, (Hesler), fall, winter

Crepidotus submollis.habitat: on fallen twigs and limbs of hardwoods

Crepidotus subsphaerosporus.nameOrigin: means 'close to [Crepidotus] sphaerosporus' or 'with more or less round spores'

Crepidotus variabilis.habitat: on hardwood and conifer twigs, branches and debris, (Hesler(3) for var. trichocystis), on hardwood (Hesler(3) for var. variabilis), mostly summer and fall, but can be found in winter and spring when winter is mild, (Bacon)

Crepidotus versutus.habitat: bark of deciduous wood, August to October, (Hesler), perhaps all year (Buczacki), summer, fall

Crinipellis piceae.habitat: gregarious on needles of Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), on needle beds that are on bare or partially moss covered ground, noted "along the margins of roads through spruce forests and, along the Pacific coast, common on the ridge tops of treed shore dunes exposed both to periods of drying offshore breezes and periods of heavy fog"; in eastern North America on needles of Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir) and Picea (spruce), (Redhead(54)), single, scattered or in groups on needles, twigs, and debris of conifers especially spruce, (Arora), late summer and fall (Miller)

Crinipellis scabella.habitat: among grass, on trunks, etc. (Moser for C. stipitaria), single or in small groups, on "dead and decaying grass stems, in grassland, woodland, parks, gardens, with marram on dunes and in neglected grassy areas"; summer and fall, (Buczacki), single or in troops on dead plant stems in dry grassy areas and on sand dunes, (Laessoe for C. stipitaria), scattered in litter layer in hardwood or mixed forests, on leaf litter, twigs of various hardwoods and once on Picea sp., woody fruits, needles or scales of Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), Thuja occidentalis (Northern White-Cedar) and bits of wood; "associated with rhizomorphs connecting the substrates" (Redhead for C. setipes)

Cuphophyllus borealis.habitat: on soil in deciduous and coniferous woods, August to December, (Hesler), scattered or in groups "on ground and humus in woods or at their edges", (Arora), summer, fall, winter

Cuphophyllus cinerellus.habitat: in "arctic-alpine zones, usually on nutrient poor soils", "in dry lichen alpine heath" with Empetrum nigrum (black crowberry), Vaccinium, and Betula nana (dwarf birch), "also in moist Sphagnum and Polytrichum bogs among Carex and Vaccinium"; "presumably biotrophic with moss" and/or some other paludine [bog or marsh] plant associate, fruiting JuneSeptember

Cuphophyllus colemannianus.habitat: gregarious "on humus in oak and beech woods", (Hesler), fall (Buczacki)

'Cuphophyllus' cremicolor^;.odour: none or (in one collection) faintly fragrant, (Hesler)
'Cuphophyllus' cremicolor^;.habitat: on ground in woods and in a dried up pool, July to November (Hesler), summer, fall

'Cuphophyllus' graveolens.nameOrigin: means "with a strong odor", gravis = heavy (Latin), oleo = I smell (Latin)
'Cuphophyllus' graveolens.odour: sickening (sweetish) (Hesler), "decidedly fragrant at first, becoming faint with age": the odor, "although faint at times, can always be detected", (Largent)
'Cuphophyllus' graveolens.habitat: cespitose-gregarious in swampy area under cedar and alder, October, (Hesler), in California, in redwood branchlet humus in redwood forest or in leaf humus in an oak forest beneath live oaks or redwood, (Largent), fall

Cuphophyllus hygrocyboides.habitat: on ground in alpine zone with moss and Salix stolonifera (Coville creeping willow)

'Cuphophyllus' lawrencei^;.nameOrigin: after Fred Lawrence, who collected the holotype

Cuphophyllus niveus.habitat: gregarious to scattered on humus and soil in coniferous and deciduous woods; August to January, (Hesler), gregarious to scattered under conifers (Largent), summer, fall, winter

'Cuphophyllus' nordmanensis.nameOrigin: after Nordman Idaho, where type found

Cuphophyllus pratensis.edibility: edible, no great cause for enthusiasm, (Arora), edible, excellent, (Phillips), choice (Lincoff)
Cuphophyllus pratensis.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious in damp places, in forests and grassy areas, (Arora), single, gregarious, or cespitose [in tufts], in open places, on grassy areas, in thickets or dense forests; May to December, (Hesler), spring, summer, fall

Cuphophyllus rainierensis.nameOrigin: after Mt. Rainier National Park where type specimen found
Cuphophyllus rainierensis.odour: strongly of freshly husked green corn
Cuphophyllus rainierensis.habitat: scattered in mixed conifer-hardwood forest, September to October, (Hesler), fall

Cuphophyllus recurvatus.nameOrigin: means 'recurved' - bent back up, perhaps referring to margin of cap
Cuphophyllus recurvatus.habitat: scattered to gregarious "under conifers and in open, grassy areas", (Arora), gregarious under conifers, October to January, (Hesler), fall, winter

Cuphophyllus russocoriaceus.taste: slightly medicinal (Arora), "mild at first but typically developing a strong unpleasant or medicinal flavor with time", (Largent)
Cuphophyllus russocoriaceus.odour: fragrant when fresh (like arborvitae or cedar), (Arora), "often strong and penetrating, usually cedar-like, at times so faint as to be almost indistinct", in these specimens medicinal taste can be used to identify species, (Largent), characteristic of Russian leather or cedar wood but often faint, (Hansen), very strong smell of Russian leather or cedar wood, (Moser)
Cuphophyllus russocoriaceus.habitat: widely scattered or in small groups in woods or at the edge of woods, (Arora), "scattered to gregarious in branchlet humus beneath coast redwood or in humus under oaks", December to February (Largent for California), in grass "on roadsides, lawns and old pastures often in small groups", (Hansen), pasture land, bushes, (Moser), fall to winter (Buczacki)

Cuphophyllus subviolaceus.taste: mild to bitter or slightly peppery (Arora), "at first mild, soon bitter to subnauseous", finally somewhat peppery, at times leaving a burning in the throat, (Hesler)
Cuphophyllus subviolaceus.habitat: scattered or in small groups in woods or swamps, late summer through fall and early winter, (Arora), gregarious on soil in swamps and deep humus, under hardwoods or conifers, (Hesler)

Cuphophyllus virgineus.odour: none or slightly pleasant (Hesler), not distinctive (Phillips)
Cuphophyllus virgineus.habitat: gregarious "on soil, at times among moss, in deciduous, coniferous, and mixed woods", (Hesler), gregarious on soil or moss in woods (Phillips), in meadows and pastures (Breitenbach for Switzerland), fall to early winter (Bacon), summer to winter (Buczacki)

Cyclocybe erebia.spores: dull brown (Phillips, Bessette), very dark brown (Hermanson), snuff brown (Watling)
Cyclocybe erebia.edibility: no (Phillips), unknown and too easy to confuse with poisonous species (Hermanson)
Cyclocybe erebia.habitat: on soil in damp woods (Phillips), scattered to gregarious "in hardwoods and conifer woods, on bare soil or in leaf litter, edges of forests, forest tracks", summer to fall, (Hermanson), in small groups on edges of woodland tracks, in shrubberies, on shady hedge banks, (Watling for Britain)

Cystinarius crassus.habitat: in coniferous forest, mainly under Picea (spruce), frequently amongst Sphagnum, but never in bogs, (Brandrud for Europe), coniferous (and deciduous?) woods, (Moser), a collection under maple with conifers (Smith(22)), under conifers and possibly maple, (Phillips), late summer and fall (Miller)

Cystinarius rubiginosus.nameOrigin: "rubiginosus" (Latin) = "rusty or rust-colored", refers to the color of the dried collections and the colors that the fruitbodies gain after handling and when old, (Niskanen)
Cystinarius rubiginosus.odour: indistinct or slightly fragrant, (Niskanen), not distinctive (Smith(22)), slight, pleasant (Phillips)
Cystinarius rubiginosus.habitat: examined collections were collected under conifers, sometimes with hardwoods present, from September to December, (Niskanen), singly to cespitose [in tufts], on humus under conifers, (Smith(22)), coniferous and mixed woods, September to November, (Phillips)

Cystoagaricus 'hirtosquamulosus'.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious "on logs and debris of hardwoods"

Cystoagaricus weberi.habitat: type on a mixture of wet soil and much-decayed wood in deep shade

Cystoderma amianthinum.habitat: single to gregarious "on rich humus, very rotten logs, among mosses and fallen leaves in mixed forests or on needle carpets under spruce", usually fruiting in late summer and fall, but one Hesler collection in June at 5200 feet altitude

Cystoderma carcharias.nameOrigin: from 'karcharos', sharp-pointed, jagged, or "karcharias", a kind of shark, perhaps referring to toothed veil remnants
Cystoderma carcharias.odour: unpleasantly moldy to gas-like, (Breitenbach), musty-earthy due to geosmin (Breheret(1))
Cystoderma carcharias.habitat: gregarious under conifers, late summer and fall, (Smith(46)), single to gregarious, primarily in conifer forests, on needle litter, (Breitenbach for Europe), one Oregon collection from a moss carpet under second growth Douglas-fir, another from Oregon from a very dense growth of Rubus, alder, and maple, (Smith(26))

Cystoderma fallax.taste: not distinctive or at times somewhat nauseous, (Smith(15)), mild (Phillips)
Cystoderma fallax.odour: not distinctive or at times somewhat nauseous, (Smith), pleasant (Phillips) pleasant or unpleasant, one variant has green corn odor, (Laycock)
