Cystoderma fallax.habitat: single, scattered or in small groups or tufts under conifers or in mixed woods, or on rotting wood, (Arora), gregarious on moss carpets under conifers, spring and fall, (Smith(15)), scattered, gregarious, or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on humus, moss beds, needle carpets, or very rotten conifer logs in conifer forests or in mixed forests of conifers and hardwoods, (Smith(46))

Cystoderma gruberianum.nameOrigin: after William B. Gruber of Portland, whose name is included with Smith's on the type, and as Smith says, "whose interest in the fleshy fungi made this publication possible"
Cystoderma gruberianum.habitat: type scattered or in groups of two along a decaying conifer log, probably Douglas-fir

Cystodermella ambrosii.nameOrigin: means 'divine' (Latin), ambrosia is food of the gods
Cystodermella ambrosii.taste: mild (Smith), mild to somewhat astringent, fungoid, (Breitenbach)
Cystodermella ambrosii.habitat: under Larix (larch) in mossy places or under Alnus (alder) in mixed alder, cedar, and Douglas-fir forests, (Smith), single to gregarious "inside and outside forests, primarily montane to subalpine, in pastures, on mossy gravel banks, or also on needle litter", near Picea (spruce), Larix (larch), or Alnus (alder); summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Europe), coniferous and mixed woods, (Courtecuisse for Europe)

Cystodermella cinnabarina.habitat: in conifer woods (Phillips), gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on very decayed conifer wood, on needle beds under various conifers and also under hardwoods, (Smith(15)), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Cystodermella granulosa.taste: mild (Smith(46)), mild, not distinctive, (Breitenbach), not distinctive (Phillips)
Cystodermella granulosa.habitat: scattered to gregarious on moss and soil under hardwoods or conifers, late summer and fall, (Smith(46)), single to gregarious in hardwood and coniferous forests, (Breitenbach), "on soil or moss in mixed woods" (Phillips)

Cystodermella subpurpurea.habitat: scattered on an area where a brush pile had been burned, September, (Smith(6), Smith(26)), fall

Cystolepiota bucknallii.odour: strong, vile, resembling that of coal tar, (Smith), strongly and unpleasantly gas-like, (like Tricholoma sulphureum), (Breitenbach)
Cystolepiota bucknallii.habitat: scattered to gregarious on moist humus in coniferous forests and mixed conifer-hardwood forests, (Smith), single to gregarious "in hardwood forests or mixed hardwood forests, on path- or roadsides, on soil", summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Cystolepiota fumosifolia.nameOrigin: means 'with smoky gills', from Latin 'fumus' meaning 'smoke', and Latin 'folium' meaning 'leaf'
Cystolepiota fumosifolia.habitat: type gregarious on ground in woods

Cystolepiota moelleri.odour: "faint and pleasant according to some authors, this collection however had a very strong unpleasant smell", like that of Lepiota cristata, (Phillips), indistinct (Buczacki), faint, gas-like, (Knudsen)
Cystolepiota moelleri.habitat: damp ground in shady hardwood woods; fall, (Phillips), usually +/- tufted in small groups; damp hardwood woodland, (Buczacki), on rich soil under hardwoods, fall, (Knudsen), damp ground, shadowy hardwood woods, (Moser)

Cystolepiota oregonensis.habitat: clustered to gregarious on soil and litter under conifers and alder, (Sieger), gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] in soil and litter under Alnus (alder), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), September and October, (Smith, H.V.), fall

Cystolepiota petasiformis.habitat: on humus in woods (Sieger), on ground in woods (Smith), type scattered or gregarious, in humus in woods, (Murrill)

Cystolepiota seminuda.taste: in some faintly like Lepiota cristata, never strong, (Smith, H.V.), like grain (farinaceous) or not distinctive, (Sieger)
Cystolepiota seminuda.habitat: "singly, scattered, or in groups in humus under conifers or hardwoods", (Phillips), gregarious on soil, usually in woods, (Smith, H.V.), scattered to gregarious on soil, usually in woods, (Sieger), summer and fall (Miller)

Daedalea quercina.odour: faintly acrid or mushroomy (Phillips), pleasantly fungoid, (Breitenbach), none (Miller)
Daedalea quercina.habitat: perennial, "solitary or sometimes in shelving groups on dead or living hardwoods, especially oak, chestnut, and chinquapin", (Arora), on different hardwoods, especially Quercus (oak) but also Castanea (chestnut), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Juglans (walnut), Populus, Prunus, Ulmus (elm), causes a brown heart rot that eventually hollows the wood, (Gilbertson), also on railway ties and wood used in construction, (Breitenbach), fruiting in summer and fall (Miller)

Daedaleopsis confragosa.habitat: usually annual, single or in groups on dead hardwoods or from wounds in living trees, especially willow, but also birch and other hardwoods and very rarely on conifers, (Arora), annual, on dead wood of hardwoods, rarely conifers, causes white rot, (Gilbertson), spores released in fall (Bacon)

Deconica angustispora.edibility: suspected to be active, but specimens not yet analyzed, (Stamets)
Deconica angustispora.habitat: single to several on dung of "sheep, cows, horses, elk, marmots, and other animals", spring and fall, (Stamets), single or scattered "on dung (cattle, sheep, horse, or wild animals such as elk or marmot)", spring to fall, (Guzman(1)), "on dung, mainly pellets of deer and elk, but also grows on horse dung, in temperate forests or alpine meadows", (Guzman(4))

Deconica argentina.spores: dark violaceous brown or dark purple brown
Deconica argentina.habitat: "Gregarious on cow and horse dung, in grassland, meadows, or outside of the wooded areas, both in shaded or sunny places.", fruiting almost all year, but mainly during rainy season

Deconica caricicola.spores: brown vinaceous to fawn when dried (Redhead(33)), violaceous umber (Watling)
Deconica caricicola.habitat: on Carex (sedge), on grass and Juncus, (Redhead(9) for BC), scattered on senescent stems and leaves of Scirpus rubrotinctus, Juncus effusus, Juncus sp., and Carex sp. "in humid enclosed spaces at the bases of hummocks in drying temporary ponds in pastures", (Redhead(33) for Quebec and Ontario), on standing dead stems of Carex riparius, (Watling for Britain)

Deconica cokeriana.taste: "initially mild, later bitter and raphanoid [radish-like], unpleasant"
Deconica cokeriana.habitat: gregarious to caespitose, "growing on wood debris, wood chips, and occasionally on small twigs, branches, leaves, or organic soil"

Deconica coprophila.spores: purplish brown to nearly black, (Arora), blackish violaceous brown, (Guzman(1)), dark purplish brown (Stamets)
Deconica coprophila.edibility: generally regarded as harmless, some strains with small amount psilocybin, (Arora), no hallucinogenic properties but has psilocybin according to a study by Leslie and Repke, but some specimens deposited by Leslie and Repke are of mixed genera, (Guzman(1)), does not produce psilocybin or psilocyn (conclusion of Stamets)
Deconica coprophila.habitat: single or in small colonies "on dung and manure (especially cow patties)", (Arora), scattered to gregarious in dense groups, rarely single, on dung (cow, horse, donkey, sheep, rabbits, and probably other animals), rarely on rich soil, (Guzman(1)), usually on cow or horse dung in spring, summer, or fall, (Stamets), fall to winter (Buczacki)

Deconica crobula.nameOrigin: derived from Greek and means a braid of hair gathered into a knot on the crown of the head, referring to scales on cap
Deconica crobula.spores: grayish chocolate brown or bister-sepia (Guzman), cigar brown (Stamets), mid-brown, not purplish, (Buczacki)
Deconica crobula.edibility: Phillips says active, but analyses have not found psilocybin or psilocin, (Stamets)
Deconica crobula.habitat: on twigs and other wood debris in fall, not on grass [but see Guzman below], (Stamets), single or gregarious "on grass stems or rhizomes, rotten twigs, or logs, or other herbaceous debris, or on sawdust, or on old or rotten dung, in grasslands" or, more often, in open hardwood forests, rarely in coniferous forests or subalpine zones, also rare in arctic zones; fruiting in summer, (Guzman), fall (Buczacki)

Deconica horizontalis.spores: purple brown to dark brown (Redhead(18)), mid-brown (Buczacki)
Deconica horizontalis.habitat: on rotting fabrics and woody litter: old fabrics or old carpets, seat covers of abandoned cars, mattresses, rotting blue jeans, or on wood, (Redhead(18)), single or in small groups, +/- tufted, on wood, often on cut faces of stacked logs, also on other organic matter such as woollen carpet, rope; spring to winter, (Buczacki)

Deconica inquilina.nameOrigin: means 'temporary inhabitant', referring to habit on twigs, sticks and grass stems
Deconica inquilina.spores: purplish brown (Stamets), "violet brown dark to blackish violet", (Guzman), mid-brown (Buczacki)
Deconica inquilina.edibility: not known to be active as hallucinogen (Stamets)
Deconica inquilina.habitat: single to gregarious, often grows from bases of matted rotting grass in fall and is difficult to harvest without stem breaking or clump of grass being pulled up, occasionally on rotting twigs or in rich soils, (Stamets), single or gregarious, rarely cespitose [in tufts], "on grass stems, rotten twigs, sticks or rotten wood", rarely on old dung or rich soil, in open coniferous forests with grasses, on dead ferns, on sawdust, (Guzman), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Deconica merdaria.edibility: no (Phillips), not known to be active as a hallucinogen, (Stamets)
Deconica merdaria.taste: not distinctive or fungoid (Guzman(1)), not distinctive (Phillips)
Deconica merdaria.odour: not distinctive or fungoid (Guzman(1)), not distinctive (Phillips)
Deconica merdaria.habitat: scattered to numerous on dung, a common dung dweller in temperate zones, (Stamets), on horse dung, (Phillips), scattered or more frequently gregarious on dung of herbivores in particular but also "on straw or piles of dung, and straw mixed with dung or refuse from paler mill, or compost, on very rich soil, or sewage, or garden soil in open sunny places, manured grasslands, or gardens, or roadsides", (Guzman(1)), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Deconica moelleri.nameOrigin: after Dr. F.F. Moeller, who first described this as Stropharia merdaria f. macrospora from the Faeroes Islands
Deconica moelleri.edibility: not conclusively shown to be active (Stamets)
Deconica moelleri.habitat: gregarious, occasionally cespitose [in tufts], "on cow or horse dung, along trails, or in soils enriched with manure", (Stamets), single or more commonly gregarious in dense groups, sometimes cespitose, "on dung (cow and horse) or on very rich soil in trails or corrals and cow yards", August to November, (Guzman), summer, fall

Deconica montana.spores: dark grayish brown (Stamets), dark gray brown (Guzman(1)), purple brown (Phillips), purple-brown to blackish violet gray, (Miller)
Deconica montana.taste: none or slightly fungal (Guzman(1)), not distinctive (Phillips)
Deconica montana.odour: none or slightly fungal (Guzman(1)), not distinctive (Phillips), pleasant (Miller)
Deconica montana.habitat: scattered to numerous, in mossy ground, less common on sandy soils, especially at higher elevations, (may be obligate saprophyte on dead root masses), (Stamets), gregarious, rarely single "on soil or sandy soil, always covered by mosses or dense bryophyte mats" (especially Polytrichum, not Sphagnum), "in open forests, roadsides, tracks, banks of rivulets, fire places, of coniferous or deciduous trees of [sic] along the margin of pasture-lands", (Guzman(1)), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller)

Deconica phillipsii.habitat: although some European collections of Deconica caricicola have been called Melanotus phillipsii (now Deconica phillipsii), the true Deconica phillipsii occurs on grasses and Carex in Europe, (Redhead), found on dead grass (Graminae) leaves and stems, and on other herbaceous plants, often in marshland, rarely if ever on Carex, (Watling for United Kingdom), on dead monocotyledon leaves, especially Carex, (according to Moser for Europe, who does not mention M. caricicola), usually gregarious or grouped on old culms and stems of Juncus, Carex, or grasses of the previous year, more rarely on herbaceous plants such as Urtica, Cirsium, Scrophularia, Origanum, from the previous year, summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Europe, but spore measurements more like Deconica caricicola)

Deconica phyllogena.nameOrigin: means 'with spores shaped like a rhombus'
Deconica phyllogena.habitat: usually gregarious, more rarely single "in hardwood and coniferous forests, on rotten wood, mosses, or leaves", (Breitenbach for Europe), on "herbal debris, small fallen twigs, or mosses, often on moist ground", (Hansen for Europe), on dead leaves or needles (Moser for Europe), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Deconica subcoprophila.spores: purpuraceous black or dark violaceous brown, (Guzman(1)), dark brown (Breitenbach)
Deconica subcoprophila.taste: none or slightly musty or fungus-like
Deconica subcoprophila.odour: none or slightly musty or fungus-like
Deconica subcoprophila.habitat: gregarious or scattered on dung (cows, horses, rarely sheep), (Guzman(1)), usually gregarious or grouped on manured soils or also directly on manure, (Breitenbach)

Deconica subviscida.habitat: usually in grassy areas, in well-manured areas or in dung, also reported from mossy areas and in decayed conifer substrates; late spring to summer, (Stamets), gregarious to scattered "on soil, rich soil, in grassy lawns, or even on horse manure, edges of roads"; fruiting in summer, (Guzman(1)), fruiting from late fall through mid-winter along the California coast (Desjardin)

Dendrocollybia racemosa.habitat: in small groups on old decayed mushrooms, or occasionally in duff under conifers (Arora), fall (Buczacki)

Dissoderma contortipes.habitat: single to tufted on logs or in moss under Douglas fir, forming on cap of Galerina species

Dissoderma odoratum.spores: pinkish (Arora), light yellow (Breitenbach), white but sometimes seem (at least microscopically) to acquire some dingy color, (Bas)
Dissoderma odoratum.taste: "none or at least not notable", (Stuntz), mild, like bon-bons, (Breitenbach), not distinctive (Bas), galls have taste reminiscent of Hebeloma species, (Mondiet)
Dissoderma odoratum.odour: grape-like, "strongly and persistently fruity-fragrant (like grape soda or grape juice)", (Arora), "strong and persistent, sweet, fruity, very nearly like that of ripe Concord grapes (or like the artificial grape flavoring used in candy and soft drinks)", (Stuntz), strongly aromatic and sweetish (like bon-bons) or like Hebeloma sacchariolens, (Breitenbach), strong, heavy, sweetish aromatic, reminding of Hebeloma sacchariolens, but sweeter, (Bas), galls smell radish-like (Mondiet)
Dissoderma odoratum.habitat: usually "in groups or clumps on ground in woods", (Arora), cespitose (rarely single or in twos) on ground under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), in October, (Stuntz), clustered or in dense groups "usually outside forests, in parks, on pathsides or alongside forest roads, commonly near hardwoods, on sandy soil", fall, (Breitenbach), terrestrial "in gardens (only in wooded areas), parks, forest plantations and woods; apparently in wooded areas where original soil structure has been disturbed", in the Netherlands on sandy and loamy soil, (Bas), fall

Dissoderma paradoxum.odour: not distinctive (Smith(26)), "not distinctive according to Smith & Singer; intensively perfume-like when young, fetid with age according to Horak; obnoxious as in Lactarius porninsis according to Herink", (Bas, with Latin name italicized)
Dissoderma paradoxum.habitat: growing on mushroom (probably Cystoderma) which it transforms into a stem-like gall, (Redhead), grows on Cystoderma amianthinum (Matheny), terrestrial among mosses in woods or near scattered trees, (Bas), summer and fall (Bacon)

Dissoderma pearsonii.habitat: single, parasitic on Cystoderma amianthinum sensu lato, (Saar), clustered, up to several fruitbodies growing out of a common bulb, "in meadows, parks, gardens, under hardwoods or conifers", (Breitenbach), type under Pinus silvestris (Scots Pine) amongst moss (Bas)

Entocybe nitida.odour: slightly farinaceous or radish-like (Castellano), mild to somewhat radish-like (Trudell)
Entocybe nitida.habitat: singly or in small groups under conifers or in mixed hardwood-conifer forests, July through November, (Castellano), coniferous woods (Moser), in woods, mainly coniferous, (Courtecuisse), "widespread and sometimes locally abundant in moist western conifer forests where it occurs on humus and litter", (Trudell), summer, fall

Entocybe speciosa.odour: "faint or distinct and then farinaceous with a definite fragrance"
Entocybe speciosa.habitat: gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] on decayed wood in coniferous forests

Entocybe trachyospora.nameOrigin: 'trachyospora' means 'rough-spored', 'carlottae' probably refers to the Queen Charlotte Islands, where type of R. carlottae was found
Entocybe trachyospora.taste: mostly indistinct, at times radish-like, (Largent for var. trachyospora), not distinct (Largent for var. griseoviolacea), not distinct, (Largent for var. purpureoviolacea), not distinctive (Redhead for var. vinacea)
Entocybe trachyospora.odour: not distinctive or somewhat fruity fragrant (Baroni(2)), mostly indistinct, at times radish-like, (Largent for var. trachyospora), not distinct (Largent for var. griseoviolacea), not distinct, at times more or less fragrant and pleasant, (Largent for var. purpureoviolacea), not distinctive or faintly fragrant (Redhead for var. vinacea)
Entocybe trachyospora.habitat: scattered to gregarious in humus of coniferous woods, (Largent)

Entoloma abortivum.edibility: edible but accurate identification with aborted forms is essential (Bessette)
Entoloma abortivum.habitat: "scattered or in groups, often gregarious, on the ground, especially in humus or near rotting stumps, in woods"; August-November, (Bessette), several to abundant, "on the ground or in leaf litter, or on or about stumps and rotten wood", August to December

Entoloma alnobetulae.habitat: "gregarious on clay bank or on poor soil", associated in Europe with alder

Entoloma alpicola.habitat: scattered on mossy humus under conifers, (Largent), single to gregarious in alpine dwarf-shrub heaths or on poor pasture soils, primarily near Salix herbacea, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Entoloma brunnescipes.odour: farinaceous or of cucumber when crushed or cut
Entoloma brunnescipes.habitat: scattered to cespitose [in tufts] in mixed woods

Entoloma clavaformipes.habitat: unknown in BC, in Florida in rich soil under a laurel oak

Entoloma 'griseum'.habitat: holotype found under "spruce and balsam fir trees", August

Entoloma heracleodora.nameOrigin: means 'with odor of Heracleum', a species in Umbelliferae
Entoloma heracleodora.taste: strong cucumber and farinaceous, with a slight celery-like component
Entoloma heracleodora.odour: strong cucumber and farinaceous, with a slight celery-like component
Entoloma heracleodora.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] in grass under birch, early July to mid-August, (Largent), summer

Entoloma lividoalbum.odour: farinaceous only when cut or crushed
Entoloma lividoalbum.habitat: scattered to gregarious under hardwoods or rarely conifers, (Largent), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Entoloma lividum.edibility: poisonous, causing severe gastric disturbances, (Ammirati), poisonous (McKnight)
Entoloma lividum.odour: of fresh meal [farinaceous], (Ammirati), faint and somewhat mealy [farinaceous], (McKnight)
Entoloma lividum.habitat: on ground "in conifer or hardwood forests, or in mixed woods", in fall, (Ammirati), on soil in oak woods, (McKnight)

Entoloma lyophylloidium.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] under Abies (fir) above 3,500 feet

'Entoloma' medianox.edibility: yes but many similar Entolomas toxic, so be careful of identification, (Arora)
'Entoloma' medianox.odour: usually farinaceous, (Arora), "distinctly farinaceous, strongly so when squashed", (Largent)
'Entoloma' medianox.habitat: single, scattered or gregarious on ground in woods, (Arora); single, scattered, or gregarious "in needle, leaf, or branchlet humus", beneath various hardwoods and conifers, (Largent), fall (Buczacki)

Entoloma myrmecophilum.odour: farinaceous, especially when cut or crushed
Entoloma myrmecophilum.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious, usually under oak (Largent), fall, (Buczacki)

Entoloma nidorosum.nameOrigin: means "with the odor of frying" according to Schalkwijk-Barendsen or "smoked", from the color of the cap according to Lincoff(1)
Entoloma nidorosum.odour: "distinctly nitrous (bleach-like) when fresh", but fading after sitting for a while in Entoloma nidorosum (E. pernitrosum said to have a persistent odor)
Entoloma nidorosum.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious (sometimes in tufts) on ground in woods

Entoloma politum.odour: "faintly but distinctly chlorinaceous or mild, at times very slightly farinaceous and then only with age"
Entoloma politum.habitat: scattered to gregarious in mossy humus under Thuja plicata (Western Red Cedar) or Alnus rubra (Red Alder) (Largent), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Entoloma pseudocostatum.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] in soil, lawns or grassy areas, under or near conifers

Entoloma pseudolividum.habitat: scattered in needle humus under conifers

Entoloma rhodopolium.nameOrigin: 'rhodo-' is Greek for 'reddish'; '-polius' is from the Greek 'polios' which means 'gray, gray-headed, gray-haired' or could be used metaphorically to mean 'bright' or 'serene'
Entoloma rhodopolium.edibility: poisonous, "causing vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal cramps that may require hospitalization", (Arora)
Entoloma rhodopolium.taste: faintly farinaceous for forma rhodopolium, indistinct or suggestively farinaceous for forma 8700, weakly farinaceous for forma 9107, farinaceous for forma 9278 and 9067, grassy for forma 8954, (Largent)
Entoloma rhodopolium.odour: mild to slightly farinaceous (Arora), faintly farinaceous for forma rhodopolium (not at all nitrous or bleach-like), indistinct to a bit pungent for forma 8700, suggestively farinaceous for forma 9067, farinaceous (particularly when squashed) for forma 9107, faintly farinaceous when crushed for forma 9278, grassy for forma 8954, (Largent)
Entoloma rhodopolium.habitat: single, scattered or in groups or clusters "on ground in woods, mainly under hardwoods", (Arora); scattered to gregarious to nearly cespitose [in tufts] in leaf humus near or under Alnus rubra (Red Alder), (see NOTES for other forms), (Largent), on soil in hardwood woodland, usually in damp areas, especially near water; summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Entoloma sericatum.odour: "when first picked typically faintly but distinctly nitrous, immediately becoming distinctly farinaceous"
Entoloma sericatum.habitat: scattered to gregarious under hardwoods (Largent), often on Sphagnum (Moser for Europe), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Entoloma sinuatum.odour: odd, like bad meal or fishy
Entoloma sinuatum.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground under conifers and hardwoods, (Phillips), spring, fall, (Buczacki), late summer, fall, (Bacon)

Entoloma subpolitum.habitat: gregarious in mossy humus and needle humus under Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)

Entoloma subsaundersii.habitat: clusters of 2-6 under oaks, often not protruding much above surface, becoming larva-infested within the ground

Entoloma subsinuatum.edibility: appears to be equally as poisonous as the European sister species E. sinuatum, (Morgado)
Entoloma subsinuatum.odour: "strong, farinaceous especially when cut, spontaneously often weak and less distinctly farinaceous" , (Morgado)
Entoloma subsinuatum.habitat: in groups close to conifers and hardwoods, including Pinus (pine), Abies (true fir), Picea (spruce), Quercus (oak), and Betula (birch), probably ectomycorrhizal, (Morgado), type cespitose, collected "in leaf-mold in rich woods" in 1901, (Murrill)

Fayodia bisphaerigera.taste: not distinct (Castellano), mild (4-spored basidia), farinaceous (2-spored basidia), (Smith(1))
Fayodia bisphaerigera.odour: not distinct (Castellano), mild (4-spored basidia), farinaceous (2-spored basidia), (Smith(1)), faint, mealy, (Buczacki)
Fayodia bisphaerigera.habitat: among sticks and debris under hardwoods and conifers, (Castellano), single to gregarious under conifers or in bogs, (Smith(1)), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Flammula abieticola.spores: ' "chestnut" to "auburn" (with a strong red tinge)', a variation from Pholiota in the direction of Psilocybe, (Smith(3) for P. flavida var. graveolens, Ridgway colors in double quotation marks)
Flammula abieticola.taste: not distinctive (Smith(3) for P. abieticola), mild (Smith(3) for P. flavida var. graveolens)
Flammula abieticola.odour: not distinctive (Smith(3) for P. abieticola), "heavy and like some fats" (Smith(3) for P. flavida var. graveolens)
Flammula abieticola.habitat: on dead Abies (true fir), September in North Carolina, (Smith(3) for P. abieticola), cespitose [tufted] at the base of a conifer stub, September, (Smith(3) for P. flavida var. graveolens)

Flammula alnicola.taste: distinctly bitter when fresh, (Smith(3) for P. alnicola), none (Smith(3) for P. subvelutina), "mild, contrary to the concept formed by some mycologists", (Trudell), bitter (Lincoff), mild to bitter (Arora)
Flammula alnicola.odour: mild or fragrant to aromatic, (Smith(3) for P. alnicola), faintly fragrant, (Smith(3) for P. subvelutina), "pleasant, with a hint of spun sugar", (Lincoff), some collections have a fragrant odor, "somewhat reminiscent of grapefruit or tangerine, while others have no distinct odor", (Trudell)
Flammula alnicola.habitat: on hardwood trunks and stumps, at times on conifers, (Smith(3) for P. alnicola), cespitose or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on rotten log, (Smith(3) for P. subvelutina), isolated but more often clustered on dead alder stumps and trunks, also on other hardwood species in damp places, (Lincoff), fall (Buczacki)

Flammula flavida.spores: cigar brown (Phillips), rusty brown (Bessette), "chestnut" to "auburn" (with a strong red tinge), (Smith(3) who note that the color of the spore deposit is a variation in the direction of the genus Psilocybe)
Flammula flavida.odour: faintly fragrant, or none (Smith), of citrus especially grapefruit, or sometimes only faintly fragrant, (Bessette), var. graveolens described from ID distinguished by odor that is heavy and like some fats, (Smith), but that variety has been synonymized with Flammula abieticola
Flammula flavida.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] "on logs and at the base of trees and stumps of conifers and hardwood"; August to November, (Smith), "in clusters or groups on the ground, often among mosses, under conifers", (Bessette), summer, fall

Flammula malicola.nameOrigin: 'malicola' means 'living on apple tree', 'macropoda' means 'big foot', makros = big (Greek), pous, podos = foot (Greek)
Flammula malicola.odour: faintly fragrant, often like green corn
Flammula malicola.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on conifer and hardwood trees, at base of stumps or attached to buried wood

Flammulaster species^.spores: sepia brown [also referred to as dark brown], (Breitenbach), rusty brown (Phillips), red-brown (Buczacki)
Flammulaster species^.habitat: single to gregarious "in hardwood forests or mixed hardwood-conifer forests, on pathsides, on leaf litter, humus, or remains of wood", summer to fall, (Breitenbach(4) for Switzerland), "On (especially loamy) earth", (Moser(1) for Europe), on bare soil in forests and parks (Hansen, L.(2) for northern Europe), mixed woods in fall (Phillips(2) for Europe), spring, summer, fall (Buczacki)

Flammulina filiformis.edibility: yes, but remove sticky skin before cooking, (Arora), anaphylactic reaction has been reported in Otsuji et al. 2015 (Benjamin), Flammulina velutipes has a toxic hemolytic protein dubbed flammutoxin which is not heat stable, and cultured Flammulina velutipes (enoki) can be contaminated by bacteria like Listeria, (Kroeger(8))
Flammulina filiformis.habitat: in tufts or clusters "on or near stumps, logs, and roots of hardwoods (but sometimes appearing terrestrial)", (Arora), cespitose [in tufts] on hardwood, often on stumps, spring or fall, in the cooler part of the season, (Lennox), fall, winter, (Bacon), spring, fall, winter

Flammulina lupinicola.edibility: edible with good flavor, but rather thin-fleshed and stems are tough, (Siegel(2))
Flammulina lupinicola.habitat: in California occurs in "small to medium-size clusters on dead bush lupine", most common on Lupinus arboreus (yellow bush lupine), "restricted to coastal dunes, riparian zones, and sandy areas near ocean where bush lupine grows", fruiting fall, winter, and spring

Flammulina populicola.habitat: found most frequently on Populus tremuloides (quaking aspen), but occasionally on other hosts or substrates

Flammulina rossica.habitat: most frequently on Salix (willow) or on Populus, but also on other hosts or substrates

Floccularia albolanaripes.habitat: single or in scattered groups on ground in woods and along paths, (Arora), single to gregarious "on humus under alder and in conifer forests", not uncommon during fall (in Pacific Northwest), rarely found in spring, (Smith(15))

Floccularia luteovirens.habitat: on ground under aspen and in mixed woods (Phillips), in Oregon in an area dominated by conifers but alder and maple present (Smith(15)), "short turf, wood pasture on calcareous soil", (Courtecuisse for Europe)

Galerina alluviana.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to detritus deposited by running water'
Galerina alluviana.habitat: type scattered on Polytrichum moss over an alluvial outwash

Galerina atkinsoniana.nameOrigin: presumably after G.F. Atkinson 1854-1918 Professor of Botany, Cornell University
Galerina atkinsoniana.habitat: scattered to gregarious on moss carpets under conifers and on mossy logs, (Smith), "single to gregarious, found with moss attached to the dead roots, stems, and leaves of mosses, saprobic or possibly parasitic, in Picea spp. and Pseudotsuga menziesii forests", (Castellano, names of genera italicized), fall (Buczacki)

Galerina autumnalis.edibility: deadly poisonous because of amanita toxins (Ammirati)
Galerina autumnalis.taste: mild to farinaceous, (Smith) may have slight taste of cucumber (Ammirati), [do not taste however because of toxins]
Galerina autumnalis.odour: mild or slightly farinaceous (Arora), slightly farinaceous when crushed, (Smith), without special odor or with slight odor of cucumber (Ammirati)
Galerina autumnalis.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in tufts on rotting wood and debris of hardwoods and conifers, (Arora), scattered to gregarious or cespitose [in tufts], primarily "on decayed conifer and hardwood logs, woody debris, wood chips, bark mulch, or in newly laid lawns", (Stamets), scattered to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] "on decaying hardwood and conifer logs, stumps etc.", (Smith), in fall or sometimes in early spring (Miller)

Galerina badipes.edibility: should be assumed poisonous, and other Galerinas considered poisonous such as Galerina venenata (Landry(1)) have been identified as G. badipes. According to M. Beug, pers. comm. February 20, 2022, G. badipes has tested negative for alpha and beta amanitins but has tested positive for gamma amanitins by at least two researchers.
Galerina badipes.habitat: gregarious "on conifer debris in wet areas, especially around chips"

Galerina borealis.habitat: gregarious on moss, late summer and fall

Galerina brunneomarginata.habitat: among leaves and grass in rich soil or under trees

Galerina camerina.habitat: on rotten stumps, on mossy trunks of conifers

Galerina camerinoides.nameOrigin: means 'like [Agaricus] camerinus' as described by Fries, the basionym for Galerina camerina (Fr.) Kuehner
Galerina camerinoides.habitat: type gregarious on moss over rocks

Galerina cascadensis.habitat: type was subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on debris of an old avalanche

Galerina castaneipes.edibility: poisonous, contains amatoxins, (Landry(1)), Galerina castaneipes has about 3/4 the alpha and beta amanitin levels of G. marginata and so should be considered deadly as well, (M. Beug, pers. comm. December 2, 2021)
Galerina castaneipes.habitat: type more or less in tufts on a rotten oak log

Galerina castanescens.habitat: type was gregarious on conifer logs

Galerina cedretorum.habitat: cespitose-gregarious [tufted-gregarious] along highways on debris, and gregarious under conifers (var. cedretorum), gregarious on conifer wood debris (var. bispora)

Galerina cerina.habitat: scattered on mossy logs or standing trunks in fall

Galerina cinnamomea.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on chipdirt in slashing and on rotting hardwood logs

Galerina cortinarioides.nameOrigin: means 'like Cortinarius', so named because its aspect is that of a Cortinarius of the acutus group

Galerina diabolissima.nameOrigin: possibly referring to Seven Devils Mts. where type found
Galerina diabolissima.habitat: gregarious on a thin moss cover over exposed soil

Galerina dimorphocystis.nameOrigin: probably refers to two types of cystidia
Galerina dimorphocystis.habitat: gregarious "on moss, especially over mossy logs, in cold bogs or cold wet springy hillsides, or on wet mossy rocks", early June to August, (Smith), summer

Galerina evelata.nameOrigin: 'evelata' refers to absence of veil; 'fulvipes' means 'fulvous foot'
Galerina evelata.habitat: gregarious on mossy logs, seems to favor patches of Dicranum

Galerina fibrillosa.habitat: type was gregarious on wet earth

Galerina fontinalis.habitat: type on wet soil in a springy area along a road

Galerina funariae.habitat: scattered near Funaria moss and on it, in a burned area

Galerina fuscobrunnea.habitat: type was gregarious on humus under alder in swampy area in mountains

Galerina heterocystis.nameOrigin: probably refers to different sizes of cystidia
Galerina heterocystis.habitat: gregarious on moss (only rarely on sphagnum), (Smith), scattered to gregarious in damp, mossy or grassy places, usually in or near woods, (Arora), "Single to gregarious, attached to the base of the mosses and lower dead stems and roots; also in the soils close by Ranunculus spp. Various grasses mixed with mosses seem to be its preferred neighbors"; summer and fall, (Castellano, with Ranunculus in italics)

Galerina insignis.habitat: gregarious on soil in debris from avalanche

Galerina jaapii.habitat: on moss, "scattered to gregarious in small bogs or along the margins of swamps, summer and fall"

Galerina lacustris.habitat: scattered among mosses and sedges at low water level of a lake

Galerina laticeps.habitat: gregarious on rotten conifer and hardwood logs, etc., fall

Galerina latispora.habitat: type scattered "on moss in wet areas along a stream"

Galerina marginata.edibility: deadly poisonous (Stamets), with alpha-amanitin (Moser), phalloidin syndrome (Courtecuisse)
Galerina marginata.taste: slightly to strongly farinaceous [but avoid tasting because it is poisonous], (Smith), floury (Moser), mealy (Courtecuisse)
Galerina marginata.odour: slightly to strongly farinaceous, (Smith), floury (Moser), mealy (Courtecuisse)
Galerina marginata.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on or near wood of conifers, summer and fall, (Smith), on coniferous wood, (Moser), gregarious, sometimes densely so, not in tufts, on stumps and wood, mainly coniferous, but also on hardwood trees, (Courtecuisse)

Galerina minima.habitat: gregarious on moss over very sterile soil

Galerina mniophila.taste: mild in American material, but European description of Kuehner says mild or slightly farinaceous especially in stem, (Smith)
Galerina mniophila.habitat: gregarious on moss in conifer forests, (Smith), among mosses (not Sphagnum) in wet grassland, occasionally in gardens, lawns, damp woodland; trooping; fall, (Buczacki)

Galerina mollis.habitat: scattered on remains of herbaceous stems (of Capnoides)

Galerina nana.odour: light or indistinct, or slightly farinaceous, (Smith)
Galerina nana.habitat: scattered on more rarely in small densely gregarious groups "on buried particles of wood, on wooden boards and wooden flower pots, on earth", on living Cyathea (tree-fern), on fence poles, on dead trunks in alder woods, "in temperate climates of the northern hemisphere, usually in gardens and in greenhouses, cellars, etc.", (Smith), litter, broadleaved trees, (Courtecuisse)

Galerina nordmaniana.habitat: type on moss along a road bank

Galerina obscurata.habitat: type gregarious to scattered on mossy hummocks under hemlock

Galerina olympiana.nameOrigin: refers to Olympic National Park in WA
Galerina olympiana.habitat: gregarious on wood of Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood)

Galerina oregonensis.edibility: has been synonymized by Gulden(1) with deadly poisonous species
Galerina oregonensis.habitat: scattered on mossy rocks, and possibly on wood

Galerina oreina.habitat: gregarious "on moss in areas made moist by runoff from nearby glaciers and snow-fields"

Galerina paludosa.habitat: sphagnum bogs, late spring to late fall, (Smith), spring, summer, fall

Galerina perplexa.habitat: gregarious on moss under pine, summer and fall

Galerina pistillicystis.habitat: gregarious on very rotten logs, mostly among moss, mostly June and July, (Smith), summer

Galerina pruinatipes.habitat: scattered on rotten wet conifer logs in cold places

Galerina pseudocamerina.habitat: scattered on old logs in advanced decay, and on humus

Galerina pseudostylifera.habitat: gregarious on rotting conifer logs in cold wet places in mountains

Galerina pteridicola.habitat: scattered on fern petioles of the past season, and perhaps other habitats

Galerina pubescentipes.habitat: type gregarious on a conifer log

Galerina pulchra.habitat: type was densely gregarious on an old mossy log

Galerina pumila.habitat: gregarious on moss beds, especially Dicranum in North America, at elevations supporting alpine fir

Galerina rainierensis.habitat: on wet soil at edge of springy area, Mt. Rainier National Park

Galerina rudericola.habitat: on debris at base of old avalanche

Galerina rugisperma.nameOrigin: refers to the wrinkled surface of the spores
Galerina rugisperma.habitat: gregarious on wet earth on edge of swamp

Galerina semilanceata.nameOrigin: means "shaped like a half lance", semi = half (Latin), lancets = in the form of a lance (Latin)
Galerina semilanceata.habitat: gregarious to scattered "on moss or in shaded, moist grassy areas with moss intermixed, also on mossy logs, etc.", often in campgrounds or clearings between buildings; spring and fall

Galerina sideroides.habitat: gregarious on rotten coniferous logs (Smith), on rotten coniferous wood (Moser), fall (Buczacki)

Galerina species^.edibility: not edible - some species contain amanita-type toxins
Galerina species^.habitat: particularly on moss beds, but some species on organic debris, humus, or wood.

Galerina stagnina.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to a pool or lake', stagnum = pool, lake; an alloy of silver and lead (Latin)
Galerina stagnina.habitat: on wet mossy stream beds, often among Sphagnum riparium, (Smith), single or in small groups; on Sphagnum and other mosses, (Hansen), summer to early fall, (Buczacki)

Galerina stylifera.habitat: gregarious "on buried sticks along roads, around debris and on decaying logs, mostly on coniferous wood", (Smith), fall (Buczacki)

Galerina subbadia.habitat: gregarious on wood of conifers, rarely on moss-covered soil, summer and fall

Galerina 'subbadipes'.odour: slightly mealy [farinaceous] when cut, (from Smith(2) for European material)
Galerina 'subbadipes'.habitat: on decaying monocots (Carex, Typha), also on wet soil among moss, (from Smith(2) for European material)

Galerina subdecurrens.habitat: type cespitose-gregarious "under alder on soil at edge of road"

Galerina subfiliformis.habitat: scattered on wet mossy conifer logs in cold localities

Galerina subochracea.habitat: scattered on debris on wet soil

Galerina subtruncata.nameOrigin: means 'somewhat truncate', probably referring to spores
Galerina subtruncata.habitat: type was scattered on wet soil among mosses

Galerina tibiicystis.nameOrigin: refers to tibiiform shape of cheilocystidia

Galerina triscopa.habitat: gregarious on wood of hardwoods or conifers, summer and fall

Galerina unicolor.edibility: has been synonymized by Gulden(1) with deadly poisonous species
Galerina unicolor.habitat: single or scattered "on sterile or burned-over soil or on moss-covered outwash from glacial streams, but also on conifer debris, very old logs, etc.", "more rarely on hardwood debris or decaying fern fronds in cold habitats"

Galerina vaccinii.habitat: cespitose-gregarious (tufted-gregarious) on duff under Vaccinium deliciosum near or above timber-line

Galerina venenata.taste: "farinaceous but slowly becoming bitter and disagreeable", "leaving a burning sensation in the throat", (Smith), bitterish (Lincoff)
Galerina venenata.habitat: gregarious in lawn, at that point only known from type locality in Oregon, (Smith), in lawns, but may also occur on buried decomposed wood; fruits November to January, (Lincoff), fall to winter

Galerina vialis.habitat: gregarious-subcespitose along a road on soil

Galerina vittiformis.habitat: scattered to gregarious on mossy logs in coniferous forest and perhaps hardwood forest, and among mosses along the margins of woods, (Smith), fall (Buczacki)

Gamundia striatula.nameOrigin: means 'striatulate', referring presumably to striate cap
Gamundia striatula.habitat: gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts]; on or near Peltigera and other lichens, in sandy soil or moss; in the open or under spruce; June to October, (Bigelow), scattered on wet soil among liverworts and mosses, September, (Smith), fall to winter (Buczacki), summer, fall, winter

Gerronema atrialbum.habitat: single, scattered or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on buried wood (alder, oak) or less commonly on logs and sticks above ground, September and October, in California December, (Bigelow), scattered to clustered, on deciduous wood such as alder, maple, and oak, May to November, (Lincoff), in rich humus or on rotting hardwoods (Arora), spring, summer, fall, winter

Gliophorus irrigatus.habitat: gregarious to scattered "on humus and soil, in coniferous and mixed woods, in swamps", (Hesler), "scattered to gregarious on humus or soil in mixed and coniferous woods and in swamps", (Phillips), characterized by grassy habitat (Largent), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Gliophorus laetus.edibility: yes but not worthwhile (Phillips), not edible (Bacon)
Gliophorus laetus.odour: faint or slightly fishy (Phillips), none or faintly disagreeable (fishy), (Hesler), fishy, skunk-like, or (p.65) wet dog-fur, (Miller(14)), "when present, is variously described as burnt rubber, fishy, skunk-like, or pleasantly herbaceous", (Trudell)
Gliophorus laetus.habitat: "scattered to gregarious in damp soil among moss or bracken or in woods", May to December, (Phillips), gregarious on damp soil in woods and on moss in bogs, (Hesler), often in large clusters, "on heaths, in the short grass of meadows, in gardens where no artificial fertiliser has been used, and among moss in moorland", August to November, (Bacon), spring, summer, fall

Gliophorus psittacinus.habitat: single to scattered or in small groups 'in damp soil, moss, humus, etc.', (Arora), gregarious to scattered "in coniferous and deciduous woods, in pastures, and along roadsides", (Hesler), summer to fall (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter

Gloeophyllum sepiarium.nameOrigin: probably derived from Latin 'sepes' meaning a fence or hedge, the adjective being 'sepiarius', referring to the habitat, rather than sepia-colored as was suggested by Gilbertson(1)
Gloeophyllum sepiarium.taste: no particular taste (Lincoff(1)), mild to somewhat bitter (Breitenbach)
Gloeophyllum sepiarium.habitat: single or in groups or overlapping tiers on dead conifers or occasionally dead hardwoods, grows on structural timber, (Arora), annual to perennial, usually on dead conifer wood, more rarely on hardwood, causes a brown rot, (Gilbertson), fruiting in summer and fall (Miller), fruitbodies may be seen year round but spores only produced late summer to fall (Bacon)

Gloiocephala caricis.habitat: scattered on Carex (sedge) or Scirpus under dense leaf cover in open marshes

Gloioxanthomyces nitidus.habitat: "scattered to gregarious on humus in wet, mossy areas under hardwoods", also in bogs, (Phillips), gregarious to scattered "on humus, on wet soil, and in bogs", (Hesler)

Gomphidius glutinosus.spores: smoky gray to blackish (Lincoff(2)), smoke gray (Miller(4))
Gomphidius glutinosus.edibility: yes (Lincoff(2)), good but remove cap cuticle first, (Lincoff(1))
Gomphidius glutinosus.habitat: single to scattered, or occasionally cespitose [in tufts], under many different conifers; June to October, (Miller(4)), under conifers especially spruce (Lincoff(2)), thought to be parasitic on the mycelia of boletes and in the Redwood Coast of California, G. glutinosus appears associated with Suillus ponderosus in Douglas-fir habitat, (Siegel), summer, fall

Gomphidius largus.habitat: gregarious under Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce) in Idaho, and under aspen and spruce in New Mexico, fruits from June in Idaho to July and August in New Mexico, (Miller), summer

Gomphidius maculatus.spores: smoke gray to nearly black, (Miller(4)), olive-black (Lincoff)
Gomphidius maculatus.edibility: yes, good, (peel cap cuticle off first), (Lincoff)
Gomphidius maculatus.habitat: single to gregarious on ground under mixed and pure conifer stands, most frequently associated with species of Larix (larch), (Miller(4)), associated with larches (Moser), in groups in mountains beneath larch (Lincoff), summer through late fall (Miller(14))

Gomphidius oregonensis.habitat: single, scattered or gregarious on ground under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and other conifers, "often in small clumps which originate deep in soil and may include one or more aborted fruiting bodies", (Arora), occasionally single, usually cespitose [in tufts], on ground under conifers, August to November, (Miller), summer, fall

Gomphidius pseudomaculatus.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on ground under conifers including Larix occidentalis (Western Larch), fruiting in late June, (Miller), summer

Gomphidius smithii.habitat: scattered to single under conifers, especially Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Miller(4)), under Douglas-fir, August to November, (Phillips), Gomphidius spp. are thought to be parasitic on the mycelia of boletes and in the Redwood Coast of California, Gomphidius oregonensis appears associated with Suillus lakei in Douglas-fir habitat, (Siegel), summer, fall

Gomphidius subroseus.edibility: edible but bland, peel off skin beforehand, (Arora)
Gomphidius subroseus.habitat: widely scattered to gregarious or occasionally in tufts on ground under conifers, especially Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Arora), single to scattered on ground under conifers especially Picea (spruce), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Abies (fir), fruiting from September to December, in the Rocky Mountains from June to October, (Miller(4)), Gomphidius spp. are thought to be parasitic on the mycelia of boletes and in the Redwood Coast of California, Gomphidius oregonensis appears associated with Suillus lakei in Douglas-fir habitat, (Siegel), summer, fall, winter

Gomphus clavatus.spores: pale tan to pale ocher (Arora), ocher to dark olive-buff (Pilz), yellowish orange (Miller)
Gomphus clavatus.edibility: edible, but some get severe gastric upset
Gomphus clavatus.habitat: scattered to gregarious often in fused pairs or clusters, under conifers, (Arora), closely gregarious to cespitose [in tufts], partially hidden in deep humus under conifers, (Castellano), occasionally gregarious but usually cespitose or in compound clusters which may even occur in arcs or fairy rings, typically on humus though often near very decayed logs, most abundant under conifers, (Smith), late summer and fall (Miller)

Gymnopilus aeruginosus.spores: rusty to rusty orange or rusty cinnamon, (Arora), "orange-rufous", "ferruginous", "xanthine-orange", or "cinnamon rufous", (Hesler), dark reddish orange or brownish rust (Phillips), rusty brown to rusty orange to reddish cinnamon (Stamets)
Gymnopilus aeruginosus.odour: mild, or can be oily farinaceous odor with slight anise component, (Hesler), mild (Phillips)
Gymnopilus aeruginosus.habitat: in groups or clusters on stumps, logs or sawdust of hardwoods and conifers, (Arora), on hardwood and conifer wood (sawdust, timber, logs, stumps), (Hesler), "in tufts on logs or stumps on hardwoods and conifers", May to November, (Phillips), spring, summer, fall

Gymnopilus arenicola.spores: [presumably somewhere from orange to rusty brown]
Gymnopilus arenicola.habitat: on soil, type on sandy soil

Gymnopilus aurantiophyllus.taste: bitter (Hesler(2) for G. aurantiophyllus and for G. subsapineus, Siegel(2))
Gymnopilus aurantiophyllus.habitat: type cespitose [in tufts] on sawdust, (Hesler(2) for G. aurantiophyllus), type on rotting wood, October, (Hesler(2) for G. subsapineus), single, "scattered, or in clumps on wood chips, woody debris, and stumps of pines"; in California fruiting "from fall into winter, or spring in wet years", (Siegel)

Gymnopilus bellulus.habitat: on conifer stumps and logs, sometimes cespitose [in tufts], (Hesler), several to many on conifer stumps and logs; June to January, (Miller), summer, fall, winter

Gymnopilus croceoluteus.nameOrigin: means 'saffron-yellow', croceus = saffron-colored (Latin), crocus = saffron (Crocus sativus) (Latin); luteus = yellow (Latin)
Gymnopilus croceoluteus.spores: [presumably somewhere from orange to rusty brown]
Gymnopilus croceoluteus.habitat: on conifers, June to November, (Hesler), summer, fall

Gymnopilus flavidellus.odour: not distinctive or slightly aromatic to radish-like
Gymnopilus flavidellus.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on coniferous and deciduous wood (stump, buried wood, fallen limbs, sawdust), fall-winter

Gymnopilus humicola.nameOrigin: means 'living in humus', or 'living on ground'
Gymnopilus humicola.spores: [presumably somewhere from orange to rusty brown]
Gymnopilus humicola.habitat: on humus in coniferous and deciduous woods, June to September, (Hesler), summer, fall

Gymnopilus 'junonius'.spores: "zinc orange" or duller rusty brown, (Hesler, Smith), rusty orange (Stamets)
Gymnopilus 'junonius'.edibility: inedible due to bitter taste, hallucinogenic in some areas of world, apparently not on west coast, (Stamets)
Gymnopilus 'junonius'.odour: slight or rarely strong (of licorice in one case), (Hesler), slight (Smith), none (Miller)
Gymnopilus 'junonius'.habitat: on conifer and deciduous logs, stumps, living and dead trunks, or buried wood, (Hesler), "spring, summer, fall to early winter on the West Coast", (Miller)

Gymnopilus liquiritiae.odour: "mild, or slightly aromatic, fragrant, or of raw potatoes"
Gymnopilus liquiritiae.habitat: more or less cespitose [in tufts] on conifer wood and sawdust, occasionally hardwood, (Hesler), in tight clusters on old wood, often burned wood (logs that were partly burned in past forest fires) (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)

Gymnopilus luteofolius.edibility: unknown (Arora), said to be hallucinogenic according to anecdotal reports, (Stamets)
Gymnopilus luteofolius.habitat: in groups or clusters "on decaying coniferous wood, sawdust, wood chips, and humus rich in lignin (rarely on hardwoods)", (Arora), cespitose to subcespitose, on wood (sawdust, logs, stumps of conifers, more rarely on oak and cottonwood), (Hesler), common on woody debris "and on wood chips used in nurseries and landscaping", (Stamets)

Gymnopilus magnus.spores: [presumably somewhere from orange to rusty brown]
Gymnopilus magnus.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] about the base of trees, August to October, (Hesler), summer, fall

Gymnopilus penetrans.habitat: on wood of conifers and hardwoods, at times on sawdust, summer and fall, (Hesler), "singly or in small tufts on hardwoods and conifers", July to October, (Phillips), common on conifer and hardwood stumps, logs, wood chips, and sawdust, (Trudell), summer, fall

Gymnopilus picreus.taste: mild or bitterish, (Hesler), not distinctive or slightly bitter (Bessette)
Gymnopilus picreus.habitat: on conifer wood and sometimes on hardwood, (Hesler), "scattered or in groups on decaying logs and stumps in mixed woods", July to October, (Bessette), summer, fall

Gymnopilus punctifolius.odour: "pleasant, not distinctive", (Phillips), "agreeable or not distinctive" (Hesler), not distinctive (Bessette)
Gymnopilus punctifolius.habitat: singly or scattered "on debris, rich humus, and coniferous wood"; August to December, (Phillips), on coniferous wood, debris, and rich humus, (Hesler), "scattered, in groups or clusters on the ground or on decaying wood under conifers", (Bessette), summer, fall, winter

Gymnopilus rufescens.habitat: single or in small clusters "on decaying conifer wood", "especially in dark, wet areas"; late fall, winter, early spring, (Siegel)

Gymnopilus rufobrunneus.spores: [presumably somewhere from orange to rusty brown]

Gymnopilus sapineus.spores: amber-orange to rusty orange to bright rusty brown, (Arora), "hazel" or "amber brown" (Ridgway(1) colors), (Hesler), rusty orange (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Gymnopilus sapineus.habitat: single to scattered or in small tufts or groups "on rotting logs, cones, and humus rich in lignin", under conifers, especially pine, (Arora), subcespitose [more or less in tufts] or gregarious to scattered, on wood of conifers and hardwoods, and on sawdust, (Hesler), always under spruce (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), summer and fall (Miller)

Gymnopilus sordidostipes.spores: [presumably somewhere from orange to rusty brown]

Gymnopilus subsapineus.spores: [presumably somewhere from orange to rusty brown]
Gymnopilus subsapineus.habitat: type on rotting wood, October, (Hesler), fall

Gymnopilus terrestris.habitat: on soil and humus, under conifers, June to October, (Hesler), summer, fall

Gymnopilus ventricosus.edibility: inedible due to bitter taste, hallucinogenic in some areas of world, apparently not on west coast
Gymnopilus ventricosus.odour: Hesler gives mild or pleasant odor for members of this subgenus where recorded, except one collection from New Hampshire with strong licorice odor, (Hesler)
Gymnopilus ventricosus.habitat: usually in clusters, occasionally single, on or around stumps and trees, (Arora), fall, winter

Gymnopilus viridans.spores: [presumably somewhere from orange to rusty brown]
Gymnopilus viridans.habitat: type in tufts on burnt coniferous log, October to November, (Hesler), fall

Gymnopilus voitkii.nameOrigin: "Honouring Dr. Andrus Voitk for his contributions to mycology in Canada, particularly Newfoundland and Labrador, where the new species commonly occurs"
Gymnopilus voitkii.odour: often with a complex odor described as "mushroom mixed with sweat, coconut, or mint"
Gymnopilus voitkii.habitat: on wood of conifers, mostly commonly Abies (true fir) but also on Picea (spruce); typically "on basal wounds of living trees, but also on dead trees and logs"

Gymnopus alkalivirens.nameOrigin: refers to green reaction with alkali, al-kali = potash (Arabic), virens = becoming green (Latin)
Gymnopus alkalivirens.habitat: single, scattered, gregarious, or cespitose [in tufts], "on soil, among moss, leaf litter, decaying wood debris, or old fern hummocks"; occurring in hardwood forests during June and July in New England, (Halling(2)), "singly or in groups on soil, moss, or very rotten conifer wood", May to July in eastern North America, October to December in the Northwest, (Phillips), spring, summer, fall, winter

Gymnopus androsaceus.nameOrigin: comes from a Greek name for an unknown marine plant according to one source or an alpine dwarf herb according to another (androsaces)
Gymnopus androsaceus.taste: mild (Desjardin), lacking or rarely somewhat bitter (Gilliam)
Gymnopus androsaceus.habitat: scattered or in troops "on needles, twigs, or leaves", (Arora), gregarious "on senescent needles and leaves (rarely bark)" of pine, Sequoia sempervirens (redwood), "hardwoods, or rarely fern fronds, in mixed coniferous-hardwood forests", (Desjardin for California), on "coniferous debris (needles, twigs, cones, bark), especially pine, also ericaceous debris (parasitic on some ericaceous plants), and occasionally plant litter of adjacent species, in mesic and boggy situations", (Redhead(6)), June to October (Gilliam), summer, fall

Gymnopus aquosus.habitat: saprotrophic, "usually gregarious, terrestrial and in humus, among grass", on roadsides, and hardwood, rarely coniferous forest; fruiting "April to June, less frequently August to October", (Antonin), "on well-decayed leaf litter", mostly in hardwood forests, "but also in boggy habitats and mixed forests", (Laessoe)

Gymnopus brassicolens.nameOrigin: means "smelling of Brassica", the genus of several vegetables including cabbage
Gymnopus brassicolens.odour: like "rotting cabbage or kale, sometimes reported as garlicky or like sewer gas"
Gymnopus brassicolens.habitat: in clumps or troops, "sometimes in large contiguous patches on wood chips or in decaying leaf litter in urban habitats and other disturbed areas", occasionally in forested habitats; fruiting "primarily in fall and winter, but can occur any time of year"

Gymnopus bulliformis.nameOrigin: means "bubble-like, referring to the appearance of cheilocystidia at lamellar edge"
Gymnopus bulliformis.habitat: dead conifer needles in temperate rain forest, mid-summer

Gymnopus contrarius.odour: "slightly alliaceous, strongly of garlic or rotten cabbage"
Gymnopus contrarius.habitat: gregarious on needles of spruce and balsam fir

Gymnopus dryophilus.spores: white to pale yellowish white when fresh, pale yellowish when dry, (Halling), white or pale cream (Arora), white to pale yellowish (Beug(6))
Gymnopus dryophilus.edibility: yes but some people are sensitive, only the caps are tender enough, it is a proficient concentrator of mercury, (Arora), yes but probably should not be eaten when attacked by Collybia jelly, (Lincoff(2)), good tasting, but sometimes causes gastrointestinal upset; discard the stems, (Ammirati)
Gymnopus dryophilus.taste: mild to slightly unpleasant in older fruiting bodies, (Halling)
Gymnopus dryophilus.odour: none to mild (Halling), none to pleasant, of peaches, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Gymnopus dryophilus.habitat: scattered to gregarious or sometimes cespitose [in tufts] on humus or well-decayed wood in conifer-hardwood forests, from June through September, (Halling), scattered to gregarious or in small tufts "in woods or near trees, often forming arcs or rings", (Arora), May to November (Lincoff(2)), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Gymnopus dysodes.odour: "pungent, like old onions or garlic", also referred to as "fetid"
Gymnopus dysodes.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] among woodchips

Gymnopus erythropus.odour: "fragrant mushroom-like when many fruit bodies present, otherwise not distinctive"
Gymnopus erythropus.habitat: scattered to cespitose [in tufts] on decaying wood, (Halling), usually found in tight clusters (Trudell), fall (Buczacki)

Gymnopus fragillior.nameOrigin: means "more fragile", referring to the more diminutive stature than Paragymnopus perforans
Gymnopus fragillior.habitat: on individual conifer needles of ?Abies grandis (Grand Fir)

Gymnopus fuscopurpureus.habitat: in humus in coniferous forest (Guzman), usually in small +/- tufted groups, fall, (Buczacki)

Gymnopus fusipes.habitat: usually in clusters, on stumps and roots, sometimes apparently on bare soil, (Breitenbach), grows at base of hardwoods especially beech and oak, (Kirkwood for Europe), growing from fruiting bodies of previous years (Lincoff), spring, fall, winter, (Buczacki)

Gymnopus glabrosipes.nameOrigin: from "glabro-", smooth, plus "pes", foot, referring to the glabrous-shining stem
Gymnopus glabrosipes.habitat: fruiting on dead Tsuga (hemlock) needles, mid-summer

Gymnopus impudicus.taste: "very strong, unpleasant, like rotten cabbage, sometimes with a garlic component"
Gymnopus impudicus.odour: "very strong, unpleasant, like rotten cabbage, sometimes with a garlic component", (Antonin), stinks but not of garlic (Moser), cabbage-like (Laessoe)
Gymnopus impudicus.habitat: saprotrophic, "usually in small groups in humus or on small twigs", in juniper heaths and hardwood and mixed forests, "less frequently in coniferous forest or on wood chips of conifers"; [one of the illustrations shows tufted groups of 3-4 fruitbodies]; fruiting July to October in Europe, (Antonin), in "small trooping or tufted groups"; on acidic soil, "often on or with heather or bracken, also wood chip mulch", (Buczacki)

Gymnopus ocior.habitat: saprotrophic; "terrestrial, usually gregarious, among moss and grass, sometimes also on rotten wood", in hardwood and coniferous woods, on forest roads, etc.; fruiting April to October

Gymnopus polyphyllus.spores: white when fresh, cream buff after storage, (Halling), white to cream (Bessette)
Gymnopus polyphyllus.habitat: scattered, gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on hardwood leaf litter, (Halling), scattered, in groups, or cespitose on leaf litter, (Bessette), in tufts of 5 or more loosely joined together at the bases (Kirkwood)

Gymnopus putillus.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on humus and needle litter under pine", (Halling), gregarious on needle beds of pine, (Smith)

Gymnopus quinaultii.nameOrigin: refers to Lake Quinault and the Quinault River in Washington, the area where the type was found
Gymnopus quinaultii.habitat: fruiting on debris of Thuja plicata (red-cedar), (less on associated Abies and Tsuga needles), fall

Gymnopus 'spongiosus'.nameOrigin: could refer to the often spongy stem base
Gymnopus 'spongiosus'.habitat: single, scattered, gregarious or cespitose "on leaf and needle litter" in pine, mixed or hardwood forests, rarely on sand; fruiting "July to October in eastern North America", "also during February and December in Louisiana and Florida"

'Gymnopus' striatipes.taste: "absent or slightly unpleasant to bitterish", (Halling), not distinctive (Smith(47))
'Gymnopus' striatipes.habitat: gregarious to scattered or cespitose [in tufts], on leaf litter or rotten stumps, (Halling), clustered to gregarious on debris of alder and cottonwood and in coniferous forests, fall, (Smith(6)), gregarious to scattered under alder (Kirkwood, Smith(47))

Gymnopus vernus.habitat: single to somewhat gregarious, on buried wood and fallen leaves, under Alnus (alder), Acer (maple), Corylus (hazelnut), "immediately after snowmelt, montane to subalpine", March to May

Harmajaea harperi.taste: not distinctive or sometimes rancid farinaceous or pungent and disagreeable
Harmajaea harperi.odour: not distinctive or sometimes rancid farinaceous or pungent and disagreeable
Harmajaea harperi.habitat: single or scattered, on humus under mixed woods, hardwoods, or conifers (often spruce), fall and winter (September to February)

Hebeloma aanenii.nameOrigin: in honor of Duur Aanen "to whom we are deeply indebted for carrying out extensive research on biological mating between Hebeloma spp. as well as molecular analysis" [Latin names italicized]
Hebeloma aanenii.spores: "brownish olive to greyish brown and umber [italicized]"
Hebeloma aanenii.habitat: often single, "usually scattered and occasionally caespitose"; recorded with a wide range of trees and shrubs, both hardwood and coniferous, "in all types of woodland, parkland and scrubland", on path-sides, on slag heaps, on dunes, "and rarely in alpine and arctic habitats"

Hebeloma albidulum.habitat: gregarious to more or less in tufts on ground in mixed or deciduous woods, (Kauffman), gregarious under grass and weeds and various shrubs such as Vaccinium (Smith(44)), among fallen leaves in hardwood stands (Smith(6))

Hebeloma album.habitat: among fallen leaves in woods, October

Hebeloma alpinicola.habitat: type under Pinus albicaulis (Smith), "gregarious, sometimes in ring, sometimes cespitose, but not completely joined", 2 collections from alpine areas over 3000 meters, with Salix (willow) or Salix and Dryas, (Cripps)

Hebeloma amarellum.nameOrigin: a diminutive form of 'amarum', which means 'bitter'
Hebeloma amarellum.habitat: holotype gregarious on cow dung in a pasture in California (Smith(7)), other collections have been found in association with Picea, Tsuga or Pseudotsuga, (Henry Beker, pers. comm.)

Hebeloma angelesiense.nameOrigin: type found at Mt. Angeles Washington
Hebeloma angelesiense.habitat: type gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] near conifers

Hebeloma arenosum.habitat: cespitose [in tufts], in conifer seedling nursery beds, and the most frequent Hebeloma in the nursery beds; occasionally in spring but most commonly in late summer or fall

Hebeloma aurantiellum.habitat: type found in mixed conifer-hardwood forest

Hebeloma avellaneum.nameOrigin: for the color of hazelnuts, such as Corylus avellana (Cripps(7))
Hebeloma avellaneum.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious under conifers, (Smith), cespitose [tufted], or clustered, in Colorado two collections in low alpine krummholz [stunted windblown trees near tree-line] with conifers and willows, (Cripps)

Hebeloma cavipes.spores: "Isabella to brownish olive to umber [italicized]", (Beker), olive-brown (Breitenbach)
Hebeloma cavipes.taste: "mild to weakly bitter, sometimes raphanoid [italicized]", (Beker), somewhat bitter and radish-like, (Breitenbach), weak of radish (Huijsman)
Hebeloma cavipes.odour: usually raphanoid [radish-like], occasionally absent, (Beker), faintly radish-like, (Breitenbach), weakly radish-like when cut (Huijsman)
Hebeloma cavipes.habitat: scattered, rarely single; recorded with a wide variety of different trees and shrubs, both hardwoods and conifers; in gardens, pathsides, roadsides, scrubland, woodland including plantations, parklands, dunes, and slag-heaps, not known from alpine or arctic habitats, (Beker)

Hebeloma colvinii.nameOrigin: in honor of its discoverer, Mr. V. Colvin
Hebeloma colvinii.habitat: sandy soil in open places, (Kauffman), scattered, on dunes and sandy beaches, etc., late summer and fall, (Smith)

Hebeloma crustuliniforme.spores: brownish olive (Beker), brown (Arora), rust-brown (Phillips), yellow-brown to brown (Miller)
Hebeloma crustuliniforme.edibility: poisonous, causing mild to severe gastrointestinal distress, (Arora), clinical effects in European accounts are similar to those produced by muscarine but some gastrointestinal effects are also present, (Smith(15))
Hebeloma crustuliniforme.taste: "mild to weakly bitter, often raphanoid" (italicized), (Beker), bitter (Phillips), radish-like or more spicy, (Smith(15))
Hebeloma crustuliniforme.odour: raphanoid [radish-like], sometimes strongly, (Beker), distinctly radish-like, (Arora), usually strongly radish-like, but odor may be faint, particularly if fruitbodies have stood for a time before being collected, (Smith(15))
Hebeloma crustuliniforme.habitat: usually scattered but sometimes single or cespitose; associated with hardwoods or conifers; soil "base-rich, grassy or sandy", found in parks, in gardens, on pathsides, on roadsides, in woodland, on plantations, or in dunes, not known from arctic or alpine areas, (Beker), single, scattered or in groups or troops on ground in woods or in grass near trees, (Arora), September to November, in California through May, (Phillips), scattered, gregarious, or in fairy rings or arcs in pastures, open woods and forests, in fall and less commonly in spring, (Smith(15)), late summer to late fall (Bacon), summer, fall, winter, spring

Hebeloma excedens.nameOrigin: named for the cap cuticle which can exceed [extending beyond] the gills
Hebeloma excedens.habitat: in alpine Colorado with Salix glauca (Shrub Willow), in New York at approximately 100 meters altitude with Pinus (pine) "on sandy soil in woodland"

Hebeloma helodes.nameOrigin: means "frequenting marshes" from Greek: Favre collected this species in peaty places
Hebeloma helodes.habitat: usually scattered, rarely gregarious or single; recorded from under a variety of hardwoods, the "medium has been recorded as base-rich and base-poor, as sandy or grassy and often as wet", "often on the side of a path or road"

Hebeloma 'hiemale'.nameOrigin: from "hiemalis" - winter and wintery, "presumably to emphasise Bresadola's view that this species produces basidiomes late in the autumn and during spring"
Hebeloma 'hiemale'.spores: "Isabella or greyish brown through brownish olive to umber [italicized]"
Hebeloma 'hiemale'.odour: raphanoid [radish-like] "sometimes with hints of cocoa, rarely absent [italicized]", (Beker(1)), raphanoid [radish-like], faint, (Cripps)
Hebeloma 'hiemale'.habitat: usually scattered, sometimes single and occasionally cespitose and gregarious, with a variety of coniferous trees, hardwoods, and shrubs, in woodlands, dunes, scrubland, parkland, gardens, arctic areas, and alpine areas, often on pathsides and slag heaps; the substrate ranges "from base-poor to base-rich and clayey soils", both on litter-covered and grassy ground, sometimes very wet, (Beker(1)), in the alpine zone with dwarf willows, Dryas, and Betula (birch), (Cripps)

Hebeloma idahoense.habitat: type scattered under conifers mostly Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce)

Hebeloma immutabile.nameOrigin: means 'not changing', perhaps referring to non-darkening stem

Hebeloma incarnatulum.spores: dingy reddish cinnamon (Smith), "brownish olive to cinnamon or umber or sepia" (italicized) (Beker)
Hebeloma incarnatulum.taste: bitterish to radish-like, +/- nauseous, (Smith), radish-like, sometimes mild, sometimes bitter, (Beker)
Hebeloma incarnatulum.habitat: single to scattered on living Sphagnum moss, (Smith), seems to favor mossy areas, sphagnum or otherwise, (Trudell), usually scattered, 16 of 17 collections were recorded with Sphagnum and all cite conifers as the most likely mycorrhizal partner, (Beker)

Hebeloma kelloggense.nameOrigin: means 'from Kellogg' where type was found in Idaho

Hebeloma lateritium.nameOrigin: refers to the 'lateritius' color on the cap, a dark brick red
Hebeloma lateritium.habitat: gregarious "on sandy soil at the edge of a forest, Seattle", "October 20-November 1, 1911"

Hebeloma lutescentipes.habitat: type on humus at edge of beaver pond

Hebeloma megacarpum.habitat: holotype cespitose [tufted] to gregarious in mixed hardwood-conifer forest, (Smith(44))

Hebeloma mesophaeum.spores: "Dresden brown" fresh, near "sayal brown" as air-dried, (Smith), "Isabella to brownish olive to umber" (italicized), (Beker), rusty to mud-brown, yellow or olive-brown
Hebeloma mesophaeum.taste: of radish to not distinctive, usually becoming bitterish, (Smith), "mild to bitter, sometimes raphanoid", (italicized), (Beker) typically radish-like, but can be mild or bitter
Hebeloma mesophaeum.odour: of radish to not distinctive (Smith), usually raphanoid, rarely no odor, (Beker), typically radish-like, but can be mild or pungent or unpleasant
Hebeloma mesophaeum.habitat: single to gregarious or clustered on soil under conifers, especially Picea (spruce), late fall, summer, and early spring, (Smith), single to gregarious and sometimes cespitose, with many different hardwood and coniferous associates, "on burnt as well as on grassy or mossy ground and on gravelly, wet or base soil" (italicized), even on wood chips; found on pathsides, in parklands, in woodlands, in alpine and arctic areas, in gardens, in dunes, in lava fields and on slag-heaps, (Beker), widely scattered to densely gregarious on ground or in grass in woods and near trees or bushes

Hebeloma nigromaculatum.habitat: type was gregarious on moss in sandy soil under Pinus (pine) and Tsuga (hemlock)

Hebeloma ollaliense.nameOrigin: after Ollalie Lake in Oregon where the holotype was found

Hebeloma olympianum.nameOrigin: type found in Olympic National Park
Hebeloma olympianum.habitat: type found on soil along a trail

Hebeloma oregonense.habitat: type found gregarious to scattered on humus in an open area

Hebeloma palustre.nameOrigin: from palustris, Latin for marshy or swampy
Hebeloma palustre.odour: raphanoid, sometimes with hints of cocoa (Beker)
Hebeloma palustre.habitat: scattered, favours boreal habitats; all our collections are from latitudes greater than 50 degrees north or between 45 degrees north and 50 deg north, but then at altitudes no lower than about 1000 meters; the ground is usually described as wet and often as boggy and covered with moss; the associates appear to be Betula (birch), Picea (spruce) and Salix (willow), holotype under Fagus, (Beker(1), but in Eberhardt(3), they say H. clavulipes and H. oreophilum are the same species with a range of habitats from lowland to alpine; Beker(1) said that the habitat of H. oreophilum is arctic/alpine, associated with Salix and possibly Dryas, scattered, mostly "from base-poor, mossy ground"), mossy ground in swampy woods (Peck)

Hebeloma parcivelum.habitat: type gregarious at edge of alder bog

Hebeloma perigoense.nameOrigin: after Perigo in Gilpin County, Colorado, where type found

Hebeloma pinetorum.habitat: type found gregarious under Gaultheria shallon (salal), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), etc.

Hebeloma praeolidum.odour: heavy and sweetly aromatic (sickening in time)

Hebeloma pungens.nameOrigin: means 'sharp' or 'acrid' and refers to odor
Hebeloma pungens.odour: pungent but soon gone (radish-like but sharper, almost as sharp as garlic)
Hebeloma pungens.habitat: type found cespitose [in tufts] on soil under pine

Hebeloma sacchariolens.taste: mild to slightly bitter (Beker), sweetish (Lincoff), bitter (Courtecuisse)
Hebeloma sacchariolens.odour: sweet, variously described as burnt sugar, sweetish reminiscent of orange blossoms (Citrus) or meadowsweet (Filipendula), (Beker), "strong, penetrating, very sweet and aromatic, like burnt sugar, orange blossom, or fruit candy", (Phillips), distinctive, of orange blossom or caramel, (Lincoff), exceptionally sweetish, like fruit sweets, orange-blossom, etc., (Moser), strong, sweet, fruity, soapy, sickly, (Buczacki)
Hebeloma sacchariolens.habitat: scattered, sometimes gregarious, occasionally cespitose, associated with hardwoods, most records "from bare or grassy ground with occasionally sandy and often base-rich soils", "often recorded in parkland, gardens, slag-heaps or on woodland pathsides", (Beker for Europe), gregarious under pine (Phillips), in woodland, or sometimes in grassland, (Lincoff), damp places, with alders or willows, (Moser for Europe), hardwood forests, under shrubs, (Hansen for Europe), hardwoods, not especially favoring damp sites, (Courtecuisse for Europe), fall (Buczacki)

Hebeloma salmonense.nameOrigin: means "from Salmon", type found at Salmon River
Hebeloma salmonense.habitat: type gregarious in brushy areas along an old ditch

Hebeloma sinapizans.spores: dull brown (Arora), medium to reddish brown (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), red-brown (Buczacki)
Hebeloma sinapizans.odour: usually distinctly radish-like (Arora), distinctly of radishes, (Smith(15)), very strongly of radish or of raw potatoes (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Hebeloma sinapizans.habitat: scattered to gregarious, sometimes in fairy rings, "on ground under both hardwoods and conifers or near planted trees on lawns", (Arora), usually found in large numbers growing cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious or scattered; favors hardwood forests or thinly wooded hillsides in Michigan, in a pine-oak forest in Oregon, (Smith(15)), fall (Buczacki)

Hebeloma species^.spores: ochraceous to clay color to various shades of reddish brown or cinnamon brown, rarely purplish brown
Hebeloma species^.habitat: single to gregarious to tufted on soil in conifer or hardwood forests, on sand dunes, disturbed soil, or on stream banks or outwash areas along streams, spring, summer and fall, typically abundant late summer and fall, most species are mycorrhiza formers with forest trees and shrubs

Hebeloma stanleyense.habitat: type on duff under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine)

Hebeloma sterlingii.nameOrigin: after E.B. Sterling, collector of the type
Hebeloma sterlingii.habitat: under spruce (Phillips), single to gregarious under spruce (Smith)

Hebeloma subhepaticum.habitat: scattered to gregarious under Sitka spruce

Hebeloma 'syrjense'.habitat: single to several or clustered, on the ground under hardwoods, September to October

Hebeloma theobrominum.odour: cocoa-like to faintly radish-like, "especially when cut"
Hebeloma theobrominum.habitat: under conifers and hardwoods, mainly on calcareous soil, August to October in northern Europe

Hebeloma velutipes.nameOrigin: from 'velutinus', Latin for 'velvety' and 'pes', Latin for 'foot', referring to the velvety stem
Hebeloma velutipes.taste: "usually bitter and raphanoid" (Beker), "somewhat raphanoid and slightly astringent", (Breitenbach)
Hebeloma velutipes.habitat: single or scattered, sometimes gregarious, few collections cespitose, "on base-poor, base-rich, clayey and sandy soils and from grassy or mossy ground", seems to have a preference for hardwoods, but appears to be associated with both hardwoods and conifers, or with Helianthemum (rock rose), (Beker(1) for Europe), gregarious, more rarely single, in Switzerland "usually outside forests, in park grounds" under Betula (birch) and Corylus (hazel), fruiting in fall, (Breitenbach)

Hebeloma vinaceogriseum.habitat: type gregarious on wet soil in a horse corral

Heliocybe sulcata.habitat: on dry, bare logs and even on piers and fences, causing a brown rot, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), on dry habitats such as debarked, dry wood in rail fences or debarked fallen trees, (Smith), on often raised, debarked, hardwood or conifer wood, Saguaro cactus, mesquite, and ocotillo, in xeric [dry] sites, (Redhead(6)), "fairly common on decorticated, exposed wood in xeric sites in North America", (Redhead(22))

Hemimycena albicolor.habitat: type gregarious on twigs of Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) (Smith), scattered to gregarious on bits of herbaceous and woody debris in stand of Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Pachistima myrisinites (myrtle boxwood) (Redhead)

Hemimycena albidula^;.habitat: scattered to gregarious on bark and fallen leaves of hardwoods, later summer and fall

Hemimycena cyphelloides.habitat: restricted to growth on monocot debris in wet areas

Hemimycena gracilis.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious under conifers, especially Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), during spring and summer, reported from deciduous woods, from sphagnum bogs, (Smith), especially on debris of Picea, fall season, (Hansen, L. for Europe)

Hemimycena hirsuta.habitat: on woody or herbaceous debris including monocot litter, leaves, coniferous litter, Douglas-fir cones, all of which are damp

Hemimycena lactea.habitat: scattered to gregarious on fallen twigs and conifer needles, late summer and fall, (Smith)

Hemimycena leucophaea.nameOrigin: means "white and dark", leucos = white (Greek), phaios = dark (Greek)
Hemimycena leucophaea.habitat: type collected among dead needles and sticks in a coniferous forest
