Hemimycena mauretanica.habitat: scattered on dead leaves (Smith collections), gregarious on alder bark (Mains collection), on debris, e.g. of ferns, rarely of conifers, (Hansen)

Hemimycena nebulophila.nameOrigin: means 'mist-loving' or 'cloud-loving' and refers to its habitat in the spray zone or mist of a waterfall
Hemimycena nebulophila.habitat: gregarious on dripping wet gametophytes of moss in spray zone of a montane waterfall

Hemimycena pseudocrispula.habitat: gregarious on rhododendron leaves and conifer needles, (Smith); Smith's Mycena litoralis [which Redhead maintains is this species] found on fern debris (Smith), single to grouped on decomposing leaves lying on ground, fine roots, petioles of Petasites, and herbaceous stems, summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Hemimycena subimmaculata.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on dead wood in woods near Seattle, (Smith), on plant debris, summer to fall, (Hansen)

Hemimycena substellata.habitat: gregarious "on the undersides of water-soaked or wet, decorticated, soft-decayed conifer wood in debris jams along a flood stream course of a steep ravine in the Subalpine forest region"

Hemimycena tortuosa.nameOrigin: means 'twisted', likely referring to the corkscrew-like pileocystidia and caulocystidia
Hemimycena tortuosa.habitat: "loose bark of senescent deciduous and coniferous trees in wet coastal forests", (Redhead), on wood and bark of hardwoods and conifers, "sometimes on undersides of large fallen logs and also on small woody fragments at stream- and pond-sides", fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)

Hemipholiota populnea.edibility: yes, but rather tough and poorly flavored (Arora)
Hemipholiota populnea.taste: "slightly disagreeable but hardly distinctive", (Smith), somewhat bitter but sometimes sweetish, (Lincoff(1)), unpleasant, bitter, (Buczacki)
Hemipholiota populnea.habitat: single or in groups or clusters "on dead cottonwood and poplar or sometimes aspen or willow, especially on the cut ends of logs", (Arora), on logs and dead wood of Populus, "especially cottonwood and balsam poplar late in the fall", (Smith)

Hemistropharia albocrenulata.edibility: said to be harmless but seldom eaten, (Arora)
Hemistropharia albocrenulata.habitat: single or in small groups (2s and 3s) on stumps, logs, and living trees, usually hardwoods (especially maple and elm), (Arora who also found it once on Ponderosa Pine), single or groups of 2 or 3 on trunks, stumps, and logs (of maple and perhaps other hardwoods, rarely on hemlock), July to October, (Smith), summer, fall

Hodophilus paupertinus.spores: white spore deposit noted for a Hodophilus sp. (Bessette)
Hodophilus paupertinus.odour: very strong, distinctive odor of mothballs, (Siegel), "exceedingly strong, penetrating, disagreeable", (Hesler), collections from Royal Road on Vancouver Island BC smelled distinctly of naphthalene mothballs (Ian Gibson, pers. comm.)
Hodophilus paupertinus.habitat: in California, scattered, "in small clusters or troops in duff or on bare soil under redwood and other conifers, typically in disturbed areas such as trailsides or along old logging roads", fruiting from late fall into spring, often near Trichoglossum and Clavaria spp., (Siegel), gregarious on humus and soil under redwoods in California, (Hesler), in mixed forest in October, November, February (BC collections)

Hohenbuehelia cyphelliformis.nameOrigin: means in the shape of a goblet or cup
Hohenbuehelia cyphelliformis.habitat: on dead twigs, or stems of woody biennial or perennial dicotyledonous plants in rich, moist environments; Ontario specimens on Arctium and Heracleum in moist "old fields", also reported on Anethum, Angelica, Clematis, Morus, Penstemon, Sambucus, Solanum, Thapsia, and Ulmus, (Thorn(5)), on dead twigs of woody dicotyledonous plants, (Thorn(2), Watling), fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)

Hohenbuehelia mastrucata.habitat: single or scattered, "occasionally as overlapping shelves" on well-decayed hardwoods, in California on tanoak, late fall and winter, (Siegel(2)), scattered on standing dead hardwood tree trunks or on sides of downed hardwood logs, early fall to spring, (Siegel(3))

Hohenbuehelia petaloides.edibility: yes, but not choice (Arora quoting other sources)
Hohenbuehelia petaloides.habitat: "Usually in groups or small clusters on rotting or buried wood, sawdust mulch, etc.", (Arora), "On soil in lawns, planting beds, or with potted plants, often associated with woody debris", (Thorn), on hardwood (Watling), fall (Buczacki)

Hohenbuehelia unguicularis.habitat: on dead trunks and branches of hardwoods, with or without bark; "An unusual feature of this species is that is fruits in spring or early summer, or in warm periods during winter", (Thorn(2)), on hardwood, late fall and winter, (Hansen, L.)

Homophron camptopodum.habitat: scattered to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on rotten hardwood logs

Homophron cernuum.nameOrigin: probably refers to the white-crenulate gill edges
Homophron cernuum.habitat: the type densely gregarious to subcespitose in moss around base of a living cottonwood tree

Homophron naucoria.habitat: type gregarious to scattered on very decayed alder logs, August, (Smith), summer

Homophron naucorioides.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious on cottonwood logs

Homophron spadiceum.nameOrigin: means "with the color of fresh dates"
Homophron spadiceum.spores: dark grayish brown to chocolate-brown, (Smith), red-brown (Breitenbach, but illustration of spore deposit color is not very red)
Homophron spadiceum.habitat: on ground or on bases of stumps and trees of Populus species, commonly clustered, (Smith), generally clustered "in forests, parks, or on pathsides, on stumps, roots, or on the base of living hardwoods" such as Aesculus, Betula, Castanea, Fagus, (Breitenbach for Europe), late summer to late fall or winter (Buczacki)

Humidicutis marginata.habitat: single on very rotten conifer wood (Hesler), single on decayed conifer wood (Phillips)

Hydropus 'marginellus'.habitat: scattered to gregarious on confer logs, spring and fall, (Smith), scattered to gregarious on conifer wood (Abies, Pinus) in forests, (Castellano), "generally gregarious to clustered", more rarely single; exclusively on stumps of Abies (true fir); fruiting in summer, (Breitenbach)

Hydropus pseudotenax.habitat: gregarious in troops in needle beds under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas fir) and Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) or under scattered conifers in pastures

Hygrocybe 'acutoconica'.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on ground in woods or under trees", (Arora), single to scattered on soil and humus, under hardwoods, conifers, or in mixed woods, April - January, (Hesler), spring, summer, fall, winter

Hygrocybe americana.habitat: singly under fir and redwood, September to December, (Hesler), fall, winter

Hygrocybe 'aurantiosplendens'.habitat: single, scattered, or in small clusters, "in duff, moss, or soil", generally under Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood) or Umbellularia californica (California Bay Laurel), (in California)

Hygrocybe cantharellus.nameOrigin: means "a small cup" but may refer to Cantharellus
Hygrocybe cantharellus.habitat: single or gregarious "on moist to mesic, sandy, loamy or peaty soils and on very decayed stumps and logs" in hardwood and mixed forests, often along trails, occasionally in bogs, (Arnolds), gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] "on rich humus, soil, decaying logs, moss-covered logs, in bogs", July to October, (Hesler), "in groups or clusters in rich soil, bogs, or on decaying and moss-covered logs", (Phillips), summer and fall (Miller)

Hygrocybe ceracea.habitat: scattered to gregarious on moss and soil, July to January, (Hesler), turf (Courtecuisse for Europe), often in clusters in damp places in mixed forest, sometimes in grassy areas, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), summer, fall, winter

Hygrocybe 'chlorophana'.habitat: on soil in open woods, April to October (Phillips), on soil in open woods, April to October, (Hesler), turf, grassy places, (Courtecuisse for Europe), spring, summer, fall

Hygrocybe coccinea.edibility: said to be edible but easily confused with H. punicea (Arora)
Hygrocybe coccinea.habitat: single, scattered or in small groups in woods and other wet places, in England it grows mainly in open fields, (Arora), gregarious on soil "in deciduous, coniferous, and mixed woods", (Hesler), on soil "among short turf, pastures, meadows, coastal areas, heathland", not usually in woodland; usually in small groups, trooping; late summer to fall, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Hygrocybe coccineocrenata.habitat: gregarious to scattered in Sphagnum bogs

Hygrocybe 'conica'.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious "on ground in damp places (usually in woods)", (Arora), gregarious or singly; spring, summer, fall, and winter, (Hesler), normally fruits in fall, but occasionally in spring, (Trudell)

Hygrocybe cuspidata.habitat: in groups on ground in mixed woods, June-August, (Bessette(2)), gregarious on humus and soil, under hardwoods or conifers or in mixed woods, May to August, (Hesler), spring, summer

Hygrocybe 'flavescens'.edibility: yes, but little substance or taste, (Arora)
Hygrocybe 'flavescens'.habitat: single to scattered or in small groups on ground, usually in woods, (Arora), gregarious on soil and humus under conifers and hardwoods, (Arora), especially in damp mossy areas, (Phillips)

Hygrocybe hondurensis.nameOrigin: type specimen from Belize (formerly British Honduras)
Hygrocybe hondurensis.habitat: on ground, Washington collection in a pasture

Hygrocybe laetissima.edibility: not recommended - "some people apparently eat it with no problems", "but there are a few reports of gastrointestinal distress", (Siegel)
Hygrocybe laetissima.habitat: scattered "in small to large patches", occasionally single, "on ground, in moss", or in well-decayed duff under Umbellularia californica (California Bay Laurel) and Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood), (in California), scattered under redwood in California (Hesler). The WA collection was growing under mostly Western Red-cedar, with some Big-leaf Maples, and a couple of Red Alders and Hemlocks, (Lauren R, pers. comm.)

Hygrocybe luteo-omphaloides.habitat: scattered or gregarious on moss, June, (Bigelow), summer

Hygrocybe 'miniata'.nameOrigin: "minium" means "red lead colored". Red lead is lead tetroxide, but this meaning for 'minium' may have solidified relatively recently. The mineral cinnabar (mercury sulfide) was apparently referred to as minium.
Hygrocybe 'miniata'.edibility: bland, but esteemed by Charles McIlvaine, (Arora)
Hygrocybe 'miniata'.habitat: single, scattered or in groups or small tufts on ground, rotting logs (unlike most waxy-caps), or in moss, (Arora), gregarious "on soil, at times among moss, or on rotting logs and humus, in deciduous and mixed woods", (Hesler), single to gregarious on soil, very decayed stumps and bogs of hardwood trees, occasionally among Sphagnum, in various types of hardwood and coniferous forests, and in poor pastures, (Arnolds), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Hygrocybe minutula.habitat: gregarious to scattered on grassy soil, (Hesler), in grassy areas and in moss in field, open forest, or mountain slope, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)

Hygrocybe parvula.habitat: "gregarious on soil and humus in deciduous and mixed woods", (Phillips), gregarious on soil and humus in deciduous and mixed woods, and under rhododendron, (Hesler)

Hygrocybe 'punicea'.edibility: listed as edible in some books, but poisonous at least to some people; concentrates cadmium, (Arora)
Hygrocybe 'punicea'.habitat: scattered to gregarious "in cool damp places (usually in woods)", (Arora), gregarious to scattered under hardwoods and conifers, (Hesler), fall (Bacon)

Hygrocybe 'reae'.taste: very bitter (Phillips, Hesler), cap pellicle (skin) is very bitter (Largent)
Hygrocybe 'reae'.habitat: in groups under conifers, July to October (Phillips), gregarious under conifers (Hesler), summer, fall

Hygrocybe reidii.odour: "peculiar, rather weak to strong (becoming stronger after preserving in a closed box), sweetish, usually with strong unpleasant component, according to some authors reminiscent of honey", (Bas), "strongly sweet and slightly foul, reminiscent of honey going bad", "(best detected when specimens are drying or have been recently dried and packaged)", (Kuo), "sweet, resembling honey, sometimes weak and only noticeable when rubbed or when drying", (Bessette)
Hygrocybe reidii.habitat: single or somewhat gregarious on the ground in grasslands, (Bas), in "seminatural grassland, fixed dunes, lawns and deciduous scrubs, including subalpine Betula forests"; summer to fall, (Knudsen(1) with Latin name italicized), scattered or gregarious under hardwoods or conifers, summer, (Kuo), on the ground in hardwood forests or among Sphagnum mosses, June to October, (Bessette)

Hygrocybe singeri.nameOrigin: after Rolf Singer, the mycologist who reported this species from Tierra del Fuego, (Hesler(8))
Hygrocybe singeri.edibility: not recommended "There are (unfounded?) reports of this species and its relatives being poisonous." (Siegel(2))
Hygrocybe singeri.habitat: single or scattered, often in large troops; late fall through winter, (Siegel (2) for Redwood Coast of California), on ground (Hesler(1))

Hygrocybe squamulosa.odour: not distinctive (Hesler), not remarkable or faintly fruity (Arnolds)
Hygrocybe squamulosa.habitat: scattered to gregarious "particularly around rotten stumps and very rotten logs", (Hesler), gregarious on and around very decayed trunks or on very humus-rich soil with fragments of rotten wood, in hardwood forests, usually in old-growth forests; July to September, (Arnolds), summer, fall

Hygrocybe subceracea.habitat: on soil under hardwoods, July to November, (Hesler), summer, fall

Hygrocybe subminiata.habitat: on soil, July to September, (Hesler), summer, fall

Hygrocybe substrangulata.nameOrigin: likely means close to Hygrocybe strangulata
Hygrocybe substrangulata.habitat: "in acid/oligotrophic habitats such as fens in fixed dunes and heathland, moist grassland and lake shores", in subarctic and arctic/alpine in dwarf scrub heathland and fens; summer to fall

Hygrocybe 'turunda'.nameOrigin: the word "turunda" in Latin means 'a ball of paste for fattening geese'
Hygrocybe 'turunda'.habitat: scattered to gregarious on moist soil and wet moss, often on Sphagnum at high elevations, summer and fall

Hygronarius renidens.habitat: under spruce, fir, and hemlock, in the higher mountains, (Kauffman(3)), coniferous forests (Brandrud), coniferous woods, (Moser(1))

Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca.edibility: avoid, as possibly poisonous according to some, (Arora), some reports hallucinogenic (Phillips)
Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca.habitat: solitary, scattered or in groups or tufts "in humus and on rotting wood, usually under conifers", (Arora), late summer and fall (Bacon)

Hygrophorus agathosmoides.nameOrigin: means "like Hygrophorus agathosmus" - agathosmus means 'nice-smelling', agathos = good (Greek), osme = smell (Greek)
Hygrophorus agathosmoides.edibility: eaten by some people without ill effects and said to be quite good, but no toxologic studies so far (Bellanger(2))
Hygrophorus agathosmoides.odour: "bitter almond, often difficult to detect in cold weather"
Hygrophorus agathosmoides.habitat: gregarious to cespitose under Picea (spruce) in basic or acidic soil, in needle litter, or in grass; fruiting in fall till the first deep frosts, preferring colder temperatures

Hygrophorus albicarneus.nameOrigin: means 'white - flesh-colored', albus = white (Latin), carneus = pertaining to the flesh (Latin)
Hygrophorus albicarneus.habitat: single to sparsely scattered, on soil next to melting snow, May, (Hesler), spring

Hygrophorus albofloccosus.nameOrigin: refers to the white flocculence of the stem, "the most useful field character to separate it from similar-looking greyish to grayish brown almond-scented species of Hygrophorus" (Bellanger(2) with Latin name italicized)
Hygrophorus albofloccosus.edibility: edible, but almond odor not persisting when cooked, infrequently collected by mushroom foragers along Pacific coast (according to Bellanger(2))
Hygrophorus albofloccosus.habitat: scattered or single, "occasionally in small clusters or sometimes large troops on ground in thick duff of coniferous forest", almost always near Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), "usually in darker, wetter closed-canopy microhabitats in mixed evergreen forest"

Hygrophorus amarus.taste: very bitter to nauseous and persistent
Hygrophorus amarus.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] under Picea (spruce) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas fir), July to November, (Hesler), summer, fall

Hygrophorus bakerensis.edibility: bland (does not taste the way it smells), (Arora)
Hygrophorus bakerensis.odour: "sweet but sometimes faint, like almond extract or crushed peach pits", (Arora), "heavy but fragrant and very characteristic, reminding one somewhat of almonds", odor easily missed if one has just a few fruiting bodies, but in large collections very distinct, (Hesler)
Hygrophorus bakerensis.habitat: widely scattered to gregarious under conifers, (Arora), scattered to gregarious under conifers, September to December, (Hesler), often on or near rotting conifer wood (Trudell), fall, winter

Hygrophorus boyeri.nameOrigin: "Named in honour of the late Raymond Boyer (1946-2005), who spent years documenting the fungi of the Sept-Iles area, in Quebec", (Moreau)
Hygrophorus boyeri.habitat: single or in small groups; "in acidic sandy to rocky soil, often among mosses" under various pine species, in western North America particularly under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole or Shore Pine), or [in California] under Pinus muricata (Bishop Pine), and in eastern North America particularly Pinus banksiana (Jack Pine) and Pinus rigida (Pitch Pine); fruiting in fall (Moreau(1))

Hygrophorus burgdorfensis.nameOrigin: after Burgdorf Idaho, where type was found
Hygrophorus burgdorfensis.habitat: type gregarious at edge of bog under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine)

Hygrophorus caeruleus.taste: "mild at first but soon rather unpleasant"
Hygrophorus caeruleus.habitat: usually partly buried in duff, under conifers, late June and early July, (Miller(2)), summer

Hygrophorus calophyllus.odour: mild or slightly fragrant (Arora), faintly fragrant (Hesler)
Hygrophorus calophyllus.habitat: single or in small groups on ground under conifers, (Arora), singly, under Abies (fir) and Pinus (pine), August to November, (Hesler), summer, fall

Hygrophorus camarophyllus.odour: "slight, faintly of coal tar", (Phillips), "very slight, reminding one of coal tar", (Hesler), without special odor (Ammirati), indistinct (Largent)
Hygrophorus camarophyllus.habitat: scattered to gregarious; June to November, (Phillips), gregarious under pine and spruce, (Hesler), can be found with pine and spruce near snowbanks in the fall [sic], (Lincoff), spring, summer, fall

Hygrophorus capreolarius.nameOrigin: means "pertaining to a roebuck", capreolus = roebuck (Latin)
Hygrophorus capreolarius.habitat: scattered under Picea (spruce) and in Sphagnum bogs, (Hesler), coniferous and deciduous woods, (Moser for Europe), conifers, especially spruce (Courtecuisse for Europe)

Hygrophorus chrysaspis.nameOrigin: means "golden shield", chrysos = gold (Greek), aspis = shield (Greek)
Hygrophorus chrysaspis.odour: mild or at times faintly fragrant, Kuehner & Romagnesi state [with the appropriate accents marked] "Odeur speciale, plutot desagreable", (Hesler)
Hygrophorus chrysaspis.habitat: on soil under hardwoods, especially beech, (Hesler)

Hygrophorus 'chrysodon'.taste: not distinctive (Hesler), mild or slightly bitter, (Phillips)
Hygrophorus 'chrysodon'.odour: not distinctive (Hesler), fungusy (Phillips), slightly unpleasant (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), distinct, said to resemble artichokes or almonds, (Kibby)
Hygrophorus 'chrysodon'.habitat: single to gregarious in woods (Arora), on soil in conifer woods, July to January, (Hesler), summer, fall, winter

Hygrophorus cossus.habitat: gregarious around an old oak stump, under conifers, (Hesler), fall (Buczacki)

Hygrophorus 'discoideus'.nameOrigin: means "resembling a disc", diskos = disk (Greek), eidos = similitude (Greek)
Hygrophorus 'discoideus'.habitat: scattered to gregarious under conifers and in Sphagnum bogs (Hesler), in California, large troops "sometimes found in late fall and winter under Sitka Spruce", (Siegel)

Hygrophorus 'eburneus'.odour: mild (Arora, Hesler), faint but pleasant (Phillips), strong sage odor which lingers on the fingers (Lincoff(1))
Hygrophorus 'eburneus'.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in tufts on ground under hardwoods or conifers, (Arora), on soil, "mostly in coniferous woods, thickets, and grassy areas", (Hesler), fall (Buczacki)

Hygrophorus ellenae.nameOrigin: after Ellen Trueblood, who found type specimen
Hygrophorus ellenae.habitat: type cespitose [in tufts] under pine and fir

Hygrophorus 'erubescens'.habitat: gregarious under pine, October to December

Hygrophorus flavodiscus.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] in pine woods, October to November, (Hesler), "scattered, in groups, or in clusters on the ground in pine woods", (Bessette(2)), fall

Hygrophorus fuscoalboides.taste: mild (Hesler(1) for both Hygrophorus fuscoalboides and H. olivaceoalbus var. intermedius)
Hygrophorus fuscoalboides.odour: slight (Hesler(1) for Hygrophorus fuscoalboides), none (Hesler(1) for H. olivaceoalbus var. intermedius)
Hygrophorus fuscoalboides.habitat: type on soil in woods, August, (Hesler(1) for Hygrophorus fuscoalboides), cespitose-scattered under Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), August, (Hesler(1) for H. olivaceoalbus var. intermedius)

Hygrophorus gliocyclus.edibility: edible, good according to some, but remove slime first, (Arora)
Hygrophorus gliocyclus.habitat: scattered to gregarious in needle duff under pines, (Arora), single to gregarious on the ground under Pinus ponderosa [Ponderosa Pine], (Stuntz(2)), gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] under spruce and pine, September to January, (Hesler), fall, winter

Hygrophorus glutinosus.habitat: on ground in deciduous woods, September to December, (Hesler), fall, winter

Hygrophorus goetzii.nameOrigin: type found by Christel and Donald Goetz, pioneering members of the Oregon Mycological Society and the Pacific Northwest Key Council, (Trudell)
Hygrophorus goetzii.habitat: single to scattered in mountain areas above 6000 feet, often in soil near melting snowbanks, late June and early July, (Largent), type under hemlock, July, (Hesler), snowbank at 5000-8000 feet, (Miller), spring, summer

Hygrophorus inocybiformis.habitat: gregarious to scattered under Picea (spruce) and Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir)

Hygrophorus karstenii.nameOrigin: 'karstenii' probably after P.A. Karsten 1834-1917 Professor of Botany, Mustiala Finland; 'minor' means 'less'

Hygrophorus marzuolus.nameOrigin: means "pertaining to the month of March"
Hygrophorus marzuolus.habitat: a collection on soil near snow bank, June, (Hesler), gregarious "beneath litter of leaves and moss in coniferous and broadleaf woods", especially in mountain areas, late winter, spring, rarely in late fall, (Lincoff), single to several, sometimes cespitose [in tufts] "under conifers (very often subalpine fir and Engelmann spruce) in needle duff, usually in the wet zone at high elevations, often in melting snowbanks", late May to July, (Bessette), spring, summer

Hygrophorus megasporus.habitat: scattered to single or rarely subcespitose [nearly tufted] on humus or mossy areas, in dense coniferous forests

Hygrophorus monticola.odour: of cherry pits or bitter almonds, lacking in one collection
Hygrophorus monticola.habitat: gregarious on soil and moss in coniferous woods

Hygrophorus morrisii.nameOrigin: after George F. Morris, who sent Peck specimens
Hygrophorus morrisii.habitat: on soil under conifers, November to December, (Hesler), fall, winter

Hygrophorus occidentalis.habitat: soil in woods, April to December, (Hesler), spring, summer, fall, winter

Hygrophorus odoratus.odour: strongly aromatic, somewhat as in Hygrophorus agathosmus [almonds]
Hygrophorus odoratus.habitat: scattered on moist earth under conifers, October, (Hesler), fall

Hygrophorus 'olivaceoalbus'.habitat: cespitose [in tufts], gregarious, or scattered under Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood) and Picea (spruce), July to December, (Hesler), solitary, scattered, or in groups on ground under conifers (especially spruce), (Arora), summer, fall, winter

Hygrophorus pacificus.odour: strong and penetrating, aromatic, (Hesler), aromatic, not like almond, (Stuntz)

Hygrophorus penarius.taste: pleasant (Hesler), "mild, pleasant and somewhat nutty", (Breitenbach), a combination of pleasant and somewhat meaty, more or less like taste of Pholiota squarrosa, (Largent)
Hygrophorus penarius.odour: none (Hesler, Breitenbach), a combination of fragrant (i.e. pleasant) and somewhat meaty, more or less like odor of Pholiota squarrosa, (Largent)
Hygrophorus penarius.habitat: in woods, especially beech, September, (Hesler), single to gregarious, in beech forests, summer to fall, (Breitenbach), California collection under Abies concolor (Largent)

Hygrophorus piceae.habitat: under Picea (spruce) and in swampy areas, (Hesler), single to gregarious, under Picea in montane pastures, summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Hygrophorus pudorinus.edibility: yes but mediocre, some variants said to have turpentine taste, (Arora), not edible (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Hygrophorus pudorinus.taste: not distinctive (Hesler), unpleasant, like turpentine, (Phillips), may be bitter (Ammirati)
Hygrophorus pudorinus.odour: not distinctive or slightly fragrant (but faintly fragrant in var. fragrans), (Hesler), mild to faintly fragrant (Arora), not distinctive or slightly fragrant for var. pudorinus; unpleasantly fragrant, at times faintly so, for var. fragrans forma fragrans; fragrant to slightly pungent and spicy for var. fragrans forma pallidus, (Largent)
Hygrophorus pudorinus.habitat: scattered to gregarious in bogs or in mixed coniferous forests, (Hesler), scattered or in groups "on ground under conifers, particularly spruce", (Arora), grows "in boggy places in moss under conifers, mixed spruce and pine", (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), fall (Buczacki)

Hygrophorus purpurascens.edibility: yes, but some variants too bitter to be palatable (Arora), edible and pleasant (Bessette(1))
Hygrophorus purpurascens.odour: mild (Arora, Hesler, Bessette(1)), mild: anise, radish or none, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Hygrophorus purpurascens.habitat: single to scattered, gregarious, or in troops under conifers, especially Picea [spruce] and Pinus [pine], especially in mountains, (Arora), gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on soil under spruce and pine, May to December, (Hesler), "single to several (occasionally gregarious), in conifer duff, often partially or almost completely buried", frequent in spring and early summer in Rockies, Cascades, and coast ranges, infrequent to rare in late summer and fall in northeastern and southeastern US, (Bessette(1)), in spring, this is the most likely of the similar species, (D. Miller, pers. comm. June 28, 2020), spring, summer, fall, winter

Hygrophorus pusillus.odour: "faintly but distinctly aromatic, or of anise", (Hesler), "faintly sweet to fragrant to fruity, soon indistinctive", (Largent)
Hygrophorus pusillus.habitat: scattered or in troops under conifers, September to December, (Hesler), fall, winter

Hygrophorus pustulatoides.nameOrigin: refers to the similarity to Hygrophorus pustulatus (Bellanger)
Hygrophorus pustulatoides.edibility: probably edible, but not choice - no toxicological studies so far, (Bellanger(2))
Hygrophorus pustulatoides.habitat: gregarious under Picea (spruce) "in needle litter, in either plantations or natural forests, in acidic or basic soil"; fruiting "in the fall until the first deep frosts, preferring cold temperatures"

Hygrophorus pustulatus.nameOrigin: after "pustules" or papillae that may occur on cap surface
Hygrophorus pustulatus.habitat: gregarious under Abies (fir) and Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood), (Hesler), in groups under fir and redwood, (Phillips), under spruce, sometimes mixed, usually in damp places, (Courtecuisse for Europe), fall (Buczacki)

Hygrophorus russula.nameOrigin: means "reddish", but may refer to Russula
Hygrophorus russula.taste: typically mild, (Arora), mild (Hesler), sometimes slightly bitter, (Lincoff(1))
Hygrophorus russula.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in fairy rings in mixed woods and under hardwoods, associated mainly with oaks, (Arora), gregarious, "at times in arcs or fairy rings", "in oak and mixed oak-pine woods", August to December, (Hesler), summer, fall, winter

Hygrophorus saxatilis.spores: white (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), white, although spore prints on the top of neighboring caps can be dark ochraceous salmon, darker than the cap color, (Hesler)
Hygrophorus saxatilis.odour: none or faintly of dried peaches (Hesler), none or faintly of dried apricots (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Hygrophorus saxatilis.habitat: scattered "under conifers on steep hillsides or very rocky dry soil", August to October, (Hesler), in cespitose bundles on decaying conifer stump, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), summer, fall

Hygrophorus siccipes.nameOrigin: means 'dry stem', which is somewhat misleading
Hygrophorus siccipes.habitat: single "or scattered in small groups"; under 2-needled and 3-needled pines (especially Pinus ponderosa, also P. radiata and P. muricata), "often on sandy soils with a moss layer"; fruiting in late fall and early winter "but occasionally found into early spring", (Moreau), type gregarious in a pine barren, October, (Hesler), fall

Hygrophorus sordidus.habitat: single to widely scattered or gregarious on ground in woods, associated principally with oaks, (Arora), gregarious on soil in open oak-hickory woods, (Hesler), single to gregarious under oaks (Largent)

Hygrophorus speciosus.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] "on soil, in bogs and under larch", (Hesler), scattered to densely gregarious in woods and bogs under conifers, especially Larix (larch) but also Pinus (pine), (Arora)

Hygrophorus subalpinus.habitat: single to gregarious on ground under conifers, known only from the mountains of western North America, (Arora), gregarious under conifers, June to October, (Hesler), summer, fall

Hygrophorus subpungens.odour: faint spicy fragrant, (Hesler), faintly aromatic, sweet or fruity, fades quickly with maturity, (Largent)
Hygrophorus subpungens.habitat: type densely gregarious on wet soil near a beaver pond, October, (Hesler), scattered to gregarious in grassy humus under Alnus rubra (Red Alder) and in humus under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Largent), fall

Hygrophorus tephroleucus.habitat: gregarious under conifers and in Sphagnum bogs, fall and winter (September to February)

Hygrophorus variicolor.habitat: on soil in woods, October to November, (Hesler), fall

Hygrophorus velatus.habitat: type on ground under conifers, August, (Hesler), summer

Hygrophorus vernalis.habitat: scattered under conifers, near snowbanks, May to July, (Hesler), in soil in association with roots of Pinaceae spp. near melting snowbanks, April to July, (Castellano), spring, summer

Hygrophorus vinicolor.nameOrigin: means 'of the color of wine', vinum = wine (Latin), color = color (Latin)
Hygrophorus vinicolor.habitat: type gregarious on a mossy bank

Hygrophorus whitei.nameOrigin: Bellanger(2) implies that Mr. White was one of the collectors of the holotype.
Hygrophorus whitei.habitat: in mixed conifer forest (Picea, Abies, Tsuga, Sequoia) or under Picea (spruce), in California December and January

Hypholoma capnoides.spores: purple-brown to deep purple gray (Arora), violet-brown (Breitenbach)
Hypholoma capnoides.edibility: yes, but not particularly tasty, (Arora), do not confuse with Hypholoma fasciculare
Hypholoma capnoides.taste: mild, (Arora, Phillips), mild or only slightly bitter (Rinaldi), mild, fungoid, (Breitenbach)
Hypholoma capnoides.habitat: gregarious, usually in clusters, on rotting conifers, (Arora), persists late in fall season (Ammirati), late summer and fall (Miller)

Hypholoma dispersum.taste: typically somewhat bitter, (Arora), mild to slightly unpleasant (Smith for var. dispersum, bitter for var. idahoense), bitter and unpleasant, (Miller)
Hypholoma dispersum.habitat: "widely scattered to gregarious in humus and debris under conifers", (Arora), "single to gregarious on debris under conifers or around and on very rotten conifer wood, often abundant or chipdirt, sawdust, etc.", (Smith), summer and fall (Miller)

Hypholoma elongatum.spores: dull cinnamon brown (Smith(3)), purplish brown (Bessette), purple brown, (Breitenbach)
Hypholoma elongatum.taste: not distinctive (Smith(3)), not distinctive to slightly bitter, (Bessette), mild, somewhat unpleasant, (Breitenbach)
Hypholoma elongatum.odour: not distinctive (Smith(3)), not distinctive (Bessette), slightly musty (Breitenbach)
Hypholoma elongatum.habitat: scattered to gregarious on Sphagnum moss, late summer and fall, (Smith(3)), scattered or in groups among Sphagnum mosses in swamps, bogs, and marshes, August to October, (Bessette), Sphagnum (Courtecuisse), single to gregarious in moors, in moist places in forests, in Sphagnum, (Breitenbach)

Hypholoma epixanthum.nameOrigin: means "of a color tending to blonde", from epixanthos (Greek)
Hypholoma epixanthum.habitat: "on deciduous, sometimes buried, wood or sawdust" (Watling who notes that Moser recorded it on conifer wood), especially on coniferous wood (Moser), fall (Buczacki)

Hypholoma fasciculare.edibility: poisonous, gastrointestinal upset in North America, several deaths in Europe and Asia, (Arora)
Hypholoma fasciculare.taste: very bitter (rarely mild), (Arora), "bitter and astringent after being chewed for a time" (Breitenbach)
Hypholoma fasciculare.habitat: gregarious, "usually in tufts or dense clusters on decaying wood of both hardwoods and conifers, but sometimes growing form buried wood or roots and thus appearing terrestrial", (Arora), clustered "in hardwood and coniferous forests, on dead wood such as stumps, roots, branches, etc."; early summer to late fall, (Breitenbach), all year (spring, summer, winter, fall), (Buczacki)

Hypholoma humidicola.habitat: single to scattered on moss in conifer forests

Hypholoma lateritium.nameOrigin: means 'almost brick-color', or may have meant Agaricus sublateritius was near to Agaricus lateritius
Hypholoma lateritium.spores: purple-brown (Phillips, Bessette), "dark vinaceous gray" or "deep slaty brown" (Smith(15), colors from Ridgway(1)), purple-gray (Miller)
Hypholoma lateritium.edibility: in European literature has been reported as poisonous, but like many Canadian and American investigators, Smith ate and enjoyed it with no ill effects, (Smith(15)), with caution (Phillips), edible (Bessette), poisonous, (Courtecuisse)
Hypholoma lateritium.taste: mild to bitterish (Smith(15)), mild to bitter (Phillips, Bessette), usually somewhat bitter or astringent, not distinctive, (Breitenbach)
Hypholoma lateritium.odour: none (Smith(15)), pleasant (Phillips), not distinctive (Bessette), pleasantly fungoid, (Breitenbach)
Hypholoma lateritium.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to subcespitose on or around old stumps, particularly oak, (Smith(15)), generally cespitose on or about old trunks or stumps of hardwood trees in fall, (Murrill), "in clusters on hardwood logs and stumps", August to October, (Phillips), "in dense clusters or scattered on hardwood stumps and logs", August to October, (Bessette), summer, fall

Hypholoma olivaceotinctum.habitat: on rich humus and debris in wet areas of conifer forests (Phillips), gregarious to scattered "on rich humus and on debris, often along the outwash of streams, in conifer forests", (Smith)

Hypholoma polytrichi.habitat: gregarious on moss in or near bogs or on wet ground, late summer and fall, (Smith), single to gregarious in conifer or mixed conifer hardwood forests, on acid soils among haircap mosses (Polytrichum), (Breitenbach for Switzerland), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Hypholoma squalidellum.habitat: usually densely gregarious on peat in bogs, "but also along the edges of marshes and on poorly drained areas"

Hypholoma subericaeum.habitat: densely gregarious to subcespitose on decaying, matted leaves of Carex comosa (longhair sedge) around bases of hummocks "in a small clearing in a hardwood swamp", (Redhead, Latin name in italics, who mentions that Kuehner(1936) "noted that the species often occurred in wet depressions in hardwood forests or at the edges of fields"), single or in groups "on peat or organic soil on heaths and moorlands and in wet base-poor pastures", (Watling(3) from British Isles), in a Scirpus marsh growing out of rotting herbaceous debris, (Squamish, BC); in a ditch filled with marsh vegetation, by a logging road, (Roberts Creek, BC), (Paul Kroeger), fall (Buczacki)

Hypholoma subochraceum.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious on decaying conifer logs, in the fall, often late

Hypholoma tuberosum.taste: slightly bitter; sclerotium slightly radish-like or mild
Hypholoma tuberosum.odour: faintly farinaceous, sclerotium earthy to somewhat like green corn
Hypholoma tuberosum.habitat: single to cespitose [in tufts] "in compost piles, rank grass, mulched gardens, and loose soil extensively burrowed by mammals", (Redhead), grows in wood chips in horticultural areas (Desjardin)

Hypholoma udum.habitat: on muck in bogs, especially along rabbit runways, (Arora quoting A.H. Smith), "scattered or in groups among sphagnum mosses in bogs or wet areas in woods", (Bessette), on wet peaty soil, usually among Sphagnum, summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Hypsizygus tessulatus.habitat: on poplar or occasionally other hardwoods, usually several stems from a common base

Infundibulicybe geotropa.nameOrigin: means "turned downward, vertically toward the ground", ge = earth (Greek), trope = turning toward (Greek)
Infundibulicybe geotropa.odour: pleasant or fungoid, (Bigelow), aromatic, of lavender or of bitter almonds, (Rinaldi for Europe)
Infundibulicybe geotropa.habitat: single, scattered, gregarious, rarely subcespitose [more or less in tufts], on leaves and humus under conifers or hardwoods, August and September, (Bigelow), fall (Buczacki), summer, fall

Infundibulicybe gibba.edibility: excellent but difficult for beginners to identify, (Arora)
Infundibulicybe gibba.taste: usually not distinctive, occasionally reported with slight alkaline or slight farinaceous component, (Bigelow)
Infundibulicybe gibba.odour: mild or faintly sweet like cyanide, (Arora), usually not distinctive, occasionally reported with slight alkaline or slight farinaceous component, (Bigelow), a little like almond or anise (Kibby)
Infundibulicybe gibba.habitat: single to scattered or in small groups especially under oak but also under conifers, (Arora); single, scattered, gregarious, at times in arcs, rarely subcespitose [more or less in tufts]; on leaves and humus, most frequently under hardwoods (maple, beech, birch, oak, aspen), sometimes in mixed hardwood-conifer woods, occasionally under conifers; July to September, sometimes to early October, recorded in February in Texas and April in California, (Bigelow), spring, summer, fall

Inocephalus appressus.nameOrigin: means 'pressed on', probably referring to appressed fibrillose cap
Inocephalus appressus.habitat: scattered to gregarious under Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Inocephalus azureus.nameOrigin: probably refers to the color of the gills

Inocephalus fabaceolus.habitat: in grass or in mossy humus beneath ferns, near Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) or Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock)

Inocephalus furfuraceidiscus.habitat: type on soil in early August (Largent), summer

Inocephalus minutopilus.habitat: type semi-gregarious on soil, late October, (Largent), fall

Inocephalus perfuscus.nameOrigin: probably 'very fuscous' or 'fuscous throughout', from per- = through, by, very (Latin), fuscus = dark (Latin)
Inocephalus perfuscus.habitat: type scattered to gregarious in lawns and in branchlet humus under cedar, mid-November, (Largent), fall

Inocephalus rhombisporus.odour: "indistinct to fungoid, grassy, somewhat spermatic, or even very slightly farinaceous, however never strong"
Inocephalus rhombisporus.habitat: "scattered to gregarious, in grass on hard clay soil, in damp leafy humus, or in branchlet humus, under ferns and near or beneath Coast Redwood or Mountain Hemlock", September to November, (Largent), fall

Inocybe agglutinata.nameOrigin: means 'stuck together' (Latin), probably referring to appressed-agglutinate fibrils on cap

Inocybe albodisca.habitat: "on bare soil with hemlock or in mixed woods" (Phillips), on the ground in hemlock or mixed woods, (Kauffman), on the ground, near conifers and deciduous trees, "especially hemlock, aspen, beech, and birch"; August to November, (Lincoff), summer, fall

Inocybe assimilata.nameOrigin: 'umbrina' (for the synonym) refers to the umber color
Inocybe assimilata.habitat: along paths under conifers (Stuntz), on soil in woodland, single or in small trooping groups, fall, (Buczacki)

Inocybe brunneolipes.habitat: gregarious on sandy soil under conifers

Inocybe castanea.nameOrigin: means 'chestnut', presumably referring to color of cap
Inocybe castanea.habitat: on needle litter under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), (Stuntz), on ground under conifers (Kauffman)

Inocybe catalaunica.habitat: under conifers, (Smith), under conifers and hardwoods, also with dwarf shrubs in alpine zone; July to November, (Kuyper), summer, fall

Inocybe ceskae.nameOrigin: "Named after Oluna Ceska who has made numerous mushroom collections and contributed to the knowledge of fungal diversity in Canada"
Inocybe ceskae.odour: "more or less spermatic when cut, otherwise sometimes indistinctive"
Inocybe ceskae.habitat: usually gregarious, rarely single, has been found on the ground in humid and subtemperate coastal regions of the Pacific Northwest, and in boreal forest in Finland

Inocybe chalcodoxantha.habitat: single or loosely gregarious in moss or needles, under conifers

Inocybe chelanensis.nameOrigin: after Chelan County in Washington, where type found
Inocybe chelanensis.odour: very faintly radish-like, (Stuntz), varying from spermatic to fungoid, faintly radish-like, like Pelargonium (geranium) in one collection, or not distinctive, (Kropp)
Inocybe chelanensis.habitat: type gregarious on needles and soil under conifers at 6000 ft., (Stuntz), single to gregarious, sometimes cespitose [in tufts], on soil; associated with Pinus (pine) and Abies (fir) in montane environments; "spring to mid-August and occasionally found near melting snowbanks at high elevations", (Kropp), spring, summer

Inocybe chondroderma.nameOrigin: "chondro-" = Greek for grain or cartilage, "-derma" = Greek for skin, named in reference to the hygrophanous-corneous cap surface
Inocybe chondroderma.spores: yellowish brown to dark yellowish brown
Inocybe chondroderma.habitat: scattered singly on soil under conifers, Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), or under Arbutus menziesii (Pacific madrone), fall, late September to December, rarely August

Inocybe cincinnata.habitat: reported under aspen or conifers in North America, with Populus, Tilia, Picea, Pseudotsuga in Europe

Inocybe cinnamomea.habitat: on ground under spruce at Crescent City CA

Inocybe decemgibbosa.nameOrigin: 'decemgibbosa' means 'with 10 humps', presumably referring to spores
Inocybe decemgibbosa.habitat: on ground in coniferous woods or sometimes grass under conifers

Inocybe 'dulcamara'.nameOrigin: Latin 'dulcis' means 'sweet' and Latin 'amara' means 'bitter', the compound presumably referring to taste, but I. dulcamara is said by Miller to be poisonous.
Inocybe 'dulcamara'.taste: not distinctive (Malloch), slightly bitter (Stuntz), mild or slightly sweet but do not taste because of toxins (Miller)
Inocybe 'dulcamara'.odour: not distinctive (Cripps(1), Malloch), faint, a little radish-like, (Stuntz), mostly fishy to faintly radish-like (Miller), faint, or honey when bruised, (Buczacki)
Inocybe 'dulcamara'.habitat: under hardwoods or conifers, especially in subalpine habitats, often along roadsides or riverbank areas; in WA under conifers, in YT with willows, dwarf willows, or Dryas, in Montana open ground under Populus tremuloides (aspen), (Cripps(1)), in gravely and mossy soils in alpine, boreal and arctic habitats, (Malloch), on moss, along a stream in woods of Abies and Pinus contorta at 6000 feet, (Stuntz), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller)

Inocybe eutheloides.habitat: on ground under hardwoods or in mixed woods

Inocybe flocculosa.nameOrigin: 'flocculosa' means 'flocculose' (finely woolly or cottony); 'lucifuga' means 'avoiding light'
Inocybe flocculosa.odour: spermatic, often strongly so, (Cripps), faintly radish-like or none, (Stuntz), spermatic-acidulous, not Pelargonium-like [not geranium-like], sometimes indistinct (Kuyper), faint, bleach, (Buczacki)
Inocybe flocculosa.habitat: under Populus tremuloides (aspen) in Montana and Idaho, also reported with willow in alpine habitats, and in Europe with Betula, Salix, Populus, Alnus, Quercus, Fagus, Picea, and Pinus, (Cripps), gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on needles and moss under Abies spp. and Pinus contorta, (Stuntz), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Inocybe fraudans.odour: "fragrant, usually spicy (cinnamon- or matsutake-like), but sometimes like overripe pears or unpleasant in age", (Arora), spicy (Kauffman), pleasantly flowery to fruity, (Breitenbach), strong, similar to Peruvian balsam, (Kuyper)
Inocybe fraudans.habitat: single, scattered, or in small groups "in woods or at their edges, under brush, along trails, etc., favoring hardwoods but also occurring with conifers", (Arora), gregarious, rarely single, in coniferous forests or mixed forests, commonly on roadsides or pathsides, summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Inocybe fuscidula.habitat: gregarious or in groups, in hardwood and coniferous forests, (Breitenbach), under hardwoods and conifers, June to October, (Kuyper), summer, fall

Inocybe fuscodisca.habitat: single, scattered or in groups on ground under conifers, (Bessette), scattered to numerous with conifers, August to November, (Lincoff), summer, fall

Inocybe 'geophylla'.spores: brown (Cripps, Arora), dull clay-brown (Miller), dark brown (Buczacki)
Inocybe 'geophylla'.taste: spermatic (Kuyper), mild, but do not taste because of toxins, (Miller)
Inocybe 'geophylla'.odour: spermatic (Cripps, Kuyper), disagreeable (spermatic), (Arora), varies from slight to disagreeable or scented, (Phillips), of green corn to disagreeable (Miller), bleach (Buczacki), mouldy (Stangl )
Inocybe 'geophylla'.habitat: with both hardwoods and conifers, in Montana in riparian areas under aspen, or mixed aspen and willow, (Cripps), on ground in hardwood and coniferous woods, (Kauffman(4)), scattered to gregarious "on ground (or occasionally very rotten wood) in woods" (Arora), early summer to fall (Miller)

Inocybe griseolilacina.odour: spermatic but not strong, (Smith), spermatic, often strong, (Cripps), somewhat Pelargonium-like [geranium-like], especially on drying, but distinctly spermatic when cut, (Kuyper), Pelargonium (geranium) (Buczacki)
Inocybe griseolilacina.habitat: under conifers in Washington, (Smith), under aspen (summer) in Montana, (Cripps), widespread with hardwoods in Europe, August to October, (Kuyper), summer, fall

Inocybe griseoscabrosa.habitat: single on ground in mixed deciduous woods (Grund(7), in Nova Scotia), on ground in woods (Kauffman)

Inocybe hemileuca.nameOrigin: means 'half-white', presumably referring to white veil remnants on brown cap
Inocybe hemileuca.habitat: single or in pairs under conifers in mountains, May and June, (Nishida), spring, summer

Inocybe heterochrominea.habitat: single to gregarious in forest of mixed conifers and hardwoods or of conifers only, June through September, (Grund), summer, fall

Inocybe hotsoniana.odour: faint to slightly radish-like, not spermatic
Inocybe hotsoniana.habitat: type single on moss and conifer needles under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)

Inocybe insinuata.habitat: type on the ground under pine, January, (Kauffman), BC collections March (on calcareous soil) and April on soil in Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) forest, CA collection June under Abies concolor (White Fir) and Pinus jeffreyi (Jeffrey Pine), (University of Tennessee herbarium, accessed December 10, 2012), scattered to gregarious "in soil in mixed hardwood-conifer forests", especially with Pinus and Pseudotsuga menziesii, "fall through mid-winter in coastal forests, in the spring in montane conifer forests", (Desjardin), usually in clumps (A. and O. Ceska)

Inocybe intricata.habitat: gregarious "on ground in hardwood or in mixed hardwood and coniferous forest"

Inocybe ionocephala.nameOrigin: "ionocephala" (Greek), ion- purple, cephala - with a head, referring to cap
Inocybe ionocephala.habitat: "small clusters or scattered singly on soil"; associated with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Notholithocarpus (tanoak), Tsuga (hemlock), and/or Arbutus; fruiting November-January in California

Inocybe jacobi.habitat: usually gregarious on sandy soils near Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), and Salix (willow), more rarely near Betula (birch), summer and fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Inocybe kauffmanii.nameOrigin: after Calvin Henry Kauffman 1869-1931, professor of botany University of Michigan, who described it as Inocybe longipes

Inocybe lacera.spores: snuff brown (Phillips), brown (Cripps), dark brown (Miller), dark brown (Buczacki)
Inocybe lacera.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), not distinct, (Kuyper), mild but do not taste because of toxins (Miller)
Inocybe lacera.odour: none (Phillips), typically fungoid, or absent, (Cripps), faint, indistinct to subspermatic, (Kuyper), none, fungoid, or faintly of green corn, (Miller), faint, bleach, (Buczacki)
Inocybe lacera.habitat: in conifer woods all over North America, (Phillips), along roads under aspen and conifers, sandy gravely or burned soil, often found by May or June, (Lincoff), typically fruiting in spring at the edges of aspen clones in sandy soil in Montana, (Cripps), under hardwoods and conifers "on siliceous, nutrient-poor, dry sand, also occurring on old fireplaces", April to November, (Kuyper), spring, summer, fall

Inocybe lampetiana.nameOrigin: named lampetiana, "after the Greek goddess Lampetia, who according to Vergil was transformed into an Alder tree after her death, because the species grows with Alnus" (Bandini(1))
Inocybe lampetiana.habitat: Inocybe lampetiana had up to the time of the original publication always been found "in moist to wet terrain with Alnus and also Picea abies nearby. The type collection and several others were from boggy acid ground at the banks of a small rivulet." (Bandini(1), with Latin names italicized)

Inocybe lanuginosa.habitat: "In North America I. lanuginosa appears restricted to rotten woody substrates, either on stumps of conifers or terrestrially on buried rotten wood. It is found under conifers (Abies, Picea, Pinus, Pseudotsuga, Thuja and Tsuga) or in mixed woods where conifers (Abies, Picea) are present. In Europe, it is cited more frequently on the ground and at times under hardwoods (Betula, Populus and Alnus)", peaks from July to September, but recorded from March through December, (Matheny), spring, summer, fall, winter

Inocybe leptophylla.nameOrigin: from "leptos", Greek for "small, thin, fine, delicate", and "phyllon", Greek for "leaf" referring to gills
Inocybe leptophylla.habitat: single to scattered or in small groups "on rotten coniferous stumps and less often on the ground under conifers (Picea, Abies, Pseudotsuga, Pinus), rarely in Sphagnum bogs", "chiefly montane extending into subalpine areas in western North America" but also occurs in other areas, predominantly July through September, but occurs from March to June and as late as November, (Matheny), spring, summer, fall

Inocybe 'lilacina'.taste: not distinctive or somewhat disagreeable (Bessette), spermatic (Kuyper)
Inocybe 'lilacina'.habitat: single, scattered or in groups on ground in woods, (Arora), in hardwood woods and coniferous woods, (Kauffman), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Inocybe melleiconica.odour: "strong of green corn, slowly changing and becoming spermatic"
Inocybe melleiconica.habitat: Nova Scotian holotype single in soil under Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock)

Inocybe mixtilis.odour: none or faintly spermatic (Cripps), faintly spermatic to farinaceous, (Breitenbach), of radish (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), spermatic (Grund), indistinct (Buczacki)
Inocybe mixtilis.habitat: under both conifers and hardwoods including aspen, (Cripps), usually gregarious "in conifer forests or mixed conifer-hardwood forests", primarily near Picea (spruce), among mosses; summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Inocybe monticola.habitat: in loose clusters on soil in mountain environments, with mixed conifers and Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), fruiting May and June, (Kropp), spring, summer

Inocybe napipes.spores: snuff brown (Phillips), dull brown (Ammirati), gray-brown (Breitenbach), gray-brown (Buczacki)
Inocybe napipes.odour: "strong, fruity or rancid", (Phillips), unpleasant of chestnut catkins (Ammirati), musty to faintly radish-like (Breitenbach), mild, radish-like, (Buczacki)
Inocybe napipes.habitat: coniferous woods (Phillips), on ground under conifers, fall and sometimes spring, (Ammirati), on ground in boggy places in hardwood forests, esp. Betula (birch) and Fagus (beech), also in coniferous forests, (Hansen for Europe), deciduous woods, often on moor-like land, (Moser for Europe), usually gregarious, more rarely single, in conifer forests or mixed hardwood-conifer forests, (and according to the literature in hardwood forests), at the edges of moors among Sphagnum or Calluna heaths, usually among mosses; summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Europe)

Inocybe 'nitidiuscula'.odour: spermatic (Cripps), "(sub)spermatic, sometimes with an acidulous component", (Kuyper), bleach (Buczacki)
Inocybe 'nitidiuscula'.habitat: under conifers and Fagus (beech) in WA, under aspen in Montana, elsewhere with Salix (willow) and Dryas, (Cripps), under conifers and hardwoods, April to November, (Kuyper), spring, summer, fall

Inocybe occulta.nameOrigin: from Latin occultus, "which means hidden or concealed, due to the likely confusion with similar taxa" of the Inocybe mixtilis group, (Esteve-Raventos(1) with Latin italicized)
Inocybe occulta.odour: "generally faint in fresh specimens, often indistinct, in some collections more or less spermatic when cut, exceptionally aromatical or even honey-like"
Inocybe occulta.habitat: usually gregarious, rarely single, "in a broad range of habitats", does not show specific soil pH requirements; "from cold boreal areas to warm Mediterranean regions of the Northern Hemisphere", in association with conifers or hardwoods

Inocybe 'oetziana'.nameOrigin: This species was named "oetziana" because "one collection was found near the valley where the famous Otzi, the Iceman, was found" (Bandini(1)). Otzi is the natural mummy of a man who lived some time between 3350 and 3105 BC, discovered in 1991 in the Otztal Alps on the border between Austria and Italy.
Inocybe 'oetziana'.habitat: "collected in subalpine Austria with conifers, along a pebbled wayside, thus probably on calcareous ground"

Inocybe olympiana.nameOrigin: probably referring to the Olympic peninsula or Olympic Mts. in Washington
Inocybe olympiana.habitat: gregarious under conifers, (Smith(6)), under conifers (Stuntz), gregarious under fir (Smith(40))

Inocybe pallidicremea.nameOrigin: referring to the pallid cream color of faded specimens
Inocybe pallidicremea.habitat: scattered singly or in groups on soil, associated with conifers including Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Picea (spruce), Tsuga (hemlock), and/or Pinus (pine); fruiting August to December (summer, fall, winter)

Inocybe petiginosa.habitat: "Gregarious to grouped in hardwood forests, especially near Fagus or Quercus, on bare soil, rotting leaves, beechnuts, or rotting wood"; summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland, Latin names italicized), on soil in hardwood woodland or mixed woodland, most frequently with Fagus, (Buczacki), in WA Brandon Matheny found the taxon he is referring to under Alnus (alder), but he says that it also occurs under Douglas fir (pers. comm.)

Inocybe picrosma.taste: a little astringent and acrid [peppery] at first, "soon becoming mild and almost sweet, but leaving an unpleasant aftertaste"
Inocybe picrosma.odour: characteristic, penetrating (though not strong), spermatic for an instant when flesh first exposed, immediately becoming complex, a mixture of radish-like and resinous with component of vinegar, "having a very decided pungency which quickly produces a tingling sensation in the back of the throat"

Inocybe 'plurabellae'.nameOrigin: The name plurabellae "refers to the name of the multiformed character, Anna Livia Plurabelle, in James Joyce Finnegans Wake, because of the very variable morphological features of this species". (Bandini(1)).
Inocybe 'plurabellae'.odour: often somewhat aromatic or with fruity tinge and subspermatic [somewhat spermatic] when cut
Inocybe 'plurabellae'.habitat: "Our collections are from Austria and Germany. All without exception were associated with Picea, several of them without any other trees in the vicinity." (Bandini(1)).

Inocybe posterula.odour: almost none to indistinctly spermatic, (Kuyper), faint, bleach, (Buczacki)
Inocybe posterula.habitat: under conifers, September to November, (Kuyper), fall

Inocybe praecox.habitat: in loose clusters or single on soil, in conifer forests or parks under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Alnus rubra (Red Alder), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), or Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), fruiting April to June from near sea level to 1200 feet (400 m), (Kropp), spring, summer

Inocybe praetervisa.habitat: usually gregarious, primarily in hardwood forests but also in mixed hardwood-conifer forests; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), on the ground in coniferous regions, (Kauffman)

Inocybe pudica.spores: brown (Arora, Cripps), dull brown (Ammirati), gray brown (Lincoff)
Inocybe pudica.odour: unpleasant or spermatic, (Arora), spermatic, (Cripps, Kuyper), unpleasant (chestnut catkins), (Ammirati), bleach (Buczacki)
Inocybe pudica.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground under conifers, (Arora), with aspen or in mixed aspen, willow and alder, (Cripps for Montana) often damp, deciduous or coniferous woods, (Courtecuisse), fall (Buczacki)

Inocybe pusio.habitat: gregarious or more rarely single in hardwood forests or at least near hardwoods, (Breitenbach), under hardwood trees, but exceptionally also under conifers; June to October, (Kuyper), summer, fall

Inocybe pyrotricha.nameOrigin: means 'fire-hair', presumably referring to red fibrils
Inocybe pyrotricha.odour: rather pleasant, somewhat radish-like or faintly spermatic, (Smith(9))

Inocybe radiata.habitat: gregarious on ground in deciduous woods

Inocybe rainierensis.nameOrigin: refers to Mt. Rainier Park where the type was found
Inocybe rainierensis.habitat: under conifers, (Smith(9)), associated with conifers in August, (Kropp), summer

Inocybe semifulva.nameOrigin: means 'half fulvous' probably referring to bicolored cap
Inocybe semifulva.habitat: gregarious in grass in open areas near hardwoods, or under conifers, August to November, (Grund), summer, fall

Inocybe sindonia.nameOrigin: 'sindon' is Latin (derived from Greek) for 'fine cotton cloth, muslin'
Inocybe sindonia.odour: like a wet dog, or a laundry room, or unpleasant, (Cripps), spermatic, but mixed with a farinaceous component, (Kuyper), "faint, bleach, sometimes with mealy component", (Buczacki), "only slightly fungal, slightly farinaceous in dried material", (Stangl)
Inocybe sindonia.habitat: under conifers or hardwoods (Cripps, Kuyper), fall (Buczacki)

Inocybe siskiyouensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Siskiyou', referring to the Siskiyou Mountains
Inocybe siskiyouensis.habitat: holotype gregarious under fir and oak, December 7, 1925

Inocybe soluta.habitat: in coniferous forest under spruce and pine at the edges of paths or in needle-duff; from the end of July until October, (Stangl), summer, fall

Inocybe stellatospora.odour: none to weakly spermatic, (Matheny), "none or more or less spermatic", (Grund)
Inocybe stellatospora.habitat: scattered singly or in small groups "on soil, humus and occasionally woody debris", on the ground under conifers, in mixed woods, or in hardwood successional forests under hardwoods mixed with seedlings of conifers; fruits most often in July through September but can fruit in late spring, (Matheny), single to gregarious in needles under Abies (fir) or other conifers, or in mixed woods, July and August, (Grund), spring, summer, fall

Inocybe suaveolens.odour: spermatic for an instant when flesh first cut, "then immediately becoming and long remaining very fragrant", almost exactly like a mixture of the odors of sweet pea and Convallaria majalis (lily-of-the-valley)

Inocybe subcarpta.habitat: in conifer woods, September to November, (Phillips), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Inocybe subdestricta.habitat: on ground in mixed woods, (Kauffman), singly under conifers or hardwoods, fall or late summer, (Grund), singly to scattered under conifers and hardwoods, late spring, summer, and fall, (Ammirati)

Inocybe submuricellata.habitat: gregarious on ground in conifer forests

Inocybe umbratica.habitat: in coniferous or mixed woods, (Kauffman), single in woods of mixed conifers or of mixed hardwoods, (Grund)

Inocybe vaccina.odour: indistinct (Kuyper), almost odorless or somewhat spermatic, (Breitenbach)
Inocybe vaccina.habitat: under hardwoods and conifers, associated with Quercus (oak) and Picea (spruce), May, September to October, (Kuyper), gregarious or grouped in coniferous forests near Picea, on needle litter or among mosses, summer to fall, (Breitenbach), spring, summer, fall

Inocybe variabillima.habitat: gregarious in grass on a lawn near Abies grandis (Grand Fir)

Inocybe venustissima.odour: almost none or spermatic when cut
Inocybe venustissima.habitat: in Austria found in moist spruce forests of "montane or subalpine regions" on the ground "near small brooks or rivulets", fruiting in August (September in Haida Gwaii BC) with Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)

Inocybe virgata.habitat: on low moist ground or in swamps

Inocybe volvata.habitat: type along a road under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga (hemlock)

Inocybe xanthomelas.habitat: under conifers, at least in the case of the Nova Scotia specimen here (Grund), on soil in hardwood woodland or mixed woodland, usually in small trooping groups, summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Inosperma calamistratum.edibility: unknown (Arora), like many Inocybes, may contain muscarine
Inosperma calamistratum.odour: mixture of fresh raw fish and pine resin, (Grund), Kuyper said for Europe, "faint, acidulous, with a sweetish component, Pelargonium-like or reminding of I. bongardii var. bongardii, sometimes disagreeable, somewhat fishy". He describes the odor of I. bongardii var. bongardii as "strong, sweet, reminding of flowers of Impatiens glandulifera, ethyl cinnamate, or overripe pears, but sometimes absent", (Kuyper(1), with Latin italicized), odd, a mixture of pine resin and fish or of green corn, (Phillips, who differentiates var. mucidiolens), slightly spermatic (Stangl for Bavaria), strong, unusual, sour-acidic, sometimes of Pelargonium or fish, (Buczacki, Great Britain and Ireland)
Inosperma calamistratum.habitat: single, scattered or in small groups "on ground under conifers or sometimes hardwoods", (Arora), in coniferous and deciduous woods, (Kauffman), in coniferous or mixed woods (Phillips), summer to late fall (Miller)

Inosperma lanatodiscum.odour: nauseous when crushed (Kauffman), variable and often complex - "in some collections aromatic and not spermatic, in others floral-like and aromatic when first cut then with a subtle spermatic element, others aromatic with a green corn component, and others spermatic", (Kropp), "at first of green corn, then changing and becoming rather sweet and aromatic but still with an admixture of green corn", (Smith), "complex, of green corn then becoming sweet-aromatic with lingering green corn component", (Stuntz), complex, with three main components: green-corn, spermatic, and fragrant (sweet-aromatic), usually "the green-corn component is strongest when the specimen is collected, but fades subsequently, and the fragrant component becomes more evident", (Grund)
Inosperma lanatodiscum.habitat: on ground in deciduous woods (Kauffman for New York and Michigan), mainly occurring "during summer and early fall with a variety of hardwoods and conifers", (Kropp), under conifers (Smith for Washington); single to gregarious, in needles under pine or spruce, (Grund for Nova Scotia)

Inosperma maculatum.odour: "penetrating, definitely not spermatic, but complex", with strong fungus-like (like young Lycoperdon), pungent aromatic, and radish-like components, (Grund), "strong, reminding of Tuber spec. or more like Amanita phalloides, rather hard to define; in one population with smell of raw potatoes", (Kuyper, Latin names italicized), pleasant, indefinite, (Buczacki)
Inosperma maculatum.habitat: single to gregarious "on clay or sandy soil or in moss, in coniferous or mixed woods, August to October", (Grund), mainly under hardwoods, but exceptionally also under conifers, (Kuyper), summer, fall

Inosperma maximum.odour: of raw fish, usually also with a strong resinous component, (Grund), usually strong, "a mix of fish and conifer resin", (Trudell), mild to fishy when young, "strong, disagreeable, like rotting fish in age", (Siegel)
Inosperma maximum.habitat: under conifer (Grund), association with hemlock has been noted (Trudell), single, scattered, or in troops "in duff or moss under conifers, especially Sitka Spruce", (Siegel)

Inosperma mucidiolens.odour: "green corn", [but note that the name of the species means "smelling moldy"], (Grund)
Inosperma mucidiolens.habitat: single or loosely gregarious "in moss or needle duff, under conifers"

Kauffmania larga.habitat: single to cespitose "around stumps of elm and ash, June-July"

Kuehneromyces lignicola.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on wood, usually of conifers but sometimes hardwoods, typically in spring, (Smith), usually in large clusters on logs or snags, typically on conifers in the Pacific Northwest, but can also occur on hardwoods; most often in spring and early summer, "often in the mountains near melting snow", (Trudell)

Kuehneromyces mutabilis.spores: cinnamon-brown (Arora), cinnamon ("Verona brown" to "cinnamon"), (Smith, colors from Ridgway(1))
Kuehneromyces mutabilis.edibility: edible but not recommended because too easy to confuse with Galerina autumnalis and others, (Arora)
Kuehneromyces mutabilis.taste: "mild or slightly unpleasant but not bitter", (Smith), sweetish (Lincoff(1)), mushroomy (Courtecuisse)
Kuehneromyces mutabilis.odour: weak, agreeably spicy (not radish-like or farinaceous), (Smith), strong, pleasant (Lincoff(1)), not distinctive, (Courtecuisse)
Kuehneromyces mutabilis.habitat: typically in clusters, often large clusters, on logs, stumps, or occasionally buried wood, (Arora), cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious on hardwood or conifer wood: logs, stumps, or more rarely on buried wood, (Smith), spring and fall (Miller), generally fruits in fall (Trudell), spring to winter (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter

Kuehneromyces obscurus.taste: none, (Smith(3) for P. obscura), mild (Smith(3) for Pholiota nigripes)
Kuehneromyces obscurus.odour: none, (Smith(3) for P. obscura), mild (Smith(3) for Pholiota nigripes)
Kuehneromyces obscurus.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on rotten wood, June, (Smith(3) for P. obscura), cespitose on conifer logs, July, (Smith(3) for Pholiota nigripes)

Laccaria amethysteo-occidentalis.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to amethyst-western', amethysteus = pertaining to amethyst (Latin), occidentalis = western (Latin)
Laccaria amethysteo-occidentalis.habitat: scattered to gregarious under conifers, often Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Mueller(1)), fall, winter

Laccaria bicolor.habitat: in mixed woodlands (Phillips), scattered, occasionally cespitose [in tufts], on soil or among mosses under conifers, (Mueller), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Laccaria laccata.edibility: fairly good, but discard the tough stems, (Arora)
Laccaria laccata.habitat: scattered or in groups or troops "in woods or near trees, especially in poor or sandy soil or in boggy areas", (Arora), single to gregarious, occasionally cespitose [in tufts], "associated with Pinaceae, Fagaceae and Betulaceae", (Mueller), summer, fall, winter, (Buczacki)

Laccaria montana.habitat: "stream banks and grassy areas, often outside woodlands", high alpine and subalpine, August to October, (Phillips), scattered to gregarious, occasionally cespitose [in tufts], "in poor soil, humus or among mosses", under Pinaceae, Betula (birch), or Salix (willow), restricted to arctic, boreal, or montane habitats, (Mueller), summer, fall

Laccaria nobilis.habitat: single to scattered usually at high elevations below tree line, (Mueller(1)), single to scattered under Pinaceae, (Mueller(2))

Laccaria proxima.habitat: scattered to gregarious on ground under conifers of Pinaceae, occasionally among mosses including Sphagnum; disturbed areas, (Mueller), under conifers and mixed woods, August to October, (Phillips), summer, fall

Laccaria pumila.habitat: scattered to gregarious, occasionally cespitose [in tufts], in poor soil, humus or among mosses, under Pinaceae (pine family), Betula (birch), or Salix (willow), restricted to arctic, boreal, and montane regions (Mueller), summer and fall (Miller), spring and fall (Buczacki)

Laccaria tortilis.habitat: scattered to gregarious, occasionally cespitose [in tufts], often on bare, poorly drained soil, apparently associated with both Pinaceae and Fagaceae, (Mueller), fall (Buczacki)

Lacrymaria echiniceps.habitat: in groups of 2 to 6 near or beside stumps or old roots of hardwoods, fall

Lacrymaria lacrymabunda.nameOrigin: means 'copious tears', referring to droplets on gills
Lacrymaria lacrymabunda.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on soil around stumps or logs of hardwoods, especially beech, late summer and fall, (Smith), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Lacrymaria subcinnamomea.habitat: densely gregarious on waste ground, along roads and sometimes in lawns, late spring and fall

Lacrymaria velutina.spores: blackish-brown (Smith, Arora), dark purple-brown to blackish brown (Miller, who says it is also known as Psathyrella lacrymabunda (Bull.) Pat.)
Lacrymaria velutina.edibility: yes but not recommended, (Arora), as similar species poisonous
Lacrymaria velutina.taste: fungoid, not very distinctive, (Smith), pleasant (Phillips), unpleasant (Miller)
Lacrymaria velutina.odour: earthy, not very distinctive, (Smith), pleasant (Phillips), none (Miller)
Lacrymaria velutina.habitat: scattered, gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] "on rich moist humus or soil, on compost heaps, very old sawdust piles, or areas rich in organic material", (Smith), single or in groups or small clusters "in grassy places, roadsides, around sawdust and compost piles, on gravelly ground, or sometimes in the woods", (Arora), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller, who says it is also known as Psathyrella lacrymabunda (Bull.) Pat.)

Lactarius aestivus.nameOrigin: "aestivus" refers to summer, and this species appears quite early in the season compared with other fall mushrooms, (Nuytinck)
Lactarius aestivus.habitat: scattered to gregarious on soil, in coniferous forests dominated by Abies (true fir) and Tsuga (hemlock); common in the Pacific Northwest from mid-summer into fall; the examined collections August-September

Lactarius affinis.habitat: "scattered or in groups in pastures or mixed woods and under conifers", July to October, (Phillips), summer, fall

Lactarius alnicola.nameOrigin: means 'living with alder' because species first found under alder (with conifers nearby)
Lactarius alnicola.spores: whitish to yellowish (Arora), "pale pinkish buff" (almost white), (Hesler), white to pale yellow in mass (Methven)
Lactarius alnicola.taste: very peppery (Arora), instantly and acutely peppery, (Hesler)
Lactarius alnicola.habitat: scattered to gregarious under spruce and other conifers (despite being called "alnicola" which implies alder), and also under live oak, and with willow, (Arora), gregarious under alder, and under conifers, summer and early fall, (Hesler)

Lactarius alpinus.odour: none or very faint (Hesler), not distinctive (Methven)
Lactarius alpinus.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts], under alder in swampy and wet places along streams, (Hesler), scattered to gregarious in seepage areas, in coastal coniferous-hardwood forests in association with Alnus (alder), (Methven for California)

Lactarius argillaceifolius.spores: whitish to buff (Arora), reported as white in some collections, (Hesler)
Lactarius argillaceifolius.taste: mild or somewhat peppery, (Arora), decidedly peppery, but some collections reported as mild, (Hesler), slowly strongly peppery (Methven)
Lactarius argillaceifolius.habitat: single, scattered or in small groups "in humus under hardwoods, (live oak, tanoak, madrone)", (Arora), on soil under oak, (Hesler), single, scattered or gregarious in duff, in coastal and montane coniferous-hardwood forests in association with Quercus (oak) species, (Methven for California)

Lactarius aspideoides.nameOrigin: means "resembling a shield" or resembling Lactarius aspideus which refers to a shield
Lactarius aspideoides.spores: yellowish pallid ("pale pinkish buff"), (Hesler), white to pale yellow (Methven)
Lactarius aspideoides.taste: bitterish then slowly slightly peppery, (Hesler), slowly peppery (Methven)
Lactarius aspideoides.habitat: gregarious under conifers and hardwoods, summer and fall, (Hesler)

Lactarius aspideus.spores: yellow, Crawshay C, (Hesler), ivory to pale cream (Buczacki)
Lactarius aspideus.habitat: soil in woods (Hesler), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Lactarius atrobadius.spores: whitish in a thick deposit, becoming creamy on standing a short time, (Hesler), white to pale cream color in mass (Methven)
Lactarius atrobadius.habitat: gregarious to scattered under Pinus (pine), Alnus (alder) and Picea (spruce) mixed

Lactarius aurantiosordidus.spores: creamy to pale yellow, (Siegel), pale yellow orange (Nuytinck)
Lactarius aurantiosordidus.taste: mild or slowly slightly peppery (Siegel), mild to very slowly faintly peppery (Nuytinck)
Lactarius aurantiosordidus.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups "on ground, in moss or duff" under Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), fall, early winter, spring, (Siegel), probably associated with Picea sitchensis (Nuytinck)

Lactarius barrowsii.nameOrigin: named for the collector of the holotype
Lactarius barrowsii.habitat: in New Mexico, the type was scattered under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine) and pinyon pine

Lactarius caespitosus.habitat: "scattered to gregarious or growing in dense tufts under conifers in wet places", common in spruce-fir zone of Rocky Mountains, (Phillips), cespitose [in tufts], gregarious to scattered under conifers, summer and early fall, (Hesler)

Lactarius californiensis.taste: slowly peppery in type, but latex "tardily and only slightly bitter" in Oregon specimen, (Hesler), slowly peppery (Methven)
Lactarius californiensis.habitat: on humus (Hesler), scattered to gregarious in duff, in coastal coniferous-hardwood forests, (Methven for California)

Lactarius carbonicola.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] "in an old burn, on mossy soil, but particularly on dried-up woodland pools"

Lactarius cascadensis.habitat: type gregarious under alder at edge of swamp

Lactarius chelidonium.odour: subnauseous, like that of Morchella esculenta
Lactarius chelidonium.habitat: on soil in coniferous forests, August to October, (Hesler), summer, fall

Lactarius chrysorrheus.spores: pale yellow (Phillips, Hesler), white to pale cream, sometimes slight salmon pink flush, (Buczacki)
Lactarius chrysorrheus.taste: slowly but distinctly peppery, (Phillips), distinctly peppery (slowly at times), (Hesler)
Lactarius chrysorrheus.habitat: "in groups in hardwood and mixed forests and under conifers", July to November, (Phillips), in hardwood and mixed forests, summer and fall, (Hesler)

Lactarius circellatus.spores: dull white to cream, (Hesler), pale yellow (Methven)
Lactarius circellatus.taste: burning peppery to bitter then at times very peppery, (Hesler), slowly peppery (Methven)
Lactarius circellatus.habitat: gregarious under conifers but birch often present as well, (Hesler), scattered to gregarious "in duff of seepage areas, in montane coniferous forests", August to September, (Methven), summer, fall

Lactarius 'controversus'.nameOrigin: Latin means "turned the other way" or "controversial"
Lactarius 'controversus'.spores: cream to "pale pinkish-cinnamon" [Ridgway(1) color], (Hesler), pale yellow in mass (Methven), pink-cream (Buczacki)
Lactarius 'controversus'.taste: slowly but strongly burning-peppery (Hesler), slowly burning-peppery (Methven)
Lactarius 'controversus'.odour: mild to slight and pleasant (Hesler), not distinctive (Methven)
Lactarius 'controversus'.habitat: on soil under Populus and Salix (willow), (Hesler), scattered to gregarious under Populus (both aspen and poplar) and Salix, (Arora), scattered to gregarious in duff, in montane conifer-hardwood forests in association with Salix spp. and Populus spp., August to September, (Methven), summer, fall

Lactarius crassus.taste: very peppery (Arora), somewhat peppery when fresh (Trappe, M.(3))
Lactarius crassus.odour: often unpleasant when old (Arora), not distinctive (Trappe, M.(3))
Lactarius crassus.habitat: forms sporocarps June through October beneath the soil surface associated with various Pinaceae species in mixed forests containing Abies concolor, A. magnifica, Pinus contorta, P. jeffreyii, or P. ponderosa from 2000 to 2200 meters elevation, (Castellano), single to gregarious in duff under conifers and in mixed woods in mountains, (Arora), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus, Abies, (Trappe, M.(3))

Lactarius deliciosus.edibility: yes, but grainy texture, (Arora), according to Sept(1) turns urine red
Lactarius deliciosus.taste: mild or slightly bitter (Arora), mild or slightly bitter or slightly peppery (Leuthy), mild to slightly soapy (Kibby)
Lactarius deliciosus.odour: slightly fruity (Phillips), mild to slightly fruity or (var. areolatus) Morchella-like (Leuthy), fruity, peach-like, (Lincoff(2))
Lactarius deliciosus.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in troops under conifers (Arora), fall, winter

Lactarius deterrimus.taste: in young caps more or less peppery, in old ones mild or practically so
Lactarius deterrimus.habitat: scattered in cold, wet, conifer forests

Lactarius fallax.taste: mild or slightly peppery (Arora), mild to faintly peppery (Hesler), not distinctive (Methven for var. fallax and var. concolor)
