Lactarius fallax.habitat: scattered or in small groups under conifers (especially Abies) or occasionally on rotting wood, (Arora), scattered to gregarious in alpine habitats under conifers, on duff or very rotten conifer logs, (Hesler), fall

Lactarius glyciosmus.spores: pale cream to +/- pinkish buff (Hesler), pale cream to buff (Phillips)
Lactarius glyciosmus.odour: fragrant (of coconut) when fresh, (Hesler), fragrant, reminiscent of coconut, (Phillips), of coconut, or coconut cake, (Courtecuisse)
Lactarius glyciosmus.habitat: scattered to gregarious under birch and alder (often mixed with conifers), (Hesler), August to November (Phillips), "occurs primarily in areas where birch has been planted, especially parks and grassy roadsides", in natural habitats, "it occurs in moist areas, primarily in sphagnum under birch, but also with alder and willow in both boreal and montane habitats", (Trudell), summer, fall

Lactarius hepaticus.spores: cream (Phillips), cream but thin deposit white, (Hesler)
Lactarius hepaticus.taste: slowly and strongly peppery, (Phillips), normally slowly and strongly peppery, at least when young, but mild when old and can be mild when young (development perhaps arrested), (Hesler)
Lactarius hepaticus.habitat: single or in groups in damp moss under pine (Phillips), single to gregarious "in damp mossy habitats under conifers, summer and fall", (Hesler)

Lactarius hysginus.nameOrigin: probably from Greek 'hysginon', a crimson or scarlet dye
Lactarius hysginus.spores: pinkish buff in one collection assigned here, Methven(2) says pale buff in mass for var. americanus
Lactarius hysginus.odour: faint (var. americanus), none or slight (var. hysginus sensu Hesler & A.H. Sm. but var. hysginus sensu Neuhoff has strong odor of fruit, and var. hysginus sensu Romagnesi has odor "disagreeable (of burnt wax?)")

Lactarius kauffmanii.nameOrigin: after Calvin Henry Kauffman 1869-1931, professor of botany, University of Michigan, who collected the species in 1915 from Washington
Lactarius kauffmanii.spores: whitish (Phillips), varies from white to off-white to "pale pinkish buff" (almost white), in at least some instances if it is weakly yellowish at first, it becomes whitish on drying out, (Hesler), white in mass (Methven)
Lactarius kauffmanii.habitat: on soil in coniferous woods; July to November (Phillips), on soil in coniferous woods, (Hesler), scattered to gregarious in duff, in coastal coniferous-hardwood forests, October to January, (Methven for California), summer, fall, winter

Lactarius lepidotus.taste: mild but milk may be very faintly subacrid [peppery]

Lactarius luculentus.taste: when mature becoming slightly bitter then slowly peppery, milk mild or a little astringent, making the tongue sting slightly

Lactarius montanus.spores: yellowish white (Arora), ivory to pale cream (Buczacki)
Lactarius montanus.edibility: said to be poisonous, avoid all purple-staining milkcaps, (Arora)
Lactarius montanus.taste: strongly resinous but not peppery, (Hesler), mild to slowly bitter or peppery, (Arora), not distinctive (Methven), bitter (Buczacki)
Lactarius montanus.habitat: gregarious under conifers, (Hesler), single, scattered or in small groups in woods (Arora), fall (Buczacki)

Lactarius mucidus.habitat: on soil in conifer woods, June to November, (Hesler), summer, fall

Lactarius necator.taste: slowly peppery (Methven), mild at first, then very peppery, (Trudell)
Lactarius necator.habitat: scattered to gregarious "in lawns and horticultural plantings in association with Betula spp.", introduced from Europe, (Methven for California, with Latin name italicized), mixed woods, especially Betula (birch), (Courtecuisse for Europe)

Lactarius occidentalis.habitat: scattered under Alnus (alder) and Thuja, (Hesler), scattered in duff, in coastal coniferous-deciduous forests in association with Alnus (alder), (Methven for California), summer, fall

Lactarius olivaceoumbrinus.spores: pale buff (Arora), "light buff" (Hesler), white to pale yellow (Methven)
Lactarius olivaceoumbrinus.taste: very peppery (Arora), mild intensely peppery, "leaving a burning sensation afterward", (Hesler), slowly peppery (Methven)
Lactarius olivaceoumbrinus.habitat: single or scattered or in small groups under conifers, late summer and fall, (Arora), single to widely gregarious on soil under conifers, (Hesler), single to scattered in duff, in coastal conifer-hardwood forests, associated with Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), (Methven for California)

Lactarius olympianus.nameOrigin: after the Olympic Mountains, where type was collected
Lactarius olympianus.taste: peppery [milk at least] (Hesler), milk extremely peppery (Trudell)
Lactarius olympianus.habitat: "scattered to gregarious in conifer forests", June to October, (Phillips), scattered to gregarious "in the montane conifer forests of the Pacific Northwest", (Hesler), summer, fall

Lactarius pallescens.spores: white to creamy depending on thickness of deposit, (Hesler), pale orange in mass (Methven)
Lactarius pallescens.taste: very slowly but distinctly slightly peppery, taste of milk not peppery, (Hesler), not distinctive (Methven)
Lactarius pallescens.habitat: on soil and humus or on moss in conifer forests, late summer and fall, (Hesler), single, scattered or in small groups, on ground in soil, humus or moss, in conifer or mixed forests, (Ammirati)

Lactarius pallidiolivaceus.spores: pale yellow (4A3-2) [color term sometimes given for cream] (Methven)
Lactarius pallidiolivaceus.habitat: type gregarious on soil under Ponderosa pine, (Hesler), single to scattered, scarcely emerging through duff, in coniferous-deciduous forests, October to November (Methven for California), fall

Lactarius payettensis.taste: instantly and strongly burning-peppery, (Hesler), immediately and strongly peppery and burning, (Phillips)
Lactarius payettensis.odour: faintly pungent, disagreeable, (Hesler), faintly bitter and unpleasant (Phillips)
Lactarius payettensis.habitat: scattered "under spruce and fir, with some alder and aspen present", (Hesler), scattered under spruce, fir, and alder, (Phillips)

Lactarius pseudomucidus.spores: white (Arora, Hesler), white to pale yellow in mass (Methven)
Lactarius pseudomucidus.taste: slowly peppery (Arora), slowly peppery or bitterish then peppery, (Hesler), peppery (Methven)
Lactarius pseudomucidus.habitat: scattered to gregarious under conifers, late summer and fall, (Arora), single to gregarious under conifers, (Hesler), scattered to gregarious in duff, in coastal conifer-hardwood forests, October to January, (Methven for California), summer, fall, winter

Lactarius pubescens.spores: cream color with flesh tint, Crawshay C-D, when old D, (Hesler), cream with salmon tint (Phillips)
Lactarius pubescens.habitat: under birch (Hesler), gregarious in grass under birch (Phillips), late summer to fall (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland, variety not specified)

Lactarius repraesentaneus.spores: whitish to yellowish (Arora), pale yellow in mass, (Methven), yellowish: Crawshay B-C, (Hesler)
Lactarius repraesentaneus.taste: slowly bitter or peppery (Arora), not distinctive to slightly peppery (Methven), at times finally bitterish to slightly pepper or both, (Hesler), mild then bitter (Buczacki)
Lactarius repraesentaneus.odour: not distinctive (Methven), not distinctive or faintly fragrant, (Hesler), "rather sweet, thyme or resin-like" (Buczacki)
Lactarius repraesentaneus.habitat: single to scattered or often gregarious on ground under conifers, (Arora), scattered to gregarious in duff, in coastal and in montane coniferous forests in association with Picea spp. (spruce) and Abies spp. (fir), (Methven for California), spruce-fir zone of Rocky Mountains, or other places where spruce is present, (Hesler), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Lactarius resimus.spores: white to "cartridge-buff" Ridgway(1) color, depending on thickness of deposit, (Hesler), whitish (Bessette), white to pale yellow (Methven for var. resimus), pale ochraceous (Buczacki)
Lactarius resimus.taste: slowly peppery or mild or bitterish, (Hesler), slowly peppery (Bessette), not distinctive to slowly peppery (Methven)
Lactarius resimus.habitat: scattered "under birch, aspen, balsam, and pine in mixed stands, late summer and fall", (Hesler), scattered under conifers or hardwoods, August to October, (Bessette), scattered to gregarious in duff, in coastal and montane conifer-hardwood forest, October-January, (Methven for California), summer, fall, winter

Lactarius rubidus.spores: white to pale yellow in mass (Methven), white to pale yellowish (Arora), "pale pinkish buff" (Hesler)
Lactarius rubidus.edibility: yes although a few people are allergic, (Arora)
Lactarius rubidus.taste: not distinctive, (Methven), mild or slightly bitter, when chopped up and slowly dried their flavor becomes sweet and can be used for this in cooking, (Arora), mild (Hesler)
Lactarius rubidus.odour: odor of maple syrup when dried, (Methven), faintly fragrant or pungent, on drying odor becoming strongly aromatic (like maple syrup, butterscotch, fenugreek, burnt sugar, sweet clover), (Arora), not distinctive, becoming aromatic when dried, (Hesler)
Lactarius rubidus.habitat: scattered, gregarious, or cespitose [in tufts] in duff, in coastal coniferous-hardwood forests in association with Quercus (oak), (Methven for California), widely scattered to densely gregarious or in small clumps on ground in woods, sometimes on wood, (Arora), on rotting conifer wood in Oregon (Hesler)

Lactarius rubrilacteus.habitat: scattered or in large troops under conifers, often with Douglas-fir, (Arora for his area of California), gregarious to scattered, especially under 2-needle and 3-needle pines; fall in the Pacific Northwest, (Hesler)

Lactarius rufus.spores: white to pale yellow in mass (Methven), pale yellowish (Arora), cream with a pale pinky tinge (Phillips)
Lactarius rufus.edibility: not recommended (canned in Scandinavia, but North American variants not tested and it may be poisonous raw), (Arora), poisonous (Phillips)
Lactarius rufus.taste: strongly peppery (Methven), strongly but often latently peppery (Arora), immediately very peppery (Phillips), after about a minute of chewing the burning sensation begins (Ammirati)
Lactarius rufus.odour: not distinctive (Methven), mild, (Arora), very slight, developing an odor like bouillon cubes as it dries, (Phillips)
Lactarius rufus.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in troops under conifers, (Arora), scattered to gregarious in duff, in coastal coniferous-hardwood forests in association with Pinus muricata (Bishop Pine), (Methven for California), scattered on soil under pine, in sand dunes, or in sphagnum bogs, (Phillips), in conifer forests, often in swampy places, (Ammirati), commonly occurs with spruce and pine, for example "near the edge of bogs or in other moist mossy areas where spruce occurs", (Trudell), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Lactarius scrobiculatus.spores: whitish to creamy or yellowish (Arora), white to cream (Crawshay A-B) for var. canadensis, but bright ocher (Crawshay D-E) in European type, (Hesler), white to pale yellow for var. canadensis and var. pubescens, pale yellow for var. montanus, (Methven)
Lactarius scrobiculatus.taste: mild or finally slightly peppery (This is var. canadensis - var. scrobiculatus has very peppery taste in Europe but has not definitely been confirmed in North America.), (Hesler), not distinctive to slightly peppery for var. canadensis and var. montana, not distinctive to slowly, slightly peppery for var. pubescens, (Methven)
Lactarius scrobiculatus.odour: faintly fragrant (Hesler for var. canadensis), not distinctive (Methven for all three California varieties), fruity (Phillips), fruity, sour, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)
Lactarius scrobiculatus.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups under northern and mountain conifers, (Arora), fall (Buczacki)

Lactarius silviae.odour: "when fresh ranging from slight to pronounced, on dried specimens strongly sweet (of maple syrup)", (Castellano), strong fragrant, like that of candy caps such as Lactarius fragilis or Lactarius camphoratus (burnt sugar), especially when dry, (Arora), strong and resembling that of Lactarius camphoratus (dried), (Singer), not distinctive despite species name, but sometimes dried fruitbodies with aroma of maple syrup, (Trappe, M.(3))
Lactarius silviae.habitat: forms fruiting bodies beneath soil surface associated with various Pinaceae species, particularly Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) from 200 to 950m elevation, March through November, (Castellano), associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Trappe), October to March (Trappe, M.(1), Trappe, M.(3))

Lactarius sordidus.spores: dull white (from a Smith specimen that seems to fit Peck's description)

Lactarius subflammeus.taste: peppery (Hesler), slowly peppery, (Arora), slowly, slightly peppery (Methven)
Lactarius subflammeus.habitat: type under Pinus (pine) on coastal sand dunes, (Hesler), scattered to gregarious under Pinus (pine), Picea (spruce) and other conifers, (Arora), scattered to gregarious in duff, in coastal coniferous-hardwood forests (Methven for CA)

Lactarius substriatus.taste: milk bitterish then slowly peppery (Hesler), slowly, mildly peppery, (Methven)
Lactarius substriatus.habitat: gregarious under conifers especially coastal, spring and fall or early winter (Hesler), scattered to gregarious in duff, in coastal and in montane coniferous-deciduous forests, (Methven for CA)

Lactarius subvillosus.habitat: cespitose-gregarious under conifers (Hesler), scattered, gregarious, or cespitose in duff, in coastal and in montane conifer-hardwood forests, October to December, (Methven), fall, winter

Lactarius subviscidus.spores: dull white to yellowish (Hesler), white to yellowish (Arora), white (Methven)
Lactarius subviscidus.taste: slightly peppery (Hesler), mild to slightly peppery (Arora), slowly peppery (Methven)
Lactarius subviscidus.habitat: gregarious on very rotten conifer wood or on humus around it, (Hesler), scattered to gregarious on ground or rotten wood under conifers (Arora), scattered to gregarious in duff, in coastal coniferous-deciduous forests in association with Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), September to December, (Methven for CA), fall, winter

Lactarius tabidus.taste: "mild and bitterish", then somewhat peppery and astringent, in gills "mild to bitterish or somewhat astringent"
Lactarius tabidus.habitat: usually gregarious in moist to wet place near Betula (birch), on moors, often among Sphagnum moss, but also near Quercus (oak), Abies (true fir), and Picea (spruce); summer to fall

Lactarius theiogalus.nameOrigin: means "with yellow milk", theion = sulfur (Greek), gala = milk (Greek)
Lactarius theiogalus.spores: white if thin, yellowish in heavy deposits, (Hesler)
Lactarius theiogalus.habitat: in leaf mold, sphagnum, or on soil under hardwoods or in mixed forest, usually with birch, (Hesler)

Lactarius torminosus.edibility: not recommended, but pickled in Europe and added to coffee in Norway, (Arora)
Lactarius torminosus.habitat: on soil "in coniferous and hardwood stands, but with birch almost always present", (Hesler), summer, fall, (Bacon)

Lactarius trivialis.habitat: single to widely gregarious under conifers, (Hesler), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Lactarius vietus.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] in small clusters or single in off-season fruitings, "widely distributed in areas where birch occurs but locally often found on decaying wood of conifers and hardwoods alike, but with birch in the vicinity", (Hesler), single to gregarious or growing in dense clumps "on decaying conifer wood or hardwoods in wet areas near birch", August to October, (Phillips), summer, fall

Lactarius vinaceorufescens.spores: dull white to yellowish (Hesler), white to yellowish (Arora)
Lactarius vinaceorufescens.taste: slightly peppery, more so after changing to yellow, (Hesler). mild to somewhat bitter or peppery, (Arora)
Lactarius vinaceorufescens.habitat: gregarious under pine, (Hesler), scattered or in groups or troops under hardwoods and conifers (Arora, who says that in his area of California it is found particularly with manzanita, oak, Douglas-fir, and pine)

Lactarius xanthogalactus.taste: slightly bitter-peppery (Siegel), not distinctive, at times slightly bitter to slightly peppery, the milk itself not distinctive to slightly astringent when white, slightly peppery to peppery when yellow, often with a bitter aftertaste, (Methven)
Lactarius xanthogalactus.habitat: single, scattered, or in small clusters "on ground, in moss or duff in mixed forests", under hardwoods or conifers, especially common with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and live oak; mid-fall through winter

Lactifluus volemus.nameOrigin: means "filling the palm of the hand", or "the size of a pear"
Lactifluus volemus.edibility: yes when properly cooked (slow best), taste not affected by fishy odor, (Arora)
Lactifluus volemus.odour: often becoming fishy when old or after picked or when being cooked, (Arora), "strong (fish-like), especially on drying", (Hesler)
Lactifluus volemus.habitat: widely scattered to gregarious "on ground under hardwoods (especially oak) or in mixed woods", (Arora), on soil, under hardwoods, apparently more rarely under conifers, occasionally in sphagnum beds, (Hesler), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Lentinellus castoreus.taste: "not acrid, mildly unpleasant, mildly to persistently anesthetic to tongue (two specimens reported as slowly acrid)"
Lentinellus castoreus.habitat: on wood of at least Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), Nothofagus (southern beech), Populus, and Quercus (oak)

Lentinellus cochleatus.taste: peppery (Watling), strongly peppery (Miller), mildly to strongly peppery to peppery-sour, unpleasant in throat, (Petersen), distinctive (Phillips)
Lentinellus cochleatus.odour: usually anise (Watling), of anise or not distinctive (Miller), strong of anise to negligible (Petersen), anise (Phillips)
Lentinellus cochleatus.habitat: on old stumps of hardwoods especially birch, "often forming fused, tightly cespitose clusters", (Watling for Britain), in tight, fused, cespitose clusters, arising from a single base, on hardwood sticks, logs, and stumps, (Miller), in clusters or tufts on logs, stumps, and decayed wood of hardwoods, July to September, (Phillips), summer, fall

Lentinellus flabelliformis.taste: slightly mealy-peppery (Watling), subfarinose [somewhat farinaceous] to slightly peppery, (Miller), "weak, more or less bitter and weakly anesthetic when fresh", sometimes slowly weakly acrid [peppery], (Petersen)
Lentinellus flabelliformis.odour: none (Watling), none or slightly aromatic (Miller), weak, sometimes fruity, typical of Lentinellus [usually described as aromatic or peppery-aromatic], (Petersen)
Lentinellus flabelliformis.habitat: usually in clusters, gregarious or even subimbricate [somewhat shingled] on bark or debarked sticks and logs of hardwoods, noted on Betula, Populus, Alnus, Arctostaphylos uva-ursi, and in a single case on a conifer log; August and September in western North America, (Miller), on twigs, branches, trunks and stumps of hardwoods, (Watling), on twigs and small branches (rarely larger branches) of hardwoods, Picea abies (Norway Spruce), (Petersen), summer, fall

Lentinellus micheneri.taste: peppery (Phillips), mild at first then peppery (Miller(10)), very bitter (Courtecuisse), peppery, "but varying from quickly to tardily, and in strength", (Petersen)
Lentinellus micheneri.odour: sharp (Phillips), fungoid (Miller(10)), none (Miller(14)), weak, spicy-peppery (typical of family), (Petersen)
Lentinellus micheneri.habitat: single or in small groups "on woody debris, sticks or logs of conifers and hardwoods, or occasionally on moss-covered ground", (Miller(10)), on wood and debris mainly under hardwoods, (Courtecuisse), single or in small groups "on the ground or on buried wood or on coniferous or deciduous wood debris", August to November, (Phillips), "on conifer and hardwood or closely associated woody debris", (Petersen), summer, fall

Lentinellus montanus.taste: mild or somewhat peppery (Bessette), often have a slowly developing peppery taste (Trudell)
Lentinellus montanus.habitat: sometimes single but most commonly in imbricate [overlapping] clusters on conifer logs, stumps, limbs, and twigs, under and near melting snow banks from 5,000 to 10,000 feet elevation, May to July, (Bessette), fruiting on conifer logs and twigs as single fruitbodies or "imbricate clusters often extending for several feet along a log"; found in, under, or very near receding snow from about 5,000 to 10,000 feet, (Miller), on wood of conifers, usually in spring, often as a snowbank fungus, (Petersen), spring, summer

Lentinellus subargillaceus.taste: "when fresh tardily mildly acrid and mildly anesthetic"; "taste of dried basidiome mild, not acrid, unpleasant in throat"
Lentinellus subargillaceus.habitat: apparently usually on Alnus (alder) or conifer wood, also Lithocarpus (tanoak) and Quercus (oak), also mentioned was manzanita

Lentinellus ursinus.edibility: inedible due to bitter or peppery taste (Arora)
Lentinellus ursinus.taste: peppery, sometimes developing slowly after chewing, (Watling), strongly peppery, sometimes slowly but most often instantly, (Miller(10)), strongly bitter (Miller(14)), slowly peppery or bitter (Arora), immediately to quickly strongly acrid [peppery], (Petersen), strongly peppery (Phillips)
Lentinellus ursinus.odour: "fairly strong, acid-fragrant, peculiar", (Watling), usually fruity, sometimes fungoid, (Miller(10)), weakly to mildly aromatic, somewhat peppery, (Petersen), not distinctive (Phillips)
Lentinellus ursinus.habitat: occasionally single, more often gregarious, sometimes imbricate [shingled], usually in deep woods in moist shaded areas, on the sides of debarked logs and limbs, sometimes on stumps, growing on both conifers and hardwoods, (Miller(10)), on rotting logs and stumps, usually in groups or shelving clusters on hardwoods and conifers, (Arora), "single to cespitose or subimbricate in groups of less than 10, and then without common tough basal knot"; usually on dead hardwood logs and boughs, but occasionally apparently on conifer wood, (Petersen), spring, fall, and winter, (Miller(14))

Lentinellus vulpinus.taste: peppery (Watling, Miller, Bessette), slowly peppery, reportedly bitter, (Petersen)
Lentinellus vulpinus.odour: not distinctive (Watling, Miller, Bessette), strong of licorice (Petersen)
Lentinellus vulpinus.habitat: imbricate (shingled) with short, stout fused stems on the sides of hardwood trees and logs, noted especially from the wounds of living elms in Europe and North America, but also reported on fallen logs of Betula and Populus, fruits August through September throughout its range, (Miller), on logs or trunks etc. of hardwoods, (Watling for Britain), overlapping on fallen logs of birch and Populus, (Mochizuki), in overlapping clusters on decaying hardwood trees, logs, and stumps, (Bessette), cespitose to densely imbricate (Petersen), summer, fall

Lentinus strigosus.edibility: edible but hairy (Arora), edible when young but very tough when mature (Miller)
Lentinus strigosus.habitat: usually in groups on rotting hardwood stumps and logs (Arora), several to clustered, on hardwood, May to November, (Lincoff), spring, summer, fall

Lenzites betulinus.habitat: annual, scattered or in overlapping rows, on rotting hardwood logs and stumps (rarely on conifers), "species epithet means birch but grows on a wide range of hardwoods, especially oak and willow", (Arora), on hardwoods, especially birch, occasionally on conifers, (Gilbertson), all year (Buczacki)

Lepiota alba.taste: mild, rather unpleasant, (Breitenbach), no radish taste (Hansen, Moser)
Lepiota alba.odour: like Lepiota cristata, (Breitenbach), no radish odor (Moser)
Lepiota alba.habitat: single to gregarious "in (dry) meadows and pastures, on grassy forest edges", summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Europe), in mountains but also in aspen parkland and boreal mixed forest, or under sagebrush, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), single in pastures, (Hansen for Europe), meadows, grassland, (Moser for Europe)

Lepiota aspera.nameOrigin: means "with sharp scales", acutus = sharpened, acute (Latin), squamosus = scaly (Latin)
Lepiota aspera.edibility: edible with caution: when eaten with wine, has caused a rash on skin exposed to sunlight, may be confused with an unidentified species in a section of Lepiota that contains poisonous species, (Sieger)
Lepiota aspera.taste: mild (Smith), not remarkable (Sieger), fairly unpleasant flavor (Lincoff(1)), not distinctive (Bessette)
Lepiota aspera.odour: pungent or absent (Smith), pungent or not remarkable (Sieger), strong somewhat acid odor (Lincoff(1)), not distinctive (Bessette)
Lepiota aspera.habitat: "on soil, in humus, on debris or leaves in woods"; July to September, (Smith), single to scattered in rich soil, humus, forest debris, (Sieger), summer, fall

Lepiota atrodisca.habitat: single, scattered, or in small groups "on ground or rotting wood under both hardwoods and conifers, fall and winter", (Arora), gregarious to single in coniferous forests on humus and rotten logs, (Sieger)

Lepiota castanea.odour: sometimes faintly sweet, (Arora), sweet, unpleasant, or not remarkable, (Sieger), strong, unpleasant, (Hansen, L.)
Lepiota castanea.habitat: single to widely scattered or in small groups "in rich humus in woods, especially under conifers", (Arora), scattered or single, in humus under conifers, (Sieger), single or a few together, sometimes somewhat bundled along paths in forests, (Hansen), fall (Buczacki)

Lepiota castaneidisca.edibility: [not noted, similar species may be deadly]
Lepiota castaneidisca.odour: strong, sweet fruity-aromatic, of cut fruitbodies with rubber component of the L. cristata odor, sometimes with cod-liver oil component, (Vellinga(2))
Lepiota castaneidisca.habitat: gregarious, on ground, in Sequoia sempervirens groves (Redwood), in stands of Cupressus macrocarpa (Monterey Cypress), and in mixed Quercus agrifolia forests (California Live Oak), (Vellinga(2)), type gregarious on ground under redwoods near Searsville Lake, California, (Murrill)

Lepiota castanescens.habitat: gregarious in small groups, rarely single, terrestrial and saprotrophic, in various forest types, e.g. mixed Alnus-Picea sitchensis forest, mixed conifer coastal forest, Cupressus macrocarpa (Monterey Cypress) groves, (Vellinga)

Lepiota clypeolaria.habitat: single to gregarious in hardwood or mixed hardwood-conifer forests, on leaf litter or on soil, summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Lepiota clypeolarioides.habitat: scattered to gregarious under conifers (Sieger), under spruce (Moser for Europe)

Lepiota cortinarius.nameOrigin: means "cobweb" referring to cobwebby veil, or possibly referring to Cortinarius
Lepiota cortinarius.habitat: on needle carpets under spruce and in cedar swamps, (Smith, H.V.(1)), "on needle carpets under conifers or in mixed woods and cedar swamps", (Phillips), fall (Buczacki)

Lepiota cristata.odour: strong, disagreeable, a few collections with an agreeable or fragrant odor, (H.V. Smith)
Lepiota cristata.habitat: single or gregarious, growing on soil, humus, sand, rotten logs, in grass, between rocks, or in woods, (H.V. Smith), "especially in ruderal, locally nutrient-rich places, on woodchips, in city-parks, on roadsides etc., and is not commonly found in natural habitats", (Vellinga(2)), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Lepiota decorata.odour: not distinctive, (Sieger), "astringent lepiotoid, strong and fungoid or indistinct", (Vellinga)
Lepiota decorata.habitat: scattered in conifer duff (Sieger), single or in small groups, on ground in forests, fruiting relatively late in the mushroom season, (Vellinga)

Lepiota eriophora.habitat: single, scattered, or in small groups in woods and in rich soil, (Arora), single, gregarious or cespitose, often in rich humus in woods, late summer and fall, (Smith), recorded under conifers, October, (Zeller)

Lepiota 'felina'.edibility: unknown, but similar species can be lethal
Lepiota 'felina'.odour: not remarkable (Sieger), "like cedar wood or somewhat unpleasant and rubbery", (Trudell), strong, unpleasant, mushroomy, (Buczacki)
Lepiota 'felina'.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to clustered, in mixed forest, near Alnus [alder] and Pseudotsuga menziesii [Douglas-fir], in duff of Thuja plicata [Red-cedar] and conifer needles, (Sieger), fall (Buczacki)

Lepiota flammeotincta.odour: "rubber-like to astringent lepiotoid and unpleasant, sometimes with fruity component", (Vellinga), not remarkable (Sieger)
Lepiota flammeotincta.habitat: single or gregarious in small groups, "terrestrial and saprophytic in litter, in different types of coniferous forests", October through December, (Vellinga), single to scattered in forests, particularly near Pacific beaches, (Sieger), single or in small groups "in woods, under trees, along trails and paths", along Pacific coast, September to November, (Phillips), fall, winter

Lepiota 'fuliginescens'.odour: like the rubber component of the odor of Lepiota cristata, indistinct, slightly rancid
Lepiota 'fuliginescens'.habitat: single to gregarious in small groups, on litter-rich soil, in various forest types, e.g. Callitropsis macrocarpa (Monterey Cypress) stands, under Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood) and other conifers in mixed woods, (Vellinga(19)), the Washington collection was from mixed forest containing conifers but presumably not the spp. above

Lepiota fuscosquamea.habitat: single to gregarious in swamps, humus under conifers, (Sieger), gregarious in cedar swamps, August and September, (Smith for MI), summer, fall

Lepiota fuscovinacea.odour: unpleasant, like Scleroderma, (Sieger), unpleasantly reminiscent of Lepiota cristata, (Breitenbach), earthy, mushroomy, (Buczacki)
Lepiota fuscovinacea.habitat: single to gregarious in or near hardwood and coniferous forests, often in openings, often on bare soil, (Sieger), single to gregarious "in forests, on pathsides, also at forest edges, usually on damp, bare soil", (Breitenbach), fall (Buczacki)

Lepiota helveola.edibility: potentially deadly - has amanitins, (Sieger), there are at least two cases of poisoning from this or similar mushroom on west coast, (Ammirati(1))
Lepiota helveola.odour: fragrant, but may be mild or absent, (Sieger), sweetish (weak), (Moser), musty (Ammirati(1))
Lepiota helveola.habitat: single to scattered, "soil, humus, in gardens, under trees", (Sieger), on ground under oaks or in mixed woods, fall and winter, (Ammirati(1)), single to scattered in soil and humus in mixed hardwood-conifer forests and under conifers, fall, (Ammirati(11))

Lepiota kauffmanii.habitat: gregarious in mixed woods and under thickets of broad-leaved bushes

Lepiota magnispora.nameOrigin: means 'with spores bulging in the middle'
Lepiota magnispora.edibility: "edible" in some European field guides, but avoid because some lookalikes deadly (Sieger)
Lepiota magnispora.habitat: scattered under fir (Sieger), single to gregarious "in hardwood and coniferous forests, on damp to moist soils", (Breitenbach), coniferous woods, (Moser), fall (Buczacki)

Lepiota oculata.nameOrigin: from the resemblance of the cap with its prominent colored umbo to an eye, (Zeller)
Lepiota oculata.habitat: single to gregarious, terrestrial in mixed coniferous, or mixed coniferous-hardwood forests, from end of September in Oregon to end of November in California, (Vellinga), fall

Lepiota 'pilodes'.nameOrigin: from a Greek word meaning tomentose
Lepiota 'pilodes'.odour: "faint, sweetish, fruity-fungoid or farinaceous", not like L. cristata
Lepiota 'pilodes'.habitat: gregarious in small groups, in hardwood forest "on rich loamy soils, also on mine waste heaps", September and October

Lepiota pulcherrima.taste: biting acidic, bitter, (Sieger), very bitter cap cuticle and surface layer of the stem below the ring, (Smith, H.V.)
Lepiota pulcherrima.habitat: single to clustered, on gravel in alder flats along rivers and in nearby needle duff, (Sieger), low moist ground under Impatiens and Sambucus, August, (Smith for MI), summer

Lepiota pulverapella.nameOrigin: probably referring to the powdery appearance of the cap surface
Lepiota pulverapella.habitat: single, in open pastures, November, (Zeller), fall

Lepiota sequoiarum.habitat: scattered or in small groups in woods and planted areas, (Arora), single to scattered under trees, (Sieger), gregarious on ground, November, (Murrill), fall

Lepiota subincarnata.edibility: deadly due to amatoxins, has caused death in Vancouver BC, (Sieger), contains alpha-amanitin and gamma-amanitin (Sarawi(1))
Lepiota subincarnata.taste: taste not remarkable [but do not taste because poisonous] (Sieger), mild (Smith)
Lepiota subincarnata.odour: slightly fragrant (Sieger, Smith), faint, boiled sweets, (Buczacki)
Lepiota subincarnata.habitat: on lawns and in woods, (Sieger), deciduous and coniferous woods (Moser), fall (Buczacki)

Lepista caespitosa.spores: lilac grayish pallid (Bigelow), pale lilac gray (Butler)
Lepista caespitosa.odour: rancid farinaceous when crushed (Bigelow), floury to sperm-like (Moser)
Lepista caespitosa.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] along road banks, September and October, (Bigelow), fall

Lepista densifolia.habitat: gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts], at times in arcs, in mixed woods or under conifers, September and October, in December in California, late July and August in Alaska, (Bigelow), gregarious or clustered, at times in fairy rings, under cottonwood, alder, or red cedar or in mixed woods; August to September, (Butler), summer, fall, winter

Lepista glaucocana.nameOrigin: "glaucocana" means "whitish, pale blue-green" 'glaucus' is Latin for sea-colored and can mean 'bluish green' or 'gray', 'canus' is Latin for 'ash-gray'
Lepista glaucocana.spores: beige-pink (Breitenbach), vinaceous buff or "pale vinaceous fawn", (Bigelow), "pinkish gray to brownish pink" (Butler)
Lepista glaucocana.odour: "rather unpleasantly herbaceous with a farinaceous component" (Breitenbach), fragrant or none (Bigelow, Butler)
Lepista glaucocana.habitat: usually gregarious, in fairy rings or rows, in hardwood and coniferous forests, "also along forest edges, on leaf and needle litter or among grass"; late summer to fall, (Breitenbach), usually gregarious to somewhat cespitose [in tufts]; in a cedar swamp, and on a trash heap, (Bigelow), or along roads where organic material is present in the fill, (Butler)

Lepista idahoensis.habitat: gregarious or cespitose [in tufts], under spruce, in Alaska also in tundra under dwarf birch and willow; June to August in Idaho, August to October in Alaska, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Lepista irina.spores: yellow, near "pinkish buff", also called dull yellow; more highly colored than var. irina
Lepista irina.habitat: single or in arcs, under hemlock, spruce or aspen, July, August, November, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Lepista nuda.nameOrigin: means 'naked'; "blewit" is a shortened form of "blue hat", (Sept)
Lepista nuda.spores: dull pinkish to pinkish buff (Arora), pinkish ("light vinaceous cinnamon", "vinaceous buff", "pinkish buff"), (Bigelow)
Lepista nuda.odour: "faintly fragrant when fresh (like frozen orange juice)", (Arora), pleasant, faintly fragrant, (Bigelow)
Lepista nuda.habitat: scattered to gregarious, often in rings or arcs - "in woods, brush, gardens, compost piles, i.e., wherever there is organic debris", (Arora), single, gregarious or cespitose [in tufts], in humus under hardwoods, under conifers, on decaying vegetable matter or near trash piles and compost heaps, in meadows, on lawns, in orchards; late summer and fall, (Bigelow), spring, summer, fall, winter, (Buczacki)

Lepista praemagna.nameOrigin: prae- Latin early or eminent/ very, magna big, very big (D. Winkler, pers. comm.)
Lepista praemagna.habitat: gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] often forming arcs or rings; in the open in grasslands or under sagebrush; June to September, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Lepista saeva.spores: "pale vinaceous fawn" or paler, (Bigelow), rosy peach color (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), grayish or brownish pink or paler, (Butler), cream-yellow with an orange tint (Breitenbach)
Lepista saeva.edibility: yes (Butler), yes (Courtecuisse, Breitenbach, both for L. personata in Europe)
Lepista saeva.habitat: in the woods, or clustered on trash heap; July to October (December in California), (Bigelow), in deciduous forests, parks, lawns; in fairy rings; late fall, (Hansen), fall to late winter, (Buczacki), summer, fall, winter

Lepista subalpina.taste: mild to disagreeable, (Bigelow), "pleasant becoming a touch astringent", (Phillips)
Lepista subalpina.odour: fungoid or absent, (Bigelow), mushroomy or none, (Phillips)
Lepista subalpina.habitat: type cespitose [in tufts], in large clusters, on sandy soil along road near conifers; August and September, (Bigelow), "in dense clusters near conifers on sandy soil along roadsides", (Phillips), summer, fall

Lepista subconnexa.spores: sordid "light pinkish cinnamon", "vinaceous buff" or "pinkish buff", (Bigelow), Arora gives pinkish-buff or flesh-colored for subconnexa group
Lepista subconnexa.edibility: yes, but not recommended, can have an unpleasant astringent taste when old, and too easy to confuse with C. dilatata or poisonous Entoloma, (Arora)
Lepista subconnexa.odour: "often fragrant, at times mild or rarely disagreeable"
Lepista subconnexa.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on humus or needles under hardwoods and conifers

Lepista tarda.spores: dingy "pinkish buff", "pale pinkish buff", (Bigelow), dingy pale pinkish (Arora)
Lepista tarda.edibility: yes, but not easy to identify (Arora)
Lepista tarda.odour: absent or merely fungoid, (Bigelow), mild or slightly fragrant (Arora)
Lepista tarda.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on soil of cultivated or fertilized areas - gardens, pastures, fields, lawns, compost piles, manure, or occasionally sawdust heaps, rarely in woods, (Bigelow), scattered to gregarious or clustered or sometimes in rings "in grass, dung, manure, straw heaps, old fields, compost piles, etc.", (Arora), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Leptonia acutoumbonata.habitat: scattered to gregarious, "in mossy humus near rotting wood, log, or rotting stump"

Leptonia anatina.habitat: gregarious on ground in mid-July, (Montana), in mixed woods or under coast redwood in California, mid-September to mid-November, (Largent), unimproved grassland, moors, on acid soils, (Courtecuisse for Europe), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Leptonia asprella.odour: indistinct to slightly fabaceous [bean-like], (Largent), +/- mealy (Courtecuisse for Europe)
Leptonia asprella.habitat: scattered to gregarious in mosses and branchlet humus under ferns and near Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), in Washington fruiting early September to late October, (Largent), grassy places, more commonly on calcareous soils, (Courtecuisse for Europe), fall (Buczacki)

Leptonia atrifucata.habitat: type single to scattered among mosses beneath ferns, in coniferous woods near Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Leptonia badissima.taste: "mild to slightly bitter or slightly farinaceous"
Leptonia badissima.habitat: scattered to gregarious in needle humus near Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)

Leptonia caesiocincta.odour: not distinct or occasionally slightly spermatic or slightly fragrant
Leptonia caesiocincta.habitat: single to gregarious in marshy area, in cut-over land, or in grass often beneath ferns and Oplopanax horridus (devil's club), near Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Largent), with Sphagnum, muddy grassland on acidic soils, (Courtecuisse for Europe), fall (Buczacki)

Leptonia chalybea.habitat: single to scattered in grass or humus under conifers and oaks, on mossy humus or on soil, (Largent), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Leptonia coacta.habitat: "scattered to gregarious on buried pieces of wood in cedar branchlet humus, beneath various species of fern and near Western Red Cedar"

Leptonia coelestina.habitat: single in lawn, late October, (Largent), fall

Leptonia convexa.habitat: "solitary to scattered to gregarious in needle humus of coniferous forest, at times beneath ferns, usually near Sitka Spruce, or in leaf humus under Red Alder", mid-October to mid-December, (Largent), fall, winter

Leptonia cyanea.odour: "faint to distinctly fragrant" (odor also referred to as "fragrant or pleasant" and as "slightly fragrant or sweet")
Leptonia cyanea.habitat: "scattered on conifer logs and rotting wood", early October to mid-November, (Largent), fall

Leptonia decolorans.habitat: single to scattered in humus near salal or ferns, under conifers

Leptonia earlei.habitat: single in mossy humus or soil, near or under conifers

Leptonia exalbida.habitat: scattered to gregarious in cedar branchlet humus, in moss, or in rotting wood, in coniferous forest near Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Leptonia exilis.habitat: scattered in mossy humus under Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Largent), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Leptonia foliocontusa.odour: "not distinctive to somewhat fragrant or somewhat spermatic"
Leptonia foliocontusa.habitat: scattered to gregarious in humus under devil's club, and near Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), in California beneath ferns and salal and near Alnus rubra (Red Alder) and Sequoia sempervirens (Coast Redwood), (var. discolor), cespitose [in tufts] on wet earth beneath conifers (var. caeruleotincta)

Leptonia fuligineomarginata.taste: mild to slightly fragrant or pungent
Leptonia fuligineomarginata.odour: mild to slightly fragrant or pungent

Leptonia gracilipes.habitat: scattered or gregarious in humus under conifers (Largent), under ferns, alder and conifers (Arora)

Leptonia grisea.habitat: in mossy humus or in grass, under Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) or Alnus rubra (Red Alder), early October to late November, (Largent), fall

Leptonia incana.odour: "most often strong and like cheese, sweat, or mice", (Largent), of mice (Phillips), strong unpleasant odor of mice, (Lincoff), "described as similar to mouse feces or rancid buttered popcorn", (Bessette)
Leptonia incana.habitat: on soil (Mazzer collection from Idaho in Largent), in grassy areas, August to October, (Phillips), single or scattered in various habitats, especially with exposed limestone, June to September, (Bessette), in "fields and meadows with low grass, or in open but damp parts of woods", (Lincoff), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Leptonia insueta.taste: indistinct to faintly pungent or questionably farinaceous
Leptonia insueta.odour: indistinct to faintly pungent or questionably farinaceous
Leptonia insueta.habitat: single to scattered in branchlet humus or in mosses under oak ferns and near conifers, early October to mid-October, (Largent), fall

Leptonia lividocyanula.habitat: scattered to gregarious in branchlet humus under Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), also lawns or grass near alder or maple, (Largent), fall (Buczacki)

Leptonia microspora.habitat: scattered to gregarious in humus under ferns and Oplopanax horridus (devil's club) near Acer circinatum (Vine Maple), Alnus rubra (Red Alder) or Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Leptonia nigrosquamosa.odour: "indistinct to somewhat spermatic or very slightly fragrant"
Leptonia nigrosquamosa.habitat: scattered in leafy humus or branchlet humus, near Alnus rubra (Red Alder) and Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), late October to November, (Largent), fall

Leptonia occidentalis.habitat: on ground among humus under fir trees in mixed woods

Leptonia ovatospora.habitat: single among mosses near Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Leptonia parva.habitat: scattered or in small groups in forest humus (Arora)

Leptonia pseudobulbipes.habitat: type single to scattered in sandy soil along stream bank, under Acer circinatum (Vine Maple) in Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) forest, mid-October, (Largent), fall

Leptonia rectangula.habitat: growing in duff in coniferous forest

Leptonia rosea.habitat: scattered on humus in mixed conifer woods, or under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), fall

Leptonia rostrata.nameOrigin: means 'beaked', perhaps referring to shape of cheilocystidia
Leptonia rostrata.habitat: gregarious in branchlet humus, in coniferous forest near Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Leptonia serrulata.taste: not distinct to unpleasant to slightly farinaceous (Largent)
Leptonia serrulata.habitat: single to gregarious in branchlet humus, in leaf humus, under or near Red Alder, Western Red-cedar, Monterey Cypress, Coast Redwood, (Largent), single to several, "on the ground in rich humus or on moss-covered logs", June to September, (Lincoff), unimproved grassland, lawns (Courtecuisse for Europe), "early spring in the western mountains and fall elsewhere", (Miller), spring, summer, fall

Leptonia sodalis.habitat: scattered to gregarious in branchlet humus of Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) in grass and under ferns, (Largent), fall (Buczacki)

Leptonia striatula.habitat: scattered in mossy area near devil's club and bracken fern and beneath Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock)

Leptonia strictipes.habitat: single, scattered or gregarious in humus under conifers

Leptonia subcoelestina.habitat: scattered on mossy humus at base of Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Leptonia subgracilis.habitat: in branchlet humus under Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Leptonia subnigra.habitat: scattered in branchlet humus or leaf humus under conifers, (in California occurs also near oaks)

Leptonia subviduensis.nameOrigin: means 'near [Entoloma] viduense', a species discussed by David Largent in the initial description, but not found in the online Species Fungorum or MycoBank, each accessed on August 24, 2017
Leptonia subviduensis.habitat: scattered to gregarious in humus under ferns or salal or devil's club and under Alnus rubra (Red Alder) or conifers such as Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Leptonia tjallingiorum.nameOrigin: means "of the Tjallingiis", probably after F. Tjallingii and G. Tjallingii-Beukers
Leptonia tjallingiorum.odour: somewhat pungent (also referred to as "pungent or unpleasant")
Leptonia tjallingiorum.habitat: on rotting conifer wood at higher elevations

Leptonia trichomata.habitat: "scattered to gregarious in mossy humus or in branchlet humus", under salal, ferns, or devil's club, near Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Leptonia turci.habitat: scattered to gregarious, in humus near or under conifers, in soil over rotting wood under conifers, (Largent), grassland and Sphagnum moss (Courtecuisse for Europe), fall (Buczacki)

Leptonia umbilicata.habitat: "solitary to scattered among mosses, near Grand Fir, Douglas Fir, Mountain Hemlock, or Western Red Cedar", late September to early November, (Largent), fall

Leptonia undulatella.habitat: in hard-packed soil under Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Leptonia violacea.habitat: single among mosses under Oplopanax horridum (devil's club) near Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), mid-September, (Largent), fall

Leptonia violaceonigra.habitat: single to gregarious on rotting conifer logs

Leptonia zanthophylla.nameOrigin: probably refers to yellow gills, 'xanthos' is Greek for yellow
Leptonia zanthophylla.odour: "unpleasant, somewhat spermatic, at times slight and then indistinct"
Leptonia zanthophylla.habitat: single to scattered "in leaf-branchlet humus with little or no moss" near Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) or Alnus rubra (Red Alder), mid-October to early November, (Largent), fall

Leratiomyces ceres.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on wood chips, sawdust, and humus rich in lignin", often on lawns, in gardens etc., (Arora), early fall to late winter, (Bacon)

Leratiomyces cucullatus.habitat: on ground, usually among grasses in wet alpine meadows, (Arora), gregarious, often in large troops, in boggy or marshy areas; on ground among grasses and sedges, (Thiers)

Leratiomyces magnivelaris.habitat: scattered to gregarious, "preferring sandy soils, alluvial plains, and/or soils rich in woody debris of Salix (willow) and Alnus (alder)", May to November, (Stamets, Latin names italicized), spring, summer, fall

Leratiomyces percevalii.spores: dark purple-brown to purplish black, (Noordeloos), "deep purple-brown to almost black"
Leratiomyces percevalii.taste: "mild or slightly raphanoid" (Noordeloos), similar to odor (Kuo)
Leratiomyces percevalii.odour: "fairly strong, more or less raphanoid, or weak, indistinct", (Noordeloos), "not distinctive, or radish-like", (Kuo)
Leratiomyces percevalii.habitat: "in groups on woodchips or raw humus in deciduous and mixed deciduous-coniferous woods, parks, gardens etc., particularly in somewhat ruderal places", June to November, (Noordeloos), "growing scattered or gregariously in waste places, grassy areas, and woodchips", "summer, fall, and winter", (Kuo)

Leratiomyces riparius.habitat: single to gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] under Alnus (alder) and species of Populus (cottonwood and small-toothed aspen), "in moist places such as seepage areas and along streams, spring and fall", (Smith(18)), common during wet periods in summer (Smith(6))

Leratiomyces squamosus.nameOrigin: means 'brittle' from Greek 'thraustos', but Guzman says "The name of this variety refers to the scaly surface of the pileus."
Leratiomyces squamosus.edibility: edible according to some, but not palatable, not active, (Stamets), not edible (Phillips)
Leratiomyces squamosus.habitat: scattered in the fall in decayed wood substrate or wood debris, (Stamets); "in small scattered clusters on wood chips and twigs", (Phillips), in small groups on fallen twigs and branches of deciduous trees, (Kibby), late summer and fall (Miller)

Leucoagaricus adelphicus.nameOrigin: "adelphicus" is the Latinized form of 'adelphikos', Greek for "brotherly" or "sisterly", because of the closeness to Leucoagaricus pilatianus, (Vellinga)
Leucoagaricus adelphicus.habitat: single or in small groups, "terrestrial and saprotrophic", in plantations of Callitropsis macrocarpa (Monterey Cypress), in woods of Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), in Eucalyptus plantings, or in mixed conifer-hardwood forests "of central coastal California", "November to January"

Leucoagaricus americanus.edibility: edible if sure of identification, similar fungi are poisonous, (Arora), edible for most people, reddens urine, (Sieger)
Leucoagaricus americanus.habitat: clustered, rarely single, near rotting wood, (Sieger), in groups or clusters "in sawdust, and compost piles, around old stumps, in waste places, rich soil, etc.", (Arora), single to cespitose [in tufts] in fields or around old stumps, (Smith, H.V.), in groups or clusters on stumps, woodchips, and sawdust piles, (Bessette)

Leucoagaricus barssii.nameOrigin: after H.P. Barss, Head Professor of Botany and Plant Pathology, Oregon State Agricultural College, one of the first to notice the characters by which the species is distinguished from Leucoagaricus leucothites, (Zeller)
Leucoagaricus barssii.edibility: choice, but be sure of identification, (Arora)
Leucoagaricus barssii.habitat: scattered to gregarious "in cultivated or composted soil, lawns, gardens, pastures, and plowed fields", (Arora), pastures, plowed fields, gardens, orchards or harvested grain fields, near old straw stacks or manure piles, favors strawberry or potato plantings, (Smith), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Leucoagaricus cupresseus.nameOrigin: refers to its occurrence under Cupressus (cypress)
Leucoagaricus cupresseus.taste: mild (Siegel), "mild and sweet at first then slowly peppery", especially in the gills, (Burlingham)
Leucoagaricus cupresseus.habitat: single "or scattered in small groups", in coastal California almost always in duff under Cupressus macrocarpa (Monterey Cypress), but also occurs in rich humus of non-native trees "or in garden soil", (Siegel(2)), Washington collection under Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) (D. Miller, pers. comm.)

Leucoagaricus erythrophaeus.nameOrigin: from erythros (red, bloody) and phaeos (dark), "because of the bright red reaction and the subsequent change into dark colors", (Vellinga(18)), roseifolia means 'rosy-gilled'
Leucoagaricus erythrophaeus.habitat: in small groups on ground in different forests, fruiting from the end of October through beginning of December (in California), (Vellinga(18)), single to scattered under trees, especially near Pacific beaches, (Sieger), fall, winter

Leucoagaricus glabridiscus.habitat: gregarious to single in conifer forests, (Sieger), single to scattered to gregarious in humus under Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), September to November, (Smith, H.V.), fall

Leucoagaricus leucothites.spores: white or very faintly pinkish (Arora), white (Smith, H.V.), white, sometimes pale pink, (Sieger)
Leucoagaricus leucothites.edibility: good but not recommended because sometimes toxic, (Arora), some people eventually become sensitive, exhibiting flu-like symptoms, the gray form being more frequently troublesome than the white, (Sieger)
Leucoagaricus leucothites.odour: mild, or in one form unpleasant, (Arora), slight, not distinctive, (Smith, H.V.), not remarkable (Sieger)
Leucoagaricus leucothites.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious "in grassy areas (lawns, pastures, etc.), sometimes also along roads, freeways, and in other disturbed places, and sometimes under trees or even in the woods", all seasons, commonest in fall and early winter, (Arora), "in lawns, meadows, waste land, under shrubs or trees, on compost; September and October", (Smith, H.V.), single to scattered on lawns, roadsides, always in the open, (Sieger), spring, summer, fall, winter

Leucoagaricus ophthalmus.nameOrigin: from Greek meaning "eye", because of the resemblance of the cap covering to an eye, and the resemblance to Lepiota oculata (Vellinga)
Leucoagaricus ophthalmus.odour: indistinct, slightly fungoid or like rubber (as in Lepiota cristata)
Leucoagaricus ophthalmus.habitat: single to grouped, terrestrial among moss and litter, in various kinds of forests, with or without Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce) or Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood), October and November, (Vellinga), fall

Leucoagaricus roseilividus.odour: not remarkable (Sieger), very weak and indistinct, fungoid, or sweet and like rubber (as Lepiota cristata), (Vellinga)
Leucoagaricus roseilividus.habitat: single to gregarious under trees (Sieger), type gregarious, growing on ground, (Murrill)

Leucoagaricus rubrotinctus.habitat: single to scattered or in small groups in humus, usually in woods, (Arora), single or scattered "on the ground, usually on humus, under conifers or hardwoods", (Smith, H.V.(1)), single to scattered under trees, (Sieger), fall

Leucocoprinus birnbaumii.edibility: poisonous to some people, according to some sources, (Arora)
Leucocoprinus birnbaumii.taste: not distinctive (Smith, H.V.), mild with bitter aftertaste (Sieger)
Leucocoprinus birnbaumii.habitat: single, in tufts or in groups "in flower pots, greenhouses and planter boxes, or if warm enough, outdoors (in lawns, gardens, etc.)", at any time of year inside, outdoors mainly in summer, (Arora), has been collected outdoors in WA "in an area with artificially heated soils" (Birkebak referring to Sheridan 1956), spring, summer, fall, winter

Leucocoprinus brebissonii.habitat: "scattered to gregarious, sometimes imbricate and more or less connate", in forests, (Birkebak), usually gregarious, more rarely single in hardwood forests, parks, more rarely also in greenhouses, on humusy soil, summer to fall, (Breitenbach), often appears in late spring but is most abundant in summer, often occurring in large groups on forest litter, (Trudell), all year in greenhouses (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter

Leucocoprinus cepistipes.taste: not remarkable, (Sieger), mild (Smith, H.V., Breitenbach), bitter (Hansen, L.)
Leucocoprinus cepistipes.odour: not remarkable (Sieger), mild (Smith, H.V.), mild, fungal, (Birkebak), faintly spicy, reminiscent of garlic, (Breitenbach)
Leucocoprinus cepistipes.habitat: in groups or clusters in decomposing organic matter: "in rich soil, wood chips, around old stumps, straw piles, gardens", (Arora), cespitose on sawdust or rich soil; June to August, (Smith, H.V.), clustered, gregarious, or rarely single; gardens, compost, mulch, (Sieger), single or subfasciculate [somewhat bundled]; in hothouses and on sawdust (Hansen, L.), fall, all year in greenhouses, (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter

Leucocoprinus cretaceus.habitat: Washington collection "subconnate imbricate on heap of mixed wood chips and horse manure"

Leucocoprinus flavescens.habitat: Washington collection from "an outdoor covered can filled with greenhouse potting soil", Massachusetts and California collections from greenhouses, (Birkebak(1)), type collection from Ohio under black locust and honey locust, 2 collections by Kuo from IL that "appear to match", one in woods dominated by black locust and one in grass under the drip of an air conditioner, with a large honey locust tree 30 feet away, (Kuo(4))

Leucocoprinus heinemannii.habitat: gregarious in potting soil in greenhouses, (Birkebak), in small groups, "saprophytic and terrestrial, in pots of plants, in greenhouses", (Noordeloos)

Leucocoprinus ianthinus.habitat: several or single in greenhouses; fruits in cactus pots, (Sieger), in hothouses and flowerpots (Hansen), summer to fall, perhaps all year, (Buczacki)

Leucocybe candicans.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), mild (Bigelow), rather strong, unpleasant, bitter, (Buczacki)
Leucocybe candicans.odour: not distinctive (Bessette), mild (Bigelow), strong, herbaceous, tomato foliage, (Buczacki)
Leucocybe candicans.habitat: scattered or in groups or clusters "on decaying leaves in hardwoods or sometimes on needle litter under conifers", August to October, (Bessette), scattered, gregarious, or cespitose [in tufts], usually under hardwoods, sometimes under conifers, or (at least in Europe) on Dryas species (mountain avens), (Bigelow), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Leucocybe connata.taste: "mild, pleasant but not distinctive", (Breitenbach), "typically somewhat sour or disagreeable" (Arora), "somewhat sour and disagreeable" (Bigelow)
Leucocybe connata.habitat: clustered to cespitose, often in groups or rows; in hardwood and coniferous forests, "commonly alongside paths and streets, on embankments, among herbs or grass, or also on bare humus-rich, nitrate-containing, calcium-rich or sandy (calcareous sand) soils"; late summer to fall, (Breitenbach), "in dense groups (gregarious or cespitose) associated with broadleaf or conifer forests, frequently adjacent to forest paths"; in this study all samples on calcareous soil; August to November, (Alvarado(2)), in dense groups or clusters in sandy or gravelly soil along roads, trails, etc., (Arora), gregarious to cespitose [in tufts], in the open on bare soil or in low vegetation, often on road shoulders, has not been found on needle beds or leaf mold, although conifers and/or alders do grow nearby at times, (Bigelow), early summer to early fall (Miller)

Leucopaxillus albissimus.odour: unpleasant or fragrant (Arora), "aromatic and sweet but often weak" (Singer(19))
Leucopaxillus albissimus.habitat: single, scattered or gregarious (often in large rings) "in woods, mainly under conifers", (Arora), mostly in mixed woods, on leaves and needles, sometimes in pure hardwood or conifer stands, usually September, (Singer(19)), fall

Leucopaxillus gentianeus.taste: very bitter (Arora), bitter in f. typicus, "bitterish to somewhat farinaceous, strong at times" in f. roseibrunneus, (Singer), "farinaceous with a faint bitter flavor which gradually becomes stronger", (Murrill), not noted for f. bicolor
Leucopaxillus gentianeus.odour: mild or pungent (Arora), peculiar, either strong or very faint and like that of Tricholoma sulphureum but more farinaceous, (Singer for f. typicus), faintly farinaceous to strongly rancid farinaceous (Singer for f. roseibrunneus), farinaceous (Murrill for f. roseibrunneus), not noted for f. bicolor
Leucopaxillus gentianeus.habitat: scattered to gregarious (often in rings) under conifers and oaks, (Arora), mostly in coniferous woods, in southern regions under Quercus (oak), (Singer for f. typicus), gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] and often in arcs or rings; in coniferous wood on needles and especially in places where Alnus rubra (Red Alder) is also present, "in pure stands of which it often occurs in great quantities", under oak more rarely; July to December, (Singer for f. roseibrunneus), summer, fall

Leucopholiota species^.habitat: "scattered, in groups, or clustered on decaying wood, typically hardwood", (Bessette), late summer and fall (Miller)

Lichenomphalia hudsoniana.habitat: scattered, gregarious, rarely somewhat cespitose [somewhat tufted], associated with the lichen Coriscium viride on tundra, June to August, (Bigelow), "grows on arctic or alpine peat and soil (rarely boreal)", forming pale green, slightly concave squamules up to 0.5cm wide much like a Cladonia but sometimes develops a more elongate, lobed thallus, (Brodo), "grows on rich humus, or mossy or rotting woody (delignified) logs and stumps in partly to completely shaded sites", (Laursen), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Lichenomphalia 'oreades'.habitat: scattered or gregarious on moss and sandy soil, lichenized with Coccomyxa, July, (Bigelow(5)), single to gregarious, "alpine to subalpine and arctic", "exposed in sandy cracks and crevasses of bare rock, or on turf, among lichen, moss, liverwort and ericaceous plants, but often away from vascular plants", end of July to October,(Lucking(1))

Lichenomphalia umbellifera.habitat: usually in groups on old lichen-laden conifer logs, or scum-covered soil, always in association with the lichen Botrydina vulgaris, (Arora), scattered to gregarious, associated with the lichen Botrydina vulgaris, on moss, conifer logs or soil, from June to September in temperate and arctic regions, on Pacific coast also March through May and October and November, (Bigelow), probably all year (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter

Limacella glioderma.odour: strongly farinaceous (Scates), distinctly but pleasantly farinaceous (Arora), strongly of meal, cucumber, or watermelon, (Courtecuisse)
Limacella glioderma.habitat: single, scattered or in groups on ground in woods, (Arora), August to October (Lincoff), summer and fall (Breitenbach)

Limacella 'glischra'.habitat: single or in small numbers under hardwoods and conifers; summer and fall (Miller), single to scattered on soil in woods (McKnight)

Limacella roseicremea.habitat: type collected on ground in woods (Murrill)

Limacella solidipes.habitat: on ground in mixed woods and wet areas, July to September, (Lincoff), summer, fall

Limacella subpessundata.nameOrigin: from the resemblance to Tricholoma pessundatum
Limacella subpessundata.habitat: gregarious; type collected in soil in woods at Glen Brook, Oregon, also collected in similar situations in 2 other locations in Oregon and 1 in California

Loreleia marchantiae.habitat: single to gregarious among vegetation of springs or in wet places, among or near Marchantia polymorpha (a liverwort), summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Europe), on living and dead thalli of Marchantia paleacea in alpine zone, (Moser for Europe), on liverworts, especially Marchantia polymorpha, (Courtecuisse for Europe)

Loreleia postii.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on mosses and liverworts or burned-over soil", May to October, (Bigelow(9)), scattered or in groups "on wet soil around springs, seepage areas or brooks", spring to fall, (McKnight), in moss (Courtecuisse), in moss, often on fireplaces, (Hansen), humus-rich woods, in moss, sphagnum, on burned ground etc., (Moser), spring, summer, fall

Lyophyllum acutipes.habitat: type gregarious in moss under pine

Lyophyllum anthracophilum.habitat: usually gregarious; in "several-year-old burned places in forests or along forest edges"; fall to winter

Lyophyllum canescentipes.nameOrigin: means 'canescent foot' (foot that becomes covered with whitish or grayish down or becoming gray or hoary)
Lyophyllum canescentipes.taste: strongly disagreeable farinaceous, more or less rancid
Lyophyllum canescentipes.odour: strongly disagreeable farinaceous, more or less rancid

Lyophyllum chamaeleon.nameOrigin: presumably refers to varied or changeable color, as the chamaeleon changes color according to the color of its background

Lyophyllum chondrocephalum.nameOrigin: means 'cartilaginous head' referring to cartilaginous cap cuticle
Lyophyllum chondrocephalum.habitat: type was cespitose [in tufts] along an old road on soil

Lyophyllum conoideospermum.nameOrigin: presumably refers to the shape of the spore
Lyophyllum conoideospermum.habitat: type single to gregarious on humus

Lyophyllum decastes.edibility: some mild cases of poisoning have been attributed (Arora)
Lyophyllum decastes.habitat: gregarious on ground, "usually in large compact clumps and often half-hidden by leaves and grass", mainly in disturbed areas

Lyophyllum furfurellum.nameOrigin: from furfur = bran, scaly infection of the skin (Latin), perhaps referring to surface of stem
Lyophyllum furfurellum.habitat: type was cespitose [in tufts] under pine on soil

Lyophyllum geminum.odour: not distinct, although var. olens from Michigan has a green corn odor
Lyophyllum geminum.habitat: type of var. geminum was single to scattered on sandy soil

Lyophyllum gracile.habitat: type closely gregarious on soil under conifers in mixed woods

Lyophyllum investitum.habitat: type in tufts under larch and pine

Lyophyllum leptosarx.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to scattered on soil

Lyophyllum loricatum.nameOrigin: means "armored", referring to the tough skin, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Lyophyllum loricatum.taste: mild, not distinctive, at times somewhat peppery, (Breitenbach), with somewhat burning aftertaste (Hansen), somewhat burnt (Moser)
Lyophyllum loricatum.habitat: usually clustered, along edges of forests and paths, in forests, gardens, and parks, "primarily under hardwoods, on bare soil or among grass or herbs", (Breitenbach for Europe), large cespitose tufts, their caps becoming irregularly shaped from crowding, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), in grass under deciduous trees, (Hansen for Europe), especially deciduous woods (Moser for Europe), fall (Buczacki)

Lyophyllum lubricum.nameOrigin: means 'lubricous' i.e. greasy but not sticky or slimy
Lyophyllum lubricum.habitat: type gregarious on soil under conifers

Lyophyllum pallidum.habitat: type gregarious on soil under conifers

Lyophyllum piceum.habitat: type single to scattered under conifers

Lyophyllum scabrisporum.habitat: type was subcespitose [more or less in tufts] under conifers and alder

Lyophyllum semitale.odour: farinaceous (Smith), slightly unpleasant, somewhat rancid, (Breitenbach), rancid (Moser)
Lyophyllum semitale.habitat: gregarious or in small clusters under conifers (Smith), single to gregarious in coniferous forests, alder groves, brushy areas, near Picea (spruce), Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), and Fraxinus (ash), primarily montane; summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Europe), single or gregarious in coniferous forests (Hansen), coniferous woods (Moser)

Lyophyllum solidipes.habitat: type cespitose [in tufts] along trail among Pseudotsuga menziesii [Douglas-fir]

Macrocystidia cucumis.spores: ochraceous pink (Hansen), pink (Stuntz), rust-ocher to orange brown (Breitenbach)
Macrocystidia cucumis.odour: rather strong of raw fish or fresh cucumber, or both, (Stuntz), putty, cod liver oil, or cucumber, (Courtecuisse)
Macrocystidia cucumis.habitat: single to several in grassy areas, May to December, (Stuntz), in the Pacific Northwest usually "in nutrient-rich soils among herbaceous plants in gardens and parks rather than in forests (although it can occur there, usually along trailsides)", (Trudell), spring, summer, fall

Macrolepiota procera.edibility: considered to be one of the best edible mushrooms (Smith, H.V.)
Macrolepiota procera.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious on ground; in Michigan, "along roads, in open oak or aspen woods and edges of woods", August to October, (Smith, H.V.), single to gregarious "in hardwood and mixed hardwood-conifer forests, at the edges of forests or along roadsides, in parks, on soil among leaf litter, grasses, or herbs", summer to fall, (Breitenbach), July to October (Bessette(2)), November to December in Florida (Phillips(1))

Mallocybe leucoblema.habitat: in spruce woods (Kuehner), one collection with Dryas octopetala in alpine habitat in Colorado (Cripps)

Mallocybe subdecurrens.habitat: specimen gregarious on humus under Alnus rubra (Red Alder) and Acer macrophyllum (Big-leaf Maple), (Stuntz), in mixed woods (Kauffman)

Marasmiellus candidus.habitat: in "groups or rows on dead sticks, branches, berry canes etc.", (Arora); densely gregarious on bark or barkless wood of Picea (spruce), Tsuga (hemlock), Alnus (alder), rarely Sequoia, Umbellularia, Rubus (berry canes), or Polystichum (sword fern), August-March, (Desjardin(1) for California), summer, fall, winter, spring

Marasmiellus filopes.odour: of cauliflower when crushed while fresh, indistinct in revived material, (Redhead(34)), mildly alliaceous (garlicky), (Desjardin)
Marasmiellus filopes.habitat: "in troops often numbering hundreds or thousands on coniferous needle beds" with each individual fruiting body on single needles of Abies balsamea, A. amabilis, Pinus contorta, P. strobus, or Picea spp., (Redhead(34)), densely gregarious, in troops on needles of Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), or Abies (fir), in mixed coniferous forests above 2000 meters, (Desjardin for California)

Marasmiellus papillatus.nameOrigin: means 'with a bud' or 'with a nipple'
Marasmiellus papillatus.taste: "vaguely bitter or not distinctive", (Redhead(28)), not distinctive (Smith(8))
Marasmiellus papillatus.habitat: "arising from silt or moss covered wood", on barkless hardwood and coniferous branches "and log pieces in wet depressions or forested areas", (Redhead(28)), gregarious on decayed mossy logs in coniferous regions (Kauffman), scattered to gregarious on humus in wet areas, often under devil's club; fall, (Smith(6)), on barkless wood in forests (Redhead(6))

Marasmiellus pluvius.habitat: "gregarious to scattered on needle beds", attached individually to needles of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) or Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) in coastal rainforests, (Redhead(29)), densely gregarious on fallen (senescent) needles of conifers, most commonly Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (pine), Calocedrus (incense-cedar), or Abies (fir) in northern mixed coniferous woods, September to November, (Desjardin for California), fall

Marasmius cohaerens.taste: "none to slightly alkaline and with a bitter aftertaste", (Phillips), "mild, not distinctive but rather unpleasant", (Breitenbach), mild to alkaline or sometimes bitter and astringent (Gilliam)
Marasmius cohaerens.odour: "somewhat pungent, earthy", (Phillips), none (Breitenbach), nondescript or faintly nitrous (Gilliam, for var. cohaerens "lacking or somewhat pungent with an earthy component")
Marasmius cohaerens.habitat: "in dense clusters or gregarious on decaying leaves, twigs, etc., in deciduous woods", July - October, (Phillips), usually single; "on leaves or small pieces of wood", in hardwood or mixed conifer-hardwood forests, (Breitenbach), gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on rotted hardwood logs or woody debris in deciduous or mixed woods, June to October, (Gilliam), fall to winter (Buczacki), summer, fall, winter

'Marasmius' epiphyllus.habitat: fallen leaves especially Populus, but also other vegetation such as standing dead Equisetum stems, overwintered apple-skins, etc., (Redhead), gregarious on leaves and petioles of Betulaceae, or rarely of Quercus (oak), Prunus, or Fraxinus (ash), in deciduous woods, August to November, (Gilliam), on leaves and sticks of hardwood trees (Hansen for Europe), leaves, stems, blackberry shoots, (Moser for Europe), in California restricted to leaf litter of aspen and dogwood (Desjardin), fall to winter (Buczacki), summer, fall, winter

Marasmius limosus.habitat: scattered on dead leaves of grasses or sedges "in dense moist culms or hummocks in open marshes, along lake margins, and in ditches", (Redhead(8)), collections on Carex (sedge), on grass, on Phragmites communis (common reed); all in wet areas (a salt marsh, a roadside ditch, the margin of an extensive marsh), (Redhead(9)), on grasses, often on Phragmites in moist localities, swamps, etc., (Hansen), on sedge and grass stems (rarely on moss or needle leaves), on damp ground, (Moser for Europe)

Marasmius oreades.nameOrigin: means "growing in the mountains" (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), or refers to Oreas, a mountain nymph
Marasmius oreades.edibility: delicious, discard stems, but make sure it is not Clitocybe rivulosa (see similar), (Arora), adverse reactions in individuals have been recorded (Phillips)
Marasmius oreades.odour: agreeable (Arora), of cyanide or chlorine, (Desjardin), pleasant to almond-like (Phillips), of cyanic acid, faint or strong, (Gilliam), fragrant (Miller)
Marasmius oreades.habitat: gregarious in grass, usually in arcs or fairy rings, (Arora), scattered to gregarious in grassy areas, often growing in fairy rings in lawns, (Desjardin), May to October (Gilliam), spring, summer, fall

Marasmius plicatulus.habitat: widely scattered to gregarious "in humus under trees and shrubs" (Arora), gregarious in humus or grassy areas under oak or various conifers, (Desjardin), July to April (Miller), spring, summer, fall, winter

Marasmius tremulae.nameOrigin: probably referring to habitat on European aspen (Populus tremula)
Marasmius tremulae.habitat: on leaves of Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood); in Europe this species apparently restricted to fallen leaves of Populus tremula, (Redhead)

Marasmius undatus.habitat: single or scattered "in duff in mixed redwood forest, fruiting from fall into early winter" (Siegel), on dead, usually buried pieces of Pteridium aquilinum (bracken fern) in fall (Breitenbach(3) for Marasmius chordalis)

Megacollybia fallax.habitat: scattered to gregarious on conifer logs and debris, summer, (Smith), single to gregarious on rotten conifer logs or lignous soil, (Hughes)

Megacollybia platyphylla.edibility: not recommended, some adversely affected, (Arora), severe gastrointestinal symptoms have been reported (Goos(1))
Megacollybia platyphylla.taste: not distinctive (Smith(15)), bitter (Phillips), mild or slightly bitter (Miller)
Megacollybia platyphylla.habitat: single or in small groups "on or near rotting logs and stumps, especially of hardwoods", common in spring and early summer in eastern North America, (Arora), single to scattered or in small groups, "usually along a rotten log or on very rich humus", June to October in central US, spring and fall along the Pacific coast, (Smith(15)), spring, summer, fall

Melanoleuca angelesiana.nameOrigin: holotype found at Lake Angeles in the Olympic Mountains of Washington
Melanoleuca angelesiana.habitat: type found singly along a trail in the Olympic Mountains of Washington, (Smith(17)), single to gregarious, occasionally cespitose [in tufts], "on ground, near melting snowbanks under conifers", "in late May to mid-July, or in early August in a heavy snow pack year, at high elevations", (Bessette), single, gregarious or scattered, rarely cespitose, on ground under conifers in the mountains of western North America, near the wet margins of melting snowbanks, (Gillman), spring, summer

Melanoleuca cognata.spores: creamy or yellowish (Arora), ochraceous cream (Phillips), deep creamy yellow (Kibby), creamy to buff to yellow ocher, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Melanoleuca cognata.odour: slightly sweet, rancid, or according to Smith peculiar, (Arora), flowery (Phillips), slightly fruity, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), floury-rancid (Kibby), "mild or sometimes sweetish with unpleasant undertones", (Trudell)
Melanoleuca cognata.habitat: single, scattered or in small groups on ground in mixed woods and under conifers, spring to early fall, (Arora), in aspen parkland, boreal mixed forest, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), "forested areas, meadows, parks, and gardens, fruiting from spring into fall", (Trudell), spring, summer, fall

Melanoleuca eccentrica.taste: nauseous and disagreeable (Inocybe-like) (Smith(6)), similar to odor and very disagreeable, (Smith(17))
Melanoleuca eccentrica.odour: nauseous and disagreeable (Inocybe-like), (Smith(6)), subspermatic as in many species of Inocybe, (Smith(17))
Melanoleuca eccentrica.habitat: under conifers in Olympic mountains, October (Smith(6), Smith(17)), fall

Melanoleuca exscissa.odour: "absent or weak, fruity"; for forma iris "strong, pleasant, sweet", reminding one of the odor of Lepista irina
Melanoleuca exscissa.habitat: single, terrestrial in grasslands and in hardwood and conifer forests, especially in coastal dunes and on rich soils, (Boekhout, T.), spring-fall (Breitenbach)

Melanoleuca griseobrunnea.nameOrigin: means gray-brown, referring to cap color
Melanoleuca griseobrunnea.habitat: on sandy soil under Pinus densiflora (Korean Red Pine) and Acer palmatum (Japanese Maple) on a road side, "and in grass in a park"

Melanoleuca humilis.habitat: in moss in spruce-birch bogs, fall (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), meadows, fields, roadsides (Moser for Europe)

Melanoleuca melaleuca.edibility: yes, but not recommended because not easy to identify
Melanoleuca melaleuca.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on ground in open places (lawns, pastures, etc.), under trees, along roads and trails, in straw and wood chips, and also in the woods"

Melanoleuca microspora.habitat: single or in small groups "on moss-covered ground, usually on very moist stream banks in mixed conifer woods"

Melanoleuca strictipes.habitat: single or usually in groups on ground in conifer forests or subalpine meadows in the Rocky Mountains, usually above 3000 feet (Gillman), single to scattered in duff under mountain conifers, "fruiting in spring near melting snow in the Sierra Nevada and Cascade Ranges" of California, (Desjardin)

Melanoleuca subcinereiformis.habitat: type single, "on the ground among decaying leaves and twigs in mixed woods", November

Melanoleuca verrucipes.odour: "faintly of bitter almonds or anise when fresh", later fruity and in some fruitbodies reminiscent of cheese rind, (Breitenbach), "fruity, then mealy-earthy", (Bon)
Melanoleuca verrucipes.habitat: occasionally single but usually gregarious, in forests or in places where wood is stored and bark is discarded, on buried, rotting wood (always?)., late spring to fall, (Breitenbach), short turf, grassy places, bare ground, (Courtecuisse)

Melanophyllum haematospermum.spores: "olive green soon drying reddish brown", (Sieger), "olive green when fresh, red-brown when dry", (Breitenbach), dull red when fresh, drying purplish brown, (Bessette)
Melanophyllum haematospermum.odour: pungent, of cucumber, (Sieger), polyporoid (Breitenbach), not distinctive (Bessette)
