Melanophyllum haematospermum.habitat: "rich soil, leaf litter, compost, bogs, burned ground, greenhouses", (Sieger), single, gregarious, to almost clustered "in forests, brushlands, alongside ditches and paths, on embankments, in places where wood is processed and bark is dumped, on soil among grasses, herbs, leaves, etc., sometimes associated with wood", late summer to fall, (Breitenbach), "scattered, in groups or clusters on rich humus, leaf litter, and very well-decayed wood under hardwoods", June to October, (Bessette)

Meottomyces dissimulans.habitat: gregarious to clustered "in open, moist hardwood or floodplain forests, along streams and rivers, usually near Fraxinus or Populus, on rotting leaves, acc. lit. more rarely under Corylus or other hardwoods and sometimes also on rotten wood"; late fall-spring, "rarely as late as the beginning of May" (Breitenbach(4) for Switzerland, with Latin names italicized)

Micromphale arbuticola.odour: strongly alliaceous (Desjardin(6)), "mild to fetid, strongly alliaceous when crushed", (Desjardin(8))
Micromphale arbuticola.habitat: gregarious "on scale bark of madrone", "fruiting from late fall through mid-winter throughout the range of madrone" [at least in California], (Desjardin(6)), densely gregarious, insititious on scale bark of Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), "often growing in zones which completely encircle the tree base", in California November to February, (Desjardin(8))

Montagnea arenaria.habitat: single, scattered or gregarious "in sandy soil, old fields, and other waste places", in arid and semi-arid areas, (Arora), scattered or gregarious "in sandy places, usually in the open sunlight", (Zeller)

Muscinupta laevis.habitat: growing on living mosses (Eriksson), on or amongst mosses and liverworts, especially of the genus Polytrichum, (Watling), late summer and fall (Trudell), summer to winter (Buczacki)

Mycena abramsii.nameOrigin: after L.R. Abrams, one of the collectors of the type (the other James McMurphy)
Mycena abramsii.taste: "indistinctive or raphanoid", (Maas Geesteranus), without characteristic taste (Murrill)
Mycena abramsii.odour: raphanoid [radish-like] "or nitrous when crushed, also said to be distinctly of chlorine", (Maas Geesteranus), not distinctive (Smith), without characteristic odor (Murrill), "mild to slightly chlorine-like odor" (Siegel)
Mycena abramsii.habitat: "scattered, in small groups or subfasciculate", growing on debris of various deciduous trees (Alnus, Fraxinus, Populus, Quercus) "or on the moss-covered base of living trees", also known from very decayed wood of Picea (spruce) or other coniferous debris, (Maas Geesteranus), gregarious to cespitose [tufted] "on leaves and debris in hardwood forests", (Smith), type scattered on the ground under oaks at Stanford University, California, November 27, 1902, (Murrill), "grows on wood, often in tufts of two or three fruitbodies", (Siegel)

Mycena acicula.habitat: solitary, scattered or in small groups "on leaves and debris in woods, especially along streams and in other wet places", (Arora), single, gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on debris in wet places, particularly along streams or borders of swamps, (Smith), on fallen twigs and decayed wood of hardwoods, (Maas Geesteranus), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Mycena aciculata.nameOrigin: means 'long-bristled' from setae on cap and stem
Mycena aciculata.habitat: single to gregarious on fallen leaves, needles, cones, (Smith), on decaying vegetable matter, including grass stems and fallen coniferous cones, (Maas Geesteranus)

Mycena 'alcalina'.nameOrigin: 'alcalina' means 'alkaline'; epithet 'stipata' according to Maas Geesteranus because "basidiomata cespitose, the fascicles not rarely crowded to form dense groups (hence the specific epithet)"
Mycena 'alcalina'.taste: acidulous but hardly distinctive (Smith), mildly acrid (Miller)
Mycena 'alcalina'.odour: faintly to strongly alkaline (like bleach), (Arora), strongly alkaline, sometimes lacking, (Smith), nitrous, also stated to be alkaline or even of chlorine, more pronounced when cut, (Maas Geesteranus)
Mycena 'alcalina'.habitat: in groups or tufts "on decaying conifer logs, or sometimes densely gregarious on needles under conifers", (Arora), gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts], on decaying wood of conifers and densely gregarious on humus under conifers, particularly larch, (Smith), cespitose [in tufts] on conifer wood (Pinus, Picea, possibly also Abies), (Maas Geesteranus for Europe), spring, summer, fall, winter

Mycena alcaliniformis.habitat: on fallen coniferous logs and other coniferous debris

Mycena algeriensis.habitat: gregarious to densely cespitose [in tufts] on logs, especially alder, spring and fall

Mycena alnicola.taste: mild, but var. odora described from WA somewhat radish-like
Mycena alnicola.odour: mild, but var. odora described from WA somewhat radish-like
Mycena alnicola.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to scattered on alder logs

Mycena alphitophora.nameOrigin: means 'bearer of barley meal', 'osmundicola' means 'living on Osmunda' - Mr. Walters found it on Osmunda fern fibers in a greenhouse in Ohio
Mycena alphitophora.habitat: single to scattered on conifer needles, fern debris, or old leaves, spring, summer, fall, (Smith), usually found on fern rhizomes in hothouses, only occasionally in nature, (Maas Geesteranus)

Mycena 'amicta'.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious on conifer needles or debris or rotten conifer wood, (Smith), often on or near well-rotted conifer wood in the Pacific Northwest, elsewhere on hardwood, (Trudell), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Mycena atroalboides.habitat: gregarious on needle beds or sphagnum, (Maas Geesteranus), densely gregarious on needle beds under conifers or in sphagnum bogs in late summer or fall, on the Pacific coast sporadic and often very abundant under Douglas fir and spruce, (Smith)

Mycena aurantiomarginata.habitat: scattered, gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] under conifers on moss and needle carpets, (Smith), fall, often rather late, (Buczacki)

Mycena bulbosa.habitat: scattered on basal sheaths of Carex (sedge), (Redhead), on herbaceous stems (e.g. Juncus, Scirpus, and Glyceria), (Maas Geesteranus for Europe), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Mycena bulliformis.nameOrigin: "in reference to the large, rather coarse, bulliform excrescences of the pileipellis and stipe cortical hyphae"
Mycena bulliformis.habitat: cespitose [tufted] on bark and wood of standing and dead Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and possibly that of Arctostaphylos glandulosa (Eastwood's manzanita), "North and Central Coast Ranges and the Sierra Nevada Foothills" in California, November to January

Mycena californiensis.habitat: gregarious to scattered, often subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on leaves and fruits of oak (Quercus agrifolia, Q. lobata, Q. kelloggii)

Mycena capillaripes.odour: weakly or strongly nitrous [bleach-like] if fresh material crushed, occasionally mild or somewhat radish-like, (Smith), like chlorine or bean sprouts, especially when crushed, (Siegel)
Mycena capillaripes.habitat: densely gregarious to scattered on needles under conifers, summer and fall

Mycena capillaris.habitat: single or gregarious on fallen oak and beech leaves, typically on undecayed fallen leaves, (Smith), single or in small groups on fallen oak (and beech) leaves, usually confined to single leaf, (Arora), fall (Buczacki)

Mycena chloranthoides.habitat: gregarious to scattered under conifers, especially Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Smith)

Mycena cinerella.habitat: single, in small groups, or gregarious among moss, fallen leaves of hardwoods, and needles of conifers, (Maas Geesteranus), fall to early winter (Buczacki)

Mycena citrinomarginata.nameOrigin: refers to gills which are yellow on the edges
Mycena citrinomarginata.habitat: single, scattered, or gregarious on moss, leaves, needles, or humus in deciduous and coniferous woods, spring and fall, (Smith), "in a wide variety of habitats, including under trees in forests and parks, under fallen leaves and mosses, on rotting tree bark, and in city-dwellers' lawns", (Trudell), fall to winter (Buczacki), spring, fall, winter

Mycena clavicularis.habitat: gregarious in large numbers under conifers, spring, summer and fall

Mycena coracina.habitat: on humus in coniferous or mixed woods (Maas Geesteranus), on humus in mixed woods but also on decaying fir logs, (Smith for Mycena excisa)

Mycena corticalis.habitat: scattered on bark of Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), October and November, (Smith), fall

Mycena culmigena.nameOrigin: means 'produced on a stem', 'juncicola' means 'living on Juncus'
Mycena culmigena.habitat: on decaying sedge leaves and stems (Maas Geesteranus), on sedges and rushes, along lake, river, and ocean shores, (Redhead(6))

Mycena deceptor.nameOrigin: 'deceptor' means 'deceiver', a name that was suggested by Smith's observations that "specimens of this species are very similar in stature to M. sanguinolenta" and "The colors of the pileus shade over into vinaceous, and cause the fruiting bodies to resemble closely those of M. capillaripes"; 'debilis' means 'weak'
Mycena deceptor.habitat: scattered on grass in pastures or in open stands of conifers, summer and fall, (Smith)

Mycena 'elegantula'.habitat: single or gregarious or at times cespitose [in tufts], on decayed conifer wood, spring and fall, (Smith), gregarious to cespitose, growing among fallen leaves under trees, (Maas Geesteranus)

Mycena 'epipterygioides'.habitat: gregarious under conifers, also oak, late in fall

Mycena fagetorum.habitat: scattered to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] among fallen leaves in oak woods (Smith) or attached by whitish fibrils to fallen beech foliage (Maas Geesteranus)

Mycena fallax.habitat: on Rubus canes in very wet localities

Mycena filopes.taste: peppery in 2 collections, but few notes have been made
Mycena filopes.odour: not distinct or none when fresh, iodoform [iodine-like] on drying out
Mycena filopes.habitat: "in mossy lawns, under conifers as well as deciduous trees, on vegetable debris, decaying wood, not infrequently also on moss-covered tree trunks", (Maas Geesteranus), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Mycena fragillima.habitat: gregarious in and around clumps of ferns (Polystichum munitum), on fern debris or on soil

Mycena fuliginella.habitat: gregarious on logs and stumps of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)

Mycena galericulata.nameOrigin: refers to a kind of head-gear worn in ancient times; 'rugulosiceps' means 'wrinkled cap'
Mycena galericulata.edibility: [yes according to some sources, but not recommended because relatives untested]
Mycena galericulata.taste: none, farinaceous, of cucumber, sometimes very strong
Mycena galericulata.odour: none, faint, farinaceous, of fresh grass, radish-like, rancid, disagreeable, or nauseous
Mycena galericulata.habitat: in small groups or fasciculate [in bundles], more rarely single, at the base of old stumps, on fallen branches and generally on decaying wood of both hardwoods and conifers, (Maas Geesteranus), spring and fall (Miller), summer and fall (Bacon), all year but most common in fall (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter

Mycena galopus.habitat: scattered, gregarious or subfasciculate, much more rarely fasciculate [bundled], on debris and decayed wood of various hardwoods, on Alnus (alder) cones as well as on fallen needles of Larix (larch) and Picea (spruce), (Maas Geesteranus), gregarious to scattered on humus under hardwood or conifers, (Smith), summer, fall, (Bacon)

Mycena gaultheri.nameOrigin: from Gaultheria shallon, on which it grows
Mycena gaultheri.habitat: singly or in groups or two or more on dead leaves of Gaultheria shallon (salal), (Smith), erumpent from fragments of decaying leaf tissue amid Gaultheria shallon (salal), Cornus canadensis (bunchberry), and Berberis nervosa (Oregon grape), beneath Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Acer circinatum (vine maple), (Redhead)

Mycena griseiconica.habitat: subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on debris in Douglas-fir forest

Mycena haematopus.taste: mild to bitterish (Smith), absent or bitterish (Maas Geesteranus)
Mycena haematopus.odour: not distinctive (Smith), not distinct or fungoid or perhaps somewhat radish-like, (Maas Geesteranus)
Mycena haematopus.habitat: single "or more commonly tufted or in groups on decaying logs and stumps (mostly hardwoods)", (Arora), single to cespitose [in tufts] on decaying wood, (Smith), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller)

Mycena hudsoniana.nameOrigin: named after the 'Hudsonian life zone' where it was found in the Olympic Mountains of Washington
Mycena hudsoniana.habitat: gregarious on needle beds under conifers (Smith), restricted to conifer forests and usually found on woody debris or duff near snow banks above 700m. elevation, April - July, (Castellano), spring species known to occur in May and June (Maas Geesteranus), spring, summer

Mycena inclinata.taste: slightly farinaceous (Smith), similar to odor but also said to be acrid [peppery] and disagreeable, (Maas Geesteranus), slightly astringent, rancid, (Lincoff(1))
Mycena inclinata.odour: slightly farinaceous (Smith), very strong when cut, farinaceous, rancid, cucumber or French beans (Maas Geesteranus), mealy [farinaceous] or rancid (Phillips), slightly alkaline (Lincoff(1)), candles (Courtecuisse), cheap soap or cucumber (Kibby)
Mycena inclinata.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to densely gregarious on stumps and debris of hardwoods, (Smith), in dense tufts on decaying hardwood stumps, especially oak, May to November, (Phillips), spring, summer, fall

Mycena insignis.habitat: gregarious in troops on needle beds: the conifer needles on which it grows become whitish

Mycena 'laevigata'.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to subcespitose on wood of conifers

Mycena latifolia.nameOrigin: means 'broad-gilled', largus = large, wide (Latin), folium = leaf (Latin)
Mycena latifolia.taste: farinaceous (Smith), strongly farinaceous, also somewhat acrid [peppery], (Maas Geesteranus)
Mycena latifolia.odour: mild (Smith), not distinct or somewhat farinaceous, (Maas Geesteranus)
Mycena latifolia.habitat: gregarious on needle beds under conifers, often in great quantity; generally most abundant in late summer or early fall, (Smith), on or among fallen needles of various conifers, one under birch, and another "among grass along a road in a wood of oak and chestnut", (Maas Geesteranus)

Mycena leptocephala.taste: acidulous (Smith), rarely recorded, once stated to be disagreeable, (Maas Geesteranus)
Mycena leptocephala.odour: weakly alkaline (stronger if crushed), (Smith), nitrous (by some collectors experienced as of potato skin or alkaline), but fugacious [fleeting] and sometimes seemingly absent, (Maas Geesteranus)
Mycena leptocephala.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on fallen sticks and on needle carpets under conifers" (Smith), on tree stumps and decayed and often moss-covered wood of both hardwoods and conifers, on fallen branches, among grass and moss, in sheltered as well as exposed habitats, (Maas Geesteranus), usually fall (Buczacki)

Mycena litoralis.habitat: gregarious on fern debris in the sand

Mycena lohwagii.taste: none or vaguely of cut grass (Redhead)
Mycena lohwagii.odour: none or vaguely of cut grass (Redhead), none (Maas Geesteranus)
Mycena lohwagii.habitat: in small to large densely aggregated groupings "emerging through litter and loamy soils" from old underground rhizomes of Athyrium filix-femina in dense coniferous forests, (Redhead), densely cespitose [in tufts], mainly on fern rhizomes, (Maas Geesteranus), cespitose to densely gregarious in low land (Smith)

Mycena macrocystidiata.odour: nitrous (Smith(1)), chlorine (Singer(22), Singer(23)), faintly sour-nitrous (B. McAdoo, pers. comm.)
Mycena macrocystidiata.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [tufted] on conifer logs and debris, in Michigan most abundant late May and early June in Ann Arbor vicinity, (Smith), a cluster on rotten conifer wood, June 17 (B. McAdoo, pers. comm.)

Mycena maculata.odour: absent, not distinctive, or faintly spermatic
Mycena maculata.habitat: fasciculate [bundled] on coniferous wood or hardwood, (Maas Geesteranus), fall (Buczacki)

Mycena madronicola.habitat: densely gregarious on scaly bark of old madrone, late November and early December, (Smith), fall, winter

Mycena megaspora.taste: mild or slightly astringent (Smith), none, indistinct, or rancid-farinaceous, (Maas Geesteranus)
Mycena megaspora.odour: none (Smith), none, indistinct or strong, said to be radish-like on being crushed by one collector, farinaceous by another (Maas Geesteranus)
Mycena megaspora.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in small clusters from common pseudorhiza in Sphagnum bogs, in swampy muck soil under Vaccinium corymbosum (highbush blueberry) and Rhus vernix (poison sumac), (Smith), scattered to gregarious or subfasciculate [somewhat bundled] "in a wide variety of habitats, burnt heaths, naked peat, Sphagnum bogs, Molinia tussocks, among Empetrum and Vaccinium, in boggy ground under conifers (Picea, Pinus)", (Maas Geesteranus for Europe, with Latin names in italics), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Mycena meliigena.habitat: "scattered or in small groups" on "(usually moss-covered) bark of various living deciduous trees", (Maas Geesteranus), on bark of standing or fallen trees (Kuo), densely gregarious "on dead or live trees, often covering large areas of the bark", (Smith)

Mycena metata.odour: sharp, rather faint (hardly alkaline), (Smith), none or hard to describe when fresh, of iodoform on drying out, (Maas Geesteranus), +/- iodoform-like (Breitenbach)
Mycena metata.habitat: scattered to gregarious under conifers, (Smith), summer to late fall (Buczacki)

Mycena monticola.habitat: gregarious on needle beds under pine (3500-4500 feet), (Smith), restricted to conifer forests above 1000m, particularly those with pine, and usually in gregarious cespitose clusters in duff, (Castellano)

Mycena murina.nameOrigin: 'murina' means 'of mice' and refers to color gray with a slight bluish tint; 'stannea' means 'of tin'
Mycena murina.habitat: in coniferous woods (Maas Geesteranus), gregarious "on humus in hardwood and coniferous forests" (Smith)

Mycena nivicola.habitat: single to scattered, gregarious or somewhat cespitose "on woody debris (often buried) adjacent to melting snowbanks", in California "common in pine-fir forests at higher elevations in the spring in the Sierra Nevada and Cascade Ranges"

Mycena odorifera.odour: strong, developing soon after picked and persistent in dried material, fragrant, fruity, (Smith), strong, persistent for a long time, fragrant according to Smith, subalkaline according to Peck, "apparently at times faint and remaining unnoticed", (Maas Geesteranus)
Mycena odorifera.habitat: gregarious to scattered, "on fallen leaves of [sic] conifer needles", late spring and summer, (Smith), scattered to gregarious on fallen conifer needles (e.g. Thuja), but also among fallen Quercus leaves, (Maas Geesteranus)

Mycena oregonensis.habitat: scattered to gregarious, inserted on needles of Douglas fir and spruce, reported by Kauffman on pine needles and oak leaves, (Smith), inserted on fallen needles of Douglas fir and spruce, (Maas Geesteranus)

Mycena overholtsii.nameOrigin: after L.O. Overholts, who sent material for study
Mycena overholtsii.odour: pungent and yeasty (Smith), pungent and yeast-like, (Maas Geesteranus), fungusy, (Phillips)
Mycena overholtsii.habitat: densely cespitose [in tufts] on rotting conifer logs and stumps at high elevations, in spring and early summer as the snow melts, often found on wood still partly buried in snow, (Smith), cespitose, forming dense clusters on well decayed conifer logs and stumps in spring and early summer, at high altitudes near melting snow, (Maas Geesteranus), clustered on conifer logs, sometimes under snow, and in deciduous woods, (Phillips), late May to early October depending on elevation (Miller), spring, summer, fall

Mycena 'parabolica'.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on wood of hardwood or conifer trees

Mycena paucilamellata.habitat: growing on redwood twigs and needles

Mycena pearsoniana.nameOrigin: after Pearson who in 1952 showed that the type specimens of Mycena pseudopura Cooke had amyloid spores, necessitating a name change for Mycena pseudopura sensu Kuehner
Mycena pearsoniana.odour: musty or radish-like, (Maas Geesteranus), faint, of radish, (Hansen, L.)
Mycena pearsoniana.habitat: "in leaf humus, among herbs, under shrubs or deciduous trees, less frequently under conifers", (Maas Geesteranus), woods, alder carrs, sometimes in Sphagnum, (Moser), in humid forests in fall, (Hansen, L.), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Mycena pelianthina.habitat: single to gregarious on humus in oak-hickory forests, late summer and fall, (Smith), under various deciduous trees (Alnus, Fagus, Fraxinus, Quercus) and also on needles in spruce woods, (Maas Geesteranus), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Mycena piceicola.habitat: gregarious or in troops on needle beds under spruce and more rarely under Douglas fir

Mycena picta.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] or single at times, "on rich humus in dense forests or thickets", summer and fall, (Smith), usually gregarious, more rarely single, "on remains of wood, needles, or leaves on the ground, also on mossy trunks of living hardwoods", in hardwood forests or mixed hardwood-conifer forests, summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Mycena pseudoclavicularis.habitat: gregarious under Pinus ponderosa (ponderosa pine), October and November, (Smith), fall

Mycena pterigena.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious along fallen senescent fronds of Athyrium filix-femina (L.) Roth (lady-fern), "mostly in very dense stands of the ferns with abundant accumulated litter", (Redhead), scattered to gregarious on decaying fern fronds, (Smith), single to gregarious on dead, moist leaf stems or rhizomes of various ferns from the previous year lying on the ground, often lying under the protecting fresh fronds: because they depend on a moist microclimate, they fruit primarily in places with a northern exposure or in ditches or ravines, (Breitenbach), fall (Buczacki)

Mycena pura.edibility: not recommended: edible according to some sources, but containing muscarine according to one study, (Arora)
Mycena pura.habitat: single or in groups or small tufts on ground in woods, (Arora), growing "on leaf humus in deciduous as well as coniferous woods", (Maas Geesteranus), scattered to gregarious on humus in both coniferous and hardwood forests, spring, early summer, and fall, (Smith)

Mycena purpureofusca.habitat: single to cespitose [in tufts] on conifer wood and debris, (Smith), single or in small groups or tufts on conifer wood and debris, on old pine cones, (Arora), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Mycena pusilla.habitat: on moss and needle carpets under Douglas fir

Mycena 'pusillissima'.habitat: gregarious on sticks of conifers (small twigs and branches that have fallen to the ground)

Mycena quiniaultensis.nameOrigin: after Lake Quinault in Washington, where a specimen was found by Kauffman in 1925 - Lake Quiniault appears to be an older or variant spelling, see for instance the article in The Nidiologist II(2): 26. 1894, entitled "Birds Observed at Quiniault Lake"
Mycena quiniaultensis.habitat: densely gregarious on needle beds under conifers

Mycena robusta.nameOrigin: means 'hard and strong like oak'; 'plumbea' means 'of lead'
Mycena robusta.habitat: scattered to gregarious on fallen needles and other debris of coniferous trees (Pinus, Pseudotsuga, Thuja), (Maas Geesteranus), densely gregarious to scattered on humus and debris in mixed woods of Alnus rubra and Thuja plicata, (Smith)

Mycena rosella.habitat: gregarious in large troops or scattered on needle beds in coniferous forests, (Smith), in coniferous woods (Picea, Pinus), (Maas Geesteranus), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Mycena rubromarginata.habitat: scattered on naked branches of dead fir or spruce trees or on lower dead branches of the living trees, often abundant in slashings, (Smith), rotten conifer wood, also hardwood, (Courtecuisse for Europe), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Mycena rutilantiformis.habitat: "scattered or in groups on humus or rotten hardwood debris", May to June, September to October, (Phillips), gregarious to scattered "on humus and debris, usually under oak and hickory during the spring and fall", (Smith), spring, summer, fall

Mycena sanguinolenta.taste: not distinctive (Smith as M. sanguinolenta), mild (Smith as M. subsanguinolenta)
Mycena sanguinolenta.odour: mild (Arora), not distinctive, (Smith as M. sanguinolenta), mild (Smith as M. subsanguinolenta), indistinct or radish-like, (Maas Geesteranus)
Mycena sanguinolenta.habitat: single or widely scattered to gregarious or in tufts "on leaf mold and needles in woods or at their edges", (Arora), gregarious on leaf mold, moss beds, or needle carpets, spring and fall, (Smith as M. sanguinolenta), densely gregarious on needle beds under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), (Smith as M. subsanguinolenta), scattered or in small groups, more rarely subfasciculate [almost bundled], on "humus and vegetable debris among grass and moss, on fallen twigs and moss-covered trunks of deciduous trees, among fallen needles of coniferous trees" (Juniperus, Pinus), more rarely even on decayed Pinus cones, (Maas Geesteranus), fall (Buczacki)

Mycena silvae-nigrae.taste: similar to odor, 'then strangely "metallic"-unpleasant, more or less astringent'
Mycena silvae-nigrae.odour: "pronouncedly nitrous (although also experienced as alkaline), stronger when bruised"
Mycena silvae-nigrae.habitat: single, "in small groups, or cespitose"; growing "on dead coniferous wood", particularly on much decayed Picea (spruce) stumps, but also among mosses (Polytrichum commune) or Sphagnum on woody debris

Mycena strobilinoidea.nameOrigin: means 'like [Mycena] strobilina', an obsolete species name
Mycena strobilinoidea.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious in needle beds under conifers (especially pine), especially in mountains, (Arora), densely gregarious, "often forming extensive carpets on needle beds, usually under pine, during late summer and fall", (Smith(1))

Mycena stylobates.nameOrigin: means 'continuous base supporting a row/circle of columns' (Latin)
Mycena stylobates.habitat: scattered or gregarious "on oak leaves or coniferous needles, spring and summer or early fall", (Smith), scattered or gregarious on fallen leaves, needles, bark, or debris, (Phillips), scattered on dead leaves of Juncus, grasses, Polystichum munitum (western sword fern), or tree leaf litter, in ditches and shady coniferous or mixed forests, (Redhead)

Mycena subcana.habitat: single to gregarious "on dead sticks, branches, or trunks of coniferous trees, particularly cedar" [found on both Thuja plicata and Chamaecyparis lawsoniana], occasionally alder and tanbark oak; usually above forest floor, (Smith), single or in pairs or small groups (not clusters) on dead sticks and branches, sometimes on living trees, (Arora)

Mycena subcucullata.habitat: gregarious on mossy logs, September, (Smith), fall

Mycena subvitrea.habitat: gregarious in small groups under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)

Mycena tenax.taste: strong, disagreeable, rancid-farinaceous, or green watermelon or watermelon rind, (Smith), strong, rancid-farinaceous or like cucumber, (Castellano)
Mycena tenax.odour: strong, disagreeable, rancid-farinaceous, or green watermelon or watermelon rind, (Smith), strong, rancid-farinaceous or like cucumber, (Castellano)
Mycena tenax.habitat: densely gregarious under conifers, common in fall but rare in spring, (Smith), densely gregarious in duff under Abies, Pseudotsuga, Picea, and Sequoia, spring and fall, (Castellano)

Mycena tenerrima.habitat: singly or in twos or threes, on twigs or mossy trunks of hardwoods and more rarely conifers, (Maas Geesteranus for Europe), scattered to gregarious on twigs, bark, and debris of conifers and hardwoods, spring and fall, (Smith), fall to winter (Buczacki)

Mycena tubarioides.nameOrigin: possibly indicating a likeness to the genus Tubaria
Mycena tubarioides.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] or in small close groups, on decayed leaf sheaths of Juncus and Typha and stems of Scirpus in wet places, (Maas Geesteranus), cespitose to scattered on decaying, water-soaked leaves and sheaths of Typha latifolia L. and Scirpus ?acutus Muhl. "in cavities among collapsed vegetations in valley bottom fens", (Redhead)

Mycena vitilis.habitat: scattered to gregarious on debris in hardwood or mixed conifer and hardwood forests, especially red alder slashes, (Smith), summer to fall (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Mycena vulgaris.odour: slight when flesh crushed, somewhat nauseous or radish-like, (Smith), in Europe can be farinaceous according to Maas Geesteranus
Mycena vulgaris.habitat: on needle beds under conifers, late fall, especially in cool wet weather

Mycenella margaritispora.nameOrigin: perhaps implies a pearl-like appearance of the spores: Latin 'margarita' and Greek 'margarites' mean 'pearl'
Mycenella margaritispora.habitat: single or in groups of 2 or 3, "on old wood, chip dirt, and debris", "in the summer and fall"

Mycenella nodulosa.habitat: scattered on humus in conifer forest

Mycetinis alliaceus.odour: strongly of garlic (product of separation of gamma-glutamyl-marismin)
Mycetinis alliaceus.habitat: on sticks and wood of Fagus (beech), rarely also on the leaves, (Hansen for Europe), foliage, needles, rotting wood, (Moser for Europe), single to gregarious on dead branches, twigs, and trunks of Fagus lying on the ground, early summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Europe)

Mycetinis applanatipes.odour: "pungent, like garlic and rotting cabbage" (Siegel), "strongly alliaceous" (Desjardin)
Mycetinis applanatipes.habitat: scattered to gregarious, "often in small fused clusters, on conifer duff and needles", most collections in Abies magnifica (Red Fir) forests, typically in high-elevation forests above 2000 meters (in California), (Siegel), October to November (Desjardin for California)

Mycetinis copelandii.edibility: yes, as seasoning but cook only slightly (Arora)
Mycetinis copelandii.taste: strongly alliaceous (Desjardin(1)), garlicky to slightly peppery (Arora)
Mycetinis copelandii.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on or among senescent leaves of Lithocarpus densiflora, Castanopsis spp., and Quercus spp. in mixed woods, (Desjardin(1) for California), scattered to gregarious on fallen leaves, also on chinquapin burrs, (Arora)

Mycetinis salalis.nameOrigin: means 'of salal', the common ericaceous undergrowth
Mycetinis salalis.habitat: on senescent leaves and branches of Gaultheria shallon (salal) and Mahonia nervosa (Oregon grape), (Desjardin), on leaves and stems of Gaultheria shallon and occasionally Mahonia nervosa (Redhead(6))

Mycetinis scorodonius.habitat: scattered to gregarious on coniferous debris in forests with Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Desjardin), "scattered or in groups on debris, bark, twigs, grass, needle duff", (Phillips), fall, on twigs and debris, commonly on dead fern stems or needles in Douglas-fir forests, (Ammirati), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller)

Mycopan scabripes.habitat: gregarious to scattered, occasionally in clusters of 2-3, on humus under hardwoods and conifers, (Smith), fall (Buczacki)

Mythicomyces corneipes.habitat: gregarious along margins of bogs among mosses or on wet soil under conifers and alders, (Redhead)

Myxomphalia maura.taste: somewhat farinaceous to mild, (Smith, Bigelow(6)), mild to slightly bitterish (Breitenbach for Europe)
Myxomphalia maura.odour: not distinctive (Smith), slightly rancid-spermatic (Breitenbach for Europe), mild, or (at least in Europe) farinaceous or fruity, (Bigelow(4))
Myxomphalia maura.habitat: single, scattered or in groups on burned soil and debris, especially under conifers, (Arora), scattered to gregarious on burned areas, during fall rainy season, but also found in spring, (Smith), May to June, September to October, (Lincoff), spring, summer, fall

Naucoria 'escharioides'.odour: mild to strongly acidic (Lincoff), no distinct odor (Trudell)
Naucoria 'escharioides'.habitat: in groups under Alnus (alder), (Hansen), damp alder thickets (Moser), under alder in boggy areas, (Lincoff), fall (Buczacki)

Naucoria salicis.nameOrigin: means 'of Salix' referring to the association with willow
Naucoria salicis.taste: mild to somewhat astringent (Breitenbach), none or slightly bitterish (Moser)
Naucoria salicis.habitat: usually gregarious in moist places near Salix (willow), (Breitenbach), bound to Salix (Hansen, L.), summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Neolentinus adhaerens.taste: bitter, astringent, (Castellano), mild (Bessette), mild, becoming somewhat peppery-bitter and irritating after fairly long chewing, (Breitenbach)
Neolentinus adhaerens.habitat: on conifer logs; Washington records in October-November (Castellano), single, gregarious to even clustered, on dead conifer wood, on stumps and on trunks lying on the ground, fall to spring, (Breitenbach), single or in small groups on dead roots and branches of Abies, Picea, Pinus, Fraxinus, logs or stumps of Fagus or Tsuga, (Bessette), fall

Neolentinus kauffmanii.nameOrigin: presumably after Calvin Henry Kauffman 1869-1931, professor of botany University of Michigan
Neolentinus kauffmanii.taste: peppery, (Mochizuki), merely fungoid, (Bier), slightly peppery at times (Trudell), slightly peppery (Siegel)
Neolentinus kauffmanii.habitat: single to scattered, rarely in small clusters along old conifer logs, especially Sitka spruce, forms a brown pocket-rot in the log, (Mochizuki), scattered to gregarious on spruce logs and stumps, May, June, September, October, (Bier), spring, summer, fall

Neolentinus lepideus.edibility: "quite good, but the tough flesh requires thorough cooking", use only young caps, as older specimens may have unpleasant taste, (Arora), not edible (Phillips)
Neolentinus lepideus.odour: "usually distinctive (pungent or fragrant)", (Arora), sweetish, like anise or balsam, (Breitenbach), fragrant, like anise, (Phillips)
Neolentinus lepideus.habitat: single, scattered, or in small groups "on conifer logs, stumps, fence posts, and other lumber, sometimes also on oak", (Arora), single, scattered, or in clusters "on logs, stumps, fence posts, railroad ties, decaying conifer wood, and occasionally hardwoods", (Phillips), spring and fall (Miller(14)), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Neolentinus ponderosus.spores: white (Arora, Miller), dull white to buff (Bessette)
Neolentinus ponderosus.edibility: choice, but thorough cooking or parboiling required because of toughness, (Arora), edible when young and tender (Bessette)
Neolentinus ponderosus.odour: often fragrant, (Arora), fruity or not distinctive, (Bessette)
Neolentinus ponderosus.habitat: single or in groups or clusters "on or near dead conifers (but often appearing terrestrial) in the late spring, summer and early fall", produces a brown rot in its host, (Arora), single to several on conifer logs and stumps, especially Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), "most often in openings or cut over areas", July through August, (Bessette), single on coniferous wood, "also reported numerous on soil", (Lincoff), occasionally on hardwoods (Mochizuki), on conifer logs and stumps, particularly Pinus ponderosa, fruiting in July in Idaho, (Miller)

Nolanea bicoloripes.odour: mild to at times unpleasant, (Largent), like gun oil (Ramsey)
Nolanea bicoloripes.habitat: typically solitary or at most scattered near or under salal or conifers

Nolanea cetrata.nameOrigin: 'cetrata' means 'shield-bearing'; 'mediospora' probably means medium spores; 'minimospora' means 'smallest spores'
Nolanea cetrata.habitat: on humus (often near or on rotting wood), near or under conifers, rarely near or under Acer circinatum (Vine Maple) and various oaks

Nolanea clandestina.taste: not distinct, at times faintly farinaceous
Nolanea clandestina.odour: not distinct, at times faintly farinaceous
Nolanea clandestina.habitat: scattered to gregarious in humus near or under salal, red alder, aspen or ornamental shrubs

Nolanea edulis.odour: indistinct to at most a bit radish-like
Nolanea edulis.habitat: scattered in duff or grass under firs or pines

Nolanea farinogusta.taste: farinaceous, at least in type collection
Nolanea farinogusta.odour: farinaceous, at least in type collection

Nolanea fructifragrans.odour: pleasant and candy-like, (Largent(1)), reminiscent of a candy store or of tooty-frooty gum (Largent(3))
Nolanea fructifragrans.habitat: scattered in leaf humus under Alnus rubra [Red Alder], late September to early November, (Largent(1)), fall

Nolanea fusco-ortonii.odour: not distinct to very faintly farinaceous
Nolanea fusco-ortonii.habitat: under oaks at least in California

Nolanea hebes.habitat: "solitary to scattered in humus or in grass near or under various conifers, specifically Douglas Fir and Coast Redwood as well as near or under Red Alder", (Largent), fall (Buczacki)

Nolanea hirtipes.habitat: single to scattered, rarely gregarious; under conifers, in California occurs under manzanita and various oaks, (Largent), spring and fall (Buczacki)

Nolanea holoconiota.taste: "unpleasant to slightly bitter, at times not distinctive"
Nolanea holoconiota.habitat: single to scattered to rarely gregarious in humus under conifers; fruits typically during late winter and spring, most common at higher elevations from late spring throughout the summer and into early fall, rarely found in coastal areas during mid to late fall

Nolanea incanosquamulosa.habitat: gregarious in moss or in humus, under conifers especially Sitka spruce, June to October, (Largent), summer, fall

Nolanea latifolia.taste: not distinct or at most slightly farinaceous
Nolanea latifolia.odour: not distinct, somewhat fragrant or at most slightly farinaceous
Nolanea latifolia.habitat: scattered in humus or leaf humus in oak-pine woods or under acacia

Nolanea minutostriata.habitat: scattered to gregarious, rarely single, in mossy habitat or branchlet humus under Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), rarely Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), salal, Acer circinatum (Vine Maple), or Alnus rubra (Red Alder)

Nolanea obscurata.habitat: scattered in mossy humus or on moss-covered logs, under conifers, at times under huckleberry, mid-September to mid-October, (Largent), fall

Nolanea occidentalis.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] among humus in woods, late October to mid-November, (Largent), fall

Nolanea papillatoides.odour: not distinct or at most grassy
Nolanea papillatoides.habitat: scattered in humus near or under salal, manzanita, redwood, oak, or California bay

Nolanea proxima.habitat: single to scattered in humus under conifers or Alnus rubra (Red Alder)

Nolanea pseudostrictior.nameOrigin: means 'false [Nolanea] strictior', Largent's name for Nolanea strictior
Nolanea pseudostrictior.habitat: scattered to gregarious in soil or humus under conifers especially Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Nolanea pusillipapillata.odour: somewhat pungent to farinaceous, especially crushed
Nolanea pusillipapillata.habitat: "scattered to gregarious in mossy humus, in grassy areas, or in fern branchlet humus", near ferns or Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Nolanea sericea.spores: deep salmon pinkish or cinnamon pinkish (Arora)
Nolanea sericea.odour: strongly farinaceous, particularly when crushed or cut, typically not rancid but more like cucumber, (Largent), usually farinaceous, at least when crushed, (Arora), of clean linen (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Nolanea sericea.habitat: single, scattered, or rarely gregarious "in lawns, grassy areas, or in mossy humus on hard-packed soil, typically in the open, along roadsides, or along trails"; fall, winter, and spring, (Largent), scattered to gregarious "in pastures, on lawns or hillsides, in waste places, sometimes also in woods or under willows", tends to fruit during rainy spells rather than following them, (Arora)

Nolanea staurospora.habitat: single to at most scattered with 1-4 fruitbodies per mycelium; under conifers, in grass, on mossy logs, under salal, devil's club, ferns, Acer circinatum (Vine Maple), Alnus rubra (Red Alder), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), July to November, in California at other times of year, (Largent), summer, fall

Nolanea strictior.habitat: single to scattered in mossy humus or even in Sphagnum or in branchlet humus; mid-May to late September in Pacific Northwest, (Largent), single, scattered or in small groups on ground or very rotten wood, under hardwoods and conifers, (Arora), spring, summer, fall

Nolanea subcapitata.habitat: scattered in leaf mold or needle humus near Cornus nuttallii (Pacific Dogwood) and under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir); spring (late March to late May)

Nolanea subsolstitialis.habitat: scattered in mossy humus or in grassy areas, mid-October to late November, (Largent), fall

Nolanea substrictior.odour: "slightly of cucumber when cut or crushed"
Nolanea substrictior.habitat: single in humus beneath hardwoods (in California), fall, winter (late January in California, late September in Idaho)

Nolanea subviolaceoverna.habitat: type scattered on soil and moss in tundra near Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir) in early June, (Largent), spring, summer

Nolanea undatomarginata.habitat: scattered to gregarious in grassy areas near or under Douglas-fir or Sitka spruce, fall

Nolanea verna.habitat: single to scattered in soil or mossy soil, often at high elevations, under conifers or in aspen-conifer woods, in spring

Omphaliaster asterosporus.habitat: single, on moss under Pinus (pine) and Tsuga (hemlock), October, (Bigelow), often single and along mossy paths, in coniferous forests, (Hansen), fall

Omphaliaster borealis.habitat: gregarious on moss (Polytrichum and Sphagnum), September and October, (Bigelow), in moist, acid, boreal heaths, (Hansen), fall

Omphalina isabellina.nameOrigin: presumably named after isabelline color (dingy yellowish brown to pale tan)
Omphalina isabellina.habitat: gregarious to scattered on old mossy logs of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)

Omphalina pyxidata.taste: not distinctive (Bigelow(5)), mild to bitterish (Phillips), mild, mushroomy, (Breitenbach)
Omphalina pyxidata.habitat: scattered or gregarious, usually on moss in the open, sometimes on wet sand or gravel, May through October in most localities, December in Oregon, (Bigelow(5)), in open or grassy places (Arora), in grass in sandy soils, subalpine to alpine, (Phillips), single to gregarious along sandy pathsides, on weathering blocks of rock, in damp places, often among mosses; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), spring, summer, fall, winter

Omphalotus olivascens.nameOrigin: means somewhat olive or becoming olive
Omphalotus olivascens.spores: whitish, "though mushroom often stains paper orange when attempting a print", (Siegel), cream-colored (Bigelow)
Omphalotus olivascens.habitat: usually in overlapping clusters, sometimes single "or in small, scattered clusters"; on stumps and dead roots, "but also from logs, rarely on trunks of standing trees"; typically "on oak, Chinquapin, or eucalyptus, also on a wide variety of other hardwoods (also rarely on conifers)"; fall into spring, (Siegel(2) for California), cespitose, usually on stump or base of stump, occasionally on buried wood; recorded in Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), Arctostaphylos sp. (manzanita), Cercis (redbud), and live Lithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak); October to February, (Bigelow)

Ossicaulis 'lignatilis'.nameOrigin: probably refers to wood habitat, lignum = wood (Latin)
Ossicaulis 'lignatilis'.taste: not distinctive to strongly fungal (Redhead), mild, slightly farinaceous (Breitenbach)
Ossicaulis 'lignatilis'.odour: "strongly fungal, fleetingly farinaceous in only the freshest uncut and water-soaked specimens, farinaceous when first cut, then developing a strong fungal odor until dried", (Redhead), strong flour smell (Moser), mealy (Courtecuisse), fruity to slightly farinaceous (Breitenbach)
Ossicaulis 'lignatilis'.habitat: on stumps of dead or living trunks of hardwoods, summer to fall, (Breitenbach), mainly in hollow old-growth hardwoods and occasionally conifers (Redhead), causes brown rot of hardwoods, especially Acer (maple) and cottonwood, (Trudell)

Panaeolus acuminatus.habitat: scattered to gregarious, in grassy areas, in well-manured grounds, at forest edges, or on dung, (Stamets), single to gregarious, fruiting all year except late winter, (Menser), spring, summer, fall, winter

Panaeolus alcis.habitat: usually on moose droppings (40 collections), rarely on droppings of reindeer (caribou) or roedeer (1 collection each), (Moser(10))

Panaeolus campanulatus.edibility: claims of hallucinogenic activity may have been based on misidentification (Stamets)
Panaeolus campanulatus.habitat: single or in groups "on or near dung or in grass where cattle have grazed, sometimes also in compost", fall, winter, spring,(Arora)

Panaeolus castaneifolius.nameOrigin: means 'with gills the color of chestnuts'
Panaeolus castaneifolius.spores: black, or also referred to as very dark purplish gray-black (Stamets)
Panaeolus castaneifolius.edibility: sometimes slightly hallucinogenic due to psilocybin contained by some but not all collections, (Stamets)
Panaeolus castaneifolius.habitat: scattered to gregarious in grassy places (Stamets), gregarious along roadsides and in grassy fields, summer and fall, (Smith)

Panaeolus cyanescens.edibility: hallucinogenic, moderately potent, a strong producer of psilocybin and/or psilocin, although highly variable in content: one study showed 0.71% psilocybin, 0.04% psilocin, and 0.01% baeocystin, (Stamets)
Panaeolus cyanescens.habitat: single to widely scattered or in groups on or near dung in pastures, (Arora), scattered to gregarious in dung in pastures and fields, (Stamets), summer to fall (Menser)

Panaeolus fimicola.edibility: not hallucinogenic to weakly hallucinogenic ("a latent producer of psilocybin, meaning that some collections, upon analysis, reveal a small amount of active indoles while other collections are devoid of them"), (Stamets)
Panaeolus fimicola.habitat: scattered in soil or dung, sometimes found in well-fertilized lawns and/or grassy places in woods, "from the late spring and in the fall", (Stamets), in manured grass or on dung, spring to fall, (Hansen), grassy places especially in woods, (Moser), short turf and meadows, tracks, roadsides (Courtecuisse), single on dung, spring to mid-fall, (Menser)

Panaeolus foenisecii.spores: deep brown or purple-brown (Arora), dark brown not black (Stamets), dark vinaceous brown (Smith)
Panaeolus foenisecii.edibility: harmless in small quantities, but potentially poisonous to toddlers in lawns, since some collections contain traces of psilocybin, but western collections apparently inactive, (Arora), not active to weakly active, no psilocybin or psilocin found in a study of Pacific Northwest specimens, (Stamets)
Panaeolus foenisecii.habitat: scattered or in groups on lawns and other grassy places, (Arora), in grassy areas but not directly on dung, commoner in spring than fall, (Stamets), single to gregarious, late spring to fall, mainly fruiting in summer, (Menser)

Panaeolus papilionaceus.habitat: on dung or on heavily manured soil, April to August, (Phillips), single to gregarious, often in large quantities in cow pastures, spring to fall, (Menser), spring, summer, fall

Panaeolus phalenarum.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on dung (especially of horses), manure, and straw" (Arora), gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts], horse dung, cow manure, in spring or during rainy season, (Stamets), single to gregarious on dung heaps, (Menser)

Panaeolus semiovatus.edibility: there have been "conflicting reports on the edibility of this species in earlier field guides"; most experts consider it nonactive and nonpoisonous (Stamets), yes, according to most sources, one dubious report of psilocybin, (Arora)
Panaeolus semiovatus.habitat: single to scattered, primarily on dung in spring and fall, (Stamets) single or in groups on dung and manure, especially of horses, (Arora), summer to fall (Bacon)

Panaeolus sphinctrinus.nameOrigin: means "tied up, pulled in", referring to the fact that cap does not expand much, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Panaeolus sphinctrinus.habitat: on dung (Menser), manured meadows, dung, (Courtecuisse), on animal droppings in woods and meadows, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), in dung-rich places (Moser), on dung and manured soil, from spring, (Hansen)

Panaeolus subbalteatus.edibility: weakly to moderately hallucinogenic, contains psilocybin and baeocystin but no psilocin, anecdotal reports of stomach cramps, loss of muscular strength, malaise when eaten raw, not "very poisonous" contrary to what is suggested by alternate name 'venenosus', (Stamets)
Panaeolus subbalteatus.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious "in dung or in well-manured ground in the spring, summer, and early fall", (Stamets), scattered to densely gregarious - often in small clumps - in manure, compost, and fertilized lawns, (Arora), single to gregarious or cespitose on freshly manured lawns, open ground, more common on horse dung than cow dung and has been found growing with cultivated mushrooms; primarily a spring mushroom, but common in summer to fall, (Menser)

Panellus longinquus.habitat: single to gregarious or subcespitose-imbricate on debarked or partially debarked fallen logs and branches of Alnus rubra (Red Alder) or rarely on conifers including stumps of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Libonati-Barnes), on branches and logs of Alnus rubra, and stumps of Tsuga heterophylla chemically treated to prevent Heterobasidion annosum attack, (Redhead)

Panellus mitis.habitat: usually gregarious and also imbricate [in shingled layers], more rarely single, on dead wood of conifers, principally Picea (spruce) and Abies (true fir), "such as fallen trunks or branches in brush piles", (Breitenbach for Europe), dead conifer wood especially larch (Arora), conifer twigs in winter (Moser), spring, summer, fall, winter, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Panellus ringens.habitat: single to grouped, on "dead twigs still attached to the tree or small standing trunks of hardwoods", especially Salix and Alnus, winter to spring, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), growing in groups on dead hardwoods (especially birch), (Arora)

Panellus stipticus.nameOrigin: refers to its reputation for stanching blood [stopping bleeding from a wound]
Panellus stipticus.edibility: inedible due to tough texture and bitter taste (Arora), inedible, possibly poisonous, (Lincoff(1))
Panellus stipticus.taste: usually peppery or astringent (Arora), bitterish-tart (Moser), astringent and harsh after being chewed for a fairly long time, (Breitenbach), very bitter (Courtecuisse), very bitter (Miller), slightly peppery to somewhat astringent (Burdsall)
Panellus stipticus.habitat: usually gregarious or in overlapping tiers on dead hardwoods, (Arora), clustered and imbricate, more rarely single, on dead wood of hardwoods, primarily on stumps of Quercus (oak) and Fagus (beech), occasionally also on conifers, throughout the year, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), usually in tightly imbricate clusters on sides of hardwood slash, noted on numerous hardwoods and hardwood products; September to November, (Burdsall), May to December (Lincoff(2)), spring, summer, fall, winter

Panus conchatus.taste: mild (Arora), mild to faintly bitterish (Breitenbach), sometimes faint earthy (Lincoff)
Panus conchatus.odour: unpleasantly like Clitocybe nebularis (Breitenbach), sometimes slight aniseed (Lincoff), mild (Miller)
Panus conchatus.habitat: single "or in small groups or clusters on hardwood logs, stumps, and fallen branches", (Arora), spring, summer, fall, and on the west coast in winter, (Miller)

Paraeccilia minutissima.habitat: single to scattered on rotting wood

Paraeccilia rusticoides.habitat: scattered to gregarious on ground or in needle humus

Paraeccilia sericeonitida.habitat: scattered on ground in mixed woods or coniferous woods

Paragymnopus perforans.taste: strong of putrid water, with a hint of garlic, (Lincoff), cabbage to garlic-like, mild, (Breitenbach), "strongly of stagnant water and/or with a hint of garlic", (Bessette), mildly unpleasant, often tardily alliaceous, (Petersen for European description), moderately alliaceous (Petersen for North American material)
Paragymnopus perforans.odour: strong of putrid water, with a hint of garlic, (Lincoff), cabbage to garlic-like, mild, (Breitenbach), "unpleasant, not really garlic-like", (Moser), "strongly of stagnant water and/or with a hint of garlic", (Bessette), unpleasant, like rotting cabbage or broccoli, (Trudell), fetid, like rotten cabbage, (Petersen for European description), negligible to fetid (occasionally weakly alliaceous), (Petersen for North American material)
Paragymnopus perforans.habitat: on conifer needles, one or two fruiting bodies per needle, summer and fall, (Lincoff for Europe), sometimes single, but usually cespitose [in tufts], "not rarely forming expanses", in spruce forests on needle litter, usually on individual needles; summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Europe), on needles of Picea (spruce), one specimen on one needle, (Hansen for Europe), on "damp spruce needle humus, often on needles", (Moser for Europe), insititious on needles of spruce and fir (Desjardin), "on individual conifer needles", 1 or 2 per needle, (Bessette), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Paragymnopus ponderosae.nameOrigin: ponderosae is Latinized, referring to Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), the fruiting habitat of the species
Paragymnopus ponderosae.habitat: fruiting on "dead needles, twigs, and debris" of Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), usually single on individual dead needles, occasionally two per needle; late fall

Paragymnopus sublaccatus.nameOrigin: "sub-" meaning "less than" and "laccatus" meaning "appearing polished or varnished", referring to the "varnished appearance" of the dried cap
Paragymnopus sublaccatus.habitat: fruiting on needles of Thuja (red-cedar) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), fruiting in fall to early winter

Paralepista 'flaccida'.spores: white or faintly cream colored ("pale pinkish buff" Ridgway(1) color)
Paralepista 'flaccida'.taste: not distinctive, in one collection bitter
Paralepista 'flaccida'.habitat: single or gregarious in arcs, on humus under coniferous trees (spruce) or hardwoods (aspen, alder, birch), August to November, in December and January in California, (Bigelow), summer, fall, winter

Paralepista inversa.spores: white to creamy yellowish (Arora), creamy white (Bigelow)
Paralepista inversa.edibility: not recommended (Arora), "European mushroom books say it is edible, but it should be tried very cautiously if at all", (Ammirati)
Paralepista inversa.odour: mild or sharp, spicy, pepper-like, (Arora), not distinctive, (Bigelow), faint but rather sharp odor, (Ammirati), faint or aromatic (of peaches), (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), sourish-mushroomy, not unpleasant, (Breitenbach)
Paralepista inversa.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in tufts on ground in woods, sometimes in large fairy rings, (Arora), gregarious on ground under mixed conifers, September to October, (Bigelow), fall

Parasola auricoma.nameOrigin: comes from 'auri' - 'golden' and 'coma' meaning 'hair of the head, mane'
Parasola auricoma.habitat: single, scattered, or clustered "in wood chips, grass, or disturbed soil", especially in urban areas, fruiting throughout the wet season, "but most common in early fall and spring", (Siegel in Redwood Coast area of California)

Parasola conopilea.habitat: single to gregarious "on sticks and debris on rich humus, occasionally on dung", (Smith), on rich soil, often in grassy places, (Barron), fall (Buczacki), late spring, summer, fall, (Bacon)

Parasola lactea.habitat: single, scattered, or in small tufts "in grassy areas, often in disturbed soil, occasionally in wood chips"; "fall and spring, or summer in irrigated lawns"

Parasola plicatilis.habitat: single, scattered or in small groups in grass, in woods, along paths etc., (Arora), single to numerous in grass and lawns, May to September, (Lincoff(2)), spring, summer, fall

Paraxerula americana.spores: presumably white based on genus characteristics (Kuo)
Paraxerula americana.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on rotting aspen wood, debris, or on soil around aspen trees, summer and early fall"

Paxillus involutus.spores: brown to yellow-brown, (Arora), rust-brown (Breitenbach), clay-brown to yellowish brown (Miller)
Paxillus involutus.edibility: poisonous: can cause hemolysis and kidney failure (Arora), severe gastrointestinal upset can result (Miller)
Paxillus involutus.taste: acid (Phillips), mild, sourish, fungoid, sometimes astringent, (Breitenbach), mild to unpleasant (Miller)
Paxillus involutus.odour: mushroomy (Phillips), pleasantly aromatic, fruity, (Breitenbach), slightly acid-fruity (Lincoff(1)), pleasant (Miller)
Paxillus involutus.habitat: usually scattered to densely gregarious on ground in woods, around the edges of bogs, and in treed parks or lawns, often with birch, (Arora), "occurs in natural forest in our region but is not common there", much more abundant in parks and landscaped areas where typically associated with birch, (Trudell), single or several, "on ground under conifer or hardwood forest including aspen and birch", summer and fall (Miller), spring, summer, fall, (Bacon)

Paxillus vernalis.spores: vinaceous brown (approaching "Verona brown" to "Rood's brown"), (Watling, with colors in double quotation marks from Ridgway(1)), cinnamon brown to chocolate brown, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), vinaceous-brown (Miller), reddish brown to chocolate brown (Arora)
Paxillus vernalis.odour: "none to unpleasant and then acidulous", (Watling), "very aromatic, like roasted corn or papaya", (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), mild to acidulous (Miller)
Paxillus vernalis.habitat: single to several on ground under mixed conifers / hardwoods, especially aspen and birch, summer and early fall, (Miller), under aspen or poplar, but also in boreal mixed forest, in spring and early fall, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)

Phaeocollybia ammiratii.nameOrigin: "In honor of Dr. Joe Ammirati, who first noted the presence of a P. kauffmanii-like species with clamp connections in the Pacific Northwest."
Phaeocollybia ammiratii.spores: pale cinnamon brown ("pinkish cinnamon" Ridgway(1) color)
Phaeocollybia ammiratii.taste: somewhat unpleasant and often bitter, reminiscent of bitter cucumbers
Phaeocollybia ammiratii.odour: distinctly cucumber-farinaceous when cut or crushed, also referred to as watermelon-like
Phaeocollybia ammiratii.habitat: single to clustered under mixed conifers (Picea, Tsuga, Abies) or in mixed deciduous-coniferous forests (Pinus, Lithocarpus, Pseudotsuga); early fall

Phaeocollybia attenuata.taste: "slightly to strongly disagreeable, often bitter", (Norvell(11)), becoming very disagreeable, often slowly, (Smith(43))
Phaeocollybia attenuata.odour: variably strong to not distinctive, radish-like, slightly fishy smelling, or floral (like pansies) with complex undertones (similar to boiled potatoes or burnt hair), (Norvell(11)), strong and radish-like (Smith(43))
Phaeocollybia attenuata.habitat: scattered to closely gregarious in highly humic soils, in moist coniferous or mixed forests, fall, (Norvell(11)), scattered in humus soil and with mosses under conifers such as Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce); mid to late fall, (Castellano), gregarious under Picea sitchensis and Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood), fall, (Smith(43))

Phaeocollybia benzokauffmanii.spores: pale purplish to dull yellowish brown ("drab" to "buckthorn brown" in Ridgway(1) colors)
Phaeocollybia benzokauffmanii.taste: farinaceous or reminiscent of bitter cucumbers
Phaeocollybia benzokauffmanii.habitat: gregarious, "originating at albic horizon in podzolic sandy or humic soils in ancient or mature second-growth mesic mixed closed canopy coniferous forests in early to mid-autumn", (Norvell(2)), single or scattered in small groups to gregarious, on ground in coniferous or mixed, coastal to montane, moist forests, (Norvell(11))

Phaeocollybia californica.taste: "not distinctive to slightly bitter, radish-like, or tart", (Norvell(11)), occasionally faintly bitter (Castellano), not distinctive (Smith)
Phaeocollybia californica.odour: vaguely like 'wild carrot', pungent and chlorine-like when old, (Norvell(11)), faint or not distinctive (Castellano), pungent (somewhat radish-like), (Arora), pungent (Smith)
Phaeocollybia californica.habitat: associated with roots of Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir), Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), March, May, October, and November, (Castellano), densely gregarious or in large loose clusters "on ground under conifers, often forming arcs or fairy rings", (Arora), gregarious in arcs under conifers, late fall, (Smith), fasciculate [bundled] to gregarious in arcs in humic soils of moist coniferous and mixed, coastal and coastal montane forests, fall, (Norvell(11)), spring, fall

Phaeocollybia dissiliens.taste: not distinctive, faintly radish-like, slightly bitter nutty, (Norvell(11)), not distinctive (Smith, Castellano)
Phaeocollybia dissiliens.odour: not distinctive, faintly radish-like, or sharply pungent, like Oxalis, (Norvell(11)), not distinctive (Smith, Castellano)
Phaeocollybia dissiliens.habitat: gregarious with Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce) in fall, (Smith), associated with the roots of Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir), Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), October and November, (Castellano), fall

Phaeocollybia fallax.nameOrigin: means "false", referring to the initial misuse of the name P. festiva for a distinct North American species, (Norvell(11))
Phaeocollybia fallax.taste: usually mild, occasionally radish-like, gluten sometimes bitter when fruitbodies old, (Norvell(11)), somewhat of radish, occasionally bitter, (Castellano), mild (Smith, Phillips), usually mild, but numerous older specimens were found to have caps with bitter-tasting cuticles and / or gluten, (Norvell(5))
Phaeocollybia fallax.odour: "not distinctive to complex with slight floral undertones (reminiscent of pansies, boiled potatoes, or burnt wet hair)", (Norvell(11)), slightly floral to reminiscent of burnt hair, (Castellano), radish-like when crushed (Smith), radishy (Phillips)
Phaeocollybia fallax.habitat: scattered to gregarious in coniferous forests, fall or (rarely) spring, (Norvell(11)), scattered to gregarious in mixed coniferous forests associated with Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga (hemlock), fall and early winter, (Castellano), gregarious under Picea sitchensis and redwood, fall and early winter, (Smith), scattered in large groups under Douglas-fir, Sitka spruce, or redwood, (Phillips)

Phaeocollybia gregaria.spores: smoky dark cinnamon brown, (Norvell(11)), dark red-brown (Castellano)
Phaeocollybia gregaria.odour: "not distinctive to complex with slightly floral undertones (reminiscent of pansies)", (Norvell(11)), not distinctive (Smith)
Phaeocollybia gregaria.habitat: densely gregarious in coniferous (Picea, Tsuga, Abies) forests, fall, (Norvell(11)), densely gregarious in small areas (not truly cespitose) under Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), (Smith), associated with the roots of Picea sitchensis and Pseudotsuga sitchensis (Douglas-fir), October and November, (Castellano), fall

Phaeocollybia kauffmanii.nameOrigin: after Calvin Henry Kauffman 1869-1931 professor of botany Michigan University
Phaeocollybia kauffmanii.taste: slightly to strongly farinaceous, occasionally slightly bitter
Phaeocollybia kauffmanii.odour: mildly to strongly farinaceous, occasionally not distinctive
Phaeocollybia kauffmanii.habitat: single, scattered or gregarious, often in loamy soils with high humus content in coastal or inland mesic closed-canopy mixed coniferous rainforests, less frequent in poor soils in open mixed coniferous-deciduous forests; fruiting in fall

Phaeocollybia lilacifolia.taste: somewhat disagreeable but not farinaceous, (Smith), not distinctive to disagreeable, (Norvell(11))
Phaeocollybia lilacifolia.odour: pungent when crushed, (Smith), "complex with floral (pansy), boiled potato, radish, and burnt hair components", when old crushed flesh sharply pungent and less floral, (Norvell(11)), slightly disagreeable (Norvell(5))
Phaeocollybia lilacifolia.habitat: with hemlock, redwood and other conifers, fall and early winter, (Smith), single to gregarious in forests of Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Tsuga (hemlock), and other moist coniferous forests; in fall, (Norvell(11))

Phaeocollybia luteosquamulosa.spores: pale cinnamon brown ("light pinkish cinnamon", "pinkish cinnamon", in Ridgway(1) colors)
Phaeocollybia luteosquamulosa.odour: not distinctive to faintly radish-like when cut or crushed
Phaeocollybia luteosquamulosa.habitat: single to clustered in humic podzolic soils in inland mature second growth or ancient mesic closed canopy coniferous rainforests, (in northern California in mixed coniferous-fagaceous forests); fruiting at the onset of fall mushroom fruiting season

Phaeocollybia ochraceocana.nameOrigin: from Latin "ochraceo-" + "cana" for the canescent sheen that develops as the drying ochraceous top cap layer lifts slightly up from the lower tissues, (Norvell(9))
Phaeocollybia ochraceocana.taste: in the type slightly bitter, (Norvell(9)), slightly farinaceous/raphanoid or bitter, (Norvell(11))
Phaeocollybia ochraceocana.odour: in the type not distinctive or mildly farinaceous when crushed, (Norvell(9)), "not distinctive or mildly farinaceous/raphanoid when crushed", (Norvell(11))
Phaeocollybia ochraceocana.habitat: single to gregarious in fall in coniferous forest (Tsuga-Pseudotsuga old-growth for type, at one site Sequoia), (Norvell(9)), in Tsuga, Pseudotsuga, and Picea forests, (Norvell(11))

Phaeocollybia olivacea.taste: not distinctive (Castellano, Smith), "mild and not distinctive, gluten occasionally bitter", (Norvell)
Phaeocollybia olivacea.odour: of raw cucumbers, soon fading, (Castellano), of raw cucumbers at time of collection but soon fading (Smith), cucumber-like or radish-like when fresh (Arora), "fleeting, complex with floral, cucumber, or boiled potato components", (Norvell)
Phaeocollybia olivacea.habitat: scattered or in arcs "in mixed forests containing Fagaceae or Pinaceae in coastal lowlands", fall, (Castellano), cespitose [in tufts] in arcs, oak-pine woods, (Smith), scattered to densely gregarious, often in large fairy rings, "on ground in mixed woods and under conifers", (Arora), clustered to gregarious (in arcs) during fall in mixed or conifers forests, (Norvell)

Phaeocollybia oregonensis.spores: dull yellowish cinnamon, with more yellowish tones than "cinnamon", darker than "Isabella color", (Norvell(3)), dark red-brown (Castellano)
Phaeocollybia oregonensis.taste: "usually farinaceous and bitter", (Norvell(3)), mild, sometimes quite bitter, (Castellano)
Phaeocollybia oregonensis.odour: "farinaceous or cucumber-like, developing unpleasant pungent tones when dry", (Norvell(3)), "mild, of cucumbers, or raw potatoes", (Castellano)
Phaeocollybia oregonensis.habitat: closely gregarious in moist locations under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) and Abies spp. (fir), also associated with Vaccinium species and dense mosses, (Norvell(3)), gregarious with conifers (Smith), associated with the roots of Abies amabilis, Pseudotsuga menziesii, and Tsuga heterophylla, (Castellano)

Phaeocollybia phaeogaleroides.nameOrigin: from morphologies shared with genus Phaeogalera (general aspect and spores), (Norvell(5)), '-oides' means 'resembling, having the form of'
Phaeocollybia phaeogaleroides.odour: not distinctive to very slightly radish-like, (Norvell(5)), not distinctive to slightly radish-like or vaguely acidic (like Oxalis), (Norvell(11))
Phaeocollybia phaeogaleroides.habitat: single, scattered, or closely gregarious in mossy low lying areas near or under mid-successional to late successional conifers such as Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), October through July, (Norvell(5)), single, scattered or loosely gregarious from spring through late fall in coniferous (Abies, Picea, Pseudotsuga, Tsuga) forests, (Norvell(11)), spring, summer, fall, winter

Phaeocollybia piceae.taste: bitter (Smith), usually slightly to intensely bitter (Castellano), usually bitter, occasionally mild or radish-like, (Norvell(11))
Phaeocollybia piceae.odour: slight, (Smith), variable, usually faint, (Castellano), vaguely radish-like to sweetly farinaceous or not distinctive when young, occasionally pungent ('like paint solvent') when very old, (Norvell(11)), mild or somewhat penetrating (Trudell)
Phaeocollybia piceae.habitat: cespitose (in tufts) with Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), (Smith), associated with the roots of Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), October and November, (Castellano), commonly in twos or single; the spruce association may be an indicator of a common factor such as moisture rather than a mycorrhizal association, (Norvell(8)), single to scattered in small groups (only rarely more than four close to each other, although pairs are common); fruiting during fall in coniferous (Picea, Tsuga, Pseudotsuga, Abies) forests, numerous collections from forests lacking spruce suggest the species is not host-specific, (Norvell(11))

Phaeocollybia pleurocystidiata.nameOrigin: refers to abundant pleurocystidia on gills, unusual for a Phaeocollybia
Phaeocollybia pleurocystidiata.spores: dark red brown ("Verona brown" to "sayal brown" in Ridgway(1) colors)
Phaeocollybia pleurocystidiata.odour: not distinctive to slightly cucumber-farinaceous or radish-like when crushed
Phaeocollybia pleurocystidiata.habitat: "scattered to gregarious in woody loam or sandy to rocky clay in moist coastal mixed coniferous forests", often associated with Synthyris reniformis (snow queen) with Corylus cornuta (hazelnut), Polystichum munitum (sword fern), Blechnum spicant (deer fern), Vaccinium spp., Eurhynchium oreganum (Oregon beaked moss), Hylocomium splendens (stair-step moss) sometimes also present; fruiting January through May, (Norvell(3)), "relatively frequent in coastal Oregon's lowland and montane western hemlock forests", (Norvell(11)), winter and spring

Phaeocollybia pseudofestiva.odour: pungent but fleeting, (Castellano, Smith), mild, occasionally sweetly nutty or complex with subtle floral - boiled potato components, (Norvell(11) who also say "The odor can at best be described as 'not distinctive', and we have not encountered the 'fleetingly pungent' odor noted by Smith. We have detected a pleasant sugary sweet odor (vaguely reminiscent of maple syrup and not uncommon in dried phaeocollybias) in dried specimens.")
Phaeocollybia pseudofestiva.habitat: single to densely gregarious during fall in coniferous and mixed forests, (Norvell(11)), scattered to cespitose [in tufts] under mature mixed conifers and hardwoods, October through December, (Castellano), with mixed conifers and hardwoods, cespitose but not fairy arcs, fall, (Smith), fall, winter

Phaeocollybia radicata.spores: chestnut brown (Norvell(11)), bright cinnamon brown in mass (at least under microscope), (Smith)
Phaeocollybia radicata.odour: not distinctive or vaguely radish-like or Oxalis-like, (Norvell(11)), none (Smith)
Phaeocollybia radicata.habitat: single to loosely gregarious in fall in coastal montane conifer (Tsuga, Pseudotsuga) forests, (Norvell(11)), scattered with redwood and conifers (Smith)

Phaeocollybia redheadii.nameOrigin: in honor of Dr. Scott Redhead, who first noted a large-spored "variant" of P. kauffmanii
Phaeocollybia redheadii.taste: strongly farinaceous (cucumber-like), glutinous cap cuticle slightly to extremely bitter
Phaeocollybia redheadii.odour: strongly farinaceous, often slightly floral when cut or crushed
Phaeocollybia redheadii.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious, "originating at the albic horizon in humic podzolic soils in coastal and inland ancient or mature second-growth mesic mixed closed canopy Tsuga-Abies forests" (hemlock-fir); early to late fall

Phaeocollybia scatesiae.nameOrigin: after Kit Scates of Post Falls Idaho, its discoverer
Phaeocollybia scatesiae.taste: not distinctive (Smith), faintly bitter when very young, later mild, (Castellano), faintly bitter when young, later generally mild or very slightly radish-like or farinaceous, (Norvell(11))
Phaeocollybia scatesiae.odour: not distinctive (Smith), faintly floral when young, sometimes radish-like, farinaceous, pungent or not distinctive, (Castellano), mildly floral (pansy-like) when young, later not distinctive (occasionally radish-like or slightly farinaceous), (Norvell(11))
Phaeocollybia scatesiae.habitat: in massive clusters under conifers, (Smith), associated with the roots of Abies species (fir), Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), and Vaccinium species from sea level to 1250m elevation, (Castellano) densely clustered, erupting in fasciculate mounds "usually with scores of tightly clustered basidiomes emanating from single points on subtending rhizomorphic pseudorhizae", (Norvell(7)), fruiting in late fall in woody humus in coastal and montane coniferous forest, (Norvell(11))

Phaeocollybia sipei.nameOrigin: after Professor Frank P. Sipe, an active collector of fungi in Oregon for many years, and collector of the type
Phaeocollybia sipei.taste: not distinctive to slightly radish-like or farinaceous, (Norvell(11))
Phaeocollybia sipei.odour: "when young, not distinct, vaguely farinaceous, or complex with floral (pansy) and burnt hair components; when old sometimes strongly pungent and unpleasant", (Norvell(11))
Phaeocollybia sipei.habitat: closely gregarious under conifers in Oregon, one collection by Professor Sipe, [but in 1990s found to be more widespread], (Smith), known from seven sites in Oregon, associated with roots of Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), October and November, (Castellano), closely gregarious (often in arcs) during fall under Tsuga, Picea, and Pseudotsuga, (Norvell(11))

Phaeocollybia spadicea.taste: slightly bitter (Castellano, Smith), "usually mild or radish-like, occasionally bitter", (Norvell(11))
Phaeocollybia spadicea.odour: vaguely floral, never farinaceous, (Norvell(9)), pungent farinaceous to mild (Castellano), odor of cut flesh pungent-farinaceous, (Smith), "not distinctive to radish-like or complex with subtle floral and boiled potato components", (Norvell(11))
Phaeocollybia spadicea.habitat: single, closely gregarious to occasionally cespitose [in tufts] during fall in moist coniferous or mixed forests, (Norvell(11)), single to scattered to closely gregarious in mature Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce) stands in coastal lowland regions, (Castellano), single, gregarious or cespitose [in tufts], with Picea sitchensis, often with clumps of ferns, (Goetz, C.), under Picea sitchensis and in the vicinity of clumps of ferns, fall and early winter, (Smith)

Phaeolepiota 'aurea'.spores: "pale yellow-brown to orange-buff", (Arora), "light yellow-brown to orange-buff", (Smith)
Phaeolepiota 'aurea'.odour: strong, aromatic, (Lincoff(1)), "mild to slightly pungent", (Smith), mild (Miller(14))
Phaeolepiota 'aurea'.habitat: "groups or clusters in rich humus and soil, under both hardwoods and conifers", (Arora), several to clustered, on compost and leaf litter, (Lincoff(2)), gregarious-cespitose often near the edges of roads under Alnus (alder), (Smith), often on flood plains in mountainous areas, on soil under poplars and conifers, (Redhead), fruiting in fall (Miller)

Phaeomarasmius erinaceus.habitat: single to cespitose [in tufts] on fallen or standing senescent corticated [barked] twigs and branches of Alnus spp. (alder), Corylus sp. (hazelnut), Salix sp. (willow), Betula papyrifera, (Paper Birch), Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), Amelanchier (serviceberry), (Redhead(26)), scattered on twigs of Corylus and Betula, (Smith), on small frequently still attached twigs and branches of hardwood trees, in damp places, (Watling for Britain), probably all year (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter

Phaeomarasmius proximans.habitat: type gregarious on hardwood logs, June, (Smith), summer

Phaeonematoloma myosotis.habitat: gregarious in boggy soil or on bog edges (Smith), August to September (Phillips), during hot dry summers (Scates), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Phlegmacium albescens.habitat: singly or in groups of three or four under conifers

Phlegmacium albofragrans.odour: fragrant, similar to Phlegmacium percome (marjoram) "or also of some flours [sic]" but Latin description says "vel florum" so probably "flowers" was intended, (Moser(4)), somewhat anise-like (M. Beug, pers. comm.)

Phlegmacium argutum.odour: "faint, mildly unpleasant, raphanoid or nauseous", (Cripps), mild (M. Beug, pers. comm.)
Phlegmacium argutum.habitat: scattered to gregarious or more commonly cespitose [tufted] in Populus tremuloides (aspen) stands with tall grasses, "in mixed stands of aspen and conifers (pine, Douglas fir, true fir, and (or) spruce) and sometimes with admixture of birch or shrubs (rose, hawthorn, willow, alder, spirea)", also reported once with Salix (willow); in Europe with Populus tremula "often on clay soil", (Cripps), a common late fall associate of Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), (M. Beug, pers. comm.)

Phlegmacium atrochalybaeum.habitat: under Lithocarpus densiflora (tanoak), Arbutus menziesii (Pacific madrone), Quercus vaccinifolia (huckleberry oak), and Q. chrysolepis (canyon live oak) on calcareous soil

Phlegmacium aurescens.nameOrigin: "refers to the yellow color change in age and where damaged", (Liimatainen), 'aurum' is Latin for 'gold', '-escens' means 'becoming'
Phlegmacium aurescens.habitat: under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) or Q. garryana and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine)

Phlegmacium balteatocumatile.odour: faintly earthy, (Breitenbach), earthy often strong (Courtecuisse), note the question of whether a taxon with over-ripe pear odor fits here, (Stuntz)
Phlegmacium balteatocumatile.habitat: gregarious "in hardwood forests and parks" near Fagus (beech) and Quercus (oak), summer to fall, (Breitenbach), especially coniferous woods, (deciduous woods for var. laetus), (Moser)

Phlegmacium balteatum.odour: weak, somewhat musty (yeast-like), (Brandrud), mild (Kauffman), not distinctive (Stuntz), mild (Arora), mild, musty, (Phillips)
Phlegmacium balteatum.habitat: coniferous forests, under Picea (spruce), more rarely Pinus (pine) and Larix (larch), (Brandrud for Europe), under pine, in the mountains, (Kauffman), singly in older conifer forests of mountains, (Stuntz), scattered to densely gregarious "on ground under hardwoods and sometimes conifers, usually with members of the Ericaceae (huckleberry, manzanita, madrone, etc.)", (Arora), in conifer woods, or with huckleberries or blueberries, September-October, (Phillips), fall
