Phlegmacium beugii.odour: mild to none, slightly of cut grass
Phlegmacium beugii.habitat: under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), or in oak woodland; the type was found under a mixture of Quercus (oak), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Salix (willow), in November

Phlegmacium blattoi.nameOrigin: after Blatto who described a similar taxon as Cortinarius pseudobalteatus, not a validly published name
Phlegmacium blattoi.habitat: Washington collection under Abies lasiocarpa (balsam fir) in subalpine forest

Phlegmacium callimorphum.habitat: collections under Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce) in fall

Phlegmacium calyptratum.habitat: in pure forest of Lithocarpus densiflora (tanoak) or in mixed stand of Lithocarpus, Quercus, Pseudotsuga, Umbellularia, Arctostaphylos, Pinus, (collections of Moser(9)), under conifers (spruce and redwood in Smith's collections, but Moser(9) note Lithocarpus occurs in all forests in the area)

Phlegmacium citrinifolium.odour: sharply fragrant (Smith), sharply sweet aromatic, fragrant (Stuntz), mild to strong, "a spicy mix of pleasant tropical fruit, lemon, and often some chemical component", (Siegel)
Phlegmacium citrinifolium.habitat: gregarious under fir (Smith), in older conifer forests (Stuntz)

Phlegmacium citriolens.odour: "rather strong and fragrant, sweetish of lemons or lemon pelargonium" (Pelargonium odoratum)
Phlegmacium citriolens.habitat: "subalpine conifer forests", Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine fir)

Phlegmacium cliduchus.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] under alder, (Smith), under hardwoods (Courtecuisse)

Phlegmacium cremeiamarescens.nameOrigin: refers to color of fruitbody and bitter taste of cap cuticle
Phlegmacium cremeiamarescens.habitat: in "hemiboreal and southern boreal conifer-dominated forests on rich to calcareous soil"; late August to late October

Phlegmacium 'cyanites'.taste: mild or slightly bitter, (Castellano), somewhat bitter (Brandrud), slight or a touch bitter (Phillips)
Phlegmacium 'cyanites'.odour: not distinct to somewhat sweet, (Castellano), indistinct or sweetish (Brandrud), distinctive (Phillips)
Phlegmacium 'cyanites'.habitat: single to gregarious or in widely separated groups, on soil in coniferous forests; August and September in montane areas, January along northern California coast, (Castellano), coniferous and hardwood woods; August to October, (Phillips), summer to fall or even winter

Phlegmacium durus.nameOrigin: 'durus' is Latin for 'hard', referring to the hard stem, but this species was recombined as Phlegmacium durus, implying that 'durus' is being used as a noun (therefore not needing to agree in gender with Phlegmacium)
Phlegmacium durus.odour: none or fairly strong and pleasant fungus-like especially when cut, "rather rank when old"

Phlegmacium fraudulosum.habitat: under Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), P. pungens (Blue Spruce), and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) in Wyoming, (Moser(2))

Phlegmacium glaucocephalus.nameOrigin: means 'glaucous cap' (presumably regarded as a noun, since it does not agree in gender with Phlegmacium)
Phlegmacium glaucocephalus.habitat: in mixed forests with Tsuga (hemlock), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Abies (fir), and Arctostaphylos manzanita (Manzanita)

Phlegmacium glaucopus.taste: Phlegmacium glaucopus slightly of meal (Phillips), some are apparently bitter (Arora)
Phlegmacium glaucopus.odour: Phlegmacium glaucopus has faint odor (Brandrud), Phlegmacium glaucopus slightly of meal (Phillips)
Phlegmacium glaucopus.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious or in small clumps or sometimes in troops, under coniferous and hardwoods

Phlegmacium luteoarmillatum.habitat: gregarious "on muck soil in low woods", September

Phlegmacium ophiopus.nameOrigin: presumably a noun as it is not agreeing with Phlegmacium in gender; 'ophis' is Greek for 'snake' and 'pus' may relate to Greek for 'foot'; Peck referred in the original description to the much bent or variously curved stem and said the long crooked stem was a noticeable feature; the patterns on the stem could have played a role as well
Phlegmacium ophiopus.habitat: on ground in woods, (Kauffman), gregarious to clustered in hardwood forests near Fagus (beech), (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Phlegmacium pallidifolium.habitat: scattered to gregarious under fir (Smith), in boreal mixed forest and aspen parkland at least in Alberta (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), in old conifer forests (Stuntz)

Phlegmacium papulosum.odour: not distinctive, (Moser), faintly grass-like to herbaceous (Breitenbach)
Phlegmacium papulosum.habitat: under conifers, (Moser), usually gregarious to almost clustered in coniferous forests near Picea (spruce) or Pinus (pine), (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Phlegmacium patrickense.nameOrigin: type is from Patrick's Point State Park
Phlegmacium patrickense.odour: "at first somewhat fruity, of green apples then slightly to strongly of green corn"
Phlegmacium patrickense.habitat: under Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Moser(9)), in coniferous forests, often on calcareous soil, (Liimatainen)

Phlegmacium percome.odour: "strong, aromatic, reminiscent of marjoram or common lemon balm (or apple etc.) blended with a more disagreeable, sour component", (Brandrud), strongly aromatic and sweet, reminiscent to different people of citronella, toilet bowl cleaner, or papaya (best detected by breaking open the flesh) (Arora), pleasant and sweet (Miller), strong, fruity, aromatic, pleasant, (Buczacki)
Phlegmacium percome.habitat: single, scattered, or in small groups under conifers (Arora), under conifers, September to October, (Phillips), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Phlegmacium pini.nameOrigin: Latin 'pini' meaning 'of pine', as it was associated exclusively with Pinus sylvestris (Scots Pine) when first described
Phlegmacium pini.habitat: boreo-nemoral to boreal-montane coniferous forests, associated exclusively with Pinus sylvestris (Scots Pine) "in mature, mixed pine-spruce (-fir) forests on mossy, calcareous ground", (Brandrud for Europe), mixed conifer forest (NACorts for Pacific Northwest, where Pinus sylvestris is not native)

Phlegmacium ponderosum.nameOrigin: means 'heavy' and likely also refers to ponderosa pine
Phlegmacium ponderosum.taste: disagreeable (Smith(22)), mild, or after prolonged chewing sometimes slightly bitterish, (Moser)
Phlegmacium ponderosum.odour: faintly spermatic as in many species of Inocybe (Smith(22)), slightly fungoid when freshly cut, or of crushed grass but mixed with some other undefined compound, (Moser), mild to somewhat spermatic (Inocybe-like), (Arora)
Phlegmacium ponderosum.habitat: scattered to gregarious under Pinus ponderosa (ponderosa pine) and various Quercus (oak) species in OR, under spruce in CA, (Smith(22)), under conifers or in mixed conifer and hardwood forests, particularly with pine species or Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), often growing in fairy rings and fruiting bodies at times almost completely covered by needle litter, (Moser), single to scattered or gregarious or in arcs on ground in mixed woods (oak, ponderosa pine etc.), late fall and winter, (Arora)

Phlegmacium saginum.nameOrigin: from 'sagina' which means 'a feasting, stuffing, fattening'
Phlegmacium saginum.habitat: in mountain forests, under conifers, (Kauffman), under spruce, more rarely under pine, (Brandrud), coniferous woods (Moser)

Phlegmacium sobrium.habitat: on grassy and poorly drained soil of an urban park, in open areas, under oaks and hickory trees, also under poplars in Europe

Phlegmacium spadicellum.habitat: with Picea (spruce), fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe)

Phlegmacium subfoetens.nameOrigin: It is implied that the name comes from the similarity to Russula foetens and related spp. and it is mentioned that cap colors are reminiscent of Russulas of the Foetentinae.
Phlegmacium subfoetens.odour: green corn or earthy, sometimes rather strong
Phlegmacium subfoetens.habitat: clustered under Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce) "on narrow, rounded ridge at roadside that had been previously disturbed by road construction"

Phlegmacium subfoetidum.odour: "very heavy-aromatic to subfoetid (somewhat sweetish and nauseous)", (Smith); "sickeningly sweet and unpleasant", (Bessette), sickeningly sweet odor has been likened to overripe pears, (Arora), "not like overripe pears", (Stuntz)
Phlegmacium subfoetidum.habitat: scattered under conifers (Smith), scattered under conifers, September to November, (Bessette), single to widely scattered or in small groups in duff and moss under conifers, especially with hemlock and/or fir, (Arora), fall

Phlegmacium subolivascens.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] under conifers in spring

Phlegmacium superbum.odour: rather strong and very distinctive, reminding one somewhat of the odor of fresh green corn, (Smith), very strong disagreeable earthy (green corn) odor that is persistent even in dried specimens, but in Oregon a forma aromaticus was collected that had "a green-corn odor only when freshly collected, but when cut or lying around for some time this odor disappeared and became a distinctly aromatic sweetish odor, mixed fruity and of green apples or even slightly sweetish, spicy (of marjoram)" (Moser(8))
Phlegmacium superbum.habitat: scattered to gregarious on steep mountain slopes

Phlegmacium variicolor.taste: mild (Phillips), mild, slightly earthy with an unpleasant component, (Breitenbach)
Phlegmacium variicolor.odour: strongly earth-like (Brandrud), obtrusively earthy to dusty (Breitenbach), strong earthy to musty smell (Moser(1)), sweetish, pleasant, (Phillips), not distinctive (Stuntz)
Phlegmacium variicolor.habitat: under conifers (Brandrud, Phillips), usually gregarious or in troops, also in fairy rings, in coniferous forests, at the edges of forests or in alpine pastures, summer to fall, (Breitenbach), coniferous woods (Moser(1))

Phlegmacium volvatum.habitat: gregarious to scattered under spruce, (Smith), under conifers, especially spruce, October to November, (Phillips), fall

Phlegmacium wiebeae.habitat: type gregarious and hypogeous under a fir tree, (Thiers), under soil surface associated with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii and Pinus ponderosa above 1200m, (Castellano), tends to grow under the duff (Arora)

Phloeomana speirea.habitat: single to scattered "on pieces of bark or on sticks usually partly buried in the mud or soil in wet places", "usually found during late spring and early summer but also fruiting in the fall"

Pholiota abietis.habitat: type cespitose-gregarious [tufted-gregarious] on Abies (fir), dead trees, logs etc., (Smith), fall and winter (Ammirati)

Pholiota abruptibulba.nameOrigin: means 'with an abrupt bulb', abruptus = broken off (Latin), bulbus = bulb (Latin)
Pholiota abruptibulba.habitat: type gregarious beside a conifer log

Pholiota acutoconica.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious around conifer wood, (Smith for type), in tufts or groups on or around conifer stumps (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)

Pholiota adiposa.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on hardwood logs (Smith for BC), on trunks, often still living, of broadleaf species such as Fagus (beech), Acer (maple) and Betula (birch), in mountainous areas, (Lincoff for Europe), summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Pholiota aurantioflava.habitat: type on debris of conifers, October, (Smith), fall

Pholiota aurivella.habitat: gregarious (often tufted or clustered) "on living or dead hardwoods and conifers"

Pholiota bakerensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Mt. Baker' where type was found

Pholiota baptistii.nameOrigin: after Mr. C.F.D. Baptist, who collected type

Pholiota brunnea.habitat: type cespitose [in tufts] on conifer wood

Pholiota brunnescens.taste: "mild, not remarkable, or slightly disagreeable", (Matheny), mild or slightly disagreeable (Smith)
Pholiota brunnescens.odour: "mild, not remarkable, or slightly disagreeable", (Matheny), usually mild (Arora), mild or slightly disagreeable (Smith)
Pholiota brunnescens.habitat: cespitose [tufted] or gregarious on burned soil, occasionally on burned wood, May to December, (Matheny), scattered to densely gregarious or clustered "on wood or soil in recently burned areas", (Arora), gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on burned areas, in fall, common after forest fires, (Smith)

Pholiota canescens.habitat: type on decayed wood, among mosses

Pholiota carbonaria.nameOrigin: means 'from Highland' after Highland Falls, New York where Peck's type was found
Pholiota carbonaria.edibility: poisonous - Ammirati(11) cite a case requiring a child to be hospitalized for dysentery for 10 days after consuming about 20 caps verified by A.H. Smith to be P. highlandensis
Pholiota carbonaria.taste: "not remarkable or somewhat musty" (Matheny), slightly disagreeable or none (Phillips), mild with a slightly unpleasant aftertaste (Miller), slightly disagreeable or none, (Smith for P. highlandensis), not distinctive (Smith for P. carbonaria, P. fulvozonata)
Pholiota carbonaria.odour: "not remarkable or somewhat musty" (Matheny), not distinctive (Phillips), not distinctive (Smith for P. highlandensis, P. carbonaria, P. fulvozonata)
Pholiota carbonaria.habitat: scattered singly to gregarious, less often in clusters of few to several fruitbodies, generally not cespitose (tufted), "on burned ground, in charcoal pits", or on tephra deposits [fragments produced by volcano], "occasionally in troops on extensive burns"; occurring April to December or year round, one to two years post-fire, (Matheny), on burned soil or burned wood, from spring to winter, (Smith for P. highlandensis), on burned ground, burned roots, rarely on manure heaps; from summer to early winter, (Smith for P. carbonaria), type on burned (partially) chip dirt (Smith for P. fulvozonata), scattered to gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] on pieces of burned or charred wood or on burned soil, from late spring to winter, (Ammirati), spring, summer, winter

Pholiota connata.habitat: type was cespitose [in tufts] on maple

Pholiota curcuma.nameOrigin: 'curcuma' is a genus of the ginger family, Curcuma longa giving the spice turmeric
Pholiota curcuma.habitat: single to scattered on aspen logs, summer and fall

Pholiota decorata.odour: none or faintly fragrant (Phillips), faintly fragrant or lacking, (Smith)
Pholiota decorata.habitat: single or scattered on fallen conifer branches and debris, July to November, (Phillips), single to scattered on fallen conifer branches and debris, July to November, (Smith), single or in small groups "on conifer (or sometimes hardwood) debris such as twigs and small branches", (Trudell), summer, fall

Pholiota ferruginea.habitat: gregarious on debris under conifers, summer and fall

Pholiota ferrugineolutescens.habitat: on conifer wood in Idaho collection, type from California on debris around logs of Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood)

Pholiota filamentosa.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Smith for the collection from which description taken), clustered on conifer wood in fall (Scates)

Pholiota flammans.habitat: single or in tufts on conifer logs and stumps, (Arora), on conifer logs and stumps, (Smith), single or in small clusters on logs, particularly Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) in the Pacific Northwest, (Trudell), summer and fall (Miller)

Pholiota fulviconica.habitat: on soil, humus, and rotten logs

Pholiota fulvozonata.habitat: type on burned (partially) chip dirt, (Smith), in groups in burned areas in fall (Scates)

Pholiota galerinoides.habitat: type on "wet seepage swampy area on very decayed conifer wood", October, (Smith), fall

Pholiota gruberi.nameOrigin: after William B. Gruber, who collected type
Pholiota gruberi.habitat: type cespitose [in tufts] in masses under the needle cover under Larix occidentalis (Western Larch), in spring

Pholiota hiemalis.habitat: type gregarious-cespitose on rotting conifer log

Pholiota humii.habitat: type gregarious to scattered on or around rotten conifer logs, July and August, (Smith), summer

Pholiota iterata.habitat: type gregarious on needle carpet under pine

Pholiota lactea.habitat: type gregarious on soil, October, (Smith), fall

Pholiota lenta.odour: slight, radishy, (Phillips), mild (Smith), faint, pleasant, fruity-spicy, (Buczacki)
Pholiota lenta.habitat: on humus debris in mixed woods, (Phillips), on humus, debris, or humus charged soil, (Smith), on soil or organic matter and among woody debris, perhaps on buried wood, fall, (Buczacki)

Pholiota limonella.habitat: in dense groups and clusters, usually on rotting logs and trees of hardwood, especially maple, sometimes in wounds in living trees, some forms also on compost, (Ammirati), type found on beech in New York, Pholiota squarroso-adiposa cespitose [in tufts] "in large masses on alder and maple logs in the Pacific Northwest", (Smith), on hardwood or conifer wood, (Scates), summer, fall, winter

Pholiota lubrica.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups "in humus and on woody debris in woods"

Pholiota luteola.nameOrigin: means 'yellowish' and "refers to the pale yellow gills"
Pholiota luteola.habitat: type gregarious on wet conifer wood

Pholiota melliodora.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on soil and near buried wood, October to November, (Smith), fall

Pholiota milleri.nameOrigin: after O.K. Miller, who found type

Pholiota mixta.taste: mild (Smith(3) for P. agglutinata), not distinctive (Smith(3) for P. fulvodisca) slight, (Smith(3) for P. virescentifolia)
Pholiota mixta.odour: mild (Smith(3) for P. agglutinata), not distinctive (Smith(3) for P. fulvodisca), slight (Smith(3) for P. virescentifolia)
Pholiota mixta.habitat: type scattered on mossy bank under Picea (spruce), late summer (Smith(3) for P. agglutinata), type on conifer duff, (Smith(3) for P. fulvodisca), on soil and humus, under Tsuga (hemlock) (in Tennessee), (Smith(3) for P. virescentifolia), on the ground, "often on paths or road-sides, in coniferous forests", summer to fall, (Hansen, L.(2))

Pholiota molesta.taste: "mild or disagreeable (somewhat soapy farinaceous)", (Matheny), fungoid, (Smith(3) for P. molesta), very disagreeable (somewhat soapy farinaceous), (Smith(3) for P. subsaponacea)
Pholiota molesta.habitat: single or in pairs "on charred remains in conifer forests", May-June and October, (Matheny), type found on burned area, June, (Smith), spring, summer, fall

Pholiota multifolia.habitat: on logs, sawdust and decaying wood of hardwoods - ash, aspen, maple, etc., June to October, (Smith), summer, fall

Pholiota nubigena.odour: fragrant as in ethyl acetate (Singer), fragrant sweet (Castellano), somewhat like bubblegum or wintergreen (Desjardin)
Pholiota nubigena.habitat: single to gregarious or in small clusters on rotting conifers, especially on Abies (fir) and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), often near melting snow, (Arora), gregarious to subcespitose [somewhat clustered] on fallen conifer logs and chips, especially of Abies magnifica [California Red Fir] and Pinus contorta [Lodgepole pine], above ground when on chips etc., 1650-2400m, often at the edge of snowbanks, late spring and summer, (Singer), fruits on the surface of rotten logs of Abies above 1300m, May through early October, (Castellano), saprophytic on well-decayed logs (Trappe), from spring into early summer (Trudell)

Pholiota occidentalis.habitat: on alder branches and debris, or on conifer wood

Pholiota olympiana.habitat: gregarious to scattered around stumps of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)

Pholiota oregonensis.taste: nutty or like almonds in dried specimens
Pholiota oregonensis.habitat: type in large cluster on living willow in November, (Smith), fall

Pholiota pallida.habitat: type cespitose [in tufts] on a conifer log, August (Smith), summer

Pholiota pattersoniae.habitat: on debris of elm, basswood, and aspen, May, June, October (Smith), spring, summer, fall

Pholiota polychroa.spores: brown, with purplish tinge when moist, cinnamon brown when drier
Pholiota polychroa.habitat: on hardwood stumps, logs, and fallen branches, more rarely on conifer wood, occasionally sawdust, July to November, (Smith), single or more often in clusters, (Bessette), summer, fall

Pholiota pulchella.habitat: scattered or single on conifer debris and humus, September to October, (Smith), fall

Pholiota rivulosa.nameOrigin: refers to rivulose cap, from 'rivula' a small stream
Pholiota rivulosa.spores: [presumably a shade of brown close to dingy tawny]
Pholiota rivulosa.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on conifer duff and rotten conifer logs

Pholiota rubronigra.habitat: on pine or redwood logs, November to December, (Smith), fall, winter

Pholiota rufodisca.habitat: on conifer wood and debris, October, (Smith), fall

Pholiota scamba.habitat: on conifers, often mossy, logs and debris, June to October, (Smith), usually gregarious, more rarely single, (Breitenbach), summer, fall

Pholiota scamboides.habitat: type gregarious on wet sand, apparently from buried wood

Pholiota sienna.nameOrigin: probably referring to the "burnt sienna" color on the cap
Pholiota sienna.habitat: type under Quercus (oak) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)

Pholiota sipei.nameOrigin: after Oregon naturalist Dr. Frank P. Sipe, the collector of type
Pholiota sipei.habitat: type on soil under fir, November, (Smith), fall

Pholiota spumosa.odour: mild (Arora, Smith), some forms have a strong fungus-like or green corn odor, but others are mild, (Trudell)
Pholiota spumosa.habitat: single to widely scattered to gregarious or tufted on ground and debris under conifers (Arora), on soil, in coniferous woods and on logs, stumps, buried wood, sawdust, duff, and humus, more rarely reported on hardwood (birch, oak, aspen), (Smith), "in often very large groups on the ground, usually among wood chips, bark chips, or other woody debris" such as slash piles, (Trudell), fall to winter (Buczacki)

Pholiota squarrosa.edibility: not recommended, some get severe stomach upset, (Arora)
Pholiota squarrosa.odour: none or garlic or onion (Smith), lemon, radish, onion, or skunk, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), faint, unpleasant, radish, (Buczacki)
Pholiota squarrosa.habitat: in tufts or dense clusters on wood, usually at the bases of conifer and hardwood trees, (Arora), cespitose [in tufts] "on living conifer and hardwood trees, at the base of living or dead trees, or on logs and stumps", (Smith), July to October, (Lincoff(2)), summer, fall

Pholiota squarrosoides.odour: not distinctive (Smith(3)), often with agreeable odor of cinnamon rolls (Ammirati)
Pholiota squarrosoides.habitat: singly or cespitose [in tufts], "on trunks and stumps of hardwood trees", especially maple, birch, beech, basswood, and alder, (Smith(3)), fallen logs and dead trunks of alder and maple in old Douglas-fir forests, (Ammirati), late summer and fall (Miller)

Pholiota subechinata.habitat: type on a conifer log, October, (Smith), fall

Pholiota subflavida.taste: mild in at least one of Smith(3) specimens, (Smith)
Pholiota subflavida.odour: pungent in at least one of Smith(3) specimens, who also refers to the "slight odor of the above collections", (Smith)
Pholiota subflavida.habitat: on conifer debris or near it, fall, (Smith), on spruce debris, summer, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)

Pholiota subfulva.habitat: more or less cespitose [in tufts]; around base of trees, on rotten wood (logs etc.), one collection on conifer duff

Pholiota sublubrica.habitat: on or near rotting conifer logs, summer and fall, (Smith), usually appearing to be terrestrial, clustered on or near rotting wood, often lodgepole pine, summer and fall, (Scates)

Pholiota subminor.habitat: type gregarious on an oak log

Pholiota subpapillata.spores: earth brown, when moisture escaped dull "sayal brown" (Ridgway(1) color, dingy cinnamon)
Pholiota subpapillata.habitat: type gregarious-cespitose on chip dirt, October, (Smith), fall

Pholiota terrestris.habitat: in groups or clusters "on the ground, especially along roads, paths and in other disturbed areas; also on lawns, lignin-rich debris, rarely on or around old stumps", (Arora), cespitose [in tufts] "on soil, roadsides, lawns, woods, more rarely on buried wood or even stumps", June to January, (Smith), summer, fall, winter

Pholiota tuberculosa.taste: mild (Smith), mild to bitter in some varieties (Scates)
Pholiota tuberculosa.habitat: on "logs, stumps and sawdust of hardwoods, especially aspen", rarely on conifer logs such as Larix (larch)

Pholiota umbilicata.habitat: type on debris of Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), September, (Smith), fall

Pholiota velata.habitat: type in woods along streams, July, (Smith), summer

Pholiota verna.habitat: on debris of Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), May, (Smith), spring

Pholiota vinaceobrunnea.habitat: scattered on conifer logs, summer and fall

Phylloporus arenicola.habitat: type single under Pinus contorta on sand dunes, (Smith), single, scattered, or in groups on sand dunes under pine, September to November, (Bessette), fall

Phylloporus rhodoxanthus.spores: brown to yellowish-tinged or olive-tinged (Arora), yellowish ochraceous (Bessette), orange-brown to yellowish brown (Miller)
Phylloporus rhodoxanthus.habitat: single to widely scattered or in small groups (usually 2s or 3s) on ground in woods, (Arora), scattered or in groups on the ground in hardwood forests under beech and oak, (Bessette), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller)

Phyllotopsis nidulans.nameOrigin: means "nesting, referring to the downy caps, like small nests"
Phyllotopsis nidulans.spores: "pale pinkish to apricot-pink to pinkish-brown", (Arora), cream-flesh-colored (Breitenbach), pinkish orange to creamy peach (Siegel)
Phyllotopsis nidulans.taste: sharp, very unpleasant, (Phillips), mild, mushroomy but rather unpleasant, (Breitenbach), bitter and unpleasant (Miller)
Phyllotopsis nidulans.odour: "typically strong and disagreeable (like sewer gas or rotten eggs), but sometimes mild", (Arora), rather like rotten cabbage (Kibby), unpleasant, cabbage-like, (Breitenbach), sharp, very unpleasant, (Phillips), faint, pleasant, (Buczacki)
Phyllotopsis nidulans.habitat: in groups or shelving masses "on rotting logs and stumps (of both hardwoods and conifers)", (Arora), in groups, usually imbricate, more rarely single, in hardwood and coniferous forests, "on rotten stumps and trunks of conifers and more rarely of hardwoods", primarily on Picea (spruce), (Breitenbach for Switzerland), early summer through fall (Miller)

Pleurocybella porrigens.edibility: In the past Pleurocybella porrigens was generally considered edible, but in 2004 there were 17 deaths in Japan: most or all deaths occurred in people who had kidney disorders and the average age was 70: they died of an acute brain condition; another person on kidney dialysis died in 2009 from this species, (Beug(1) and M. Beug pers. comm.).
Pleurocybella porrigens.habitat: in shelving groups or overlapping clusters on old rotting conifers, especially hemlock; fruiting especially in fall

Pleurotus dryinus.taste: pleasant (Phillips), bitter almonds according to Kauffman (Brown)
Pleurotus dryinus.odour: mild to pungent or fragrant (Arora), pleasant (Phillips), slightly fragrant (anise-like) to musty (Siegel)
Pleurotus dryinus.habitat: single or in small groups on hardwoods, usually living, (Arora), July to October (Phillips), fall to winter (Buczacki), summer, fall, winter

Pleurotus ostreatus.spores: lilac to lilac-gray, to light purplish vinaceous
Pleurotus ostreatus.edibility: delicious, douse in water to remove beetles between gills, remove stems, and check for white grubs (Arora for P. ostreatus complex), adverse reaction from combination with alcohol has been reported with oyster mushrooms (Benjamin)
Pleurotus ostreatus.odour: "pleasant and anise-like, becoming fungoid and unpleasant in age"
Pleurotus ostreatus.habitat: single, or more usually in large imbricate [shingled] clusters on the sides of stumps, logs and branches of hardwood trees, less commonly on conifers (Pinus - pine and Abies - true fir), fruiting during cool weather wherever hardwood hosts are found, especially fond of riparian habitat [fall, winter]

Pleurotus populinus.edibility: delicious, douse in water to remove beetles between gills, remove stems, and check for white grubs (Arora for P. ostreatus complex)
Pleurotus populinus.habitat: single to numerous and often imbricate [shingled] "on limbs, stumps, or logs of hardwood trees", especially Black Cottonwood (Populus trichocarpa), and aspen (Populus tremelloides and Populus tridentata), collections were mostly in May to July but also in October, (Vilgalys), spring, summer, fall

Pleurotus pulmonarius.nameOrigin: means 'of the lungs' probably referring to the shape when young
Pleurotus pulmonarius.spores: "variable, white, yellowish, buff to lavender gray when heavy", (Vilgalys), can appear gray (B. McAdoo, pers. comm.)
Pleurotus pulmonarius.edibility: delicious, douse in water to remove beetles between gills, remove stems, and check for white grubs (Arora for P. ostreatus complex)
Pleurotus pulmonarius.taste: "mild at first and pleasant, becoming strongly fungal and eventually putrescent"
Pleurotus pulmonarius.odour: "pleasant, with a vague anise-like aroma when fresh"
Pleurotus pulmonarius.habitat: in imbricate [shingled] clusters, rarely single, on logs, limbs and stumps of conifers at mid-level elevations (1200-3000 m) in the western US, of hardwoods (primarily) in the eastern states

Pluteus atromarginatus.taste: not unpleasant, fungoid, (Banerjee after Singer 1956), pleasant (Phillips)
Pluteus atromarginatus.odour: sweetish or fungoid (Banerjee after Singer 1956), pleasant (Phillips)
Pluteus atromarginatus.habitat: single "on conifer logs and debris, rarely reported from soil and deciduous woods", June to October, (Banerjee), on fallen conifer logs (Phillips), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Pluteus aurantiorugosus.habitat: single to scattered to gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] "on rotting hardwood stumps or logs", (Homola), single to several or clustered on decayed hardwood, August to October, (Lincoff), summer, fall

Pluteus brunneidiscus.taste: similar to odor or indistinct (Justo(4)), mild (Banerjee)
Pluteus brunneidiscus.habitat: single or gregarious, on decayed hardwood (Betula - birch, Umbellularia - California laurel, Populus) "or on the humus layer under hardwoods or conifers", June to September except in California (November to January), (Justo(4)), single to scattered on mossy hardwood logs, (Banerjee)

Pluteus cervinus.spores: flesh-colored to pinkish-brown, (Arora), "cinnamon" (Kornerup(3) color), (Banerjee), salmon to pink (Miller)
Pluteus cervinus.edibility: yes, especially when fresh and firm, do not eat any that are not clearly growing on wood (to avoid confusion with Entolomas), (Arora)
Pluteus cervinus.taste: earth-like to radish-like (occasionally disagreeable), (Banerjee), not distinctive (Phillips)
Pluteus cervinus.odour: usually radish-like, (Arora), mild (Banerjee), not distinctive (Phillips), strong of radish or potato (Trudell)
Pluteus cervinus.habitat: single or in groups "on decaying wood, debris, sawdust piles, or humus rich in lignin", (Arora), single to scattered (to gregarious) on decayed hardwood logs, stumps and sawdust, but also reported from conifer duff, and at least one case from an Abies log, (Banerjee), "in cool damp weather usually in spring and fall", (Miller), "can be found throughout the year when temperature and moisture are conducive", (Trudell), spring, summer, fall, (Bacon)

Pluteus cyanopus.nameOrigin: means "blue foot", kyanos = deep blue (Greek), pous = foot (Greek)
Pluteus cyanopus.habitat: single "in a clearing on soil rich in wood chips" or gregarious on dead oak logs, (Homola), summer and fall (Smith)

Pluteus exilis.nameOrigin: means 'slender', 'thin', referring to a thin stem that was initially thought to be one of the important diagnostic features
Pluteus exilis.habitat: single or gregarious, growing on well-decayed wood of hardwoods (Alnus - alder, Notholithocarpus - tanoak) or conifers (Picea - spruce, Pseudotsuga - Douglas-fir), September-January

Pluteus flavofuligineus.habitat: on fallen hardwoods, July to October (Phillips), single "on very decayed sticks and wood of hardwood trees"; fruiting both during early summer and fall, (Smith)

Pluteus fulvibadius.nameOrigin: means 'fulvous-badious' referring to color of cap
Pluteus fulvibadius.habitat: single to scattered to gregarious on soil or rotten hardwood, rarely on rotten conifer wood, (Minnis), type collected on ground in woods (Smith(16))

Pluteus granularis.nameOrigin: presumably referring to the granular surface of the cap
Pluteus granularis.habitat: single or scattered on decaying conifer wood or hardwood; July - October, (Bessette), scattered to single on rotting conifer wood or hardwood; summer and fall, (Smith)

Pluteus heterocystis.nameOrigin: refers to two forms of cystidia

Pluteus leoninus.habitat: usually single "in hardwood and mixed conifer-hardwood forests, on dead branches or pieces of wood on the ground, also on rotten stumps", (Breitenbach), singly or in small clusters on hardwood or sometimes coniferous wood or woodchips, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), deciduous and coniferous tree stumps etc., (Moser), fall (Buczacki)

Pluteus leucoborealis.nameOrigin: from leucos, Greek for white or pale, and borealis, referring to the northern distribution, (Justo)
Pluteus leucoborealis.habitat: commonly gregarious, more rarely single; on decayed wood of Betula (birch), more rarely Alnus (alder), in "boreal or transitional boreal/temperate forests", fruiting June to September

Pluteus magnus.habitat: single or occasionally scattered on decayed hardwood, sometimes found on buried and burned wood

Pluteus orestes.nameOrigin: from the Greek meaning "mountaineer, mountain hiker", for "its distribution in the mountain ranges of Western North America"
Pluteus orestes.habitat: single or in pairs, "on decayed conifer wood, more rarely on conifer litter", in conifer or mixed forest, recorded only from mountain areas, May to October

Pluteus parilis.nameOrigin: "parilis" means "similar", "because of the close resemblance to other species in this complex"
Pluteus parilis.habitat: in small groups of 2 or 3, "on wood in various mixed conifer or conifer-hardwood forests, up to an elevation of 1500 m.", January on the coast (Mendocino County) and June in the mountains (Yosemite National Park)

Pluteus petasatus.spores: pinkish to deep flesh-color (Arora), pink (Bessette), "pink to pinkish brown" (Justo)
Pluteus petasatus.edibility: good, and firmer and meatier than Pluteus cervinus, (Arora)
Pluteus petasatus.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), similar to odor or indistinct (Justo)
Pluteus petasatus.odour: mild or radish-like (Arora), not distinctive (Bessette), "strongly sweet and unpleasant, sweet-raphanoid or indistinct", (Justo)
Pluteus petasatus.habitat: gregarious or clustered "on sawdust or woodchips in gardens, along roads, etc. (often appearing terrestrial)", (Arora), on wood debris, mulch, sawdust piles; spring, summer, and fall, (Bessette), single to scattered, mostly on soil (usually under Acer, Liquidambar, Liriodendron, or Quercus), sometimes on decaying sawdust, or rarely on stumps of old hardwoods, (Banerjee for midwest US), commonly gregarious to cespitose, more rarely single; on decayed wood of hardwoods (Acer, Betula, Quercus, Fagus, Populus), "also on wood chips, sawdust or on the humus layer"; often "in urban parks, lawns, roadsides and other disturbed/ruderal areas but also occurring in natural, undisturbed forests"; fruiting year round, (Justo)

Pluteus plautus.nameOrigin: 'plautus' is Latin for 'broad, flat, flat-footed' (Brown, R.W.(1))
Pluteus plautus.habitat: single or in small groups "on well-decayed hardwoods, with some variants also on conifers"; throughout the wet season, (Siegel), British Columbia collections at the University of British Columbia from August to October, December, February

Pluteus primus.habitat: single or gregarious, growing on well-decayed wood of conifers (Abies - fir, Picea -spruce, Pseudotsuga - Douglas-fir), also recorded "on conifer sawdust, woodchip piles or on the litter layer under conifers", one collection recorded as growing on Fagus (beech) stump; in conifer or mixed forests; found year round

Pluteus romellii.spores: pinkish to deep flesh color (Arora), dull pinkish (Siegel)
Pluteus romellii.edibility: said to be edible (Arora(1)), unknown, likely nontoxic (Siegel(2))
Pluteus romellii.habitat: single or in small groups "on rotting hardwood logs, sticks and debris", (Arora), single or gregarious on hardwood debris or wood, (Homola, for the unnamed variety, but var. lutescens commonly found also on soil), single "or in small scattered groups", "on well-decayed woody debris, logs, branches, and stumps of hardwoods"; fruiting from fall to spring, (Siegel)

Pluteus rugosidiscus.odour: slightly fragrant (Smith(6)), none to slightly fragrant (Homola)
Pluteus rugosidiscus.habitat: single to gregarious on hardwood or on debris, summer and fall (Smith(6)), single to gregarious "on fallen deciduous trees or occasionally on debris", (Homola)

Pluteus salicinus.edibility: weakly to moderately hallucinogenic, 0.05-0.35% psilocybin, 0-0.11% psilocin, 0.008% baeocystin, edibility unknown, (Stamets)
Pluteus salicinus.taste: like Clitocybe nebularis (Banerjee quoting Smith), mild (Breitenbach)
Pluteus salicinus.odour: "mild to rarely disagreeable (acid-like)", (Banerjee), none (Courtecuisse), faintly radish-like (Breitenbach)
Pluteus salicinus.habitat: single to scattered on rotten hardwood logs, occasionally on conifer logs, May to August, (Banerjee), in deciduous woodlands in riparian habitats, typically on alder and willow or on their woody debris, (Stamets), stumps and wood of various hardwoods, (Courtecuisse), summer, fall, (Bacon), spring, summer, fall

Pluteus thomsonii.nameOrigin: type was found in company with Dr. Thomson (Minnis(1))
Pluteus thomsonii.spores: reddish ocher (Breitenbach, illustration looks pinkish brown)
Pluteus thomsonii.habitat: single to scattered on hardwood twigs and logs, sometimes apparently on ground (probably on buried wood), (Homola), usually single, "but also up to a few together in forests on dead wood of hardwoods", summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Pluteus tomentosulus.habitat: singly or in small numbers in summer on hardwoods (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), on conifer wood, often in swampy areas (Barron), on decaying conifer wood or hardwood, July to October, (Bessette), single to scattered on decaying hardwood logs, (Smith & Stuntz), summer, fall

Pluteus umbrosus.odour: indistinct or slightly earthy or radish-like
Pluteus umbrosus.habitat: single or in small groups "on well-decayed hardwoods", most common on live oak and Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak) from mid-fall into winter, (Siegel(2) for Redwood Coast of California)

Podaxis pistillaris.edibility: said to be edible when young and white inside, but tough and dusty when old, (Arora), edible when young, widely eaten in northern India, (McKnight)
Podaxis pistillaris.habitat: single or scattered to gregarious or clustered on ground "in deserts, washes, lawns, gardens, irrigated fields, etc." in warm dry areas, (Arora), spring, also summer and fall after rain, (Lincoff)

Polyozellus atrolazulinus.nameOrigin: "atrolazulinus" means "dark blue" in Latin, referring to the typical color of the young fruitbody (Voitk)
Polyozellus atrolazulinus.edibility: edible but opinions vary as to desirability (Voitk)
Polyozellus atrolazulinus.habitat: "on soil and conifer duff, often among mosses", under Picea (spruce) most commonly, and Abies (true fir); mainly August through October, "depending in part on latitude and elevation, with earlier fruiting in the north and at higher elevations"

Polyozellus marymargaretae.nameOrigin: The name pays homage to Mary Margaret "Maggie" Rogers, "mushroom lover and lifelong resident of Washington and Oregon where this species is found. Maggie was cofounder of Mushroom: The Journal of Wild Mushrooming and is a lover of dye mushrooms." (Voitk(5), with name of journal italicized)
Polyozellus marymargaretae.habitat: fruits under conifers "with the first fall rains in late Aug to Sep through early Nov when snow falls"

Polyozellus purpureoniger.nameOrigin: "refers to the purple-black color that distinguishes this species from the others in the genus" (Voitk(5))

Pouzarella fernandae.habitat: "scattered in marshy area or in tundra area among lichens", mid-September to late September, (Largent), fall

Pouzarella versatilis.odour: "unpleasant, grassy to spermatic, at times slight", (Largent)
Pouzarella versatilis.habitat: found in lawns near red cedar, (Largent), under hardwoods (Fagus, Quercus, Carpinus), (Moser)

Protostropharia alcis.nameOrigin: means 'of moose', from the moose's Latin name "Alces alces"
Protostropharia alcis.habitat: on moose dung, August to October, (Noordeloos), generally scattered; on dung of moose and red deer, on buried dung of herbivore (?sheep), (Halama), summer, fall

Protostropharia dorsipora.nameOrigin: dorsi- means back, -pora means pore - presumably refers to the eccentric position of the germ pore on the spore
Protostropharia dorsipora.habitat: single, "scattered, or in small clusters or troops on dung", especially cow dung; fruiting "throughout the wet season, with primary flushes soon after first rains in early fall and in spring"

Protostropharia semiglobata.edibility: yes, but mediocre, (Arora), not hallucinogenic (Stamets), easy to confuse with poisonous species
Protostropharia semiglobata.odour: none (Breitenbach), mealy (Lincoff), clean, spicy, like fenugreek, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Protostropharia semiglobata.habitat: single or in small groups on dung, manure, rich soil, straw, and grazed or fertilized grass, (Arora), on cow or horse dung, spring, summer, or fall, (Stamets)

Psathyrella abieticola.nameOrigin: means 'living with Abies', referring to fir habitat

Psathyrella acuticystis.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on chip-dirt, October, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella albescens.spores: "blackish brown", note on gills implies purplish-tinged
Psathyrella albescens.habitat: type scattered on piles of chips

Psathyrella alboalutacea.habitat: type cespitose [in tufts] on dead alder stubs and logs, fall

Psathyrella alluviana.nameOrigin: means 'alluvial' referring to detritus deposited by running water
Psathyrella alluviana.habitat: scattered on black muck "often in the flood plain of a mountain stream, September", (Smith), fall

Psathyrella ammophila.nameOrigin: means 'sand-loving', ammos = sand (Greek), philos = friend (Greek), or could refer to preference for habitat of Ammophila arenaria
Psathyrella ammophila.habitat: cespitose-gregarious on sand dunes, December in California, (Smith), growing on Ammophila in dunes, (Hansen for Europe), on sand, especially dunes, (Moser for Europe), among marram grass (Ammophila arenaria), in coastal dunes, (Courtecuisse for Europe), summer to fall (Buczacki), summer, fall, winter

Psathyrella annulata.habitat: type was gregarious on conifer duff under old-growth hemlock

Psathyrella aquatica.nameOrigin: refers to aquatic habitat; the English name refers to the Rogue River where it was found and perhaps to its unusual habitat
Psathyrella aquatica.habitat: developing underwater in a cold flowing river, on the substrates that "include water-logged wood, gravel, and the silty riverbed"

Psathyrella atrifolia.habitat: gregarious "on humus under brush and hardwood trees, especially cottonwood, summer and fall"

Psathyrella avellaneifolia.habitat: subcespitose [more or less in tufts] to gregarious on rotting hardwood logs, June, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella barlowiana.nameOrigin: after the old Barlow Trail on Mt. Hood in Oregon, where type found
Psathyrella barlowiana.habitat: gregarious on alder debris, October, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella bifrons.habitat: scattered on wet soil and organic debris

Psathyrella bipellis.odour: faintly to strongly fruity and pleasant, or unpleasant, especially when old, 'sometimes reported as "like cat urine" ', (Siegel), mild (Smith)
Psathyrella bipellis.habitat: single or in clumps "often in large troops in wood chips and leaf litter, almost always in urban or disturbed areas", fruiting from winter through early spring, (Siegel for California), gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on soil and humus (Smith)

Psathyrella borealis.habitat: gregarious in Sphagnum at edge of bog

Psathyrella boulderensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Boulder', referring to Boulder Lake, Idaho, where type found
Psathyrella boulderensis.habitat: type gregarious on moist earth in a campground, July, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella caput-medusae.nameOrigin: after the mythical head of Medusa
Psathyrella caput-medusae.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on or near conifer wood such as stumps, etc., (Smith), on conifer wood (Phillips), fall (Buczacki)

Psathyrella carbonicola.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious on burned ground, (Smith), scattered to densely gregarious or clustered on burned soil and burned wood, (Arora), fruiting "during spring to fall into winter in California" (Miller)

Psathyrella caudata.nameOrigin: means 'with an appendage or tail', presumably referring to pseudorhiza
Psathyrella caudata.habitat: gregarious to scattered "on grassy places in the woods and on humus or sandy soil"

Psathyrella circellatipes.nameOrigin: means 'with ring around foot', circellus = small ring (Latin), pes = foot (Latin)
Psathyrella circellatipes.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on rotten wood and on humus under Populus species (in North America), spring and early summer

Psathyrella columbiana.nameOrigin: probably refers either to the Columbia River or to British Columbia

Psathyrella communis.habitat: gregarious on soil with lignicolous debris in it, September, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella corrugis.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on soil and debris, often in grassy areas under alder and cottonwood, mostly in the fall", (Smith), summer and fall (Miller), large fruitings may occur among wood chips in landscaped areas; "in natural settings under hardwoods such as alder and cottonwood, the fruitings are usually much smaller", (Trudell)

Psathyrella cortinarioides.habitat: gregarious on beech logs in Michigan

Psathyrella crassulistipes.habitat: type was cespitose [in tufts] on sand at edges of dirt road, September, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella cuspidata.habitat: densely cespitose [in tufts] in large masses on Alnus (alder) logs and debris

Psathyrella deserticola.habitat: type gregarious under sagebrush after heavy rains in June (Smith), summer

Psathyrella directa.habitat: gregarious "on debris of mixed conifer and deciduous forest, September", (Smith), fall

Psathyrella duplicata.habitat: gregarious on debris in an alder flat

Psathyrella ellenae.nameOrigin: after Ellen Trueblood of Nampa, Idaho, who collected the type

Psathyrella elwhaensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Elwha', type found at Elwha Lake in Washington
Psathyrella elwhaensis.habitat: scattered to gregarious on humus in spring

Psathyrella epimyces.habitat: grows on Coprinus comatus (shaggy mane), (Smith, Schalkwijk-Barendsen)

Psathyrella equina.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to horse' presumably referring to habitat on horse dung

Psathyrella fibrillosa.habitat: single to gregarious "on debris in mixed conifer-hardwood forests, late summer and fall"

Psathyrella flexuosipes.nameOrigin: refers to the stem which is often flexuous [wavy]
Psathyrella flexuosipes.habitat: single on debris along roads through alder stands

Psathyrella fragilissima.habitat: gregarious on decayed leaves etc. in mixed woods

Psathyrella fragrans.habitat: type cespitose [in tufts] on conifer debris, August, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella frustulenta.nameOrigin: means 'with clinging crumbs', frustum = crumb, morsel, scrap of food (Latin), lentus = clinging, tenacious, pliable (Latin)
Psathyrella frustulenta.habitat: scattered to gregarious under ferns on conifer needles (Smith), on rotting hardwood, especially Quercus (oak) and Ulmus (elm), fall, (Buczacki)

Psathyrella fulvescens.habitat: scattered on hardwood logs or the debris beside them

Psathyrella fulvoumbrina.habitat: type gregarious under aspen and fir, June, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella fusca.habitat: on humus under Alnus (alder) (Smith), usually with Fagus (beech), spring to fall, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Psathyrella fuscofolia.nameOrigin: means 'with dark gills', fuscus = dark, folium = leaf
Psathyrella fuscofolia.habitat: gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] "on soil or on decaying wood in woods or open places"

Psathyrella fuscospora.habitat: type gregarious on soil along a road

Psathyrella grasmerensis.nameOrigin: after Grasmere, Idaho where type specimen found
Psathyrella grasmerensis.habitat: type on soil in grassy area in arid part of Idaho

Psathyrella griseopallida.habitat: on grass under aspen, June; on sandy soil near oak log, March, (Smith), spring, summer

Psathyrella gruberi.nameOrigin: type found by William Gruber of Portland, Oregon
Psathyrella gruberi.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on soil in a burned area, fall

Psathyrella hirta.habitat: subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on manure or fertilized soil, (Smith), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Psathyrella hymenocephala.habitat: scattered to gregarious on humus and debris under hardwoods or along edges of roads or bogs

Psathyrella idahoensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Idaho', where type was found
Psathyrella idahoensis.habitat: type gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on disturbed soil in a slashing, September, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella incerta.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] or scattered on damp soil with woody debris, or near stumps of hardwoods, late spring and summer, (Smith), gregarious or subcespitose, on ground among bushes, June and July, (Peck)

Psathyrella incondita.habitat: type scattered "under brush on humus and debris in a mixed conifer and alder stand"

Psathyrella indecorosa.nameOrigin: either 'not ornamented' from in- + decorosa, or 'ugly, shameful' from indecoris = ugly, shameful (Latin)
Psathyrella indecorosa.habitat: type subcespitose [somewhat cespitose] on alder logs

Psathyrella iterata.habitat: on wood and lignicolous debris of cottonwood, May, (Smith), spring

Psathyrella kauffmanii.nameOrigin: after Kauffman who made one of the early collections
Psathyrella kauffmanii.spores: dark purple-brown (with a slight red component)
Psathyrella kauffmanii.habitat: subcespitose [more or less in tufts] to gregarious under beech

Psathyrella lanatipes.habitat: gregarious on debris under mixed Thuja (red-cedar) and Alnus (alder)

Psathyrella longicauda.habitat: saprotrophic, in a mixture of decaying plants and fragmented branches/twigs, wood chips, (Mycoquebec), terrestrial, "on humus, decaying leaves, rotting hay or manured grass", (Hansen, L.), on humus, "also burnt ground", (Moser)

Psathyrella longipes.habitat: single, scattered, or in small groups "on ground or debris in woods", under hardwoods or conifers

Psathyrella longistriata.spores: dull vinaceous-brown to purplish brown, (Smith), deep brown to nearly black (Arora)
Psathyrella longistriata.habitat: scattered to gregarious on humus and debris under conifers and also under Alnus (alder), (Smith), single to scattered or in small groups in woods, particularly under conifers, (Arora), usually in fall, occasionally in spring, (Miller)

Psathyrella lutensis.habitat: single, gregarous, to grouped, "in forests, in wet places in cart tracks", on pathsides or roadsides, "on soil or rotten, buried wood"; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), single, "or in small to large groups", often +/- trooping, on soil or rotting wood of hardwoods; fall, (Buczacki), in marshy places (Moser), in hardwood forests (Hansen)

Psathyrella luteovelata.habitat: single to gregarious "on humus under alder and cottonwood"

Psathyrella maculata.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to subcespitose on alder stumps and logs, fall, (Smith), in tufts or in groups on stumps of hardwoods and conifers, (Courtecuisse)

Psathyrella madeodisca.habitat: gregarious "on wet mossy sticks in areas where water accumulates during wet seasons in forests of aspen and birch, May-June", (Smith), on decaying stumps, spring, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), spring, summer

Psathyrella mazamensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Mazama' referring to Mazama Ridge, Mt. Rainier National Park, where type was found
Psathyrella mazamensis.habitat: type single on soil on exposed bank of a trail, 5200 feet elevation

Psathyrella mesocystis.habitat: gregarious under spruce and fir, July, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella microrhiza.habitat: single to gregarious, in forests, parks, gardens, at the edge of forests or alongside paths, on damp to moist soils, on rotting plant remains or buried wood; late summer-fall, (Breitenbach), "on bare soil in gardens, hedgerows or woodland"; fall, (Phillips)

Psathyrella minima.habitat: scattered to gregarious on deer dung

Psathyrella monticola.habitat: type on earth in an old burn, July, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella mucrocystis.habitat: type cespitose [in tufts] on outwash of a stream in July, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella nezpercii.nameOrigin: type found in Nezperce National Forest, Idaho
Psathyrella nezpercii.habitat: type scattered on mud in a pasture, August, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella noli-tangere.habitat: cespitose-gregarious on wet earth (Smith), on soil or rotting vegetation in wet habitats, marshes, carr, ditches, pond habitats, usually fall, occasionally spring, (Buczacki)

Psathyrella obtusata.nameOrigin: likely refers to obtuse apex of pleurocystidia which are acute to obtuse in the section of Psathyrella of which this species is the type, or possibly to the obtuse cap
Psathyrella obtusata.habitat: single to gregarious on hardwood logs, especially oak

Psathyrella ochracea.habitat: on soil, July to October, (Phillips), grouped, gregarious, or single "inside or outside forests, on pathsides and roadsides, in places where wood is stored, on soil, leaf litter, or buried wood", late summer-fall, (Breitenbach)

Psathyrella olympiana.nameOrigin: refers to Olympic National Park where type was found
Psathyrella olympiana.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on old wood and debris of alder and cottonwood"

Psathyrella orbitarum.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on wet earth in shady places"

Psathyrella oregonensis.habitat: type gregarious on rotten conifer wood, October, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella owyheensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Owyhee' after Owyhee County Idaho where type was found
Psathyrella owyheensis.habitat: type was gregarious among native grasses in an area where cattle were pastured, in April, (Smith), spring

Psathyrella pallida.habitat: type on debris in mixed woods (alder and conifers), September, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella paradoxa.habitat: scattered near and on very decayed Alnus (alder) logs

Psathyrella payettensis.habitat: type scattered on conifer duff, September, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella piluliformis.taste: not distinctive (Smith), some collections are bitter (Arora)
Psathyrella piluliformis.habitat: cespitose gregarious on decaying wood of hardwood trees, "at times appearing terrestrial but arising from buried wood, late fall", (Smith), gregarious, usually in tufts or large, dense clusters "on hardwood stumps, logs, and buried wood", (Arora), summer and fall (Miller), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Psathyrella polycephala.habitat: densely cespitose [in tufts] "around dead hardwood trees and stumps or on chip dirt"

Psathyrella populorum.habitat: type subcespitose [more or less in tufts] around aspen, June, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella potteri.nameOrigin: named after the person who collected the holotype
Psathyrella potteri.habitat: gregarious on ground around horse dung

Psathyrella praetenuis.habitat: gregarious under cottonwood on debris, October, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella prona.habitat: scattered "on soil and straw in barnyards and on fertilized soil", (Smith), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Psathyrella pseudocotonea.habitat: type near conifer stumps, October, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella pseudofulvescens.habitat: type on debris under alder, vine-maple etc.

Psathyrella pseudogracilis.habitat: single to gregarious "on pathsides or along the edges of forests, in parks on soil or small branches or pieces of wood buried in the ground"; summer-fall, (Breitenbach), in grass "or on naked soil along roadsides", (Hansen, L.)

Psathyrella pseudolimicola.habitat: type gregarious on mud in a cow pasture with mud and manure present, August, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella pseudolongipes.habitat: type on a meadow in a campground

Psathyrella pseudovernalis.nameOrigin: means 'false [Psathyrella] vernalis', a European species with paler spores
Psathyrella pseudovernalis.habitat: single to gregarious "on humus and debris under alder and cottonwood, particularly close to logs, stumps, etc.", in spring

Psathyrella psilocyboides.habitat: type scattered "on soil in a wet mountain meadow, July", (Smith), summer

Psathyrella quercicola.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on mossy oak trunks or logs, November", (Smith), fall

Psathyrella ramicola.habitat: type gregarious on small branches of alder slash, October, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella rigidipes.habitat: gregarious "in damp places under herbs or in grassy places or along gravel roads"

Psathyrella rogueiana.nameOrigin: type found at Grant's Pass, Oregon, near Rogue River
Psathyrella rogueiana.habitat: type scattered "on clay soil in an old road through mixed woods"

Psathyrella roothaanensis.nameOrigin: "dedicated to Father Roothaan, who directed much of the early exploration of the Priest Lake Country" in Idaho in the fur trading days
Psathyrella roothaanensis.habitat: type gregarious on moss in a swampy area

Psathyrella rubescens.habitat: gregarious on rich humus under alder

Psathyrella rubicola.habitat: single or in small groups of 2-3 on canes of Rubus and on rotten alder, July, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella rufogrisea.nameOrigin: 'rufogrisea' means 'reddish gray', 'riparia' means 'of stream banks'; 'bonnerensis' means 'from Bonner'
Psathyrella rufogrisea.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] in small clusters on soil, var. bonnerensis on wood

Psathyrella salictaria.habitat: type gregarious on wet moss under willow and dwarf birch, August, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella semivestita.habitat: scattered to gregarious on debris in woods

Psathyrella senex.habitat: scattered on decaying wood of hardwoods (Smith), on soil with grass or with heather on acidic sites, usually single, usually fall, (Buczacki)

Psathyrella septentrionalis.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious on hardwood logs (aspen, beech, oak), summer and fall

Psathyrella solheimii.nameOrigin: after W.G. Solheim who found the type
Psathyrella solheimii.habitat: on moist soil under aspen, especially around beaver dams

Psathyrella spadiceogrisea.habitat: gregarious "on muck around edges of bogs and pools", in spring

Psathyrella sphaerocystis.nameOrigin: refers to sphaerocysts that make up the powdery outer veil

Psathyrella sphagnicola.habitat: scattered on sphagnum moss in bogs (Smith), spring to fall (Buczacki)

Psathyrella stuntzii.nameOrigin: after Dr. D.E. Stuntz of the University of Washington, who collected the type
Psathyrella stuntzii.habitat: type gregarious on moss and needle carpet under Pinus contorta

Psathyrella suavissima.habitat: usually "gregarious to slightly clustered in and outside forests, always associated with wood debris such as wood chips or shreds of bark"; spring to fall

Psathyrella subagraria.habitat: scattered to gregarious on moist ground in woods (especially elm swamps), late summer and fall

Psathyrella subalpina.nameOrigin: probably means 'subalpine', the type being found at Eagle Peak, Mt. Rainier National Park in Washington
Psathyrella subalpina.odour: "imperceptible or very faint and reminding one of cinnamon"
Psathyrella subalpina.habitat: type on "soil forming face of a bank along a trail", near conifer roots

Psathyrella subargillacea.habitat: scattered on rotten hardwoods - logs, stumps etc., June, (Smith), summer

Psathyrella subcaerulea.nameOrigin: means 'near sky-blue', probably referring to basal tomentum which becomes bluish
Psathyrella subcaerulea.habitat: scattered to gregarious on mossy oak trunks (living trees), November, (Smith), the BC collections mentioned above were in mixed forest with oak in December

Psathyrella subcaespitosa.habitat: type cespitose-gregarious on wet soil, October, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella subhepatica.habitat: gregarious on wet soil in low woods

Psathyrella sublateritia.nameOrigin: from 'later' meaning 'brick', probably referring to brick red spore deposit
Psathyrella sublateritia.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] "around hardwood stumps and dead trees"

Psathyrella subnuda.habitat: scattered on humus under cottonwood, October

Psathyrella subpurpurea.habitat: on conifer debris and duff, late fall

Psathyrella subradicata.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] on soil under fir

Psathyrella subrubella.nameOrigin: means 'somewhat reddish' perhaps referring to pinkish tint in cap

Psathyrella subtenacipes.habitat: type single to gregarious on debris among willows and cottonwood

Psathyrella tahomensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Tahoma' referring to Tahoma Creek, Mt. Rainier National Park, Washington, where type found

Psathyrella tenera.habitat: on damp mucky ground in open woods

Psathyrella trepida.habitat: single to scattered on organic debris

Psathyrella undulatipes.habitat: type gregarious on wood and debris of conifers or possibly alder, October, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella uskensis.habitat: type on mud under spruce, September, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella variata.habitat: type somewhat tufted on conifer log, October, (Smith), fall

Psathyrella velibrunnescens.habitat: cespitose [in tufts], gregarious or scattered on rotting wood of hardwoods

Psathyrella vesiculocystis.nameOrigin: refers to cheilocystidia which are vesiculose: appearing inflated like a large sac or bladder (vesicle)

Psathyrella wapinitaensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Wapinita' in reference to Wapinita Summit in the Cascades south of Mt. Hood, Oregon, where type found
Psathyrella wapinitaensis.habitat: subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on conifer logs

Psathyrella warrenensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Warren', referring to Warren in Idaho where type was found

Pseudoarmillariella ectypoides.habitat: on decaying conifer logs (Barron), on rotting conifers, often hemlock, July to September, (Lincoff), "scattered or in groups on decaying conifer wood, especially hemlock", (Bessette), summer, fall

Pseudobaeospora pillodii.habitat: rooting in loamy soil under a mature forest of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), Oplopanax horridum (devil's club), and Athyrium felix-femina (lady-fern), (Redhead(30)), subalpine under Larix (larch), Rhododendron, Alnus viridis (Green Alder), etc. (Moser for Europe), on soil in Alnus (alder), Betula (birch), and Salix (willow) shrubs (Hansen for Europe)

Pseudoclitocybe cyathiformis.spores: white (Arora), usually white, yellowish in one collection, (Bigelow)
Pseudoclitocybe cyathiformis.edibility: not recommended because of similar species of unknown edibility, (Arora)
Pseudoclitocybe cyathiformis.habitat: single or in small groups "in humus or on rotten logs, in woods and at their edges", (Arora), single, scattered, gregarious, or subcespitose [more or less in tufts], usually "on or near logs and stumps of conifers or hardwoods", sometimes on soil and humus, (Bigelow), fall (Bacon), late fall to winter, but moribund fruitbodies persist, (Buczacki),

Pseudolaccaria pachyphylla.taste: similar to odor or somewhat bitter, (Redhead), "bitter, often farinaceous also at first", (Bigelow)
Pseudolaccaria pachyphylla.odour: indistinctive to faintly or strongly farinaceous or faintly rancid, (Redhead), farinaceous but fading (Bigelow)
Pseudolaccaria pachyphylla.habitat: single, scattered, or gregarious, in the open on bare soil or sand, sometimes in grass or in Polytrichum, in open coniferous woods (hemlock, pine), June to October, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Pseudomarasmius pallidocephalus.habitat: gregarious "in troops on spruce and fir needle carpets, June to October", (Smith), gregarious on senescent needles of Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), or Abies (fir), (very rarely on Pinus (pine)), (Desjardin), on needles in needle beds, mostly commonly Picea, Tsuga, and less often Pinus, (Redhead), gregarious or sometimes in troops "on needles of conifers, particularly spruce or hemlock", (Gilliam), summer, fall

Pseudoomphalina angelesiana.nameOrigin: type specimen from Mt. Angeles in Washington
Pseudoomphalina angelesiana.habitat: single to several on soil and needles, in or near melting snowbanks, May to July, frequent to common at high elevations, (Bessette), "it appears that N. angelesianus is neither totally restricted to high elevations near snowbanks, nor to vernal [spring] fruitings", (Redhead), spring, summer, fall

Pseudoomphalina intermedia.taste: "slightly to markedly farinaceous" (Voitk), farinaceous or rancid farinaceous, (Bigelow)
Pseudoomphalina intermedia.odour: "slightly to markedly farinaceous" (Voitk), farinaceous or rancid farinaceous, (Bigelow)
Pseudoomphalina intermedia.habitat: gregarious; terricolous, under pine in the late fall (Voitk), scattered to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on soil, along trails, roadways, or in open woods, September and October, (Bigelow)

Pseudoomphalina kalchbrenneri.odour: absent or faintly fragrant, (Bigelow), faintly but distinctly fragrant (Smith)
Pseudoomphalina kalchbrenneri.habitat: on soil and needles under conifers or on exposed soil in roadway, July to October, (Bigelow), summer, fall

Pseudosperma breviterincarnatum.nameOrigin: "refers to the briefly incarnate, or pinkish, color" of the immature gills, (Kropp(4))
Pseudosperma breviterincarnatum.habitat: with conifers and Populus tremuloides [Quaking Aspen] in montane areas in summer

Pseudosperma flavellum.habitat: associated with aspen in Montana, (Cripps), Fagus, Corylus, Populus cv. canadensis, and Picea in Europe, (Kuyper)

Pseudosperma holoxanthum.habitat: single to gregarious on ground under conifers, or in mixed conifer and hardwood woods

Pseudosperma niveivelatum.nameOrigin: refers to white abundant veil that covers the cap
Pseudosperma niveivelatum.habitat: in montane environments, with conifers or Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), fruiting during summer

Pseudosperma obsoletum.habitat: "under hardwoods and conifers during summer in Washington", in a montane area with aspen and conifers in summer in Utah, under conifers in late summer in Nova Scotia

Pseudosperma occidentale.nameOrigin: "refers to presence of the species in western North America" (Kropp(4))
Pseudosperma occidentale.odour: "spermatic or, at times, featuring a pleasant truffle-like component"
Pseudosperma occidentale.habitat: with conifers in montane areas, fruiting in summer

Pseudosperma rimosum.nameOrigin: means "inclined" or "with a pointed gable" because of cap shape
Pseudosperma rimosum.spores: snuff brown (Phillips), dull yellow brown (Barron), brown (Bessette), dull brown (Miller), olive-brown (Buczacki)
Pseudosperma rimosum.taste: none (Lincoff(1)), as odor (Kuyper), mild but do not taste because of toxins (Miller)
Pseudosperma rimosum.odour: slight, of meal, for Inocybe fastigiata var. fastigiata, spermatic for var. microsperma, slight for var. umbrinella, (Phillips), strongly spermatic (Arora), spermatic (Lincoff(2), Lincoff(1)), strong and disagreeable, or lacking, (Kauffman for I. fastigiata), fetid (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), not distinctive for type variety of Inocybe fastigiata, spermatic for I. fastigiata var. microsperma, (Bessette), "indistinct to distinct, rather disagreeable, spermatic", or more as Amanita phalloides, or reminiscent of acorns, (Kuyper), of green corn or spermatic (Miller), "barely perceptible, fungal", (Stangl), acorns, bleach, (Buczacki)
Pseudosperma rimosum.habitat: deciduous or mixed woods (Phillips), on the ground in moist woods, (Kauffman for I. fastigiata), in woods (Kauffman for I. rimosa), single, scattered, or in groups "on the ground and among mosses under conifers and hardwoods", (Bessette), under hardwoods and conifers, also in alpine vegetation, (Kuyper), summer and fall (Miller)

Pseudosperma sororium.edibility: poisonous, contains high concentrations of muscarine, (Arora)
Pseudosperma sororium.odour: "usually strongly pungent, like freshly husked or green corn", (Arora), very strong, of "green corn", not at all spermatic, very persistent, (Stuntz), somewhat pungent or lacking (Kauffman)
Pseudosperma sororium.habitat: single, scattered, or in small groups on ground in woods, (Arora), a collection under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Larix (larch), (Stuntz), type collected in deciduous woods in Michigan, (Kauffman), summer, fall, winter

Pseudosperma spurium.habitat: in Utah fruiting with mixed Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen) and conifers in montane areas in summer

Pseudosperma squamatum.odour: none or faintly spermatic (Cripps), none to somewhat acidulous, or even reminding of sour apples, (Kuyper), slightly acidic or fungal (Stangl)
Pseudosperma squamatum.habitat: with Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen) in Montana, with Populus tremula (European Aspen) in Europe, (Cripps), under hardwoods, associated mainly with Populus, but also with Salix (willow) and Alnus (alder), (Kuyper)

Psilocybe allenii.nameOrigin: in honor of John W. Allen "who deeply believed in this new species and repeatedly insisted on a detailed study and DNA sequencing"
Psilocybe allenii.spores: "dark violet brown to dark tobacco brown"
Psilocybe allenii.edibility: hallucinogenic potency roughly equivalent to P. cyanescens (Borovicka)
Psilocybe allenii.habitat: scattered to gregarious, sometimes cespitose [tufted], on woody debris, usually on wood chips (Pseudotsuga menziesii, Alnus, Pinus radiata, Cupressus macrocarpa, Eucalyptus, and others); fruits in cold weather from late September to January

Psilocybe apelliculosa.habitat: gregarious on soil in grassland, September, (Guzman(1)), scattered to gregarious or cespitose [in tufts], "in dense troops on soils supplemented with wood-chips-manure compost", in recently established horticultural plantations and lawns, (Guzman(4)), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Psilocybe atrobrunnea.spores: deep purple brown (Phillips), dark violaceous brown (Stamets), dark brown violaceous (Guzman)
Psilocybe atrobrunnea.edibility: no, (Phillips), possibly active: one report of psilocybin, (Stamets)
Psilocybe atrobrunnea.habitat: "gregarious in swamps and bogs", (Phillips), gregarious to scattered "in or near sphagnum bogs, in coniferous and deciduous woodlands", September and October, (Stamets), gregarious to scattered in Sphagnum bogs or moors or along their edges, "in coniferous or deciduous forest zones", (Guzman), fall

Psilocybe azurescens.spores: dark purplish brown to purplish black
Psilocybe azurescens.habitat: cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious on deciduous wood chips or in sandy soil rich in lignicolous debris, along the northern Oregon coast near Astoria, favoring land adjacent to shoreline, strong affection for dune grasses, especially Ammophila maritima, fall and winter (late September to early January)

Psilocybe baeocystis.nameOrigin: name refers to comparatively shorter cheilocystidia (Greek baio means small)
Psilocybe baeocystis.edibility: hallucinogenic, 0.15-0.85% psilocybin, up to 0.59% psilocin, up to 0.10% baeocystin, losing considerable potency from drying or in damage, (Stamets)
Psilocybe baeocystis.habitat: single to gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on decaying conifer mulch, in wood chips, lawns with high lignin content, seed cones of Douglas-fir, fall to early winter or rarely spring, (Stamets), scattered to gregarious, rarely cespitose [in tufts], sublignicolous [somewhat growing on wood] "on mulch with wood chips or bark or decayed sawdust of conifers, under bushes, in gardens or flower beds, more rarely in campus grasses", unknown in fields, very rare in forests, (Guzman(1))

Psilocybe cyanescens.spores: dark purplish brown (Stamets), dark brown violet or fuscous (Guzman(1)), "purple-brown to purple-gray or purple-black", (Arora)
Psilocybe cyanescens.edibility: potent hallucinogen, especially raw, only one or two caps needed to alter perception and sensation, (Arora), 0.3-1.7% psilocybin, 0.28-0.51% psilocin, 0.02-0.03% baeocystin, (Stamets)
Psilocybe cyanescens.taste: farinaceous especially when young (Guzman(1)), bitter or farinaceous (Siegel)
Psilocybe cyanescens.odour: farinaceous especially when young (Guzman(1)), none (Miller), "mild, farinaceous or earthy" (Siegel)
Psilocybe cyanescens.habitat: scattered to gregarious "in humus enriched with woody debris, amongst leaves and twigs, in woodchips, sawdust, or in debris fields rich with rotting wood", often "under mixed woods at the edges of lawns, along paths, and in heavily mulched rhododendron and rose gardens", grows well with rhododendrons, azaleas, lupines, (Stamets), gregarious, rarely scattered, sometimes forming rings, on humus or on very rotten wood mixed with soil, or on sawdust or soil mulched containing wood chips or bark, in deciduous forests, but also very common in gardens and under bushes, very rarely in grasses, (Guzman(1)), widely scattered to densely gregarious "on wood chips, sawdust, mulch, and humus, and on lawns rich in lignin", "partial to conifer debris but also fond of alder and eucalyptus", (Arora), October to January (Miller), typically appears around the end of October with the onset of colder weather, (Trudell), they can grow together densely enough that their stem bases are jointed; appearing in fall and winter

Psilocybe cyanofibrillosa.nameOrigin: means 'blue-fibrillose', referring to fibrils on stem becoming bluish
Psilocybe cyanofibrillosa.edibility: weakly to mildly active, containing up to 0.21% psilocybin and 0.062% psilocin, but actual potency of fresh specimens "is probably much higher than chemical analyses revealed" because it "loses much of it potency from handing and in drying", (Stamets)
Psilocybe cyanofibrillosa.habitat: gregarious to scattered along coastal regions from northern California to BC, associated with bush lupines and especially common on flood plains on river estuaries flowing into Pacific, also frequent in coastal rhododendron gardens and nurseries, (Stamets), growing in large colonies, cespitose [in tufts] or subcespitose, sometimes scattered in small groups, in decayed urea-enriched fir sawdust in fall, in WA, (Guzman(1))

Psilocybe fimetaria.taste: farinaceous, especially in young stages or when cut, (Guzman)
Psilocybe fimetaria.odour: farinaceous, especially in young stages or when cut, (Guzman)
Psilocybe fimetaria.habitat: single to gregarious on horse manure, in grassy areas or in rich soils, often in large fairy rings, (Stamets), single or gregarious "on dung (horse) or in rich soil, in grassland or among juncaceous plants", sometimes forming large rings, (Guzman), fall (Buczacki)

Psilocybe laticystis.habitat: gregarious on sticks or logs of conifer wood, October to November, (Guzman), fall

Psilocybe liniformans.nameOrigin: refers to edge of gill, a thread-like band that is removable as an elastic strip, but which is absent in the American variety
Psilocybe liniformans.edibility: weakly to moderately active, 0.16-0.89% psilocybin, no psilocin, (Stamets)
Psilocybe liniformans.taste: weak, not unpleasant to somewhat farinaceous, this taste for European variety, (Guzman)
Psilocybe liniformans.odour: peculiar, strongly aromatic with fetid component when crushed, to farinaceous, these odors for European variety, (Guzman)
Psilocybe liniformans.habitat: scattered to gregarious on horse dung or in manure-enriched soil in meadows and pastures, (Stamets, not specifically for var. americana which "grows in rich pastures or in grasslands"), scattered on soil in fields, (Guzman for var. americana), scattered or gregarious on horse dung or rich soil in meadows, summer to fall, (Guzman for var. liniformans in Europe)

Psilocybe ovoideocystidiata.nameOrigin: from the frequent ovoid pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia
Psilocybe ovoideocystidiata.habitat: on the Pacific coast on wood chips, (Borovicka), type gregarious, "on wood or wood debris, in trails or places with herbaceous plants, in a deciduous forest", (Guzman)

Psilocybe pelliculosa.nameOrigin: refers to removable gelatinous pellicle of cap
Psilocybe pelliculosa.spores: purplish brown (Stamets), purplish brown or dark violaceous brown (Guzman(1))
Psilocybe pelliculosa.edibility: less potent than Psilocybe semilanceata and P. cyanescens, up to 0.4% psilocybin, no psilocin, and 0.04% baeocystin, (Stamets)
Psilocybe pelliculosa.taste: farinaceous mainly when young and fresh (Guzman(1))
Psilocybe pelliculosa.odour: farinaceous mainly when young and fresh (Guzman(1))
Psilocybe pelliculosa.habitat: scattered to gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on well-decayed conifer substrate, in mulch, or in soil rich in lignin, often "along paths in conifer forests and along abandoned logging roads that are being recaptured by alders and firs", "mid-to-late fall to early winter", (Stamets); scattered to gregarious or cespitose on humus, "in trails or clearing of conifer forests, predominantly along the forest edge", "sometimes on bark mulch beds or different debris in gardens below shrubs", uncommon in grasslands, (Guzman(1))

Psilocybe sabulosa.habitat: gregarious or single, sometimes in small groups or scattered, "in sand dunes or sandy soil in pastures (or in alpine areas)"

Psilocybe semilanceata.nameOrigin: means half spear-shaped, from shape of cap
Psilocybe semilanceata.spores: purple-brown (Arora), "dark violet brown or brown purplish darker" (Guzman(1)), dark purplish brown (Stamets)
Psilocybe semilanceata.edibility: hallucinogenic, not as potent as P. cyanescens but much stronger than P. pelliculosa, (Arora), 0.2-2.4% psilocybin, no psilocin, 0.2-0.36% baeocystin, important to distinguish from poisonous Galerinas, (Stamets), hallucinogenic and widely collected for this purpose, "but should be regarded as mildly poisonous; also, there is the possibility of misidentification", (Phillips)
Psilocybe semilanceata.taste: slightly farinaceous (Guzman(1)), slightly unpleasant, grassy, (Phillips), mild (Miller)
Psilocybe semilanceata.odour: slightly farinaceous (Guzman(1), Siegel(2)), not distinctive (Phillips), mild to unpleasant (Miller)
Psilocybe semilanceata.habitat: widely scattered to gregarious in pastures, tall grass, etc., but not on dung, (Arora), very scattered to gregarious "on rich soil, among grass in fields near farmyards, in well-manured pastures or meadows, rarely along roadsides", single but very rarely cespitose [in tufts], frequently abundant around clumps of tall grasses; fruiting August to November, rare in June-July, sometimes in December, (Guzman(1)), scattered to gregarious "in pastures, fields, lawns, or another grassy areas, especially rich grasslands grazed by sheep and cows", especially abundant in or around clumps of sedge grass in damper parts of fields, not on dung, fall to early winter, less common in spring, (Stamets), spring, summer, fall, winter
