Psilocybe silvatica.spores: dark purplish brown (Stamets), dark violaceous brown (Guzman)
Psilocybe silvatica.edibility: contains psilocybin and/or psilocin but estimated not to be potent, (Stamets)
Psilocybe silvatica.odour: farinaceous when crushed fresh and young, (Guzman)
Psilocybe silvatica.habitat: gregarious but not cespitose [not in tufts] on wood debris or wood chips or in well-decayed conifer substrate in fall, (Stamets), scattered to gregarious, non-cespitose, "on debris of conifers or amongst fallen leaves of hardwood trees, rarely on twigs or very rotten wood", in conifer or hardwood (mainly Fagus grandifolia) forests; fruiting September to November, (Guzman)

Psilocybe strictipes.nameOrigin: means 'rigid foot', i.e. 'rigid stem', the Latin 'strictus' also carrying the connotation 'drawn together, close, tight', and "refers to the tough or hardened texture of the stem, especially the base, in drying"
Psilocybe strictipes.edibility: estimated moderately to highly active, but analyses not available, probably low in psilocin because of limited blueing reaction
Psilocybe strictipes.habitat: "rich, grassy areas such as lawns, along roadsides, and in fields" but not on dung, although common in fields with and without manure, (note conifer wood and debris are not typical as described by Singer(7)), late summer to fall in Pacific Northwest

Psilocybe stuntzii.nameOrigin: after Dr. Daniel Stuntz who collected type
Psilocybe stuntzii.spores: dark purple brown (Arora), "deep violaceous to dark violaceous purple", (Guzman), dark purplish grayish brown, (Stamets)
Psilocybe stuntzii.edibility: weakly to moderately active, 0-0.36% psilocybin, 0-0.12% psilocin, 0.02% baeocystin; beware of the poisonous Galerina autumnalis which has similar shape though different color, (Stamets)
Psilocybe stuntzii.taste: strongly farinaceous when young, but weak when mature, (Guzman)
Psilocybe stuntzii.odour: strongly farinaceous when young, but weak when mature, (Guzman)
Psilocybe stuntzii.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious or clustered "on wood chips, mulch etc., in lawns, gardens, and landscaped areas; also under conifers and in fields", (Arora), scattered to gregarious in dense clusters, rarely single, "on soil or on small plant fragments such as bark residues, or on bark mulch of conifers, or on well decomposed manure, in grasses, gardens or lawns in the cities, rarely in grassland or meadows", (Guzman), in gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] clusters "on conifer wood chips, in soils rich with woody debris, in newly placed lawns and fields, along roads, paths, in gardens", mostly fall to early winter, to a minor degree in spring, especially within 90km of coastal regions in BC, WA, OR, (Stamets)

Psilocybe subborealis.nameOrigin: refers to northern distribution of fungus, and independent of Psilocybe borealis which is in another section, (Guzman)
Psilocybe subborealis.habitat: gregarious to scattered on conifer sticks and debris, October, (Guzman), fall

Psilocybe subfimetaria.edibility: active as hallucinogen, but potency unknown, (Stamets)
Psilocybe subfimetaria.habitat: single to gregarious on dung, primarily in grassy areas, (Stamets); single to gregarious on dung in meadows and other grassy areas, October-November, (Guzman(1)), fall

Psilocybe washingtonensis.edibility: activity unknown, could be weakly psilocybin positive, (Stamets)
Psilocybe washingtonensis.habitat: scattered to gregarious "in forests, directly on decaying conifer wood in the fall", (Stamets), gregarious "on decaying conifer debris or humus, in conifer forests", (Guzman)

Pyrrhulomyces astragalinus.spores: brown (Tian, Arora, Phillips), reddish brown (Bessette(1)), yellowish brown (Miller)
Pyrrhulomyces astragalinus.odour: none (Smith(3)), distinct (Phillips), not distinctive (Bessette(1)), faint, mushroomy, (Buczacki), mild (Tian)
Pyrrhulomyces astragalinus.habitat: scattered to gregarious "in small clusters on rotting conifers", (Arora), on logs, stumps and rotting conifer wood, (Smith(3)), late summer through fall (Miller), on "logs, stumps, and rotting conifer wood in late states of decay (rarely on hardwood per Holec 2001)", (Tian)

Resinomycena montana.habitat: "scattered to gregarious on coniferous needles, cone debris and small twig fragments" under conifers

Resinomycena saccharifera.nameOrigin: means 'sugar-bearing'; 'kalalochensis' refers to Kalaloch Washington where found originally
Resinomycena saccharifera.habitat: on wet decaying vegetation, grasses, leaf litter, small twigs, along beaches, in seepage areas, and in dense hummocks, (Redhead(6)), on litter of Rubus, Alnus rubra, and grasses in coastal forest zone (Redhead(17)), on debris of Alnus rubra (red alder) and Rubus parviflorus (thimbleberry), (Smith), "in groups on grasses and sedges in peat bogs, marshes", (Courtecuisse for Europe)

Resupinatus applicatus.habitat: on bark and wood of fallen hardwoods, not conifers (Thorn(2)), underside of logs or branches, (Barron), on stems and fallen branches of hardwoods, more rarely on conifers, (Hansen), all year (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter

Resupinatus niger.habitat: on dead deciduous wood of Juglans (walnut) and Alnus (alder), (Thorn(2))

Resupinatus striatulus.nameOrigin: probably refers to the usually striate margin
Resupinatus striatulus.habitat: on old and well-rotted conifer or deciduous wood that is without bark and is usually soft and white-rotted, growing most often on the undersides of logs

Rhizocybe rhizoides.odour: "slight when crushed (suggestive of grass or ripe apples)"
Rhizocybe rhizoides.habitat: scattered to gregarious, on soil under Pinus (pine), December through March, (Bigelow), collections from WA and OR fruiting between March 27 and May 13th, (D. Miller, pers. comm.)

Rhizomarasmius epidryas.habitat: "scattered to gregarious on dead cortical tissues of living stems and roots" of D. drummondii (yellow mountain avens), D. integrifolia (entire-leaf mountain avens), D. octopetala (eight-petaled mountain avens), and D. octopetala subsp. alaskensis, "in arctic and alpine tundra, and down into montane valley bottoms along creek or glacier paths", reported from Greenland on Dryas spp. and Vaccinium uliginosum (bog blueberry), (Redhead(63)), single to gregarious in mats of Dryas octopetala, on dead stems or pieces of roots, summer, (Breitenbach), on Dryas in (sub)alpine and (sub)arctic habitats, (Hansen for Europe), in cushions of Dryas octopetala (white mountain avens) in mountains, (Moser for Europe), grows on dead bark tissue of certain avens species, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)

Rhodocollybia badiialba.habitat: gregarious to loosely cespitose [in tufts] on much decayed logs or on ground in thick duff in dense conifer woods

Rhodocollybia 'butyracea'.spores: "creamy to yellowish, buff, or pinkish-buff" (Arora), pale pinkish buff (Halling), cream to light orange (Lennox), "whitish-light cream" (Breitenbach), cream to pinkish buff (Beug(6))
Rhodocollybia 'butyracea'.edibility: yes but careful with identification (Arora), yes, mediocre, (Lincoff(1))
Rhodocollybia 'butyracea'.taste: mild or absent (Halling), mild, fungoid, or not distinctive, (Lennox), mild, pleasant, not distinctive, (Breitenbach), sweetish (Lincoff(1)), mild or slightly bitter (Miller)
Rhodocollybia 'butyracea'.odour: mild or absent (Halling), mild, fungoid, or not distinctive, (Lennox), pleasantly spicy-resinous (Breitenbach), rancid (Lincoff(1))
Rhodocollybia 'butyracea'.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in tufts "in humus under conifers (especially pine) or occasionally hardwoods", late fall, winter, and early spring, (Arora), late summer and fall, (Miller), scattered, gregarious or subcespitose [more or less in tufts] among conifer humus and needle litter, (Halling), usually gregarious in hardwood and conifer forest, on leaf and needle litter, (Breitenbach), spring, summer, fall, winter

Rhodocollybia butyracea.nameOrigin: 'butyracea' means 'pertaining to butter' (Latin), 'asema' means 'without sign', a = without (Greek), sema = sign (Greek)
Rhodocollybia butyracea.habitat: generally gregarious in hardwood and coniferous forests, on leaf and needle litter, (Breitenbach)

Rhodocollybia extuberans.spores: "cream to pale orange in thick deposit, becoming quite yellow with age"
Rhodocollybia extuberans.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on well-decayed conifer wood, in dense moist woods

Rhodocollybia maculata.spores: creamy to pale peach or pinkish buff(Arora), cream (Lennox)
Rhodocollybia maculata.edibility: no because of frequently bitter taste, (Arora)
Rhodocollybia maculata.taste: bitter (var. maculata, var. scorzonerea, var. nigra), mild to slightly farinaceous (var. occidentalis but Halling says var. occidentalis has bitter taste), mild (var. immutabilis, var. fulva), (Lennox)
Rhodocollybia maculata.odour: none or fungoid (var. maculata), mild (var. fulva), sweet, fruity (var. nigra), faint, somewhat fragrant, (var. scorzonerea), faint and sweet (var. immutabilis), faint, pleasant and aromatic or fruity (var. occidentalis), (Lennox)
Rhodocollybia maculata.habitat: scattered to gregarious on much decayed wood in dense coniferous forests, (Lennox), single, scattered or in groups or tufts "on decaying wood or lignin-rich humus under conifers", (Arora), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller), spring, summer, fall, winter, but mainly fall, (Buczacki)

Rhodocollybia oregonensis.taste: somewhat bitter, (Arora), faint and unpleasant or none (Lennox)
Rhodocollybia oregonensis.odour: heavy sweet benzaldehyde or almond extract, (Arora), strong almond or benzaldehyde, (Lennox)
Rhodocollybia oregonensis.habitat: single or in small groups "around old stumps and in lignin-rich humus", including fall, (Arora), gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] "on much decayed wood in dense woods", (Lennox)

Rhodocollybia subsulcatipes.odour: faint but heavy and aromatic (somewhat like benzaldehyde), very distinctive, (Smith)

Rhodocollybia unakensis.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] on rotten wood, summer and fall

Rhodocybe caelata.habitat: on grass, moss, lichen, or humus in coniferous or deciduous forest, occasionally wood chips

Rhodocybe hirneola.nameOrigin: means "small pitcher", diminutive of hirnea = pitcher for wine (Latin)
Rhodocybe hirneola.spores: pinkish (Baroni), moderately grayish brown when fresh becoming rosy brown upon drying (Wells and Kempton in Baroni), gray-brown (Phillips)
Rhodocybe hirneola.taste: "not distinct or slowly farinaceous to green corn" (Baroni), bitter (Buczacki)
Rhodocybe hirneola.odour: not distinct or faintly to distinctly farinaceous when flesh cut or crushed
Rhodocybe hirneola.habitat: scattered to gregarious, terrestrial on hard-packed sandy soil, on mosses including Sphagnum, under or near conifers or hardwoods, (Baroni), fall (Buczacki)

Rhodocybe nitellina.spores: "pale pinkish buff", "pinkish buff" or "light pinkish cinnamon", (Baroni), pink-ocher (Breitenbach)
Rhodocybe nitellina.taste: farinaceous (Baroni), "mild, farinaceous, with a sourish component", (Breitenbach)
Rhodocybe nitellina.habitat: single, scattered to gregarious on soil or humus in conifer or mixed woods, "July to November and through May in the Pacific Northwest of the United States", (Baroni), single to gregarious or grouped in hardwood forests, on humus or leaf litter, (Breitenbach), spring, summer, fall, winter

Rickenella fibula.habitat: single, scattered, or gregarious on beds of moss, (Smith), in moss, June to November, (Phillips, Lincoff), late spring to fall, (Bacon), spring, summer, fall

Rickenella swartzii.habitat: usually scattered to gregarious in groups of 6-12 on beds of moss or occasionally debris, spring, summer, or fall, (Smith), locally abundant in small troops or among mosses under hardwoods (Castellano)

Rimbachia arachnoidea.habitat: occasionally somewhat confluent where crowded, more often borne among or associated with mycelial strands on substrates; on moss leaves, usually on undersides or along stems, often of Mnium sensu lato and also on adjacent substrate such as soil or decayed wood, in hardwood or mixed forests

Rimbachia bryophila.habitat: on various species of moss in humid places such as ravines in coastal coniferous forests

Rimbachia neckerae.nameOrigin: means 'of Neckera' referring to habitat on Neckera curtipendula (= Antitrichia curtipendula (Hedw.) Brid., a moss that grows on trees and rocks in areas of high precipitation)
Rimbachia neckerae.spores: presumably white or whitish, but not recorded
Rimbachia neckerae.habitat: gregarious on algal fluxes and amongst mosses on soil or (according to Watling) old wood

Ripartites species^.habitat: often single; on ground in forests and on fire-sites; fruiting in fall, (Hansen, L.)

Roridomyces roridus.habitat: gregarious on needle beds under conifers and scattered on small sticks or branches of conifer wood (Smith), single or scattered to gregarious on ground and debris under conifers and in mixed woods (Arora), single to gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] among Rubus vines, ferns, and herbs, on twigs, leaves, and other plant remains lying on the ground from the previous year, principally in damp but not wet habitats, May to October, (Breitenbach for Europe), spring, summer, fall

Russula 'abietina'.spores: yellow, Crawshay E-F, (Woo), bright yellowish ochraceous (Peck), bright-yellowish-ochraceous, (Burlingham), yellow (Thiers)
Russula 'abietina'.habitat: under Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir) (Woo), under Abies balsamea (Peck), under Balsam Fir (Burlingham), in dense coniferous-hardwood forests, (Thiers)

Russula acrifolia.taste: flesh somewhat peppery, but the gills very peppery
Russula acrifolia.odour: "weak and not distinctive when fresh, but soon like herrings"
Russula acrifolia.habitat: single to gregarious "in hardwood and mixed forests", primarily near Fagus (beech), but also near Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), "on neutral to alkaline, damp soils, colline to montane", (for Switzerland)

Russula adusta.taste: mild (Shaffer), sweet (Lincoff), mild (Phillips), a bit like bread (Roberts, C.)
Russula adusta.odour: "with odor of empty wine casks (according to European authors) or not distinctive" (Shaffer), of sour wine, (Phillips), not of empty wine casks for Vancouver Island collections, but sometimes smell a bit like bread, (Roberts, C.), odor of empty wine barrels has not been noticed in Pacific Northwest specimens (Trudell)
Russula adusta.habitat: conifers (Woo), usually under conifers (Phillips), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Russula aeruginea.nameOrigin: means "copper-colored" or "copper-green rust", aerugo = the rust of copper (Latin)
Russula aeruginea.spores: deep cream, Crawshay D-E, (Woo), pale orange yellow (Shaffer), "creamy to pale yellow or pale orange-yellow" (Arora)
Russula aeruginea.taste: mild or slightly peppery when young (Woo), nondescript (Shaffer), mild or slightly hot (Rayner), mild (Arora), slightly peppery then sweet (Lincoff(1))
Russula aeruginea.habitat: conifers or deciduous woods (Woo), single or gregarious on humus in coniferous-deciduous woods, (Shaffer), birches (Rayner for Britain), single, scattered or in groups in woods, (Arora), in groups in coniferous forests, more rarely beneath aspen and birch (Lincoff(1)), late summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Russula albidigleba.taste: mild at first, finally tardily slightly acrid [slowly slightly peppery]
Russula albidigleba.habitat: type collection closely gregarious under Abies grandis (Grand Fir), July

Russula 'albidula'.spores: very pale yellow to pale yellow, (Thiers)
Russula 'albidula'.habitat: single to gregarious in conifer or conifer-hardwood forest, (Thiers), pine woods, November, (Peck)

Russula albonigra.edibility: said to be edible if thoroughly cooked, but a closely related Oriental species is poisonous, (Arora)
Russula albonigra.taste: mild (Woo), mild or slowly peppery, (Arora), odd, mild with a menthol aftertaste, (Kibby), mild or faintly peppery (Shaffer), mild, slightly peppery after a few seconds, especially in gills, in very old specimens persistently mild and very slightly bitterish in the flesh, (Singer), mild, like menthol, (Miller)
Russula albonigra.odour: indistinct (Woo), slight or none (Shaffer), fruity or none when young, eventually developing an "adusta odor" (of old wine barrels), (Singer)
Russula albonigra.habitat: mixed or deciduous woods, (Woo), scattered or in groups or troops under both hardwoods and conifers, (Arora), single to gregarious in deciduous and mixed forests, (Shaffer), on ground in woods, mostly under hardwoods, from June until fall, (Singer), summer, fall

Russula alcalinicola.habitat: holotype under greasewood, between 6700 and 6800 feet altitude

Russula alleinstanleyae.nameOrigin: "In honor of mycologist and educator Allein Stanley for her more than 40 years of dedicated service to the North American Mycological Association." (Elliott, T.F.(1))
Russula alleinstanleyae.habitat: type gregarious under Pinus contortus (Lodgepole Pine), July, (Singer)

Russula alutacea.nameOrigin: means "resembling thin leather" or "light tan", aluta = thin leather (Latin)
Russula alutacea.habitat: single to gregarious in dense conifer-hardwood forests or in oak savannahs (Thiers for California)

Russula americana.spores: Crawshay D in intensity, color near "Naples yellow", "light buff", or "cartridge-buff" (Ridgway(1) colors) (Singer), white (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Russula americana.taste: more or less rapidly intensely peppery or at least with a distinct burning aftertaste
Russula americana.habitat: under conifers such as Abies (fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), (Singer), associated with conifers, especially Larix (larch) or Picea (spruce), (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), also under Pinus contorta (Shore Pine) (R. Sieger, pers. comm.)

Russula amerorecondita.nameOrigin: 'amerorecondita' refers to the fact it is a North American species similar to the European R. recondita Melera & Ostellari, (Adamcik(3))
Russula amerorecondita.taste: slightly peppery in gills, sometimes almost mild
Russula amerorecondita.odour: at first like parmesan cheese, "then unpleasant, bleachy"
Russula amerorecondita.habitat: The collections used in the original description from 4 locations in Indiana were all from hardwood woods or hardwood forest, in July and August; some specimens "are involved in associations with mycoheterotrophic orchids" (Corallorhiza) The Vancouver collection F30154 was under oak in July

Russula atrata.habitat: gregarious in mixed forests (Quercus, Pinus), (Shaffer), single to gregarious in conifer-hardwood forests, (Thiers)

Russula atropurpurea.taste: slightly to moderately peppery (Woo), slight, peppery or nondescript taste, (Shaffer(2))
Russula atropurpurea.odour: none, or (European descriptions of R. atropurpurea) apples, (Woo), slight, nondescript (Shaffer(2))
Russula atropurpurea.habitat: deciduous or coniferous forests (Woo), single or scattered on humus in deciduous and deciduous-coniferous woods, (Shaffer(2) for eastern North America), summer and early fall (Bacon for Europe)

Russula azurea.spores: white, Crawshay A, (Woo, Rayner), white (Pilat, Thiers)
Russula azurea.odour: none (Woo following Pilat), no particular odor (Pilat), mild (Thiers)
Russula azurea.habitat: dry conifer forests or pine woods (Woo following Pilat), conifers, especially spruce, (Woo following Rayner), dry coniferous forests, particularly pine forests, June to September, (Pilat for Europe), conifers, especially spruce, (Rayner for Britain), conifers (Courtecuisse for Europe), most under oaks, one in a predominantly conifer forest, (Thiers), summer, fall

Russula basifurcata.nameOrigin: means 'forked base', probably referring to gills
Russula basifurcata.taste: mild then bitterish (Woo, Peck), mild, but may also have a somewhat bitter taste that is slow in developing, (Thiers)
Russula basifurcata.habitat: dry woods and brushy places, (Woo), dry ground in woods and bushy places, July and August, (Peck), summer

Russula benwooii.nameOrigin: after Benjamin Woo, whose carefully documented collections were the basis of molecular studies
Russula benwooii.spores: cream, in Woo collections about 60% Crawshay B-C, about 40% Crawshay D-E
Russula benwooii.taste: mild, in gills sometimes slightly peppery
Russula benwooii.habitat: associated with Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), possibly also with other conifers

Russula betularum.spores: white to faintly yellowish white, (Romagnesi 1 a-b), (Bills), 5Y, close to white as illustrated, (Breitenbach), pure white (Hora)
Russula betularum.odour: faint, rather unpleasant, (Breitenbach), mild (Bills), "faint but distinct, rather like honey" (Hora)
Russula betularum.habitat: usually gregarious "on moors or in moist coniferous forests, on acidic, nutrient-poor soils", always near Betula (birch), "colline to montane"; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), in birch woods (Hora), UNITE's collection of 175 sequences indicates it can also be with spruce or pine (D. Miller, pers. comm. August, 2022)

Russula bicolor.habitat: mixed woods, (Woo), type collected under yellow birch in Vermont, (Burlingham), particularly under birch; August to September, (Phillips), in soil or rotten wood, (Roberts, C.), summer, fall

Russula blackfordiae.spores: pale yellow, Crawshay D, (Woo), Crawshay E (Singer)
Russula blackfordiae.taste: slightly to distinctly but never strongly peppery (Singer), mild (Thiers)
Russula blackfordiae.habitat: singly or more often in groups, with or near Betula (birch), on the ground, rarely on rotten wood, summer and fall, (Singer)

Russula brevipes.nameOrigin: means "short foot", brevis = short (Latin), pes = foot (Latin)
Russula brevipes.spores: white to pale cream, Crawshay B, (Woo), white to light cream color, lighter than Crawshay B, even when colored, almost white in thin deposits, (Shaffer), white to pale buff (Arora), normally cream rather than white, although paler than R. cascadensis (D. Miller, pers. comm.)
Russula brevipes.edibility: yes, but insipid and granular, substantially improved when parasitized by Hypomyces lactifluorum, (Arora), not edible (Phillips)
Russula brevipes.taste: mild or slightly peppery (Woo), mild or slightly and tardily peppery (Peck), mild to slightly peppery (Shaffer), mild or slowly peppery, (Arora)
Russula brevipes.habitat: coniferous woods (Woo), woods and open places, July to October, (Peck), single or more often scattered or in groups or troops on ground in woods, (Arora), summer, fall

Russula brunneola.spores: white (Burlingham), white to palest cream, Crawshay A-B, (Phillips), white to yellowish white, (Shaffer), white, Crawshay A or very slightly off A, never reaching B, (Singer)
Russula brunneola.taste: mild (Burlingham, Phillips), nondescript (Shaffer), mild, sometimes nutty, (Roberts, C.)
Russula brunneola.habitat: type under spruce and yellow birch, (Burlingham), conifer and mixed woods, July to September, (Phillips), single, scattered, or gregarious on humus in hardwood, coniferous, and mixed woods, (Shaffer), summer, fall

Russula brunneoviolacea.spores: yellow, Crawshay C-E, (Woo), pale orange-yellow, Crawshay C-E, (Phillips), Crawshay C-E (Rayner), pale orange yellow, between Romagnesi IIb and IIc, (Shaffer)
Russula brunneoviolacea.odour: none (Woo, Crawshay), pleasant (Phillips), with a slight fruity odor (Shaffer)
Russula brunneoviolacea.habitat: oaks (Woo), restricted entirely to the vicinity of oak trees, (Crawshay), in mixed woods, July to September, (Phillips), under hardwoods, (Courtecuisse), deciduous trees especially oak, (Rayner), on humus in deciduous woods, (Shaffer), summer, fall

Russula cascadensis.nameOrigin: means 'from the Cascade [Mountains]' (where type was found)
Russula cascadensis.spores: pale cream-yellow, Crawshay C, (Woo), pale cream-yellow ("cartridge buff" Ridgway(1)), (Shaffer), white, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Russula cascadensis.taste: intensely peppery (Woo, Shaffer), slowly peppery (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), strongly and quickly peppery (Thiers)
Russula cascadensis.odour: slight or none (Shaffer), faint, but unpleasant when drying, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)

Russula castellanoi.nameOrigin: "In honor of Dr. Michael (Caz) Castellano for his career-long fascination with and research on sequestrate fungi" (Elliott, T.F.(1))
Russula castellanoi.habitat: found in association with roots of Abies grandis (Grand Fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) above 1000 meters elevation, July and September, (Castellano), under mixed conifers and hardwoods, September, (Singer)

Russula cerolens.nameOrigin: means 'smelling of wax' from Latin, presumably referring to the odor of dried specimens
Russula cerolens.spores: light cream-yellow, Romagnesi IIc to d, (Roberts, C.), pale yellow to yellow, (Thiers), pale orange yellow in mass [unclear whether this is a macroscopic or microscopic observation], (Shaffer)
Russula cerolens.taste: strongly peppery (Shaffer), "unpleasant, slowly peppery to acrid, especially in the gills, and with an oily, soapy component", (Roberts, C.)
Russula cerolens.odour: "disagreeable in odor, the dried specimens with a strong waxy smell noticeable even above the odor of naphthalene" [the latter presumably used to deter insects in the herbarium], (Shaffer), "strong, at first somewhat like bleach but with fresh, pleasant overtones, of ozone or cottonwoods in spring, eventually smelling strongly spermatic or of bleach, even after drying", (Roberts, C.), oily, unpleasant, spermatic, (Thiers)
Russula cerolens.habitat: gregarious on soil under conifers (Pinus, Picea), sometimes on dunes, (Shaffer), "in shrubby woodland edges" with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), September to December, (Roberts, C.), fall to early winter

Russula cessans.nameOrigin: means 'being inactive, ceasing from, delaying, resting' (Latin)
Russula cessans.spores: ocher, Crawshay G, (Woo), slightly deeper than Crawshay G, usually between G and H or reaching H, (Singer), deep ocher, Crawshay G, (Phillips), yellow (Thiers(3))
Russula cessans.taste: mild (Woo, Phillips), "mild or rarely slightly bitter-markish", (Singer)
Russula cessans.habitat: pine woods (Woo), on ground under conifers, most frequently Pinus (pine), summer and fall, (Singer)

Russula chamaeleontina.spores: yellow-orange, Crawshay G-H, (Woo), yellow to dark yellow, (Thiers), yellow-orange (Pilat)
Russula chamaeleontina.odour: fruity (Woo), mild to slightly spicy (Thiers), not marked, smelling of fruit juice when decaying, (Pilat)
Russula chamaeleontina.habitat: various woods (Woo), dry coniferous and deciduous woods, (Pilat)

Russula chlorineolens.taste: very unpleasant, somewhat chlorinaceous but not acrid [not peppery]
Russula chlorineolens.odour: of chlorine, "faint in the youngest specimens, strong in old ones and becoming objectionable"
Russula chlorineolens.habitat: found in association with roots of Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis) and western hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla) below 200m elevation, (Castellano), scattered to gregarious under spruce and hemlock, (Smith(24))

Russula claroflava.spores: yellow, Crawshay E-F, (Woo), yellowish orange, [Romagnesi] IIIa-b, (Bills), very pale creamy ocher (Lange), yellow-ocher (Arora), pale ocher, Crawshay F, (Phillips)
Russula claroflava.taste: mild or slightly peppery when young, (Woo), not distinctive (Bills), mild (Lange, Arora), mild to slightly peppery (Phillips)
Russula claroflava.habitat: under birch, (Woo), single to gregarious on soil, humus or moss, in forests, July to October, (Bills), under Betula (birch), especially on somewhat boggy or heathy ground, (Lange), scattered or in small groups in woods, mainly northern or montane in distribution and partial to birch, aspen and various conifers, summer and fall, (Arora), in wet swampy places in mixed woods (Phillips), sphagnum and Betula, also damp broadleaf woods, (Courtecuisse), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Russula crassotunicata.spores: white, Crawshay A, (Woo), white, Crawshay A, (Singer), white (Shaffer), white, Crawshay A, (Phillips)
Russula crassotunicata.taste: bitter and peppery (Woo), bitterish and slightly burning after a while in the throat, never quite mild when fresh, (Singer), slight peppery-bitter or nondescript, gills peppery, (Shaffer), peppery to burning, (Phillips), peppery, often bitter, unpleasant, (Thiers)
Russula crassotunicata.odour: faintly fungoid (Woo), of trimethylamine (Singer), Lycoperdon puffball-like or coconut-like, (Shaffer, Phillips)
Russula crassotunicata.habitat: under mixed conifers (Woo), single or gregarious on humus, usually under conifers, in hardwood-conifer woods, (Shaffer), under conifers, August to September, (Phillips), summer, fall

Russula cremoricolor.taste: peppery (Woo, Arora, Burlingham), quickly and strongly peppery, persisting, (Thiers)
Russula cremoricolor.odour: none (Woo), mild or slightly fragrant (Arora), mild (Thiers), almost none (Burlingham)
Russula cremoricolor.habitat: single, widely scattered or in groups or troops in woods, in Pacific Northwest favors conifers, (Arora), single to scattered or gregarious in conifer-hardwood forests or pure hardwood or pure conifer forests, (Thiers), on the ground in woods (Burlingham)

Russula crenulata.habitat: conifers and oaks (Woo), type under conifers and oaks (Burlingham)

Russula cuprea.spores: deep yellow, Crawshay F-G, (Woo), "cream flesh" Crawshay D, (Grund), yellow to dark yellow, (Thiers), ocher (Moser)
Russula cuprea.taste: peppery (Woo), peppery or sometimes weakly peppery, (Grund), peppery, developing only after a few seconds, (Thiers), very peppery (Courtecuisse)
Russula cuprea.habitat: deciduous trees and reported by Grund in coniferous forests, (Woo), in deciduous and coniferous forests, (Hansen), deciduous woods (Moser), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Russula 'cyanoxantha'.spores: white, (Siegel), white (Arora), white, rarely very pale yellow, (Thiers)
Russula 'cyanoxantha'.habitat: single or scattered on ground or in duff, on the Redwood Coast usually under Tanoak or live oak; late fall through winter, (Siegel), single, scattered or in groups or troops under hardwoods or sometimes conifers, (Arora), in either coniferous-hardwood forests or predominantly hardwood forests, (Thiers)

Russula decolorans.nameOrigin: means "changing colors" having to do with change when exposed to air
Russula decolorans.spores: deep cream to yellow, Crawshay E-F, (Woo), rich cream to butter color (Pilat), deep yellow, Crawshay E-F, (Phillips)
Russula decolorans.edibility: edible, but several lookalikes of unknown edibility, (Arora)
Russula decolorans.taste: mild (Woo, Phillips), mild, sometimes somewhat sharp when young, (Pilat)
Russula decolorans.habitat: conifer woods (Woo), in the moss of damp pine forests (Pilat), under conifers, August to October, (Phillips), summer, fall

Russula 'densifolia'.spores: white, Crawshay A, (Woo), white or with a faint tinge of cream color (Shaffer), white (Arora)
Russula 'densifolia'.taste: mild to somewhat peppery (always peppery in gills), (Woo), usually slightly peppery to burning peppery, sometimes mild (Shaffer), peppery (Kranzlin), mild (B. Buyck, pers. comm. via D. Miller)
Russula 'densifolia'.odour: faintly earthy (Woo), not distinctive except in forma fragrans which has "odore frangranti", (Shaffer), of orange juice when just beginning to ferment, sweetish, not of old wine barrels but variable and sometimes more unpleasant like that of Boletus satanas or even farinaceous, (Singer), faintly earthy, then slightly soapy to faintly of pickled herrings, (Pilat), faintly herring-like (Kranzlin)
Russula 'densifolia'.habitat: hardwoods, mixed or conifer woods, (Woo), single or gregarious "in small groups in deciduous, mixed, and coniferous forests", (Shaffer), single, scattered or in groups in woods, (Arora), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Russula disparilis.nameOrigin: means 'dissimilar' as Burlingham found it so different in appearance from other Russula species
Russula disparilis.spores: cream, Crawshay D-E, (Woo), ochroleucous (Burlingham), cream, Crawshay B (Grund)
Russula disparilis.odour: not distinctive (Woo, Burlingham), none or not definite, (Grund)
Russula disparilis.habitat: deciduous woods in Massachusetts, August to September, (Burlingham), in conifer woods (Grund), summer, fall

Russula dissimulans.taste: mild to slightly peppery (Woo), mild or becoming slightly or burning peppery (Shaffer)
Russula dissimulans.habitat: conifers or mixed woods (Woo), single or gregarious in coniferous and mixed forests (Shaffer)

Russula emetica.spores: white, Crawshay A, (Woo), yellowish white to almost white, never as dark as Romagnesi 1b, (Shaffer), white, Crawshay A, (Phillips)
Russula emetica.edibility: poisonous, may cause vomiting, parboiling may destroy toxins, (Arora for emetica group)
Russula emetica.odour: slightly fruity (Woo), with a Lycoperdon like odor (Shaffer), fruity (Phillips), mild (Arora for emetica group)
Russula emetica.habitat: mossy, swampy woods (Woo), single, scattered, gregarious, or rarely cespitose [in tufts], usually on Sphagnum, rarely on very rotten wood or humus, often in boggy areas of coniferous or hardwood-coniferous woods, (Shaffer), in swampy conifer woods, July to October, (Phillips), summer, fall, (Bacon)

Russula favrei.nameOrigin: after Favre who recognized the taxon as Russula xerampelina fm. "b" in Champ. Zone Subalpine 1960.
Russula favrei.spores: deep-cream to pale yellow, Romagnesi IIc, (Roberts, C.), ocher (Moser(11), German)
Russula favrei.odour: "mild, nutty, or with a slight to strong fishy odour", (Roberts, C.), sweet, fungal, in age sometimes fishy, (Moser(11) Latin), when young not herring-like, rather slightly sweetish mushroom-like, only when old developing a mild herring-like odor, and sometimes this is not noticeable, (Moser(11), German)
Russula favrei.habitat: "Sitka spruce zone, often in krummholz where there is little light and undergrowth, on sandy soils, also in old-growth coastal Douglas fir with western hemlock, again with little undergrowth"; "Sitka spruce and western hemlock are both possible hosts", (Roberts, C.), found under Pinus cembra (Swiss Pine) and Larix (larch) in subalpine woods, (Moser(1)), in subalpine conifer woods under Picea (spruce) and Pinus cembra (Swiss Pine), (Moser(11), Latin)

Russula 'firmula'.taste: somewhat peppery to peppery, especially in gills
Russula 'firmula'.habitat: usually gregarious "in coniferous and mixed forests" near Picea (spruce), "more rarely near other hardwoods, on damp alkaline to neutral, base-rich soils", summer to fall, (Kranzlin(1) for Switzerland)

Russula flava.nameOrigin: 'flava' means 'yellow'; 'pacifica' refers to the Pacific Ocean coast

Russula flaviceps.spores: yellow, Crawshay E-F, (Woo), yellow (Peck), yellow to dark yellow (Thiers), probably "ochre" (G) in deposit, but more egg yellow, (Grund)
Russula flaviceps.taste: mild to slightly peppery (Woo, Peck), fishy, slightly disagreeable, slightly bitterish when old, and perhaps slightly peppery when young, (Singer), mild (Thiers, Grund)
Russula flaviceps.odour: none, (Woo), fruity, somewhat like bananas (Singer), mild (Thiers), slightly shrimpy (Grund)
Russula flaviceps.habitat: woods (Woo, Peck), in low mixed (pine and oak) forest on ground, fruiting in summer, (Singer for eastern North America), under oak (Grund)

Russula 'foetens'.spores: pale cream, Crawshay B-D, (Woo), pale cream (Pilat), Crawshay B-D (Rayner)
Russula 'foetens'.edibility: inedible, if eaten raw causes vomiting, if cooked may cause poisoning in more sensitive people; in Russia, it is "silaged so that it loses its unpleasant taste and smell and the milk-fermented mushroom may then be used in cooking like any other edible mushroom", (Pilat)
Russula 'foetens'.taste: sharply peppery, (Woo), "usually with sharp stinging taste lasting for a long time, and repulsively sweet", "this irritates the throat and causes vomiting", the old fruiting bodies sometimes have a quite mild taste, (Pilat), of gills very peppery, but of stem center sometimes almost mild, in addition bitter or oily, (Rayner)
Russula 'foetens'.odour: strongly unpleasant oily, sweet and repulsive, nauseating, reminiscent of vomit, (Woo), unpleasant smell of sweet oil, (Pilat), strongly oily or rancid, (Rayner)
Russula 'foetens'.habitat: all kinds of woods, (Woo), "in forests of all kinds but particularly in grassy places", (Pilat for Europe), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Russula 'fragilis'.spores: white to cream, Crawshay A-B, (Woo), whitish (Arora), yellowish white, Romagnesi Ib or darker, but not as dark as IIa, (Shaffer(2)), usually yellowish white, rarely almost white (almost Ia), (Shaffer(6)), whitish to faintly yellowish (Pilat)
Russula 'fragilis'.taste: very peppery (Woo), peppery (Arora), slightly or moderately peppery, sometimes also with a radish-like component, (Shaffer(2)), slightly to strongly peppery, sometimes also with radish-like component, (Shaffer(6)), sharp stinging, (Pilat)
Russula 'fragilis'.odour: pleasant fruity, (Woo), variable (Arora), none, or more usually, of apples or coconut, or even spermatic, (Shaffer(2)), mild or more usually of apples, mint, or coconut, or even spermatic, in Europe of amyl acetate (pear-like), (Shaffer(6)), pleasant fruity (Pilat), strong, like coconut with a hint of Pelargonium [geranium], (Courtecuisse)
Russula 'fragilis'.habitat: conifer forests in moss or on decayed wood, (Woo), single, scattered, or in groups in woods, especially conifers, (Arora), single to scattered on humus or rotten wood in coniferous and mixed woods, (Shaffer(2)), in forests of all kinds, but particularly in damp and shady coniferous forests on ground, in moss and needles or on very rotten tree stumps, (Pilat), fall and winter (Buczacki)

Russula 'fragrantissima'.spores: pale orange-yellow, Crawshay C-D, (Phillips), pale orange-yellow, Romagnesi IIb or slightly lighter (Shaffer)
Russula 'fragrantissima'.taste: oily-peppery, (Phillips), tasteless or slightly peppery or oily-peppery, (Shaffer), pleasant (Miller), very unpleasant, usually bitter and pungent at first, then peppery, (Thiers)
Russula 'fragrantissima'.odour: fetid to almond-like, rarely very fragrant in North American collections, (Phillips), of benzaldehyde [almond-like] and sometimes also somewhat fetid when young, often becoming more strongly fetid and the benzaldehyde odor decreasing or disappearing with age or drying, (Shaffer), pleasant like anise, (Miller), "very strong, pleasant, of bitter almonds or of anise when young", typically becoming fetid and unpleasant when old, persisting in dried fruitbodies, (Thiers, who notes that although some Europeans report an odor of anise, this odor not detected in the California collections), strong, of maraschino cherries or cheap almond essence, developing an oily, rancid or stale component as it ages, (Roberts, C.)
Russula 'fragrantissima'.habitat: single, scattered, or gregarious on humus in deciduous, coniferous, and mixed woods, (Shaffer)

Russula fragrantissima.taste: nauseating, at least gills peppery (Arora), may be unpleasant, nauseating, oily, bitter, (Shaffer, Pilat, Rayner, Phillips)
Russula fragrantissima.odour: heavy and penetrating - "at first sweet (like maraschino cherries, almond extract, or benzaldehyde)", but when old with a nauseating (fetid) component
Russula fragrantissima.habitat: single or scattered to gregarious on ground under both hardwoods and conifers, including fall

Russula fuscoviolacea.nameOrigin: means 'fuscous violaceous', referring to the cap color
Russula fuscoviolacea.habitat: type collection single under Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), July

Russula gilva.spores: yellow ochre, Crawshay F-G, (Woo), "cream flesh" Crawshay D (Grund)
Russula gilva.habitat: beech woods (Woo), in deep conifer woods (Grund)

Russula gracilis.spores: yellowish buff, Crawshay D-E, (Woo), pale cream (Hansen), creamy to pale ocher (Arora), pale yellow to yellow (Thiers)
Russula gracilis.edibility: not edible due to peppery taste (Arora)
Russula gracilis.odour: none (Woo), without special odor (Burlingham(2)), mild, not distinctive, (Thiers)
Russula gracilis.habitat: mixed woods, (Woo), type collected among weeds in maple, spruce, and willow woods bordering a stream, (Burlingham(2)), associated with birch (Hansen), widely scattered to gregarious on ground in woods: said to grow only with birch, but similar if not identical species abundant in California with Douglas-fir, (Arora), in coniferous or conifer-hardwood forests, (Thiers)

Russula graminea.nameOrigin: "graminea" (Latin) refers to the green color of the cap, 'gramen, graminis' is Latin for 'grass'
Russula graminea.taste: mild in flesh, fairly peppery to mild in young gills, later mild
Russula graminea.habitat: grows in fairly old forests of Picea abies (Norway Spruce), "very often on slopes of hills, in paludified brooksides, in or close to Sphagnum", mid-July to mid-September,(Vauras(1) for Scandinavia, with Latin name italicized), associated with spruce in Europe but can be found with the common conifers of the Pacific Northwest like Douglas-fir and hemlock, (D. Miller, pers. comm.)

Russula granulata.spores: pale orange yellow, slightly lighter than Romagnesi IIc, (Shaffer), Crawshay D, tone almost of E but distinctly paler, considerably darker than R. foetens, (Singer)
Russula granulata.taste: cuticle spermatic-peppery or radish-peppery, flesh with a slight spermatic or peppery taste that soon fades, gills when young with moderately oily-peppery taste that may soon fade, the taste sometimes nondescript at maturity, (Shaffer), disagreeable to slightly bitter and fetid and at the same time slowly very slightly to strongly burning peppery, (Singer)
Russula granulata.odour: "slightly fetid and also having a cocoa-like component", (Shaffer), variable, sometimes only with the oily component of R. foetens, but sometimes with distinct fruity odor of its own, (Singer)
Russula granulata.habitat: single to gregarious on humus in hardwood and hardwood-coniferous forests, (Shaffer)

Russula 'grisea'.spores: cream flesh, Crawshay C-D, (Woo), dark cream (Hansen), pale yellow to yellow (Thiers)
Russula 'grisea'.taste: mild or slightly peppery (Woo), mild or very slightly peppery (Rayner)
Russula 'grisea'.habitat: with Fagus (beech) (Woo, Rayner), on soil in hardwood woodland, often with Fagus, usually in groups, +/- trooping, summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Russula 'heterophylla'.spores: white, Crawshay A, (Woo), white (Pilat), white, Crawshay A, (Phillips)
Russula 'heterophylla'.habitat: "deciduous woods but also in conifers, in clearings or at roadsides", (Woo), in deciduous woods, more rarely coniferous forests, particularly at the edge of woods or along paths, (Pilat), in deciduous woods, July to September, (Phillips), late summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Russula hunsuckeri.nameOrigin: "In honor of naturalist, mycologist, botanist, and philosopher Dr. Robert Hunsucker", (Elliott, T.F.(1))
Russula hunsuckeri.habitat: type gregarious under fir (Smith), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest in Pinaceae (Trappe)

Russula hypofragilis.nameOrigin: refers to resemblance to Russula fragilis
Russula hypofragilis.spores: white (of Ben Woo collections, 90% Crawshay A, 10% Crawshay B)
Russula hypofragilis.taste: mild mostly, to slightly peppery (especially in gills)

Russula inconstans.taste: peppery in young specimens, slowly peppery when mature
Russula inconstans.habitat: under Douglas fir on the edge of woods

Russula iodiolens.habitat: type single to gregarious, above ground to somewhat buried, under Tsuga (hemlock) and Abies (fir)

Russula laccata.habitat: single to gregarious "among dwarf willows, primarily Salix herbacea [italicized], on siliceous soils, alpine"; summer, (Kranzlin for Switzerland)

Russula 'laurocerasi'.nameOrigin: means "with the odor of bitter almonds"
Russula 'laurocerasi'.spores: Crawshay B-C, (Woo), pale egg-yellow, Crawshay C-D, (Phillips), pale orange yellow, Romagnesi IIa-c, (Shaffer)
Russula 'laurocerasi'.taste: unpleasant, rather peppery, (Phillips), cap flesh slightly to strongly nauseating-peppery, gills moderately to strongly peppery, "with slightly to strongly oily-nauseating component and rarely a bitter one", (Shaffer)
Russula 'laurocerasi'.odour: more or less marked of bitter almonds or marzipan, (Phillips), fragrant, benzaldehyde-like with a slight fetid component, (Shaffer), maraschino cherries, nitrobenzene with a fruity component, (Grund in a description he says is from R. Singer Sydowia 10: 162. 1957), a maraschino odor occurs in specimens of fragrantissima group (Arora), of bitter almonds (Miller)
Russula 'laurocerasi'.habitat: in mixed deciduous woods (Phillips), single, scattered, or gregarious on humus in deciduous and mixed woods, (Shaffer)

Russula lilacea.spores: white to pale cream, Crawshay A-B, (Woo), spores often faintly pigmented and weak spore deposits may appear white or whitish, but the spores are pale cream to pale yellow in heavy deposits, (Thiers)
Russula lilacea.taste: mild (Woo, Rayner, Lange), +/- peppery (Courtecuisse), usually mild, sometimes very slowly and weakly peppery, (Thiers)
Russula lilacea.habitat: deciduous woods, especially beech, (Woo), hornbeams (Rayner), "Mixed frondose copses and woods of Fagus" [beech], (Lange), rather damp broadleaved woods, (Courtecuisse), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Russula 'lutea'.spores: strongly yellow-orange, Crawshay G-H, (Woo), ocher, Crawshay H, (Phillips(2)), yellow to deep ocher (Bessette)
Russula 'lutea'.odour: nil to fruity (Woo), nil when young, later fruity and suggesting apricots, (Phillips(2)), not distinctive, or sweet, especially when old, (Bessette)
Russula 'lutea'.habitat: under hardwoods (Woo, Phillips(2)), single, scattered or in groups under hardwoods, July to September, (Bessette), often found where paper birch is found (Miller), summer, fall

Russula lymanensis.nameOrigin: in reference to Lyman Lake, near which the holotype was collected
Russula lymanensis.odour: strongly yeasty with a slight wine essence
Russula lymanensis.habitat: type was single to gregarious or tufted in the compacted soil of a campsite (Cazares), associated with the roots of Abies amabilis and A. lasiocarpa at 1700m elevation, (Castellano)

Russula mariae.nameOrigin: presumably after a Mary, as Peck calls it "Mary Russula"
Russula mariae.spores: pale yellow (Peck), pale yellow (Romagnesi II b-c), (Bills), creamy yellow (Arora)
Russula mariae.taste: mild or slightly and tardily peppery (Peck), mild to slightly peppery or oily (Bills), mild or slightly peppery, (Arora)
Russula mariae.odour: mild, oily, of Juniperus wood or of Lactifluus volemus, (Bills)
Russula mariae.habitat: in woods and open places (Peck), single to gregarious on soil or humus in deciduous forests or mixed deciduous-coniferous forests, (Bills), single or in groups on ground in woods, (Arora)

Russula maxima.spores: cream, Crawshay B-C, (Woo), cream-colored (Burlingham), pale yellow to cream (Thiers)
Russula maxima.odour: not special (Woo, Burlingham), mild to slightly fragrant, (Thiers)
Russula maxima.habitat: type under conifers and deciduous trees in WA, (Burlingham)

Russula 'medullata'.spores: deep cream, Romagnesi IId to IIIa
Russula 'medullata'.taste: "mild but with a very faint hint of pepperiness"
Russula 'medullata'.habitat: British Columbia collection near Pinus contorta among kinnikinnick in open coastal dunes, (Roberts, C.(2) who notes that Romagnesi said it has been found with many hardwoods as well as pines and firs)

Russula montana.spores: yellowish white (but not as dark as Romagnesi 1b) in mass
Russula montana.taste: moderately to strongly peppery (flesh, gills), slightly to moderately peppery (cap cuticle)
Russula montana.odour: none or with slight odor of apple sauce
Russula montana.habitat: single, scattered, or gregarious "on duff or very rotten wood in coniferous forests (Douglas-fir, true fir, spruce)"

Russula mordax.odour: none (Burlingham, Phillips), mild (Thiers), often with a floral odor (D. Miller, pers. comm.)
Russula mordax.habitat: type under Douglas-fir in Seattle WA (Burlingham), under fir, September to November, (Phillips), fall

Russula murina.taste: mild then slowly slightly peppery, decidedly so in young specimens
Russula murina.habitat: in dirt and needle duff under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Pinus contortus (lodgepole pine)

Russula murrillii.nameOrigin: after William Alphonso Murrill 1869-1957, agaricologist with New York Botanical Garden, editor of Mycologia, who collected the type
Russula murrillii.spores: pale yellow, Crawshay D-E, (Woo), pale yellow (Burlingham), in the deepest prints between Crawshay D and E, (Singer(8))
Russula murrillii.habitat: type collected in fir forests with scattered oak, birch, willow and maple, (Woo, Burlingham), in groups on the ground in coniferous woods (under Pseudotsuga, Tsuga mertensiana, Chamaecyparis nootletensis [sic, probably nootkatensis], etc.), (Singer(8))

Russula mustelina.habitat: scattered to gregarious at higher elevations, usually associated with Abies (true fir), (Thiers(3) for California), BC collection under Douglas-fir in highland area near Victoria (Roberts, C.(2)), conifer woods at about 3000 feet (Grund)

Russula nancyweberae.nameOrigin: "In honor of Dr. Nancy Weber, for her extensive research on taxonomy of epigeous Ascomycetes, especially the genus Morchella", (Elliott, T.F.(1) with Morchella italicized)

Russula nigricans.taste: "mild or sometimes slightly peppery when young" (Woo), slightly peppery or mild, (Shaffer), slowly peppery (Phillips), usually mild, but when young may sometimes be slightly peppery or astringent, (Pilat), mild to somewhat peppery (Kranzlin)
Russula nigricans.odour: earthy (Woo), none or slightly sweetish, (Shaffer), fruity, (Phillips), rank especially when aging (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), unpleasant earthy (Pilat), faintly unpleasant (Kranzlin)
Russula nigricans.habitat: coniferous or deciduous woods (Woo), single to gregarious in deciduous and coniferous forests, (Shaffer), summer, fall, occasionally spring (Buczacki)

Russula obscurozelleri.nameOrigin: refers to its similarity to Russula zelleri
Russula obscurozelleri.spores: cream to dark cream (of Woo specimens about 15% Crawshay A-C, about 85% Crawshay D-F)
Russula obscurozelleri.habitat: recorded with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole pine).

Russula occidentalis.spores: cream, Crawshay B, (Woo), varying from intensity of D and tone quality of between C and E to between E and F (nearer to E), (Singer), cream, Crawshay B, (Phillips)
Russula occidentalis.odour: none to faintly fruity (Woo), weak (Singer), none (Phillips)
Russula occidentalis.habitat: under Douglas fir, western hemlock, (Woo), on the ground, on needles, under Larix (larch), Pinus (pine), and Tsuga (hemlock) in mixed woods, August through October, (Singer), under fir and hemlock (Phillips), summer, fall

Russula odorifera.odour: of fresh specimens strongly of ethyl acetate (fragrant), (Smith), strong of ethyl acetate (Singer)
Russula odorifera.habitat: on humus under conifers and hardwoods, July, (Singer)

Russula olida.odour: aromatic, of cherry pits, reminding one of Russula laurocerasi

Russula 'olivacea'.spores: egg yellow, Crawshay G-H, (Woo), egg-yellow (Pilat), deep yellow-orange, Crawshay G-H, (Phillips)
Russula 'olivacea'.edibility: yes, good, (Phillips), numerous reports indicate that this species is at least mildly toxic, (Thiers)
Russula 'olivacea'.taste: mild, nutty, (Woo), mild, pleasant, of hazelnut, (Pilat), mild, nutty, (Phillips)
Russula 'olivacea'.odour: faintly fruity, (Woo), weak, of fruit, (Pilat), pleasant (Phillips)
Russula 'olivacea'.habitat: under conifers (Woo), in deciduous and coniferous woods, June to September, (Pilat for Europe), under beech, July to August, (Phillips), summer, fall

Russula 'olivina'.odour: indistinct, when old as in Russula lutea
Russula 'olivina'.habitat: in rich forests with Picea abies, mostly in moist sites, especially calcareous, hemiboreal to northern boreal zone, July to September (for Sweden and Finland)

Russula pallescens.spores: white, Crawshay A, (Woo for R. farinipes),

Russula parapallens.nameOrigin: "refers to the sometimes pale colour of the cap"
Russula parapallens.spores: white (of Woo specimens, 90% Crawshay A, about 10% Crawshay B-C)

Russula parazurea.nameOrigin: means "almost sky-blue", or more probably 'near [Russula] azurea'
Russula parazurea.spores: cream-yellow, Crawshay C-D, (Woo), cream-yellowish (Lange), pale yellow to cream (Thiers)
Russula parazurea.taste: mild or very slightly peppery, (Woo following Rayner), tasteless (Lange), mild to weakly peppery (Thiers)
Russula parazurea.habitat: deciduous woods (Lange, Woo following Rayner); in deciduous and coniferous forests, (Hansen), gregarious in conifer-hardwood or conifer forests, (Thiers), on soil in hardwood woodland, most frequently with Fagus, Quercus (oak), or Tilia (lime), usually in groups, +/- trooping, summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Russula parksii.nameOrigin: after Harold E. Parks, who collected many hypogeous fungi in California
Russula parksii.habitat: type in California in heavy clay soil under Quercus (oak)

Russula 'pectinata'.spores: white to pale cream, Crawshay C-D, (Woo), between Crawshay B and C (Singer)
Russula 'pectinata'.taste: hot, (Woo), slightly to strongly peppery, with a more or less developed disagreeable by-taste, (Singer)
Russula 'pectinata'.odour: unpleasant like coal gas, (Woo), very variable in old specimens (smoked herring, camembert cheese, spermatic, but in younger specimens almost invariably pleasantly like Russula mariae or Lactifluus volemus), (Singer)
Russula 'pectinata'.habitat: "road edges, open woods, park areas", (Woo), on the ground, preferring conifers and Fagales, also on watered lawns under trees, (Singer)

Russula pectinatoides.spores: cream to pale yellow, Crawshay B-D, (Woo), whitish (Peck), pale orange yellow, Romagnesi IIc to IID, (Shaffer), Crawshay C (Singer), cream, Crawshay D-E, (Phillips), pale yellow to yellow (Thiers)
Russula pectinatoides.taste: mild (Woo), mild or slightly and tardily peppery, (Peck), slightly spermatic or waxy and sometimes also faintly peppery in flesh, faintly spermatic or spermatic-peppery in cap skin, gills having both spermatic to waxy and peppery components, always at least slightly peppery and may be more strongly so, (Shaffer), mild or slightly peppery (Phillips), "nauseeuse de caoutchouc, recouvrant un fond fruite plus ou moins distinct" - fruity with nauseating rubber component, (Romagnesi for Europe), slightly oily or fetid (Phillips), mild at first and slightly sweet, finally peppery to acrid and leaving a soapy, oily aftertaste, (Roberts, C.), mild but disagreeable, more rarely with a slight bitterish taste, and very rarely very slightly and tardily acrid as an after-taste, (Singer)
Russula pectinatoides.odour: pleasant, fruity, (Woo), "slight to moderate, spermatic, waxy, or fetid", (Shaffer), slightly oily or fetid (Phillips), fishy with rubbery or almond and rancid components, (Roberts, C.(2)), rather variable especially in old specimens, usually of fresh fish or cod-liver oil, but usually rather weakly so, (Singer)
Russula pectinatoides.habitat: open areas in woods (Woo), grassy ground in groves and woods, (Peck), single, scattered, or gregarious on soil or rarely on rotten wood in deciduous and deciduous-coniferous forests, (Shaffer), in mixed hardwoods, July to September, (Phillips), summer, fall

Russula 'pelargonia'.spores: cream, Crawshay A-B, (Woo), Crawshay A-B, (Rayner), cream, Crawshay B (Grund), almost C (Moser)
Russula 'pelargonia'.odour: crushed geraniums (Pelargonium), (Woo, Grund), suggestive of Pelargonium zonale, (Rayner), strong, like Pelargonium, (Courtecuisse), rather strong of geraniums, but it is sometimes necessary to crush the flesh to detect the odor, (Thiers), stewed apples (Moser), "faint, sweet, fruity, cloves, cooked apples", supposedly Pelargonium although the odor not unique to this species, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)
Russula 'pelargonia'.habitat: Douglas fir and hemlock woods, (Woo), under various deciduous trees (Rayner), under Douglas fir and hemlock (Grund), deciduous trees, especially Populus, (Courtecuisse for Europe), with poplars, limes and other deciduous trees (Moser for Europe), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Russula phoenicea.nameOrigin: "phoenix-like, a reference to its pleasing colouration"
Russula phoenicea.spores: very pale (in Woo collections, Crawshay A about 75%, Crawshay B-C about 25%)
Russula phoenicea.taste: mild most often, to faintly peppery, in gills and flesh
Russula phoenicea.habitat: associated consistently with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) with other conifers sometimes mixed in

Russula piniamans.habitat: type gregarious under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine)

Russula placita.spores: light yellow, Crawshay D-E, (Woo), ochroleucous tone 1-2, (Burlingham), pale yellow to yellow (Thiers)
Russula placita.odour: none (Woo), no special odor (Burlingham), mild to pungent, not distinctive, (Thiers)
Russula placita.habitat: under Douglas fir, sometimes pine, (Woo, Burlingham), single to scattered on ground in conifer or conifer-hardwood forest, (Thiers)

Russula postiana.spores: orange ("80 Y 40 M") (Kranzlin), yellow (Hansen, L.), Romagnesi 4d-e (Ruotsalainen)
Russula postiana.odour: faint and not distinctive, (Kranzlin), smell of iodine at the stem base, (Ruotsalainen)
Russula postiana.habitat: single, more rarely gregarious in conifer and mixed forests, primarily near Picea (spruce), "sometimes colline, but preferentially montane", summer to fall

Russula pseudopelargonia.nameOrigin: from its prior confusion with Russula pelargonia
Russula pseudopelargonia.spores: cream (of Woo collections, about 25% Crawshay A and about 75% Crawshay B-C)
Russula pseudopelargonia.taste: medium to very peppery in gills and flesh
Russula pseudopelargonia.odour: fruity or more often reminiscent of Pelargonium (geranium)
Russula pseudopelargonia.habitat: consistently associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), or Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), often mixed with other trees

Russula pseudotsugarum.nameOrigin: refers to its presumed association with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)
Russula pseudotsugarum.spores: cream to yellow (about 25% Crawshay D-E, about 75% Crawshay F-G)
Russula pseudotsugarum.habitat: Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) was present at every collection site, but other conifers usually present as well

Russula 'puellaris'.spores: yellow to ocher, (Siegel), "yellow to pale ochraceous in deposit", (Thiers), light buff-cream, Romagnesi IIa-c, (Roberts, C.)
Russula 'puellaris'.odour: indistinct (Siegel), mild, not distinctive, (Thiers), "slightly fruity, sometimes none", (Roberts, C.)
Russula 'puellaris'.habitat: occasionally single, "more often scattered in troops on ground, in duff or moss under conifers", especially Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) and Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), fall and early winter, (Siegel(2) for California), single to gregarious "often along trails in dense conifer-hardwood forests", (Thiers for California), single or in small groups on sandy soils under Picea sitchensis, May through October, (Roberts, C.)

Russula punicea.taste: quickly and strongly peppery, "leaving a lingering peppery, burning sensation in mouth", (Siegel), strongly peppery (Thiers)
Russula punicea.habitat: single or scattered "on ground, in duff or moss in coniferous forests", especially under Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), fall, (Siegel), gregarious in soil and mosses under Picea sitchensis (Thiers)

Russula 'queletii'.nameOrigin: presumably after Lucien Quelet, 1832-99, first President of Societe Mycologique de France
Russula 'queletii'.spores: cream to light yellow, Crawshay C-E, (Woo), cream to pale yellow (Thiers)
Russula 'queletii'.taste: very peppery (Woo), peppery (Burlingham), fairly peppery (Courtecuisse), peppery, sometimes only moderately so, (Thiers)
Russula 'queletii'.odour: pleasant (Woo), not distinctive (Burlingham), of gooseberry compote (Hansen), strongly of apple (Courtecuisse), mild to fruity (Thiers)
Russula 'queletii'.habitat: conifers (Woo), in spruce or pine woods (Burlingham), associated with Picea (spruce), rarely other conifers, on rich soil, (Hansen), especially spruce woods, (Moser), spruce, more often on neutral to calcareous soils (Courtecuisse), single to gregarious on soil, usually under Pinus (pine) but occasionally under other conifers, especially Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Thiers), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Russula raoultii.spores: yellowish white in mass, (Shaffer), white (Thiers), white (A) (Phillips)
Russula raoultii.taste: moderately to strongly peppery, (Shaffer), peppery (Thiers, Phillips)
Russula raoultii.habitat: single or scattered on very humus or very rotten wood in hardwood and hardwood-coniferous woods, (Shaffer), single to scattered or gregarious in coniferous, hardwood, and coniferous-hardwood forests, (Thiers), in deciduous woods, August to September, (Phillips), summer, fall

Russula rhodocephala.nameOrigin: means "refers to the red colour of the cap" (Hyde)
Russula rhodocephala.spores: yellowish (of Woo collections, about 40% Crawshay B-C, about 60% D-E), (Hyde), deep cream, Crawshay D-F, (Woo), pale yellow (Arora)
Russula rhodocephala.taste: very peppery in gills and flesh (Hyde), quickly peppery (Woo), very peppery (Arora)
Russula rhodocephala.odour: "none or weakly pleasant" (Hyde), none, but some collections have a distinct fruity or geranium odor, (Woo), mild (Arora)
Russula rhodocephala.habitat: associated with Pinus contorta (Lodgepole pine), (Hyde), conifer woods, (Woo), scattered or in large troops under conifers, especially Pinus (pine), (Arora)

Russula salishensis.spores: pale cream (of Woo collections, about 25% Crawshay B, about 35% Crawshay C-D, and about 40% Crawshay E)
Russula salishensis.taste: slightly peppery to mild in flesh, usually very peppery in gills
Russula salishensis.habitat: "probably associates with both" Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), found up to 1200 m altitude

Russula sapinea.spores: to the border between ocher and yellow, Romagnesi IIIc or IVa
Russula sapinea.taste: always sweet even in immature gills
Russula sapinea.odour: none, sometimes vaguely fruity to unpleasant
Russula sapinea.habitat: Four collections by Ben Woo were associated with Douglas-fir/hemlock, Douglas fir/true fir, spruce/pine, and spruce, (D. Miller, pers. comm., using information that includes Bazzicalupo(2)), in the mountain forests of Picea in subalpine areas, at relatively high altitudes, growing in dry soils that are sometimes a little mossy, or on needle beds, (Sarnari for Europe)

Russula sardonia.spores: pale ocher (Hansen), light ocher, Crawshay E-F, (Moser for group in key), cream-yellow, Crawshay E-F, (Phillips)
Russula sardonia.habitat: under pine (Hansen, Courtecuisse, Phillips), summer and early fall (Bacon)

Russula sierrensis.habitat: holotype gregarious to scattered in soil in oak-pine woodlands

Russula silvicola.spores: yellowish white to white (Romagnesi 1a or more yellowish but never as dark as Romagnesi 1b)
Russula silvicola.habitat: single, scattered, gregarious, or almost cespitose [in tufts], usually on humus or rotten wood, rarely on Sphagnum, in coniferous or hardwood forests, [including fall]

Russula smithii.nameOrigin: after A.H. Smith who collected the type
Russula smithii.habitat: under Douglas fir in the Olympic Mountains of Washington, (Woo, Singer), single to scattered or gregarious, conifer-hardwood forests or predominantly coniferous forests, (Thiers)

Russula sororia.spores: creamy to pale yellow (Arora), pale yellow to yellow (Thiers for R. cerolens)
Russula sororia.taste: mild or slightly peppery, gills slowly but distinctly peppery (Arora), peppery (Thiers for R. cerolens), slowly peppery & soapy (C. Roberts for R. cerolens sensu Shaffer 1972), slowly acrid (C. Roberts for R. amoenolens sensu Romagnesi 1976), slowly strongly acrid, oily, (C. Roberts for R. sororia sensu Romagnesi 1976), spermatic, waxy, mildish to faintly acrid, (C. Roberts for R. pectinatoides sensu Shaffer 1972), acrid, sometimes slowly, (C. Roberts for R. pectinata sensu Singer 1957)
Russula sororia.odour: unpleasant (rancid or spermatic), (Arora), oily, unpleasant, spermatic, (Thiers for R. cerolens, but under R. pectinatoides he says the odor of R. cerolens is usually non-distinctive or faint), waxy when dried (Shaffer(8) for R. cerolens), strong, at first somewhat like bleach but with fresh, pleasant overtones, of ozone or cottonwoods in spring, eventually smelling strongly spermatic or of bleach, even after drying, (C. Roberts for R. cerolens sensu Shaffer 1972), Jerusalem artichokes, Camembert, spermatic, (C. Roberts for R. amoenolens sensu Romagnesi 1967), spermatic, like R. amoenolens but weaker, fruity, (C. Roberts for R. sororia sensu Romagnesi 1967), spermatic-waxy with fruity, fishy or rubber component, (C. Roberts for R. pectinatoides sensu Shaffer 1972), smoked herring, spermatic, camembert or pleasant, of Jerusalem artichokes when young, (C. Roberts for R. pectinata sensu Singer 1957)
Russula sororia.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious in woods or at their edges, on lawns under trees, etc., (Arora), R. cerolens most frequently found under conifers, but also in conifer-hardwood forests, (Thiers for CA)

Russula sphagnophila.spores: cream, Crawshay D-E, (Woo), cream (Kauffman), Crawshay (D-)E when fresh, in herbarium reaching tone between E and G, (Singer(8))
Russula sphagnophila.habitat: on sphagnum in swamp (Woo), scattered, on sphagnum in swamps, (Kauffman), among Sphagnum and on forest humus, in the first case often in pure coniferous woods, in the latter (more commonly) near Betula (birch), (Singer(8)), Sitka spruce - Western Hemlock forest (Roberts, C.)

Russula stricklandiorum.nameOrigin: "in honor of Bob and Babs Strickland for their support of the natural sciences and contributions to conservation" (Elliott, T.F.(1))
Russula stricklandiorum.taste: like raw potatoes (Phillips), slowly but distinctly acrid [peppery], (Smith), acrid (Arora), mild, (Trappe, M.(3))
Russula stricklandiorum.habitat: "just under or on the surface of ground under conifers", September to October, (Phillips), under Tsuga (hemlock) and Picea (spruce), (Smith), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga, Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), year-round, (Trappe, M.(3))

Russula stuntzii.nameOrigin: after Professor Daniel Stuntz of the University of Washington
Russula stuntzii.spores: white, Crawshay A, (Grund), white to pale yellow (Thiers), pale buff (Roberts, C.)
Russula stuntzii.taste: strongly peppery, (Grund), peppery to strongly peppery, (Thiers)
Russula stuntzii.habitat: single, in coniferous forests, typically under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Grund), usually single, rarely scattered or gregarious in coniferous-hardwood forests, the only Russula species in California that often grows on well-rotted conifer logs, (Thiers), on conifer logs that have brown cubical rot and become friable, (Roberts, C.)

Russula subloculata.edibility: said to be edible, but be sure of identification, (Arora)
Russula subloculata.habitat: single to gregarious or clustered "in duff under conifers (sometimes buried)", especially under Picea (spruce), Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Pinus (pine), mainly in summer and fall, (Arora), July to November (Lincoff), underground to above ground on and in deep conifer duff, often in large groups, near and under stands of Abies, Picea, and Pseudotsuga, July to August in Idaho, (Singer)

Russula subolivacea.nameOrigin: refers to the subolivaceous color of the mature cap
Russula subolivacea.habitat: type gregarious under spruce, (Smith(24)), under pines and firs in CA, (Thiers(4))

Russula subrosacea.nameOrigin: refers to the subrosaceous (somewhat rose-colored) cap
Russula subrosacea.habitat: single to scattered under spruce and fir (Smith), under lodgepole pine in CA, (Thiers(4))

Russula torulosa.spores: pale ocher (Hansen), cream straw, Crawshay C, (Grund)
Russula torulosa.taste: peppery but less so than R. queletii (Moser), peppery (Courtecuisse, Grund)
Russula torulosa.odour: fruity (Hansen), strongly of raw apple, (Courtecuisse), fungoid (Grund)
Russula torulosa.habitat: associated with Pinus (pine), rarely Picea (spruce), on sandy soil, (Hansen for Europe), especially under pines, on chalk, (Moser), under Pinus (Courtecuisse), single specimen in deep conifer woods of Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Grund), late summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Russula 'turci'.spores: deep eggyolk yellow, Crawshay F, (Woo), Crawshay G (Rayner), deep ocher to pale yellow, (Hansen), deep yellow-orange, Crawshay G, (Phillips)
Russula 'turci'.odour: without odor, or of iodoform at base of stem, (Woo), of iodoform at stem base (Rayner), stem base often with strong odor of iodoform when collected (Hansen), stem smelling of iodoform (Moser), of ink or iodine at stem base when scratched, (Phillips)
Russula 'turci'.habitat: under conifers (Woo, Rayner, Phillips); in coniferous forests, especially with Pinus (pine), (Hansen), coniferous woods (spruces, pines), (Moser), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Russula velenovskyi.habitat: single to gregarious in beech forests, according to literature also in other types of forest, near Betula (birch), Picea (spruce), and Larix (larch), summer to fall, (Kranzlin(1) for Switzerland)

Russula versicolor.spores: light yellow ocher, Crawshay D-E, (Woo), light ochery yellow, (Lange), dark cream to pale ocher (Hansen), medium yellow, Crawshay E-F, (Phillips)
Russula versicolor.taste: flesh mild, gills somewhat peppery, (Woo), vapid [insipid], the gills slightly peppery after chewing, (Lange), +/- peppery, at least of gills, (Hansen), mild to rather peppery, (Phillips), strongly peppery (Thiers)
Russula versicolor.odour: indistinct (Woo), pleasant, (Phillips), mild or according to Romagnesi slightly fruity, (Thiers)
Russula versicolor.habitat: birches (Woo), always under Betula (birch), in boggy places or on drier ground, (Lange), associated with Betula, (Hansen), under birches, (Moser), in wet, boggy areas, August to November, (Phillips), summer, fall

Russula vesca.spores: white, Crawshay A, (Woo, Phillips), "white with a faint yellowish tinge (not even as dark as Romagnesi 1b)", (Shaffer)
Russula vesca.taste: mild, pleasantly nutty, (Woo), none or slight nondescript (Shaffer), mild, nutty, (Phillips), nutty (Courtecuisse)
Russula vesca.odour: none to faintly fishy when old (Woo), slight nondescript (Shaffer), not distinctive (Phillips)
Russula vesca.habitat: deciduous woods (Woo), single or scattered "on humus in deciduous and deciduous-coniferous woods", (Shaffer), under hardwoods, July to September, (Phillips), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Russula veternosa.spores: orange ocher, Crawshay G-H, (Woo), yellowish buff (Burlingham), G-H (Rayner), yellow to dark yellow, (Thiers)
Russula veternosa.taste: peppery (Woo, Burlingham), slightly to moderately peppery (Rayner), peppery (slightly to moderately peppery according to Kibby and Fatto), (Thiers)
Russula veternosa.odour: honey or gingerbread, but Pacific Northwest specimens under conifers generally without distinctive odor, (Woo), suggestive of honey or gingerbread, (Rayner for Britain), "usually of honey, sometimes weakly so", (Thiers), slightly fruity and faintly of ginger biscuits, (Roberts, C.)
Russula veternosa.habitat: under beeches, in Pacific Northwest found under conifers (Woo), oak, beech and maple woods, (Burlingham), beeches (Rayner for Britain), conifer-hardwood forest or hardwood forest, (Thiers), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Russula vilgalysii.nameOrigin: "In honor of Dr. Rytas Vilgalys for his research and teaching of all aspects of mycology." (Elliott, T.F.(1))
Russula vilgalysii.habitat: under Picea (spruce) and Abies (fir), summer, (Smith(4)), under Picea and Abies, August, (Singer)

Russula 'vinososordida'.habitat: often but not always associated with Betula (birch)

Russula violacea.spores: cream to yellow, Crawshay B-D, (Woo), Crawshay B-D (Rayner), almost Crawshay C (Moser), white, Crawshay A, (Grund), white to pale cream (Courtecuisse, but illustrated as cream)
Russula violacea.odour: of menthol and geranium (Woo), geranium (Hansen), suggesting menthol and Pelargonium (geranium), (Rayner), stewed apples (Moser), strong like apple, Pelargonium, (Courtecuisse)
Russula violacea.habitat: moist deciduous woods (Woo, Rayner for Britain), in moist deciduous forests with Quercus, Betula, and Carpinus, (Hansen for Europe), deciduous woods (birches, poplar, hornbeams, etc.), (Moser for Europe), under broadleaved trees (Courtecuisse for Europe)

Russula 'virescens'.spores: white, Crawshay A-B, (Phillips), "yellowish white (Romagnesi Ib to almost IIa)", (Shaffer), "white or with a faint yellow tinge", (Arora)
Russula 'virescens'.taste: almost tasteless, gill slightly farinaceous or nondescript, (Shaffer), mild (Arora), mild, nutty, (Phillips)
Russula 'virescens'.odour: odorless or nearly so (Shaffer), mild (Arora), pleasant (Phillips)
Russula 'virescens'.habitat: single, scattered, or gregarious on soil and humus in deciduous woods, (Shaffer), single to widely scattered or in groups under hardwoods, especially oak and beech, in Montana under birch, (Arora), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Russula viridofusca.habitat: single under conifers especially under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Grund), under hemlock, September to October, (Phillips), fall

Russula 'viscida'.spores: pale cream, Crawshay B-C, (Woo), pale, the color of white flour with an insignificant butter tint, (Pilat), pale yellow (Thiers)
Russula 'viscida'.taste: mild peppery (Woo), young specimens, particularly the gills, usually have a sharp to peppery taste, "although the sharpness soon disappears", otherwise usually with a mild taste, especially in lower stem, (Pilat), almost mild to moderately peppery, (Hansen), somewhat peppery (Courtecuisse), slowly and mildly peppery (Thiers), mild (Roberts, C.)
Russula 'viscida'.odour: not distinctive (Woo), in older specimens slight but insignificant (Pilat), "complex, fruity acid", (Courtecuisse), mild, not distinctive (Thiers), mild, slightly fruity or nutty, (Roberts, C.)
Russula 'viscida'.habitat: old spruce or fir woods (Woo) old spruce and particularly fir woods, summer and fall, (Pilat for Europe), in coniferous and deciduous forests on rich soil, (Hansen for Europe), conifers, especially spruce, (Courtecuisse for Europe), gregarious to scattered in soil under conifers or in conifer-hardwood forests, (Thiers)

Russula 'xerampelina'.nameOrigin: xerampelina means "color of dried vine leaves"
Russula 'xerampelina'.spores: pale yellow, Crawshay D-F, (Woo), yellowish (Arora), deep yellow, Crawshay E-F, (Phillips)
Russula 'xerampelina'.edibility: edible and good (Arora), smells fishy while cooking but does not taste fishy; avoid eating if you are not sure of identification - among other characters, an edible R. 'xerampelina' should have purplish cap, rosy blush to stem, cream gills (not white), bruising brown when handled, and fishy odor before cooking
Russula 'xerampelina'.odour: "none when young and fresh, becoming distinctly fishy or like crabshells in older specimens or after mushrooms have been collected and stored for a short time", (Woo), mild becoming shrimpy or crab-like when old, (Arora), of fish, crabs, or shrimp, distinctive but not detected by everyone, often strong and persistent in dried specimens, (Thiers)
Russula 'xerampelina'.habitat: coniferous or mixed woods, (Woo), single to gregarious under conifers, (Arora), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Russula zelleriana.nameOrigin: referring to Zeller who identified the type incorrectly as Elasmomyces mattirolanus

Sagaranella tylicolor.habitat: single to gregarious, in hardwood forests or mixed hardwood-conifer forests, on leaves or needles on ground, summer to fall, (Breitenbach), gregarious or in rings, "on humus, on mosses, in needle beds, on decaying mushrooms, pastures, fertilized forests", (Hansen for Europe), deciduous and coniferous forest, (Moser for Europe), on human feces, on decaying eagle carcass, (Redhead(4)), may be found on rotting mushrooms or rotting flesh or human feces (Paul Kroeger, pers. comm.)

Sarcomyxa serotina.edibility: yes, mediocre and sometimes bitter as it ages, (Arora), no (Phillips), edible but rather tough, must be cooked a long time over low heat, (Bessette), stomach upset recorded (Brown)
Sarcomyxa serotina.taste: not distinctive or bitter (Bessette), "mild, somewhat bitter after being chewed for a rather long time", (Breitenbach)
Sarcomyxa serotina.habitat: scattered or in shelving groups "on dead hardwood logs and branches (especially wild cherry), sometimes also on conifers", fall and winter, usually appearing late in season, (Arora), single to clustered or imbricate on dead or living wood or hardwoods, (Breitenbach), often found on alders in December and January (Sept)

Schizophyllum commune.edibility: too small and tough to be of value, but some natives of Madagascar sometimes chew them, (Arora)
Schizophyllum commune.taste: pleasant (Phillips), sourish, like Heterobasidion annosum, mild, (Breitenbach)
Schizophyllum commune.odour: pleasant (Phillips), sourish, like Heterobasidion annosum, mild, (Breitenbach)
Schizophyllum commune.habitat: scattered "or in groups, rows, or fused clusters on hardwood sticks, stumps, logs, etc.", (Arora), on wood of a broad range of species, (Ginns(4)), spring, summer, fall, and even warm spells in winter, (Miller)

Setchelliogaster tenuipes.habitat: gregarious in soil, under or near Eucalyptus (Cupressus or Quercus often present), (Smith), subhypogeous [almost underground] on earth and humus under Eucalyptus globulus, Quercus sp. etc., in California during the rainy season (November until April), in Oregon also in June, (Singer)

Simocybe species^.habitat: on wood, sawdust, leaves and other plant debris; not ectomycorrhizal

Sphagnurus paluster.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious on Sphagnum in bogs, spring and summer, (Smith), on Sphagnum "usually in quaking bogs, in very damp places" (Moser), single to grouped, in moors and ditches, in damp areas among Sphagnum, sometimes growing on moss, (Breitenbach), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Spodocybe trulliformis.habitat: "scattered or in groups on leaf litter or debris" under conifers or hardwoods, (Phillips), scattered or gregarious on humus under conifers or hardwoods, "May to October, but chiefly in July and August", (Bigelow), spring, summer, fall

Stagnicola perplexa.nameOrigin: means 'intricate', assigned by Orton to species as Phaeocollybia with unusual microscopic characters
Stagnicola perplexa.spores: earthy brown between "avellaneous" and "deep olive buff" (milky-coffee or pale hazel according to Orton)
Stagnicola perplexa.habitat: gregarious "on rotting plant remains (needles, leaves, twigs, bits of wood) in bogs, ditches and in drying temporary pools in coniferous forests"
