Strobilurus albipilatus.habitat: on senescent often buried cones of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Pinus spp. (pine), wood of Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch), "and unidentified woody debris including stumps and masses of buried cone scales husked by rodents", (Redhead(1)), in scattered groups on litter, usually at high elevation, often in the spring near melting snow, (Trudell), scattered to gregarious among debris and dead logs of Abies (fir) and Pinus (pine), very rarely on cones of Pinus spp., in high elevation conifer forest, June, September-November, (Desjardin(1) for California), spring, fall

Strobilurus occidentalis.odour: not distinctive (Desjardin), none or slightly of radish (Lennox)
Strobilurus occidentalis.habitat: on "buried or exposed senescent cones or cone scales" of Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce); "in coastal flood plains, boreal forest, or subalpine forest, sometimes near melting snow banks", (Redhead(1)), scattered to gregarious on senescent cones of Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), in mixed coniferous woods, October to December, (Desjardin for coastal northern California), on old cones (sometimes buried), cone bracts, and needles of pine, spruce, and Douglas fir, leaf stems of poplar, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), in dense conifer woods, on buried wood or cones of Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce) and Picea glauca (White Spruce), mostly 1 but sometimes 2-3 fruitbodies per cone, early spring or late fall, (Lennox), spring, fall, winter

Strobilurus trullisatus.habitat: in colonies on old Douglas-fir cones or rarely cones of other conifers (Arora), on senescent often buried cones of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) or rarely Pinus spp. (pine), (Redhead(1)), scattered to densely gregarious on senescent cones of Pseudotsuga menziesii, rarely Pinus spp., August to January, (Desjardin(1)), summer, fall, winter

Strobilurus wyomingensis.habitat: cespitose on rotten wood, spruce and fir, altitude 10,000 feet, June 21, 1938

Stropharia aeruginosa.spores: dark purple-brown to purple-black (Arora) dark vinaceous purple-brown to purple-black (Stamets), brown-violet (Breitenbach), gray to chocolate-brown or blackish brown
Stropharia aeruginosa.edibility: sometimes reported as poisonous, in Europe thought to be edible, (Arora), activity suspected but not known, one analysis showed no psilocybin or psilocin, edibility is questioned, (Stamets)
Stropharia aeruginosa.taste: not distinctive (Phillips), indistinct or with a slightly bitter aftertaste, (Noordeloos)
Stropharia aeruginosa.habitat: single or in small groups" in rich soil, humus, woody debris, or grass, (Arora), "on wood debris, in gardens, parks, and occasionally along grassy areas at the edge of woodlands", in Pacific Northwest under conifers, and in the Southwest under aspen, (Stamets), usually gregarious but also single, "in forests and parks, at forest edges, on decomposing plant remains and buried wood, late summer to fall, (Breitenbach), single or in small groups "in rich soil, humus, wood debris, or grass, in woodland", (Phillips), woods, wood edges, parkland, (Courtecuisse), usually fall, also spring and summer, (Buczacki)

Stropharia albivelata.habitat: single to scattered on debris, under conifers, fall

Stropharia albonitens.habitat: grassy meadows, July to November (Phillips), in tufts of Deschampsia caespitosa and other grasses in pastures and open places in forests, (Hansen for Europe), single or grouped "in meadows and pastures, in grassy places near shrubs", especially under Alnus [alder], summer to fall, (Breitenbach), in "mixed woods with conifers and deciduous trees such as maple and alder", (Kroeger)

Stropharia ambigua.spores: dark purplish to nearly black (Arora), brownish purple (Phillips), purple-brown (Smith)
Stropharia ambigua.taste: not distinctive (Phillips), faint and sometimes like raw potatoes (Smith)
Stropharia ambigua.habitat: single to scattered or in groups "in rich humus, usually under conifers, but also with alder and other hardwoods", (Arora), usually gregarious "on humus in coniferous forests or in river valleys under alder", fall or sometimes spring, (Smith), large fruitings can occur among wood chips (Trudell)

Stropharia caerulea.habitat: garden-like habitats or soils enriched with manure (Stamets), in grass and leaf litter (Phillips), disturbed places, rubbish tips, roadsides, etc., (Courtecuisse), usually gregarious, but also single in forests and parks, at the edges of forests, in waste places, commonly among Urtica (nettle), (Breitenbach), late summer to fall, (Bacon)

Stropharia coronilla.odour: faint and slightly pungent (Smith), almost odorless, somewhat herbaceous, (Breitenbach), slightly disagreeable (Miller)
Stropharia coronilla.habitat: scattered to gregarious on grassy areas, most frequent in fall, (Arora), in small groups or scattered, late summer, fall, or early winter, (Smith)

Stropharia hornemannii.odour: a little unpleasant (Phillips), none or acidulous fungus-like when cut (Watling)
Stropharia hornemannii.habitat: single, scattered, or in small groups "on ground or rotting wood under conifers", (Arora), on rotting conifer logs, August to November, (Phillips), summer, fall

Stropharia inuncta.taste: faint, none or slightly disagreeable, (Watling), mild, +/- fungoid, (Breitenbach)
Stropharia inuncta.odour: faint, none or slightly disagreeable, (Watling), faint, not distinctive, (Breitenbach)
Stropharia inuncta.habitat: usually gregarious, more rarely single, "in meadows, cow pastures, waste places", on roadsides or pathsides, in grasses and mosses, summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Europe), grassy or mossy waysides, edges of woods, (Moser for Europe), "amongst grass and moss in heaths and pastures, under hedges, especially at roadsides", (Watling for Britain)

Stropharia kauffmanii.nameOrigin: after Calvin Henry Kauffman 1869-1931, professor of botany University of Michigan
Stropharia kauffmanii.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups "in rich humus, around brush piles and decayed woody debris, etc.", usually under hardwoods, (Arora), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller)

Stropharia melanosperma.spores: purplish black, (Noordeloos), dark brown (Breitenbach), dark violet (Cortez)
Stropharia melanosperma.odour: "slightly unpleasant when cut or bruised", (Noordeloos), almost odorless (Breitenbach)
Stropharia melanosperma.habitat: "in small groups, terrestrial on humus-rich soils", saprobic; May to July in Europe, (Noordeloos), single to gregarious "in meadows and pastures or along grassy forest edges, in grass on soil", summer to fall, (Breitenbach), single on litter and humus rich soil (in Brazil), (Cortez), grows on dung or in pastures (Arora)

Stropharia pseudocyanea.spores: purplish brown (Stamets), spores on annulus of Pholiota subcaerulea said to be pale cinnamon brown, (Smith(3))
Stropharia pseudocyanea.odour: not distinctive (Redhead), usually rather strong, peppery, (Buczacki)
Stropharia pseudocyanea.habitat: gregarious on wet rotting vegetation, including Scirpus acutus, in collapsed piles in a fen in Ontario and on mossy leaf and needle litter in a wet depression in a stand of Pinus contorta in Alberta, (Redhead), prefers "tall grass in wetlands, marshes, and meadows, or tall shrubs along trails at field-forest interfaces", (Stamets), unimproved grassland, dunes, wood edges, (Courtecuisse), fall (Buczacki)

Stropharia rugosoannulata.nameOrigin: means "wrinkled and ringed", referring to radially grooved ring
Stropharia rugosoannulata.spores: deep purple-brown to black (Arora), dark brownish violet (Breitenbach)
Stropharia rugosoannulata.odour: pleasant (Phillips), pleasant, faintly farinaceous, (Miller), "herbaceous-raphanoid (like cut grass), with a pleasant aromatic component", (Breitenbach)
Stropharia rugosoannulata.habitat: scattered to gregarious "in mulch, wood chips, straw, lawns, gardens, and other cultivated areas", (Arora), May to October (Lincoff(2)), spring, summer, fall

Stropharia scabella.habitat: type single on soil in dense coniferous forests, October

Stropharia semigloboides.habitat: type single among leaves in woods, (Murrill), single on humus under spruce (Smith(20))

Stropharia silvatica.habitat: type single under cedar and hemlock in the spring

Tapinella atrotomentosa.spores: yellowish to brownish (Arora), yellow-brown with a slight olive tint, (Breitenbach), clay color to mustard yellow (Miller)
Tapinella atrotomentosa.taste: mild, sometimes bitterish (Breitenbach), very bitter (Lincoff(1)), bitter (Courtecuisse, Schalkwijk-Barendsen), rather bitter (Kibby), not distinctive (Phillips, Bessette), acrid [peppery], (Trudell)
Tapinella atrotomentosa.habitat: single or in groups or tufts "on or around conifers (usually dead) or madrone", causes a brown rot in host, (Arora), conifer stumps or decayed wood, especially pine, July to October, (Lincoff(2)), "from rotting conifer stumps, snags, and logs", (Trudell), summer, fall

Tapinella panuoides.spores: yellowish buff to brown or dingy ochraceous, (Arora), light brown (Breitenbach), pale brown to yellowish brown (Miller)
Tapinella panuoides.taste: not distinctive or slightly bitter (Bessette), pleasant (Miller)
Tapinella panuoides.habitat: single or in groups or clumps on coniferous logs, stumps, debris, mine timbers, humus rich in lignin, (Arora), "scattered or in overlapping clusters on decaying conifer wood", May to November, (Bessette), on conifer logs, wood chips, and rich accumulations of humus, (Trudell), spring, summer, fall

Tectella patellaris.nameOrigin: 'patella' is a small pan or dish
Tectella patellaris.habitat: in groups or clusters on hardwood, especially Fagus (beech), Betula (birch), and Salix (willow); July to October, (Bessette), in groups on fallen branches and logs of hardwoods; July to October, (Phillips), on logs and fallen branches of hardwoods, especially Alnus (alder), Fagus, Betula, and Salix, (Lincoff), on branches of Alnus, late fall to spring, (Hansen, L.), spring, summer, fall, winter

Tephrocybe rancida.habitat: single to gregarious in hardwood and coniferous forests (Breitenbach), fall (Buczacki)

Tetrapyrgos subdendrophora.habitat: on grasses and Rubus canes in cavities in dense enclosing vegetation, (Redhead(6)), single or scattered on stems of dune grass (Ammophila spp.), less often on other grasses, sedges, or Rubus canes; fall into early winter, (Siegel, Latin italicized), single to gregarious, "on dead stems of sedges, beach grass, blackberry, or various shrubs in moist shaded habitats", late fall to mid-winter in coastal forests, (Desjardin for California), on monocot leaves and stems of Carex spp., Phalaris arundinaea and various other grasses, and rarely on dicot stems (Rubus) and twigs (Baccharis)

Thaxterogaster caesiolamellatus.odour: "faint to distinct of honey" in the flesh of the stem base (Liimatainen), "distinct of honey when cut, especially in the bulb", (Brandrud)
Thaxterogaster caesiolamellatus.habitat: fruits in "montane to middle boreal, mesic coniferous forests, often on rich soil", in Europe apparently mainly or only under Picea (spruce), but in USA also under Pinus (pine); collected from June (France) to November (WA), (Liimatainen), in "boreal-boreonemoral, montane and subalpine coniferous forests, often on rich, sometimes calcareous ground", (Brandrud)

Thaxterogaster causticus.taste: mild to bitterish, cuticle very bitter, (Breitenbach), only cap skin bitter (Moser)
Thaxterogaster causticus.habitat: usually gregarious to clustered under conifers or hardwoods on poor, sandy soils, especially under Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Europe), coniferous woods or hardwood woods (Moser)

Thaxterogaster comarostaphylidis.nameOrigin: named after the habitat with Comarostaphylis arbutoides
Thaxterogaster comarostaphylidis.taste: slime tastes mild, flesh tastes mild or slightly of radish, "after several minutes taste becomes slightly astringent", and the gills have a mild taste
Thaxterogaster comarostaphylidis.habitat: gregarious or cespitose "in small or large groups", often producing large numbers of fruitbodies in one area; in the paramo under Comarostaphylis arbutoides or in forested areas under Comarostaphylis arbutoides with Q. costaricensis in adjacent areas (Ammirati(19) for Costa Rica), Comarostaphylis arbutoides is a shrub in Ericaceae limited to Central America

Thaxterogaster herpeticus.habitat: coniferous and deciduous forests, most often under Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine) but also Fagus (beech), (Brandrud for Europe), "with moss and lichen in coniferous woods", September to November, (Phillips), on mosses, in moist coniferous forests, (Kauffman), mostly under spruce (Stuntz), fall

Thaxterogaster leucophanes.habitat: mainly in dry, sandy Pinus (pine) heathland, rarely with Picea (spruce); fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe)

Thaxterogaster montanus.habitat: type among humus in dense coniferous forests of cedar and hemlock in Oregon (Kauffman(3)), mostly older conifer forests in mountains (Stuntz)

Thaxterogaster multiformis.odour: faint of honey when bruised, (Brandrud(1)), "none or faint of honey, at least in bulb when bruised", (Brandrud(5)), odorless to smelling faintly like honey, may be stronger in base of stem than in other parts of fruitbody, (Breitenbach)
Thaxterogaster multiformis.habitat: spruce forests (Brandrud(1)), associated with Picea abies (Norway Spruce), "mainly in oligotrophic-acid, mossy sites, often in large numbers in young plantations", boreal(-boreonemoral) "and (more rarely) montane-subalpine coniferous forests", (Brandrud(5) in Europe)

Thaxterogaster 'mutabilis'.habitat: gregarious under conifers (Smith), scattered or in groups on ground under conifers, especially in the mountains, (Bessette)

Thaxterogaster oregonensis.taste: not distinctive, cap skin not bitter, (Smith), mild, (Phillips)
Thaxterogaster oregonensis.habitat: gregarious under spruce in Oregon (Smith), under conifers, October to November, (Phillips), fall

Thaxterogaster pallidirimosus.nameOrigin: "The name refers to the pale pileus with streaks."
Thaxterogaster pallidirimosus.habitat: in "middle to northern boreal, mesic, mixed forests" with Betula (birch), "among mosses, on oligotrophic to eutrophic soil"; often single or in small groups; fruits late summer to fall

Thaxterogaster parksianus.nameOrigin: named in honor of Mr. H.E. Parks of Trinidad, California and collected on his estate
Thaxterogaster parksianus.habitat: type cespitose [in tufts] to gregarious under redwood in California

Thaxterogaster pinophilus.odour: "slightly cheese-like (Brie), yeasty or not distinctive", (Ammirati), very faint, pleasant, (Soop)
Thaxterogaster pinophilus.habitat: gregarious to scattered in forest with Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) or Tsuga heterophylla and/or Pinus contorta (lodgepole pine); September to mid-November, (Ammirati), in Sweden found in sub-alpine forests of Pinus sylvestris, among Cladonia, in a calcareous region, (Soop), fall

Thaxterogaster pluvius.taste: bitterish (Moser for T. pluvius), bitter (Breitenbach for T. pluvius), markedly bitter (Moser for T. pluvialis), slightly bitter to almost mild, slime more bitter, (Moser for C. pluviorum)
Thaxterogaster pluvius.odour: slightly raphanoid to iodoform-like (Breitenbach for T. pluvius), iodoform (Hansen for C. pluviorum)
Thaxterogaster pluvius.habitat: "with birches, (but also coniferous woods?)", (Moser for T. pluvius), usually gregarious in wet coniferous forests or high moors near Pinus (pine), Picea (spruce), and Betula (birch), (Breitenbach for T. pluvius), mixed woods, (beech-fir), (Moser for T. pluvialis), woods (Moser for C. pluviorum)

Thaxterogaster porphyropus.odour: distinct, honey-like when cut, (Brandrud), none (Kauffman), slight (Phillips)
Thaxterogaster porphyropus.habitat: in boreonemoral, boreal and subalpine deciduous and mixed forests, also in low alpine Betula nana heaths, associated with Betula species, (Brandrud for Europe), beech woods (Moser for Europe), under birch, etc., in moist places, (Kauffman), in broadleaved woods, especially beech and birch, September to October, (Phillips), late summer to fall (Buczacki), [under hardwoods in PNW], fall

Thaxterogaster purpurascens.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in small clumps "on ground or very rotten wood under conifers" especially at high elevations

Thaxterogaster rufoallutus.nameOrigin: probably from 'rufo' meaning 'red' and Cortinarius allutus
Thaxterogaster rufoallutus.odour: "none or faint of honey in bulb when bruised", (Brandrud), sweetish, honey-like with scratching of the stem, (Bidaud)
Thaxterogaster rufoallutus.habitat: associated with Picea abies (Norway Spruce), "mainly in oligotrophic-acid, mossy sites, sometimes in young plantations", "boreal (-boreonemoral) and montane-subalpine coniferous forests", (Brandrud(5), in Europe)

Thaxterogaster scaurus.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious on ground in woods

Thaxterogaster subpurpurascens.odour: slightly that of radish, somewhat pungent, (Kauffman), distinctly honey-like (Brandrud)
Thaxterogaster subpurpurascens.habitat: on the ground in coniferous forests, (Kauffman), in Europe, deciduous woods, especially with birches, (Moser), under conifers (Arora)

Thaxterogaster talus.taste: mild at least in one specimen (Cripps), mild, sweet, (Buczacki)
Thaxterogaster talus.odour: strong, sweet, honey-like, (Cripps), honey-like when cut or bruised (Brandrud(1)), "usually sweetish, [flowery,] honeylike", (Moser), faint honey-like (Trudell)
Thaxterogaster talus.habitat: under Populus tremuloides (aspen) with occasional conifers present in Montana July-August, reported from conifer forest that includes aspen and Betula (birch) in Alaska in August, (Cripps(6) who note "host delineation is more difficult because the ecological information is rather diffuse for most collections"), sometimes occurring in the Pacific Northwest in moist areas in subalpine forests, (Trudell), in nemoral to subalpine deciduous forests and low alpine to arctic heaths, usually in dry places, both on acid and somewhat richer soil, rather frequent under Quercus (oak), Fagus (beech), and Betula (birch), (Brandrud(1) for Europe), beech woods (Moser for Europe), fall (Buczacki), also summer

Thaxterogaster variegatus.habitat: in conifer forest (rarely in Fagus (beech) forests), late fall, (Knudsen(1) for northern Europe)

Thaxterogaster vespertinus.odour: distinct, somewhat reminiscent of Cortinarius subtortus, (Brandrud)
Thaxterogaster vespertinus.habitat: in montane conifer forest among Abies (true fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), (NACorts), usually under various Pinaceae species, (Castellano), deciduous and coniferous forests (Brandrud)

Thaxterogaster vibratilis.taste: bitter cap surface and intensely bitter flesh (Kauffman), bitter, especially cap surface, which can usually be detected by pressing your tongue to the cap surface, (Arora)
Thaxterogaster vibratilis.habitat: humus in rich woods, in hardwood and coniferous forests, (Kauffman), single to widely scattered or in small groups, usually with conifers, but also "under manzanita, madrone, and huckleberry", (Arora), in coniferous and deciduous woods, (Phillips), fall (Buczacki)

Trichaptum laricinum.habitat: annual, on sapwood of dead conifers, associated with white pocket rot of dead conifers

Tricholoma aestuans.nameOrigin: 'aestuans' means 'being in commotion, burning, rising in waves, vacillating', perhaps referring to undulating cap margin
Tricholoma aestuans.taste: bitter (Ovrebo), bitter or not distinctive at first, then strongly peppery, (Bessette(2))
Tricholoma aestuans.habitat: single to gregarious under many species of Pinus (pine); September to November, (Ovrebo), single, scattered or in groups on ground under pine or sometimes oak, (Bessette(2)), fall

Tricholoma albobrunneum.habitat: in sandy Pinus (pine) forests (Hansen for Europe), especially with pines (Moser for Europe)

Tricholoma ammophilum.nameOrigin: from the Greek "ammos" = sand and "philos" = loving; "recognizing the species' common name in the Pacific Northwest", "the sandy," "based on its frequent occurrence in sandy soils", (Trudell(6))
Tricholoma ammophilum.edibility: yes but be sure associated with cottonwood and is not in the Tricholoma pessundatum group (Arora)
Tricholoma ammophilum.habitat: scattered or "often in dense close-packed groups or clusters" "in sandy soil"; ectomycorrhizal "with Populus species, most commonly P. balsamifera" [Balsam Poplar], (Trudell(6)), often occurring in dense groups under black cottonwood (Trudell(8)), scattered to densely gregarious, frequently fruiting in large fairy rings or dense masses in sandy soil or along rivers, "apparently always in association with poplar or cottonwood", (Arora)

Tricholoma apium.taste: mild, (Moser, Hansen), mild, somewhat spicy, (Breitenbach), "mild or a bit farinaceous or spicy" (Bessette)
Tricholoma apium.odour: of celery, (Moser), "strong, reminiscent of fennel, celery, or aniseed", (Hansen), strongly like celery or like Lactarius helvus, (Breitenbach), strong, like celery or somewhat curry-like (like Lactarius camphoratus or L. helvus), (Bessette), others say fresh baked bread or similar to Tricholoma murrillianum
Tricholoma apium.habitat: especially with pines, (Moser), in oligotrophic Pinus forests (Hansen), single to gregarious, in coniferous forests under Pinus (pine) and Picea (spruce), prefers dry, sandy habitats, (Breitenbach), fall (Buczacki)

Tricholoma argenteum.habitat: gregarious under conifers (Pinus banksiana, Pinus rigida, Picea mariana), September to October, (Ovrebo), fall

Tricholoma 'argyraceum'.habitat: single, scattered, or in large groups or clusters "on ground or in duff" under Quercus agrifolia (Coast Live Oak), uncommon and local "on the San Francisco Peninsula, more common southward", fruiting through winter and into spring in wet years, (Siegel(2)), under Quercus agrifolia, "on the campus of Stanford University, Santa Clara County, California", January 2011, (Bessette(5))

Tricholoma 'arvernense'.nameOrigin: refers to the occurrence of this species in the Auvergne region of France, named after a Gallic tribe, Arverni, that once inhabited the area, (Bessette(5))
Tricholoma 'arvernense'.odour: "mildly farinaceous-fruity or like cucumber", (Bessette), weakly subfarinaceous, a little fruity after a time and finally somewhat unpleasant, (Bon)
Tricholoma 'arvernense'.habitat: in North America under Tsuga (hemlock) and other conifers; in Europe under Pinus (pine), Abies (true fir), and Picea (spruce), (Bessette)

Tricholoma atrofibrillosum.nameOrigin: from the Latin ater = black and fibrilla = fiber, for the dark fibrils on the cap surface, (Trudell(6))
Tricholoma atrofibrillosum.edibility: not recommended, poisonous at worst, insipid at best, (Arora(1) for Tricholoma sejunctum)
Tricholoma atrofibrillosum.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups "under conifers, especially Picea sitchensis" (Sitka Spruce), (Trudell(6)), mainly in fall (Arora)

Tricholoma atrosquamosum.habitat: single to gregarious in hardwood and coniferous forests, (Breitenbach), coniferous woods (Moser), fall (Buczacki)

Tricholoma atroviolaceum.taste: slightly to strongly farinaceous, (Smith(17)), farinaceous (Shanks), somewhat bitter (Trudell)
Tricholoma atroviolaceum.odour: very strongly farinaceous (Smith(17)), "strongly rancid farinaceous to mildly farinaceous", (Shanks)
Tricholoma atroviolaceum.habitat: under conifers (Smith(17)), single to scattered under conifers, September to December, (Shanks for California), fall, winter

Tricholoma aurantio-olivaceum.taste: not distinct or slowly peppery (Shanks), mild (Smith)
Tricholoma aurantio-olivaceum.habitat: gregarious with Douglas-fir, (Shanks for California), densely gregarious under conifers (Smith)

Tricholoma aurantium.taste: "strongly farinaceous and disagreeable (like rancid oil or cucumber)", (Arora), farinaceous, cap cuticle may be bitter, (Shanks), bitter (Courtecuisse)
Tricholoma aurantium.odour: "strongly farinaceous and disagreeable (like rancid oil or cucumber)", (Arora), farinaceous, (Shanks), cucumber (Courtecuisse), "disagreeable, strong, as old meal or corn silk", (Miller)
Tricholoma aurantium.habitat: single or scattered on ground in woods, (Arora), single to gregarious in mixed woods, (Shanks), summer and fall (Miller)

Tricholoma badicephalum.habitat: holotype collection under "low scrubby spruce trees" in November

Tricholoma 'bufonium'.odour: repulsive, like carbide-illuminating gas, (Breitenbach), repulsive, like coal tar gas, (Parker), less strong than Tricholoma sulphureum, ?insecticide, (Courtecuisse)
Tricholoma 'bufonium'.habitat: single to gregarious from needle litter in mixed conifer forests, (Parker), single to gregarious in conifer forests or mixed conifer-hardwood forests, late summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), especially conifers (Courtecuisse for Europe)

Tricholoma cingulatum.habitat: gregarious, associated with Salix (willow) in sandy soil, October to December, (Shanks for California), gregarious or in cespitose clusters under Salix (willow), September to October, (Ovrebo), mixed forest under conifers, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), pasture especially willow (Moser), late summer to fall (Buczacki), summer, fall, winter

Tricholoma davisiae.nameOrigin: "honors Mrs. H. C. Davis, who collected the species near Falmouth, Maine, and sent material and notes to Peck", (Bessette(5))
Tricholoma davisiae.habitat: gregarious in coniferous forests, especially common under Pinus banksiana (P. contorta in OR), (Ovrebo(2)), gregarious to single under conifers in fall, (Smith, Ovrebo(1))

Tricholoma dryophilum.edibility: unknown but best avoided because some other viscid red-brown Tricholomas are poisonous, (Bessette)
Tricholoma dryophilum.habitat: scattered or in groups under Quercus agrifolia (Coast Live Oak), reported under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), (Bessette), under Quercus agrifolia, November to January, Marin County in California southward, (Shanks(1))

Tricholoma dulciolens.edibility: edible and the forms that are not disagreeable in taste or odor said to be as good as Tricholoma murrillianum, (Arora)
Tricholoma dulciolens.taste: Pacific Northwest collections often have an unpleasant taste, (Trudell(4)), "mild to nutty, bitter, or disagreeable", (Arora), extremely bitter, collections with pleasant taste may be a different, possibly undescribed taxon, (Shanks), in western North America usually mild, in eastern North America can be bitter, (Phillips), bitterish and somewhat unpleasant, (Breitenbach for Europe)
Tricholoma dulciolens.odour: Pacific Northwest collections often have an unpleasant odor, (Trudell(4)), variable, in western North America typically has spicy-cinnamon odor of Tricholoma murrillianum, in eastern North American it is more apt to have mild to fruity to pungent or disgusting odor, (Arora), spicy, like cinnamon, (Shanks), in western North America usually fragrant, in eastern North America can be foul, (Phillips), "fruity to flowery but rather unpleasant", (Breitenbach for Europe)
Tricholoma dulciolens.habitat: single to scattered or in groups on ground in woods, (Arora), single to gregarious with conifers, November to December, (Shanks for California), under hardwoods, particularly oak in eastern North America, under conifers in western North America, (Phillips), fall, winter

Tricholoma equestre.nameOrigin: means "greenish yellow" or "yellow of the spring" according to 2 sources
Tricholoma equestre.edibility: not recommended: there are reports of poisoning (in France, for instance) and species concepts are still not clear
Tricholoma equestre.odour: "farinaceous or somewhat like coconut", (Arora), not distinctive to mildly farinaceous, (Shanks)
Tricholoma equestre.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious under pines, rarely other conifers, found occasionally with madrones, and in southwest US it is quite common under aspen, (Arora), "most often under pine but with other conifers, cottonwood, and aspen as well", (Trudell(4)), scattered to gregarious, occasionally cespitose [in tufts], associated with conifers, or rarely hardwoods, (Shanks), late summer and fall (Miller)

Tricholoma farinaceum.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [more or less in tufts], in humus in woods, (Murrill), in leaf litter in woods (Bessette)

Tricholoma focale.nameOrigin: means "scarf" in reference to the ring (Bessette(5))
Tricholoma focale.edibility: severe GI symptoms all night after 2 slices in a 2010 report, not clear whether raw, (Beug)
Tricholoma focale.habitat: in conifer woods, especially pines, (Moser), especially under conifers, on sand, (Courtecuisse), fall (Buczacki)

Tricholoma fulvum.taste: farinaceous (Phillips, Ovrebo), rather bitter (Bon), farinaceous, bitterish, (Breitenbach)
Tricholoma fulvum.odour: farinaceous (Phillips, Ovrebo, Lange), strong, farinaceous (Bon), faintly farinaceous (Breitenbach)
Tricholoma fulvum.habitat: "in groups or dense clusters under hardwoods or in mixed hardwood and coniferous forests", (Phillips), gregarious or in cespitose [in tufts] clusters under hardwoods or mixed conifers-hardwoods, (Ovrebo), under birch (Bon for Britain), on somewhat boggy ground under birch, (Lange), single to gregarious in hardwood and coniferous forests, primarily near Betula and Picea, "Authors with a narrow species concept distinguish two species within the one described here: Tricholoma fulvum, an obligate mycorrhizal partner of Betula, with pronouncedly yellow lamellae and yellow stipe flesh along with a ribbed pileal margin; and T. nictitans, under conifers or in mixed forests without birches, with scarcely to slightly yellow lamellae, and with a smooth pileal margin. Microscopic differences are not significant.", (Breitenbach for Switzerland, Latin names italicized), on acidic soil in mixed woods or hardwood woods, usually with birch, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland), June-October (Bacon), summer, fall

Tricholoma 'imbricatum'.edibility: not recommended because easy to confuse with Tricholoma pessundatum group (Arora)
Tricholoma 'imbricatum'.taste: mild to slightly farinaceous (Smith), absent to slightly peppery, (Ovrebo), sometimes slightly bitter aftertaste (Lincoff(1))
Tricholoma 'imbricatum'.odour: mild or faintly farinaceous (Arora), mild to slightly farinaceous (Smith), absent (Ovrebo)
Tricholoma 'imbricatum'.habitat: single to scattered or densely gregarious under conifers, particularly Pinus (pine) and Picea (spruce) - often hidden by needles, (Arora), scattered to gregarious under conifers (Smith), single, gregarious or in cespitose clusters under Pinus (pine) or Picea (spruce), September to October, (Ovrebo), fall

Tricholoma inamoenum.taste: like motor oil (Shanks), mild, cabbage-like, (Breitenbach), disagreeable (Bessette(2)), of raw meal (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Tricholoma inamoenum.odour: like coal-tar (like T. sulphureum), (Shanks), unpleasantly like cooking gas, (Breitenbach), "pungent, disagreeable, like coal tar", (Bessette(2)), unpleasant chemical odor (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), (Lincoff(1) says not unpleasant smell of acetylene and in another place coal gas but also says not known in North America), "pungent and disagreeable like coal tar or with a heavy floral scent like that of hyacinths or paperwhites", (Bessette(5)), odor is due to a mixture of benzaldehyde, 1-octen-2-ol, and phenylacetaldehyde, (Watson)
Tricholoma inamoenum.habitat: single to gregarious with conifers, particularly Picea (spruce), (Shanks), single to grouped on calcareous subsoil in spruce forests, (Breitenbach for Europe), single or scattered on ground under conifers, August to November, (Bessette(2)), "In the Pacific Northwest I found it in the mountains, but also in boreal mixed forest and aspen parkland growing in moss under spruce in boggy areas", (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), summer and fall (Miller)

Tricholoma intermedium.nameOrigin: "intermedium" means "intermediate" referring to its intermediate position between T. equestre and T. sejunctum, (Bessette(5))
Tricholoma intermedium.habitat: single to gregarious with conifers, (Shanks), single or gregarious under conifers in fall, (Ovrebo), September to October (Phillips), thin woods in the Catskill Mountains, September, (Peck)

Tricholoma luteomaculosum.habitat: single to gregarious in mixed woods (Shanks), gregarious under hardwoods, September to November, (Ovrebo), fall

Tricholoma lutescens.nameOrigin: from the Greek "leukos" = white and "xanthos" = yellow, for the whitish fruitbodies that develop yellow stains
Tricholoma lutescens.odour: "complex, a mix of pungent, disagreeable, and coal tar-like, with a floral or fruity component", (Trudell(6)), not unpleasant at first whiff, but builds to be sharp, penetrating, and unpleasant, (A. Parker, pers. comm., prior to formal description)
Tricholoma lutescens.habitat: known in conifer and mixed forests with Picea (spruce) present, (Trudell(6)), all collections came from forests with abundant Picea (spruce), often accompanied by Betula (birch), (Trudell(8))

Tricholoma marquettense.nameOrigin: means from Marquette: the holotype was collected near Marquette, Michigan
Tricholoma marquettense.habitat: single or gregarious under Pinus banksiana (Jack Pine), single fruitbody under Fagus grandifolia (American beech); fruiting late August to October

Tricholoma megalophaeum.nameOrigin: from the Greek megas = large, great and phaios = dark, recognizing the large size and dark cap color of the basidiomes, (Trudell(6))
Tricholoma megalophaeum.odour: "slightly farinaceous, sometimes somewhat like green corn"
Tricholoma megalophaeum.habitat: so far known only from coastal Picea sitchensis-Tsuga heterophylla forests [presumably on the ground], (Trudell(6)), Trudell(8) said, "All known collections to date have come from coastal conifer forests that contain abundant Sitka spruce."

Tricholoma moseri.nameOrigin: after Dr. Meinhard Moser, author of "Keys to Agarics and Boleti" and many other mycological publications
Tricholoma moseri.habitat: single to cespitose [in tufts] under conifers, often in disturbed soil or near melting snow; in CA "May to August in montane regions, rarely from October to December in montane and coastal regions", (Shanks), spring, summer, fall, winter

Tricholoma muricatum.habitat: single to gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] under pine

Tricholoma murrillianum.nameOrigin: refers to mycologist William Alfonso Murrill; matsutake means pine mushroom from mats = pine (Japanese), take = mushroom (Japanese)
Tricholoma murrillianum.edibility: choice (Arora, Phillips), a prized edible species harvested for commercial sale, (Shanks), there is a report of a young girl dying from an anaphylactic reaction to Tricholoma matsutake by Ichikawa et al.(2006), (Benjamin)
Tricholoma murrillianum.odour: distinctly spicy aromatic (cinnamon-spicy together with dirty socks), (Arora), distinctly fragrant (Phillips), spicy, like cinnamon, (Shanks), spicy with a sweet smell (Miller)
Tricholoma murrillianum.habitat: "widely scattered to gregarious on ground in forests, thickets, and pine barrens", "In the mountains of Idaho, Washington, and Oregon it is common under mixed conifers and second-growth Douglas-fir, while on the coast it favors sandy pine forests", (also tanoak-madrone in coastal California), tends to occur in thickets of ericaceous shrubs (like manzanita, huckleberry and rhododendron), (Arora), "scattered to numerous under pine and in sandy soil, especially near coastal areas", August to November, in California December to February, (Phillips), single to gregarious with conifers, particularly in sandy soil, in coastal forests and montane regions, (Shanks), summer, fall, winter

Tricholoma mutabile.taste: strongly sweet farinaceous or like grapefruit
Tricholoma mutabile.odour: strongly sweet farinaceous or like grapefruit, (Shanks(1)), described as strongly sweet-farinaceous under T. mutabile, and as having a strong cucumber odor in the discussion of T. portentosum, (Shanks(2))
Tricholoma mutabile.habitat: scattered to gregarious in mixed coniferous forest, December to January in California, October in Washington, (Shanks(1)), fall, winter

Tricholoma myomyces.nameOrigin: means "mouse mushroom", myos = mouse (Greek), mykes = mushroom (Greek)
Tricholoma myomyces.habitat: "in groups or dense clusters under conifers in woods or on lawns", (Phillips), gregarious or in cespitose clusters under conifers, (Ovrebo)

Tricholoma nigrum.habitat: under Pinus contorta in coastal Oregon (Shanks for type), also occurred in "an old growth, mixed conifer forest dominated by Douglas-fir and western hemlock, with occasional western white pines"

Tricholoma odorum.taste: farinaceous (Phillips), at first nutty, then farinaceous (Peck), "farinaceous or otherwise unpleasant" (Bessette(5))
Tricholoma odorum.odour: of coal tar (Phillips), "The species is remarkable for its peculiar and strong odor which resembles that of jessamine blossoms.", (Peck in original description), rather strong, reminding one of the odor of T. sulphureum (Kauffman, who also refers to the odor as peculiar), "farinaceous or like coal tar" (Bessette(5))
Tricholoma odorum.habitat: "in groups or dense clusters under hardwoods or in mixed deciduous and coniferous woods" (Phillips), among fallen leaves in moist places in woods (Peck from original description)

Tricholoma orirubens.habitat: single to gregarious or in fairy rings, under hardwoods and conifers, (Breitenbach for Europe), deciduous, more rarely coniferous woods, (Moser for Europe), especially under hardwoods (Courtecuisse for Europe), fall (Buczacki)

Tricholoma 'pardinum'.nameOrigin: refers to the leopard, from spot-like appearance of cap, (Bessette(5))
Tricholoma 'pardinum'.edibility: poisonous, can cause severe and persistent gastroenteritis requiring hospitalization, (Arora)
Tricholoma 'pardinum'.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious on ground in woods, under conifers or hardwoods (including at least tanoak, madrone), (Arora), scattered to gregarious with conifers or in mixed woods, September to December, (Shanks), gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] under conifers, (Ovrebo), usually fruiting in fall, but up to January, (Miller), fall, winter

Tricholoma pessundatum.habitat: gregarious or in cespitose clusters under hardwoods or conifers, September to October, (Ovrebo), fall

Tricholoma platyphyllum.odour: not mentioned in original description (Murrill), coal tar (Arora), like Tricholoma sulphureum (Smith)
Tricholoma platyphyllum.habitat: type single in humus in woods (Murrill), associated with conifers (Arora)

Tricholoma portentosum.nameOrigin: means "like an omen", or according to Bessette(5) "monstrous, hideous, unnatural, or marvelous"
Tricholoma portentosum.edibility: excellent, but be sure of identification, (Arora)
Tricholoma portentosum.taste: mild to farinaceous, (Arora), not distinct to mildly farinaceous, (Shanks), mild, farinaceous, (Breitenbach), mealy, cucumber-like, (Kibby)
Tricholoma portentosum.odour: mild to farinaceous, (Arora), not distinct to mildly farinaceous, (Shanks), slightly farinaceous (Breitenbach)
Tricholoma portentosum.habitat: scattered to gregarious on ground in woods, coniferous or hardwood, (Arora), single to gregarious in association with conifers, particularly pine, (Shanks), single, gregarious, sometimes in fairy rings; in coniferous forests, more rarely in (mixed) hardwood forests, on soil, needle litter etc., (Breitenbach for Europe), scattered or in groups in sandy soil under conifers and oaks, October to November (February in California), (Phillips), in groups or scattered among mosses or on ground under pines, September to November, (Bessette(2)), late in season, often in fairy rings or troops under pines or beech, (Kibby), fall, winter

Tricholoma robustum.habitat: pine woods (Moser), especially in conifer woods (Ricken)

Tricholoma saponaceum.taste: mild to farinaceous, soapy, or "of washrooms", (Arora), "historically described as like soap, rather sharp and rancid with a sweet overtone", (Shanks), mushroomy (Phillips), mild or slightly sweet (Miller)
Tricholoma saponaceum.odour: mild to farinaceous, soapy, or "of washrooms", (Arora), "historically described as like soap, rather sharp and rancid with a sweet overtone", (Shanks), fragrant, said to be of soap or flowers, or sour like sesame oil, or of green almonds, (Kibby), of soap, sometimes pungent or mild, (Miller)
Tricholoma saponaceum.habitat: single, scattered, cespitose [in tufts], or in groups or troops under both hardwoods and conifers, (Arora), single to cespitose [in tufts] with hardwoods or conifers, (Shanks), summer and fall (Miller), often found in spring, unlike most Tricholomas (Bessette)

Tricholoma 'scalpturatum'.nameOrigin: means "engraved", "perhaps in reference to the manner in which the cap surface breaks up into patches", (Bessette(5))
Tricholoma 'scalpturatum'.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups under conifers or hardwoods: "Currently, the dominant concept in Europe is of a hardwood species that occurs only occasionally with conifers. This is the opposite of the prevailing concept in North America", (Bessette(5) who separate T. cingulatum, T. argyraceum, T. inocybeoides, and T. alboconicum), gregarious to subfasciculate [somewhat bundled] with hardwoods, bushes, scrub, from late summer, (Hansen), grassy woods (Moser), summer, fall, (Bacon)

Tricholoma 'squarrulosum'.odour: "variously described as farinaceous and somewhat disagreeable, sweet-fruity and somewhat spicy-peppery, or not distinctive" (Bessette), "farinaceous and somewhat disagreeable" (Ovrebo)
Tricholoma 'squarrulosum'.habitat: scattered or in groups under Quercus (oak) or Fagus (beech), or in mixed woodlands (Bessette(5) who comment that their accompanying photographs are all from conifer forests, so that they might not be the "real" T. squarrulosum), coniferous woods (Moser), gregarious under hardwoods (oak-hickory and beech-maple forests), late August to October, (Ovrebo)

Tricholoma stans.habitat: single to gregarious, under Pinus, more rarely near other conifers, (Breitenbach), coniferous woods, (Hansen and Moser for Europe)

Tricholoma subacutum.edibility: may be poisonous and resembles poisonous Tricholoma pardinum, (Arora)
Tricholoma subacutum.taste: usually sharp or peppery (Arora), peppery to bitter, (Ovrebo(2)), bitter (Ovrebo(1)), bitter and peppery, (Phillips), bitter or peppery (Shanks)
Tricholoma subacutum.odour: mild or earthy (Arora), absent (Ovrebo(2), Ovrebo(1)), musty (Phillips)
Tricholoma subacutum.habitat: single or scattered to gregarious in mixed woods and under conifers, (Arora), gregarious under conifers, (Ovrebo(2)), late summer and fall, in California into winter, (Miller)

Tricholoma subannulatum.habitat: among fallen leaves under Quercus (oak), (Peck), under oaks "or in cultivated fields" (Murrill), in lawns under hardwoods, October to November (Zeller)

Tricholoma subluteum.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups on ground under conifers, August to October, (Bessette(2)), gregarious under mixed hardwoods - conifers, (Ovrebo), summer, fall

Tricholoma subumbrinum.habitat: type scattered under conifers in fall

Tricholoma 'sulphureum'.taste: similar to odor (Shanks), mild (Breitenbach), unpleasant or mild (Bessette(5))
Tricholoma 'sulphureum'.odour: usually strong and repulsive like coal tar gas, (Arora), coal-tar (Shanks), repulsively like carbide-illuminating gas, (Breitenbach), "strongly of coal tar or a heavy floral scent like that of hyacinths or paperwhites" (Bessette(5))
Tricholoma 'sulphureum'.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on ground under both hardwoods and conifers", (Arora), scattered to gregarious under conifers in coastal forests, October to December, (Shanks for California), single to gregarious in hardwood and coniferous forests, among leaf or needle litter, (Breitenbach), fall, winter

Tricholoma terreum.edibility: Tricholoma terreum contains two compounds poisonous to mice (Yin, X.), not recommended (Arora)
Tricholoma terreum.taste: mild and not distinctive, (Breitenbach), slightly farinaceous (Hansen), weakly farinaceous, (Bessette), sweetish but somewhat bitter when mature or old (Lincoff who is describing a complex of species)
Tricholoma terreum.odour: almost odorless, (Breitenbach), slightly farinaceous (Hansen), weakly farinaceous, (Bessette), weak (Courtecuisse), slightly unpleasant, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Tricholoma terreum.habitat: single to gregarious in coniferous forests under Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), "more rarely also in hardwood forests, but then possibly with scattered conifers, also along forest edges and in forest meadows", (Breitenbach for Europe), often gregarious, in calcareous to eutrophic habitats, with Pinus (pine), (Hansen for Europe), under conifers and hardwoods, especially on chalk, (Moser for Europe), in groups, almost tuft-like, or in rings in woodland, especially under conifers, (Lincoff who is describing a complex), on ground in mixed forest, spring and fall, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), summer, fall (Buczacki), fruits in Europe from May to December depending on the climatic zone, (Christensen/Heilmann-Clausen per A. Parker, pers. comm.), spring, summer, fall

Tricholoma transmutans.nameOrigin: means "shifting", "presumably in reference to the change in gill color as the mushroom ages", (Bessette(5))
Tricholoma transmutans.edibility: unknown, but similar species are poisonous (Bessette(5)), yes, but poor (McNeil(1))
Tricholoma transmutans.habitat: "scattered or in groups under conifers or in mixed woodlands", (Bessette), single or more or less gregarious in conifer or mixed forests, under birch, often among mosses, in fall, (McNeil), on ground in woods, August, "occurs in wet weather and manifests a tendency to grow in circles", (Peck)

Tricholoma triste.habitat: grassy and mossy woods, (Moser for Europe), copses of broadleaved trees, often in wet places, (Bon for Europe), found in garden-shrubberies, (Lange for Europe)

Tricholoma vaccinum.nameOrigin: means "of the cow" pertaining to color
Tricholoma vaccinum.edibility: considered mildly poisonous by some authors (Arora)
Tricholoma vaccinum.taste: not distinguishable (Shanks), nondescript to farinaceous, (Ovrebo), bitter (Phillips), unpleasant and bitter (Miller)
Tricholoma vaccinum.odour: "usually farinaceous but sometimes mild", (Arora), not distinguishable, (Shanks), nondescript to farinaceous, (Ovrebo), farinaceous (Phillips), unpleasant (Miller)
Tricholoma vaccinum.habitat: scattered or in small tufts, groups or large troops "under conifers, especially pine and spruce", (Arora), single to gregarious with conifers, (Shanks). gregarious or in cespitose [in tufts] clusters under Pinus (pine) and/or Picea (spruce), (Ovrebo), summer and fall (Miller), associated with conifers, especially spruce (Trudell(8))

Tricholoma venenatoides.nameOrigin: The specific epithet reflects the similarity of the species to Tricholoma venenatum (Greek -o + eides = a thing that is like), (Trudell(6))
Tricholoma venenatoides.edibility: poisonous (severe gastrointestinal distress), (Shanks in California for T. venenatum)
Tricholoma venenatoides.habitat: "in montane conifer forests with Pseudotsuga menziesii and usually Abies"; examined collections were fruiting October to December

Tricholoma vernaticum.nameOrigin: refers to fruiting in spring; 'olida' means 'emitting a smell'
Tricholoma vernaticum.odour: distinctive of cucumber or watermelon rind or rotting potatoes or fresh-mown grass or old fish, (Arora), strongly cucumbery or farinaceous, (Shanks(2)), strongly of raw potatoes or cucumber, (Desjardin)
Tricholoma vernaticum.habitat: single to gregarious or in small clumps of two or three in duff (often partially buried) under mountain conifers, in spring, (Arora), single to gregarious with conifers (Abies and Pinus) above 1200m, April to July, (Shanks(2) for California), spring, summer

Tricholoma zelleri.nameOrigin: "zelleri" after American mycologist Dr. S.M. Zeller of Corvallis Oregon, "who published an account of it under the name A. robusta", (Smith, with Latin name in italics)
Tricholoma zelleri.edibility: "not edible because of the unpleasant taste and smell" (Arora)
Tricholoma zelleri.taste: slightly farinaceous (Smith), strongly rancid-farinaceous, (Arora), rather like fresh meal but with an added pungent, somewhat metallic component, (Ammirati, who however says T. focale may the correct name)
Tricholoma zelleri.odour: slightly farinaceous, (Smith), potato-like (Paul Kroeger, pers. comm.), strongly rancid-farinaceous (Arora), rather like fresh meal but with an added pungent, somewhat metallic component, (Ammirati, who however says T. focale may the correct name)
Tricholoma zelleri.habitat: scattered to gregarious under pines, either along the coast or in the mountains, (Smith), scattered to gregarious on ground under conifers or hardwoods, (Arora)

Tricholomopsis bella.habitat: single "on conifer logs, stumps and debris, late summer and fall", (Smith)

Tricholomopsis decora.edibility: unknown (Phillips), a toxic reaction was reported by K. Richmond in Fungi magazine (Richmond(1))
Tricholomopsis decora.habitat: single, scattered or in groups on conifer logs, (Phillips), single to gregarious on rotten conifer wood, (Breitenbach), scattered to gregarious on decaying conifer logs, often on hemlock, (Smith), fruiting in fall (Miller), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Tricholomopsis 'flammula'.nameOrigin: diminutive form of Latin 'flamma', which means 'blaze, fire'
Tricholomopsis 'flammula'.odour: indistinct, one collection with a pleasant, flowery odor
Tricholomopsis 'flammula'.habitat: single or in small clumps, on conifer wood or hardwood

Tricholomopsis flavissima.habitat: "scattered or in clusters or tufts on coniferous wood", September to October, (Phillips), scattered to subcespitose [more or less in tufts] on conifer wood in fall, (Smith(42))

Tricholomopsis fulvescens.habitat: found single on decayed conifer wood above 1000 feet elevation; September and October, (Castellano), type single on very rotten conifer wood, (Smith), fall

Tricholomopsis glaucipes.nameOrigin: means 'glaucous foot' or in this case 'glaucous stem', glaucous being a color referring to the sea and ranging from gray to blue-green, probably referring to the hoary coating on the stem

Tricholomopsis 'rutilans'.habitat: single, in tufts, or in small groups "on or near rotting conifers, wood chips, and humus rich in lignin", (Arora), single, several, or in groups on coniferous wood, June to October, in California November to February, (Phillips), summer, fall, winter

Tricholomopsis sulphureoides.habitat: single or in groups on coniferous logs, July to October (Phillips), single to gregarious on conifer logs, often hemlock, late summer and fall, (Smith)

Tricholomopsis thompsoniana.habitat: on decaying wood of Pinus (pine) in fall

Trichopilus jubatus.habitat: in humus near ferns, devil's club, or salal, near conifers, (Largent), grassland, moors, exposed sites, (Courtecuisse)

Trichopilus plebeioides.habitat: "gregarious in arcs in a mountain meadow or under conifers", fall

Tubaria 'confragosa'.spores: brown to dark reddish cinnamon (Arora), darker than Tubaria furfuracea complex, (Matheny), ochraceous brown (Buczacki)
Tubaria 'confragosa'.habitat: gregarious (often clustered) on rotting logs, sawdust, wood chip mulch, etc., (Arora), on rotting logs of hardwoods and conifers, (Smith), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Tubaria 'conspersa'.habitat: usually gregarious and grouped "in forests, at the edges of forests, on soil, small pieces of wood, plant remains, etc.", summer to fall, (Breitenbach), in BC there are vouchered O. Ceska collections from every month but January, February, May, and August.

Tubaria furfuracea.spores: ocher-brown to pale ocher (Arora), yellow-brown (Miller), ocher-brown (Breitenbach, although illustration of the spore print colour looks cinnamon)
Tubaria furfuracea.taste: not distinctive (Phillips), mild (Breitenbach), faint, mushroomy or radish-like (Buczacki)
Tubaria furfuracea.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on ground, sticks, and woody debris in wet places" - "woods, vacant lots, landscaped areas, along trails etc.", (Arora), summer half of the year (Breitenbach), April to November (Bessette), late in the fall and sometimes early in spring (needs cool temperatures to fruit), (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), mainly fall to early winter but may grow in spring and summer, (Bacon)

Tubaria punicea.habitat: on rotten wood or base of Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), typically in hollowed bases of large trees, sometimes damaged by fire, in mixed forest of Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Arbutus, or Quercus (oak), (Matheny), type on a burned stump, (Smith)

Tubaria vinicolor.spores: "Saccardo's umber" (in heavy deposits on white paper) to orange-brown
Tubaria vinicolor.habitat: single, gregarious or cespitose [in tufts], 'in grass covering soil and rotting wood, around stump of Eriobotrya japonica (Japanese plum, Rosaceae)' [Latin binomial italicized], also summarized as being 'found in ruderal landscapes with introduced vegetation', fruiting in October in Washington and December, January and March in California, (Matheny), fall, winter, spring

Tulosesus congregatus.habitat: often "tending to grow in clumps"; included in section of key for fruitbodies growing on dung

Tulosesus ephemerus.habitat: generally gregarious on manure piles, in manured places, more rarely on old cow or horse manure (but usually found only in early morning), (Breitenbach), on dung (Moser, Hansen), fall, occasionally spring, (Buczacki)

Tulosesus eurysporus.habitat: gregarious on sticks lying on the ground, (Lange, M.)

Tulosesus heterosetulosus.habitat: single or somewhat gregarious on horse dung, (Ulje), on dung, "often when rather old and washed out", (Lange, M.), spring, summer, fall, winter, (Buczacki)

Tulosesus hiascens.habitat: gregarious and fasciculate [bundled], usually in bundles of more than ten; on naked soil or grassy places, (Ulje), usually in clumps, not on dung, (Moser), on open land (Hansen), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Tulosesus impatiens.habitat: among foliage (Moser), single or in small groups, on soil or leaf litter, shady woods, especially with beech, fall, (Buczacki)

Tulosesus sclerocystidiosus.nameOrigin: refers to the sclerocystidia typical of this species
Tulosesus sclerocystidiosus.habitat: scattered to gregarious or even subfasciculate, "on wet, rich soil with scattered vegetation, along drives in woods, sometimes attached to small bids [presumably 'bits' was meant] of wood"

Tulosesus velatopruinatus.habitat: usually "gregarious on old saw-dust and small pieces of wood mixed with soil", (Ulje), fruiting in a plant pot in Oregon

Turbinellus bonarii.edibility: not recommended: some cases of gastric upset (Bessette)
Turbinellus bonarii.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), mild to slightly unpleasant (Miller)
Turbinellus bonarii.habitat: scattered or in groups or clusters under conifers, often in deep humus, May to October, (Bessette), closely gregarious to cespitose [in tufts], partly hidden in deep humus under pine and fir, (Smith), closely gregarious to cespitose, partly hidden in deep humus under Pinus [pine] and Abies [fir] species, spring and fall, (Castellano)

Turbinellus floccosus.edibility: causes digestive upset in some (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea), onset can be delayed, may be due to norcaperatic acid, (Benjamin(1)), compounds have been found that may be harmful to the liver (Ammirati(1)), onset of symptoms delayed 8-14 hours, (Ammirati(11))
Turbinellus floccosus.habitat: under conifers or in mixed woods, (Lincoff), single, gregarious, or subcespitose (often at higher elevations with 2 or 3 arising from a single stem), under conifers in late summer and fall, (Smith)

Turbinellus kauffmanii.nameOrigin: after Prof. Calvin Henry Kauffman of Michigan University who collected it in Washington in 1935
Turbinellus kauffmanii.spores: ocher-yellow (Bessette), pale ochraceous in thin deposits (Smith)
Turbinellus kauffmanii.edibility: not recommended: a common cause of gastric upset, (Bessette), contains toxin norcaperatic acid, like Turbinellus floccosus (Ammirati(11))
Turbinellus kauffmanii.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), mild, sometimes slightly peppery, (Castellano)
Turbinellus kauffmanii.odour: not distinctive (Bessette), mild, often faintly to obviously aromatic, (Castellano), "sharp and penetrating but often absent in old caps", (Smith)
Turbinellus kauffmanii.habitat: single, scattered or in groups under conifers, especially hemlock, July to September, (Bessette for eastern North America), closely gregarious to cespitose [in tufts], partially hidden in deep humus under Pinus and Abies spp., (Castellano)

Typhrasa delineata.taste: mild, K. McKnight found a bitter variant, (Smith)
Typhrasa delineata.habitat: scattered to gregarious on humus or decayed wood (Smith), on woody debris (Barron)

Typhrasa gossypina.taste: mild (Orstadius from R. K. Schumacher pers. comm.)
Typhrasa gossypina.odour: none or "etwas sauerlich-kakaoartig" [umlaut on second a] (Orstadius from R. K. Schumacher pers. comm., translates as 'slightly tart - cocoalike')
Typhrasa gossypina.habitat: on ground often on burned areas, September to October, (Phillips), single, gregarious or cespitose [tufted] in hardwood or coniferous forests with Betula (birch), Fagus (beech), Quercus (oak), Picea (spruce) or Pinus (pine), "on logs, twigs, wood chips and fireplaces", (Orstadius)

Volvariella bombycina.habitat: single or in small groups "on dead hardwoods or fruiting from wounds in living trees", (Arora), single to gregarious on red maple, sugar maple, silver maple, magnolia, mango, beech, oak, American elm, (Shaffer), late summer and fall (Miller)

Volvariella hypopithys.taste: slight or none (Shaffer), slight to none (Butler)
Volvariella hypopithys.odour: slight or none (Shaffer), slight to none (Butler)
Volvariella hypopithys.habitat: single to scattered, "on humus in coniferous, deciduous, and mixed woods", (Shaffer), single or in small groups, "in soft or hard woodland humus, summer and early fall", (Butler)

Volvariella smithii.nameOrigin: after Alexander H. Smith, who collected the type
Volvariella smithii.habitat: single to scattered "on soil and humus in mixed woods" (Shaffer), single or in small groups in soil or humus in woods, (Arora)

Volvariella surrecta.habitat: single to gregarious and parasitic on Clitocybe spp. (usually C. nebularis), (Shaffer), single to gregarious on species of Clitocybe, usually Clitocybe nebularis, in fall, (Smith), also on species of Tricholoma (Breitenbach), summer and fall (Miller)

Volvariella volvacea.habitat: single to gregarious on soil or compost piles, reported in hothouses and cellars, (Shaffer), in loam in greenhouses or gardens, on sawdust or other vegetable residue, in areas where field mushrooms cultivated; spring to fall, with heat all year, (Lincoff), spring, summer, fall, winter

Volvopluteus gloiocephalus.edibility: yes, take a spore deposit because some Amanitas have pinkish gills in old age, (Arora)
Volvopluteus gloiocephalus.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious in cultivated soil, occasionally in woods, (Arora), single to gregarious "on dung or rich soil in lawns, gardens, fields, woods, and greenhouses", (Shaffer), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller), spring and summer, persisting as late as December, (Bacon), spring, summer, fall, winter

Xeromphalina brunneola.taste: disagreeable (Bessette), usually disagreeable (bitter), (Redhead), persistently disagreeable (chew thoroughly), (Miller)
Xeromphalina brunneola.habitat: dense cespitose clusters on debarked conifer logs, (Bessette), in densely cespitose clusters on debarked conifer logs, late September and early October, (Miller), fall

Xeromphalina campanella.spores: white to pale buff (Arora), 'yellow "light buff"', (Miller), cream-whitish (Breitenbach)
Xeromphalina campanella.odour: insignificant (Breitenbach), may have faint odor of household geranium, may have carrot odor, (Redhead), not distinctive (Smith), not distinctive (Miller)
Xeromphalina campanella.habitat: in groups or dense clusters on rotting conifers, (Arora), gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] "on decaying conifer sticks, logs and stumps often long after they are moss covered, usually not on newly fallen wood or fresh stumps", "usually found in gregarious to caespitose clusters on the sides of logs or stumps", summer, fall, and (where mild) winter, (Miller), densely cespitose to somewhat clustered, more rarely single, on rotten, often moss-covered stumps of conifers, (Breitenbach), very rarely on hardwoods, one on a burnt oak log, (Redhead(2))

Xeromphalina cauticinalis.habitat: colonizes litter on soil in coniferous and mixed forests, (Redhead), scattered to densely gregarious on conifer needles and debris, (Arora), fall (Buczacki)

Xeromphalina cirris.habitat: type on conifer needles; often in mountains

Xeromphalina cornui.nameOrigin: after the collector of type species, M. Cornu
Xeromphalina cornui.habitat: in sphagnum bogs or on coniferous debris

Xeromphalina fulvipes.habitat: scattered on conifer debris (Phillips), single to scattered on debris of conifers, more rarely on alder, spring and fall, key says typically gregarious to scattered or only in clusters of a few fruiting bodies, (Smith)

Xeromphalina parvibulbosa.habitat: "on coniferous debris, often in low wet areas, or in subalpine forests"

Zhuliangomyces 'illinita'.habitat: scattered or in groups in woods (Arora), "scattered or in groups in various habitats, including woods, fields, and sand dunes", July to November, (Bessette), summer, fall

Auriscalpium 'vulgare'.habitat: primarily on (often buried) Douglas-fir cones in the Pacific Northwest, (Trudell), single or in groups of two or three on rotting, often buried conifer cones, or sometimes on thick debris made up partly of decaying cones, (Arora), single or in groups of two or three on Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) cones buried in moss (Hall), on fallen rotting pinecones, also reported on Douglas-fir cones, (Lincoff(2)), on cones, typically ponderosa pine or Douglas-fir, (Tylutki), on pine cones, occasionally on spruce, Douglas-fir, and fir cones; summer and fall, (Miller), recorded mostly on Douglas-fir, but twice on Sugar Pine (Pinus lambertiana) cones in the Sierra Nevada foothills (MykoWeb)

Echinodontium tinctorium.habitat: single or several on living or occasionally downed conifers such as fir and hemlock, (Arora), perennial, primarily on Abies (true fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), rarely on other conifers, causes a yellowish laminated to stringy heartrot of living conifers, the main cause of heartrot and volume loss in true firs in western coniferous forests, (Gilbertson)

Hericium abietis.habitat: single or sometimes several together on dead conifers, especially fir and Douglas-fir, mainly in the fall, (Arora), Abies amabilis, A. concolor, A. grandis, A. lasiocarpa, A. procera, (all true fir), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce), Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga heterophylla (western hemlock), Tsuga mertensiana (mountain hemlock), (Ginns), on conifer logs, especially fir and hemlock, (Trudell), confined to coniferous wood in the Pacific Northwest (Harrison)

Hericium americanum.habitat: found on wood of hardwoods and conifers, (Ginns(5)), on old logs, dead stubs, or cankers on living trees with heart rot, (Harrison), late summer and fall (Miller)

Hericium coralloides.habitat: on hardwoods (Acer, Alnus, Betula, Carya, Fagus, Fraxinus, Populus, Quercus, Salix, Ulmus), reports on Picea need to be rechecked because they may be H. abietis, (Ginns), single or in small groups on fallen hardwood branches, logs, and stumps, (Arora), Hall records var. caput-ursi on rotting conifer wood (Hall)

Hericium erinaceus.edibility: excellent when fresh, but tougher than other Hericium species and sometimes developing a rather sour unpleasant taste when old, (Arora), significant gastrointestinal reaction has been reported (Benjamin)
Hericium erinaceus.habitat: single or rarely several together on wounds of living hardwoods or cut ends of recently felled hardwood logs, (Arora), grows from rotting wood of hardwoods, causing a heartwood rot, (Coker), late summer and fall (Miller)

Hydnellum aurantiacum.taste: bitter to farinaceous (Arora), mild or slightly unpleasant (Miller)
Hydnellum aurantiacum.odour: mild (Arora), in drying faint but distinct and fragrant, "not at all like fenugreek", and undiminished for years, (Coker), fragrant, persistent, (Phillips), pungent, disagreeable, (McKnight)
Hydnellum aurantiacum.habitat: single or in groups or sometimes in fused clusters on ground under pines and other conifers, (Arora), single or a few fruitbodies fused, on ground in duff and moss, under Douglas-fir and fir, (var. bulbipodium and var. colliculosum under Douglas-fir and hemlock), (Hall), on ground in both pine and deciduous woods, (Coker), summer and fall (Miller)

Hydnellum auratile.habitat: single or gregarious in duff and moss under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), (Hall), single or irregularly fused together in groups, on soil in mixed hardwood-conifer forests, (Breitenbach)

Hydnellum caeruleum.spores: fawn brown (Hall), brown (Arora), vinaceous brown (Harrison(3)), light brown (Bessette)
Hydnellum caeruleum.taste: strong farinaceous (Arora, Hall), not distinctive (McKnight, Harrison(3)), mild (Breitenbach), mild or slightly acid (Bessette), mild but slightly unpleasant (Miller)
Hydnellum caeruleum.odour: strong farinaceous (Arora, Hall), not distinctive (McKnight, Harrison(3)), slightly farinaceous (Breitenbach), none or slightly of cooked meat (Bessette), heavy and unpleasant, anise-like, (Miller)
Hydnellum caeruleum.habitat: single to gregarious or in fused clusters on ground under conifers or hardwoods, (Arora), gregarious to concrescent under conifers, (Harrison(3)), single or gregarious on ground in duff and moss under Abies (fir), Tsuga (hemlock) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Hall), gregarious or rarely single under pines, spruce, or other conifers, (Bessette), late summer and fall (Miller)

Hydnellum complectipes.odour: farinaceous with a slight smoky-sweetish component (var. complectipes), farinaceous (var. disjunctipes)
Hydnellum complectipes.habitat: on ground in duff or moss under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga (hemlock)

Hydnellum complicatum.odour: mildly fungoid when young, when dry slight odor of machine oil
Hydnellum complicatum.habitat: from debris under conifers (Kauffman for Oregon in Coker)

Hydnellum concrescens.odour: weak, of meal [farinaceous] (Pegler), weakly farinaceous, (Breitenbach), mealy (Phillips(2))
Hydnellum concrescens.habitat: usually concrescent [becoming joined together], occasionally single; in woodlands, associated with conifers and hardwoods, (Pegler), generally single, but often up to several concrescent; in hardwood forests, according to the literature also in conifer forests, "commonly in places covered with moss or leaf litter"; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), usually fusing together, conifer woods and hardwood woods, fall, (Phillips(2))

Hydnellum conigenum.odour: faint to lacking, (McKnight), none to farinaceous (Harrison(3))
Hydnellum conigenum.habitat: gregarious or concrescent in coniferous forests, (Harrison(3)), on fallen pine cones (Coker)

Hydnellum cumulatum.nameOrigin: named for the heaped appearance of the connate masses of caps, (Harrison(1))
Hydnellum cumulatum.taste: mild, not at all acrid, (Harrison(1)), farinaceous (Hall)
Hydnellum cumulatum.habitat: on ground in duff under Pseudotsuga and Tsuga, (Hall), single to gregarious in connate masses, appearing sessile in duff, in Nova Scotia under Pinus resinosa and Tsuga canadensis, found on edges of small hollows and in depressions around exposed roots, in unused rodent burrows, (Harrison(1))

Hydnellum cyanopodium.habitat: single, gregarious, or concrescent under Sitka spruce and pine (type from California)

Hydnellum fuscoindicum.taste: mild to somewhat farinaceous or cinnamon-like, can cause a burning sensation in the throat (Arora), mild (Harrison), farinaceous (Hall)
Hydnellum fuscoindicum.odour: mild to somewhat farinaceous or cinnamon-like (Arora), mild, occasionally mentioned as of cinnamon and penetrating, (Harrison), farinaceous (Hall)
Hydnellum fuscoindicum.habitat: scattered to gregarious on ground in woods, in the Pacific Northwest under conifers, especially hemlock and pine, further south grows under tanoak and madrone, (Arora), single, gregarious to somewhat cespitose, under pines and in coniferous woods, (Harrison)

Hydnellum geogenium.habitat: single or often fused with others; in coniferous forests; August to October, (Phillips), locally common under spruce and fir in coastal areas, (Barron for northeastern North America), single to gregarious, on soil "in mountain spruce forests, commonly in dense young growth in sunny locations", summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Hydnellum mirabile.taste: faint, somewhat farinaceous but finally slowly peppery, (Harrison(3))
Hydnellum mirabile.odour: faint of raw cucumber or somewhat farinaceous, (Harrison(3)), farinaceous (Phillips)
Hydnellum mirabile.habitat: gregarious, subcespitose, in mixed and coniferous woods, (Harrison(3)), single to clustered in mixed woods, (Phillips)

Hydnellum nigellum.habitat: closely gregarious under spruce in Nova Scotia; "habit of growing from deep within needles and moss"

Hydnellum peckii.nameOrigin: named after C.H. Peck who collected the type
Hydnellum peckii.taste: typically extremely peppery (Arora), peppery (Breitenbach), farinaceous but with a peppery after-taste in the throat, remaining peppery when dried, (Harrison(3))
Hydnellum peckii.odour: mild to fragrant or pungent (Arora), weakly sour (Breitenbach), slightly disagreeable (Lincoff)
Hydnellum peckii.habitat: single to scattered, gregarious, or in fused clusters on ground under conifers, (Arora), single (sometimes concrescent) or gregarious-cespitose on soil among mosses and needle litter in conifer forest, (Breitenbach), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Hydnellum regium.spores: pale brown in thin deposit (Harrison), brown (Hall)
Hydnellum regium.taste: disagreeable or mealy, slightly bitter, not noted in others and assumed to be mild, (Harrison), slightly peppery (Phillips), not distinct (Hall)
Hydnellum regium.odour: pungent aromatic in one, faint or none in other collections, (Harrison), fragrant, heavy, (Phillips), slightly farinaceous (Hall)
Hydnellum regium.habitat: single or gregarious under conifers, (Harrison), on ground in duff under Thuja, Tsuga (hemlock), and Alnus (alder), (Hall)

Hydnellum scabrosum.taste: "strongly bitter and/or acrid to farinaceous" (Arora), bitter to slightly peppery-farinaceous, in stem mild to farinaceous-bitter, (Hall), very bitter (McKnight), strongly bitter (Breitenbach), very bitter (Harrison(8)), bitter (Franklin)
Hydnellum scabrosum.odour: farinaceous or smoky (Arora), farinaceous to smoky, in stem farinaceous, (Hall), faint (McKnight), farinaceous (Breitenbach), slight (Harrison(8))
Hydnellum scabrosum.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious on ground under conifers or sometimes hardwoods, (Arora), single or gregarious in coniferous or occasionally mixed woods (Harrison(8)), fall (Buczacki)

Hydnellum scrobiculatum.nameOrigin: means 'scrobiculate' (pitted with conspicuous wet-appearing slightly depressed areas)
Hydnellum scrobiculatum.taste: mild to farinaceous (Arora), farinaceous, mild, (Breitenbach), mild to slightly farinaceous (Hall), mildly like some pine-tar product (Coker), mild, slightly pungent to farinaceous-disagreeable; var. zonatum mild, one collection rancid, (Harrison(3))
Hydnellum scrobiculatum.odour: mild to farinaceous (Arora), farinaceous, mild; when dry with weak spicy odor of Maggi, (Breitenbach), farinaceous (Hall), not strong, slightly acid-fungoid (Coker), mild, slightly pungent to farinaceous-disagreeable; var. zonatum slight, (Harrison(3))
Hydnellum scrobiculatum.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in fused clusters in woods, usually with conifers, (Arora), single or several concrescent, on soil in conifer or mixed conifer-hardwood forest, (Breitenbach), single, gregarious, or concrescent, in hardwood woods and conifer woods, (Harrison(3) for Michigan), on ground in duff and moss, under Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga (hemlock), (Hall), fall (Buczacki)

Hydnellum suaveolens.taste: mild to somewhat bitter, (Breitenbach), none (Coker), mild to slightly cinnamon-like (Phillips), mild or slightly cinnamon-like (Harrison)
Hydnellum suaveolens.odour: "often strongly fragrant (like anise or peppermint)", sometimes absent (Arora), pleasantly anise-like or coumarin-like, pronounced, (Breitenbach), "variable in intensity, faint when first collected but after a few hours usually distinctly aromatic as of wintergreen or peppermint and persisting for many years", (Coker), coumarin or anisealdehyde (Hall), strong, sweet or sickly, (Phillips), strongly fragrant (sickening-sweetish), (Harrison)
Hydnellum suaveolens.habitat: single to gregarious or in fused clusters under conifers (Arora), singly to fused, under Tsuga (hemlock), and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Hall), under conifers, often under hemlock mixed with rhododendron (Coker), usually concrescent to form large expanses, under conifers, (Breitenbach), occasionally in arcs, (Harrison), summer and fall (Miller)

Hydnellum subsuccosum.habitat: gregarious to confluent under conifers, (Harrison), on ground in duff and moss, under Pinus (pine) or Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), (Hall)

Hydnellum subzonatum.nameOrigin: means "somewhat zonate" or "close to [H. scrobiculatum var.] zonatum"
Hydnellum subzonatum.habitat: "gregarious, connate", under spruce on Cape Split, Nova Scotia

Hydnellum underwoodii.taste: bitter in cap, farinaceous or bitter in stem, (Hall), extremely bitter (Harrison), bitter (Coker), very bitter (Baird)
Hydnellum underwoodii.odour: slightly smoky or farinaceous in cap, farinaceous in stem, (Hall), slightly fragrant (Baird)
Hydnellum underwoodii.habitat: on ground in duff under Abies (fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), (Hall), under hardwoods (Harrison), in moist deciduous woods (Coker), associated with hardwoods (Baird)

Hydnellum versipelle.taste: mild to somewhat bitter with a farinaceous component (Breitenbach), none or fungoid (Hall), farinaceous (Harrison(4)), mild or slightly peppery (Smith), mild or slightly acrid [peppery] in some collections (Harrison(8))
Hydnellum versipelle.odour: pleasantly spicy (Breitenbach), fenugreek when collected, becoming smoky, (Hall), unpleasant (Harrison(4)), mildly medicinal (Smith), mildly medicinal (Harrison(8))
Hydnellum versipelle.habitat: single, gregarious, or in dense clusters, on soil in conifer and mixed conifer-hardwood forests, summer to fall, (Breitenbach), singly but grouped in a small area under Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa pine), (Hall), single, gregarious, or clustered, in Nova Scotia under spruce and fir (Smith), single, gregarious, occasionally cespitose [in tufts], under spruce and hemlock in Nova Scotia, (Harrison(8))

Hydnum melitosarx.nameOrigin: in reference to the honey color of the fruitbodies (Niskanen(10))
Hydnum melitosarx.habitat: in mixed forests (Pinus (pine), Picea (spruce), Fagus (beech), Quercus (oak), Corylus (hazel)); fruiting in fall

Hydnum melleopallidum.nameOrigin: "refers to the pale honey color" of the fruitbodies
Hydnum melleopallidum.habitat: holotype from mixed old-growth coniferous forest, 21 August

Hydnum olympicum.nameOrigin: "in reference to the first location found in Olympic National Park, named after Mt. Olympus in Washington", (Niskanen)
Hydnum olympicum.habitat: in coniferous forest, fruiting in fall

Hydnum oregonense.nameOrigin: referring to the type locality in Oregon
Hydnum oregonense.habitat: in coniferous forests (Pinus muricata - Bishop Pine, Pseudotsuga menziesii - Douglas-fir, Tsuga heterophylla - Western Hemlock), fruiting in late spring and fall

Hydnum repandum.nameOrigin: from Latin, "bent backwards", (Lincoff(1)), from Latin "repandum" meaning "spreading", (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Hydnum repandum.edibility: yes, peppery taste disappears with cooking, (Arora)
Hydnum repandum.taste: mild to somewhat bitter or peppery, (Arora), none (Hall), mild to rather sharpish (Breitenbach), older specimens may taste bitter (Sept(1))
Hydnum repandum.habitat: single, scattered, gregarious, or in troops under hardwoods and conifers, throughout the mushroom season but in California peaking in late winter or early spring, (Arora), single or gregarious in duff and moss under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies (fir), and Tsuga (hemlock), (Hall), summer and fall (Miller)

Hydnum 'umbilicatum'.habitat: single or gregarious, on ground in duff of coniferous forests, (Castellano), single or gregarious on ground in duff under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies (fir), or Tsuga (hemlock), (Hall)

Hydnum washingtonianum.habitat: with conifers (Abies - true fir, Picea - spruce, Pinus - pine), fruiting in fall, (Niskanen), on ground in conifer woods (Swenie)

Mucronella 'bresadolae'.nameOrigin: 'of Bresadola', probably referring to Giacopo Bresadola 1847-1929, Italian mycologist
Mucronella 'bresadolae'.habitat: on rotten wood and bark (?always coniferous), (Corner(3)), on very rotten wood or old polypores, (Breitenbach)

Mucronella calva.habitat: on rotten pine wood (Corner(2)), on rotten conifer wood, (Corner(3) for BC specimen), in clusters, sometimes covering a fairly large area on sides or undersides of large, well-rotted conifer logs, often Douglas fir, (Siegel), on the underside of small rotten trunks of Picea (spruce) lying on the ground, (Breitenbach), in small to large groups, on rotting wood, usually old trunks or stumps of conifers, typically on the underside, occasionally on hardwood; late summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Mucronella fusiformis.habitat: type illustrated by Kauffman showing over 50 fruitbodies on a small piece of wood, (Harrison), on decayed coniferous wood, (Corner(2)); on well-rotted, very wet, fallen stump of ancient tree, (Dentinger(1))

Mucronella pendula.habitat: "single, gregarious or occasionally cespitose or two or three fasciculate"; generally on conifer wood, associated with a brown rot; cited collections in October and November

Phellodon atratus.odour: mild or faintly fragrant (Arora), none to smoky fungoid (Harrison), fenugreek in cap, faintly smoky in stem, (Hall)
Phellodon atratus.habitat: scattered to gregarious, on ground under conifers, especially Sitka spruce, (Arora), gregarious, compound and often concrescent [becoming joined], under conifers, (Harrison), singly or in extensive patches in duff under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies (fir), or Tsuga (hemlock), (Hall)

Phellodon fuligineoalbus.taste: not distinctive when fresh (Harrison), none (Baird), mild (Breitenbach, Miller)
Phellodon fuligineoalbus.odour: when fresh not distinctive, "when dried the odor distinctive (as in most species of Phellodon)", (Harrison), odor "of light fenugreek when dry" (Baird), weak, but when dry intensely like Maggi, (Breitenbach), slight or of fenugreek or curry (Miller)
Phellodon fuligineoalbus.habitat: single to scattered or widely gregarious, usually under pine, (Harrison), single to gregarious under conifers, specifically under pine, (Baird), single to gregarious or clustered on soil in dry pine forests, (Breitenbach for Europe), summer and fall (Miller)
