Phellodon melaleucus.taste: mild to somewhat bitter (Breitenbach), not distinguishable (Hall), mild (Harrison)
Phellodon melaleucus.odour: when drying like Maggi seasoning (Breitenbach), of fenugreek, especially when dried, (Hall), none, but "has the strongly fragrant odor of most Phellodon species when dried", (Harrison)
Phellodon melaleucus.habitat: gregarious to concrescent [growing joined] in large masses, under conifers, (Harrison(3)), single or in small groups, on ground in duff under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), or Tsuga (hemlock), (Hall), cespitose or in fairy rings, in mixed conifer-hardwood forests, (Breitenbach)

Phellodon tomentosus.taste: mild or slightly bitter (Arora), "mild or slightly sweetish with a slight biting reaction in the throat", (Harrison), none (Hall), faintly sweetish-bitter (Coker)
Phellodon tomentosus.odour: usually fragrant (like fenugreek) (Arora), faint to slightly fragrant of fenugreek as fruitbodies dry, (Harrison), fenugreek to fungoid (Hall), faintly fragrant, not noticeably of fenugreek, more like rabbit tobacco (Gnaphalium obtusifolium), when dried, distinct of blackstrap molasses, (Coker), when drying like Maggi seasoning, (Breitenbach), faint, indefinite, pleasant, spicy when dry, (Buczacki)
Phellodon tomentosus.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious or clustered under conifers, (Arora), gregarious to cespitose and often forming extensive concrescent patches or arcs under conifers, (Harrison), on ground in duff and moss under Tsuga (hemlock) and Abies (fir), (Hall), cespitose or in fairy rings, in conifer or mixed forests, (Breitenbach), fall (Bacon), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Phellodon violascens.odour: faintly fragrant, strongly fragrant when dried, (Harrison), fragrant like maple syrup when fresh, soon disappearing after picking, (Bessette), pleasant, when dry intensely like Maggi, (Breitenbach)
Phellodon violascens.habitat: single, gregarious, to cespitose under conifers, (Harrison), single, scattered, or in groups on ground under conifers or in mixed woods, (Bessette), usually single, also gregarious and in groups, on soil in conifer forests under Picea (spruce), (at least in Europe), (Breitenbach)

Sarcodon atroviridis.odour: rather pleasant, aromatic-woody, (Coker), none to slight when fresh, soon having a smell of a strong acid, (Baird)
Sarcodon atroviridis.habitat: terrestrial (Banker), in the southern Appalachians single to gregarious, Acer rubrum (Red Maple) and Liriodendron tulipifera always present and Tsuga canadensis found at most sites, (Baird)

Sarcodon calvatus.taste: mild then slowly bitter, not farinaceous (in var. odoratum mild or in the type faintly farinaceous), (Harrison(1)), mild to spicy-fragrant to farinaceous (Arora for H. calvatum group)
Sarcodon calvatus.odour: pungent in var. calvatus, fragrant in var. odoratus, (Harrison(4)), not distinctive in var. calvatus, in var. odoratum spicy, similar to that of Hydnellum suaveolens, (Harrison(1)), in var. odoratum fragrant, of coumarin or vanilla extract, (Hall), variable, mild to spicy-fragrant to farinaceous (Arora for H. calvatum group)
Sarcodon calvatus.habitat: "in groups or clumps, often with small or aborted fruiting bodies present, on ground in mixed woods and under conifers", (Arora), sometimes concrescent [growing joined together]; cespitose [in tufts], gregarious in coniferous forests (var. odoratum under alder and willow, near fir), (Harrison(1))

Sarcodon imbricatus.nameOrigin: from Latin, meaning "covered with tiles", from the cap appearance, (Lincoff(1))
Sarcodon imbricatus.spores: brown (Arora, Hall), fawn color in light deposits, buffy brown in heavy ones, (Coker)
Sarcodon imbricatus.edibility: yes, but often bitter, causes indigestion in some people, (Arora)
Sarcodon imbricatus.taste: mild to bitter (Arora), mild (Hall), astringent or slightly bitter (Lincoff(1)), slightly bitter (Harrison(8))
Sarcodon imbricatus.odour: "mild or when dry somewhat smoky or chocolate-like" (Arora), faint (Hall), weakly and pleasantly spicy (Breitenbach), slightly iodized, sometimes horse-like, (Lincoff(1))
Sarcodon imbricatus.habitat: single to gregarious on ground under conifers or hardwoods, late spring, summer, or fall, (Arora), single on ground in duff and moss, under pine, (Hall), single to clustered, often in fairy rings, (McKnight)

Sarcodon indurescens.nameOrigin: means 'becoming hard', referring to the hard consistency of dried specimens
Sarcodon indurescens.odour: mouldy with a spicy component, in stem "pleasant like that of the pileus"
Sarcodon indurescens.habitat: single on ground in duff under pine

Sarcodon leucopus.taste: none or farinaceous (Hall), almost none (Coker), bitter after some time (Maas Geesteranus via Franklin)
Sarcodon leucopus.odour: slightly smoky or medicinal in cap, in stem none or slightly smoky, (in description, but then later and in key they say distinctly farinaceous when fresh specimens cut open), (Hall), none, but it is noted that Bresadola described a strong nauseous odor, (Coker), commonly experienced as disagreeable (Maas Geesteranus via Franklin)
Sarcodon leucopus.habitat: single on ground in duff under Abies (fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), (Hall), in dense pine duff (Coker)

Sarcodon rimosus.taste: not distinctive, two collections noted as peppery, (Harrison), variable, farinaceous to peppery-farinaceous, (Hall), absent to mildly farinaceous (Franklin)
Sarcodon rimosus.odour: not distinctive (Harrison), smoky or farinaceous (Hall), absent to weakly farinaceous (Franklin)
Sarcodon rimosus.habitat: gregarious under pines, one record under "conifers" (Harrison), single or in small groups, on ground in duff and moss, under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies (fir), or Tsuga (hemlock), under bushes of evergreen huckleberry, (Hall), associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and hardwood forests, fruiting October through December, (Franklin)

Sarcodon squamosus.edibility: edible "but not recommended; often bitter and slightly astringent"
Sarcodon squamosus.taste: mild, "or occasionally slightly bitter-farinaceous and/or astringent"
Sarcodon squamosus.habitat: single or in scattered troops, "often forming arcs and rows on ground under conifers", especially pine on the North Coast [of California, also occurs with chinquapin in California]; early fall into winter in California

Sarcodon stereosarcinon.taste: none (Baird(1)), slightly farinaceous (Smith), slight, farinaceous, (Harrison), absent to mildly pungent (Franklin)
Sarcodon stereosarcinon.odour: none (Baird(1), Harrison), absent to weakly pungent or farinaceous, (Franklin)
Sarcodon stereosarcinon.habitat: single to concrescent; Coker and Beers indicated that Sarcodon brevipes was always found under conifers, (Baird(1)), single, gregarious or fused, under conifers, (Smith), single, gregarious or connate, under spruce and fir in Nova Scotia, (Harrison)

Sarcodon subincarnatus.taste: very bitter to farinaceous (Harrison), slightly bitter (Hall), very bitter-farinaceous (Smith)
Sarcodon subincarnatus.odour: farinaceous, pungent, penetrating as of chlorine or cucumber, (Harrison), farinaceous (Hall), farinaceous and pungent (Smith)
Sarcodon subincarnatus.habitat: single, gregarious, or cespitose [in tufts], under oaks and pines, (Harrison), single or in small groups, on ground under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), or Tsuga (hemlock), (Hall), single, gregarious, or cespitose [tufted] under oak and pine, (Smith)

Crucibulum crucibuliforme.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious "on sticks, wood chips, nut shells, vegetable debris, humus, and manure", (Arora), "on stems, twigs, old nut shells, chips, old matting, and on manure", but not on soil or large logs, (Brodie(1)), on decaying logs and twigs, July to October, (Phillips), spring to late fall (Lincoff(1))

Crucibulum parvulum.habitat: fruits on old or dead roots of Juniperus horizontalis and stems of Artemisia spp., dead stems of Tetradymia and Atriplex, (Brodie(1))

Cyathus helenae.habitat: type growing on dead stems and roots on mountain scree, (an occasional fruitbody anchored to a small stone), altitude 7000 feet in Alberta, (Brodie(2)), as far as is known alpine and boreal in habitat except for collections from dry areas of Idaho, (Brodie(1)), can occur on manure (Arora)

Cyathus olla.nameOrigin: from Latin, a pot, from the shape, (Lincoff)
Cyathus olla.habitat: especially on black soils and on old wood, including old boards and dead stems of perennial plants, usually in rather shaded and very moist conditions, (Brodie(1)), fruits in fall, although the empty cups are persistent, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), July to October (Phillips), on thin soil, roots, or rotting sticks, in flower pots, (Lincoff)

Cyathus pygmaeus.habitat: attached to old dead stems of shrubby plants of arid areas; also on dung, (Brodie(1)), attached to wood stems of Artemisia, Chrysothamnus, and Sarcobatus, mostly collected between February and April in essentially desert areas with annual precipitation of 7-10 inches, (Brodie(4)), gregarious on dead twigs, typically in arid habitats, (Zhao)

Cyathus stercoreus.habitat: densely gregarious on ground, manure and other organic debris, in California almost any season, (Arora), chiefly on dung, but also fruits on manured soil, (Brodie), horse manure, rotten plant remains, burnt sites, (Courtecuisse), scattered or in dense clusters on dung, manured soil, and sawdust piles; July to October, (Phillips)

Cyathus striatus.nameOrigin: means "with fine grooves and ridges" from Latin "stria" meaning "furrow", (Brodie(1))
Cyathus striatus.habitat: in open woodland on small twigs and woody leaf mould, occasionally in gardens, (Brodie(1)), can grow in manure, but more common on sticks and other vegetable matter, (Arora), scattered or in groups on dead wood or vegetable debris in open woods, July to October, (Phillips), on dead wood, bark, twigs, and wood chips, in open woods, (Lincoff(2)), "on decaying plant materials such as wood chips, small branches, and needles", (Trudell)

Mycocalia denudata.habitat: decaying leaves of Juncus effusus, decaying grass culms, hardwood or coniferous wood (logs, branches, twigs or chips, from apparently sound to severely decayed, usually barkless, mainly on underside in contact with soil or at the junction between soil and wood), charcoal (once), dead Rubus canes, Vaccinium debris, Pteridium debris, moss, rabbit or sheep dung, generally developing in acidic damp conditions, collected in every month except January and February, (Palmer for United Kingdom), on rotting wood and other plant debris in wet acidic habitats, "often on debris of rushes and sedges, also on old herbivore dung"; in small to large trooping or +/- fused groups; summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Nidula candida.nameOrigin: from Latin "candida" meaning "shining white", a misnomer since it is not shining or white, (Arora)
Nidula candida.habitat: in groups, "on rotting wood, berry canes, and herbaceous debris in gardens, woods, along streams, etc.", in California common in late fall and winter or even spring, but empty nests persisting for months, (Arora), on old berry canes, rotten wood, or rich soil, June to October, (Phillips)

Nidula niveotomentosa.habitat: usually on sticks or in moss, (Arora), often seen growing among mosses, in BC grows invariably in close association with bracken fern, (Brodie), on old wood, bracken, berry canes, (Fay)

Nidularia deformis.habitat: several to many "on wood and wood debris of both hardwoods and conifers"; summer and fall, (Miller)

Nidularia pulvinata.habitat: on a variety of kinds of old wood, occasionally on driftwood; moist mixed hardwoods in Ontario, fairly common on driftwood in BC, (Brodie)

Sphaerobolus stellatus.habitat: gregarious on rotting wood, sawdust, plant debris, and dung or manure, (Arora), hardwood, twigs, rotten pine, packed sawdust, horse dung, May to September, (Lincoff(2)), typically "gregarious on rotting wood, sticks, leaves, or sawdust", all year, (Lincoff(1))

Adelphella babingtonii.nameOrigin: named for Mr. Babington, collector of type
Adelphella babingtonii.habitat: on water-soaked rotten logs, sometimes underwater, or on leaves and woody debris or on encrusted algae, (Pfister), single or gregarious, "On wet dead wood and spruce cones, also on other rotting plant parts (for example Carex), in drainage ditches and obstructions in streams", May to September (in Europe), (Breitenbach)

Albotricha albotestacea.nameOrigin: means 'white-testaceous', 'testaceus' indicating an orangy pink or brick color
Albotricha albotestacea.habitat: scattered on dead grasses, Phragmites, Andropogon, and undetermined, (Seaver), on grass, May, (Kanouse), on grasses (Hansen), collections examined on grass and on sedge (Haines)

Albotricha washingtonensis.nameOrigin: 'washingtonensis' means 'from Washington'; 'pteridis' means 'of Pteris' referring to host
Albotricha washingtonensis.habitat: sparse, superficial, (Dennis), on Dryopteris fern (Hansen, L., for northern Europe), single on stems of Pteris sp. (a fern), (Seaver), on old stems of Pteris (in another part of the description on fern leaves), (Kanouse), only known from the fern Pteridium aquilinum (bracken fern) [at least in western Washington], common in spring, (Haines(1))

Aleuria aurantia.habitat: scattered to gregarious or in fused clusters on ground, preferring bare soil or sand along roads, paths, landslides, etc., but also in grass or moss, (Arora), in groups or clusters on hard or disturbed soil in gardens, in grass, or along roadsides, (Phillips), on west coast fruits in spring and fall but most abundant in fall (McKnight), summer and fall (Bacon)

Anthracobia macrocystis.habitat: on burnt ground, July to October, (Dennis for UK), gregarious to crowded on burned ground (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Anthracobia melaloma.habitat: on burnt wood and sites of bonfires, July to January (Dennis for UK), gregarious on burned ground and charred wood (Breitenbach for Switzerland), clustered or crowded, often in broad masses, (Lincoff)

Ascobolus albidus.habitat: scattered or gregarious, superficial, on dung of cow, horse, sheep, goat, moose, dog, wolf, rabbit, hare and muskrat, (Brummelen), "on dung, especially that of cow but also that of horse, sheep and rabbit, throughout the year", (Dennis), on dung of herbivores (Hansen)

Ascobolus carbonarius.habitat: gregarious or crowded on charcoal, burnt vegetable debris, and burnt soil, rarely on humid soil without remnants of a fire, (Brummelen), sometimes single but usually gregarious to crowded, on burned ground, March to August, (Breitenbach)

Ascobolus crenulatus.nameOrigin: from Latin 'crenulatus', diminutive of 'crenatus', meaning 'notched'; means 'crenulate' (finely scalloped)
Ascobolus crenulatus.habitat: single to gregarious on dung of various animals, such as deer, dogs, and goats, principally in winter months, (Breitenbach), gregarious, superficial on "dung of grouse, pheasant, partridge, pigeon, raven, deer, porcupine, fox, dog, and rabbit, but also on paper saturated with dog urine, on rotten leaves of oak and on rotten leaves and stalks of herbs", (Brummelen)

Ascobolus foliicola.habitat: single or gregarious on rotten leaves, stems, wood and bark of plants, (Brummelen)

Ascobolus geophilus.habitat: scattered, gregarious or crowded on humid soil, especially when covered with algae, also on bark of a tree covered with mud, (Brummelen)

Ascobolus immersus.nameOrigin: "from Latin, immersus, plunged, below the surface", (Brummelen)
Ascobolus immersus.habitat: in dung of cow and many other animals, especially in fall, (Dennis), scattered or gregarious on dung of cow, horse, sheep, goat, dog, hare, rabbit, (Brummelen), scattered or thickly gregarious, but not usually crowded, on dung of various kinds, especially after it has weathered for a long time, (Seaver)

Ascobolus lignatilis.habitat: scattered or gregarious on rotten wood, branches or leaves, on manure heap, on rotten straw and old paper, on humus in a hothouse, on owl-pellets, on dung of cows and humans, and on all kinds of substrates that have been dirtied or mixed with dung or urine, (Brummelen)

Ascobolus michaudii.habitat: gregarious or scattered on dung of cow, horse, and rabbit, (Brummelen)

Ascobolus stercorarius.habitat: sometimes single, but usually gregarious to crowded on dung, principally of cow, (Breitenbach), single or gregarious on dung of cow, horse, deer, goat, bear, pig, fox, rabbit, and hare, on manured soil, on rotten refuse, and on rotten stems of cabbage, (Brummelen)

Ascobolus viridis.habitat: scattered or gregarious on humid soil, especially in woods, (Brummelen), on rich soil, often only one or two fruiting bodies, summer to fall, (Hansen)

Atropellis pinicola.habitat: single or gregarious, erupting from outer layers of bark on living branches of Pinus lambertiana, Pinus monticola, Pinus strobus, and Pinus contorta

Atropellis piniphila.habitat: Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine) and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine) (Weir)

Belonidium cenangioides.habitat: superficial, on dead herbaceous stems, at 6000 feet (1800 m), June, in UT; on decaying stems of Mertensia paniculata, at 6000-7000 feet (1800-2100 m), September, in WA

Belonidium sulphureum.habitat: gregarious to densely cespitose on "dead stems of Urtica (nettle), as well as other herbs, especially Umbelliferae (carrot family)", April to October, (Breitenbach), especially on Urtica but also found on Anthriscus (chervil), (Hansen), on herbaceous stems, on Sambucus sp., on Rubus stems, (Kanouse), scattered on dead herbaceous stems, (Seaver)

Belonioscypha miniata.habitat: on old stems of Carex, the infected area of the leaf blade was outlined by an irregular darkened band that did not touch the fungus, (Kanouse)

Bisporella sulfurina.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to sulfur' because of its color
Bisporella sulfurina.habitat: gregarious or in small clusters "on hardwood logs, usually associated with old, black, crustose fruitbodies of a pyrenomycete", fall through early spring, (Desjardin), often "in small masses of many fruitbodies or in scattered troops on decaying logs, branches or woody debris, almost always with small, round, black fruitbodies of a Pyrenomycete present", generally "found on oak and Tanoak, but will occur on many different hardwoods", (Siegel), occasionally single, "but usually compactly clustered and fused at the base", growing on dead branches of hardwood trees, "usually on old fruiting bodies of Sphaeriales", fall-spring, (Breitenbach)

Byssonectria cartilaginea.habitat: directly associated with rodent dung, in the western mountains of the US and Canada, generally early in the season as the snow is melting, (Pfister)

Byssonectria terrestris.habitat: gregarious or more often crowded together into confluent masses, on the ground, (Seaver), "covering and binding leaves, mosses, pine needles, and twigs and on soil in areas where animals have urinated", "dung sometimes present"; found in early spring, (Pfister)

Calathella ellisii.habitat: on branches of Salix sp. (willow), (Cooke for Flagelloscypha coloradensis), single to gregarious on branches of Salix sp., (Cooke for Lachnella oregonensis)

Calathella eruciformis.habitat: often widely scattered, but sometimes occurring in groups of 2 or 3, occasionally appearing aggregated into small dense colonies, (Reid), on bark, dead wood, fallen branches, twigs, barkless logs, herbage, on Populus and Salix, (Ginns), single to gregarious, on dead wood and herbage, usually on Populus species, but also on other hardwoods and Juncus, (Cooke)

Calloria atrosanguinea.nameOrigin: from "ater" meaning "black" and "sanguineus" meaning "of blood, bloody"
Calloria atrosanguinea.habitat: gregarious, parasitic on the mycelium of a Stereum on conifer logs

Caloscypha fulgens.edibility: poisonous at least to some individuals, (Ammirati)
Caloscypha fulgens.habitat: "on soil among mosses or sometimes attached to buried rotten wood, apparently only under conifers", generally in May in Canada, but as early as mid-April in BC, (Ginns), fruiting shortly after snow melts (Arora), single to gregarious on mossy ground or needle and leaf litter, in hardwood and coniferous forests, March to May, may be mycorrhizal with Abies, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), in boggy places and in mountainous coniferous areas (Lincoff), single, scattered or in clusters, (Ammirati)

Calycina citrina.habitat: gregarious and cespitose on dead branches of hardwoods, usually covering entire branches, (Breitenbach), gregarious, on wood or erumpent from bark, (Dennis), in large numbers on dead wood of hardwoods (Phillips), spring to fall (Lincoff(1)), in large numbers on hardwood branches that have lost their bark (Trudell)

Calyptella capula.habitat: on senescent stems of Medicago sativa, Lathyrus sp., Lactuca serriola var. integrata, Cirsium arvense, Symphytum officinale, leaves of Carex sp.; in fields, swamps and wet depressions back of coastal dunes, near the ground level, (Redhead(35)), gregarious, without subiculum, on dead wood and herbaceous litter (Cooke), dead wood, dead stems, herbs and grass litter, Carex sp., Cirsium arvense, Eupatorium sp., Foeniculum sp., Lactuca serriola, Lathyrus sp., Medicago sativa, Pelargonium zonale, Pteretis pensylvanica, Symphytum officinale, (Ginns), single to gregarious on dead plant remains and dead wood in damp places, (Breitenbach), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Capitotricha bicolor.habitat: found most frequently on old canes of salmonberry and other Rubus species, but also common on branches of hardwoods such as Alnus (alder), (Trudell), gregarious to cespitose on fallen twigs and branches of hardwoods, (Breitenbach), closely gregarious, or scattered, on small twigs of various trees and shrubs, (Seaver), on small twigs, July to September, (Phillips), on deciduous twigs (Hansen)

Cenangium acuum.habitat: on needles of Pinus strobus and other pine species, (Seaver), on needles of Pinus (pine) and Juniperus (juniper), early summer to early fall, (Hansen)

Cenangium ferruginosum.nameOrigin: means "ferruginous", presumably referring to reddish-brown powder that coats exterior
Cenangium ferruginosum.habitat: singly or in small clusters on dead twigs and small branches of Pinus, (Dennis), "gregarious, usually occurring in cespitose clusters", "on branches of various species of Pinus, Abies, Picea and probably other conifers", (Seaver), on twigs and small branches of Pinus, (Hansen)

Chaetothiersia vernalis.habitat: gregarious to cespitose (tufted) on decaying wood and bark of conifers and on woody debris in soil; fruiting April to June, associated with moisture produced by spring snowmelt

Cheilymenia fimicola.habitat: scattered to gregarious, on dung, (Denison), single to densely gregarious "on dung and manure or compost, etc., fruiting in wet weather", (Arora), gregarious or scattered on dung (Seaver), on cow patties as well as the droppings of wild animals, (Trudell)

Cheilymenia stercorea.habitat: scattered to gregarious on dung, (Denison), single or gregarious on cow and deer manure, perhaps on dung of other animals, (Breitenbach)

Cheilymenia theleboloides.habitat: gregarious to crowded on dung, rich soil, or decaying plant debris, (Denison), cow dung or occasionally rich soil, rubbish, paper, cloth, etc., (Seaver), "on spent hops, less often on leaf-mould or lime waste," (Dennis), gregarious on rotting remains of plants and decomposed paper, as well as horse manure mixed with straw, (Breitenbach), "on rotting plant remains, or horse manure and straw", (Trudell)

Chlorencoelia versiformis.nameOrigin: from Latin "verso", meaning "to turn up, to turn hither and thither", plus "formo", meaning "to shape or form", "referring to the fact that the shape of the apothecium may be spathuloid or otideoid and sometimes convoluted", (Dixon)
Chlorencoelia versiformis.habitat: superficial, single to gregarious, occasionally in cespitose clusters from a common stem, on decayed wood of conifers and hardwood trees, collected on Betula (birch), Nothofagus (southern beech), Quercus (oak), Tsuga (hemlock), and unidentified wood; fruiting in summer and fall, most frequently in fall

Chlorociboria aeruginascens.nameOrigin: "from Latin, aeruginosus, deep-green with a mixture of blue, + -ascens, becoming, perhaps referring to the fact that the wood becomes aeruginous", (Dixon)
Chlorociboria aeruginascens.habitat: single to gregarious on barkless and decayed wood; spring, summer, and fall, (Dixon), on rotting logs and barkless wood, especially oak, (Lincoff)

Chlorociboria aeruginosa.nameOrigin: "from Latin, aeruginosus, deep-green, with a mixture of blue, referring to color of fruitbody", (Dixon)
Chlorociboria aeruginosa.habitat: single to gregarious on decayed and barkless wood; spring, summer, and fall

Chloroscypha alutipes.habitat: gregarious on dead foliage of Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-Cedar), (Seaver)

Ciboria amentacea.habitat: on mummified catkins of Alnus incana and Salix discolor (Seaver), "solitary or in small groups on old, fallen alder and willow catkins", usually fruiting in the spring, (Arora), on fallen male catkins of Alnus and Salix, (Dennis)

Ciboria caucus.habitat: arising from mummified sclerotium in fallen catkins of Populus tremuloides and Salix, (Seaver), on catkins of Populus, Salix, and Alnus, exceptionally Corylus, fruiting in spring and early summer, (Hansen)

Ciboria gordonii.nameOrigin: named after C.C. Gordon (1928-1981), forest mycologist, University of Montana, (Funk(8))
Ciboria gordonii.habitat: on dead retained needles of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)

Ciboria rufofusca.nameOrigin: means 'rufous-fuscous' referring to color of fruitbody
Ciboria rufofusca.habitat: single to a few per scale, on damp scales of Abies (fir) cones lying on ground, April to May, (Breitenbach), on stromatized cone scales of Abies, spring and early summer, (Hansen), on scales of Abies cones, May and June, (Kanouse)

Ciboria seminicola.habitat: single or two or three arising from a seed, on seeds of Alnus rubra (Red Alder)

Ciborinia whetzelii.habitat: fruitbodies on sclerotia lying on ground that have dehisced from the leaves of Populus tremuloides, (Seaver), sclerotia on aspen and cottonwood leaves, (Allen), on aspen, rarely on balsam poplar, (Callan)

Cistella geelmuydenii.habitat: on hardwood, noted from Fagus (beech), (Hansen), on wood debris (Kanouse)

Cistella xylita.habitat: on wood of conifers (Hansen), Nannfeldt said to limit this species to Populus, Kanouse collection appears to be on Alnus rubra (Red Alder), (Kanouse)

Claussenomyces olivaceus.habitat: superficial, scattered, on resinous exudates of conifers

Claussenomyces pini.habitat: single or subcespitose in a stem of Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), collection made in mid-winter

Coprotus glaucellus.habitat: scattered to gregarious on dung of deer, goat, moose, porcupine, and rabbit

Coprotus granuliformis.habitat: mostly on cow dung, but also on deer and sheep dung, (Kimbrough)

Coprotus luteus.habitat: scattered on dung of various animals (moose, cow, deer, goat, horse)

Coprotus ochraceus.habitat: on dung of various animals (most often cow, in Pakistan on camel)

Cudoniella clavus.habitat: on wet, rotting twigs and leaves, in ditches and swamps, also on dead stems; August to October, (Phillips), gregarious or single, best developed "on rotting twigs and leaves covered with water, as in ditches and swamps, but also on dead stems of Chamaenerion and the like, May and June, sometimes in July", (Dennis), single to gregarious, on dead twigs of trees and shrubs, as well as woody remains of herbs, always in very wet places such as wheel ruts and drainage ditches, spring to summer, (Breitenbach), on submerged leaves and barkless twigs, spring to early summer, (Hansen), "on very wet plant debris, such as cones and twigs, often at least partly submerged in running water", (Trudell), single to gregarious on rotting stems of grasses and herbs in boggy mountain meadows, in spring shortly after snow melt, (MykoWeb)

Cyathicula alpina.habitat: on Equisetum sp.; on stems; on stems (?of Delphinium), (Kanouse), on dead stems of Pedicularis and culms of Elymus condensatus, altitude 9500 feet, (Seaver)

Cyphellopsis confusa.habitat: densely crowded in cushion-shaped colonies 0.15-0.35cm across, "the colonies often consisting of well over 50 fruiting bodies", (Reid), in colonies like those of Merismodes anomala, having areas up to 2cm x 5cm; on barkless wood, Populus in one collection and hardwood in the other, (Redhead for BC)

Daleomyces petersii.habitat: often clustered, on "burnt ground in woods and on charred stumps", June to October, (Dennis), on burnt ground in hardwood forests with rich soil, fall, (Hansen), gregarious, scattered or cespitose on charcoal and burned areas, (Seaver)

Daleomyces phillipsii.edibility: "Several herbarium labels and notes refer to its excellent esculent qualities." (Korf(8))
Daleomyces phillipsii.habitat: on ground in woods, especially of Fagus, often after fires, September to October, (Dennis), "on the ground in burnt places (Seaver), usually occurs on burned-over areas, not uncommonly on burned stumps and/or soil in beech or predominantly beech forests", (Korf)

Dasyscyphella nivea.habitat: gregarious to densely cespitose (tufted), on damp rotten wood of Quercus (oak) lying on the ground, rarely on Fagus (beech), "commonly on cavities and on buried pieces of wood", fruiting throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on fallen sticks and decaying wood of Quercus robur (English Oak), more rarely on Carpinus spp., Betula spp., Fagus spp., Populus spp., Salix spp., Pyrus communis, (Raitviir for Eurasia), O. Ceska's collections from BC were fruiting in January, May, and June and growing on Quercus garryana or unidentified hardwood

Dasyscyphus pini.habitat: fruitbodies "separate or aggregate, occurring abundantly on resinous cankers" of 5-needled pines (parasitic on them): Western White Pine (Pinus monticola), Eastern White Pine (Pinus strobus), Whitebark Pine (Pinus albicaulis), and in Europe on the 2-needled Scots Pine (Pinus sylvestris); in the Pacific Northwest it grows at upper elevations

Dennisiodiscus crossotus.habitat: scattered, superficial; on weather-beaten wood, at 6000 feet (1800 m) in May in UT, on dead branches of Arctostaphylos nevadensis (pinemat manzanita), at 6000-7000 feet (1800-2100 m) in WA

Dermea balsamea.habitat: apothecia "erumpent, gregarious, mostly separate, sometimes cespitose with 2-4 in a cluster", on Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir) and Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock); conidial fruitbodies "erumpent to subimmersed, gregarious to scattered", (Groves), BC specimens mostly on Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), also on Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir), Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), and Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Dermea cerasi.habitat: emerging from bark on dead branches of Prunus cerasus (sour cherry) or Prunus avium (wild cherry) in compact groups, in spring, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), simple, or more often cespitose [in tufts], "on branches of various species of Prunus", (Seaver), erumpent, "gregarious, separate or sometimes cespitose, with few in a cluster", on Prunus species

Dermea grovesii.nameOrigin: "in honor of Dr. J. W. Groves whose studies on the genus Dermea have clarified this difficult genus", (Reid, J., genus name italicized)
Dermea grovesii.habitat: "erumpent, scattered to gregarious, separate or sometimes two to four in a cluster" on Picea glauca (White Spruce); conidial fruitbodies "erumpent, scattered, single, or clustered in groups of two to five and then united at their base", arising from a spherical to irregularly shaped basal stroma, (Reid, J.), BC specimens were also on Picea glauca

Dermea libocedri.habitat: apothecia "erumpent, gregarious", separate or in small clusters of 2 to 4, on Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar); conidial fruitbodies erumpent, separate

Dermea molliuscula.habitat: apothecia "strongly erumpent, scattered, separate or in clusters of about 2-6", on Betula spp. (birch); conidial stromata erumpent, gregarious

Dermea prunastri.habitat: "erumpent, scattered, cespitose, occasionally single", on Prunus spp.; conidial fruitbodies "erumpent, cespitose, occasionally single", (Groves), erumpent in small groups from cracks in bark, on dead twigs of Prunus, (Dennis), single or cespitose [clustered], erumpent, on various species of Prunus, conidial bodies also erumpent, occasionally single, more often cespitose, (Seaver)

Dermea pseudotsugae.habitat: "erumpent, separate, gregarious", on branches and stems of Pseudotsuga menziesii [Douglas-fir], late August and September, conidia produced somewhat earlier in the year, many of the apothecia overwintered "and in the spring were found to contain ascospores which did not appear to be viable", (Funk(2))

Dermea rhytidiformans.habitat: superficial on the cork ridges of cork bark of Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), fruiting perennially from the sides of the ridges: the fruitbodies are "at first slightly erumpent through the outer cork cells, but then appearing superficial, though sometimes slightly hidden in small cracks"; apothecia aggregated or single, superficial, "appear to be prime in late summer and autumn and occur intermixed with the conidial state"; conidial fruitbodies "single or aggregated, superficial on cork ridges or erumpent through smooth bark in early infections", "usually very abundant and present throughout the year"

Dermea tetrasperma.nameOrigin: means 'with 4 spored', referring to the 4-spored asci
Dermea tetrasperma.habitat: erumpent, single, gregarious, on stem of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), the conidial state first described from a blister rust canker of Pinus monticola (Western White Pine); "associated with die-back in semimature trees and also with small cankers in young trees", one collection "found on callus growth around a graft"

Desmazierella acicola.habitat: on old needles of Pinus (pine) in spring, (Hansen), on needles of hemlock (Kanouse)

Discinella schimperi.habitat: grows on the sphagnum moss Sphagnum squarrosum and commonly infects the mucilaginous cells in the axils of its phyllids

Disciotis venosa.edibility: edible when cooked but not recommended (Arora), poisonous if eaten raw (Lincoff(2))
Disciotis venosa.odour: conspicuously like chlorine bleach (Breitenbach for Switzerland), slight odor of chlorine (Lincoff(1)), strong smell of bleach (at least when rubbed), (Courtecuisse for Europe)
Disciotis venosa.habitat: "single, scattered or in small groups in damp soil or humus under or near trees or occasionally in the open", mainly in spring, (Arora), single to grouped in "forest on floodplains, clearcuts, hedges, among herbs on damp or mossy ground", (Breitenbach for Switzerland), typically on ground under hardwoods, but in Pacific Northwest reported under conifers; March to May (Lincoff(2))

Discocainia treleasei.nameOrigin: after William Trelease, taxonomist and the Missouri Botanical Garden's first director
Discocainia treleasei.habitat: erumpent, scattered or clustered, on Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) and Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce)

Donadinia nigrella.habitat: single or in a cluster of 2 to several on conifer sticks, usually in or near melting snow, at 3000-8000 feet elevation, late May to early August, (Miller), scattered on rotten wood in coniferous woods, (Seaver), single to gregarious "in duff and debris or on buried or rotten wood under conifers (particularly fir and spruce)", in spring shortly after snow melts or even developing under snow, (Arora)

Drepanopeziza ribis.habitat: erumpent [emerging] from surface of fallen Ribes leaves, (Dennis), erumpent on leaves of species of Ribes (Seaver)

Encoelia furfuracea.habitat: singly or in small clusters on living branches of Alnus and Corylus, December to May, (Dennis for U.K.), emerging in small dense groups from bark of "still-standing dead trunks and branches of Corylus (hazel) and Alnus (alder)", often covering entire branches, December to March, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), in cespitose [in tufts] clusters of five or six, or more rarely singly, on branches of species of Alnus, (Seaver)

Encoelia pruinosa.habitat: in BC known only from Populus tremuloides (Trembling Aspen), but reported to occur occasionally on P. trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood) and P. balsamifera (Balsam Poplar) in other areas, (Callan), on trunks of Populus, gregarious, occurring in large numbers under outer aspen bark, which rolls back exposing large blackened areas on which fruitbodies are seated, (Seaver), aspen is associated with a number of canker diseases: this one is common in most areas of the central Rocky Mountains, rather uniformly distributed through older or mature stands, seldom found in young stands up to 60 years, the bark over the cankered area usually remaining intact and tightly attached even after the tree dies, the cankers not being conspicuous but sometimes taking on "a slightly target-like appearance where part of the outer white surface has flaked away in a somewhat zoned pattern exposing part of the blackened inner bark", except for the thin white outer layer the bark becomes a uniform sooty black, fruitbodies usually develop abundantly on the old diseased black bark or under the loosened white surface layer, the fruitbodies being present in all seasons, (Davidson)

Encoeliopsis rhododendri.habitat: on seed capsules and stems of the inflorescence of Rhododendron californicum, June, (Zeller)

Eustilbum aureum.nameOrigin: refers to its occurrence on resin exudate
Eustilbum aureum.habitat: "gregarious or solitary, caespitose, with up to 8-10 in a cluster (usually 2-4), rarely single"; on resin exudate of conifers; "observations over several years indicate that the apothecial state usually develops most abundantly during the winter season in the south coastal region of British Columbia", but in the interior of BC, well-developed fruitbodies "have been found in mid-summer"

Flagelloscypha libertiana.nameOrigin: after M.A. Libert who collected the type
Flagelloscypha libertiana.habitat: on dead canes of Rosa spauldingii, (Lachnella rosae), on barkless branches of Cornus mas (Lachnella libertiana), (Cooke)

Flagelloscypha minutissima.habitat: gregarious, forming small scattered colonies, on very rotten fallen trunks, on woody and herbaceous debris, (Reid), on twigs of Picea sp., ? Pseudotsuga menziesii, ? dead Alnus sapling, Populus bark, fallen Pteridium aquilinum (bracken fern), dead Vicia ?gigantea, (Redhead(21)), also Poria sp. (Ginns), in densely +/- tufted groups; on dead wood and other woody debris of hardwoods, occasionally on other plant debris, summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Flagelloscypha orthospora.habitat: on dead twigs and herbage of various plants, (Cooke), on leaves and stems of herbaceous plants, foxglove, mullein, etc., on an apple branch, (Bourdot), in British Isles mainly on gorse (Buczacki)

Geopora arenosa.habitat: scattered on sandy soil, (Seaver), single to gregarious on damp sandy ground, also around burned places, spring and fall, (Breitenbach)

Geopora cercocarpi.habitat: single to scattered, "buried under leaf litter or deeper in soil", under the canopy of Cercocarpus ledifolius (curl-leaf mountain mahogany), collections recorded May to July

Geopyxis carbonaria.odour: none or fetid (Wang, X.-H.), sometimes smells a little like sulphur (M. Beug, pers. comm.)
Geopyxis carbonaria.habitat: gregarious to densely gregarious; on burned ground, (Wang, X.-H.), on burnt ground or attached to charred wood, (Dennis), single to gregarious and in troops on burned ground, May to September, (Breitenbach)

Geopyxis deceptiva.nameOrigin: "For being deceptive in comparison with G. alpina and G. rehmii, and because mycologists were deceived to believe it represented G. vulcanalis" (Wang, X.-H.(1), Latin names italicized)
Geopyxis deceptiva.odour: "indistinctive, rarely unpleasant", (Wang, X.-H.(1)), may have a distinct sulphur odor (M. Beug, pers. comm.)
Geopyxis deceptiva.habitat: scattered or gregarious, often on burned ground, rarely from unburned ground, collections June, July, September, (Wang, X.-H.(1) for G. deceptiva), Geopyxis rehmii was described as a species from burned ground. In comparison with G. carbonaria it was also recognized "to have a lower tolerance to burn conditions", and fruitbodies "developed later (in second year) and toward the edge of the burns, until pH values had lowered in the center (in third year)". "Our data from broad sampling show that this species occurs on both burned and unburned places." In Poland it is restricted to mountain areas, "which may also be the case in North America (based on the localities in the material examined by us).", collections June, July, September, (Wang, X.-H.(1) for G. rehmii)

Geoscypha tenacella.habitat: single or gregarious, "often several individuals fused together to form a cluster", on burned places, principally in the first 12 months after fire, "also occurring in masses on sandy forest paths without any relationship to charred wood", (Breitenbach), often clustered, on burned ground in woods and heaths, occasionally on sawdust; October to May, (Dennis), fruiting 10-150 weeks after the firs (Hansen, L.)

Geoscypha violacea.habitat: on burned ground, often amongst Funaria, spring and fall, (Dennis)

Gloeotinia granigena.habitat: causes blind seed diseases of grasses (described from rye, but subsequent occurrence on this species is rare, and the disease is primarily a problem of forage and turf grasses grown for seed); one to seven (usually one to three) fruitbodies emerge from each infected seed, infected caryopses appear shriveled, rough on the surface, and rusty brown or pinkish in color, conidia "accumulate on seed surface in a spore secretion (slime), which may be waxy and clear or pale pink in color", (Alderman(1)), fruitbodies arising on caryopses of grasses, macroconidial state produced in a copious pink slime on surface in summer, microconidial state produced in pink pulvinate [cushion-shaped] sporodochia on surface, (Hansen), on fruits of Secale cereale (rye) "to which is gives poisonous properties", (Seaver)

Godronia cassandrae.habitat: "erumpent, separate to cespitose in small clusters or sometimes up to 10 in a cluster", see NOTES for hosts

Godronia confertus.habitat: "erumpent, densely gregarious and cespitose with up to 40 or more in a cluster but usually much less and occasionally single", "usually found in the spring or early summer on cankered areas near the base of Prunus saplings" (genus name italicized)

Godronia davidsonii.habitat: "erumpent, scattered to gregarious, separate", on Ribes spp., (Groves), single on stems of Ribes wolfii, and on R. bracteosum X R. nigrum, (Seaver), on dead canes of Rubus sp. (Kanouse)

Godronia fuliginosa.habitat: "erumpent, densely gregarious to cespitose in effused patches, sometimes more scattered or singly among the conidial fruiting bodies in cankered areas", on Salix (willow)

Godronia grossulariae.habitat: "erumpent, separate to subcespitose or more or less in rows", type on Ribes watsonianum (spring gooseberry)

Godronia multispora.habitat: "erumpent, separate to cespitose in small clusters", on Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch) and B. pendula (European White Birch)

Godronia spiraeae.habitat: "erumpent, separate or cespitose in small clusters", on Spiraea spp.

Godronia uberiformis.nameOrigin: 'uber' means 'breast, teat, udder' but also as an adjective 'fruitful, full, copious', '-formis' means 'in form or shape', the name being chosen by Groves to emphasize the connection to Topospora uberiformis, the conidial state, and because it suggested copious fruiting, which is applicable to the sexual fruitbody as well as the conidial state
Godronia uberiformis.habitat: "erumpent, densely gregarious, cespitose, occasionally single", on Ribes spp.

Grovesiella abieticola.habitat: single or gregarious, on cankers on living branches and twigs of Abies grandis and Abies amabilis

Hamatocanthoscypha laricionis.nameOrigin: refers to Larix (larch), one of its hosts
Hamatocanthoscypha laricionis.habitat: gregarious, mostly in fall, mostly on conifers (cones, fallen needles, twigs, and bark chips), more rarely on Lycopodium, once on Rhododendron leaves

Hamatocanthoscypha uncinata.habitat: scattered to gregarious; on needles of Abies (Washington), in Europe on Juniperus; spring to the end of the growing season

Helotium albuminum.habitat: single, more often gregarious, sometimes crowded and tending to become confluent, on wood and bark, reported on quince and maple, (Seaver), single or more often gregarious, sometimes crowded and showing a slight tendency to become confluent; on dead wood and bark of hardwoods, (quince?, maple, and undetermined), one collection on a pyrenomycete, (White)

Helvella crassitunicata.habitat: single, gregarious, or subcespitose [somewhat tufted] on soil under conifers, May to October, (Abbott), scattered to gregarious on soil, especially along trails, in montane regions with Abies spp. (fir), August to October, (Castellano)

Helvella leucomelaena.habitat: single, gregarious, subcespitose [somewhat tufted], or scattered and numerous on bare soil, moss, or litter in coniferous woods, April to September, (Abbott), gregarious in forests and meadows, commonly on pathsides and roadsides, in stony, sandy, humus-poor places, April to June, (Breitenbach), scattered to densely gregarious or clustered, occasionally single, on ground, usually near or under pine or other conifers, favoring bare, grassy or hard-packed soil along roads and paths; in spring and early summer, or in California in winter and early spring, (Arora)

Henningsomyces candidus.habitat: on rotting coniferous and hardwood wood and bark (Cooke), on hardwood and conifer wood: bark and wood, barkless and decaying wood, rotten wood, twigs, dead branches, rotten logs, old plank; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), single "or in densely tufted or trooping groups" on rotting wood of hardwoods, all year, (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter

Henningsomyces puber.habitat: scattered in small groups or densely crowded in large colonies, on dead wood, (Reid), type on rotten wood of Betula, (Cooke)

Humaria hemisphaerica.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups on ground or occasionally rotten wood, under both hardwoods and conifers, summer and fall, (Arora), usually gregariously, sometimes singly, on damp ground and very rotten wet wood, July to October, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), "on soil in woods or, occasionally, on very rotten wood in wet places, July to October," (Dennis for UK)

Hyaloscypha diabolica.habitat: gregarious to confluent, on bulky coniferous wood (in one case spruce), March and August

Hyaloscypha fuckelii.habitat: on hardwood, rarely on coniferous wood, sometimes on pyrenomycete, once on sacking, once on dead grass, (Huhtinen)

Hyaloscypha vitreola.habitat: gregarious to confluent, on hardwood, especially very soft water-soaked inner wood already degraded by other organisms, March to November, peaking in summer

Hymenoscyphus epiphyllus.habitat: scattered, or in groups of 2 to 4 on leaves of various hardwood or more rarely coniferous trees, also on forest debris, (Seaver), scattered on fallen leaves (Dennis), on leaves of Alnus (alder), arising in most cases from the veins of the leaves, (Kanouse), on fallen leaves or needles (Hansen)

Hymenoscyphus fastidiosus.habitat: on petioles and midribs of fallen leaves of Alnus (alder) in wet places, also reported on catkins, (Seaver)

Hymenoscyphus rufescens.habitat: gregarious on decaying leaves; including Alnus, Acer, (Kanouse), arising from leaf laminas of withered Alnus leaves, (Schumacher re-examination of type)

Hymenoscyphus salicellus.habitat: scattered, emerging through bark of fallen branches of Salix (willow)

Hymenoscyphus scutula.nameOrigin: from 'scutula' Latin for 'small plate or dish'
Hymenoscyphus scutula.habitat: thickly gregarious, on herbaceous stems of various kinds, (Seaver), occasionally single but usually gregarious and covering entire stems; on rotting stems of various herbs, especially Compositae, in damp places under the plants, (Breitenbach), scattered on dead herbaceous stems, (Dennis), on leaves of Salix (willow), (Kanouse for var. caudatum), on herbaceous stems (Kanouse for var. grossulariae), on Rubus stems (Kanouse for forma rubi)

Hymenoscyphus virgultorum.habitat: gregarious on partially buried sticks and roots, (Seaver), on hardwood (Hansen), scattered or in small clusters on dead wood and fallen twigs, (Dennis)

Iodophanus carneus.habitat: gregarious on animal dung, according to literature also on rotting plant debris and cloth, etc.; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on dung, rotting vegetable matter, including textiles and rope, and on soil, throughout the year, (Dennis), gregarious or occasionally crowded in clusters of variable size, on dung of various kinds, (Seaver), in burn areas or on dung, wet rags, etc. (Beug)

Ionomidotis irregularis.habitat: singly, or more often in cespitose clusters from a common stem-like base, on rotten wood and branches lying on the ground

Lachnella alboviolascens.nameOrigin: refers to white and violet colors
Lachnella alboviolascens.habitat: bark and branches of trees and shrubs, woody herbaceous stems, litter and duff; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), in densely tufted groups; on dead wood, twigs and branches of hardwood trees and shrubs, "herbaceous stems and other plant debris, often on gorse and broom"; spring to fall, (Buczacki for British Isles), densely gregarious to scattered on woody herbaceous stems of plants and on the bark and branches of trees and shrubs, (Cooke)

Lachnella tiliae.habitat: gregarious in colonies that may be small or extend over many square feet, sometimes covering entire trunks, almost confined to branches and trunks of Tilia (basswood), but has been reported on Juglans regia (English Walnut), Acer spp. (maple, but some of these misidentified), Populus tremuloides and Ulmus (elm), (Reid), scattered to gregarious on bark of twigs and branches of Tilia spp. and Tilia americana (American Basswood), also reported on Juglans regia, Acer spp., and Populus tremuloides, (Cooke), Tilia spp., Ulmus sp., (Ginns)

Lachnella villosa.habitat: gregarious to separate on herbaceous litter and twigs of woody plants and hardwoods (Cooke)

Lachnellula agassizii.habitat: gregarious on bark and wood of conifers (Seaver), on branches of Abies (fir), Pinus (pine), and Tsuga (hemlock), (Trudell), it is most commonly found on Abies species but also occurs on Pinus and Tsuga, "It has never been known to be associated with cankers of living trees, although it may appear on quite recently killed trees.", (Haines)

Lachnellula arida.habitat: gregarious on fallen dead branches of Larix (larch) still with bark, according to literature also on other conifers, (Breitenbach), on wood of Abies (fir) species (Trudell), scattered, on bark of conifers (Abies, Larix, Picea), or more rarely on the needles (Seaver)

Lachnellula calyciformis.habitat: gregarious "on the bark of dead conifers (fir)"; in California fruiting "from spring through summer", (Desjardin), mostly on branches of Abies (true fir), but also on Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), (Hansen, L.), single or gregarious to cespitose, on dead branches of Abies and Picea, spring and fall, (Breitenbach)

Lachnellula ciliata.nameOrigin: probably referring to the long hairs (ciliate)
Lachnellula ciliata.habitat: "so far as we know D. ciliata is restricted in its growth to the small, shaded-out, dead branches and twigs of Douglas fir", (Hahn, Latin name italicized), usually scattered, occasionally grouped, on dead branches of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Seaver), cups single, "erumpent throughout the bark of the recently killed host", known only from Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Haines)

Lachnellula occidentalis.habitat: gregarious on dead branches of Larix (larch) still with bark, (sometimes also on old cankers), Picea (spruce), according to literature also on other conifers; March to December, (Breitenbach), abundant, scattered, or grouped, on species of larch (Seaver)

Lachnellula populina.nameOrigin: means 'of Populus' referring to its host
Lachnellula populina.habitat: thickly gregarious on bark and barkless wood of Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen)

Lachnellula pseudotsugae.nameOrigin: means 'of Pseudotsuga' referring to its host
Lachnellula pseudotsugae.habitat: scattered, or closely grouped, forming cankers on living branches of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Seaver), on living branches and trunks of Pseudotsuga menziesii, (Hahn(2))

Lachnellula suecica.habitat: single to gregarious on dead branches of Pinus (pine), according to literature also on Larix (larch), July to September, (Breitenbach), emerging through outer bark of conifers, frequently in Rocky Mountains on Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce) and occasionally on Pinus (pine), (Seaver), saprophytic on branches of Larix, Picea, Pinus, and Juniperus, (Hansen), in the Pacific Northwest mostly east of the Cascade crest on branches of Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), (Trudell)

Lachnellula willkommii.habitat: gregarious on attached branches of Larix (larch) or in the immediate vicinity of cankers, March to December; it is a wound parasite that causes larch canker, (Breitenbach), "scattered, or gregarious in small groups and occasionally several closely crowded together", on branches of Larix europaea, (Seaver), parasitic on Larix, causing cankers and sinuose growth of the trunk, (Hansen)

Lachnum capitatum.nameOrigin: means 'with a head', probably referring to crystalline cap on hairs
Lachnum capitatum.habitat: on leaves of Quercus (oak), (Seaver), on old leaves (Kanouse)

Lachnum cerinum.habitat: gregarious on wood of hardwoods, (Seaver), saprophytic on hardwood, found on Quercus (oak), (Hansen), on hardwood remains (commonly Populus) (Haines)

Lachnum clandestinum.habitat: gregarious to cespitose, on Rubus idaeus (raspberry) canes lying on the ground, and according to literature other herbs, May to August, (Breitenbach), on twigs of willow (?), on Acer circinatum, on woody stems of nettle, on Rubus canes, (Kanouse), scattered, on dead herb stems, especially Rubus idaeus, April to August but especially in spring, (Dennis)

Lachnum flavofuligineum.nameOrigin: means 'yellow-fuliginous', fuliginous meaning 'sooty brown or dark-smoke colored'

Lachnum gaultheriae.nameOrigin: means 'of Gaultheria (salal)', referring to its host
Lachnum gaultheriae.habitat: on Gaultheria shallon (salal), (Seaver), on the underside of a large leaf spot of Gaultheria shallon, February to July, (Zeller)

Lachnum nardi.nameOrigin: originally reported on Nardus (mat-grass or nard)

Lachnum pulverulentus.habitat: on fir needles, (Kanouse for Washington), scattered on fallen pine needles (Seaver), on fallen needles of Pinus (Hansen for Scandinavia), on fallen pine needles, in spring and fall, (Dennis for United Kingdom)

Lachnum pygmaeum.habitat: "gregarious or cespitose, typically occurring in a few cespitose clusters of five to ten each, surrounded by a few growing singly", "arising at ground level on partly buried plant debris of all sorts, especially on roots and rhizomes of grasses and other herbaceous plants" and on limbs of both hardwood and coniferous trees, (Seaver), clustered or gregarious "on dead wood or branches just covered by soil or on dead roots and grass rhizomes, often on Ulex", in spring and fall, (Dennis), on buried dead branches, roots and rhizomes, (Hansen), "usually found on roots or other partially buried wood" (Haines)

Lachnum virgineum.habitat: gregarious to densely cespitose on dead branches and twigs, canes of Rubus (blackberry), beechnut shells, cones, etc.; throughout the year but especially in spring, (Breitenbach), on "many kinds of substrates such as wood, woody stems, cupules, cones and leaves", (Hansen), "scattered or in large groups on dead wood, twigs, and plant stems", April to June, September to October, (Phillips), primarily on hardwood debris (Trudell)

Lambertella pruni.habitat: gregarious, as many as a hundred springing from a single fruit, on mummified fruits and seedlings of Prunus avium (sweet cherry)

Lamprospora crechqueraultii.habitat: gregarious on clayey soil, (Seaver), on wet clay soils, June to October, (Dennis), on bare soil, in wheel tracks, etc., fall, (Hansen)

Lamprospora miniata.habitat: gregarious or crowded on damp soil, usually among mosses, (Seaver), "among Tortula ruraliformis, T. intermedia etc., on sandy soils and old walls", November to April, (Dennis for United Kingdom), growing with/on various mosses, e.g. Barbula, Tortula, and Encalypta, (Hansen for Scandinavia)

Lanzia luteovirescens.habitat: growing from blackened patches on stems of fallen sycamore leaves, September to October, (Phillips), "arising from stromatized patches of host tissues without a clear stromatal rind", singly on petioles of fallen leaves of Acer (maple), Tilia (linden), Fagus (beech), and Quercus (oak), summer and fall, (Hansen), single or gregarious from blackened places in substrate, on rotting petioles of Acer, September to October, (Breitenbach)

Lasiobelonium corticale.habitat: gregariously in groups on dead hardwood, "bare or still with bark, and on rootstocks, usually growing in cracks and on undersurfaces", (Breitenbach), thickly gregarious on bark of various hardwoods, (Seaver), single or in groups on rotten hardwood, (Dimitrova), on hardwood (Hansen), apparently a spring species that occurs on hardwood bark, especially of Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), (Haines)

Lasiobolus cuniculi.habitat: gregarious on dung of rabbit, hare, sheep, goat, raccoon, cow, horse, and other animals

Lasiobolus intermedius.nameOrigin: refers to intermediate size of spores between large-spored species such as L. papillatus and L. diversisporus and small-spored species like L. microsporus and L. trichoboloides
Lasiobolus intermedius.habitat: gregarious to crowded, on dung of moose, horse, deer, elk, opossum, sheep, muskox, and porcupine

Lasiobolus lasioboloides.habitat: scattered to gregarious on dung of moose, deer, rat, elk, sheep, and goat

Lasiobolus macrotrichus.habitat: gregarious to crowded on dung of various animals

Lasiobolus papillatus.habitat: gregarious on various kinds of dung, including human feces

Lasiobolus ruber.habitat: gregarious on dung of cow, deer, wapiti, goat, and wolf

Legaliana badia.habitat: gregarious on path embankments, in forests, on bare sandy ground, commonly on freshly broken sandy-loamy soils, June to October, (Breitenbach), on ground in hardwood, coniferous or mixed woods, in two collections only from rotten or buried wood, (Elliott, M.E.(2)), on ground in woods, especially on sandy soil, (Dennis)

Legaliana limnaea.habitat: often under Alnus (alder); on moist rich soil, fall, (Hansen), single to gregarious on sandy, muddy path edge, sandy-loamy building rubble, bare ground on streetsides, under Urtica (nettle) and Petasites (butterbur), in summer, (Breitenbach)

Leptotrochila repanda.habitat: on living leaves of Galium (bedstraw) and occasionally on other herbaceous plants

Maireina marginata.habitat: scattered to somewhat gregarious, emerging from outer bark, on dead twigs of fruit trees including those of Pyrus malus (cult apple), Prunus persica (peach) and P. amygdalus, and on twigs of Cytisus scoparius (Scottish broom), the dead twigs usually on living trees, (Cooke)

Maireina thujae.nameOrigin: means 'of Thuja', referring to its host Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)
Maireina thujae.habitat: on wood and bark of Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Cooke)

Malvipezia emileia.habitat: gregarious or scattered on damp soil in woods [but in key says "on wood"], (Seaver), in hardwood forests (Hansen), gregarious on lawns and in woods, June to October, (Dennis)

Marcelleina persoonii.habitat: single or gregarious on bare ground, also among mosses, under Petasites (butterbur), and on roots, in damp places, (Breitenbach), on humus and roots in swamps, under Glyceria, Juncus (rush), and Filipendula (meadowsweet), also on bare soil under Tussilago (coltsfoot), July to October, (Dennis), on calcareous soil and burnt ground, summer to fall, (Hansen, L.)

Melastiza chateri.nameOrigin: named after J.J. Chater, the finder, in 1872, a gardener in Cambridge, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Melastiza chateri.habitat: on bare or mossy soil, (McKnight), on damp sandy soils, October to March, (Dennis for UK), growing "singly, gregariously to clumped together", "along the edges of paths and roads, in forests and on grassy herb-covered spots, on bare sandy or loamy ground, May to September", (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Merismodes anomala.habitat: "in groups or densely cespitose, sometimes covering areas decimeters in size", on dead wood of hardwoods, shrubs, and more rarely of Picea (spruce), with and without bark; throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on a variety of hardwoods, wood, dead bark, twigs and branches, slash, logs; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on rotting and fallen hardwood, especially Fagus (beech), and often on the cut surfaces of felled timber, in large densely tufted groups, all year, (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter

Merismodes fasciculata.habitat: fasciculate, rarely single, in clusters of 3-10 or more from lenticels or from cracks in bark, clusters reaching 1cm across, (Cooke), "single, in small groups of twos and threes or in densely crowded colonies of 20 or more fruitbodies", on small twigs and branches of hardwoods, especially Alnus spp. (alder), (Reid)

Merismodes ochracea.habitat: scattered to closely gregarious on rotting wood and litter of many genera of hardwood trees and shrubs, (Cooke), on rotten wood, decayed stump, rotting litter, on Acer macrophyllum, Fagus grandifolia, Populus trichocarpa, Salix nigra, Salix scouleriana, (Ginns)

Micropodia pteridina.nameOrigin: refers to its host, the fern Pteridium

Microstoma protractum.habitat: the hard black pseudorhiza is usually attached to buried wood, (Dennis), on buried sticks and roots (Kanouse), "fruits right after snowmelt, sometimes on frozen ground", (Beug)

Miladina lecithina.habitat: gregarious or scattered, on decorticated wood (in many cases Betula), in or under moving water, (Pfister), single or in small clusters, on water-soaked wood, (Dennis), gregarious on stones and water-soaked logs, (Seaver), on water-soaked or immersed wood, summer to fall, (Hansen)

Moellerodiscus tenuistipes.habitat: gregarious, arising from Alnus leaf blades or veins without stroma, (Kanouse)

Mollisia amenticola.habitat: single, gregarious or clustered, "on damp female cones of Alnus (alder), lying on the ground", November to February, (Breitenbach), on cones of Alnus (Kanouse)

Mollisia caespiticia.habitat: for the most part in cespitose clusters, on old wood, Salix (willow), Ulmus (elm), etc., (Seaver), emerging from bark in small clusters, "often seated over some member of the Sphaeriales", on "dead branches as of Betula, Ribes, Salix and Sambucus, September to October", (Dennis), on sticks; on Alnus (alder); on crab-apple, (Kanouse)

Mollisia cinerea.habitat: gregarious to cespitose and crowded, on "damp rotting wood, especially of Quercus (oak) and Fagus (beech)", (Breitenbach), gregarious or scattered, on decaying wood of many kinds, (Seaver), gregarious and superficial on dead wood and branches, throughout the year, (Dennis), gregariously crowded, on decaying wood of hardwoods, throughout the season, (Hansen)

Mollisia complicatula.habitat: erumpent on wood of Lonicera (honeysuckle) and Populus, (Seaver), on Lonicera in Washington and in original description from the Tyrol, (Kanouse)

Mollisia gaultheriae.nameOrigin: means "of Gaultheria", referring to host Gaultheria shallon (salal)
Mollisia gaultheriae.habitat: on living leaves of Gaultheria shallon (salal), on both sides but more numerous on underside, (Seaver)

Mollisia plantaginis.nameOrigin: means 'of Plantago' referring to its host
Mollisia plantaginis.habitat: leaf necrosis of Plantago lanceolata associated with Mollisia plantaginis develops in late fall and early winter in Europe, primarily December to March, and is considered common there; collected in Oregon March to May

Monilinia demissa.nameOrigin: refers to host, Prunus virginiana var. demissa, 'demissa' means 'drooping'
Monilinia demissa.habitat: mostly single, sometimes two from overwintered mummy of Prunus virginiana var. demissa

Monilinia fructicola.habitat: arising from mummified overwintered fruit on Prunus, conidia on fruit, peduncles, twigs, leaves, or blossoms, (Elliott, M.E.), fruitbodies in considerable numbers from a mummified fruit, on overwintering orchard fruits, the cause of brown-rot of fruits throughout eastern North America, (Seaver)

Monilinia gregaria.habitat: conidial stage on living leaves and fruits of Amelanchier cusickii (serviceberry), gregarious ascus-bearing stage on mummified fruits of same host

Monilinia laxa.habitat: usually several from the same stroma from mummified plums (Prunus); conidial stage consists of a Monilia of the cinerea type, (Seaver), macroconidial anamorph (Monilia cinerea Bonord.) on flowers and branchlets and later on young fruits in spring and summer; ascus-bearing fruitbodies gregarious on mummified fruits but rare in nature, (Hansen)

Monilinia oxycocci.habitat: fruiting body arising from sclerotia (usually one from each sclerotium), in fallen mummified fruits of Vaccinium oxycoccos (cranberry), (Seaver), 1 to 6 fruiting bodies in early spring from hollow black pseudosclerotium (mummified berry), macroconidial state on wilting shoot of the host in summer, (Hansen), mummies are roughly spherical and about 1.2cm in diameter (McManus)

Monilinia urnula.habitat: 1-3 on fallen mummified berries of Vaccinium species, spring and early summer, (Hansen), buff macroconidial state on wilting shoots of host [in summer], mainly on the axis of the dead shoot, (Dennis)

Myriosclerotinia caricis-ampullaceae.nameOrigin: means 'of Carex ampullacea', a synonym of Carex rostrata
Myriosclerotinia caricis-ampullaceae.habitat: sclerotium developing apically between leaf sheaths of young shoots of Carex; at least in north Europe cups develop on stems of Carex rostrata and C. aquatilis in spring and early summer, (Hansen, L.), further ecological details are discussed in Holec(2) including that it prefers areas with rather deep Sphagnum peat and a high amount of water

Myriosclerotinia curreyana.habitat: "one to several from a sclerotium through a slit in the culm" of Juncus spp.

Myriosclerotinia duriaeana.habitat: 1-3 fruitbodies arising from sclerotium, on Carex, "Sporodochial locules in groups of 3-6 distributed at regular intervals along the host culm, each group dull black, elongate, 1-3mm long", (Hansen), on Carex, sclerotia "one to three in each culm, when mature exposed by the rupture of the epidermis along one or two faces of the culm which thus weakened soon breaks over widening the slit and allowing the sclerotia to fall", (Seaver), one to several from sclerotium in culm of Carex and Eriophorum spp. (Schumacher)

Neofabraea populi.nameOrigin: means 'of Populus' referring to its host
Neofabraea populi.habitat: thickly gregarious, usually occurring singly, or rarely two or three crowded together, (Seaver), mature fruitbodies are produced in June, usually erumpent [emerging] first near the center of the cankered area on P. tremuloides, P. trichocarpa, and its hybrids, (Callan for BC, but notes that it occurs on other Populus species elsewhere)

Neottiella hetieri.habitat: on "old burnt place which has been overrun with mosses, or occasionally where there is no trace of fire", (Seaver), single or gregarious, on burned ground among mosses (Funaria), in spring, (Breitenbach), amongst Funaria on burnt soil and charcoal, spring and fall, (Dennis for UK), on burnt places, 1-2 years after the burn, among Funaria hygrometrica, (Hansen for north Europe)

Neottiella rutilans.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious on soil among mosses (especially Polytrichum), apparently growing on dead remnants and often hidden by the living mosses, (Seaver), on sandy soils among Polytrichum, October to January, (Dennis for UK)

Neournula pouchetii.habitat: in conifer stands ranging from about 35 to over 200 years old, March through July, (Castellano), gregarious to scattered, in conifer litter, April through July, (Paden), in conifer litter, under western cedar and hemlock, (Lincoff)

Nipterella parksii.habitat: Nipterella parksii "is evidently common on dead attached branches" of Alnus rubra (Red Alder) on Vancouver Island, (Tanney(2)), gregarious on "decorticated stems of Vaccinium parvifolium, Rhamnus purshiana, Garrya elliptica, Physocarpus capitatus and Castanopsis chrysophylla", (Seaver from Cash)

Nipterella tsugae.habitat: superficial, single, gregarious, in branches of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), appears to be a colonizer of the understory branches that are dying due to shading out

Octospora leucoloma.habitat: gregarious or scattered on ground among mosses (Seaver), typically in cushions of Bryum argenteum in winter and spring, (Dennis for UK), together with Bryum argenteum, spring to fall, (Hansen)

Octospora rubens.habitat: on damp soil among mosses, (Seaver), same habitat as O. rustica which is found on burnt ground and sandy soil with Ceratodon purpureus (Hansen for northern Europe)

Orbilia angiosubvinosa.nameOrigin: "referring to the growth on angiosperms and the similarity with O. subvinosa" (Baral(3) with Latin italicized).
Orbilia angiosubvinosa.habitat: "very scattered to gregarious in small groups"; collected 1-1.5 m above the ground, "on partially to sometimes entirely decorticated", 0.7-4.0cm thick branches of Corylus, Rosa, and Salix, up to 0.1cm deep, "medium to strongly decayed wood", slightly to strongly grayed, +/- covered by green algae; collected repeatedly at water bodies such as ponds or streams; altitude: 83-1548 m; possibly fruiting throughout the year

Orbilia brettii.nameOrigin: in honour of Bob Brett M.Sc., "forest ecologist and environmental consultant in British Columbia" [Bob Brett has also organized annual Whistler bioblitzes]
Orbilia brettii.habitat: holotype collection scattered to subgregarious, 1.5m above the ground, on a dry, 1.4cm thick, decorticated, medium rotten, attached branch of Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood)

Orbilia canadensis.nameOrigin: "from the geographical origin of the holotype, Canada", (Baral(3))
Orbilia canadensis.habitat: scattered to +/- gregarious in small groups; collected 0-2.5 m above the ground, partially to sometimes entirely decorticated, 0.3-1.0cm thick, dry hardwood twigs/branches of the families Betulaceae and Salicaceae, on 0.02-0.03cm deep medium to strongly decayed wood, also on bark, +/- greyed, with some green algae; altitude 200 m (subpolar tundra), 500-1165 m (boreal forests); fruiting June to August "but probably throughout the year", long-lived

Orbilia coniferarum.nameOrigin: "named after the occurrence on coniferous hosts" (Baral(3))
Orbilia coniferarum.habitat: "scattered to subgregarious"; collected 0.5-3 m above the ground, decorticated, 0.8-8.0cm thick branches of Abies concolor, Juniperus, Picea sitchensis, Pinus halepensis, P. sylvestris, and Pseudotsuga menziesii, on 0.01-0.04cm "deep medium to strongly decayed wood" or bark, slightly to strongly grayed, "green algae sparse to medium abundant", altitude 1-2778 m, inhabits slightly to strongly rotten wood or bark of dry branches of different coniferous trees and shrubs; fully viable for at least 17 months

Orbilia delphinus.nameOrigin: "named after the ascospores which partly resemble a dolphin" (Baral(3)); it does not agree with the genus gender because it is a noun
Orbilia delphinus.habitat: very scattered to +/- gregarious; recorded from rotten wood, more rarely bark, of dry twigs and branches of hardwood or more rarely coniferous trees and shrubs, collected 0.1-3 m above the ground, corticated or more often +/- decorticated, 0.4-2.5(8.0)cm thick twigs and branches of Abies concolor, Amelanchier, Betula, Cercocarpus, Cistus laurifolius, Corylus cornuta, Ericameria nauseosa, Larix sibirica, Lonicera, Pinus sylvestris, Populus tremuloides, Potentilla fruticosa, Prunus domestica, Quercus gambelii, Ribes cereum, Rosa, Salix, on 0.01-0.1cm deep (medium to) strongly decayed wood, more rarely bark, partly +/- detaching, sometimes eroded, slightly to strongly grayed, "green algae sparse or abundant"; altitude: 1083-2980 m; fruiting throughout the year, long-lived

Orbilia flavida.nameOrigin: "from the yellowish colour of the apothecia in the holotype (though recent samples are consistently reddish)", (Baral)
Orbilia flavida.habitat: "very scattered to medium gregarious", collected on dry ground or 0.05-5m above the ground, 1(?-2) years old, 0.6-3.5cm thick "herbaceous stems, rarely petioles", O. flavida prefers to grow on rotten, dry herbaceous stems, but also occurs on rotten wood and bark of dry branches of different hardwood trees and shrubs; fruiting February to November

Orbilia flexisoma.habitat: scattered to subgregarious, collected 1-2.5 m above the ground, decorticated, 0.7-1.9cm thick dry branches of Acer (maple), Cercocarpus ledifolius (Curlleaf Cercocarpus), Juniperus osteosperma (Utah Juniper), Quercus gambelii (Gambel Oak), on 0.05-0.1cm deep very decayed wood, strongly grayed, "with sparse to abundant green algae"; altitude 830-2500 m; also in a boreal humid conifer forest with Populus tremuloides (Black Cottonwood) and Acer in the Canadian Rocky Mountains.

Orbilia idahoensis.nameOrigin: "named after the state Idaho (USA) in which the type was collected"
Orbilia idahoensis.habitat: +/- scattered, partially to entirely decorticated, 0.4-1.6cm thick, dry twigs and branches of Amelanchier, Cercocarpus, Ribes cereum, on 0.02-0.05cm deep strongly decayed wood, grayed, no algae, altitude 1750-2570 m

Orbilia macrodelphinus.nameOrigin: "similar to O. delphinus but with wider ascospores", (Baral(3))
Orbilia macrodelphinus.habitat: scattered to subgregarious; found on rotten wood, rarely bark, of dry twigs and branches of both hardwood and conifer trees and shrubs; collected 0.5-2.5 m above the ground, decorticated or +/- corticated, 0.4-1.4cm thick twigs and branches; on 0.02-0.1cm deep "(medium to) strongly decayed wood" and bark, strongly grayed, "a few or many green algae"; altitude 975-2650 m; fully viable for at least nine months; occurring on Baccharis salicifolia, Canotia holacantha, Cytisus supranubius, Juniperus osteosperma, Larrea tridentata, Picea sitchensis, Pseudotsuga menziesii, and Purshia stansburyana; in western North America it occurred in "semiarid pinyon-juniper woodlands" and "boreal humid Douglas fir mixed forests" of the Middle Rocky Mountains and adjacent Columbia Plateau, and also in warm-temperate semiarid paloverde-mixed cacti desert scrubs

Orbilia maeandrina.nameOrigin: "named after the flexuous, meandering spore bodies" (Baral(3))
Orbilia maeandrina.habitat: scattered to often medium gregarious; mainly from western North America in semiarid Sonoran paloverde-mixed cacti desert scrubs, in pinyon-juniper woodlands, and in "humid ponderosa pine, Douglas fir, and Engelmann spruce forests of Middle and Southern Rocky Mountains"; collected (0)0.1-3 m above the ground, "partially to entirely decorticated", 0.4-3.0cm thick twigs and branches, medium to strongly grayed, "green algae absent or sparse"; altitude 615-2980 m (North America); fully tolerant to desiccation at least 15 months

Orbilia ovalis.nameOrigin: "named after the frequently ovoid spore shape, also referring to the substrate of the type, Amelanchier ovalis", (Baral(3) with Latin name italicized)
Orbilia ovalis.habitat: scattered to subgregarious; collected 0.2-2.5 m above the ground, +/- corticated, 0.3-3.5cm thick twigs and branches, on medium to strongly decayed phloem (periderm rolled aside or removed, also on inner surface of detached bark), more rarely wood, slightly greyed, sometimes blackened, green algae sparsely present; from mixed conifer forests, the Canadian collection from a boreal humid forest with Populus tremuloides and Acer adjacent to conifer forests in a valley of the Canadian Rocky Mountains; altitude 340-1605 m; February-March, August-November (but long-lived)

Orbilia spathulata.habitat: scattered to subgregarious in small groups; collected 0.3-0.5-?2 m above the ground, corticated or decorticated, dry, rotting, 1.2-2.0cm thick branches, partly in small clefts; in Utah on bark of Artemisia tridentata in sagebrush and saltbush area at 1700- 1795 m altitude; in British Columbia on wood of Populus tremuloides (Black Cottonwood) in a conifer forest with cottonwood and maple, at 830 m altitude

Orbilia species^.habitat: saprophytic "on wood, herbaceous stems and old stromatic pyrenomycetes", (Hansen, L.), mostly on wood or bark, occasionally on woodier herbaceous stems (Dennis)

Orbilia subtrapeziformis.nameOrigin: in reference to the similar O. trapeziformis (Baral(3))
Orbilia subtrapeziformis.habitat: "scattered to medium, sometimes densely gregarious", on +/- rotten wood and bark of dry twigs and branches of various hardwood (exceptionally coniferous) trees and shrubs, collected (0.1)0.3-2.5(4)m above the ground, "corticated to decorticated", 0.4-3.0cm thick twigs and branches, rarely ~ 8-25cm thick trunks, on 0.01-0.02cm deep slightly to strongly decayed wood and bark, scarcely to strongly grayed, "covered by a few to many green algae"; altitude 470-2600 m; probably fruiting throughout the year; in BC at 830 m on maple branch and in UT at 2600 m on willow branch

Orbilia 'trapeziformis'.habitat: scattered to +/- gregarious; collected (0)0.8-4(16) m above the ground, on dry, corticated to decorticated, 0.8-3.5(15)cm thick branches, rarely trunks, of a variety of hardwoods as well as juniper and pine, on 0.03-0.2cm deep, slightly to mostly strongly decayed wood and bark, "wood often white-rotten, (strongly) greyed, often eroded, with a few to many green algae"; altitude: 4-1385 m; throughout the year

Orbilia vibrioides.nameOrigin: named after the ascospores which resemble bacteria of the genus Vibrio, (Baral(3))
Orbilia vibrioides.habitat: "scattered to densely gregarious in small groups"; "so far only found on woody substrates: slightly to strongly decayed wood and bark" of dry twigs and branches of both coniferous and hardwood trees and shrubs; collected 0.1-3 m above the ground, corticated to decorticated, 0.25-4.5cm thick twigs and branches, partly on or close to long decorticated old wounds, on 0.01-0.1cm deep, slightly to strongly decayed wood and bark, greyed, covered by green algae; altitude 3-1320 m; throughout the year

Orbilia xanthostigma.nameOrigin: referring to the golden fruitbody color, (Baral)
