Orbilia xanthostigma.habitat: often densely gregarious, "lying on moist or sometimes wet ground, also in 0.3-0.5 or rarely 1-2 m above the ground (especially when on water-soaked, deeply rotten wood) [sic]", on lower, lateral or upper side, decorticated, rarely corticated, (1-)3-35cm thick branches or often logs, trunks and stumps (often on cut area), also roots, fungi, rarely cones, of a wide variety of hardwood especially beech, oak, and birch, also on conifer wood; throughout the year; "Although O. xanthostigma predominantly forms its apothecia on the upper and lateral sides of the branches and logs and O. leucostigma preferably on the shadowed underside, colourless and bright yellow apothecia grew sometimes together on the exposed upper side", (Baral(3))

Otidea alutacea.nameOrigin: means 'of soft leather' presumably referring to alutaceous color
Otidea alutacea.habitat: scattered to densely clustered in humus, usually under conifers, (Arora), in hardwood forests on the ground, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), often in clusters; on ground in woods, August to September, (Dennis for UK), in hardwood forests on rich soil, often along roadsides, summer to fall, (Hansen for north Europe)

Otidea concinna.habitat: sometimes single but mainly growing in groups and crowded together, in hardwood forests, under Fagus (beech), on mossy ground, summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), often gregarious; in rich soil in hardwood forests, often with Quercus (oak), summer to fall, (Hansen for north Europe), with Quercus and Corylus (hazel) (Harmaja for Finland)

Otidea leporina.habitat: gregarious or cespitose [tufted], for examined collections, under conifers, especially spruce; for examined collections, fruiting August to December, (Olariaga), among mosses in coniferous forests, fall, (Hansen for north Europe), prefers the company of Picea (spruce), usually in needle litter, at times among mosses, (Harmaja)

Otidea microspora.habitat: on ground; 3 collections cited - in August, October, and December (Kanouse)

Otidea nannfeldtii.nameOrigin: presumably after Professor John Axel Frithiof Nannfeldt, University of Uppsala, who published numerous papers on discomycetes and other fungi
Otidea nannfeldtii.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [tufted]; in the examined collections under conifers; in the examined collections fruiting in September, October, and December

Otidea onotica.edibility: edible according to some but one study revealed the presence of the toxin MMH, (Arora)
Otidea onotica.habitat: "scattered or more often in groups or clusters under both hardwoods and conifers", winter and spring in California, (Arora), associated with forests dominated by Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Castellano), gregarious, often cespitose, on the ground, usually in conifer forests, (Kanouse), in rich soil in hardwood forests (Hansen for north Europe), on ground in woods, especially Quercus (oak), (Dennis), prefers the company of hardwoods (Harmaja), summer and fall (Bacon)

Otidea oregonensis.nameOrigin: named after Oregon "where most of the specimens of this species have been collected"
Otidea oregonensis.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [tufted], under conifers (for examined collections where habitat mentioned), October to December for examined collections

Otidea propinquata.nameOrigin: related to 'propinquus' which is Latin for 'near'
Otidea propinquata.habitat: gregarious or cespitose [tufted], spruce forests on calcareous ground in Europe, the Washington collection under fir; August to October in the collections examined

Otidea pseudoleporina.nameOrigin: means false (Otidea) leporina, referring to a close relationship with that species
Otidea pseudoleporina.habitat: gregarious under conifers (conifers at least mentioned when habitat specified for collections examined), fruiting from September to November in the collections examined, except for one collection each from March, May, August, and December

Otidea rainierensis.nameOrigin: means "from Mt. Rainier", where the type was found
Otidea rainierensis.habitat: single to gregarious on humus in woods, collections in August and September, (Kanouse)

Otidea smithii.nameOrigin: presumably after A.H. Smith who collected this species in California
Otidea smithii.habitat: single to gregarious on exposed soil, duff or moss under Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), August through December, (Castellano), on soil under conifers, (Kanouse), gregarious or cespitose; in collections examined fruiting September to December, (Olariaga)

Otidea tuomikoskii.nameOrigin: after R. Tuomikoski, the name associated with the type collection
Otidea tuomikoskii.habitat: gregarious to cespitose [tufted], most often among needle litter or even on very decayed wood, in coniferous forests; the type was found on an anthill; in collections examined fruiting August to December

Otidea unicisa.nameOrigin: means 'with one cut', presumably referring to the split fruitbody
Otidea unicisa.habitat: single or in clusters on ground in mixed or coniferous woods, (Phillips), on ground (Kanouse), single or cespitose [in tufts] on soil in coniferous or mixed woods, (Seaver), gregarious to cespitose [tufted], cited collections from eastern North America fruiting in July and August, (Olariaga)

Ovulinia perplexa.habitat: one to many from a single sclerotium, on Jerusalem artichoke, onions, cucumber, cabbage, and a large number of cultivated vegetables (at type locality)

Pachyella adnata.nameOrigin: means "broadly attached", referring to broad attachment of the fruiting body to the substrate
Pachyella adnata.habitat: gregarious or scattered, on rotten, usually water-soaked wood

Paragalactinia michelii.habitat: single or gregarious on "bare ground on edges of paths and streets, within and outside of forests", July to September, (Breitenbach), on bare soil in woods (Dennis)

Paragalactinia succosa.habitat: single or gregarious in coniferous and hardwood forests on stony, loamy soil and embankments, June to October, (Breitenbach), on the ground in woods, July to September, (Dennis), gregarious or scattered, on damp soil in woods (Seaver), June to August (Phillips)

Paratrichophaea boudieri.nameOrigin: probably after Jean Louis Emile Boudier, 1828-1920, a French pharmacist who wrote "Histoire et classification des discomycetes d'Europe"
Paratrichophaea boudieri.habitat: on soil (Kanouse), single to gregarious "on moss-covered ground in floodplain forest", summer, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Pellidiscus pallidus.habitat: "scattered or somewhat crowded, rarely a few imperfectly confluent", on rotten bark and wood, old woody stems and fallen branches, dead herbaceous stems, and also on rotten leaves of hardwoods, apparently year round, (Donk), Alnus (alder), Cytisus scoparius (broom), Populus, Pteridium aquilinum (bracken fern), Vicia gigantea (giant vetch), (Ginns), on leaf litter of hardwood trees and shrubs, occasionally on conifer needle litter, "also recorded on stems of broom, gorse, clematis, and stinging nettle", usually in small, scattered groups; fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)

Perrotia flammea.habitat: gregarious or crowded on dead branches and twigs of hardwoods and conifers, (Seaver), on hardwood (Hansen, L. for northern Europe), scattered on dead twigs and branches, as of Corylus, Ligustrum, Prunus, Salix, (Dennis(1)), on decorticated hardwood (Haines)

Pestalopezia brunneopruinosa.habitat: on large dead spots on living leaves of Gaultheria shallon (salal), (Seaver)

Pestalopezia tsugae.habitat: erumpent, single or in small groups, in stem of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)

Pezicula corni.nameOrigin: means 'of Cornus' referring to its host
Pezicula corni.habitat: single or cespitose, on Cornus alternifolia (alternate-leaf dogwood), Cornus stolonifera (red-osier dogwood), and unnamed species of Cornus, (Seaver)

Pezicula corylina.habitat: erumpent [emerging from surface], scattered, or more or less in rows, separate, or cespitose, sometimes crowded, on Corylus rostrata (Beaked Hazelnut); conidial fruitbodies erumpent, thickly scattered or more or less in rows, mostly separate, sometimes two or three together, (Seaver)

Pezicula ocellata.habitat: single to gregarious on dead branches and twigs, still with bark, of Populus (poplar), and Salix (willow), spring and fall, (Breitenbach), scattered on Salix branches in spring, also on Hippophae, Populus, and Rhamnus, (Dennis), singly on branches of Salix petiolaris, Salix discolor and other species of Salix and Populus, (Seaver)

Pezicula pruinosa.habitat: scattered, erumpent, "single or in cespitose clusters of three to five apothecia each springing from a stromatic base", emerging from Amelanchier canadensis, Amelanchier alnifolia, and unnamed species of Amelanchier (serviceberry), (Seaver)

Peziza ammophila.nameOrigin: means 'loving sand', may also refer to Ammophila (beachgrass) among which it often grows
Peziza ammophila.habitat: in sandy soil, (Seaver), partly buried in pure sand, in coastal areas, fall, (Hansen), semi-immersed [partly buried] in sand; in coastal sands, often among Ammophila (beachgrass), September to December

Peziza ampliata.habitat: on very rotten wood and on soil containing decayed woody debris, May, (Dennis), late spring to early summer (Hansen), on large trunks or smaller pieces of hardwood, (Hansen, K.)

Peziza arvernensis.nameOrigin: likely refers to Auvergne region of France, named after a Gallic tribe, Arverni, that once inhabited the area
Peziza arvernensis.habitat: single to gregarious in beech forests on ground among leaf litter, April to July, (Breitenbach), on the ground in woods, May to July, (Dennis), on soil, sawdust, and rotting wood, (Hansen)

Peziza brunneoatra.habitat: scattered to gregarious or clustered "on damp soil along roads and paths through the woods, near streams, under trees, etc.", (Arora), scattered or gregarious on the ground in damp places (Seaver), on bare ground (Dennis)

Peziza cerea.habitat: on woody debris, rotting sandbags, and on the soil between paving stones in a damp cellar; all seasons, (Dennis), on limestone, or often on soil mixed with mortar, in wet cellars and garages on plaster covering timber, straw; all year round, (Hansen)

Peziza domiciliana.odour: not distinctive (Phillips), pungent fragrance of fresh morels (R. Sieger, pers. comm.)
Peziza domiciliana.habitat: single to gregarious or clustered "on a wide range of domestic materials: plaster, cement, sand, gravel, coal dust, carpets, fireplace ashes, etc."; said to favor strongly alkaline substrates; in houses, "cellars, greenhouses, shower stalls, damp closets, under porches, on wet rugs, behind refrigerators, around leaky water beds", in cars, (Arora), enriched soil, sawdust, etc., (Hansen), usually associated with buildings, often on damp sand, plaster, in cellars, on rotten wood in houses, (Phillips)

Peziza echinospora.habitat: single, or fused with each other to form clusters, on places "where charcoal has been prepared, burned places on damp ground or in shady spots, in early stages of succession"; May to October, (Breitenbach), on burnt soil and charcoal, May to October, (Dennis), on burnt ground 10-120 weeks after the fire, (Hansen), only on burnt ground (Hansen, K.)

Peziza fimeti.habitat: scattered on cow dung, (Seaver), on dung of herbivores, summer to fall, (Hansen), on dung of cow, horse, sheep, reindeer, (Hansen, K.), on dung of various animals or (at times) on soil or burnt woody remnants (Medardi)

Peziza moseri.habitat: single or in small clusters or gregarious, on old burned places, April to October, but usually in spring, (Breitenbach), often found in fire pits (M. Beug, pers. comm.)

Peziza nivalis.habitat: single to gregarious, on the ground, "commonly in burned places, appearing just when the snow begins to melt, often already developed under the snow", alpine, according to the literature up to 2600m., (Breitenbach), collections in Sierra Nevada always occurred next to decaying grasses, often on burnt ground, (Hansen, K.)

Peziza oliviae.nameOrigin: "for Doris Olivia for help finding this cryptic cup fungus; also reflecting the olive hue of the ascomata"
Peziza oliviae.habitat: "associated with dead woody debris embedded in stream bottoms or on saturated wood, at the stream surface or on stream banks", June through October

Peziza ostracoderma.habitat: on burnt ground or in mushroom-beds, fall, (Hansen), associated with burning or with sterilized soil casing a mushroom bed, (Dennis)

Peziza 'repanda'.edibility: "said to be edible, but easily confused with look-alikes of unknown edibility", (Arora)
Peziza 'repanda'.habitat: single, gregarious, or in clusters on logs and branches (especially of hardwoods), lignin-rich humus, etc., (Arora), on rotten logs or occasionally on soil or chip-piles, (Seaver), on the ground in woods, luxuriant forms on sawdust heaps, (Dennis), on rich soil (Hansen)

Peziza sepiatra.habitat: single on "ground along the edges of paths, in pastures and fields of tall perennials", according to the literature on burned ground and rotten cloth, summer, (Breitenbach), on soil, charcoal, and rotting textiles, (Dennis), on burned ground (Hansen)

Peziza sterigmatizans.habitat: on wet ground; in fall and winter, (Dennis)

Peziza varia.habitat: single or fused together in clusters, in "forests and gardens on buried or rotting wood, roots, and so forth", (Breitenbach), on soil rich in humus and in contact with rotting wood, decaying tree roots and the like, June and fall, (Dennis), on rotting wood or occasionally in basements (Arora), "wood (raw or trimmed, sometimes also painted, occasionally buried), sandy or gravelly, calcareous or acid soil, composted loam, between floor tiles, in cellars or caves, on burnt remnants", "on building, textile, or papery residues", and on dung of herbivores, such as equine or bovine or bear (but not recorded from moose dung), (Medardi)

Peziza vesiculosa.nameOrigin: "blister-like", coming from the fact that the spore-bearing surface in the center of the cup commonly detaches from underlying flesh to form blisters, (Dennis)
Peziza vesiculosa.edibility: not recommended, one source says it is poisonous unless well-cooked, (Arora)
Peziza vesiculosa.habitat: single or gregarious, "usually fused together in clusters to form large clumps", on "dungheaps, manured ground, commonly on horse manure, in commercial mushroom beds", throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on manure heaps and richly manured soil, mushroom beds, etc., August to April, (Dennis), restricted to +/- manured straw or hay, richly manured soil and mulched beds, but apparently not or rarely directly on dung, (Hansen, K.), single "or more often gregarious (sometimes in large clusters) on manure, dung, rotting straw, in corrals, around stables, gardens, and other fertilized areas, etc.", (Arora), "on manure heaps and rich manured soil", "June to October; November to February on West Coast", (Lincoff(2)), on droppings of large herbivores or on the ground, all year especially late winter and spring, (Lincoff(1)), "on manure heaps, old straw, or composted soil", (Trudell)

Pezoloma ciliifera.habitat: gregarious on the ground among Sphagnum moss and Carex (sedge), (Dennis), gregarious in wet places, bogs, on Sphagnum, wood, and various kinds of debris; collections examined from April, May, August, October, (Garcia), single or gregarious, (Galan), in OR in Sphagnum bog at the end of May (main photograph)

Phialina lachnobrachya.habitat: gregarious on leaves of Betula (birch), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Rhododendron, Corylus (hazel), 3 collections from leaf petioles, 2 from capsules of Aesculus (buckeye-horsechestnut); mainly fruiting in fall

Phylloscypha phyllogena.habitat: "scattered, in groups, or in clusters on soil or decaying wood; spring and early summer, also winter and spring in California", (Beug), summer to fall, especially on trunks of Salix (willow), (Hansen, L.(1) for northern Europe)

Pithya cupressina.habitat: gregarious on recently killed foliage of various species of Juniperus, Cupressus, Thuja, and Sequoia, (Seaver), on twigs and needles of Juniperus, late fall to spring, (Hansen), on dead leaves of Juniperus (Dennis)

Pithya vulgaris.habitat: "on wet, dead, usually detached branch tips (with needles) and twigs of Abies and Sequoia, in montane areas often within several yards of snowbanks or within a few weeks of snowmelt", March to May, also in fall, (Castellano), gregarious on foliage and bark on Abies, Sequoia, and Libocedrus, (Seaver), on branches and needles of Abies, more rarely Picea, (Hansen, for Europe)

Plectania melastoma.nameOrigin: Plectania harnischii is "dedicated to our Canadian friend Johannes Harnisch, who first brought this species to our attention and who miraculously survived the attack of a Grizzly". 'Melastoma' means 'with a black mouth'.
Plectania melastoma.habitat: Plectania harnischii has been found under conifers so far (all 6 collections), sometimes on decaying wood, from May to August; Plectania melastoma has been found under hardwoods or conifers or the decaying wood of either, (Carbone), single or more often in small groups or clusters "on decaying sticks and other debris of both hardwoods and conifers", mainly fruiting in spring, (Arora), usually associated with decaying woody debris of relatively small diameter (often less than 7.5-10cm), fruiting in spring, (Castellano)

Plectania milleri.nameOrigin: named after Orson K. Miller, who collected the type material
Plectania milleri.habitat: gregarious to crowded, saprophytic in plant debris, fruiting during May and June, (Paden), associated with mixed conifers (Castellano)

Plicaria carbonaria.habitat: gregarious on burned ground, September to May, (Breitenbach), on burned ground, fruiting 10-200 weeks after fire, (Hansen)

Plicaria endocarpoides.habitat: single to gregarious "on burnt ground, old campfire sites, etc.; usually but not always fruiting in the spring", (Arora), scattered to gregarious on burned soil in spring, (Tylutki), on burned ground, 20-130 weeks after fire, all through the year, (Hansen)

Plicaria trachycarpa.habitat: gregarious or densely crowded, often forming continuous masses over a space of several centimeters, on burned ground and charcoal beds, (Seaver), scattered to gregarious on burned soil, spring and fall, (Tylutki), on burned ground and on sterilized soil, October to May, (Dennis), on burned ground, 10-130 weeks after fire, the whole year, (Hansen)

Podophacidium xanthomelum.habitat: gregarious or tightly clustered, on bare or needle-covered or moss-covered ground in coniferous forests, more rarely in hardwood forests, (Breitenbach), thickly gregarious, occasionally a few closely crowded, on soil in coniferous woods, (Seaver)

Polydesmia pruinosa.nameOrigin: means 'pruinose' probably referring to appearance of spore-bearing surface
Polydesmia pruinosa.habitat: often confluent, on different pyrenomycetes, (Korf), single to cespitose or crowded together, growing on Sphaeriales on dead branches, (Breitenbach)

Porotheleum fimbriatum.nameOrigin: means "fringed, with a border of hairs", (Gilbertson)
Porotheleum fimbriatum.habitat: annual, on dead conifers and hardwoods, associated with a spongy white rot, (Gilbertson), on dead wood of hardwood and coniferous trees and rarely even on bare soil, (Reid)

Pseudaleuria quinaultiana.nameOrigin: refers to Lake Quinault, Washington, where type was collected
Pseudaleuria quinaultiana.habitat: scattered or in clusters, near the butt end of fallen conifers, on wood or soil, in spring, (Lusk), primarily in old growth forest with Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Trudell)

Pseudociboria umbrina.nameOrigin: probably referring to brown color of fruitbody
Pseudociboria umbrina.habitat: arising from leaf-blades or veins, on decaying leaves of alder, without stroma, (Kanouse, repeated by Seaver)

Pseudombrophila cervaria.habitat: gregarious, superficial, on dung of deer, (Brummelen)

Pseudombrophila deerrata.habitat: on rotting remains of plants according to literature, April-July (October), (Breitenbach, whose collection was on needles and twigs covered with bird droppings), on dead herbaceous stems, especially on Brassicaceae, (Seaver), on plant debris, including decaying bracken, flax, rotting stems of Heracleum, Cirsium, Lupinus, and Brassica and on rotting swedes, May to November, (Dennis), Pseudombrophila habitat given as dung or manured soil, a habitat also suggested by 'merdaria', (Hansen, L.), collection on soil, dead grass & weeds and dead apple twigs in the weed control strip between apple trees, (H. Larsen, pers. comm.)

Pseudombrophila hepatica.habitat: members of this genus fruit on dung or on manured soil (Hansen)

Pseudopeziza medicaginis.habitat: on living or dying leaves of species of Medicago (medick), Trigonella and Melilotus (sweet clover)

Pseudopeziza trifolii.nameOrigin: means 'of Trifolium (clover)', referring to its host
Pseudopeziza trifolii.habitat: gregarious to cespitose, on upper sides of green leaves of Trifolium spp. (clover), in fall, (Breitenbach), on living leaves of Trifolium spp., May to November, (Dennis), gregarious to cespitose, on living leaves of species of Trifolium (clover), (Seaver)

Pseudopithyella minuscula.habitat: on decaying foliage of cedar (Seaver for Bermuda and Portugal), on foliage of Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), (Larsen(2))

Pseudoplectania melaena.habitat: single to gregarious on "rotting trunks and branches of Abies alba (silver fir) which lie on the ground, also on buried wood", March to May, (Breitenbach), gregarious or scattered, on decaying wood in coniferous woods, especially among Sphagnum, (Seaver), "on twigs and other woody debris, usually of conifers", late winter or early spring, (Trudell)

Pseudoplectania nigrella.habitat: single, gregarious, or clustered, "in cushion-like low mosses on very rotten conifer stumps, on path embankments on bare sandy ground", according to the literature also on ground covered with needle litter, April to May, (Breitenbach), "gregarious or occasionally closely crowded", on "decaying wood in coniferous woods, especially among Sphagnum", (Seaver)

Pulvinula carbonaria.nameOrigin: refers to habitat on burned ground
Pulvinula carbonaria.habitat: gregarious or crowded on "soil among mosses in places which have been burned but subsequently overgrown with mosses"

Pulvinula convexella.habitat: in sandy soil, along brooklets, etc., (Hansen for P. convexella), on rich mull, burnt ground and in pure limestone, (Hansen for P. constellatio), single to gregarious or in clusters on bare sandy ground on roadsides and pathsides, or among mosses, or on burned ground, (Breitenbach)

Pulvinula laeterubra.habitat: "on the ground and on burnt ground which has been overrun by mosses"

Pyrenopeziza benesuada.habitat: gregarious to clustered on "dead branches of Salix (willow) still with bark and attached or lying on the ground", according to the literature on Alnus; summer, (Breitenbach), on dead wet sticks (Kanouse)

Pyrenopeziza revincta.habitat: gregariously on rotting stems of Filipendula ulmaria (meadowsweet), (Breitenbach, for Switzerland), on herbaceous stems or Rubus canes, (Kanouse)

Pyrenopeziza rubi.habitat: gregarious or occasionally crowded, on dead canes of Rubus

Pyronema domesticum.habitat: "crowded together to form lumpy coatings" over a few square decimeters, growing on burned ground (usually developing in the beginning stage of the recovery), (Breitenbach), on burnt ground, steam-sterilized soil, and wet plaster, (Dennis), in North America the Pyronema that invades greenhouses is Pyronema domesticum, although P. omphalodes has been found in greenhouses in Japan, (Beug), recorded in Washington from campground fireplaces on burned wood as well as on soil and on pebbles in the fireplaces, (I. Gibson, pers. comm.)

Pyronema omphalodes.habitat: on burned places, in greenhouses on steamed soil or soil that has been sterilized by dry heat, (Seaver), on burned ground, throughout the year, (Dennis), already one to two weeks after a burn, fruiting all year, (Hansen, L.)

Rectipilus idahoensis.habitat: type on wood of Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), (Cooke)

Resupinatus poriaeformis.habitat: annual, on dead hardwoods, associated with a white rot, (Gilbertson), associated with a soft brown rot (Ginns), on rotting hardwood, typically on large fallen branches or trunks in old hardwood woodland, massed together "in irregular patches and easily mistaken for a lichen", summer to all year, (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter

Resupinatus urceolatus.nameOrigin: means 'urceolate' (having the shape of a pitcher with large body and small mouth)
Resupinatus urceolatus.habitat: on dead hardwood, (Breitenbach), on rotting wood (Cooke)

Rhodotarzetta rosea.habitat: gregarious on burned ground, September to October (Dennis for United Kingdom), growing in masses on burned ground, June to September, (Lincoff), on burned ground, summer to fall (Hansen for Scandinavia), in groups or clusters on burned ground, June to September, (Bessette), found in burned areas (Arora)

Roseodiscus subcarneus.habitat: growing on and apparently killing various species of liverworts and mosses: Jungermania sp., Dicranum flagellare, (Seaver), on a liverwort on a log, parasitic on liverworts and mosses, (Kanouse), single, sparse, or rather numerous, growing on and apparently killing various species of Jungermaniaceous liverworts and mosses, originating from the leafy branches, all collections in September except once in July, (White)

Rutstroemia sydowiana.habitat: scattered, growing singly, erumpent from beneath the surface on petioles, midribs, lateral veins and blades of fallen overwintered leaves of Quercus (oak), the leaves not showing evidence of stromatization, in Oregon two collections said by collector to be on Quercus garryana in November and Acer sp. in September, in England and Germany September to December, (White, W.L.), on "oak leaves lying on the ground in damp places, principally on the petioles but also on the ribs", August to September, usually single, but also up to 3 fruitbodies on a leaf, (Breitenbach), 1-3 from stromatized areas of petioles and leaf nerves of Quercus leaves, fruiting in the fall, (Hansen, L.)

Saccobolus depauperatus.habitat: scattered or gregarious on dung of horse, cow, sheep, deer, porcupine, moose, rabbit, hare, also on mud plaster of a wall, (Brummelen)

Saccobolus versicolor.habitat: scattered or gregarious on dung of cow, caribou, horse, goat, sheep, deer, hare, rabbit, lemming, muskrat, and mouse, also on rotten stems of cabbage and on pasteboard, (Brummelen)

Sageria tsugae.habitat: single or cespitose in clusters of 2 or 3, on stem and branches of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)

Sarcoleotia globosa.nameOrigin: refers to the spherical head on the fruiting body
Sarcoleotia globosa.habitat: gregarious or occasionally single, usually in disturbed habitats or in open plant communities, typically with moss, August and September, (Jumpponen)

Sarcoscypha coccinea.habitat: single or in groups on buried or fallen hardwood sticks or branches, winter and early spring, (Arora), singly to gregariously on branches of hardwood trees covered with earth or moss, February to May, (Breitenbach for Europe), hardwood twigs and branchlets that have started to decompose and are partly buried within the top 5cm of soil and forest litter, (Harrington)

Sarcosphaera coronaria.edibility: not recommended: a few people are adversely affected by it, (Arora), edible cooked, but indigestible for some, poisonous raw, (Lincoff(1))
Sarcosphaera coronaria.habitat: single to gregarious in clusters of 2-5, developing at or below ground level, but usually exposed or partly exposed when mature, common under western conifers, found in spring but also summer and fall, (Arora), single or clustered in hardwood and coniferous forest, park grounds, path borders, ground, street gravel, needle litter, (Breitenbach), February to July, (Trappe, M.(3))

Sarea resinae.nameOrigin: refers to its growth on resin
Sarea resinae.habitat: gregarious to densely crowded, on "resinous exudates of conifers" (Breitenbach), on "resinous exudations on the bark on conifers, often associated with the conidial state", "and on coniferous stumps, in winter and spring", (Dennis)

Sclerotinia juncigena.habitat: in culms of Juncus, usually one fruitbody from each sclerotium

Sclerotinia veratri.nameOrigin: means 'of Veratrum', referring to the host
Sclerotinia veratri.habitat: single to gregarious on stems of rotting Veratrum spp. (corn-lily), fruiting in the spring shortly after snow melt, (MykoWeb(1)), type on Veratrum californicum in Colorado: the sclerotia were often observed on old stems but cups seldom found, (Davidson, R.W.)

Scutellinia crucipila.habitat: scattered on soil (Denison), single to crowded together in troops, on damp bare ground, on path edges, in ruts, under grasses and herbs; June to August, (Breitenbach), "among mosses or on bare ground under grasses and other herbaceous plants", (Trudell)

Scutellinia erinaceus.habitat: intensely gregarious, but rarely so crowded as to be distorted by mutual pressure, on well rotted deciduous wood, July to December, (Denison)

Scutellinia scutellata.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "bowl-shaped" or "flat", (Lincoff(1)), "scutella" is Latin for "a little dish", (Denison), "scutellate" is a botanical term means 'shaped like a shield or platter'
Scutellinia scutellata.habitat: scattered to gregarious "on rotten wood, bark, or soil; less often on a variety of other substrates: e.g., wood ashes, decaying leaves, and rotting sporophores of Fomes spp.; throughout the growing season", (Denison), gregarious to thickly clustered, sometimes single, on damp rotten wood, (Breitenbach), spring, summer, fall, (Bacon)

Scutellinia umbrarum.nameOrigin: from Latin "umbra" = "shade", meaning 'of the shadows'; 'umbrorum' would mean 'of the Umbri' (a people of central Italy)
Scutellinia umbrarum.habitat: scattered to single on soil or trash, rarely on fragments of rotten wood embedded in moist soil, May to November, (Denison), singly to cespitose and in troops on damp bare ground, rotten wet wood and plant debris, May to October, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Scutellinia verrucipolaris.nameOrigin: means 'with warts at poles', referring to spores
Scutellinia verrucipolaris.habitat: gregarious on soil and occasionally wood

Selenaspora guernisacii.habitat: "In Oregon cespitose to gregarious, rarely scattered, among mosses (especially Funaria hygrometrica Hedw.) on soil where logging slash had been burned 12-16 months earlier", from France "on old walls and slaty slopes, among small mosses", from Netherlands "sur fiente animal, entre les mousses sur une place a charbon"

Smardaea planchonis.habitat: gregarious or scattered on sandy soil by roadsides, hillsides and on sand-dunes

Sowerbyella rhenana.habitat: scattered to gregarious or cespitose in duff of moist, relatively undisturbed, older coniferous forests, (Castellano), gregarious, often in small clusters, on ground or moss in woods (usually under conifers), (Arora)

Stictis chrysopsis.habitat: on a variety of woody plants, apparently characteristic of dry interior regions

Stictis polycocca.habitat: gregarious, on herbaceous debris, rarely on wood

Stictis radiata.habitat: "On bark, decorticated wood, herbaceous stems, and even conifer needles and old leather", (Sherwood), gregarious on wounds on living hardwood trees, fruiting in fall and winter, (Breitenbach), on woody twigs, (Dennis)

Strobiloscypha keliae.nameOrigin: honors Keli Kuykendall who made the first collection
Strobiloscypha keliae.habitat: on damp decaying cones of Chamaecyparis lawsonia (Port-Orford-cedar) and on cones of Sequoiadendron giganteum (Giant Sequoia), the old cones in each case partly worked into the ground, each fruiting in February

Stromatinia gladioli.habitat: densely cespitose [in tufts], parasitic on Gladiolus, Freesia, and Crocus

Stromatocyphella conglobata.nameOrigin: means 'conglobate' which means 'massed into a ball or (with stem) fused together making a fleshy mass'
Stromatocyphella conglobata.habitat: arising from within lenticels on bark of Alnus, Betula, and Juglans cinerea (Cooke)

Strossmayeria atriseda.nameOrigin: from Latin, meaning "with a black subiculum"
Strossmayeria atriseda.habitat: single to gregarious (but growing individually), on old moist wood that it covers in stellate [star-shaped] fashion, and on barkless wood of Corylus avellana (Common Hazel), (Iturriaga)

Tapesia fusca.habitat: gregarious to cespitose on various kinds of bark and rotting wood, but usually on hardwood trees, spring to fall, (Breitenbach), scattered or gregarious on wood and bark of various kinds, (Seaver)

Tarzetta catinus.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "small bowl", from the shape, (Lincoff(1))
Tarzetta catinus.habitat: several to gregarious "on the ground in gardens, mulch beds under hardwoods and conifers"; "spring, summer, and fall during wet weather", (Miller), single or more rarely crowded together, in forests, in gardens, on roadsides, or on soil, June to September, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), single or in clusters, in woods, especially of Fagus, (Dennis for UK)

Tarzetta cupularis.nameOrigin: means "like a small mug" from Greek, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Tarzetta cupularis.habitat: on burned ground, damp soil, and moss in coniferous woods, June to September, (Phillips), usually single, but also gregarious, on "loamy streetsides and embankments, under trees, bushes, and herbs, usually on bare ground", April to October, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Tatraea macrospora.habitat: single or more rarely in crowded clusters of 6-12, on hard parts of decaying stumps, logs, and fallen limbs of hardwood species, also reported on conifer wood

Thecotheus cinereus.habitat: on dung of animals including cow, goat, horse, (Kimbrough)

Thecotheus crustaceus.nameOrigin: means "without granules", referring to spores without granular markings, (Kimbrough)
Thecotheus crustaceus.habitat: on dung of animals, including horse, moose, (Kimbrough)

Thecotheus keithii.nameOrigin: "from Latin, apiculus, for the apiculate spores", (Kimbrough)
Thecotheus keithii.habitat: on dung of animals including horse, (Kimbrough)

Thecotheus pelletieri.habitat: on dung of animals including cow and horse, (Kimbrough)

Thelebolus stercoreus.habitat: on dung of all kinds, throughout the year, (Dennis), gregarious or scattered; on dung of various kinds, especially abundant on goat dung; more rarely on wood, (Seaver), scattered, somewhat gregarious, or sometimes clustered, (Kimbrough)

Triblidium caliciforme.habitat: collection on bark of Quercus (oak) in fall (Dennis), BC collection also on oak bark but in February

Tricharina gilva.habitat: on burnt ground and cinder heaps, especially after they have become overgrown with moss, (Dennis for UK), cespitose to clustered on bare and mossy burned ground, April to July, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)

Trichobolus zukalii.nameOrigin: in honor of the mycologist H. Zukal
Trichobolus zukalii.habitat: on 12 North American collections, 11 occurred on deer dung, the remaining one on moose dung, reported in Europe on goat dung and deer dung, (Kimbrough(3))

Trichophaea abundans.habitat: on peat moss on burned soil; on sterilized soil in a greenhouse, (Kanouse), on burnt ground, very soon after the burning, (Hansen), on charred wood and burnt ground, spring and fall, (Dennis)

Trichophaea bullata.habitat: scattered to gregarious on soil among mosses, on cellar floor, on wet earth and humus

Trichophaea contradicta.habitat: gregarious to crowded, on burned soil or charcoal in late spring or early summer, (on burned soil and litter at the edge of a forest fire site, beside highway in Glacier National Park, BC, June 26, 1971, and on burnt ground, New York Botanical Garden, NY, June 27, 1916)

Trichophaea gregaria.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to a flock or herd', presumably referring to gregarious habit
Trichophaea gregaria.habitat: single to gregarious on bare sandy ground on the edges of paths, also (less often) on burned places, July-September, (Breitenbach), on soil, rotting wood and decayed leaves, (Kanouse)

Trichophaea hemisphaerioides.habitat: single to gregarious "on burned ground, commonly among the burned-ground moss (Funaria stage of succession) and on burned pieces of wood", April-October, (Breitenbach), on burnt ground, 20-50 weeks after the burning, all year, (Hansen), on burnt ground amongst Funaria in woods, April to September, (Dennis)

Trichophaeopsis bicuspis.nameOrigin: refers to the hairs which go in two directions from the attachment - the Latin description calls the hair "bicuspidatis"
Trichophaeopsis bicuspis.habitat: gregarious and crowded together, on "damp dead barkless branches" of hardwood, according to the literature also on damp ground, fruiting August to October, (Breitenbach), on wet aspen leaves, on rotten wood, May, August, and September, (Kanouse), the fruitbodies "were originally described from soil, but most of the collections are either on decaying leaves or on decorticated wood, or twigs or branches", predominantly of various species of Populus, (Korf)

Tympanis alnea.habitat: usually cespitose in clusters of 10-20 or more, occasionally single, on Alnus (alder) and Betula (birch), (Groves), in groups of 5-30, on "dead branches of Alnus (alder) still attached to the tree and with bark, as well as small trunks", according to the literature also on Betula (birch); spring, (Breitenbach), occasionally on Abies (Ouellette)

Tympanis amelanchieris.habitat: gregarious to scattered cespitose in small clusters of 2 to 8, occasionally single, on Amelanchier spp. (serviceberry, shadbush)

Tympanis confusa.habitat: "gregarious, separate, or cespitose, usually with less than six in a cluster but occasionally in large clusters of 15 or more", on pine; conidial fruitbodies erumpent, scattered to gregarious, separate or cespitose, (Groves)

Tympanis hypopodia.habitat: gregarious, separate to cespitose with usually less than 6 in a cluster, erumpent [emerging], on Pinus spp. (pine); conidial fruitbodies also gregarious to scattered, separate or cespitose, erumpent, (Groves), may occur also on Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), or hemlock (at least on Tsuga canadensis in eastern North America)

Tympanis laricina.habitat: scattered, separate or cespitose, erumpent [emerging] "in small usually more or less elongated clusters", on Larix spp. (larch); conidial fruitbodies "erumpent, cespitose, in clusters of up to 12-15, occasionally single", the clusters 0.05-0.1cm across and 0.04-0.1cm high, (Groves), on Larix (larch), Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), and Thuja (Red-cedar), (Ouellette)

Tympanis spermatiospora.habitat: gregarious, separate, or cespitose in clusters of about 2-8, erumpent; on Populus spp.; conidial fruitbodies "erumpent, gregarious, cespitose in clusters of up to 15, occasionally single", (Groves), single or more often in dense cespitose clusters, on dead branches of Populus, especially Populus tremuloides (quaking aspen), (Seaver), erumpent, separate or cespitose, on Populus or Salix, (Hansen)

Tympanis truncatula.habitat: gregarious, cespitose, or occasionally single; erumpent on Abies spp. (fir); conidial fruitbodies "usually scarce, erumpent, cespitose or single", (Groves)

Unguiculella oregonensis.habitat: growing superficially on the stroma of a Eutypa sp., (Kanouse)

Valdensinia heterodoxa.habitat: found on Gaultheria shallon (salal), Vaccinium membranaceum (mountain huckleberry), Vaccinium alaskaense (Alaskan blueberry), and other species (Acer macrophyllum (big-leaf maple), Dryopteris austriaca (spinulose wood fern), Malus fusca (Pacific crab-apple), Menziesia ferruginea (false azalea), Polystichum munitum (sword fern), Pteridium aquilinum (bracken fern), Rubus parviflorus (thimbleberry), Rubus pedatus (trailing raspberry), Rubus ursinus (pacific dewberry), (Ginns for BC)), other species elsewhere

Velutarina rufo-olivacea.habitat: single or several together in dense clusters on dead branches of various kinds: Quercus (oak), Betula (birch), Andromeda, Sassafras, and Rubus, (Seaver), single or in small clusters on dead twigs and branches, Acer (maple), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Rosa (rose), Rubus, Ulex (gorse), December to May, (Dennis), single or in small clusters, on deciduous trees and shrubs e.g. Salix (willow), (Hansen)

Vexillomyces atrovirens.habitat: on wet, very rotten hardwood; April to October in Europe

Vexillomyces pseudotsugae.habitat: gregarious, separate or cespitose in clusters of up to 10, on Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Groves)

Vibrissea decolorans.habitat: gregarious on decaying sticks lying in the water, (Seaver), on a wet stick (Kanouse), gregarious to cespitose on damp barkless wood of hardwoods lying in wet places, according to literature commonly on wood of Rosaceae; March to June, (Breitenbach), on hardwood soaked in water, (Hansen)

Vibrissea filisporia.habitat: single or gregarious, on dead sticks and wood in water, (Seaver), on deciduous wood and culms of Phragmites reed soaked in water, (Hansen)

Vibrissea truncorum.habitat: single, gregarious, or in clusters of 2 or 3 each, on wholly or partly submerged sticks etc., in brooks, mostly at higher altitudes, (Seaver), gregarious, cespitose [in tufts] or scattered, on decaying wood, leaves etc. in cold wet places, often in streams, (Mains), the ascospores, when mature, project and vibrate in the running water above the fertile area giving the fruiting body a white silky appearance, (Tylutki), gregarious on wood and remains of roots that are very wet or under water, in ditches among Sphagnum, or in small streams, commonly montane to alpine, (Breitenbach for Europe)

Wynnella silvicola.odour: unique strong odor when dried, but not detected fresh, (Abbott)
Wynnella silvicola.habitat: "solitary to gregarious or scattered and numerous on duff, rarely in burned areas, under conifers", June to September, (Abbott)

Abortiporus biennis.habitat: typically "on the ground arising from buried roots (perhaps both live and dead roots), also on hardwood and conifer logs, causing a white rot", (Ginns), annual, on numerous hardwood genera, rarely on conifers, often on ground from buried roots; causes white rot of dead hardwoods and white trunkrot of living hardwoods, (Gilbertson), single or in groups, on soil but always associated with buried dead wood, (Breitenbach), summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Albatrellopsis confluens.nameOrigin: means "running together, blended into one, confluent", (Gilbertson)
Albatrellopsis confluens.odour: pleasant, often aromatic (Gilbertson), pleasant, even fragrant, (Miller)
Albatrellopsis confluens.habitat: annual; single to several on a branched stem, on soil in coniferous forest, (Gilbertson), fruiting in summer and fall (Miller)

Albatrellopsis flettii.habitat: annual; "scattered to gregarious or in fused clusters on ground in mixed woods and under conifers", (Arora), on soil in coniferous forest systems, (Gilbertson)

Albatrellus avellaneus.nameOrigin: means 'avellaneous in color': type specimen was avellaneous on cap center and margin; 'avellana' is Italian for 'hazelnut'
Albatrellus avellaneus.taste: none or disagreeable or somewhat bitter
Albatrellus avellaneus.habitat: annual; under conifers especially hemlock and spruce

Albatrellus ovinus.edibility: edible when cooked well, but large quantities can have laxative effects (Arora)
Albatrellus ovinus.taste: mild, sometimes bitterish (Lincoff(2)), sweet, of almonds, sometimes a little bitter, (Lincoff(1))
Albatrellus ovinus.odour: aromatic with pleasant odor (Gilbertson), mild (Lincoff(2)), somewhat acid, fruity, (Lincoff(1))
Albatrellus ovinus.habitat: annual; single to scattered or gregarious, sometimes in fused clusters, on ground in mixed woods and under conifers, (Arora), on ground in coniferous forest, (Gilbertson), late summer and fall (Miller)

Albatrellus subrubescens.habitat: annual; single or cespitose (2-8 joined at base), under conifers, especially 2-needle and 3-needle pines, (Ginns(1)), the holotype was under oak in Florida

Amaropostia stiptica.habitat: annual, single or in small clusters, on dead wood of conifers and hardwoods, associated with brown cubical rot, (Gilbertson), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Amylocystis lapponica.habitat: annual; on conifers, forming a brown cubical rot, and functioning as a decomposer of fallen trees, particularly common on spruce logs and its fruiting bodies develop near melting snow early in spring

Anomoloma albolutescens.nameOrigin: mean "a combination of white and yellow" (Gilbertson)
Anomoloma albolutescens.habitat: annual; on coniferous wood, causing a brown rot, more rarely on hardwood such as maple or birch, (Gilbertson(1)), causes a white rot: contrary to previous reports, does not cause a brown rot (Ginns)

Anomoloma myceliosum.habitat: annual; on fairly rotten conifer wood, causing a white rot, rarely on hardwood such as Betula (birch)

Anomoporia bombycina.habitat: annual; on conifer wood, causing a brown rot

Antella americana.habitat: annual, on hardwoods including Fagus (beech) and also reported on Hymenochaete species, causes a white rot, (Gilbertson), a successor of Hymenochaete tabacina, usually fruiting on its dead fruitbodies, (Miettinen)

Antrodia albida.habitat: annual; on hardwood, more rarely on conifer wood, common on dead branches on junipers; causes a brown rot (Gilbertson), all year (Buczacki)

Antrodia albobrunnea.nameOrigin: means "a combination of white and dark brown" (Gilbertson)
Antrodia albobrunnea.habitat: annual, or sometimes reviving a second year, on conifer wood, seemingly most common on Pinus (pine), restricted to high altitude and areas with continental climate, causes a brown cubical rot, "white mycelial felts develop in the decayed wood"

Antrodia alpina.habitat: perennial, on conifer wood, especially Pinus (pine) and Larix (larch), causes a brown cubical rot in dead conifers

Antrodia carbonica.habitat: annual to occasionally perennial, on conifer wood, mainly Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), causes a brown cubical rot on conifer wood, "important in decay of mine timber and utility poles"

Antrodia gossypium.habitat: annual, on conifer wood; causing a brown rot, (Gilbertson), on dead and rotting conifer wood, perhaps all year but mainly fall, (Buczacki)

Antrodia heteromorpha.habitat: annual, on conifer wood, occasionally on hardwood, causes a brown cubical rot in conifer wood

Antrodia madronae.nameOrigin: means 'of madrone', referring to the only known substrate tree, Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone)
Antrodia madronae.habitat: the two known collections on dead branches of standing Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone); causing a brown rot

Antrodia mappa.habitat: annual, mainly on dead conifer wood, a few records on hardwood, rail fences and timber bridges are likely substrates; associated with brown cubical rot

Antrodia sinuosa.habitat: annual, dead conifers, and often on burnt logs, rarely on hardwoods, causes a brown cubical rot on conifers, (Buczacki), all year (Buczacki)

Antrodia variiformis.habitat: annual, on conifers, and also reported on Betula (birch) and Quercus (oak), causes a brown rot

Antrodia xantha.habitat: annual, usually on conifers, often in open and dry localities and commonly on wood without bark, more rarely on hardwoods, especially on Salix (willow) species, causes a brown cubical rot, (Gilbertson), probably all year (Buczacki)

Antrodiella canadensis.habitat: annual, on dead conifers, reported only from Picea (spruce), causes a stringy white rot

Antrodiella romellii.habitat: annual, on dead conifers, also on Populus, causing white saprot, primarily on conifers

Antrodiella semisupina.habitat: annual, usually on hardwoods such as Betula, Alnus, Populus and others, rarely on conifers like Abies, Picea, and Pinus, and on fruiting bodies of other polypores like Fomes, Fomitopsis, and Trichaptum; causes a white rot, (Gilbertson), usually in dense clusters, more rarely single, on dead hardwood, according to literature also rarely on conifers, (Breitenbach), summer, fall, winter, (Buczacki)

Aporpium caryae.habitat: annual, on hardwoods, produces white rot of hardwoods and slash, (Gilbertson)

Auriporia aurea.habitat: annual, on dead conifers and hardwoods

Bjerkandera adusta.habitat: annual, causing a white rot of hardwood logs and slash and occasionally on conifers: it is "particularly common in aspen and is always a conspicuous fungus in older aspen stands", (Gilbertson), on dead hardwood: on stumps, standing trunks, and damaged places on living trees, (Breitenbach), spring to fall (Bacon), all year (Buczacki)

Bjerkandera fumosa.habitat: annual, on dead hardwood, causes white rot of sapwood logs and stumps, (Gilbertson), on dead hardwood or damaged living hardwood trees, (Breitenbach), all year (Buczacki)

Boletopsis grisea.edibility: edible but often bitter: the Japanese soak it in brine to remove the bitterness, (Arora), palatable if soaked, parboiled, and then cooked, (Lincoff(1))
Boletopsis grisea.taste: mild to bitter (Arora), weak when fresh, sweetish to spicy when dry, (Gilbertson)
Boletopsis grisea.habitat: annual, single to scattered or gregarious under hardwoods and conifers, (Arora), growing on ground, mostly under conifers, but also under hardwoods, (Gilbertson), summer and early fall (Miller)

Boletopsis smithii.spores: "although no spore print was taken, it is assumed that it is slightly colored" (Harrison)
Boletopsis smithii.habitat: annual, terrestrial, not a wood-rotting fungus, (Gilbertson), type was brought to annual mushroom show of Puget Sound Mycological Society in Seattle in October 1972 (Harrison)

Bondarzewia occidentalis.taste: mild or sometimes bitter when old, (Arora), sharp when fresh, somewhat bitter when dry, (Breitenbach)
Bondarzewia occidentalis.habitat: annual, single or in groups under conifers, usually near stumps or trunks, (Arora), at or near the base of living conifers, particularly common on Larix (larch), causing white stringy rot of heartwood of roots and stumps of living conifers, (Gilbertson), usually as single compound fruitbodies, a parasite on roots or stumps of Abies (fir), often apparently arising from ground, (Breitenbach for Europe)

Bridgeoporus nobilissimus.nameOrigin: means "very well-known" or "famous" (Gilbertson), could refer to noble fir habitat; the English name comes from Ali and Fred Sandoz who brought it to the attention of scientists in 1943
Bridgeoporus nobilissimus.habitat: perennial, single or occasionally shingled on old growth Abies procera (Noble Fir) that is 1-2 meters or more in diameter at chest height, rarely Abies amabilis, possibly Tsuga heterophylla; position is on root collar of living trees or snags, or up to 1 meter from ground on snags, (Burdsall), "primarily on very old noble firs, at the base of living trees and snags or on top of stumps", (Trudell)

Brunneoporus juniperinus.habitat: perennial, known only from juniper wood, causes a brown cubical heartrot of living Juniperus spp., thick buff-colored mycelial felts develop in the decayed wood

Brunneoporus malicola.habitat: annual to biennial, on dead hardwood, causes a brown rot, (Gilbertson)

Butyrea luteoalba.nameOrigin: means "a combination of golden yellow and white" (Gilbertson)
Butyrea luteoalba.habitat: annual, on dead wood of conifers, causes white pitted and laminated rot of dead conifer wood, (Gilbertson), on the underside of dead conifer wood, (Breitenbach)

Byssoporia terrestris.habitat: annual, "on rotten debris on ground or on dead wood, mostly brown-rotted, of conifers, but also noted on hardwoods like Populus and Quercus", (Gilbertson), mycorrhizal with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (western hemlock), (Larsen), on soil or rotting hardwood, often on large old stumps and logs, (Buczacki)

Calcipostia guttulata.nameOrigin: means "sprinkled with dots of resin or oil" (Gilbertson)
Calcipostia guttulata.habitat: annual, single or imbricate [shingled], primarily on dead conifer wood, but also on hardwoods, associated with a brown cubical rot, also associated with a brown butt rot of living Picea (spruce)

Cerioporus leptocephalus.habitat: annual, usually single, on dead hardwoods, occasionally on conifers, associated with white rot of dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), single or several together "on decaying hardwood sticks, branches and debris (only rarely on conifers)", (Arora)

Cerioporus varius.habitat: annual, on dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, associated with a white rot

Ceriporia excelsa.habitat: annual, growing on dead hardwoods, rarely on conifers, causing a white rot, (Gilbertson), on the underside of dead conifers and hardwoods, (Breitenbach), fall (Buczacki)

Ceriporia purpurea.habitat: annual, on dead hardwoods and conifers, causing white rot, (Gilbertson)

Ceriporia reticulata.habitat: annual, common on dead aspen but also occurring on other hardwoods, rarely on conifers, causing white rot of dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), on hardwoods, usually Populus, (Ginns), on the underside of rotten hardwood, more rarely conifer wood, (Breitenbach), probably all year (Buczacki)

Ceriporia spissa.habitat: annual, on dead hardwoods, occasionally on conifers, causing a white rot, (Gilbertson), typically on underside of deciduous wood, rarely on conifers, (Lincoff)

Ceriporia tarda.habitat: annual, on dead hardwoods, occasionally on conifers, causing a white rot

Ceriporia viridans.habitat: annual, on hardwood, more rarely on conifer wood, mostly on rather rotten wood, causing white rot in hardwoods, (Gilbertson), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Ceriporiopsis mucida.habitat: annual, on rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, causing a white rot

Ceriporiopsis pseudoplacenta.nameOrigin: means "false placenta", based on superficial similarity with Rhodonia placenta
Ceriporiopsis pseudoplacenta.habitat: annual, on rather rotten logs of various conifers, associated with a white rot (although the wood under fruitbodies is "usually quite dark as the fungus causes some red-brownish wood coloration")

Cerrena unicolor.habitat: annual, on dead wood of many genera of hardwoods, rarely on conifers, causing white rot of dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), on living hardwoods as wound parasite, or dead trunks, as well as stumps and hardwood on ground, (Breitenbach), fall (Buczacki)

Cinereomyces lindbladii.habitat: annual, usually on dead conifers especially in pine forests, but also on hardwoods, causes a white rot, (Gilbertson), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Climacocystis borealis.habitat: annual, known almost exclusively from conifers, causes "a white mottled rot in the butt and roots of living conifers, continues decay in dead trees and stumps", developing late in season, (Gilbertson), August to November (Phillips), gregarious, sometimes adjacent fruitbodies growing together, rarely single, on dead wood of conifers, rarely on hardwood, (Breitenbach)

Coltricia cinnamomea.habitat: annual, on the ground usually in deciduous forests, apparently not a wood-rotter, (Gilbertson), "solitary or in small groups on ground or moss in woods, often along well-beaten paths, roadbanks, and in clearings (rarely on rotten wood)", (Arora)

Coltricia montagnei.habitat: annual, "on ground in hardwood forests, rarely in coniferous ones, often on exposed soil, footpaths, clay banks, etc.", apparently not a wood rotting fungus

Coltricia perennis.habitat: annual, on ground "in coniferous forests, often on exposed soil like paths, roadsides, clearings, in vicinity of fireplaces, etc.", (Gilbertson), single to gregarious, "in hardwood and coniferous forests, on soil, among needle litter and mosses, commonly on embankments of sandy soil", (Breitenbach), fruiting in summer and fall (Miller), on the ground or on woody debris, "most characteristic of disturbed areas such as trail edges and roadsides in coniferous forests", (Trudell), fall to early winter (Bacon), all year (Buczacki)

Coniferiporia sulphurascens.habitat: on "live conifers, predominantly Pinaceae", especially Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Abies (true fir), (Ginns), Douglas-fir form [Coniferiporia sulphurascens] produces fruitbodies rarely, on upturned roots and the underside of decayed logs, (Allen), annual on Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and conifers other than Thuja plicata (Western Red-Cedar)

Coniferiporia weirii.habitat: perennial on live and dead conifers, predominately on Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Ginns), perennial or annual, on conifers, causing yellowish laminated rot of roots and butt of living conifers, important as a heart rot of Western Red-cedar and as a root rot of second growth Douglas-fir and true firs, (Gilbertson, including Coniferiporia sulphurascens), causes butt rot in Thuja plicata

Coriolopsis gallica.habitat: annual, on dead hardwood, most common on Salix (willow) and Populus spp., very rarely on conifers, (Gilbertson), single or in groups or rows on dead or living wood of hardwoods, (Breitenbach), fall (Buczacki)

Coriolopsis trogii.habitat: annual, on dead hardwoods, most common on Populus and Salix (willow), associated with a white rot of dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), occasionally single but usually irregularly imbricate [shingled] on dead wood of Populus, rarely on other hardwoods, (Breitenbach)

Cryptoporus volvatus.spores: pinkish or flesh-colored (Arora), white to cream-color (Miller)
Cryptoporus volvatus.habitat: annual, "solitary or more often in groups on dead or occasionally old living conifers", (Arora), single or in large numbers, on recently killed conifers, "commonly fruiting a year after trees are killed by fire, bark beetles, or other factors and then displaced by other saprophytic wood-rotting fungi", especially on Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), causes soft grayish-white rot of sapwood, (Gilbertson), fruiting in spring, summer, and fall, (Miller)

Cyanosporus arbuti.nameOrigin: named after the host Arbutus menziesii
Cyanosporus arbuti.habitat: "so far collected only from fallen dry branches" of Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone)

Cyanosporus caesiosimulans.nameOrigin: 'caesio-' means 'blue-gray', and 'simulans' means 'imitating', perhaps referring to Cyanoporus caesius or Cyanoporus simulans
Cyanosporus caesiosimulans.habitat: on fallen logs and branches of hardwoods and conifers - in Europe preferably on Corylus (hazelnut), in North America on Fagus (beech) and Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen), in East Asia and North America also on Abies (true fir) and Picea (spruce), Washington collections on Abies and on Picea, October 11-17, 2014

Cyanosporus caesius.spores: pale ashy-blue (Arora), bluish (Gilbertson), "pale blue or whitish with a gray-blue tinge", (Phillips)
Cyanosporus caesius.habitat: annual, usually single, on dead conifers and hardwoods, (Gilbertson), single or in small groups on decaying hardwood and conifer wood, associated with a brown carbonizing decay, (Arora), summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Cyanosporus livens.habitat: on fallen logs and branches of conifers (Abies, Picea, Larix, Tsuga) and hardwood trees (Acer, Betula, Fagus)

Cyanosporus simulans.habitat: mostly on conifers (Abies, Cedrus, Juniperus, Picea, Pinus, Thuja, Tsuga) but also regularly on hardwood trees (Corylus, Fagus, Populus, Sorbus, Ulmus)

Cyanosporus subviridis.habitat: conifer logs (Picea, Pinus, the type probably from Abies or Picea)

Cystidiopostia hibernica.habitat: annual, on dead conifers, reported on Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), causing a brown rot, (Gilbertson), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Datronia mollis.habitat: annual, dead hardwood, causing white rot with conspicuous black zone lines in decayed wood, (Gilbertson), on hardwoods, especially Alnus (alder), (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)

Datronia scutellata.nameOrigin: means "covered with small scales or plates" (Gilbertson)
Datronia scutellata.habitat: annual, on several genera, with a slight preference for Alnus (alder), causing a white rot in dead hardwoods

Datronia stereoides.habitat: annual, on dead hardwood, most commonly on Populus and Betula (birch), very rarely on conifers, causes a white rot, (Gilbertson), single or in rows, on underside of dead trunks and branches of Fagus (beech) lying on the ground, also on other hardwoods, (Breitenbach for Europe)

Dichomitus campestris.habitat: annual to perennial, on dead hardwoods including Alnus (alder) and Quercus (oak) in North America, in Europe on many other hosts as well, causes a white rot, (Gilbertson), single to several on one trunk, on "dead, usually standing or attached trunks and branches of Corylus (hazel), but also on Quercus (oak) and Juglans (walnut tree)", (Breitenbach for Europe), mainly fall (Buczacki)

Dichomitus squalens.habitat: annual to reviving a second year, on conifers, causes "a white pocket rot in heartwood of living conifers and also of dead conifer wood"

Diplomitoporus crustulinus.nameOrigin: means "covered by a tough, hard surface layer or crust", (Gilbertson)
Diplomitoporus crustulinus.habitat: annual, on dead conifers, very rarely on angiosperms

Diplomitoporus rimosus.habitat: perennial, virtually restricted to Juniperus (juniper) but also occurring on Cupressus (cypress) in Arizona, causes a white heartrot in living and dead juniper

Erastia salmonicolor.nameOrigin: means "the color of a salmon or salmon flesh, pink" (Gilbertson)
Erastia salmonicolor.habitat: annual, on wood in coniferous forests, associated with a yellowish stringy saprot

Fibroporia radiculosa.habitat: annual, most common on conifer wood, rarely on hardwood, causes a brown cubical rot

Fibroporia vaillantii.habitat: annual, known only from conifers and "mostly found in mines, basements, etc. on structural timbers in humid locations", causes a brown cubical rot, (Gilbertson), probably all year (Buczacki)

Fistulina hepatica.spores: pinkish salmon to pale ocher or pale rusty brown, (Arora), pale rusty brown to pinkish brown (Miller)
Fistulina hepatica.edibility: yes, with strong sour taste (which can be reduced by parboiling), (Arora)
Fistulina hepatica.taste: rather sour or strongly acidic (Arora), sour (Miller)
Fistulina hepatica.habitat: single or sometimes several together "at the bases of hardwoods and on stumps, especially of chestnut and oak"; in coastal California on chinquapin in the fall and winter, (Arora), generally on Quercus (oak) or Castanea (chestnut) but occurring on other hardwoods; causes brown rot of living and dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), July to October (Lincoff(2))

Fomes 'fomentarius'.nameOrigin: from Latin, "producing tinder for fire", from its use, (Lincoff(1)), "fomentarius" points to its use in medicine: Hippocrates wrote about its use in cauterizing wounds to stop bleeding (with a smoldering conk), (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Fomes 'fomentarius'.odour: during its growth it develops a marked banana-like odor (Lincoff(1)), pleasantly fungoid (Breitenbach), none (Miller)
Fomes 'fomentarius'.habitat: on dead or living hardwood trees, including birch, beech, maple and poplar, (Phillips), perennial, on living and dead hardwoods, especially Betula (birch) and Alnus (alder), causing white mottled heartrot of living hardwoods, continuing to fruit on dead and fallen trees, (Gilbertson), on dead hardwoods or wounds in living trees, including maple, birch, beech, hickory, poplar, and cherry, (Lincoff(2)), fruiting all season (Miller), spores produced in fall (Bacon)

Fomes meliae.habitat: annual or biennial, mainly on hardwoods but occasionally on conifers, causes a brown cubical rot of living and dead hardwoods and confers, important "as a heartrot fungus in living peach trees and decay of wood in service", (Gilbertson), can cause a heart rot of living Prunus persica trees.

Fomitiporia fissurata.nameOrigin: "fissurata" is Latin, "referring to striking fissures on pileal surface of the fungus"
Fomitiporia fissurata.habitat: perennial, causing white rot on living Quercus (oak), common on living Quercus spp. in the US southwest

Fomitiporia punctata.habitat: perennial on hardwoods, causing a uniform white rot, (Ginns), perennial, on dead hardwoods and conifers, also on living trees, associated with uniform white rot of dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, (Gilbertson), "on all types of broadleaf wood or bushy shrubs, sometimes parasitic on vines", (Lincoff), all year (Buczacki)

Fomitiporia repanda.habitat: perennial, on dead conifers, generally on fallen trees, associated with white pocket rot of conifer logs and slash

Fomitiporia robusta.nameOrigin: means 'hard and strong like oak' or perhaps referring to habitat on oak
Fomitiporia robusta.habitat: perennial, most common on Quercus (oak) in southern U.S. (but also on other hardwood genera), near the base of the living trees, (Gilbertson), all year (Buczacki)

Fomitiporia tsugina.habitat: perennial, on living and dead conifers, usually fruiting on the underside of branches and in branch crotches, most common on Tsuga (hemlock), associated with a uniform white rot of heartwood of living conifers, continuing in dead trees and logs, (Gilbertson)

Fomitopsis betulina.edibility: no (Phillips), edible when young according to McIlvaine, but tough, (Arora)
Fomitopsis betulina.taste: slightly bitter (Phillips), bitterish (Lincoff(1)), somewhat sour and bitter (Breitenbach)
Fomitopsis betulina.habitat: annual, single or in groups or columns on dead or sometimes living birch trees, (Arora), on birch, especially in North America Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch) and B. alleghaniensis (Yellow Birch), associated with brown cubical rot of the sapwood of dead birch, (Gilbertson), parasitic on birch, rarely on beech, (Lincoff(1)), fruiting in spring, summer, and fall, (Miller)

Fomitopsis mounceae.nameOrigin: named for Irene Mounce (1894-1987), "a pioneering Canadian mycologist, for her contributions to mycology and Fomitopsis (fide Ginns 1988)" (Haight(1) with Latin name italicized)
Fomitopsis mounceae.spores: white or pale yellowish (Arora for Fomitopsis pinicola complex), light yellow (Miller for Fomitopsis pinicola complex)
Fomitopsis mounceae.taste: none (Miller for Fomitopsis pinicola complex), bitter (Breitenbach for Fomitopsis pinicola in Europe)
Fomitopsis mounceae.odour: rather strong and fungal when fresh (Arora for Fomitopsis pinicola complex), citrine-like when fresh and growing (Miller for Fomitopsis pinicola complex)
Fomitopsis mounceae.habitat: perennial, mainly on conifers and aspen, producing a brown cubical rot of dead hardwoods, especially aspen, and conifers, (Haight), perennial, "solitary or in groups on dead trees, logs, and stumps or rarely on living trees", (Arora for Fomitopsis pinicola complex), on "dead conifers and occasionally causing heartrot of living conifers, a major heartrot fungus in black cherry", "also occasionally on aspen and birch", causes brown cubical rot of living and dead conifers and hardwoods, conspicuous "white mycelial felts develop in shrinkage cracks of the decayed wood", (Gilbertson for Fomitopsis pinicola complex), buttons forming in spring, but conks present all year round, (Miller for Fomitopsis pinicola complex), spores produced in fall (Bacon for Fomitopsis pinicola in Europe)

Fomitopsis ochracea.habitat: perennial, producing a brown cubical rot of dead hardwoods and conifers, occasionally on living Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), (Haight), perennial, on "logs and dead, standing trunks of hardwoods and conifers, causing a brown cubical rot", (Ginns)

Fulvifomes robiniae.habitat: on Robinia (locust) and a few other hardwood genera, causing a white rot of heartwood of living black locust

Fuscocerrena portoricensis.habitat: annual to perennial, on hardwoods, causing a white rot of dead hardwoods

Fuscoporia ferrea.habitat: perennial, on dead wood of conifers and hardwoods, associated with uniform white rot, (Gilbertson), all year (Buczacki)

Fuscoporia ferruginosa.habitat: annual, on dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, causing a white laminated rot, (Gilbertson), all year (Buczacki)

Fuscoporia gilva.habitat: often perennial, single or more often in groups on dead or occasionally living hardwoods, producing a general delignifying decay of sapwood, making it whitish and brittle; rarely on conifers, (Arora), perennial or annual, on living and dead hardwoods, especially oak, rarely on conifers, associated with a uniform white rot of dead wood of hardwoods and a heart rot of living trees, (Gilbertson)

Fuscoporia viticola.habitat: perennial, most commonly on conifers, but also on hardwoods, associated with uniform white rot of dead wood, (Gilbertson), [at least in western North America] grows on live and dead hardwoods, rarely on conifers, (Ginns)

Fuscopostia fragilis.habitat: annual, single, on dead conifers, rarely on Populus; associated with brown cubical rot of dead conifer logs and slash, (Gilbertson), single "or in groups or fused clusters on rotting conifers", (Arora), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Fuscopostia lateritia.nameOrigin: refers to the brick-red color of the staining
Fuscopostia lateritia.habitat: annual, on Pinus (pine); causes a brown rot

Fuscopostia leucomallella.nameOrigin: means "like a small white lock of matted wool" (Gilbertson)
Fuscopostia leucomallella.habitat: annual, on dead conifers, causing a brown rot

Ganoderma applanatum.spores: brown or reddish brown (Arora), rust-brown (Lincoff(1)), appear chocolate brown on cap surface (Gilbertson)
Ganoderma applanatum.habitat: perennial, dead standing trees, stumps, and living trees of numerous genera of hardwoods, also common on conifers in Pacific Northwest and rarely on conifers elsewhere, causes a white mottle rot and butt rot of living aspen, also found on dead standing or fallen hardwoods, (Gilbertson), young buttons start in summer but continue fruiting all year (Miller)

Ganoderma brownii.habitat: perennial, on hardwoods, causing white rot of living and dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), single or in small groups "on living or standing dead hardwood trees, stumps, or logs"; in California common, fruiting throughout the year, primarily on bay laurel, (Desjardin), collections in BC on live Aesculus hippocastaneum (Horsechestnut), live Prunus cerasifera var. pissardii (a cultivar of Cherry Plum), and an unidentified log, (Ginns)

Ganoderma lucidum.habitat: single or in small groups at bases of living hardwoods or on stumps and roots, very rarely on conifers (Arora), annual, living hardwoods, also continuing fruiting on dead trees and stumps, causes white root and butt rot of living hardwoods, developing at or near ground line, (Gilbertson)

Ganoderma oregonense.habitat: annual, commonly on dead standing conifers and on conifer stumps, main substrates are Abies (fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), causes white butt and root rot of living and dead conifers, (Gilbertson), fruiting in spring, summer, and fall, (Miller)

Ganoderma tsugae.habitat: annual, "single or clustered", on "live and dead conifers, causing a white butt rot", (Ginns), annual, single or in clusters, on living and dead conifers of several genera, particularly Abies (true fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), causing a white butt rot, (Gilbertson)

Gelatoporia subvermispora.habitat: annual, most common on conifer wood, occasionally on hardwood; causing a white rot

Gilbertsonia angulopora.habitat: annual, known only on dead fallen Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), where it causes a brown cubical rot and cream-colored mycelial felts develop in shrinkage cracks

Gloeophyllum carbonarium.habitat: on charred coniferous wood, causes a brown cubical rot

Gloeophyllum odoratum.odour: with a strong scent of anise when fresh, (Gilbertson), strong of anise or vanilla tending to disappear when old, the odor also present in wood invaded by the hyphae (Lincoff)
Gloeophyllum odoratum.habitat: perennial, on dead coniferous wood, often on structural timber, causes a brown rot

Gloeophyllum protractum.odour: no scent of anise when fresh
Gloeophyllum protractum.habitat: "annual (perennial?)", on coniferous wood especially Pinus (pine), mostly on decorticated wood in open habitats, rarely on hardwoods like Populus and Quercus (oak), causes a brown rot

Gloeophyllum trabeum.nameOrigin: means "wearing a ceremonial robe with purple stripes" (Gilbertson)
Gloeophyllum trabeum.habitat: annual or perennial, most common on hardwood trees, but also noted on conifer wood especially structural timbers, causes a brown rot, one of the most important causes of decay in houses and other wood structures in North America, (Gilbertson), single to gregarious on dead barkless wood of hardwoods and conifers, commonly on construction wood in sunny places, (Breitenbach), probably all year, (Buczacki)

Gloeoporus pannocinctus.nameOrigin: means "with the texture of felt and banded" (Gilbertson)
Gloeoporus pannocinctus.habitat: annual, on dead wood of many genera of hardwoods, especially common on aspen, causes white rot, (Gilbertson), fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)

Grifola frondosa.edibility: only the young tender caps are worth eating but they are choice: long slow cooking is recommended; "allergies" have been reported, (Arora)
Grifola frondosa.odour: pleasant, nut-like, (Gilbertson), mushroomy with a hint of meal (Lincoff(1)), mild (Miller)
Grifola frondosa.habitat: annual, on the ground from roots at the base of living hardwoods and conifers, especially Quercus (oak), fruiting may continue at the base of dead trees and stumps, causes a white rot and butt rot of living trees, (Gilbertson), fruiting in late summer and fall (Miller)

Hapalopilus nidulans.nameOrigin: means "nesting or lying in a cavity" (Gilbertson)
Hapalopilus nidulans.habitat: annual, on dead hardwoods, very rarely reported on conifer wood in eastern North America, but not uncommon on Pinus (pine) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) in Arizona, causes a white rot, (Gilbertson), probably all year (Buczacki)

Haploporus odorus.habitat: perennial, most commonly on living Salix (willow) also known on Fraxinus (ash), causes white heartrot of living trees, (Gilbertson), also known from single collections on Alnus and Populus, (Ginns(38))

Heterobasidion annosum.habitat: annual to perennial, on living and dead conifers, rarely on hardwoods, one of the major root pathogens in North American conifers, causing a white pocket rot of the roots and butt of living conifers, "pathogenic on living sapwood and causing mortality and windthrow of infected trees", (Gilbertson), also on some timbers (Lincoff(2)), trees attacked by the fungus easily blown down by the wind (Lincoff(1)), fruiting in spring and summer (Miller), typically "on the underside of logs, in cavities of trees, snags, and stumps, and often as a flat layer of tubes on the underside of woody substrates", (Trudell), summer to fall (Bacon), According to a USDA forest service article https://apps.fs.usda.gov/r6_decaid/views/heterobasidion_root_disease.html accessed November 21, 2021, focusing on Heterobasidion Root Disease in Oregon and Washington, H. irregulare affects a broad range of conifer and hardwood tree species, whereas H. occidentale affects many conifer species. According to an article at https://forestpathology.org/root-diseases/annosus/ accessed the same day, H. irregulare is hosted by Pinus, Juniperinus, and less commonly Calocedrus decurrens (California incense-cedar), whereas H. occidentale is hosted by Abies, Picea, Tsuga, and in some areas Pseudotsuga menziesii and Sequoiadendron giganteum.

Hyphodontia latitans.habitat: on wood, hosts including Pinus (pine) and Acer (maple); associated with a white rot, (Ginns(5)), dead conifer wood, common on Pinus in southern United States, also on hardwoods, associated with uniform white rot of conifers (Gilbertson)

Inocutis dryophila.habitat: annual, primarily on living oaks (Quercus), but also reported on a few other hardwoods, causes a white rot of heartwood in the trunk of living oaks, rarely other hardwoods

Inocutis rheades.nameOrigin: means "of Rhea, daughter of Uranus and Gaea, mother of Zeus", (Gilbertson)
Inocutis rheades.habitat: annual, on Populus tremuloides (quaking aspen) "and Populus grandidentata", causes white rot "of heartwood of living aspen, also continues to decay dead standing and fallen trees", (Gilbertson)

Inonotopsis subiculosa.nameOrigin: means "with a profuse production of mycelium below the fruiting body" (Gilbertson)
Inonotopsis subiculosa.habitat: annual, on dead conifer wood, causing a white rot

Inonotus andersonii.habitat: annual, mainly on Quercus (oak) but also on Carya, causing white rot of the heartwood of living trees, especially oaks, growing into the sapwood and killing it, causing a canker on trunks or large branches that weakens them at that point

Inonotus cuticularis.nameOrigin: means "pertaining to a cuticle or skin" (Gilbertson)
Inonotus cuticularis.habitat: annual, on hardwoods, causing white rot of dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), generally imbricate [shingled], more rarely single, on living hardwoods, usually on wounds, (Breitenbach)

Inonotus glomeratus.habitat: annual, mainly on Acer (maple) and Fagus (beech), not uncommon on Populus, and occasionally on other hardwood genera, "Inonotus glomeratus does not fruit on living trees, but often produces sterile conks on beech and maple", "It fruits profusely on stumps and fallen trees in which it continues to decay after death of the host."

Inonotus hispidus.odour: aromatic mushroom odor when young (Lincoff), pleasant, somewhat acidic, (Breitenbach)
Inonotus hispidus.habitat: annual, on living hardwoods particularly Quercus (oak), causing white rot of heartwood in trunks, commonly associated with cankers, (Gilbertson), parasitic on various hardwoods, including ash, mulberry, oak and willow, also reported on pine and fir, (Lincoff)

Inonotus obliquus.nameOrigin: 'obliquus' means "slanting sideways", (Gilbertson), English name 'clinker' after the stony residue from burnt coal or from a furnace, because the canker resembles something that has been burned and fused together, (Lincoff)
Inonotus obliquus.habitat: annual, on Betula (birch), rarely Ulmus (elm), Fagus (beech), Ostrya, causing white rot of heartwood of living birch and rarely other hardwoods, (Gilbertson), imperfect form occurs on trunks of hardwoods, but perfect form with pores and basidia produced under bark only after tree dies, (Breitenbach), year round with new growth in fall (Bacon), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Ischnoderma resinosum.edibility: no (Phillips), said to be edible when young and watery (Arora)
Ischnoderma resinosum.odour: the rot has a strong anise odor, (Gilbertson), aromatic when fresh, exposed wood sometimes with anise odor, (Trudell)
Ischnoderma resinosum.habitat: annual, single or rarely imbricate [shingled], causing white rot (yellowish and stringy to spongy) of dead conifers and hardwoods, (Gilbertson), on logs and stumps of hardwoods, September to October (Lincoff), fruiting mostly in summer and fall, in the Pacific Northwest favoring larger (first growth) conifers, (Arora), summer, fall, winter, (Buczacki)

Jahnoporus hirtus.odour: according to Daniel Stuntz has iodine odor soon after picking (Arora), some with an odor of iodine evident soon after picking (Ginns(28)), pleasantly fragrant, nut-like, (Gilbertson)
