Jahnoporus hirtus.habitat: annual, single or in groups on ground, "around old stumps and trees (especially conifers), sometimes also on wood (often buried)", (Arora), usually on ground under conifers, apparently from roots or other buried wood, (Gilbertson)

Junghuhnia collabens.habitat: annual, on dead wood of conifers, rarely on hardwoods, causes a white pitted rot of dead conifer wood: the "decayed wood tends to become laminated and in the advanced stages often contains masses of pinkish buff mycelium"

Junghuhnia fimbriatella.nameOrigin: diminutive of "fimbriata", meaning "fringed or with a border of hairs" (Gilbertson)
Junghuhnia fimbriatella.habitat: annual, on dead wood of hardwoods, particularly Populus, causes a white rot of dead hardwoods

Junghuhnia nitida.habitat: annual, on dead hardwood, causes a uniform white rot, (Gilbertson), on the underside of fallen dead hardwoods, (Breitenbach), on hardwoods, rarely on conifers, (Ginns), fall (Buczacki)

Junghuhnia zonata.habitat: annual, on recently fallen conifers with bark still attached, known from Abies (fir), Larix (larch), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga (hemlock), causes white pocket rot of dead conifer wood, with conspicuous black flecks in advanced pockets running parallel to the wood grain, in advanced stages "the decayed wood separates along the annual rings and becomes laminated"

Laetiporus conifericola.nameOrigin: 'conifericola' means 'living with conifers'; the common name refers to the chicken texture rather than the taste, (Sept(1))
Laetiporus conifericola.edibility: delicious when thoroughly cooked, but caution advised because poisoning has occurred, this species should never be eaten raw, tough and sour when not young, margin more tender than the rest of the fruiting body, (Arora), allergic and gastrointestinal symptoms have occurred (Lincoff), there have been reports of death following Laetiporus ingestion (Benjamin)
Laetiporus conifericola.taste: nearly mild or acidic becoming quite sour or unpleasant when old, (Arora), nut-like, pleasant, (Gilbertson), of chicken (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Laetiporus conifericola.odour: fungal or rather pungent (Arora), nut-like, pleasant, (Gilbertson)
Laetiporus conifericola.habitat: on mature conifer, (Burdsall), annual, single or more often in overlapping clusters on dead stumps and logs, or sometimes on living trees or from roots, (Arora), single or in shingled clusters up to a square meter or more in extent, causes brown cubical butt rot of living hardwoods and conifers, "also on dead standing and fallen trees, stumps, and utility poles", (Gilbertson), fruiting in fall, taking about 4 weeks to develop, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)

Laetiporus gilbertsonii.nameOrigin: "in honor of Dr. Robert L. Gilbertson, mycological taxonomist and specialist in the Aphyllophorales, teacher and mentor to young mycologists, and valued colleague of mycologists throughout the world", (Burdsall)
Laetiporus gilbertsonii.habitat: associated with a brown rot of Quercus spp. and Eucalyptus spp., "occurring on living trees or dead trunks and logs", also found on Prunus

Laricifomes officinalis.nameOrigin: means "used in medicine" (Gilbertson), (as an official drug plant in pharmacopoeia)
Laricifomes officinalis.habitat: perennial, single or several on living or dead conifers, (Arora), single on living conifers, continuing decay and fruiting on dead trees and stumps, especially on old growth western larch and Douglas-fir, but also on Pinus (pine), Picea (spruce), Abies (fir), and Tsuga (hemlock), causing brown cubical heartrot of living conifers, commonly called brown trunk rot, thick white mycelial felts develop in shrinkage cracks, (Gilbertson)

Lentinus arcularius.nameOrigin: from Latin "vaulted", referring to pore shape, (Lincoff(1))
Lentinus arcularius.habitat: annual, single on dead hardwood, also on juniper and Douglas-fir decking, associated with a white rot of dead hardwoods, rarely on conifer wood, (Gilbertson), single or in small groups on dead hardwoods (Arora), on "dead branches and sticks in woodland or on the ground growing from buried wood", (Lincoff(1)), fruiting in summer and fall (Miller)

Lentinus brumalis.nameOrigin: from Latin "brumalis" meaning "of the winter or shortest day", (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Lentinus brumalis.habitat: annual, on dead hardwood, associated with a white rot, (Gilbertson), on dead hardwood, especially birch, (Phillips), fall, winter, early spring (Buczacki)

Lentinus longiporus.habitat: often in small, tight groups of 4-10 individuals fused at the margin of the cap or fused at the base of the stem; on dead poplar and willow wood, on small branches on the ground, causing a white rot; May to early June

Leptoporus mollis.habitat: annual, on dead wood of conifers, causing a brown cubical rot, (Gilbertson), single, laterally growing together, or imbricate [shingled] on dead, standing, or fallen Picea [spruce] and Pinus [pine], (Breitenbach for Europe), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Mensularia radiata.habitat: annual, on hardwoods, causing white rot of dead hardwoods (Gilbertson), year round, with new growth in fall (Bacon), summer, fall, winter, (Buczacki)

Meripilus sumstinei.taste: slightly sour (Phillips), mild but somewhat acrid [peppery] (Miller)
Meripilus sumstinei.habitat: annual, on ground close to hardwood stumps, also reported on Douglas-fir, causes a white rot in dead and living hardwoods, (Gilbertson), "at the base of deciduous trees or stumps, especially oak and beech", (Phillips), fruiting in late summer and fall (Miller)

Neoalbatrellus subcaeruleoporus.taste: "mild and slightly sweetish to slightly peppery" (Audet)
Neoalbatrellus subcaeruleoporus.habitat: annual; single to cespitose, some small clusters with stems confluent, on soil associated with conifers, two collections on woody debris or on very rotten wood, (Ginns(1)), arising from deep in forest duff, mid-September to mid-December, associated with conifers, (Audet)

Neoantrodia serialis.habitat: annual to biennial, on dead conifers, also common on some hardwoods, especially aspen; causes a brown cubical rot, (Gilbertson), all year (Buczacki), "often grows on the end of cut logs, from which it is practically impossible to remove except in small pieces", (Ginns)

Neofavolus alveolaris.habitat: annual, on dead hardwood, associated with a white rot, (Gilbertson), on dead hardwood (Phillips), summer and fall (Miller)

Niveoporofomes spraguei.habitat: annual, on living trees and dead wood of various hardwoods, "particularly common on Quercus and Castanea", causes a brown cubical rot "of dead hardwoods and also a butt rot in living trees"

Obba rivulosa.nameOrigin: means "with fine, wavy channels or grooves" (Gilbertson)
Obba rivulosa.habitat: annual, on dead conifers and also in living Redwood, and Western Red-cedar, causes white ring rot, (Gilbertson), on live and dead Abies spp. (true fir), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), and Pseudotsuga menziesii, causing a white ring rot, (Ginns)

Onnia tomentosa.spores: pale yellow to pale brown (Arora), whitish buff (Miller)
Onnia tomentosa.habitat: annual, single or in groups on ground under conifers, "(presumably arising from roots or buried wood), sometimes also on stumps or bases of trunks", (Arora), associated with conifers, particularly common with spruce, causes white pocket rot of the heartwood in roots and butt, distinguished by large empty pockets separated by apparently sound firm wood, (Gilbertson), sometimes enclosing plant remains (Breitenbach), fruiting in summer and fall (Miller)

Onnia triquetra.habitat: annual, found on conifers, most commonly Pinus (pine), causing white pocket rot of the heartwood in the roots and butts of living conifers, the rot "characterized by sharply defined empty pockets separated by wood that is firm and apparently undecayed"

Osteina obducta.habitat: annual, usually single, sometimes imbricate [shingled], on dead wood of conifers, rarely on hardwoods; associated with brown rot of dead conifers, particularly common on Douglas-fir and also causes decay of Douglas-fir timbers, (Gilbertson), on conifers, especially Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce) and Pseudotsuga, (Ginns(28)), on dead conifers and birch (Phillips), usually clustered, more rarely single, on dead wood of Larix (larch), usually on stumps, according to literature on other conifers and more rarely hardwoods, (Breitenbach for Europe)

Osteina undosa.habitat: annual, primarily on dead conifer wood, but occasionally on hardwoods associated with conifers, causing brown cubical rot of dead conifer and hardwood logs and slash, white mycelial felts developing in shrinkage cracks

Oxyporus corticola.habitat: annual or sometimes perennial, on dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, causing a white rot, (Gilbertson), single or more often in rows or fused masses on rotting hardwood logs and branches, less commonly on conifers, producing a white rot, (Arora)

Oxyporus cuneatus.habitat: annual, single or imbricate [shingled], mainly on Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), developing with bark still attached, also reported on Sequoia, Abies, Larix, Taxodium, and Tsuga, causing white rot of sapwood of Western Red-cedar

Oxyporus latemarginatus.habitat: annual, on dead wood of hardwoods and also in living oaks, causing white rot of dead hardwoods, "also in living oaks, particularly following fire", (Gilbertson), fall, winter, (Buczacki)

Oxyporus populinus.habitat: perennial, on living hardwoods, especially Sugar Maple, associated with white heartrot of living trees, (Gilbertson), on trunks or in wounds of hardwood trees, especially living maple, (Phillips), on hardwood, especially from old wounds or knot-holes, typically on sycamore, all year, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Oxyporus similis.habitat: annual, growing on dead hardwoods, rarely on conifers, most common on Populus, and particularly common on Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood) in northern Idaho and Montana; associated with white rot of hardwoods and conifers

Perenniporia ellisiana.habitat: annual, known only from Shepherdia [buffalo-berry], where it causes a white heart-rot

Perenniporia fraxinophila.habitat: perennial, the major cause of trunkrot in living Fraxinus [ash], a white trunkrot, also a few records on other hardwood genera and juniper

Perenniporia medulla-panis.habitat: annual to perennial, on dead wood of numerous hardwood genera, rarely on conifers, causes white rot of dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), on dead wood of Quercus (oak), according to literature also on Robinia (locust) and Picea (spruce), (Breitenbach), all year (Buczacki)

Perenniporia subacida.habitat: perennial, mainly on conifers, causing butt rot in fir and hemlock, and common on dead fallen trees in many areas, also not infrequent on dead hardwoods; causes "feather rot", a white stringy rot of dead conifers and hardwoods and also a butt and root rot of living conifers, "cream to golden yellow mycelial felts develop in the decayed wood", (Gilbertson)

Perenniporia tenuis.habitat: annual, on dead fallen aspen, rarely on other substrates, causes white rot of dead hardwoods and conifers

Phaeolus schweinitzii.nameOrigin: after American mycologist Lewis David von Schweinitz, 1780-1834 (Gilbertson)
Phaeolus schweinitzii.spores: white or tinged yellow to green (Arora), white (Miller)
Phaeolus schweinitzii.habitat: annual, single or in tiers or groups on or around dead and living conifers, usually appearing terrestrial, causing red-brown cubical butt rot, (Arora), on conifers (living trees, dead trees, stumps, and logs), rarely on hardwoods in North America, causing brown cubical rot of heartwood of butt and roots of living conifers; the major cause of butt rot in Douglas-fir, (Gilbertson), fruiting early summer to early fall (Miller)

Phellinidium ferrugineofuscum.nameOrigin: means "a combination of rust color and dark brown", (Gilbertson)
Phellinidium ferrugineofuscum.habitat: annual or with 2 layers of tubes, on dead wood of conifers, especially common in spruce-fir zone, associated with white laminated rot of dead wood of conifers, the wood "often has small longitudinal pits similar to those seen in wood decayed by C. weirii. The wood is also frequently mottled with transversely oriented white streaks and may have flecks scattered through it.", (Gilbertson), perennial (Breitenbach)

Phellinopsis conchata.nameOrigin: means "like the half shell of a mollusc", (Gilbertson)
Phellinopsis conchata.habitat: perennial, single or imbricate [shingled] on dead wood of hardwoods, occasionally on living trees, associated with uniform white rot, (Gilbertson), reported on live and dead hardwoods, principally on Salix (willow), (Ginns), on living or dead, standing or more rarely fallen trunks of hardwoods, (Breitenbach), all year (Buczacki)

Phellinopsis overholtsii.habitat: perennial, restricted to Crataegus species (hawthorns), causing uniform white rot of heartwood of living hawthorn

Phellinus arctostaphyli.habitat: perennial, primarily on Arctostaphylos [manzanita], but also on Adenostoma and rarely on Cercocarpus [mountain-mahogany], causing a uniform white rot of heartwood

Phellinus everhartii.habitat: perennial, usually on oak, but occasionally on other hardwoods, associated with white rot of living hardwoods

Phellinus igniarius.habitat: perennial, single or in small groups on hardwood trunks (usually living), especially common on birch and aspen, occurring year round, (Arora), perennial, on living hardwoods, continuing decay in dead trees; associated with uniform white rot of heartwood of living hardwoods, (Gilbertson), year round, but new pore layer in fall (Bacon)

Phellinus laevigatus.habitat: perennial, on dead hardwoods, especially Betula (birch), also reported on Picea (spruce), associated with white laminated rot of dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), perennial, on hardwoods, preferring Betula, causing a white laminated rot, (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)

Phellinus lundellii.habitat: perennial, on dead Betula (birch) and Alnus (alder) in North America, causing a uniform white rot, but on a few other genera in Europe, (Gilbertson)

Phellinus pomaceoides.nameOrigin: referring to the similarities with Phellinus pomaceus

Phellinus pomaceus.habitat: perennial, virtually restricted to Prunus, reported on Crataegus, associated with uniform white rot of the heartwood of living fruit trees, (Gilbertson), all year (Buczacki), single or in small groups "on living plum trees", (Desjardin)

Phellinus prunicola.habitat: on dead wood of Prunus, causing a uniform white rot

Phellinus tremulae.odour: sweet wintergreen, (Gilbertson), similar to methyl salicylate (Breitenbach from Romagnesi), indistinct (Buczacki)
Phellinus tremulae.habitat: perennial, developing at branch scars, only on Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen) and P. grandidentata (Bigtooth Aspen), associated with a white trunk rot of living trees, and "a major decay fungus throughout the range of aspen", (Gilbertson), mostly on standing aspen or on other Populus species, according to literature rarely on Alnus, Quercus, Sorbus, (Breitenbach for Europe), all year (Buczacki)

Phellopilus nigrolimitatus.nameOrigin: means "bounded or limited by a black line or layer" (Gilbertson)
Phellopilus nigrolimitatus.habitat: perennial, on conifers, especially Picea (spruce), associated with white pocket rot of conifer logs, and also a butt rot of living trees, the rot being distinctive because of the large size of the pockets (up to 2.5cm long) with firm wood between, (Gilbertson), single to gregarious, on very rotten wood of Picea (spruce), usually on the underside of fallen trunks, and other conifers, also on wood used in construction, (Breitenbach)

Phylloporia ribis.habitat: perennial, on living deciduous bushes and trees, most common on Ribes (currants and gooseberries), but also known from other genera, causing a white heartrot of living shrubs, (Gilbertson), on wood of living trunks of spindle, currant, and occasionally other hardwood trees and shrubs, (Buczacki)

Physisporinus sanguinolentus.habitat: annual, or reviving a second year, on dead wood of conifers and hardwoods, causing a white rot, (Gilbertson), on moist dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, "commonly on stumps and then often growing over surrounding plant remains and soil", (Breitenbach), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Physisporinus vitreus.habitat: annual, on dead wood of hardwoods, rarely conifers, associated with a white pocket rot, (Gilbertson), on moist dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, "commonly on stumps and then often growing over surrounding plant remains and soil", (Breitenbach), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Picipes badius.habitat: annual, single or clustered, on dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, associated with a white rot, (Gilbertson), single or in groups on rotting hardwoods or occasionally conifers, (Arora), on stumps and logs of hardwoods, on ground on buried wood, also reported on conifer wood, (Lincoff(2)), found in summer and fall (Miller)

Picipes melanopus.habitat: annual, on ground, presumably developing from buried wood of hardwoods and conifers, (Gilbertson), on ground or on buried wood (Phillips), single to gregarious, on buried dead wood of hardwoods and conifers, apparently only on soil, according to literature also on roots of hardwoods, (Breitenbach), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Picipes rhizophilus.nameOrigin: means "with a secret or hidden foot" (Gilbertson)
Picipes rhizophilus.habitat: annual, on ground in pastures or prairie habitats, according to Overholts attached to dead grass roots, according to Weir a specimen was attached to bark at the base of a dead lodgepole pine, (Gilbertson)

Polyporoletus sylvestris.habitat: on the ground under Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), and Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), usually in the subalpine zone; presumably "attached to live tree roots and probably ectomycorrhizal", (Ginns), "single or in clusters", the clusters composed of three or four confluent pilei with the stems also partially united, (Overholts(3))

Polyporus radicatus.habitat: annual, on the ground, "but probably from buried roots", probably causing a white rot in hardwoods, (Gilbertson), typically single (Ginns), single or scattered, on the ground (but actually fruiting from buried wood), "in grassy and open areas," "causing a white rot", (Kuo)

Polyporus squamosus.edibility: yes (Phillips), the tender edges of caps can be pickled, sauteed or fried, (Lincoff(2)), sometimes boiled to add flavor to soup stock, then discarded, (Lincoff(1)), yes but older caps too tough (McKnight)
Polyporus squamosus.taste: mild and pleasant when young (Phillips), farinaceous (Breitenbach), like watermelon rind (Lincoff(2), Lincoff(1))
Polyporus squamosus.odour: strongly of meal (Phillips), farinaceous (Breitenbach), like watermelon rind (Lincoff(2)), cheese-like then mealy, (Lincoff(1))
Polyporus squamosus.habitat: annual, single or several from branched base, on living hardwoods, also often found on stumps or dead standing or fallen trees, associated with white heartrot of living and dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), single or "in overlapping clusters on the wounds of dead trees", (Phillips), spring and summer (Bacon)

Polyporus tuberaster.nameOrigin: from Latin, "tuberous", (Lincoff(1)), from Latin, "like a truffle", (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), "like a little potato" (Gilbertson)
Polyporus tuberaster.edibility: edible, "but tough unless young, fresh and thoroughly cooked", sclerotium inedible because full of dirt, (Arora)
Polyporus tuberaster.habitat: annual, on hardwoods or on the ground from a large blackish sclerotium (even on wood, there is often a connection through wood to underground sclerotium), causing a white rot of hardwoods, (Gilbertson), spring, late summer, fall, (Bacon)

Polyporus umbellatus.habitat: annual, on ground, close to stumps of hardwoods, reported also on Picea, causing a white rot in hardwoods, (Gilbertson), on ground on buried wood, around stumps or hardwood trees, (Lincoff(2)), summer and fall, (Buczacki)

Polypus dispansus.habitat: annual; associated with conifers and Rocky Mountain Maple in Idaho, with Ponderosa Pine, Douglas-fir and Southwestern White Pine in Arizona, (Gilbertson), under conifers, sometimes at the base of tree or stump, Canfield concluded that it is "a lignicolous species (one basidiome was traced to buried wood) and caused a brown rot", (Ginns(1)), "in montane mixed conifer forests, sometimes associated with woody debris or buried wood", (Trudell)

Porodaedalea cancriformans.habitat: forming cankers on the trunks of Abies spp. (fir), 1-8 m from the base, "and eventually fruiting from the wounded area" of mature fir, producing overlapping, or fused clusters, perennial with growth typically in spring in fall

Porodaedalea 'chrysoloma'.nameOrigin: means "with a gold-colored fringe or margin" (Gilbertson)
Porodaedalea 'chrysoloma'.habitat: perennial or sometimes annual, on living and dead conifers in all genera of Pinaceae, causing a white pocket rot, "pathogenic in true firs, killing sapwood, and causing stem cankers in which the basidiocarps develop", (Gilbertson), sometimes perennial, "in dense overlapping clusters or partly fused rows on decaying or living conifer trunks", (Phillips)

Porodaedalea pini.habitat: perennial, single or more often in rows or columns up and down living or recently fallen conifers, mostly on older trees, (Arora), single or imbricate [shingled] on living conifers, a few reports on hardwoods, associated with a white pocket rot of the heartwood of living conifers, (Gilbertson), conks visible year round (Miller)

Postia amara.habitat: annual, causes brown cubical pocket rot of heartwood of living Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), and "is the most important cause of volume loss in that host", fruiting bodies "deteriorate rapidly in the field and are usually quite high on the trunk of older trees", (Gilbertson)

Postia balsamea.habitat: annual, on living conifers, also dead conifer wood, rarely on hardwoods, causing brown cubical butt or trunk rot, (Gilbertson), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Postia ceriflua.habitat: annual, in crevices and hollows of very rotten conifer logs, in North America on Tsuga (hemlock) and Pinus (pine), in Europe on Picea (spruce); associated generally with a brown cubical rot

Postia leucospongia.habitat: annual, on dead conifer wood "that is under deep snow for several months, particularly fir and spruce, rarely on aspen", developing under snow and deteriorating rapidly with onset of snow melt and higher temperatures, found throughout the western mountains, associated with brown cubical rot, (Gilbertson), single to gregarious on dead conifers, usually from fissures in bark, usually in the spring, often beginning development under the snow, but the fruiting bodies persist for months without decaying; causes a brown rot of both heartwood and sapwood, (Arora), on old logs and stumps of conifers at over 5000 feet altitude, found up to timberline, (Lincoff), single to several on decorticated [debarked] conifer logs, stumps, and limbs; Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce) and Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir) are common hosts, but on other conifers as well; "fruiting on wood covered with snow, reaching maturity shortly after the snow recedes; from May to July", (Bessette)

Postia perdelicata.habitat: annual, single, on dead wood of conifers, rarely on hardwoods, associated with brown cubical rot of dead conifers

Postia ptychogaster.nameOrigin: Greek ptyx, ptychos means fold, leaf, layer or plate; Greek gaster means stomach, belly, paunch, or womb
Postia ptychogaster.habitat: annual, in BC on a mossy log

Postia sericeomollis.habitat: annual, on living and dead conifers, associated with a brown cubical pocket rot, said to be the main cause of volume loss in living Western Red-cedar in BC, (Gilbertson), on live and dead conifers, especially in living Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Ginns(28) for BC), mainly summer, fall, winter, (Buczacki)

Postia tephroleuca.nameOrigin: means "a combination of ash-colored and white", (Gilbertson)
Postia tephroleuca.habitat: annual, on dead wood of conifers and hardwoods, associated with brown cubical rot, (Gilbertson), single to shingled on dead hardwood, more rarely on conifers, (Breitenbach), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Pseudoinonotus dryadeus.nameOrigin: means "similar to a dryad or wood nymph", (Gilbertson), "refers to association with oak" (Lincoff)
Pseudoinonotus dryadeus.habitat: annual, primarily on Abies (fir) in the Pacific Coast region, in eastern North America primarily on Quercus (oak); typically developing at ground line at the base of trees or from roots at some distance from base, causes white rot of heartwood in butts and roots of living true firs and oaks, (Gilbertson), on live and dead Abies (true fir), Tsuga (hemlock), and Quercus (oak), causing a white rot, (Ginns)

Pycnoporellus alboluteus.habitat: annual, on dead conifers, especially Picea (spruce), occasionally on aspen, associated with brown cubical rot of conifer and aspen logs covered by snow in winter, (Gilbertson), on fallen logs of conifers, usually on undersides, often developing in snow, mainly in spring but persisting later in the year, (Arora), on conifers, especially Picea, infrequently on Populus, developing "in spring in association with receding snow banks", (Ginns)

Pycnoporellus fulgens.habitat: annual, single or imbricate [shingled], "mainly on conifer logs and slash but also occasionally on hardwoods", associated with brown cubical rot of dead conifers and hardwoods, (Gilbertson), in a Haida Gwaii study, Kroeger(5) found that it was almost invariably associated with old fruitbodies of Fomitopsis pinicola complex, on some cases on the fruitbodies themselves

Pycnoporus cinnabarinus.nameOrigin: from Greek meaning "cinnabar red or vermilion", (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), means pertaining to 'cinnabar', a red mineral mercury sulphide
Pycnoporus cinnabarinus.habitat: annual, on hardwoods, also rarely on conifers, associated with a white rot, (Gilbertson), on fallen timber, mainly oak, (Phillips), especially cherry and oak (Lincoff(2)), single, or several concrescent, (Breitenbach), fruiting in summer and fall (Miller)

Pyrofomes demidoffii.habitat: annual, perennial, on Juniperus (juniper), causing white trunk rot of living junipers "and a major decay fungus of junipers in western North America", abundant "buff-colored mycelial felts develop in cavities in the decayed wood"

Raduliporus aneirinus.habitat: annual, "primarily on dead, fallen aspen, rarely on other hardwoods", causing a white rot, the decayed wood becoming quite soft, developing a laminated structure, and separating readily along the annual rings, (Gilbertson), fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)

Resinoporia crassa.habitat: perennial, on conifer wood, causes a brown rot

Resinoporia ferox.nameOrigin: means "fierce, bold", in reference to the rot (Gilbertson)
Resinoporia ferox.habitat: perennial, known only from Juniperus (juniper), causing a brown cubical rot with conspicuous cream-colored to pale buff mycelial mats or mycelial felts

Resinoporia sitchensis.nameOrigin: means "of the island of Sitka, Alaska" (Gilbertson)
Resinoporia sitchensis.habitat: annual to perennial, on dead conifers, causes a brown cubical rot

Resinoporia sordida.habitat: perennial on dead conifer wood; causing a brown rot

Rhodofomes cajanderi.habitat: perennial, on dead conifers, but also on madrone and various fruit trees, (Arora), on dead wood of numerous genera of conifers, particularly common on Douglas fir, rarely on hardwoods including Populus tremuloides, Betula, Prunus, causes a brown cubical rot of dead conifers, rarely of hardwoods, plays a major role in carbon and nutrient recycling, (Gilbertson)

Rhodofomes roseus.habitat: perennial, mainly on conifers, especially Douglas-fir and spruce, also on quaking aspen logs at high elevations, causing brown cubical rot of dead conifers or rarely, hardwoods, reported to cause a decay called yellow-brown top rot in Douglas-fir, (Gilbertson), single to gregarious on dead wood of Picea (spruce) with and without bark, commonly on construction wood, (Breitenbach)

Rhodofomitopsis oleracea.habitat: annual, on dead hardwoods, especially Quercus (oak), causing a brown rot, (Gilbertson), in BC known only from Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone) (Ginns)

Rhodonia placenta.habitat: annual, on dead wood of conifers, associated with brown cubical rot of dead conifer wood, (Gilbertson), on conifers, rarely on Populus, (Ginns), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Rigidoporus crocatus.habitat: annual to perennial, on dead conifers and hardwoods, associated with a white rot

Sarcoporia polyspora.habitat: causes a brown cubical rot "of dead conifers and hardwoods and living black cherry"; common on Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine)

Scutiger ellisii.habitat: annual; single, scattered, gregarious, or in fused clusters, on ground in woods, especially conifer forest, (Arora), on soil in coniferous forest, (Gilbertson)

Scutiger pes-caprae.habitat: annual; single or in groups or clumps on ground in woods (Arora), single or several on a branching stem, on ground in coniferous forest, (Gilbertson)

Sidera lenis.habitat: annual, most common on dead conifers but also recorded on hardwoods, causes a white rot

Skeletocutis albocremea.habitat: on Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), "causing a white rot"

Skeletocutis alutacea.habitat: annual, on dead wood of conifers and hardwoods, associated with a white rot

Skeletocutis amorpha.habitat: annual, on dead conifer wood, associated with a white rot, (Gilbertson), on fallen and standing trunks, with or without bark, of conifers, (Breitenbach), all year (Buczacki)

Skeletocutis nivea.habitat: annual, on dead wood of hardwoods, rarely conifers, associated with a white rot of dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), usually on hardwood branches that are lying on the ground, (Breitenbach), all year (Buczacki)

Skeletocutis odora.habitat: annual, on dead conifers, causes a brown rot

Skeletocutis stellae.habitat: perennial, on dead wood of conifers, especially Picea (spruce), associated with white mottled rot of dead conifers

Skeletocutis subincarnata.habitat: annual, on dead wood of conifers, especially Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), rarely on hardwoods, associated with a white rot

Skeletocutis subodora.nameOrigin: from the Latin "odora-like", referring to the similarity to Skeletocutis odora, (Vlasak)
Skeletocutis subodora.habitat: annual, on debarked log of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), associated with a white pocket rot

Spongipellis delectans.habitat: annual, single or imbricate [shingled], on dead standing or fallen hardwoods, also causing a heartrot in living trees, especially Populus, associated with a white mottled rot of living or dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), on rotting hardwood, especially on large old fallen Fagus (beech) trunks causing white pocketed rot, fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)

Spongipellis spumea.habitat: annual, on living and dead hardwoods, associated with a white rot, (Gilbertson), single on hardwoods (Breitenbach), single, on living and dead hardwoods, especially in parks and gardens, typically on Fagus (beech); summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Spongipellis unicolor.habitat: annual, single, commonly on living oaks, occasionally on other genera, associated with white trunkrot of living hardwoods

Spongiporus floriformis.nameOrigin: means "with the appearance of a flower" (Gilbertson)
Spongiporus floriformis.habitat: annual, on dead hardwoods and conifers, causing brown cubical rot, (Gilbertson), late summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Steccherinum lacerum.habitat: annual, on dead hardwoods, causing a white rot

Trametes gibbosa.odour: like Heterobasidion annosum [which the authors describe as "strongly fungoid"], (Breitenbach)
Trametes gibbosa.habitat: single to gregarious and imbricate [shingled], on dead hardwood, especially on stumps of Fagus (beech), causes white soft-rots, (Breitenbach), annual, on hardwood, in north Europe especially beech, (Ryvarden(2)), annual; in Europe on dead wood of hardwoods, particularly Carpinus, Fagus, less often Alnus, Populus or Betula, "annual, but rather durable and sometimes hibernating", (Domanski), usually imbricate (Bernicchia), sporulating in late spring (Phillips), most common (in Europe) on Fagus, but also recorded from other hardwoods, including Acer, Aesculus, Ailanthus, Alnus, Betula, Castanea, Corylus, Crataegus, Eucalyptus, Fraxinus, Juglans, Malus, Morus, Platanus, Populus, Prunus, Pyrus, Rhamnus, Quercus, Salix, Sorbus, Tilia, and Ulmus, once recorded on Picea; preference for Fagus strict in northern part of its European range, less so in southern Europe; causes white rot of Fagus, rarely in other hardwoods, (Ryvarden(3)), may be seen year round (Bacon), all year (Buczacki)

Trametes hirsuta.nameOrigin: means "hairy, with rather coarse, erect or ascending hairs" (Gilbertson)
Trametes hirsuta.habitat: annual, single or "more often in groups, fused rows, or overlapping clusters on dead hardwoods (or occasionally conifers)", (Arora), annual, on dead hardwood, rarely on conifer wood, associated with a white rot of hardwoods, (Gilbertson), all year (Buczacki)

Trametes ochracea.habitat: "annual or reviving", on dead wood of hardwoods, rarely on conifer wood, associated with a white rot of dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), all year (Buczacki)

Trametes pubescens.habitat: annual, often in imbricate [shingled] clusters, on dead wood of hardwoods, rarely on conifer wood, associated with white rot of dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), all year (Buczacki)

Trametes suaveolens.odour: pleasant anise when fresh, (Gilbertson), conspicuous anise when fresh (Breitenbach)
Trametes suaveolens.habitat: annual, most common on Salix (willow) and Populus, also reported on Betula (birch) and Abies (fir), associated with white heartrot of living hardwoods and also on stumps, (Gilbertson), single or imbricate [shingled], often concrescent, on "old, dead or still living trunks and branches of Salix (willow)", (Breitenbach)

Trametes versicolor.habitat: typically "in groups, rows, tiers, shelving masses, or overlapping clusters on logs, stumps, and fallen branches of dead hardwoods", "sometimes also on wounds in living trees and rarely on conifers", (Arora), annual, often in large imbricate [shingled] clusters on dead wood of numerous genera of hardwoods, associated with a white rot of dead hardwoods, (Gilbertson), fruiting from late spring to fall (Miller), may be seen year round (Buczacki)

Trametopsis cervina.habitat: annual, often in large imbricate [shingled] clusters, on dead hardwood, rarely on conifer wood, associated with white rot of dead hardwoods

Trichaptum abietinum.habitat: annual, in groups, shelving masses, or overlapping tiers on decaying conifers, (Arora), annual, on dead sapwood of conifers, reported to be occasional on hardwoods; associated with white pocket rot of dead sapwood of conifers: "pockets are hollow and the wood becomes fragile and lacy in the late stages of decay", (Gilbertson), may be seen year round (Bacon)

Trichaptum biforme.habitat: annual, single or imbricate [shingled], on dead hardwoods of many genera, rarely on conifers, associated with white pocket rot of sapwood of dead hardwoods, the wood becoming "lacy and fragile with small empty pockets", (Gilbertson), "numerous, single, or overlapping caps on dead stumps" of hardwood trees, reducing them to sawdust, (Phillips), fruiting from late spring to fall (Miller)

Trichaptum fuscoviolaceum.habitat: on conifers, (Ginns), annual, on dead sapwood of conifers, seemingly preferring Pinus (pine) but also on Abies (true fir) and Tsuga (hemlock), causing a white pocket rot of the sapwood, (Gilbertson)

Trichaptum subchartaceum.habitat: annual, restricted "to dead Populus and common on aspen and cottonwood", associated with white pocket rot of aspen and cottonwood logs and slash

Tyromyces chioneus.odour: weakly to moderately aromatic, sweetly spicy with a citrus tinge, (Ginns), with a slight aromatic scent when fresh, (Gilbertson), fragrant when fresh (Phillips)
Tyromyces chioneus.habitat: annual, single or a few specimens together, on dead wood of hardwoods, causing a white rot, (Gilbertson), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Tyromyces galactinus.habitat: annual, single or imbricate [shingled], on dead deciduous wood, associated with a white rot

Tyromyces kmetii.nameOrigin: likely after the Slovak botanist Andrej Kmet
Tyromyces kmetii.habitat: on hardwood, associated with a white rot

Vitreoporus dichrous.habitat: annual, on dead hardwood, occasionally on conifers and dead polypores, (Gilbertson), spring, summer, fall, (Buczacki)

Wolfiporia cocos.nameOrigin: means "resembling a cocoanut, in reference to sclerotia" (Gilbertson)
Wolfiporia cocos.edibility: the large underground sclerotium was apparently eaten by various North American first nations, (Arora)
Wolfiporia cocos.habitat: annual, on living and dead conifers and hardwoods, especially oaks, associated with a brown cubical root and butt rot of conifers and hardwoods, "also decays dead standing and fallen trees", (Gilbertson), occasionally on conifer logs, but more often on "tree roots and stumps (of both hardwoods and conifers), and the fruiting bodies appearing terrestrial if they arise from sclerotia", (Arora)

Wrightoporia lenta.habitat: on "conifers in the United States, on hardwoods and palms in subtropical and tropical areas"; associated with a brown rot

Xanthoporus syringae.habitat: gregarious to cespitose, confluent, on the ground associated with dead or wounded roots, under Alnus (alder), Salix (willow), and conifers, (Ginns(28)), annual; "Gregarious to cespitose in humus under Alnus; gravel roadside attached to dead roots of Salix sp.; in young mixed conifers; gravel roadside under tall herbaceous weeds, and edge of logging road in grasses (no woody plant within 10 m)", (Ginns(1))

Xeroceps skamania.taste: none, but leaving a sensation in the mouth, as though one had just chewed spinach or a tea bag (Ginns, quoting J. Lindgren)
Xeroceps skamania.habitat: annual; typically in clusters of 2-6 confluent, imbricate [shingled] caps united at bases of stems, growing on the ground among conifers, (Ginns)

Yuchengia narymica.habitat: annual, in Victoria found on Alnus (alder), (Ginns), causing a white rot of dead hardwoods (Gilbertson)

Acaulopage trachyspora.habitat: grown from grass detritus from Idaho

Acrasis rosea.nameOrigin: refers to the pink color of the cells
Acrasis rosea.habitat: can be isolated from dead attached parts of plants

Akanthomyces aculeatus.habitat: "covering dead adult moths that are often adhered by the fungus to a branch, leaf, fern frond, or other such substrate", summer

Allomyces arbusculus.habitat: Allomyces species are widely distributed around the world where they exist in soil and water as saprobes. (Alexopoulos)

Anisogramma anomala.nameOrigin: means 'anomalous' Peck described it as a species of Diatrype and said in the original description "The peculiar and anomalous character of this species is found in its unusual spores and it its attacking living stems."
Anisogramma anomala.habitat: on stems, branches, and twigs of Corylus spp.

Apiosporina morbosa.habitat: single or several, "clasping and enveloping branches and twigs of cherry and plum trees; year round", (Bessette), wild and cultivated plum and cherry, (Corlett)

Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis.nameOrigin: means 'of Dendrobates', a genus of frogs
Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis.habitat: B. dendrobatidis causes a fungal infection of the skin and only grows in keratinized cells.

Botrytis cinerea.habitat: on many plants; parasitic or saprophytic, (Barnett)

Bulleromyces alba.habitat: Bullera alba yeast forms (from Hordeum jubatum, air in a dairy, grass, dead leaf of Platanus sp., leaf of Ligustrum, leaf of Juglans regia), were induced to reproduce sexually in the laboratory

Carcinomyces polyporina.habitat: fruiting body lines the tubes of Tyromyces lacteus, (Ginns), all year (Buczacki)

Clathrus ruber.habitat: "solitary to densely gregarious or clustered in soil, wood chips, rich humus, etc.", (Arora), single or in small groups in woods, in grasslands, or in greenhouses, spring to late summer, (Lincoff), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Claviceps purpurea.habitat: on damp sclerotia that formed the previous year in the panicles of various grasses, (Breitenbach), singly or in small clusters on fallen sclerotia, (Dennis)

Coccomyces arbutifolius.nameOrigin: refers to the habitat on Arbutus leaves
Coccomyces arbutifolius.habitat: densely gregarious, on leaves of Arbutus menziesii

Coccomyces dentatus.habitat: on "dead (rarely living) leaves of a wide variety of angiosperms, notably on Fagaceae and Ericaceae, widespread and common, chiefly in warm temperate areas, summer and fall in the northern part of its range, throughout the year in subtropical areas", (Sherwood)

Daldinia childiae.nameOrigin: after Child, who wrote a monograph on Daldinia
Daldinia childiae.habitat: on hardwood, single to infrequently aggregated

Daldinia grandis.habitat: on hardwood, infrequently aggregated or confluent, (Ju)

Daldinia lloydii.nameOrigin: after C.G. Lloyd who described the type as Hypoxylon fissum

Daldinia loculata.habitat: on hardwood (Ju), most European collections examined were on Betula (birch) with one on Alnus (alder), (Stadler)

Daldinia loculatoides.nameOrigin: named for morphological similarities to Daldinia loculata (Stadler)
Daldinia loculatoides.habitat: on living Acer (maple) in BC, July; in United Kingdom on exposed trunk of old Fagus (beech) on burnt wood of hollow trunk and on unburned parts, August

Exobasidium burtii.nameOrigin: after E.A. Burt who monographed the genus and who suspected that this fungus on R. albiflorum might be distinct
Exobasidium burtii.habitat: on Rhododendron albiflorum (white rhododendron also known as cascade azalea)

Exobasidium cordilleranum.habitat: on leaves of Vaccinium parvifolium (type) and Vaccinium ovalifolium "The spores tend to be slightly smaller on V. ovalifolium than on V. parvifolium, but from the available series it is uncertain whether the difference is real. Four-spored basidia also seem to be commoner on V. ovalifolium than on the type host." (Savile)

Exobasidium dimorphosporum.habitat: type on Vaccinium caespitosum (dwarf blueberry, also known as dwarf bilberry or low bush blueberry)

Exobasidium empetri.nameOrigin: means 'of Empetrum' referring to the host

Exobasidium phyllodoces.habitat: The three collections examined were on Phyllodoce empetriformis (pink mountain heather).

Exobasidium vaccinii.nameOrigin: after Vaccinium, one of its hosts
Exobasidium vaccinii.habitat: according to Breitenbach et al. on Exobasidium vitis-idaea (they describe a variety of other Exobasidium species on other ericaceous plants); according to Burt, common and widespread on many ericaceous plants including Vaccinium vitis-idaea in Europe, and in the Pacific Northwest V. deliciosum, V. membranaceum, Arctyostaphylos uva-ursi, A. nevadensis, and Menziesia ferruginea, (Burt), reported on V. angustifolium (lowbush blueberry) among others in eastern North America, and in BC on the following species: V. macrocarpon (large cranberry), V. ovalifolium (mathers), V. parvifolium (red bilberry), V. scoparium (grouseberry), V. vitis-idaea (bog cranberry), Andromeda polifolia (bog rosemary), Arbutus menziesii (arbutus), Arctyostaphylos uva-ursi (bearberry), Cassiope mertensiana (white heather), Ledum groenlandicum (Labrador tea), Menziesia ferruginea (false azalea), Rhododendron macrophyllum (west coast rhododendron), 3 species of rhododendron imported from Japan, (Ginns who comments that redisposition needs to be made following Nannfeldt's studies in Europe), according to Savile on Andromeda glaucophylla, A. polifolia, Arctostaphylos alpina, A. uva-ursi, Cassiope tetragona, Chamaedaphne calyculata, Kalmia polifolia, Rhododendron viscosum (type of E. discoideum), R. macrophyllum, Vaccinium angustifolium, V. corymbosum, V. macrocarpon, V. myrtilloides, V. myrtillus, V. ovalifolium, V. ovatum, V. oxycoccos, V. parvifolium (E. parvifolii), V. pennsylvanicum, V. scoparium, V. uliginosum, and V. vitis-idaea, (Savile), appears in summer and fall

Exobasidium vaccinii-uliginosi.habitat: on Vaccinium uliginosum (bog bilberry), (Breitenbach), reported on Vaccinium uliginosum in YT, V. caespitosum (dwarf bilberry) in BC, (Ginns who notes that redisposition of records needs to occur as a result of Nannfeldt's work on European Exobasidium species), on Vaccinium membranaceum, in WA, V. uliginosum and V. myrtillus in Europe, (Burt), collections examined from Ledum groenlandicum, Vaccinium myrtillus, Vaccinium uliginosum, (Savile)

Fuligo septica.habitat: "On rotten wood, litter, or compost at first, migrating to live plants and soil", May to October, usually in cool weather in spring and fall, (Lincoff), rotten wood and litter, living plants, soil, (Martin)

Heterogastridium pycnidioideum.nameOrigin: refers to pycnidioid method of fruiting
Heterogastridium pycnidioideum.habitat: collected on various types of decaying plant material (tomato plant in the case of the BC specimen) and mushrooms and induced to sporulate in the laboratory

Insolibasidium deformans.habitat: parasitizes leaves of Lonicera (honeysuckle), possibly also Symphoricarpus and Cornus

Isaria farinosa.habitat: growing on a variety of insects (Beug)

Labyrinthula zosterae.nameOrigin: means 'of Zostera' referring to its host
Labyrinthula zosterae.habitat: in blackened or brown necrotic spots, streaks and patches on leaves of Zostera marina [eelgrass]

Lasiosphaeria ovina.nameOrigin: from Latin, means 'pertaining to sheep', presumably referring to the woolly appearance of the whitish covering
Lasiosphaeria ovina.habitat: cespitose or growing in compact groups, on rotten wood "of a great diversity of species", fruiting all year

Letharia columbiana.nameOrigin: presumably referring to the Columbia river basin or to British Columbia
Letharia columbiana.habitat: bark or wood, rarely rock, (McCune), associated with the green alga Trebouxia (Brodo), especially on Larix lyallii, Pinus albicaulis, and Abies lasiocarpa, (Vitt)

Lycogala epidendrum.habitat: scattered to clustered on dead wood, especially large logs, June to November, (Lincoff)

Malassezia furfur.nameOrigin: means 'bran-like scales' referring to the appearance of the skin patches

Nosema ceranae.nameOrigin: means 'of [Apis] cerana' the Asiatic honey bee and one of its hosts
Nosema ceranae.habitat: parasite of the Asiatic honey bee (Apis cerana) and other bees

Plasmodiophora brassicae.nameOrigin: means 'of Brassica', referring to its host

Podosphaera pannosa.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "tattered", because of its appearance on the host plant
Podosphaera pannosa.habitat: "attacks roses and, in a similar form, peaches and apricots", (Lincoff)

Poronia punctata.nameOrigin: means 'punctate', probably referring to the black ostioles visible on the disc
Poronia punctata.habitat: on horse dung (Dennis, Hansen, L.), gregarious on horse dung during summer and fall (Thompson), fall (Phillips)

Reticularia lycoperdon.nameOrigin: refers to the fungal genus Lycoperdon
Reticularia lycoperdon.habitat: "typically on dead alder branches, logs, and stumps in wet places beside rivers, streams, and wetlands", also on a variety of other hardwoods and on pine; fruiting often after late frost in spring and fall

Rhytisma punctatum.habitat: on Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple) and Acer spicatum (Mountain Maple), (Funk), islands of black spots form around mid-August (which will produce sexual spores the following spring), (Trudell)

Rhytisma salicinum.habitat: on leaves of various species of willow (Thompson)

Sawadaea bicornis.nameOrigin: means 'two-horned', presumably referring to the double-hook shaped appendages

Sirotrema parvula.habitat: arising within fruiting bodies of Lophodermium pinastri on fallen needles of Pinus contorta

Sirotrema pusilla.habitat: originating in spore-bearing surface of Hypoderma ?pacificensis ascomycete fruiting bodies growing on fallen petioles of Acer macrophyllum (bigleaf maple)

Sirotrema translucens.habitat: developing in hysterothecia of Lophodermium and Hypodermella spp. on dead needles and cones of Pinus and needles of Abies spp.

Sporothrix schenckii.habitat: lives as a saprophyte on plants in many parts of the world (Braunwald)

Stachybotrys chartarum.nameOrigin: means 'leaf of paper, thin plate, lamina'
Stachybotrys chartarum.habitat: wet surfaces of buildings (gypsum wall board, wall paper, ceiling tiles, paper products, carpets with natural fibers, insulation, wood, organic debris, etc.); in Europe at least found on straw, (Nelson)

'Stereopsis' humphreyi.habitat: gregarious on mossy needle beds, cones, twigs, fern fronds, and mosses, in coniferous forest, (Redhead), on cones and other litter of conifers, especially Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), in rather wet areas, (Trudell)

Syzygospora effibulata.nameOrigin: "fibula" means "clasp", "effibulata" refers to the absence of clamp connections
Syzygospora effibulata.habitat: on Gymnopus dryophilus caps and stems

Taphrina occidentalis.habitat: occurs on female catkins of Alnus rubra (Red Alder) and several other Alnus species, fruiting in summer

Taphrina populina.habitat: on P. trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), TXD, TXN hybrids; T. populi-salicis is limited to P. trichocarpa and Salix (willow) spp., (Callan for BC)

Tetragoniomyces uliginosus.habitat: on unidentified basidiomycete fungus growing on decaying plant material in wet habitats

Tilachlidium brachiatum.nameOrigin: 'brachiatum' is Latin for 'with arms or branches'
Tilachlidium brachiatum.habitat: on decomposed gilled mushrooms, on Helvella crispa, (Mycoquebec), on fungi (Trametes, Mycena and other) and ? insects, (Seifert)

Ustilago maydis.nameOrigin: after the host plant maize, Zea mays

Valsa sordida.habitat: in BC reported on maple, cottonwood, Trembling Aspen, Lombardy Poplar, and willow; elsewhere in North America also on Paper Birch, Water Birch, White Poplar, oak, apple, chokecherry, elderberry, and mountain-ash

Venturia inaequalis.nameOrigin: refers to the ascospores which are two-celled, with the cells being unequal in size
Venturia inaequalis.habitat: occurs wherever apples are grown and can occur also on crabapple and mountain ash (Cornell)

Xenolachne flagellifera.habitat: parasitic on the spore-bearing surface of Hyaloscypha atomaria (a tiny ascomycete), growing on the lower side of damp logs of Libocedrus decurrens, Pinus strobus, and Pseudotsuga menziesii

Aureoboletus citriniporus.nameOrigin: refers to the intense lemon yellow color of the pores
Aureoboletus citriniporus.habitat: single to gregarious in soil under Quercus chrysolepis (Canyon Live Oak) and Q. agrifolia (California Live Oak)

Aureoboletus flaviporus.habitat: single to scattered to occasionally cespitose [in tufts] in soil in mixed or hardwood forests, especially with madrone, (Thiers), under hardwoods, especially oak, madrone, manzanita, or in mixed woods, September to April, (Bessette), fall, winter, spring

Aureoboletus mirabilis.edibility: choice (Thiers), delicious, some have a distinct lemony flavor, avoid specimens attacked by Hypomyces, (Arora)
Aureoboletus mirabilis.habitat: single or in small groups "on or near rotting conifers, (especially hemlock), but sometimes appearing terrestrial", (Arora), single to scattered in soil in coastal forests, typically with hemlock logs and stumps, (Thiers), summer and fall (Miller)

Boletus barrowsii.nameOrigin: in honor of its discoverer, Charles Barrows (1904-1989), a New Mexico amateur mycologist
Boletus barrowsii.odour: not distinctive (Bessette), pleasant (Phillips), mild or sometimes strong and unpleasant when dried, (Thiers), strong odor when drying (Trudell)
Boletus barrowsii.habitat: scattered or in groups under ponderosa pine, fir, spruce, and live oak, (Bessette), single or scattered to gregarious under hardwoods and conifers

Boletus edulis.nameOrigin: "grand" means "large" and "edulis" refers to Boletus edulis
Boletus edulis.habitat: in California, single to gregarious in coastal pine forests and at their edges, less commonly associated with live oaks, "and found at mid-to-high elevations in the Sierra Nevada" with pine and true fir, (Arora(2)), Siegel(2) say in the California context that it occurs in various coniferous forests, especially under Monterey Pine and Bishop Pine, also Shore Pine on the Far North Coast, into the Pacific Northwest. They also mention that it occasionally associates with live oak and madrone, more rarely with Valley Oak. (Siegel(2))

Boletus fibrillosus.edibility: unknown (Thiers), edible but inferior to B. edulis (Trudell)
Boletus fibrillosus.habitat: single to scattered in soil in dense mixed coastal forests, (Thiers), in dense mixed coastal forests or in conifer woods (Bessette), in old growth forests of Abies (fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), earlier succession forests of T. heterophylla and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and other mixed forest stands, (Trudell)

Boletus mottiae.habitat: type was found under conifers (Thiers), fall

Boletus regineus.spores: "olive-brown in mass, but yellower than closely related species under the microscope", (Arora(2)), dark olive-brown (Arora(1), Thiers)
Boletus regineus.habitat: single or in groups, in California north to Oregon commonly associated with hardwoods (tanoak especially, madrone, golden chinquapin, manzanita, and oak), usually in fall (October to December) but occasionally in spring, less commonly in the Cascades of Oregon and Washington associated with conifers, (Arora(2)), single, scattered, or gregarious in mixed woods and under hardwoods (especially oaks), (Arora(1)), scattered to gregarious under oaks and madrones (Thiers for California)

Boletus rex-veris.habitat: scattered to gregarious or clustered under mountain conifers, especially Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), and Abies spp., often buried in needle duff beneath understory shrubs

'Boletus' smithii.habitat: single to gregarious on soil in dense mixed coastal forests, fall and winter, (Thiers), single, scattered, or in groups on ground in conifer or mixed woods, July to December, (Bessette), summer, fall, winter

Boletus subalpinus.nameOrigin: means "subalpine, growing below the timber line" (Both(1))
Boletus subalpinus.habitat: single to gregarious "in soil or duff under mountain conifers in late spring and summer", developing underground but often partially exposed when mature, (Arora), single to gregarious, underground or partly emerging, under Pinus albicaulis or Abies magnifica and possibly other conifers of montane and subalpine forests, "Commonly found late spring and summer", (Thiers), developing under soil surface associated with the roots of various Pinaceae above 1550m elevation, particularly Abies magnifica (Red Fir), Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), and Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), September and October, (Castellano), with Pinus albicaulis, Pinus contorta, Abies, Tsuga mertensiana, at relatively high elevations to the tree line; July to October, (Trappe, M.(3))

Buchwaldoboletus lignicola.taste: weakly acidic or not distinctive (Bessette), pleasant (Phillips)
Buchwaldoboletus lignicola.odour: faintly aromatic (Bessette), faint, aromatic, (Phillips), 2 records of unpleasant odor (Ortiz-Santana)
Buchwaldoboletus lignicola.habitat: single or scattered "on or around conifer stumps or sawdust", July to October, (Bessette), "always on stumps or trunks of conifers, exceptionally on sawdust", (Phillips), "with white pine and other pines, on and around conifers stumps", (Both), associated with pines, also with Larix (larch), rarely with hardwoods (Prunus avium), (Ortiz-Santana)

Buchwaldoboletus sphaerocephalus.spores: olive brown (Bessette), "olive brownish or tinged ochraceous in the olive-brown range", (Smith)
Buchwaldoboletus sphaerocephalus.taste: not distinctive or somewhat bitter (Bessette), mild to bitterish (Smith)
Buchwaldoboletus sphaerocephalus.habitat: "scattered, in groups or clusters in sawdust, or on stumps or the surrounding soil", (Bessette)

Butyriboletus abieticola.habitat: "scattered or in groups on the ground in conifer forests, especially firs, at higher elevations, August-January", (Bessette), rare at lower elevations but not uncommon in the zone characterized by Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir) / Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), (R. Bishop, pers. comm.), summer, fall, winter

Butyriboletus autumniregius.nameOrigin: "autumni" refers to autumn fruiting, and "regius" means "kingly" and also refers to the European Butyriboletus regius
Butyriboletus autumniregius.spores: spores dark olive brown in mass, at least under microscope
Butyriboletus autumniregius.habitat: single or in groups on the ground in coastal and mid-elevation forests, "associated with conifers and possibly also with hardwoods", has been observed in pure stands of Douglas-fir; fruiting generally in the fall (September to December)

Butyriboletus persolidus.nameOrigin: from "per", Latin for "very" and "solidus", Latin for "solid" or "dense"
Butyriboletus persolidus.habitat: single or in groups "in soil under hardwoods or in mixed forests", usually associated with Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), probably with other trees in Fagaceae, e.g. Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak), Chrysolepis chrysophylla (Golden Chinquapin); typically fruiting October to December in California

Butyriboletus primiregius.nameOrigin: from "primi" meaning "first" because it is the first butter bolete to fruit in the year in the western USA mountains, and "regius" meaning "kingly" and referring also to the European Butyriboletus regius
Butyriboletus primiregius.spores: dark olive brown, at least in mass under microscope
Butyriboletus primiregius.habitat: single or in groups in soil under conifers (primarily Abies), fruiting in late spring and early summer (May to July), in the mountains, not known from the coastal region

Butyriboletus querciregius.nameOrigin: from "querci" meaning "pertaining to oak" and "regius" meaning "kingly" and referring also to the European Butyriboletus regius
Butyriboletus querciregius.spores: dark olive brown, at least in mass under microscope
Butyriboletus querciregius.habitat: single or in groups in leaf litter under oak (mainly Quercus agrifolia and Q. garryana, less commonly with other Quercus spp.); mostly fruiting in fall (September to December) but has been found in May and in June

Butyriboletus regius.habitat: single to gregarious in woods (Arora(1)), single, scattered or in groups under oaks or conifers, especially firs, August to November or sometimes May to June, (Bessette), spring, summer, fall, winter

Caloboletus 'calopus'.habitat: single, scattered or in groups on ground in conifer or mixed forests, sometimes with oak, (Bessette), "solitary, scattered, or in groups on ground in mixed woods and under conifers in the late summer and fall (or occasionally spring)", (Arora)

Caloboletus conifericola.habitat: single, scattered or in groups under conifers, (Bessette)

Caloboletus marshii.nameOrigin: "Named after Ben Marsh, who found it near the type locality in 1972" and brought it to the attention of David Arora "after unsuccessfully trying to make it palatable" (Frank)
Caloboletus marshii.taste: "distinctly bitter in fresh specimens at least for most people, but sometimes indistinctly in old or waterlogged specimens" (Frank), "bitter, at least latently", (Arora), slightly sweet at first then slowly somewhat bitter (the sweetness cutting the bitter sensation), (M. Beug, pers. comm.)
Caloboletus marshii.habitat: single "or in groups or small clusters on ground in association with oaks", especially Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak) but not limited to that species, also with Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), (Frank), single to gregarious on ground near or under live oak in summer and early fall (Arora)

Caloboletus rubripes.odour: unpleasant or not distinctive (Bessette), often strong, unpleasant (Thiers)
Caloboletus rubripes.habitat: single to scattered or grouped primarily under conifers (Arora), single, scattered or in groups under conifers or sometimes oak, July to November, (Bessette), in Pacific Northwest in montane conifer forests; in California described from coastal conifer and mixed forests, (Trudell), summer, fall

Chalciporus piperatoides.spores: dark smoky olive when fresh, rusty cinnamon when dry, (Bessette)
Chalciporus piperatoides.taste: slowly acrid [peppery] (Bessette), slowly peppery (not as hot as B. piperatus), (Smith)
Chalciporus piperatoides.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups on ground under conifers or hardwoods, (Bessette), fall

Chalciporus piperatus.spores: brown to cinnamon brown (Bessette), cinnamon brown (Thiers, Desjardin), dull cinnamon (Smith)
Chalciporus piperatus.edibility: unknown (Bessette), McIlvaine reports that peppery taste is lost in cooking and then edible, but Murrill warns that it is poisonous, (Thiers)
Chalciporus piperatus.taste: distinctly hot and peppery (Bessette), very sharply and distinctly acrid [peppery] (Smith)
Chalciporus piperatus.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups on ground under conifers or hardwoods, (Bessette), summer and fall (Miller)

Gastroboletus amyloideus.habitat: single or scattered, "forming underground, typically remaining buried, occasionally emerging from duff when mature"; associated with Pinaceae, especially Abies magnifica (Red Fir) and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine); "summer and fall"

Gastroboletus ruber.habitat: fruitbodies develop under the soil surface associated with the roots of assorted Pinaceae species above 1,350 m in elevation, particularly Abies amabilis, A. procera, A. magnifica var. shastensis, Pinus monticola, or Tsuga mertensiana, August through September, (Castellano), single to gregarious or cespitose, underground or emergent, Cascade Mountains at elevations 1200-1800m, (Cazares), emergent from heavy duff under conifers, especially hemlock, during late summer in the Cascade Mountains of Washington, (Smith), type emergent from heavy duff under hemlock, (Zeller)

Gastroboletus turbinatus.nameOrigin: means "shaped like a spinning top, obconical, turbinate", (Both(1))
Gastroboletus turbinatus.habitat: single to scattered or gregarious "on ground in woods or at their edges, often partially buried", (Arora), on humus under conifers, often Abies spp. (fir), along mountain paths and roadsides, July through September, (Smith), spring through fall (Trudell)

Gastroboletus vividus.habitat: growing underground or partially underground under mature conifers (Abies concolor, A. magnifica var. shastensis, Pinus contorta and Tsuga mertensiana), July to September, (Trappe(2)), above 1650m elevation (Castellano)

Gyroporus borealis.edibility: to be avoided in general as poisonous Gyroporus is known (Davoodian(1))
Gyroporus borealis.habitat: "with native vegetation in Vermont (Betula, Tsuga; Acer in vicinity) and Ohio (Quercus, Fagus, Tsuga; mixed hardwoods in vicinity) [Latin italicized]", and in Washington occurs presumably by way of planted ectomycorrhizal landscape trees, for example birch, oak, pine etc.

Gyroporus castaneus.spores: pale yellow to yellow, (Arora), pale yellow to buff (Bessette)
Gyroporus castaneus.edibility: to be avoided in general as poisonous Gyroporus is known (Davoodian(1))
Gyroporus castaneus.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), hazelnut (Lincoff(1)), mild, slightly acidic (Miller)
Gyroporus castaneus.habitat: single or in groups under hardwoods, (Arora), single, scattered, or in groups under mixed conifers and hardwoods, (Bessette), summer and fall (Miller)

Hemileccinum subglabripes.habitat: scattered on ground under hardwoods, especially birch, occasionally under conifers, (Bessette)

Hortiboletus coccyginus.habitat: single or in small clusters, in the Pacific Northwest often in stands of Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), on the California coast under Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Alnus rubra (Red Alder), and Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), in the Sierra Nevada in mixed forest with Abies concolor (White Fir), A. magnifica (California Red Fir), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), and Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen); late summer and fall, (Frank), gregarious to subcespitose [almost tufted] under conifers, (Thiers)

Hortiboletus 'rubellus'.taste: not distinctive (Bessette(3)), mild, sourish, (Breitenbach), slightly soapy (Phillips)
Hortiboletus 'rubellus'.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups on the ground in hardwood forests and mixed woods, especially under oak and beech; July to October, (Bessette(3)), single to gregarious, in mixed hardwood forests, parks, gardens, and floodplain forests, primarily on calcareous soils; summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Leccinum atrostipitatum.edibility: reported by some authors including Bessette(3) as edible, but orange Leccinum species have been implicated in poisoning episodes
Leccinum atrostipitatum.habitat: single to scattered under hardwoods, usually birch, July to September, (Bessette), summer, fall

Leccinum aurantiacum.spores: brown (Bessette, Thiers), dark yellow-brown to dull cinnamon (Smith(35))
Leccinum aurantiacum.edibility: reported by some authors including Bessette(3) as edible, but orange Leccinum species have been implicated in poisoning episodes
Leccinum aurantiacum.habitat: scattered or in groups under aspen or pine, July to September, (Bessette), summer and fall (Bacon)

Leccinum brunneum.habitat: gregarious to scattered on ground under aspen

Leccinum clavatum.habitat: type gregarious under spruce and fir, (Smith(38))

Leccinum cyaneobasileucum.edibility: edible, "and with a good flavor, but often quite slimy in texture", (Siegel)
Leccinum cyaneobasileucum.habitat: single or scattered in troops, "sometimes in large numbers on urban lawns under planted birches"; in California Redwood Coast frequently found with Russula versicolor, Paxillus cuprinus, Lactarius pubescens var. betulae, and Cortinarius hemitrichus, and common in late summer and early fall, (Siegel), with birch in moss, but not normally in Sphagnum, summer to fall, (Phillips), on soil and peat on heathland, moorland and other acidic sites with birch, sometimes among mosses although often in drier habitats and not usually with Sphagnum, (Buczacki)

Leccinum discolor.edibility: reported by Theirs(1) as edible, but orange Leccinum species have been implicated in poisoning episodes
Leccinum discolor.habitat: single, scattered or in groups on ground under pine and aspen, (Bessette), single to scattered in soil under aspen (Thiers(13))

Leccinum fallax.edibility: orange Leccinum species have been implicated in poisoning episodes

Leccinum fibrillosum.edibility: reported by some authors including Bessette(3) as edible, but orange Leccinum species have been implicated in poisoning episodes
Leccinum fibrillosum.habitat: scattered or grouped under conifers, especially Engelmann Spruce and Lodgepole Pine, (Bessette(3)), late summer and early fall (Miller)

Leccinum holopus.habitat: single to scattered on ground in and around bogs, cedar swamps or wet birch woods, (Bessette), scattered to single in cold bogs, cedar swamps, etc., (Smith), summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Leccinum idahoense.spores: brown, (Bessette), dingy cinnamon when air-dried (Smith(4)), "Sayal-brown" (Ridgway color) when moist, pale cinnamon after loss of moisture as in most species of Suillus, (Smith(37))
Leccinum idahoense.habitat: single or scattered on ground under conifers, (Bessette), under western cedar, hemlock, and western white pine mixed, (Smith(4))

Leccinum insigne.edibility: reported by some authors including Bessette(3) as edible, but orange Leccinum species have been implicated in poisoning episodes
Leccinum insigne.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground under aspen or birch (Bessette), associated primarily if not exclusively with aspen (Arora), gregarious to scattered in soil under aspens, (Thiers(13)), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller)

Leccinum manzanitae.edibility: reported by some authors including Bessette(3) as edible, but orange Leccinum species have been implicated in poisoning episodes
Leccinum manzanitae.habitat: singly to scattered or gregarious, under manzanita and madrone, (Arora), single, scattered, or in groups under madrone or manzanita (Bessette), fall

Leccinum ponderosum.edibility: reported by some authors including Bessette(3) as edible, but orange Leccinum species have been implicated in poisoning episodes
Leccinum ponderosum.habitat: single, scattered or in groups on or near decaying conifers, especially pines, (Bessette), scattered under Ponderosa or Lodgepole Pine, (Smith(4)), type under Pinus ponderosa and P. lambertiana (Smith(38)), fall

Leccinum rotundifoliae.habitat: scattered or in small groups on the ground under birch, (Bessette), scattered under dwarf birch in and along the edges of cold bogs, (Smith)

Leccinum scabrum.habitat: single, scattered or in groups on ground under hardwoods, especially birch, (Bessette), under birch (Smith), summer and fall (Miller), common in urban and suburban settings and less so in natural habitats, (Trudell)

Leccinum versipelle.nameOrigin: "versipelle" means "with a different skin or pellicle", (Both(1)); "testaceoscabrum" means "brick-red and scabrous" (Both(1))
Leccinum versipelle.edibility: suspected to cause gastric distress in some people, (Bessette)
Leccinum versipelle.habitat: scattered or in groups under beech, oak, or birch, July to September, (Bessette), summer, fall, (Bacon)

Neoboletus 'luridiformis'.edibility: poisonous, causing gastrointestinal distress (Bessette), rated edible by some, but red pores serve as a warning of poisonous species, (Thiers), poisonous to some people (Arora)
Neoboletus 'luridiformis'.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups under conifers or hardwoods, (Bessette), single in soil in mixed forests (Thiers), late summer to fall (Bacon)

Porphyrellus porphyrosporus.nameOrigin: porphyr- refers to a purple or dark red color
Porphyrellus porphyrosporus.spores: dark reddish brown, (Bessette), distinctly reddish brown when moist, dark grayish brown when air-dried, (Smith(35))
Porphyrellus porphyrosporus.taste: weakly bitter or mild (Bessette), mild (Smith(35)), bitter with an aftertaste (Miller)
Porphyrellus porphyrosporus.odour: pungent, clove-like or resembling coal tar when fresh, stem base sometimes with a strong odor of chlorine, (Bessette), sharp and rather pungent, strong, (Smith(35)), antiseptic-like (Miller)
Porphyrellus porphyrosporus.habitat: single, scattered, or rarely in groups on ground "in mixed woods or conifer woods, sometimes growing on well-decayed logs and stumps", (Bessette), scattered to gregarious in hardwood and mixed forests along old roads, etc., (Smith(35)), summer and early fall (Miller)

Pulveroboletus ravenelii.spores: olive gray to olive brown, (Bessette), smoky olive (Smith from Coker & Beers), dark olive brown (Thiers)
Pulveroboletus ravenelii.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), acidulous (Smith), rather sour (Phillips), mild but soon unpleasant (Miller)
Pulveroboletus ravenelii.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups on ground in woods, (Bessette), mostly single to scattered in pine woods as well as hardwoods, (Smith), on the ground, in mixed pine, hemlock, and deciduous stands, spruce woods, and laurel and rhododendron thickets, (Lincoff), in mixed forests, most commonly under oaks (Thiers for California), summer, fall, and winter, (Miller)

Rubroboletus eastwoodiae.nameOrigin: Rubroboletus eastwoodiae is named after the collector of the type, Miss Alice Eastwood. Incidentally the name Boletus satanas is after Satan, the ecclesiastical Latin name for whom is "Satanas". Some authors including Alexander Smith and the Millers call that species Boletus satanus but this usage is hard to defend. The ecclesiastical Latin for "Satan" is "Satanas" and Lenz presumably used this noun as the species name - there is no reason to correct it to "satanus".
Rubroboletus eastwoodiae.edibility: poisonous, at least raw, causing vomiting, diarrhea, and severe cramps, (Arora)
Rubroboletus eastwoodiae.odour: not distinctive (Thiers(1)), cabbage or dung when mature (Lincoff)
Rubroboletus eastwoodiae.habitat: single or in groups under oaks, (Arora), single to gregarious under oaks, (Thiers(1)), Washington collection associated with Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), (Michael Beug, pers. comm.), late fall and winter (Miller)

Rubroboletus haematinus.habitat: associated with fir species, especially A. lasiocarpa in Washington and A. magnifica in the Sierra Nevada mountains, apparently limited to subalpine forests, (Castellano), on ground under mountain conifers, especially red fir, (Bessette)

Rubroboletus pulcherrimus.edibility: poisonous, causing severe gastrointestinal distress, at least one fatality, (Bessette)
Rubroboletus pulcherrimus.habitat: single to gregarious in humus in mixed woods, (Thiers), single or scattered on ground in conifer or mixed woods, August to January, (Bessette), summer, fall, winter

Suillellus amygdalinus.edibility: avoid on the basis of the general rule about avoiding red-pored boletes
Suillellus amygdalinus.habitat: "solitary, scattered or in groups on ground, typically under oak and manzanita, but also reported under redwoods", October to January, (Bessette), fall, winter

Suillus acidus.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "about the color of a fresh olive", (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Suillus acidus.habitat: scattered or in groups under mixed conifers, (Bessette), gregarious under mixed conifers (Smith), scattered to gregarious under conifers, particularly Western White Pine, (Arora)

Suillus albivelatus.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "with a white veil", (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Suillus albivelatus.spores: cinnamon-brown to buff (Bessette(3)), near cinnamon-buff after moisture has escaped (Smith)
Suillus albivelatus.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups on ground under conifers, especially ponderosa pine and other pines, June to August, (Bessette(3)), late summer and early fall (Miller)

Suillus americanus.spores: dull cinnamon (Smith(34)), brown (Bessette), light brown to brownish orange (McKnight), dull cinnamon, (Bessette for S. sibiricus), "Sayal brown" (Ridgway color), (Smith(34) for S. sibiricus), brown to dull cinnamon-brown (Arora for S. sibiricus)
Suillus americanus.edibility: yes (Bessette), yes (Bessette for S. sibiricus), yes, but A.H. Smith reports a case of acute allergic reaction by merely touching it, (Arora for S. sibiricus)
Suillus americanus.taste: not distinctive (Bessette, Smith(34)), acidic (McKnight), acidic or not distinctive (Bessette for S. sibiricus), acidulous (Smith(34) for S. sibiricus), mildly bitter (Phillips for S. sibiricus)
Suillus americanus.odour: not distinctive (Bessette, Smith(34)), not distinctive (Bessette for S. sibiricus), none or slight (Smith(34) for S. sibiricus), distinctive (Phillips for S. sibiricus)
Suillus americanus.habitat: single or in groups or cespitose [in tufts] on ground under white pine, (Bessette), gregarious under Pinus strobus (Eastern White Pine), (Smith(34) for northern and eastern US), single, gregarious or cespitose under white pine, (Smith(35) for Michigan), late summer and early fall (Miller), scattered or in groups under pine and larch, (Bessette for S. sibiricus), gregarious under Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), (Smith(34) for S. sibiricus), scattered to gregarious or clustered under conifers, associated with white (5-needle) pines, especially common in Pacific Northwest and northern California with Western White Pine, in Southwest with southwestern white pine and limber pine, (Arora for S. sibiricus), fall

Suillus ampliporus.spores: brown, (Bessette), dark olive-brown when moist, (Smith(34)), dark olive to brown (Arora), olivaceous (Phillips)
Suillus ampliporus.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground under larch in forests and bogs, (Bessette), gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] under larch, (Smith(34)), late summer and fall, (Miller)

Suillus brevipes.spores: near "cinnamon" (Smith), cinnamon-brown (Bessette), brown to dull cinnamon (Arora)
Suillus brevipes.edibility: yes (Bessette), peel cap cuticle before cooking (Arora)
Suillus brevipes.habitat: scattered to cespitose [in tufts] under 2-needle and 3-needle pines, in the Rocky Mountains and the Pacific Coast under P. contorta, summer, fall, warm wet winter weather, (Smith), scattered or in groups under pine, August to November, (Bessette), scattered to densely gregarious under conifers, particularly 2-needle and 3-needle pines, also spruce, (Arora), June to November (Phillips), summer, fall

Suillus brunnescens.spores: brown (Bessette), brown (Bessette for S. borealis), pale "orange-cinnamon" when fresh, "cinnamon-buff" after moisture escapes (Ridgway colors), (Smith for S. borealis)
Suillus brunnescens.edibility: yes (Bessette), yes, when gluten has been removed, (Bessette for S. borealis)
Suillus brunnescens.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), mild (Smith for S. borealis)
Suillus brunnescens.odour: not distinctive (Bessette), slight (Smith for S. borealis)
Suillus brunnescens.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground under pines (Bessette), type under Sugar Pine (Smith), single, scattered or in groups on ground under conifers, especially Western White Pine, (Bessette for S. borealis), gregarious to subcespitose [somewhat tufted] in white pine area of Idaho, with larch and fir, mostly in rather dry areas, (Smith for S. borealis), fall

Suillus caerulescens.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), mild or slightly acidulous (Smith(34)), none or slightly sour, (Phillips)
Suillus caerulescens.odour: not distinctive (Bessette), mild or slightly acidulous (Smith(34)), none or slightly sour, (Phillips)
Suillus caerulescens.habitat: "scattered or in groups on ground or among mosses under conifers", (Bessette), scattered to densely gregarious on ground under or near Douglas-fir, (Arora), mostly under mixtures of Douglas-fir, lowland fir, hemlock and redwood, with larch present at times, (Smith(34)), confined to Douglas-fir (Thiers), summer, fall, winter

Suillus clintonianus.nameOrigin: after Scottish mycologist R. K. Greville, (Lincoff(1), Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Suillus clintonianus.spores: dull cinnamon-brown, (Bessette), olive-brown to dull cinnamon (Arora), olive brown when moist, dull cinnamon when dry, (Smith)
Suillus clintonianus.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), mild to slightly astringent to bitterish (Smith)
Suillus clintonianus.odour: not distinctive or acid-metallic (Bessette), none to somewhat metallic (Smith)
Suillus clintonianus.habitat: cespitose to gregarious, often in arcs and always associated with larch, (Smith), early summer to late fall (Miller)

Suillus discolor.habitat: single, scattered or in groups, on the ground under white pine, fall (September to October), (Bessette), associates with soft pines (subgenus Strobus), in particular P. monticola (Western White Pine) and P. albicaulis (Whitebark Pine) in western North America, (Nguyen)

Suillus elbensis.spores: vinaceous brown (Bessette), vinaceous brown when moist, nearer avellaneous when air dried, (Smith), reddish brown (Miller)
Suillus elbensis.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground under larch, (Bessette), late summer and fall, (Miller)
