Suillus flavidus.spores: dull cinnamon (Smith), olive-brown to dull cinnamon-brown, (Arora)
Suillus flavidus.habitat: gregarious to subcespitose [somewhat tufted] under Pinus contorta (Smith), scattered to gregarious or in small clumps under conifers, "particularly lodgepole and beach pines (Pinus contorta)", (Arora)

Suillus flavogranulatus.spores: pale rusty cinnamon, (Bessette), "pale rusty cinnamon after escape of moisture", (Smith)
Suillus flavogranulatus.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground under pines, (Bessette)

Suillus fuscotomentosus.taste: not distinctive to weakly acid and unpleasant, (Smith)
Suillus fuscotomentosus.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious on ground under pines, (Arora), single, scattered, or in groups on ground under pine, (Bessette), type single to gregarious in sandy soil in mixed woods, (Smith)

Suillus glandulosipes.nameOrigin: means 'having glandules (small glands) on the stem' (referring to the glandular dots and smears), (Both(1))
Suillus glandulosipes.spores: brown (Bessette), dark brown when moist, deep yellowish brown to dark yellowish brown when dry, (Palm for S. neoalbidipes), yellow-brown (Bessette for S. neoalbidipes), dull reddish brown (McKnight for S. neoalbidipes)
Suillus glandulosipes.edibility: yes, remove gluten, (Bessette), recently reported as toxic (McKnight, 1987, for S. neoalbidipes)
Suillus glandulosipes.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground under pine (Bessette), type gregarious to cespitose [in tufts] in humus under scrubby Lodgepole Pine (Pinus contorta) in pygmy forest, (Smith), near 2-needle, 3-needle, or 5-needle pines, (Palm for Suillus neoalbidipes), single, scattered, or in groups in sandy soil under pines, (Bessette for S. neoalbidipes)

Suillus 'granulatus'.spores: brown (Bessette), dingy cinnamon to cinnamon (Smith(34)), brown to dull cinnamon or ocher (Arora), dingy cinnamon to red-brown (Miller)
Suillus 'granulatus'.edibility: edible, but note that a few people develop contact dermatitis with swelling and itchy rash on handling this species, (Bessette), occasionally gastric upset has resulted (Miller)
Suillus 'granulatus'.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), mild to acid (cap cuticle) (Smith(34))
Suillus 'granulatus'.odour: not distinctive (Bessette), mild to slightly fragrant (Smith(34)), pleasant, slightly acid, fruity, (Lincoff(1))
Suillus 'granulatus'.habitat: scattered or in groups on the ground under pines, (Bessette), scattered to gregarious under pine (Smith(34)), especially under 5-needle white pines; late spring, summer, and fall, (Miller), spring, summer, fall, winter

Suillus imbellus.habitat: single under Tsuga mertensiana and Abies amabilis, midsummer, (Thiers), "sporocarps beneath the soil surface associated with the roots of Abies grandis, A. lasiocarpa, Tsuga mertensiana, with an understory of Antennaria lanata, Fragaria sp., Pachistima myrsinites, Sorbus sitchensis, and Vaccinium sp. at 1,650m elevation", (Castellano)

Suillus lakei.spores: dull cinnamon (Bessette, Smith), cinnamon-brown to olive-brown (Miller)
Suillus lakei.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground under conifers, especially Douglas-fir, (Bessette), scattered to gregarious, typically associated with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Smith), prefers poor, exposed soil and often on roadbanks or in campgrounds, (Arora), confined to Douglas-fir (Thiers), spring, summer, and fall, (Miller), spring, summer, fall, winter

Suillus luteus.spores: brown, (Bessette), '"sayal brown" to "clay color" dull cinnamon when moisture has escaped' (Ridgway colors), (Smith(34)), brown to dull cinnamon (Arora)
Suillus luteus.edibility: yes (Bessette), some people are apparently "allergic" to it, (Arora), may cause transient diarrhea if slime not removed, (Lincoff(2)), good after removing cuticle and drying, although some experience diarrhea, (Lincoff(1))
Suillus luteus.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground near or under pine, spruce, and mixed conifers, (Bessette), scattered to gregarious under conifers, (Smith(34)), summer and fall (Miller), occasionally spring, mainly fall, (Bacon), spring, summer, fall, winter

Suillus ochraceoroseus.spores: dark reddish brown to purplish brown, (Bessette), dark vinaceous brown (Smith)
Suillus ochraceoroseus.taste: slightly acrid [peppery] to bitter (Bessette), very slightly peppery, bitterish in cooked material, (Smith)
Suillus ochraceoroseus.habitat: scattered or in groups under larch in conifer woods, August to October, (Bessette), mostly late spring and summer (Trudell)

Suillus pallidiceps.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground under Lodgepole Pine [Pinus contorta], (Bessette), type gregarious under Pinus contorta (Smith)

Suillus 'placidus'.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground under eastern white pine (Bessette, referring to eastern North America), reported from WA under white pine, (Smith)

Suillus ponderosus.odour: acidic or not distinctive (Bessette), sharply acidulous, (Smith)
Suillus ponderosus.habitat: scattered or in groups on ground under conifers, especially Douglas-fir, (Bessette), scattered "in forests of Douglas-fir, hemlock and pine (P. contorta) mixed", (Smith), confined to Douglas-fir (Thiers(11))

Suillus pseudobrevipes.taste: slightly acidic or not distinctive (Bessette), mild to slightly acidulous, (Smith)
Suillus pseudobrevipes.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups on ground under pine, (Bessette), gregarious to scattered under Lodgepole Pine (Pinus contorta), (Smith), scattered to gregarious under pines, mainly Lodgepole and Ponderosa Pine, (Arora)

Suillus punctatipes.odour: pungent or not distinctive (Bessette), none (Smith(34), Smith(35))
Suillus punctatipes.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups on ground in conifer forests, (Bessette), type collected under Douglas-fir, hemlock and fir, (Smith(34)), single in mixed conifers (Smith for single collection in Michigan)

Suillus quiescens.nameOrigin: "refers to the species' ability to lay quiescent in the spore bank until it encounters pine roots", (Bruns)
Suillus quiescens.spores: not determined but probably between 'strong yellow brown' and 'strong brown' as seen on cap surface
Suillus quiescens.habitat: fruiting in small groups with pines, November to March, (Bruns), fall, winter, spring

Suillus subalpinus.habitat: single or scattered in soil under Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), "summer or fall in high-elevation subalpine forest", (Siegel), growing under five-needle pines - Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), Pinus flexilis (Limber Pine), "in subalpine forests up to timber line", (Moser)

Suillus suilloides.habitat: single to gregarious, "hypogeous to partially emergent", under conifers including Abies magnifica (California Red Fir) and Pinus contorta ssp. murrayana (Sierra Lodgepole Pine) in higher elevations of the Sierra Nevada of California, late summer

Suillus tomentosus.spores: brown  (Bessette), dark olive brown, very slowly changing to dull cinnamon, (Smith)
Suillus tomentosus.taste: not distinctive (Bessette), slightly acid to mild (Smith)
Suillus tomentosus.habitat: scattered or in groups under conifers, (Bessette), scattered to gregarious under 2-needle pines, (Smith), summer and fall (Miller), primarily under Lodgepole and Shore Pines (Trudell)

Xerocomellus amylosporus.spores: "olive brown to dark reddish olive" (Frank(9)), dark reddish brown (Bessette), dark "wood brown" on white paper, (Smith)
Xerocomellus amylosporus.habitat: single or scattered in troops under conifers, especially Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce); type collection was under Alnus rubra (Red Alder) but Alnus has not been present at all sites, (Frank(9)), single or scattered on ground under hardwoods or in mixed woods, frequently associated with oak or red alder, (Bessette), type gregarious under Alnus rubra in Idaho, (Smith)

Xerocomellus atropurpureus.nameOrigin: atro- (from ater, Latin for black or dark), -purpureus (from purpureus, Latin for purple), referring to the color of the cap, (Frank)
Xerocomellus atropurpureus.habitat: single "or scattered in troops", "on well-decayed, moss-covered logs and stumps or duff", both with hardwoods and with conifers, in California mostly fruiting in fall and winter, with scattered spring fruitings, (Siegel), single or scattered in small groups, sometimes cespitose, in mixed forests, typically with conifers, sometimes with oak and other hardwoods, "occasionally emerging from well-rotted wood", (Frank)

Xerocomellus diffractus.nameOrigin: from diffringere in Latin, meaning "to break", "referring to the extensively cracking pileus surface"
Xerocomellus diffractus.edibility: yes but not choice and bear in mind the risk of confusing with untested species, (Thiers)
Xerocomellus diffractus.habitat: single "or scattered in troops", "under both conifers and hardwoods", "fall and early winter, or occasionally in spring on the California and Oregon coast, and summer in the Southwest, and at higher elevations", (Frank), single to gregarious under hardwoods and conifers, (Thiers)

Xerocomellus dryophilus.nameOrigin: means 'tree-loving' or 'oak-loving', in this case probably the latter
Xerocomellus dryophilus.edibility: edible, consumed where better boletes unavailable, but mature specimens soft, and even young ones commonly parasitized by Hypomyces, (Siegel)
Xerocomellus dryophilus.taste: mild (Siegel, Frank), slightly acid near the cap cuticle, otherwise mild, (Thiers)
Xerocomellus dryophilus.habitat: single or scattered, "often in drier forests under live oak", late fall into spring, (Siegel), single to gregarious "in humus in open oak woods", in California associated with coastal live oak, (Thiers)

Xerocomellus mendocinensis.edibility: edible - texture is a bit soft, with an unremarkable flavor, (Siegel)
Xerocomellus mendocinensis.habitat: single, scattered in troops or in small clumps, "most common under live oak in the southern part of our range" [Redwood Coast of California], but found in mixed forest of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak) northward, fruiting in fall and early winter, (Siegel), single, in small groups or scattered in troops, "typically not clustered", found "in a wide variety of forest types": in the Pacific Northwest with conifers, commonly in California under Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak) and Notholithocarpus densiflorus, sometimes with Chrysolepis chrysophylla (Golden Chinquapin), (Frank)

Xerocomellus rainisiae.nameOrigin: in honor of Arleen Rainis Bessette who first collected it
Xerocomellus rainisiae.habitat: single, "scattered in troops or small clusters, in conifer forests, both along the coast and in the foothills and drier eastern slopes of the Cascade Range"; typical sites forested with mixed conifers including Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), Abies grandis (Grand Fir), Abies concolor (White Fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), "along coast from mid to late fall into winter, typically later than other Xerocomellus, and at higher elevations in summer and fall", (Frank with Latin names italicized), scattered or in groups under mixed conifers, including Douglas-fir and Western Hemlock, October to December, (Bessette(3))

Xerocomellus salicicola.nameOrigin: from genus Salix (willow) and -cola, Latin for "inhabitant of", "referring to the dominant tree in the habitat where it is most commonly encountered"
Xerocomellus salicicola.habitat: in small groups of 1-4 fruitbodies, "sometimes clustered, often from wet, muddy or hard-packed soil in riparian areas", typically associated with willow species, and in one case with Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), occasionally in landscaped areas under Betula pendula (Silver Birch); "in spring, summer, and fall"

Xerocomellus zelleri.nameOrigin: after American mycologist Sanford Myron Zeller (19 October 1885 - 4 November 1948)
Xerocomellus zelleri.edibility: edible and good, with a pleasant lemony taste (Siegel)
Xerocomellus zelleri.habitat: single or scattered in moss, "or on or around moss covered stumps and logs"; found extensively in mature and old growth coniferous forest, (Siegel), single or scattered in moss or on and around moss-covered stumps and logs, "in mature and old growth conifer forest", (Frank)

Xerocomus ferrugineus.spores: dark olive brown (Thiers), olive to pale olive brown (Bessette)
Xerocomus ferrugineus.habitat: "in groups on the ground in mixed woods and under conifers, along road banks and trails", (Bessette)

'Xerocomus' oregonensis^.habitat: holotype is a single specimen "on the ground in sandy pine barrens on the immediate coast at Newport, Oregon"; "Although growing in sand, the weather conditions were very humid"

Xerocomus subtomentosus.taste: mild to slightly acid (Thiers), not distinctive (Bessette)
Xerocomus subtomentosus.habitat: single or scattered on ground or among mosses under hardwoods or conifers, (Bessette), early summer to late fall (Miller)

Alpova diplophloeus.nameOrigin: from Greek "diplo-" meaning "double" and "-phloeus" meaning "rind", for the 2-layered peridium, (Trappe, M.(1)); "concolor" refers to "the similarly dark rusty brown peridium and gleba when dried"
Alpova diplophloeus.odour: fruity at maturity (Trappe(11), Smith(4)), usually fruity at maturity (Arora)
Alpova diplophloeus.habitat: under alder; June through December, (Smith(4)), widely scattered to gregarious in humus or soil (usually buried) under or near alder, (Arora), mycorrhizal with Alnus (Trappe(13))

Alpova trappei.nameOrigin: refers to James Trappe, author of a 1975 revision of the genus Alpova
Alpova trappei.odour: mildly garlicky to fruity when old, (Smith), "variously described as mildly garlicky to fruity in age", (Fogel)
Alpova trappei.habitat: under conifers, April through October, (Smith), underground, a probable mycorrhizal associate with Abies spp. (fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and possibly other Pinaceae, April through October, low to middle elevations, (Fogel), April to December (Trappe, M.(3))

Ambispora gerdemannii.nameOrigin: "In honor of Dr. James W. Gerdemann for his contributions to knowledge of the Endogonaceae, particularly those of Oregon." (Rose)
Ambispora gerdemannii.habitat: "on volcanic soils in climatically stressed and pioneer sites"; associated in the field with vesicular-arbuscular mycorrhizae of Ceanothus velutinus, C. prostratus, and C. integerrimus, (forming mycorrhizae in pot culture with C. velutinus)

Arcangeliella gardneri.nameOrigin: after N.L. Gardner, who collected the type
Arcangeliella gardneri.habitat: under leaves of Quercus agrifolia (Coast Live Oak), December, (Zeller), associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus, (Trappe)

Arcangeliella tenax.taste: milk quickly and strongly peppery, (Smith(4)), milk immediately and very strongly peppery, (Smith(24)), immediately peppery (Thiers(4))
Arcangeliella tenax.odour: "moderately sweetish-fungoid when fresh, not distinctive in dried specimens", (Smith(24)), strong, unpleasant, (Thiers(4))
Arcangeliella tenax.habitat: conifer forest (Smith(4)), type single "in clay soil along an old road through a conifer woods mostly composed of firs", about half exposed, (Smith(24)), under red fir (Thiers(4) for California), associated with Pinaceae (Trappe)

Balsamia alba.habitat: underground in variously mixed forests under Abies concolor, Picea engelmannii, Pinus jeffreyi, P. lambertiana, P. ponderosa, P. sabiniana, Pseudotsuga menziesii, Quercus garryana, Q. kelloggii, and Quercus species; Sierra Nevada and Klamath-Siskiyou mountains and foothills; April, June, August, December, (Southworth(2) with Latin italicized), associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), (Trappe)

Balsamia cascadensis.nameOrigin: named "for the Cascade Range in southern Oregon"
Balsamia cascadensis.habitat: fruiting underground under Abies concolor (White Fir), Pinus jeffreyi (Jeffrey Pine) or Quercus garryana, (Oregon White Oak), southern Oregon mountains; May and June

Balsamia filamentosa.habitat: underground "in mixed conifer-hardwood stands" with Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pinus sabiniana (Digger Pine), Pseudotsuga macrocarpa [Bigcone Douglas-fir], Pseudotsuga menziesii [Douglas-fir], Quercus douglasii (Blue Oak), Quercus kelloggii (California Black Oak), and Quercus wislizeni (Interior Live Oak) "in foothills of the Sierra Nevada and Klamath Mountains in California and in the Pinal Mountains of Arizona"; February, March, November, December

Balsamia latispora.habitat: underground under Abies grandis (Grand Fir), A. x shastensis (Shasta Red Fir), A. procera (Noble Fir), Pinus jeffreyi (Jeffrey Pine), P. ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga macrocarpa (Bigcone Douglas-fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), and Quercus kelloggii (California Black Oak), "widespread from the Sierra Nevada range in southern California through the Klamath Mountains in California and Oregon, and the central Cascade Range of Oregon and in Canada"; fruiting January, March, May, June, December

Balsamia lazyana.nameOrigin: lazyana "refers to the type locality, the Lazy A Ranch" (Southworth(2))
Balsamia lazyana.habitat: underground "under variously mixed conifer-hardwoods": Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), Arctostaphylos, Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), and Q. kelloggii (California Black Oak); collections January, February, March, October, November

Balsamia magnata.habitat: underground, commonly under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), but also in conifer-hardwood forests: Abies concolor (White Fir), Alnus (alder), Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), Pinus coulteri (Coulter pine), Pinus contorta var. contorta (Shore pine), Pinus jeffreyi (Jeffrey's Pine), Pinus muricata (Bishop pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), P. sabiniana (Digger Pine), and Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), Quercus chrysolepis (Canyon Live Oak), or Quercus kelloggii (California Black Oak), "widespread in mountains of the PNW, California, Montana and Arizona"; fruiting January, March, April, May, June, October, November, and December, (Southworth), single to usually gregarious "under various trees and shrubs (oak, pine, madrone, etc.)", (Arora), in forests (Gilkey), associated with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus, Quercus, (Trappe(13)), Pinus, Abies, Pseudotsuga, Quercus; year round (Trappe, M.(3))

Balsamia nigrans.habitat: underground under Abies concolor (White Fir), Pinus attenuata (Knobcone Pine), Pinus jeffreyi (Jeffrey's Pine), Pinus lambertiana (Sugar Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pinus sabiniana (Digger Pine), Pseudotsuga macrocarpa (Bigcone Douglas-fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus chrysolepis (Canyon Live Oak), Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), Quercus kelloggii (California Black Oak), and Quercus wislizeni (Interior Live Oak); "widespread in Sierra Nevada and Cascade Mountains and foothills"; fruiting January, March, May, June, October, December, (Southworth), underground associated with various Pinaceae spp., particularly Pinus jeffreyi (Jeffrey Pine) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), "and at low to mid elevation", (Castellano), associated with Pseudotsuga, Pinus, Quercus (oak), (Trappe(13)), associated with Pinus, Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga, Quercus, (Trappe, M.(3))

Balsamia oregonensis.habitat: single or in small groups in soil in woods, associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and possibly other trees, commonest in spring and early summer, (Arora), beneath tree of Cascara sagrada, (Gilkey(1)), with relatively young Pseudotsuga menziesii, mostly 10-60 years old; year round, but mostly late winter to late spring, (Trappe, M.(3))

Balsamia quercicola.nameOrigin: 'Quercus' (oak) and '-icola' (inhabitant) signifying an inhabitant of oak woodlands
Balsamia quercicola.habitat: underground under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa pine), P. sabiniana (Digger Pine), Quercus douglasii (Blue Oak), Q. garryana (Oregon White Oak), or Q. wislizeni (Interior White Oak); collections in January, March, November

Balsamia trappei.nameOrigin: "named in honor of James Martin Trappe who collected the type specimen" as well as many other Balsamia specimens in the Pacific Northwest
Balsamia trappei.habitat: underground under Abies grandis (Grand Fir) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) or with hardwoods, e.g., Alnus (alder), Populus and Salix (willow), "in the intermountain region of Idaho, Oregon, Washington, and Alberta, Canada", and in Alaska; collected July to October

Cazia flexiascus.nameOrigin: from "flexus", Latin for "crooked", and "ascus", in reference to the distinctively bent asci
Cazia flexiascus.habitat: type erumpent in a mowed lawn under an introduced Quercus (oak) species, but usual habit presumed to be underground

Chamonixia brevicolumna.habitat: under ground in spruce-fir forests, summer, (Smith(4))

Chamonixia caespitosa.habitat: underground in association with various Pinaceae spp., particularly Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir) and Tsuga sp. (hemlock) at high elevation and Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) in coastal forests; fruits June through November, (Castellano), fruitbodies develop underground and can become visible on surface when mature, (Breitenbach)

Chamonixia caudata.habitat: under oak and other hardwoods (Arora), in leaf mold of Quercus (oak), (Smith)

Choiromyces alveolatus.habitat: under soil surface associated with various Pinaceae species, particularly Abies procera (Noble Fir), other Abies, Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), and T. mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) above 1300m elevation, May through November

Choiromyces meandriformis.odour: "faint when fresh (like Tuber rufum)", (Castellano), strong and aromatic, (Dennis)
Choiromyces meandriformis.habitat: under soil surface associated with various Pinaceae species, particularly Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) at low elevation, in October, (Castellano)

Cortinomyces niveus.habitat: underground under hardwoods and conifers, May to September

Descolea albella.habitat: underground "in litter near ectomycorrhizal plants, particularly Myrtaceae", probably indigenous to Australia but now widespread throughout the world in gardens and plantations of Eucalyptus and other Myrtaceae, (Bougher), under Quercus (oak), fruiting in Oregon in October, (Dodge)

Destuntzia fusca.nameOrigin: means 'fuscous' (dark blackish brown), referring to color of spore mass
Destuntzia fusca.habitat: under soil surface associated with roots of Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tan Oak), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) below 1000m, October and December, (Castellano), underground in Tsuga-Pseudotsuga-Notholithocarpus stands in December, (Fogel)

Destuntzia rubra.nameOrigin: means "red", "possibly in reference to color of peridium in alcohol"
Destuntzia rubra.habitat: under the soil surface associated with roots of Abies grandis (Grand Fir), Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), Notholithocarpus densiflorus (Tanoak), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood), below 650 meters elevation, March to December, (Castellano), underground under Pseudotsuga menziesii, Quercus (oak), and Notholithocarpus, from December to July, (Fogel), mycorrhizal host Pseudotsuga (Trappe)

Destuntzia subborealis.habitat: in hemlock-cedar forests, (Smith(4)), in duff in Tsuga-Thuja association, (Smith(27))

Elaphomyces 'anthracinus'.habitat: under the soil surface associated with roots of Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine) in Oregon and with roots of assorted Fagaceae in Europe

Elaphomyces asperulus.nameOrigin: means 'asperulate', appearing roughened with tiny points
Elaphomyces asperulus.habitat: in coniferous forests, rarely under Betula (birch), (Hansen, L.)

Elaphomyces 'granulatus'.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "granular", because of appearance of peridium, (Lincoff(1))
Elaphomyces 'granulatus'.edibility: yes according to some reports but not choice, used for centuries in Europe as aphrodisiac and truffle substitute, (Arora)
Elaphomyces 'granulatus'.odour: not very distinctive (Arora), faintly metallic (Trappe, M.(3))
Elaphomyces 'granulatus'.habitat: scattered at or several centimeters below ground, "under conifers or hardwoods, summer or fall, widely distributed", (Smith), single, scattered or gregarious "in soil or humus under conifers or less commonly hardwoods", usually 5-8cm below surface, "often embedded in or resting on clay soil at point where it meets the humus layer", (Arora), year round (Bacon)

Elaphomyces 'muricatus'.nameOrigin: means 'spiny like a murex' (a shellfish yielding a purple dye)
Elaphomyces 'muricatus'.odour: not very distinctive, (Arora), metallic, unpleasant (Trappe, M.(3))
Elaphomyces 'muricatus'.habitat: single to gregarious in soil or duff in woods, (Arora), associated with members of Pinaceae and Fagaceae (Trappe)

Elaphomyces muricatus.habitat: associated with Pinus (pine) (Trappe), in hardwood forest (Hansen, L.)

Elaphomyces subviscidus.nameOrigin: means 'subviscid': Zeller reported this species to be subviscid on the surface
Elaphomyces subviscidus.habitat: type above ground on decayed granite soil, (Trappe), underground associated with roots of Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine) and Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) at high elevation (2200 m), June and August, (Castellano), in Colorado underground in a Pinus ponderosa stand (Ponderosa Pine) with a scattered understory of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), 2135m elevation, (Fogel)

Endogone acrogena.nameOrigin: from Latin "acrogenus" (born at apices), referring to the acrogenous development of spores in rows
Endogone acrogena.habitat: epigeous [above ground], fruiting on soil surface or on mosses, from low elevations to near timberline, May, September, and October

Endogone flammicorona.nameOrigin: from Latin "flammi-" (flame) and "corona" (crown), referring to the flame-shaped projections of the spore mantle as seen in cross section
Endogone flammicorona.habitat: hypogeous [underground] or rarely subhypogeous, "in coniferous forests from coastal areas to relatively low elevations in the mountains and in seedling beds of a tree nursery"; spring, early summer, fall, and early winter; occurring among ectomycorrhizae of Pinaceae, (Gerdemann), most often found "in young stands of trees in mixed woods"; sometimes "fruits by the tens of thousands in conifer nurseries"; occurs year-round, (Trappe, M.(3))

Endogone lactiflua.nameOrigin: from Latin "lacti-" (milk) and "fluo" (flowing), referring to the latex exuded by cut surfaces of fresh young fruitbodies
Endogone lactiflua.habitat: underground, in coniferous or oak forests from sea level to subalpine zones, generally April through July but occasionally as late as November, probably ectomycorrhizal association with members of Pinaceae as well as Quercus garryana (Garry Oak)

Endogone oregonensis.habitat: underground associated with roots of Picea sitchensis (Sitka spruce), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), below 350m elevation, February, July, September, November, (Castellano), underground, in coniferous forests (Picea, Pseudotsuga, Tsuga) at elevations less than 500m, June, July, September, and November, (Gerdemann)

Endogone pisiformis.habitat: underground or above ground, in soil or humus, on coniferous litter, wood or bark of fallen trees, old fruitbodies of polypores, or on sphagnum, "in mountains up to timberline and occasionally at low elevations", fruiting after heavy rains in late summer or fall through winter, "and in spring and early summer, when it is often found under the edges of melting snowbanks"; apparently a saprophyte or mycoparasite, (Gerdemann)

Fevansia aurantiaca.nameOrigin: means "pale orange", referring to the color of the glebal trama, (Trappe)
Fevansia aurantiaca.habitat: underground under mature coniferous forests, 1000-1700 meters, probably ectomycorrhizal with Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and other species of Pinaceae, August, (Trappe), August to November (Trappe, M.(3))

Fischerula subcaulis.habitat: probably associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas fir) and other conifers, maturing in summer and fall, (Smith), in coniferous or mixed conifer-alder forests, probably mycorrhizal with Pseudotsuga menziesii, Abies procera (Noble Fir), and possibly other conifers, (Trappe(7))

Gautieria caudata.habitat: under Sequoia and Quercus in California, March to April

Gautieria gautierioides.nameOrigin: means 'like Gautieria', originating before it was in this genus (Hymenogaster gautierioides Lloyd)
Gautieria gautierioides.odour: mild when young becoming slightly garlic-like and offensive when old (States)
Gautieria gautierioides.habitat: under conifers and hardwoods, (Smith), under Acer (maple), Arbutus (madrone), Quercus (oak), and Sequoia, April to October, (Dodge), mycorrhizal with Pinaceae (Trappe)

Gautieria 'magnicellaris'.nameOrigin: means 'large celled', perhaps referring to the large spores
Gautieria 'magnicellaris'.habitat: under the soil surface associated with roots of Pinus spp. (pine) in Mexico and Abies concolor (White Fir) in western North America above 1650m elevation, July through October, (Castellano), single to gregarious, underground under Pinus (pine) in a coniferous forest and under Quercus (oak) in a mixed Quercus-Pinus forest, (Cazares)

Gautieria monticola.edibility: edible according to some, but rubbery, (Arora)
Gautieria monticola.odour: often strong when old, sometimes of decaying onions, (Arora), very strong when old, like sour milk, (Miller), sweet-oily, may become nauseating, (Trappe, M.(3))
Gautieria monticola.habitat: single, scattered or in groups or clusters, sometimes partially exposed at maturity, in duff under conifers, especially mountain conifers, late spring through early fall, (Arora), on the ground under conifers (Dodge), associated with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Pinus (pine), Abies (fir); March to November (Trappe, M.(3))

Gautieria 'morchelliformis'.edibility: eaten in Europe but not recommended because little known about edibility of similar species or of this one in North America (Lincoff(1))
Gautieria 'morchelliformis'.odour: often strong (Lincoff(2)), strongly fetid when fresh (Zeller(2) for an Oregon collection), very strong odor of bouillon cubes, (Lincoff(1))
Gautieria 'morchelliformis'.habitat: in clay soil under hardwood trees and shrubs, often in oak woods, develops underground and often emerges at maturity, (Lincoff(2)), in clay soil, under hardwood trees and shrubs, spring, summer, and fall, (Dodge)

Gautieria otthii.habitat: associated with roots of Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine) and other Pinaceae between 800m and 1650m, (Castellano), fruiting in June in Switzerland, (Dodge)

Gautieria parksiana.nameOrigin: named after H.E. Parks of the University of California
Gautieria parksiana.habitat: under hardwoods and conifers, April to June, (Smith), gregarious in soil under Heteromeles (Christmas berry), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Quercus (oak), March to June, (Dodge), with Pseudotsuga, Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock), Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Quercus; year round (Trappe, M.(3))

Gautieria plumbea.nameOrigin: probably after the color of the gleba which is "plumbeous-black"

Gautieria pterosperma.habitat: associated with Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock); April to September

Geastrum bushnellii.nameOrigin: after W. Bushnell, member of the North American Truffling Society and collector of the type
Geastrum bushnellii.habitat: underground, under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Asarum caudatum (wild ginger), at about 120m elevation, May and August, (Dominguez), probably saprophytic (Trappe)

Geastrum fuscogleba.habitat: underground under Abies concolor (White Fir), Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Alnus sp. (alder), Arbutus menziesii (Pacific Madrone), Arctostaphylos spp., Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), Corylus californica (California Hazel), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), at 70-1640m elevation, March through October, (Dominguez), fruits year-round (Trappe, M.(3)), underground or above ground in duff of coniferous forest, (Zeller), probably saprophytic (Trappe(13))

Geastrum taylorii.nameOrigin: after C. Wilder Taylor who collected the type
Geastrum taylorii.habitat: underground under Abies concolor (White Fir), Alnus sinuata (Sitka Alder), Pinus spp. (pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Quercus spp. (oak), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), and Umbellularia californica (California Bay Laurel) at 190-1870m elevation, from April to January, most often August through October, (Dominguez), underground under loose leaf mould of redwood, (Zeller), probably saprophytic (Trappe)

Genabea cerebriformis.nameOrigin: means 'with the form of a brain', from 'cerebrum' (Latin) meaning 'brain'
Genabea cerebriformis.odour: mild or strong, (Arora), pleasant, faintly garlicky, (Trappe, M.(3))
Genabea cerebriformis.habitat: underground, single to gregarious in soil or humus in woods and under trees, especially Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Arora), deciduous and coniferous woods, especially under Douglas fir, spring, (Smith), leaf mold, in hardwood woods or coniferous woods, (Gilkey), fruits only in spring in the western United States and summer in Mexico, (Castellano), with Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga, and Quercus (oak); March to October (Trappe, M.(3))

Genea arenaria.habitat: single, scattered, or in small groups in soil under trees (mainly live oak), typically November through April, (Arora), "under shrubs" (Gilkey from Harkness)

Genea gardneri.habitat: with Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Quercus (oak), January to September, (Trappe, M.), under oaks (Gilkey)

Genea harknessii.nameOrigin: means "of Harkness", for H.W. Harkness, pioneer 19th Century truffle taxonomist, (Trappe, M.(1))
Genea harknessii.habitat: single to gregarious in humus or soil under oak, manzanita, Baccharis (coyote bush), and other trees and shrubs, (Arora), with leaf mold under trees and shrubs (Gilkey), associated with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Quercus (oak), (Trappe, M.(3))

Geopora cooperi.nameOrigin: means "of Cooper", for J.G. Cooper, who made the first collections of the species in California in the early 1880s, (Trappe, M.(1))
Geopora cooperi.odour: usually mild, but in one form like fermented cider, (Arora), faintly aromatic (Trudell), mild to radish-like or garlicky (Trappe, M.(3))
Geopora cooperi.habitat: single, scattered, or gregarious on or in ground under hardwoods and especially conifers, spring, summer, and fall, in Alaska has been found under willow and aspen, (Arora), summer and fall, (Smith), with Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies (fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Larix (larch), Salix (willow), (Trappe, M.(3))

Gilkeya compacta.nameOrigin: "compacta" means "compressed or compacted together", possibly referring to the tendency of fruitbodies to form in groups, (Smith, M.E.)
Gilkeya compacta.habitat: single to gregarious; underground in soil in woods, (Arora), leaf mold, (Gilkey), February to August, mostly April to June, (Trappe, M.(3)), associated with Quercus (oak), Abies (fir), Pinus (pine), and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) in pure or mixed stands, March through August, but mostly May and June, (Smith, M.E.)

Glomus caledonium.nameOrigin: means "pertaining to Scotland", where type was found
Glomus caledonium.habitat: in soil in fields, parks, orchards, and forests, probably occurring throughout the year, (Gerdemann), forms arbuscular mycorrhizae with many plants (Trappe(13))

Glomus convolutum.nameOrigin: means "convolute", referring to the form of the fruiting body
Glomus convolutum.habitat: underground or on ground, on soil or conifer needles and rotted wood near melting snowbanks, June to August, Gerdemann(1), probably saprobic rather than mycorrhizal (Trappe(13))

Glomus fasciculatum.habitat: underground: in dunes, cultivated fields, meadows, orchards, and forests, greenhouses (where sometimes on top of soil), collected most commonly in November through February in the field, (Gerdemann), forms arbuscular mycorrhizae with many plants (Trappe(13))

Glomus halonatum.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "haloed": "in transmitted light in optical cross section, hyaline outer spore wall appears as a bright ring around the spore", (Rose)
Glomus halonatum.habitat: under Ceanothus velutinus in arid volcanic soils in Oregon, with roadside grasses in grasslands in Mexico, under Hippophae rhamnoides (sea-buckthorn) in sand dunes in United Kingdom; associated in the field with vesicular-arbuscular mycorrhizae of Ceanothus velutinus and Hippophae rhamnoides

Glomus lacteum.nameOrigin: from Latin, "milk-white", referring to the opaque milky appearance of the spores under incident light, (Rose)
Glomus lacteum.habitat: in arid, volcanic soil in edaphically stressed sites; associated in the field with vesicular-arbuscular mycorrhizae of Ceanothus velutinus and of Purshia tridentata (antelope-brush)

Glomus macrocarpum.habitat: in soil in forests, meadows, fields, orchards, and greenhouses, throughout the year, (Gerdemann)

Glomus microcarpum.habitat: in soil in fields, orchards, and forests; collected May to November in the field, (Gerdemann), year round (Trappe, M.(3))

Glomus monosporum.habitat: forests, fields, and greenhouses, August through March in the field

Glomus mosseae.nameOrigin: in honor of Dr. Barbara Mosse, the discoverer of the species
Glomus mosseae.habitat: underground, "from coastal dune sands to mountain forests and semi-arid zones; especially common in alkaline flats, fields, roadbanks, and forest clearings", collected throughout the year

Glomus occultum.nameOrigin: from Latin "occultum" meaning "hidden", "referring to the obscurity of the spores caused by their small size, angular shape, and lack of coloration"
Glomus occultum.habitat: borne singly or in loose clusters in the soil, or in compact clusters in the cortex of roots; associated with the roots of various plants, forms vesicular-arbuscular mycorrhizae in pot culture

Glomus pubescens.habitat: two collections growing on rotten hardwood sticks, May and June

Glomus radiatum.nameOrigin: means "radiate", referring to the radiate arrangement of spores from the sporocarp base (Gerdemann)
Glomus radiatum.habitat: associated with roots of Chamaecyparis nootkatensis (Alaska yellow-cedar) and Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood) below 1650m elevation (Castellano), underground, "in the Pacific Northwest from wet mountain soils (stream banks and hummocks in a boggy, montane meadow)", October and November, (Gerdemann)

Glomus rubiforme.nameOrigin: means "having the form of Rubus", referring to the resemblance of the sporocarp to a miniature blackberry
Glomus rubiforme.habitat: in soil in fields, orchards, meadows, beach dune sands, throughout the year, (Gerdemann)

Glomus vesiculiferum.habitat: type on soil surface of potted Philodendron in greenhouse

Hydnangium carneum.edibility: fair (Lincoff, but note history of nomenclatural confusion)
Hydnangium carneum.habitat: introduced from Australia as a mycorrhizal associate of Eucalyptus spp., (Castellano), widespread in all warm temperate areas or in greenhouses, beneath various hardwoods, but associated essentially with eucalyptus; in warm climates in winter and spring under leaf litter, (Lincoff), November to May (Trappe, M.(3)), all year (Buczacki)

Hydnobolites californicus.habitat: under trees (Gilkey), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), (Trappe)

Hydnotrya cerebriformis.nameOrigin: means 'with the form of a brain', from 'cerebrum' (Latin) meaning 'brain'
Hydnotrya cerebriformis.odour: typically strong garlic odor when mature (Arora), somewhat garlic-like, but pungent, (Trudell)
Hydnotrya cerebriformis.habitat: often inside rotten wood, (Arora), leaf mold (Gilkey), in montane conifer forests (Trudell)

Hydnotrya cubispora.habitat: in mixed woods (Smith), sandy soil and leaf mold in mixed woods (Gilkey), usually terrestrial (Arora), with Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce); March to November (Trappe, M.(3))

Hydnotrya inordinata.nameOrigin: means "disorderly" in reference to the spore ornamentation, (Trappe)
Hydnotrya inordinata.habitat: usually associated with roots of Abies amabilis, Pinus contorta, Pseudotsuga menziesii, and Tsuga heterophylla from 1100m to 2000m elevation, March, April, July, (Castellano), underground under mature Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir) and Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) at about 1800m elevation, July, (Trappe)

Hydnotrya subnix.nameOrigin: means "under snow", in reference to the occurrence of the type under a melting snow bank in spring, (Trappe)
Hydnotrya subnix.habitat: usually in association with roots of Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir) at 1000m elevation, June, (Castellano), subhypogeous [partly underground] under a small, receding, icy snow bank +/- 10cm thick, near Abies amabilis, about 950m elevation, June, (Trappe(2))

Hydnotrya tulasnei.nameOrigin: "in honor of the pioneering nineteenth-century French truffle taxonomists, the brothers Rene and Charles Tulasne (Rene wrote the species descriptions; Charles painted beautifully detailed illustrations of them)" (Trappe, M.(3), acute accent on second e in Rene)
Hydnotrya tulasnei.edibility: avoid alcohol beverages when eating this species (Trappe, M.(3))
Hydnotrya tulasnei.odour: odoriferous when mature (Arora), musty (Dennis), faintly pungent to garlicky when young, becoming musty and unpleasant when old, (Trappe, M.(3))
Hydnotrya tulasnei.habitat: developed in the surface layers of woodland soils, both coniferous and hardwood, (Dennis), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) (Trappe(13)), with Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga, Tsuga (hemlock), (Trappe, M.(3))

Hydnotrya variiformis.nameOrigin: from Latin "vari-" meaning "variable" and "-formis" meaning "form", for its highly variable shaped, (Trappe, M.(1))
Hydnotrya variiformis.taste: not distinctive (Trappe, M.(3) for var. pallida)
Hydnotrya variiformis.odour: not distinctive (Trappe, M.(3) for var. pallida)
Hydnotrya variiformis.habitat: single or in groups in soil or inside very rotten wood under conifers in Sierra Nevada, Cascades, and other western mountains, (Arora), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Pinus (pine), and Abies (fir), "often in well-decomposed wood and other organic materials on the forest floor"; May to October, (Trappe, M.(3) for var. pallida)

Hydnotryopsis setchellii.habitat: underground, single or scattered, "buried in duff or soil", "from a number of different habitats, and most have oaks ... as the dominant tree species", can also develop in conifer forest such as spruce or fir; fruiting in spring and summer, (Siegel)

Hymenogaster alnicola.habitat: type collection underground under alder in July, (Smith(27)), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Alnus (alder), (Trappe)

Hymenogaster boozeri.nameOrigin: after L.M. Boozer, who found the type
Hymenogaster boozeri.odour: of fresh specimens cheese-like (Smith(4)), odor "like cheese (fermentation)", (Dodge)
Hymenogaster boozeri.habitat: mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Corylus (hazel), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe), under Quercus (oak), April, (Smith(4))

Hymenogaster farinaceus.habitat: under hardwoods (oak, maple, and basswood mixed) with pine and hemlock nearby, July, (Smith(4) for MI), gregarious and emergent on a roadway, "trees within 100 ft. of the spot where the specimens were found were one oak, two beeches, three maples, with hemlock and pine some distance away", (Smith(27))

Hymenogaster gardneri.nameOrigin: after N.L. Gardner, who found the type, (Dodge)
Hymenogaster gardneri.habitat: in clay soil under oak (Smith(4) for CA), in clay soil under Quercus (oak) and Salix (willow), March, (Dodge)

Hymenogaster gilkeyae.nameOrigin: after H.M. Gilkey, who made one of the early collections
Hymenogaster gilkeyae.habitat: mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe), in mixed woods and under Aesculus and Quercus, November to April, (Dodge)

Hymenogaster glacialis.nameOrigin: Latin 'icy, frozen', referring to the Lyman Glacier where the type was found
Hymenogaster glacialis.habitat: underground under stones in wet area among dwarf Salix roots in raw moraine

Hymenogaster griseus.nameOrigin: means 'gray', referring probably to the color of the spore mass
Hymenogaster griseus.odour: of Convallaria majalis (European lily of the valley) (Dodge), lily-of-the-valley (Buczacki)
Hymenogaster griseus.habitat: under Populus, Quercus (oak), and Fagus (beech), (Dodge), underground or at soil surface in organic soil on alkaline sites, with hardwoods, especially Fagus (beech), or with conifers; usually in large groups; summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Hymenogaster idahoensis.habitat: in spruce-fir forests, (Smith(4)), type single under spruce-fir, August, (Smith(27))

Hymenogaster occidentalis.habitat: under Quercus (oak) and conifers, March to May, (Smith(4)), scattered through loose moist soil, under Quercus (oak) and Abies (fir), (Dodge), mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Quercus (Trappe)

Hymenogaster olivaceus.habitat: underground under hardwoods or conifers, April to January (Dodge), underground or at soil surface in organic soil, usually in large groups; usually in hardwood woodland with Fagus (beech), Quercus (oak), and Tilia (lime), rarely with conifers; late summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Hymenogaster parksii.nameOrigin: named after H.E. Parks, who found the type
Hymenogaster parksii.habitat: scattered just under leaves and through the soil about 5cm deep, under Quercus (oak) and Heteromeles arbutifolia (Christmasberry), November to April, (Dodge for California)

Hymenogaster subalpinus.odour: strongly of mushrooms and pungent when old, (States), unpleasant (Trappe, M.(3))
Hymenogaster subalpinus.habitat: in duff under cedar-hemlock, (Smith(27)), associated with Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), and in pine stands mixed with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Quercus gambelii (Gambel Oak), (States), with Pseudotsuga menziesii at low to middle elevations, October to March, (Trappe, M.(3))

Hysterangium aureum.nameOrigin: means 'golden', presumably referring to the golden-brownish color of the fruitbody
Hysterangium aureum.habitat: under Acer circinatum (Vine Maple) and conifers

Hysterangium coriaceum.habitat: under Betula (birch), Corylus (hazel) and Fagus silvatica (European beech) in Germany, (Zeller), in the Pacific Northwest with a broad spectrum of hosts, (Trappe)

Hysterangium crassirhachis.nameOrigin: from Latin "crassi-" meaning "thick" and "-rachis" meaning "spine", for the thick columella in the spore mass, (Trappe, M.(1))
Hysterangium crassirhachis.odour: "mild to slightly fruity or pungent" (Trappe, M.(3))
Hysterangium crassirhachis.habitat: under Quercus (oak) and Acer (maple), May, (Zeller), with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), Abies (fir), Larix (larch); year round, (Trappe, M.(3))

Hysterangium occidentale.odour: when mature, nearly odorless or with pleasant odor of some species of Polyporus, (Zeller), absent or pleasant (Trappe, M.(3))
Hysterangium occidentale.habitat: under Quercus (oak), spring and early summer, (Zeller), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), and Quercus (oak), at low elevations, April to October, but mostly spring, (Trappe, M.(3)), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Quercus and Pinaceae (Trappe)

Hysterangium separabile.nameOrigin: from Latin "coriaceum" meaning "leathery" for the tough texture, (Trappe, M.(1))
Hysterangium separabile.edibility: "Although it has little odor or flavor, its chewy texture provides an interesting additive to omelettes or scrambled eggs", (Trappe, M.(1))
Hysterangium separabile.odour: offensive at maturity (Zeller(8)), "mild to faintly fruity or sometimes of iodine", (Trappe, M.(3))
Hysterangium separabile.habitat: single to gregarious "in humus or soil (usually buried) under both hardwoods and conifers", common late spring through fall, (Arora), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), and Larix (larch), year round but mostly in spring, (Trappe, M.(1)), gregarious under both conifers and hardwoods, (Smith), underground under conifers and hardwood trees and shrubs, (Zeller), mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Quercus (Trappe(13))

Hysterangium setchellii.habitat: mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest trees in Pinaceae (Trappe), in duff under Quercus densifolia (Zeller)

Kalapuya brunnea.nameOrigin: means "brown", referring to the brown peridium, (Trappe, M.(4))
Kalapuya brunnea.odour: mildly garlicky-cheesy, the odor reminiscent of mature Camembert, (Trappe, M.(4)), can be strongly garlicky, (Trappe, M.(3))
Kalapuya brunnea.habitat: underground under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) up to about 50 years old in the top 2-10cm of mineral soil, beneath scant litter layers from near sea level to about 500 m, fruiting October to March but occasionally as early as September and as late as July, (Trappe, M.(4))

Lactarius lactarioides.habitat: underground associated with various Pinaceae spp., particularly Abies magnifica and Pinus ponderosa above 1650m elevation, July through November, (Castellano), in fir woods below timberline (7500 feet), (Zeller), associated with Abies (Trappe)

Lactarius rubriviridis.nameOrigin: refers to the red and green colors
Lactarius rubriviridis.habitat: underground, single or scattered, "buried under duff", ectomycorrhizal with Pinaceae, known locations have both Pinus (pine) and Abies (true fir); both California collections in disturbed areas (campgrounds); fruiting is spring

Lactarius southworthiae.nameOrigin: named "in honor of Dr. Darlene Southworth for her work on truffles, oaks and mycorrhizal ecology in southern Oregon"

Leccinum pachyderme.habitat: under leaves or on the ground under Alnus (alder), Eucalyptus, and Fagus (beech), November to April

Lepiota geophana.nameOrigin: means 'with small spores' (in comparison to those of C. americana)
Lepiota geophana.habitat: underground; under Pinus contorta in one location and Cercocarpus in another location

Lepiota viridigleba.nameOrigin: "viridigleba" refers to the green gleba (spore mass)
Lepiota viridigleba.habitat: type hypogeous [underground] under Populus spp. (Castellano), found in mixed forests of conifers and Populus (Trappe(13))

Leucangium carthusianum.nameOrigin: means "Carthusian", "for the Carthusian monastery in France where the species was first found", (Trappe, M.(1))
Leucangium carthusianum.odour: fungoid, pungent, or slightly garlic-like, (Miller), "strong pungent fruity (often like pineapple)" when mature, (Trudell), pleasant and fruity (most often resembling pineapple) when young, becoming increasingly pungent and earthy when old, (Trappe, M.(3))
Leucangium carthusianum.habitat: under Douglas fir, fall and winter, (Smith), single, scattered or in small groups in soil and humus in woods, (Arora), several to many, in soil under conifers or oaks; early spring and summer (Miller), with relatively young Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), often 10-25cm deep in the soil; September to February, (Trappe, M.)

Leucogaster candidus.habitat: June in California, (Zeller), associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Leucogaster citrinus.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to the citron [a lemon-like fruit]', probably in reference to its surface color
Leucogaster citrinus.habitat: found in association with the roots of Abies concolor (White Fir), A. lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), from 280 to 2000m elevation, August through November, (Castellano), under manzanita and laurel, April, (Zeller), with Pseudotsuga, Tsuga, Pinus, Abies, June to November, (Trappe, M.(3))

Leucogaster microsporus.habitat: found in association with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) at 330-1000m elevation, August through November

Leucogaster odoratus.habitat: mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Quercus (oak), (Trappe), June to July in California (Zeller)

Leucogaster rubescens.odour: mild but pleasant, when mature may develop a coconut odor, (Trappe, M.(3)), not distinctive (Phillips)
Leucogaster rubescens.habitat: in duff and humus, spring, (Smith), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest trees in Pinaceae (Trappe(13)), in leaf mold under maple (Zeller for type), partly or entirely underground, in soil and leaf litter, April to June, (Phillips), associated with Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), (States), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), May to December, (Trappe, M.(3))

Leucophleps levispora.habitat: type from California underground under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa pine), December

Leucophleps magnata.odour: on drying astringent, also referred to as acrid, (Fogel)
Leucophleps magnata.habitat: underground in stands of Abies (fir) and Tsuga (hemlock) "in western Oregon and Washington from June to October", and low-elevation second growth stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) "from April to May in western Oregon and December in northern California", specific mycorrhizal associates probably being Pseudotsuga and Abies, (Fogel)

Leucophleps spinispora.odour: "slight to acrid on drying", said to be similar in odor to Leucophleps magnata whose odor is described as astringent, (Fogel), little odor when fresh, "but dried specimens develop an odor of celery salt", (Trappe, M.(3))
Leucophleps spinispora.habitat: underground in coniferous forests of Picea (spruce), Larix (larch), Abies (fir), and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), June to December, (specific mycorrhizal associate probably Abies or infrequently Pseudotsuga menziesii), (Fogel), single to gregarious "in soil or duff (usually buried) under western conifers", (Arora), with Pseudotsuga, Tsuga (hemlock), Pinus (pine), Abies, June to December, (Trappe, M.(3))

Melanogaster 'ambiguus'.nameOrigin: means 'changeable, uncertain, doubtful, of double meaning'
Melanogaster 'ambiguus'.odour: strongly metallic and disagreeable (States), "faint, indefinite, then sweet, then foul, foetid, rotting onions, rubber", (Buczacki)
Melanogaster 'ambiguus'.habitat: under hardwoods, April to October, (Zeller(12)), found once associated with a mixed stand of Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) beneath a thick layer of duff in September, (States for Arizona), broad spectrum of hosts in the Pacific Northwest (Trappe), at soil surface on organic or sandy soil in woodland, usually with oak or beech, fall, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Melanogaster broomeanus.nameOrigin: probably after Christopher Edmund Broome, with whom Berkeley co-authored many publications
Melanogaster broomeanus.odour: of coffee grounds (Zeller), "faint, sweet, fruity, pleasant", (Buczacki)
Melanogaster broomeanus.habitat: under hardwoods, July to February, (Zeller), single or in small to large groups, shallowly underground or at soil surface "on organic soil and among litter in woodland on alkaline sites"; summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Melanogaster euryspermus.nameOrigin: means 'with wide spores', from 'eurys' = wide (Greek), or 'with widespread spores'
Melanogaster euryspermus.odour: usually strong when old, "sometimes like sewer gas, at other times with a pleasant citrus component", (Arora), distinctive odor of Rhenish wine (Zeller(12)), pronounced when mature, and disagreeable (States)
Melanogaster euryspermus.habitat: single, widely scattered, or in small groups in duff or soil both under hardwoods and under conifers, (Arora), in strawberry patch, March to April, (Zeller(12)), beneath litter of Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine) and in the mineral soil up to 10cm deep, July and September, (States for Arizona), in the Pacific Northwest mycorrhizal with a broad spectrum of hosts, (Trappe)

Melanogaster intermedius.habitat: under hardwoods (Zeller), associated with trees in family Pinaceae (Trappe), shallowly underground or at soil surface "on organic soil and among litter in woodland on alkaline sites"; fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)

Melanogaster macrocarpus.nameOrigin: means 'with large fruit', presumably referring to the large size of the fruitbody
Melanogaster macrocarpus.odour: "of spoiled silage or of onions without the tear-producing qualities"
Melanogaster macrocarpus.habitat: in forest duff under conifers, especially Tsuga (hemlock), August to October

Melanogaster 'tuberiformis'.nameOrigin: from Latin 'tuber', meaning 'swelling' or 'bulb', and 'forma' meaning 'shape', hence 'bulb-shaped', or 'shaped like a truffle (Tuber)'
Melanogaster 'tuberiformis'.odour: musty and disagreeable, (States), "oily-metallic with a touch of garlic", (Trappe, M.(3))
Melanogaster 'tuberiformis'.habitat: associated with roots of Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), embedded in mineral soil up to 6cm "but occasionally in humus beneath a deep litter layer", spring and fall, (States), under Pinus (pine), Quercus (oak), Erica, (Zeller), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus, Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), Abies (fir), year round, (Trappe, M.(3)), in the Pacific Northwest mycorrhizal with a broad spectrum of hosts (Trappe(13))

Melanogaster variegatus.habitat: under Quercus (oak) and Cistus monspeliensis (Montpelier rock rose); August to December, (Zeller), in the Pacific Northwest with a broad spectrum of hosts (Trappe)

Modicella malleola.nameOrigin: from Latin "malleolus" (a small mallet): "Harkness's intent in use of this epithet is unknown, but it possibly refers to the sporangia with attached hyphae, which in his illustration could be thought to appear mallet-like", (Gerdemann)
Modicella malleola.odour: distinctly of onions when fresh (perceptible when kept moist for a while in a closed container)
Modicella malleola.habitat: above ground on bark or among mosses or underground under moss or litter, in stands of Quercus (oak), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Sequoia, or mixed forests, mostly collected in April and May, but also found in November; mycorrhizal associations unknown, "but often fruiting in the complete absence of endomycorrhizal hosts"

Mycolevis siccigleba.taste: similar to odor but slight, (Smith(31)), similar to odor but less intense (Fogel)
Mycolevis siccigleba.odour: subspermatic as in Inocybe (nauseous), (Smith(31)), fruity to nauseous (Fogel)
Mycolevis siccigleba.habitat: in duff under conifers, late spring to late fall, (Smith(4)), may be an ectomycorrhizal associate of Abies (fir) spp. and perhaps Picea (spruce) spp., May to November, all but one collection examined were from montane or subalpine coniferous forests, one lowland coastal record, (Fogel)

Octaviania cyanescens.habitat: mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest Tsuga (hemlock) and trees in Fagaceae, (Trappe(13)), type was underground under and possibly ectomycorrhizal with Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) at 1900m elevation, September, (Trappe(2))

Octaviania macrospora.habitat: under hemlock, August, (Singer), found in association with the roots of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), August, (Castellano)

Pachyphlodes austro-oregonensis.nameOrigin: "austro-" means "southern", and "oregonensis" means "from Oregon", referring to the fact that type "was collected in southern Oregon with the support of Southern Oregon University", and additionally "the interior morphology of folded golden hymenia mirrors the landscape of southern Oregon with its golden dry hills"
Pachyphlodes austro-oregonensis.habitat: below leaf litter in top 2-5cm of mineral soil, associated with Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), fruiting May to June

Pachyphloeus citrinus.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to the citron [a lemon-like fruit]', probably in reference to its surface color
Pachyphloeus citrinus.odour: when mature, sometimes pungent, according to Herb Saylor "like rotting weeds", after collecting, at other times mild, (Arora), unpleasant (Dennis)
Pachyphloeus citrinus.habitat: single to gregarious in soil under hardwoods and under conifers, (Arora), in woods (Smith), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest Quercus (oak), Notholithocarpus, (Trappe)

Pachyphloeus thysellii.nameOrigin: named "in honor of the collector of the type specimen, David Thysell, a research botanist in the USDA Forest Service and cooperator on the Forest Ecosystem Project at Fort Lewis"
Pachyphloeus thysellii.habitat: underground in 55-65 year-old thinned stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) on glacial till, August

Paurocotylis bynumii.nameOrigin: "in honor of Otis Bynum, the collector of the holotype and most of the paratypes", (Trappe)
Paurocotylis bynumii.habitat: underground, a probable mycorrhizal associate with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Corylus cornuta var. californica (California hazel), April through August

Peziza ellipsospora.habitat: under shrubs and trees (Gilkey(3)), Oregon collection under leaves of Quercus (oak) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), in March, (Zeller(2)), associated with Quercus (Trappe(13))

Peziza infossa.odour: "fungoid to strong, sweet, phenolic or dimethyl sulfide-like", (Fogel), often phenolic or chemical (Trappe, M.)
Peziza infossa.habitat: underground under Quercus turbinella (Shrub Live Oak) and Quercus gambelii (Gambel's Oak) in Utah, May to late June, (Fogel), with Quercus in woodlands and scrub chaparral; March to July, (Trappe, M.)

Peziza stuntzii.nameOrigin: in honor of Dr. Daniel E. Stuntz of the University of Washington
Peziza stuntzii.habitat: type collection underground in mixed woods of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), elevation about 550m, (Trappe)

Phlegmacium sublilacinum.odour: "slight, fungoid, occasionally aromatic (resin or varnish), becoming farinaceous", (Fogel), mild to sweetly fragrant (as in Cortinarius foetidus), (Smith(27)), "variable, intense, generally farinaceous, resinaceous or herbaceous, sometimes fruity", (Vidal), "variable (mild, sweetish, farinaceous etc.)", (Arora)
Phlegmacium sublilacinum.habitat: single to gregarious "in soil or duff under mountain conifers especially fir, spruce, and lodgepole or ponderosa pine", (Arora), probably mycorrhizal hosts Abies concolor (White Fir), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce), Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), Pinus aristata (Bristlecone Pine), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine); May to August in the Cascades of Oregon, July in the Olympic Mountains of Washington, (Fogel), cespitose about 4 inches deep in duff of Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce) in ID (Smith(27)), ripening in spring and summer after snowmelt, March to July in Europe, June to August in North America, "following the altitude and the latitude", (Vidal)

Protogautieria lutea.habitat: type collection single under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Larix (larch), early July

Rhizopogon abietis.nameOrigin: means 'of true fir [Abies]', referring to the type collection near fir trees
Rhizopogon abietis.odour: "faint, fungal-fruity when young, distinctly of road tar in age", (Miller)
Rhizopogon abietis.habitat: in duff under alpine fir with some spruce present, summer, (Smith(4)), gregarious in duff under Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), summer, (Smith(30)), associated with 2-needle and 3-needle pines in southeastern United States, but reported with Tsuga (hemlock), Abies, and Picea from western states, (Miller)

Rhizopogon albidus.nameOrigin: refers to the white color of the surface
Rhizopogon albidus.habitat: under alpine fir and Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), (Smith(4)), under Pinus albicaulis and Abies (spruce), August, (Smith(30)), with Pinus, Abies, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga (hemlock), usually at higher elevations, July to October, (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon albiroseus.nameOrigin: refers to the white surface that becomes red when bruised
Rhizopogon albiroseus.habitat: under alpine fir, (Smith(4)), cespitose-gregarious [clustered-gregarious] in a road through Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), 5000 feet elevation, July, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon alexsmithii.nameOrigin: after A.H. Smith, North American mycologist
Rhizopogon alexsmithii.habitat: underground associated with various Pinaceae spp., particularly Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) and Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) from 1200m to 3200m elevation, August to December, (Castellano), mycorrhizal with Tsuga (Trappe(11))

Rhizopogon alkalivirens.nameOrigin: means 'green with alkali', referring to KOH reaction

Rhizopogon anomalus.nameOrigin: means 'anomalous, deviating from the regular rule'

Rhizopogon arctyostaphyli.nameOrigin: refers to one of its mycorrhizal hosts, Arctostaphylos
Rhizopogon arctyostaphyli.habitat: mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Arbutus, Arctostaphylos, (Trappe)

Rhizopogon argillaceus.nameOrigin: means 'clay-like', referring to color of surface
Rhizopogon argillaceus.habitat: in duff under conifers (Smith(4)), gregarious under spruce, (Smith(30) for type from ID)

Rhizopogon argillascens.nameOrigin: means 'becoming clay-like' referring to the color of the surface when the fruitbody is dried
Rhizopogon argillascens.habitat: under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), (Smith(4)), gregarious under Pinus contorta, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon ater.odour: "not distinctive or sometimes sweet or onion-like"
Rhizopogon ater.habitat: single to gregarious associated with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Grubisha), with Pseudotsuga in moist forests, September to January, (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon atroviolaceus.habitat: under pine, spruce and fir mixed, summer and fall, (Smith(4)), underground to emergent, scattered to grouped, associated with Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga (hemlock), May through December, (Castellano), moderate to high elevations (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon avellaneitectus.habitat: scattered to single along old roads under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), some Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) present in the area

Rhizopogon bacillisporus.nameOrigin: means 'with spores shaped like rod or small stick'
Rhizopogon bacillisporus.habitat: alpine, under alpine fir, (Smith(4)), associated with Pinaceae (Trappe(13))

Rhizopogon brunneifibrillosus.habitat: single in duff under mixed conifers, (Smith(30) for type), summer and fall, (Smith(4)), mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon brunneiniger.odour: not distinctive (Smith(30) from Trappe's notes), mild, "almost fruity" to cheesy, (Trappe, M.(3))
Rhizopogon brunneiniger.habitat: under Alnus (alder) and Tsuga (hemlock) (Smith(30)), found in association with roots of Pinaceae including Abies concolor (White Fir), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), P. monticola (Western White Pine), P. muricata (Bishop Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), and T. mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), from sea level to 2350m elevation, September and October, (Castellano), April to November, (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon butyraceus.habitat: type in duff near Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Smith), associated with Pseudotsuga and Pinus (pine), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon canadensis.habitat: under conifers, (Smith), type collected in August, (Harrison)

Rhizopogon chamaleontinus.habitat: found in association with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and scattered Pinus lambertiana (Sugar Pine) at 1100m elevation in Oregon, has fruited in June and September, (Castellano), under conifers (Smith(4)), mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Trappe)

Rhizopogon cinerascens.habitat: under conifers, summer, (Smith(4)), in duff under mixed conifers, July, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon clavitisporus.nameOrigin: refers to clavate shape of spores
Rhizopogon clavitisporus.habitat: under conifers, mostly Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), (Smith(4)), in duff under conifers, July in Idaho and November in Oregon, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon colossus.habitat: cespitose-gregarious [clustered-gregarious] under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), (Smith(4)), type cespitose-gregarious in an old corral under Pinus contorta, (Smith(30)), confirmed ectomycorrhizal association with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Molina & Trappe (1994) as mentioned in Martin, M.P.(2))

Rhizopogon columbianus.nameOrigin: means 'from Columbia', likely referring to British Columbia
Rhizopogon columbianus.habitat: collection under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), summer, (Smith), under Larix (larch), Pseudotsuga menziesii, and Pinus ponderosa, July, (Harrison)

Rhizopogon cusickiensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Cusick (Washington)' where type was found

Rhizopogon cylindrisporus.habitat: type in duff, October, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest trees in Pinaceae (Trappe)

Rhizopogon deceptivus.habitat: gregarious in duff under conifers, summer, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon ellenae.nameOrigin: in honor of Ellen Trueblood of Nampa, Idaho, who found the type
Rhizopogon ellenae.habitat: under mixed conifers, (Smith(4)), scattered or in groups or clusters in soil or needle duff under conifers, particularly pine, September to November, (Phillips), scattered in duff under conifers, late summer and fall, (Smith(30)), often breaking through the ground, (Arora), with Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies (fir), and Arbutus (madrone), year-round, (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon ellipsosporus.nameOrigin: refers to "ellipsoid" shape of spores, in reference to the relatively broad spores compared to other Rhizopogon species
Rhizopogon ellipsosporus.habitat: associated with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii, (Douglas-fir) and scattered Pinus lambertiana (Sugar Pine) at 850m elevation, (Castellano)

Rhizopogon evadens.nameOrigin: from "evadens", Latin for "escaping", "going out", possibly because fruitbodies of this fungus are frequently erumpent, (Miller, S.L.), "subalpinus" means "subalpine" (on higher mountain slopes just below timberline)
Rhizopogon evadens.habitat: under Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), (Smith(30)), usually found in association with roots of Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) or Abies spp. (fir) from 1250m to 2350m elevation, August through October, (Castellano)

Rhizopogon exiguus.habitat: in heavy duff under hemlock, (Smith(30)), found in association with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii and Tsuga heterophylla at 950m elevation, (Castellano)

Rhizopogon fallax.habitat: under Pinus contorta, August and September

Rhizopogon flavofibrillosus.habitat: under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), July, (Smith(4)), associated with roots of various conifers from 950m to 2350m elevation, July through November, (Castellano)

Rhizopogon florencianus.nameOrigin: refers to Florence, Oregon, where type was found

Rhizopogon fragrans.habitat: under spruce and fir, (Smith(4)), in duff under conifers (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon fuscorubens.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "dark brown and reddening", "referring to the abundant dark brown rhizomorphs, and the reddish brown color often found in the peridium of older and dried basidiocarps", (Miller)
Rhizopogon fuscorubens.odour: absent to faintly metallic (Miller), musty (Trappe, M.(3))
Rhizopogon fuscorubens.habitat: underground or erumpent in forests, usually under a deep litter layer, associated with 2-needle and 3-needle pines, October to December, (Miller), unknown (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal in the Pacific Northwest with Pinus (pine), (Trappe), with Pinus, usually on sandy soils, July to February, (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon griseogleba.habitat: dug from ashes of an old campfire, under Picea (spruce), (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon griseovinaceus.habitat: under conifers (Smith(4)), mycorrhizal in the Pacific Northwest with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon hawkerae.nameOrigin: after Lilian Hawker who found the type
Rhizopogon hawkerae.habitat: type collection in a very rotten log, August, (Smith(30)), associated with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir); year-round, (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon hysterangioides.nameOrigin: means 'like Hysterangium' in reference to the spores
Rhizopogon hysterangioides.habitat: in duff under spruce and fir, (Smith(4)), in duff under conifers (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon idahoensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Idaho', where type was found
Rhizopogon idahoensis.habitat: in duff under conifers in ID, July and August

Rhizopogon inquinatus.habitat: under cedar and hemlock, (Smith), found in association with roots of Pinus jeffreyi, Pseudotsuga menziesii and Tsuga heterophylla from 500 to 1400m elevation, (Castellano for Oregon), in duff in cedar-hemlock association, (Smith(30) for Idaho)

Rhizopogon isabellinus.nameOrigin: refers to the Isabella-color of the surface
Rhizopogon isabellinus.habitat: type brought to a mushroom show from near Portland Oregon

Rhizopogon kauffmanii.nameOrigin: after Calvin Henry Kauffman, 1869-1931, professor of botany Michigan

Rhizopogon libocedri.nameOrigin: means 'of Libocedrus' referring to the Incense-cedar under which the type was found
Rhizopogon libocedri.habitat: type in duff under Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), (Smith), associated with Pinaceae (Trappe)

Rhizopogon luteoalboides.habitat: under alpine pines and fir and spruce, summer, (Smith(4)), type collection underground under Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), and Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), August, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon luteoalbus.habitat: under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), summer and early fall, (Smith(4))

Rhizopogon luteoloides.habitat: type collection under Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine), (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon luteolus.nameOrigin: from Latin "lute-" meaning yellow and "-olus", a diminutive suffix, meaning "yellowish", the fruitbody color, (Trappe, M.(1))
Rhizopogon luteolus.habitat: single in duff under fir, summer, (Smith(30)), underground or at soil surface with pine, often among litter; usually in small to large groups; late summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Rhizopogon luteorubescens.habitat: in duff under conifers, July and August

Rhizopogon lutescens.habitat: gregarious in a rotten conifer log (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon masoniae.nameOrigin: names after Miss Marjorie Mason of the Oregon Mycological Society, the collector of the type
Rhizopogon masoniae.habitat: under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga (hemlock) in mixed conifer-hardwood area, (Smith(4)), type collection on humus, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon milleri.nameOrigin: after O.K. Miller, who found the type

Rhizopogon molallaensis.nameOrigin: after Molalla in Clackamas County, Oregon, where type was found
Rhizopogon molallaensis.habitat: type collection gregarious under grass near roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), 60m elevation, November, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon molligleba.habitat: gregarious under Pinus albicaulis (Whitebark Pine) and Abies (fir), August, (Smith(30)), under alpine fir and white-bark pine, (Smith(4))

Rhizopogon monticola.habitat: type underground under Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), August

Rhizopogon nitens.habitat: under conifers, (Smith(4)), type collection gregarious under moss, September, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon obscurus.habitat: gregarious under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), July, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon occidentalis.habitat: under mixed conifers (Smith(4)), single or scattered in sandy soil under mixed conifers, (Phillips), totally or partially underground, single or in groups, often in sandy soil, under conifers, especially Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), in fall, seems to be most common in coastal region, (Ammirati), with 2-needle and 3-needle pines "in the mountains and, especially, the pine woodlands on coastal dunes", (Trudell), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pinus (pine), (Trappe), September to March, (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon ochraceisporus.habitat: under fir, in duff, summer and fall, (WA and ID), (Smith), Pseudotsuga is a known mycorrhizal associate in the Pacific Northwest(Trappe)

Rhizopogon ochraceobrunnescens.habitat: type collection single in conifer duff, July, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pinus (pine), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon ochraceorubens.odour: none at first, when old acid to acid metallic at times, (Smith(30)), faint and unpleasant (States), mild (Trappe, M.(3))
Rhizopogon ochraceorubens.habitat: single to clustered in duff under pine, mostly under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), summer and fall, (Smith(30)), single to clustered under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), usually found shallowly embedded in mineral soil under deep duff, (States for AZ, but notes a report by Hosford under Ponderosa Pine in the Cascades of the Pacific Northwest), with 2-needled to 3-needled pines in mountain forests, (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon ochroleucoides.habitat: gregarious under conifers, summer and fall

Rhizopogon ochroleucus.habitat: in duff in a campground, and under conifers, late summer and fall, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in Pacific Northwest Pinus (pine), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon odoratus.odour: sweetly fragrant (Smith(4)), sweetly fragrant on cut fresh specimens (like that of drying Suillus subolivaceus), (Smith(30))
Rhizopogon odoratus.habitat: type under Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), October, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon olivaceofuscus.habitat: under mixed conifers (spruce, fir, white pine), July and August, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon olivaceoluteus.habitat: under alpine fir, (Smith(4)), in conifer duff under Abies (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon olivaceotinctus.habitat: underground, associated with various Abies (fir) species, Arbutus menziesii (Arbutus), Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Quercus kelloggii (California Black Oak), (Castellano), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Abies (fir), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon oregonensis.habitat: type collection in duff under conifers, November, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon oswaldii.nameOrigin: after Oswald, collector of the type
Rhizopogon oswaldii.odour: earthy then pungent-disagreeable, finally offensive, somewhat like spoiled garlic, (Smith(30))
Rhizopogon oswaldii.habitat: cespitose-gregarious in sandy soil under mixed conifers, fall, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon pachyspora.habitat: single to scattered, under moss-covered humus, in association with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), July and August

Rhizopogon parksii.nameOrigin: named after H.E. Parks, who collected the type
Rhizopogon parksii.taste: not distinctive (Castellano), mild to slightly garlicky or of spicy sausage, (Trappe, M.(3))
