Rhizopogon parksii.odour: fungoid to pungent (Castellano), mild to slightly garlicky or of spicy sausage, (Trappe, M.(3))
Rhizopogon parksii.habitat: common particularly under Douglas-fir and Sitka spruce along the west coast (Smith(4)), August through December, usually found in small or large groups in duff in Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) forests (Castellano), associated with Pseudotsuga, August to December, (Trappe, M.(3)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Trappe(13))

Rhizopogon pedicellus.nameOrigin: 'pedicellus' is Latin for 'small stalk' but reason for name is obscure
Rhizopogon pedicellus.habitat: with Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), often at higher elevations; June to November, (Trappe, M.), in duff under Pinus, August, (Smith)

Rhizopogon ponderosus.habitat: in duff under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine) and Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), October and November, (Smith), mycorrhizal with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon proximus.habitat: type collection under Larix (larch) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), October, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon pseudoaffinis.habitat: in clusters in the debris under Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), summer, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon pseudoroseolus.habitat: in duff under Pinus (pine), Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce), spring and summer

Rhizopogon pseudovillosulus.habitat: under spruce and fir with some larch present, (Smith(4)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe), in duff under conifers (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon quercicola.habitat: type collection in duff under Quercus muehlenbergii (Chinquapin Oak), October, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon reae.nameOrigin: after the collectors of the type, Paul and Marion Rea
Rhizopogon reae.habitat: type cespitose, superficial, on ground under oak

Rhizopogon rogersii.nameOrigin: after D. P. Rogers, who collected the type
Rhizopogon rogersii.habitat: mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe), not given in Smith(30)

Rhizopogon roseolus.habitat: in duff under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), July, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon rubescens.odour: mild to disagreeable when old, (Smith(4)), slight (Phillips), none or when old at times disagreeable, like rotten cabbage, (Smith(30)), slight, sweet-fungal when young, when old strong and distinctly of road tar, (Miller, S.L.)
Rhizopogon rubescens.habitat: single to cespitose under conifers especially 2-needle pine, summer and fall, (Smith(4)), under conifers, especially pine, July to November, (Phillips), single to cespitose [clustered] under conifers, especially 2-needle pines but not limited to this group or the genus Pinus, summer and fall, (Smith(30)), underground, erumpent, or fully exposed in soil in well-developed forested areas, associated with 2-needle and 3-needle pines, October to December, (Miller, S.L., for southeastern US)

Rhizopogon rudus.habitat: type under ground in an old logging road near Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon salebrosus.habitat: in humus under fir and pine, (Smith(30)), with Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies (fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), year-round, (Trappe, M.(3)), associated with Pinaceae (Trappe)

Rhizopogon semireticulatus.habitat: under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Larix (larch), (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest Abies (fir), Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga, (Trappe)

Rhizopogon semitectus.habitat: under cedar and hemlock (Smith(4)), under a cedar shake (Smith(28))

Rhizopogon separabilis.nameOrigin: means 'separable', probably referring to the separable peridium layer
Rhizopogon separabilis.odour: "resembling that of raw potatoes to somewhat farinaceous"
Rhizopogon separabilis.habitat: type found in summer and fall under Pinus contorta in OR

Rhizopogon sepelibilis.nameOrigin: from Latin 'sepelibilis', 'that can be buried, that can be concealed'
Rhizopogon sepelibilis.habitat: mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon sipei.nameOrigin: after Frank P. Sipe who collected the type

Rhizopogon smithii.nameOrigin: in honor of Dr. Alexander H. Smith "who has contributed so much to the taxonomy and knowledge of Rhizopogon" (Hosford, generic name italicized)
Rhizopogon smithii.habitat: single to gregarious, underground to partially exposed in sandy soil, especially in dune areas; associated with Pinus (pine), particularly Pinus contorta; fruiting in fall

Rhizopogon sordidus.nameOrigin: from Latin 'sordidus' meaning 'dirty', probably referring to the sordid or dingy color of handled or dried fruitbodies

Rhizopogon subareolatus.odour: none, but in J. Trappe's collections placed here "apparently also distinctive but variable, according to Trappe resembling fresh frankfurters, fermenting molasses, or merely pungent-fruity", (Smith(30)), mild to garlicky-pungent (Trappe, M.(3))
Rhizopogon subareolatus.habitat: type collection in duff under pine, during fall rainy season, (Smith(30)), associated with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir); fruiting year-round, (Trappe, M.(3)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Trappe(13))

Rhizopogon subbadius.habitat: type in duff under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine)

Rhizopogon subcitrinus.habitat: in groups in duff under conifers, (Smith(30)), under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), (Smith(4))

Rhizopogon subclavitisporus.habitat: in duff under mixed conifers, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon subcroceus.nameOrigin: refers to the color 'subcroceus' (somewhat saffron-colored) of the fruitbody
Rhizopogon subcroceus.habitat: gregarious under pine, July, (Smith(30)), singly or in clusters, in humus layer beneath litter of pinyon pine, (States for AZ)

Rhizopogon subgelatinosus.habitat: gregarious under mixed conifers (pine, spruce, fir), (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon sublateritius.habitat: type in arcs under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine)

Rhizopogon subolivascens.habitat: type collection in duff under conifers, July, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon subpurpurascens.habitat: under Pinus contorta (lodgepole pine) and Abies lasiocarpa (alpine fir), July and August, (Smith(30)), with Pinus, Abies, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), July to December, (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon subradicatus.habitat: type collection under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon subsalmonius.nameOrigin: from 'subsalmonius', meaning somewhat salmon in color, referring to one of the colors of the surface
Rhizopogon subsalmonius.habitat: in spruce-fir zone in the mountains of Idaho after heavy rains in August, (Smith(4)), with Abies "at moderate to high elevations, often abundant with subalpine fir at timberline", March to September, (Trappe, M.(3)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Abies (fir), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon truncatus.nameOrigin: from Latin "truncatus", meaning "cut off", referring to the truncate prominent basal scar on the spores, (Miller)
Rhizopogon truncatus.odour: slightly oily or not distinctive (Castellano), slightly oily or not distinctive (Miller)
Rhizopogon truncatus.habitat: underground to emergent, scattered to grouped associated with Pinaceae spp. especially Pinus spp. (pine), April through November, (Castellano), underground or imbedded in well-rotted conifer logs, or woody debris; on west coast associated with Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Abies spp. (fir), (Miller), moderate elevations to subalpine forests, year-round, (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon tsugae.habitat: under hemlock (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe(13))

Rhizopogon udus.habitat: under Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), (Smith(4)), in dry duff under Picea and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), summer, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon umbrinoviolascens.habitat: under Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) and Larix (larch), summer and fall, (Smith(4)), in duff hypogeous to subhypogeous under conifers, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga, (Trappe)

Rhizopogon variabilisporus.habitat: gregarious to single in duff under Picea (spruce) and Abies (fir), July and August, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon ventricosporus.nameOrigin: means 'with spores that are ventricose (wider in middle)'
Rhizopogon ventricosporus.habitat: type collection gregarious under Picea (spruce) and Pinus albicaulis (White-bark Pine), August, (Smith(30))

Rhizopogon vesiculosus.habitat: mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe), type under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), (Smith)

Rhizopogon villescens.habitat: under fir and pine in northern Idaho, July, Smith(4), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon villosulus.nameOrigin: refers to the villous surface of the fruitbody
Rhizopogon villosulus.odour: when mature "of spicy, garlicky sausage" (Trappe, M.(3))
Rhizopogon villosulus.habitat: under Picea (spruce) and Abies (fir) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), June to September, (Smith(4)), in duff under conifers, June to September, (Smith(30)), associated with Douglas-fir, fruiting year-round, (Trappe, M.(3)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe(13))

Rhizopogon vinicolor.habitat: under conifers, especially Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Smith(4)), in groups or single in duff under Pseudotsuga, July and August, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga, (Trappe(13)), fruiting year-round (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon viridis.habitat: type collection in duff under pine, (Smith(30)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Rhizopogon vulgaris.edibility: edible when immature, but too difficult to identify accurately (Lincoff for Europe)
Rhizopogon vulgaris.odour: slight (Smith(4)), slightly acid and fruity then acrid and penetrating (Lincoff), faint, like Scleroderma, or in some mature specimens strong and offensive, (Smith(30)), similar to the commercial mushroom when fresh, when old strongly of road tar, (Miller)
Rhizopogon vulgaris.habitat: under mixed conifers (Smith(4)), underground under conifers, often gregarious (Lincoff), "occurring primarily on disturbed, eroded, or less than optimal sites", associated with a variety of conifers, (in the western United States including Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), P. contorta (Lodgepole Pine), P. monticola (Western White Pine), Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain hemlock), and Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir)), July to December, (Miller), with Pinus, Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Abies, and other conifers "in young to mature stands from sea level to subalpine", year-round, (Trappe, M.(3))

Rhizopogon willamettensis.habitat: from a mixed collection brought to Annual Mushroom Show of Oregon Mycological Society from somewhere in the Willamette River Valley

Rhizopogon zelleri.nameOrigin: "dedicated to Dr. S.M. Zeller, whose work in the Pacific Northwest did much to advance our knowledge of this group of fungi"
Rhizopogon zelleri.habitat: in duff under conifers April in Oregon, July and August in Idaho, (Smith(4)), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Roesleria subterranea.habitat: on roots of commercial grapes (Redhead), single on bark, (Dennis)

Russula aromatica.odour: vanilla-like when fresh; dried collections have a fragrant odor resembling that of some species of Hydnellum, (Smith(24))
Russula aromatica.habitat: found in association with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) or Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) from 1500m to 2500m, June through November, (Castellano), type collection under alpine fir in August, (Smith(4)), single to gregarious under Abies (fir), August, (Smith(24)), under Abies (Trappe(13))

Russula dodgei.nameOrigin: "In honor of C.W. Dodge, who collaborated with S.M. Zeller in describing numerous new species of sequestrate fungi, including this taxon", (Elliott(1))
Russula dodgei.habitat: type collection in duff under oaks, March, (Singer)

Russula ellipsospora.habitat: under conifers, June to August, type under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Singer), associated with Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), (States)

Russula extramaculata.nameOrigin: 'maculatum' means 'with spots', probably referring to the spotty amyloid reaction of the spore ornamentation; 'extra-' is used to distinguish the species name from Russula maculata Quel.
Russula extramaculata.habitat: found in association with the roots of various Pinaceae spp. from sea level to high elevation, September through November, (Castellano), under Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), (Singer)

Russula ferruginascens.habitat: spruce-fir forests in ID, summer, (Smith), single to scattered under Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce) and Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), (Singer)

Russula fulvispora.nameOrigin: refers to the color of the spores as fulvous
Russula fulvispora.odour: strong, of burnt sugar, (Smith(4)), "strong odor of slightly burnt sugar", (Smith(24))
Russula fulvispora.habitat: in duff in spruce-fir forest, summer, (Smith(4)), single or gregarious under conifers, August, (Smith(24))

Russula gilkeyae.nameOrigin: after Helen Gilkey, collector of the type
Russula gilkeyae.habitat: underground under Corylus californicus (California Hazel), April and May, (Singer), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest are trees in Pinaceae (Trappe)

Russula idahoensis.habitat: single to gregarious "in duff in spruce-fir forests", summer, (Smith), single to gregarious, beneath the duff under Picea engelmannii (Engelmann spruce) and Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), (Singer), mycorrhizal host Abies (fir) (Trappe(13))

Russula marshallorum.nameOrigin: "In honor of Australian truffle-growing Marshall family for their strong support of Australasian truffle research and conservation" (Elliott, T.F.(1))
Russula marshallorum.habitat: under Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), October, (Singer), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), Abies (fir), Pinus (pine); March, June to November, (Trappe, M.(3))

Russula mattsmithii.nameOrigin: "In honor of Dr Matt Smith for his extensive research on taxonomy and ecology of sequestrate fungi" (Elliott, T.F.(1))

Russula medlockii.nameOrigin: after Bill Medlock, who collected the type
Russula medlockii.habitat: type underground under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), elevation 170m, in the laboratory forms ectomycorrhizae with Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine)

Russula monticola.habitat: under Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), August, (Singer), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest are trees in Pinaceae, (Trappe)

Russula nondistincta.nameOrigin: Latin "nondistincta" (not distinctive), "in reference to the lack of distinctive features of this species", (Trappe)
Russula nondistincta.habitat: type found under Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir) and Tsuga mertensiana (Mountain Hemlock) at 1800m elevation, September

Russula oregonensis.habitat: in duff and mixed woods and under Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), Oregon, March to June, (Smith), under duff in mixed woods (Singer), mycorrhizal with Pinaceae (Trappe)

Russula orsonmilleri.nameOrigin: "In honor of Dr. Orson K. Miller Jr. for his wide ranging contributions to taxonomy of North American fungi, including sequestrate and subalpine species", (Elliott, T.F.(1))
Russula orsonmilleri.habitat: under alpine fir, August, (Smith(4)), type collection in duff under Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), August, (Smith(24))

Russula rogersii.nameOrigin: after the collector of the type, D.P. Rogers
Russula rogersii.habitat: collection under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) in May, (Singer)

Russula rolfalexii.nameOrigin: after Rolf Singer and Alexander H. Smith, who described Martellia parksii
Russula rolfalexii.habitat: mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest are trees in Pinaceae, (Trappe)

Russula setigera.nameOrigin: means 'bearing setae' referring to the seta-like dermatocystidia in the epicutis of the peridium
Russula setigera.habitat: type collection under moss in dense coniferous woods, March, (Singer)

Russula shafferi.nameOrigin: "To honor Dr. Robert Shaffer for his important contributions to knowledge of North American Russulae" (Elliott, T.F.(1), with 'Russulae' italicized)
Russula shafferi.odour: "often sweet (somewhat reminiscent of vanilla)", at least when old, (Arora), not distinctive (Trappe, M.(3))
Russula shafferi.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups "in soil or in humus (buried) in woods", favoring conifers, collections found in mixed woods and under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), April, July, and October, (Arora), under conifers, May, (Smith(4)), with Pseudotsuga menziesii, July to December, (Trappe, M.(3))

Russula similaris.habitat: in soil under Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), (Singer), under hardwoods (Arora)

Russula stewartii.nameOrigin: "In honor of Dr Elwin L. Stewart, mycologist and plant pathologist, for his contributions to taxonomy of sequestrate fungi", (Elliott, T.F.(1))
Russula stewartii.habitat: type underground in old roadbed in woods of 20 to 30 year old Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), July

Russula subabietis.habitat: underground, under Abies amabilis, A. concolor, A. grandis, A. lasiocarpa, A. magnifica, A. procera and possibly Tsuga mertensiana, July through October, (Trappe(2)), above 1000m elevation (Castellano), August to December (Trappe, M.(3))

Russula subfulva.nameOrigin: means 'nearly fulvous', color in Latin description is "pallide fulvis"

Russula subochracea.nameOrigin: 'subochraceum' is one of the colors in the Latin description used to describe the peridium
Russula subochracea.habitat: type collection in duff under Abies (fir) in ID, August, (Smith(24)), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), (Trappe)

Russula taetra.odour: when fresh pungent, reminiscent of Russula foetens, (Singer), disagreeable, resembling that of Russula foetens (Smith)
Russula taetra.habitat: single under Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), August, (Singer)

Russula unicalifornica.nameOrigin: contraction of 'University of California', the site of the type collection, (Elliott(1))
Russula unicalifornica.habitat: type from California underground under Quercus agrifolia (Coast Live Oak)

Schenella pityophilus.habitat: underground, buried in dead needle litter, in sandy soil, under Pinus (pine), March to May, (Malencon), with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), and Quercus (oak) "in dry, lowland forests and woodlands", December to June, (Trappe, M.(1)), probably saprotrophic (Trappe(13))

Schenella simplex.nameOrigin: means 'with black gleba', 'gleba' refers to the spores and supporting structures and comes from Latin for 'clod, lump'
Schenella simplex.odour: often rather unpleasant in the inky stage (Arora), metallic, resembling that of actual ink, (Smith(15) quoting Gruber)
Schenella simplex.habitat: single "or more often in groups or large, mycelium-incrusted clusters in soil or duff in woods and along old roads through the woods, usually buried or only partially exposed", mainly with conifers in summer or fall, (Arora), usually gregarious, under conifers, May to November, most often August through October, (Dominguez), in closely connected, almost ingrown, clusters of 15-30, deep in the soil with only a few visible, (Smith(15) quoting Gruber), probably saprotrophic (Trappe(13))

Scleroderma hypogaeum.taste: when fresh strongly rubbery, but when dried mild or sometimes disagreeable, (Guzman), farinaceous when young (Zeller)
Scleroderma hypogaeum.odour: when fresh strongly rubbery, but when dried mild or sometimes disagreeable, (Guzman), farinaceous when young, but becoming strongly alkaline when deliquescing, (Zeller)
Scleroderma hypogaeum.habitat: hypogeous or subhypogeous [underground or somewhat underground], occasionally in sand, growing gregariously, in coniferous woods, (Guzman), gregarious in conifer woods only, (Ramsey), in clay soil under lawn sod (Zeller)

Sedecula pulvinata.odour: mild (Castellano), unpleasant and strong when old and moist (Thiers)
Sedecula pulvinata.habitat: found in association with roots of Abies concolor (White Fir), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), Abies magnifica (California Red Fir), Picea engelmannii (Engelmann Spruce), and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine) above 2000m elevation, June through September, (Castellano), under duff of Abies magnifica shastensis (Shasta Red Fir) at 2140m elevation, September, (Zeller), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest trees in Pinaceae (Trappe)

Trappea darkeri.nameOrigin: named for the collector of the type, G.D. Darker
Trappea darkeri.odour: unpleasant, suggesting stinkhorns or gasoline, (Castellano, Trappe, M.(3))
Trappea darkeri.habitat: hypogeous or epigeous [buried or partly buried], single to scattered, under conifers usually at elevations 1000-3100m; in western North America May through November, (Castellano), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), Abies (fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), and Quercus (oak) at moderate to high elevations, April to November, (Trappe, M.(3))

Trappea phillipsii.nameOrigin: named for the collector, C.L. Phillips
Trappea phillipsii.habitat: in California, usually single on or in rotten wood, presumptively mycorrhizal with conifers and possibly Quercus spp. at elevations 600-2400m, January to September

Truncocolumella citrina.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to the citron [a lemon-like fruit]', probably in reference to its surface color
Truncocolumella citrina.edibility: edible but reported to have little flavor (Trudell), one report of licorice taste delayed to an hour or two later (Arora)
Truncocolumella citrina.habitat: single to gregarious under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and possibly other conifers, especially in summer and fall, often surfaces when mature or is dug up by rodents, (Arora), single to gregarious, rarely cespitose [clustered], in the duff or only slightly projecting, usually associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii, late summer and fall, (Smith(29)), with Pseudotsuga, and rarely Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine); fruiting August to December (Trappe, M.(3))

Tuber anniae.nameOrigin: "in honor of Annie Kiel, who facilitated the Fort Lewis Ecosystem Study in many useful ways"
Tuber anniae.habitat: underground, in stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), August through December, (Colgan), "Members of the Tuber anniae species complex have been found forming ectomycorrhizas with Corylus avellana in truffle orchards, and also with Pinus contorta, Pseudotsuga menziesii, and Betula papyrifera on forestry sites" (Berch(4), Latin names italicized)

Tuber asa.habitat: found in association with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) at 170-500 um elevation in Oregon, under Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine) in Nebraska; fruits in July and October

Tuber bellisporum.nameOrigin: from Latin 'belli' meaning 'lovely' and '-sporum' meaning 'spored', "in reference to the attractive, tidy ornamentation of the spores", (Bonito)
Tuber bellisporum.odour: when young fruity-farinaceous, when mature 'pungent and "truffly"'
Tuber bellisporum.habitat: in mesic to xeric habitats, associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) in pure stands or in mixture with Tsuga heterophylla, other Pinaceae, or Arbutus menziesii, fruiting October to June

Tuber beyerlei.nameOrigin: "In honor of Adrian Beyerle, avid truffle collector, long-term member of the North American Truffling Society and discoverer of the holotype"
Tuber beyerlei.habitat: under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), May and November; ectomycorrhizae belonging to T. beyerlei have been sequenced from truffle orchards in BC, Canada, established with Corylus and Quercus spp. that had been inoculated with T. melanosporum (Shannon Berch pers. comm. to Guevara(1))

Tuber californicum.edibility: yes, some people detect a bitter taste, Arora found strong mushroomy flavor
Tuber californicum.odour: often distinctive when old (rather cheesy or like gourmet crackers), (Arora), mild to slightly garlicky (Trappe, M.(3))
Tuber californicum.habitat: single to gregarious "in or on soil (but under humus) in woods and at their edges", (Arora), in Quercus (oak) and other woods (Gilkey), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), Quercus, and Corylus (hazel), at low to moderate elevation, October to June, (Trappe, M.(3)), mycorrhizal hosts in Pacific Northwest are trees in Pinaceae (Trappe(13))

Tuber candidum.odour: mild to slightly earthy (Frank), "mild to slightly earthy and at full maturity of fresh green beans", (Trappe, M.)
Tuber candidum.habitat: fruits below leaf litter in top 2-7cm of mineral soil, associated with Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) in southern OR, also associated with Quercus (oak) spp. from Washington and Idaho south to southern California, (Frank), under trees or shrubs, (Gilkey), primarily with Quercus, but also found with Pinus (pine), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), and other conifers and hardwoods; fruiting year-round, (Trappe, M.)

Tuber castellanoi.nameOrigin: in honor of Michael Castellano for collecting the type and his contributions to mycology and truffle taxonomy, (Bonito)
Tuber castellanoi.habitat: mostly in relatively xeric habitats, associated with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) in pure stands or in mixture with other Pinaceae or Quercus (oak) spp., also known from one location without Pseudotsuga menziesii; fruiting February to June, December

Tuber gardneri.habitat: nearly always associated with Douglas-fir (one collection from Oregon, one from the midwest, and one from Mexico are recorded from oak stands), (Trappe, J.), under trees of various species, (Gilkey), with Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Pinus (pine), Tsuga (hemlock), and Quercus (oak), May-September, "often in warm, dry habitats", (Trappe, M.(1))

Tuber gibbosum.edibility: choice, but widespread collecting can be destructive, (Arora), commercially harvested for culinary use (Bonito), toxic in a 2010 report: stomach queasy, diarrhea (4x), later fainted (3x), felt cold: consumed brie infused/odor of truffle, (Beug)
Tuber gibbosum.taste: as odor (Bonito), mild but like garlic when mature (Miller)
Tuber gibbosum.odour: mild when young, soon 'strong, pungent and complex, "truffly"', (Bonito), '"truffly", a complex of garlic, spices, cheese, and indefinable other essences', (Trappe, M.(3)), usually strong and garlicky when fully mature (Arora)
Tuber gibbosum.habitat: below about 600 m in pure stands up to about 100 years old of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) or Pseudotsuga mixed with Tsuga heterophylla, Picea sitchensis, or Abies, often in Christmas tree plantations as young as 5 years (in one such farm the only host species Abies procera), occurs as ectomycorrhizae on Pinus sabiniana; fruiting January to June, (Bonito), with young to early-mature Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir); January to June, (Trappe, M.(3)), single, scattered or gregarious "in woods or at their edges, associated mainly if not exclusively with Douglas-fir (usually trees between the ages of 8 and 65 years)", normally underground but sometimes on surface, (Arora), almost year-round depending on location and weather conditions, (Ammirati), underground under Douglas-fir, reported under oak (Lincoff)

Tuber harknessii.nameOrigin: means "of Harkness", for H.W. Harkness, pioneer 19th Century truffle taxonomist, (Trappe, M.(1))

Tuber irradians.habitat: in woods, (Gilkey), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest is Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Tuber lauryi.nameOrigin: "In honor of Dr Daniel Laury, who found the southernmost collection of the species"
Tuber lauryi.habitat: underground, single in mixed forests of Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) or in pure stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii; July, October, and December; sequence data from ectomycorrhizae confirm that T. lauryi is mycorrhizal with species of Quercus (oak), Notholithocarpus (Tanoak), and Epipactis (an orchid genus)

Tuber luomae.nameOrigin: "In honor of the distinguished mycologist Dr. Dan Luoma, collector of the holotype, for his many contributions to mycology."
Tuber luomae.habitat: various mixtures and ages of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Abies grandis (Grand Fir), and Alnus rubra (Red Alder), "to in one case, a partially harvested old-growth", and in another, a pure stand of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), August (relatively immature), October, and November

Tuber monticola.habitat: type collection among firs in dense woods in the Sierra Nevada mountains, (Gilkey), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest are trees in Pinaceae, (Trappe)

Tuber oregonense.nameOrigin: means 'from Oregon' "in reference to western Oregon being its central region of abundance", (Bonito)
Tuber oregonense.odour: mild when young, 'soon becoming strong, pungent and complex, "truffly"', (Bonito), '"truffly," a complex of garlic, spices, cheese, and indefinable other essences', (Trappe, M.)
Tuber oregonense.habitat: in pure stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) forests up to 100 years old or Pseudotsuga mixed with Tsuga heterophylla, Picea sitchensis or Alnus, also in Christmas tree plantations as young as 5 years, and found along golf course fairways; fruits September to mid-March, primarily in fall to early winter, (Bonito), with young to early-mature Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), October to February, (Trappe, M.), fall to late winter; principally with young, vigorously growing Douglas-firs, (Trudell)

Tuber pacificum.nameOrigin: referring "to the Pacific Ocean, near which the known localities of this species occur", (Trappe(2))
Tuber pacificum.habitat: underground under and probably mycorrhizal with mature Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), February, June, and July, (Trappe(2)), in association with roots of Pseudotsuga menziesii and Tsuga heterophylla at 235m, (Castellano)

Tuber quercicola.odour: "mild to slightly earthy or often of fresh green beans"
Tuber quercicola.habitat: fruiting underground in association with Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) in southern Oregon, below leaf litter in top 2-7cm of mineral soil, March to August, (Frank), with Quercus and Pinus (pine), especially in warm, dry sites; fruiting year-round, (Trappe, M.)

Tuber rapaeodorum.habitat: found in gardens in three different BC locations, one of them associated with Betula sp. (birch) and another with Salix scouleriana (Scouler's Willow), (Berch(4)), underground in association with hardwoods (Salix, Populus, Fagus, Carpinus, Quercus), (Halasz)

Tuber separans.habitat: beneath oaks in clay soil, (Gilkey), mycorrhizal hosts in the Pacific Northwest are trees in the family Pinaceae (Trappe)

Tuber shearii.nameOrigin: after Shear who identified this taxon as Terfezia oligosperma
Tuber shearii.habitat: in pure stands of Pinus (pine) and Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir) or in conifer-hardwood mixtures, (Trappe, M.), in woods (Gilkey)

Tuber sphaerosporum.habitat: under trees (Gilkey), mycorrhizal host in the Pacific Northwest is Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Trappe(13))

Tuber whetstonense.nameOrigin: means 'from Whetstone' in reference to Whetstone Savanna Preserve where the type was found
Tuber whetstonense.habitat: found in association with Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak) in dry habitat

Xerocomellus behrii.nameOrigin: "in honour of the late Dr. H.H. Behr, for his valuable assistance and companionship on joint collecting excursions with Dr. H.W. Harkness (Harkness 1899)"
Xerocomellus behrii.habitat: underground, scattered or clustered under litter or in soil beneath mixed stands of Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), Quercus chrysolepis (Canyon Live Oak), Quercus douglasii (Blue Oak), Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), or other Quercus species, occasionally with Pseudotsuga macrocarpa (Big-cone Douglas-fir) or Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine); December through August

Xerocomellus mcmurphyi.nameOrigin: after Professor James McMurphy of Stanford University, collector of the holotype J. McMurphy 292 in California
Xerocomellus mcmurphyi.habitat: underground, scattered or clustered "under litter or in soil" beneath mixed stands of Quercus agrifolia (California Live Oak), Quercus chrysolepis (Canyon Live Oak), Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), Fraxinus latifolia (Oregon ash), Heteromeles arbutifolia (Toyon), and Umbellaria californica (Bay Laurel); January through April

Youngiomyces stratosus.nameOrigin: Latin "stratosus" (layered), referring to the form of the sporocarp
Youngiomyces stratosus.habitat: type on or in mineral soil under humus in a 40-year-old stand of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)

Zelleromyces alveolatus.habitat: type found on soil under duff about 7.6cm deep, under Quercus garryana (Oregon White Oak), May, (Singer)

Zelleromyces oregonensis.habitat: type collection under Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), October, (Singer), under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Trappe)

Zelleromyces scissilis.nameOrigin: means 'that may be split readily', referring to the peridium which cracks off easily when fresh
Zelleromyces scissilis.odour: strong of Hamamelis (witch-hazel), (Zeller(16) for Arcangeliella scissilis), not distinctive (Trappe, M.(3))
Zelleromyces scissilis.habitat: under conifers, November, (Singer for Martellia scissilis), collection under Acer circinatum (Vine Maple) in mixed woods (Singer for type of Zelleromyces gilkeyae), with Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Picea (spruce), and Abies (fir) at low elevations; fruiting September to December, (Trappe, M.(3))

Arrhenia acerosa.habitat: on various mosses, especially Dicranum species, "or near mosses and then either terrestrial or on litter close to the soil or mosses, in coniferous forests, burn sites, seepage sites, or moss carpets", (Redhead)

Arrhenia retiruga.habitat: on mosses, tree trunks, sometimes on twigs or leaves near mosses, (Redhead)

Clavariadelphus truncatus.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "cut or broken off", (Lincoff(1))
Clavariadelphus truncatus.spores: white in deposit, gradually yellowing during storage, (Methven), pale orange-red (Miller)
Clavariadelphus truncatus.edibility: delicious when sweet (Arora), edible, but slightly laxative in quantity, the sugary flavor is due to a large amount of mannitol, (Lincoff(1))
Clavariadelphus truncatus.taste: sweet (Methven), mild to sweetish, or bittersweet, (Arora), not distinct (Castellano), sweet (Miller)
Clavariadelphus truncatus.habitat: scattered to gregarious on soil and duff, under mixed conifers, July through November, (Castellano), "Scattered to gregarious; terrestrial; duff; coniferous forests", (Methven),

Cotylidia diaphana.habitat: single or in groups among humus and debris in woods; fall and winter, (Arora for California), on ground; amongst humus and twigs; moist woods of conifers or hardwoods; lawns under trees, (Ginns), on the ground in damp coniferous or hardwood woods, or on lawns under trees, (Reid)

Cotylidia pannosa.habitat: single to gregarious or in rows, on soil among leaf and needle litter in mixed forests or hardwood forests, (Breitenbach), growing on ground in woods, (Ginns), on soil in hardwood forest (Eriksson), on bare soil in woods, especially under Fagus (beech), (Reid), fall (Buczacki)

Cudonia circinans.nameOrigin: from a Latin word meaning 'going round' and is used in a botanical context to mean 'coiling'
Cudonia circinans.edibility: poisonous, said to contain high concentrations of monomethylhydrazine (gyromitrin), (Arora)
Cudonia circinans.habitat: scattered to gregarious or often in dense clusters in humus, soil, and on rotting wood; particularly common under conifers, but also found with hardwoods, (Arora), single or gregarious on rotten wood or humus among leaves, often under conifers, (Seaver), gregarious to clustered or in fairy rings, in coniferous forests on needle litter and among mosses, (Breitenbach), several to gregarious "on humus, well-decayed wood, under or near conifers", late summer and fall, (Miller), Kem Luther (pers. comm.) pointed out that spring observations occur on the west coast in iNaturalist and Mushroom Observer, and Oluna and Adolf Ceska deposited several spring collections at the University of British Columbia; on the Consortium of PNW Herbaria website, about 10% of 90 records are before June

Marasmius caricis.habitat: scattered on Carex (sedge) or Scirpus under dense leaf cover in open marshes

Marasmius epiphyllus.habitat: fallen leaves especially Populus, but also other vegetation such as standing dead Equisetum stems, overwintered apple-skins, etc., (Redhead), gregarious on leaves and petioles of Betulaceae, or rarely of Quercus (oak), Prunus, or Fraxinus (ash), in deciduous woods, August to November, (Gilliam), on leaves and sticks of hardwood trees (Hansen for Europe), leaves, stems, blackberry shoots, (Moser for Europe), in California restricted to leaf litter of aspen and dogwood (Desjardin), fall to winter (Buczacki), summer, fall, winter

Thelephora palmata.odour: garlic-like, becoming fetid (unpleasant) when old, (Arora), strong, fetid, particularly on drying, commonly without odor when fresh, (Corner), fetid, of rotting cabbage or garlic, disappears when drying, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Thelephora palmata.habitat: moist ground in coniferous woods, also in grassy fields, (Ginns), single or in groups on moist ground in woods and at their edges, often along woodland paths, late fall, winter, or spring, (Arora, for California), on the ground in coniferous woods, (Corner), August to November, later in California, (Phillips)

Alloclavaria purpurea.taste: none, or slightly fishy or nauseous, (Corner)
Alloclavaria purpurea.odour: none, or slightly fishy or nauseous, (Corner), not distinctive (Phillips), unpleasant or indistinct (Lincoff)
Alloclavaria purpurea.habitat: generally cespitose, up to 20 in a tuft, sometimes gregarious or single, among grass or on bare soil, generally under conifers, (Corner), in groups or clusters on wet soil near conifers in mountainous areas (Phillips), scattered to densely gregarious (often in tufts or clusters) on ground in wet areas, usually under or near conifers, (Arora), spring, summer, and early fall, (Miller)

Artomyces cristatus.taste: unknown (Dodd), distinctly peppery in iNat 102622936 which matched other Artomyces cristatus sequences, spores were 4.5-5 x 2 um (one at 2.5) in the peppery collection
Artomyces cristatus.habitat: on partly decayed logs of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and other conifers, (Corner), on rotten logs, December in Oregon, October in Washington, August in Quebec, (Dodd)

Bryoglossum gracile.habitat: associated with mosses in arctic or alpine environments, (Redhead), attached to and evidently parasitic on Paludella squarrosa in bogs, (Seaver), fruits August through October (Castellano), gregarious on moist living mosses on soil and rocks, (Breitenbach)

Clavaria falcata.taste: none in particular (Breitenbach), none or ill-defined (Corner)
Clavaria falcata.odour: none in particular (Breitenbach), none or ill-defined (Corner)
Clavaria falcata.habitat: single to gregarious in groups, more rarely in clusters, on bare soil "or among leaf litter and grass, in hardwood forests, on path embankments, etc."; summer to fall, (Breitenbach), single or gregarious in small groups, or densely fasciculate, among grass or on bare earth in fields and woods, or in flower pots, (Corner), "scattered individuals or fused pairs or trios", usually "on bare soil in somewhat disturbed areas", (Trudell)

Clavaria fragilis.nameOrigin: refers to fragile nature of flesh
Clavaria fragilis.habitat: often in huge masses in mossy soil under conifers, especially spruce, (Trudell), in tufts or clusters in moist soil, grass, fields, and woods, (Phillips), densely cespitose [in tufts] in tufts of 20-50, occasionally in tufts of 3-6 or gregarious, rarely single, among grass or on bare soil in fields and woods, (Corner), in tufts, clusters, or groups, on ground in woods or grassy places, (Arora), summer and fall (Miller)

Clavaria globospora.habitat: single, gregarious or scattered, on forest floor of western coniferous forests

Clavaria maricola.habitat: gregarious, often very abundant, on decaying needles, and, mostly, on decaying male cones of Pinus ponderosus (Western Yellow Pine), (Corner)

Clavaria neonigrita.habitat: single to gregarious in groups of 2-15, on rotting debris in low conifer forest with mostly Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)

Clavaria rosea.taste: none or slight and not particular (Corner)
Clavaria rosea.odour: none or slight and not particular (Corner)
Clavaria rosea.habitat: on the ground among grass and in the woods (Corner), on the ground, often beside woodland paths (Barron), single or in small groups, in woods or amongst grass, fall, (Phillips), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Clavariadelphus caespitosus.nameOrigin: refers to growth in cespitose clusters
Clavariadelphus caespitosus.habitat: gregarious, densely gregarious or in cespitose clusters, on ground, in duff, in coniferous or mixed forest

Clavariadelphus ligula.spores: white to pale yellowish (Arora, but Methven specifically says not white), "light buff", "cartridge buff", "pale ochraceous buff", or "pale ochraceous salmon", (Methven), white (Miller)
Clavariadelphus ligula.taste: mild or bitter (Arora), not distinctive or slightly sweet, (Methven), slightly bitter (Miller)
Clavariadelphus ligula.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious or tufted in humus under conifers, (Arora), scattered to gregarious, on ground, in duff, under mixed conifers, (Methven)

Clavariadelphus mucronatus.nameOrigin: means 'mucronate' (with a short sharp point on a flatter surface)
Clavariadelphus mucronatus.spores: white, 'pale yellow' or 'orange white', "cartridge buff", "seashell pink", "light buff", "pale ochraceous-buff" or "pale ochraceous-salmon", (Methven)
Clavariadelphus mucronatus.habitat: gregarious in coniferous humus, (Corner), "Gregarious; terrestrial; coniferous needles and debris", (Methven)

Clavariadelphus occidentalis.taste: not distinctive (Methven(4)), "not distinct or bitter" (Castellano - phrasing ambiguous),
Clavariadelphus occidentalis.habitat: single to gregarious or in cespitose clusters of 2 or 3, on soil or duff in mixed hardwood-coniferous forests or hardwood forests, mostly September through February but also in May, (Castellano), "Scattered to gregarious, infrequently in cespitose clusters; terrestrial; duff; coniferous or mixed deciduous-coniferous forests", (Methven(4))

Clavariadelphus pallidoincarnatus.edibility: "Edible; not as sweet tasting as C. truncatus", (Siegel(2), with Latin name italicized)
Clavariadelphus pallidoincarnatus.habitat: single or scattered in troops "on ground or in thick duff" in the fall in coniferous forest, especially under Sitka spruce, (Siegel, in the context of Northern California), scattered to gregarious under Sequoia sempervirens (Redwood), Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), and Alnus (alder).

Clavariadelphus sachalinensis.nameOrigin: named after the Russian island of Sakhalin, where it was first found, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Clavariadelphus sachalinensis.spores: "pinkish buff" (Petersen, using Ridgway color), 'yellowish white' to 'pale orange', "light buff", "pale ochraceous-buff" or "cartridge buff", (Methven)
Clavariadelphus sachalinensis.habitat: scattered to gregarious on soil or duff, under mixed conifers, June through October, (Castellano), scattered to gregarious; "terrestrial; duff; under mixed conifers", (Methven)

Clavariadelphus subfastigiatus.habitat: fasciculate in clusters of 6-20, on well-decayed humus of coniferous woods, (Corner), "Scattered to gregarious; terrestrial; duff; coniferous or mixed deciduous-coniferous forests", (Methven)

Clavicorona taxophila.taste: unknown (Dodd), none, based on one report (Lickey)
Clavicorona taxophila.habitat: gregarious, usually single, occasionally paired, on leaf duff usually under conifers, often Taxus (yew), "appears to lack the lignicolous habit, but the fruit bodies are attached to twigs and needles in the duff on the ground", also on hardwood leaves though under Taxus, or on bare ground, (Dodd), single or 2-3 together, or subcespitose, on moist, very rotten leaves and twigs of hardwood trees and conifers under prostrate branches of Taxus brevifolia (Pacific Yew) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Corner), mostly growing erect from small bits of charred wood, needles, and small twigs and among mosses under heavy cover of small Douglas-firs in dense coniferous woods, October, (Doty), fall to winter (Buczacki)

Clavulinopsis gracillima.habitat: single, gregarious, or subcespitose [somewhat tufted] in 2s and 3s but not fasciculate [bundled], "on deciduous or coniferous leaf litter, often in moist, low areas"

Clavulinopsis laeticolor.nameOrigin: means 'of a bright or joyful color'
Clavulinopsis laeticolor.habitat: growing "on deciduous or coniferous leaf mold or humus", (Petersen(4)), single, scattered, in groups, or tufted on mossy banks, wet soil, and woodland humus, fruiting in fall, winter, and spring, (Arora), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Cordyceps bifusispora.nameOrigin: The spores are described as bifusiform.
Cordyceps bifusispora.habitat: on the pupa of an insect (Noctuidae)

Cordyceps militaris.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "military", because its shape resembles a plume, (Lincoff(1))
Cordyceps militaris.habitat: single to gregarious or clustered on buried pupae (or less commonly caterpillars) of moths and butterflies, (Arora), usually single, on larvae and pupae of moths and butterflies, which are usually buried in soil, (Dennis), single to several "on the ground or in humus or well-decayed wood"; late summer and fall, (Miller)

Cudonia grisea.habitat: gregarious on rotten conifer wood (Seaver), under conifers, usually in spring, (Arora), gregarious on rotting coniferous wood, (Mains)

Eocronartium muscicola.habitat: parasitic on the gametophytes of mosses belonging to the families Leskeaceae and Hypnaceae, (Klett), parasitic on various mosses, (Martin, G.W.)

Geoglossum fallax.habitat: single on clay or loamy soil in woods or on slopes of ravines, (Seaver), scattered to crowded on humus and rotting logs, (Mains)

Geoglossum glabrum.habitat: single or rarely clustered, gregarious, on very rotten wood, logs, stumps, or rich humus, rarely on soil, (Seaver), scattered to crowded, on soil or in the case of var. inflatum also in sphagnum or other mosses, (Mains)

Geoglossum umbratile.habitat: usually single, on wet ground, banks or among leaves on rich humus, rarely on rotten ground, (Seaver), scattered or in small groups, type variety very variable in habitats, occurring among sphagnum and other mosses, on soil in well drained areas and on wet soil by streams and in bogs, var. heterosporum on conifer log, (Mains)

Glutinoglossum glutinosum.habitat: scattered to cespitose [in tufts] on soil on hillsides and in wet places, under cedar and in hardwoods, (Mains), single or clustered, on the ground and on rotten wood, in rich woods, (Seaver), single, scattered, or in small groups "in humus, moss, or sometimes rotten wood, usually in the woods", (Arora)

Heyderia abietis.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious in needle duff under northern and mountain conifers, sometimes in large carpets on forest floor, spring, summer and fall, (Arora), scattered on fallen needles of conifers (spruce, hemlock, fir and larch), (Mains), growing singly on conifer needles, but gregariously, (Breitenbach)

Hypocrea alutacea.habitat: typically gregarious, single or sometimes fused, on barked but typically wet, rotten wood, and on wood chips

Hypocrea leucopus.nameOrigin: means 'white foot', referring to the white stem
Hypocrea leucopus.habitat: single, on ground among litter, typically in mixed forest type

Lysurus cruciatus.edibility: presumably edible in egg stage, but strip away gelatinous layer
Lysurus cruciatus.odour: spore mass has unpleasant fetid odor
Lysurus cruciatus.habitat: "solitary or in groups or clusters in lawns, gardens, under trees, in rich soil, on rotten wood, etc.", (Arora)

Lysurus periphragmoides.habitat: single to gregarious (occasionally two from same volva), in rich soil, lawns, gardens, open woods, on rotten wood, etc., (Arora), single to numerous on fertile ground or on mulch, following spring rains, or also fall and winter, (Metzler)

Macrotyphula fistulosa.habitat: single to gregarious, occasionally in masses, on hardwood and conifer wood, (Breitenbach), on dead sticks and debris, especially of alder, (Arora), single or gregarious, never cespitose, on dead sticks and branches of coniferous and hardwood trees, (Corner), on soil among litter in hardwood woodland, often with birch, (Buczacki)

Macrotyphula juncea.habitat: scattered to gregarious "in humus and leaf litter, on rotting twigs, etc.", in California on oak and tanoak leaves and redwood needles and "fairly common in the fall and winter, especially along streams and in other dank places", (Arora), usually gregarious, on "decomposing stems of herbs, bud scales, remains of leaves and twigs, in damp humusy locations", fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), on litter, especially on petioles of rotting leaves in damp hardwood woodland, most usually seen on ash, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Microglossum atropurpureum.habitat: on soil, (Mains), on the ground or humus for C purpurascens, on the ground in woods for C. atropurpureus, on rich sandy humus among leaves in damp woods for C. robustus, (Seaver)

Microglossum fumosum.habitat: scattered to cespitose [in tufts] on soil and rotting wood, (Mains), single, or more often densely cespitose, on much decayed rotten logs and about the bases of stumps, (Seaver)

Microglossum olivaceum.habitat: scattered to cespitose [in tufts], on soil, (Mains), single, or clustered, on the ground among leaves or in grassy places in rich woods, (Seaver), on the ground in mixed woods, (Barron)

Mitrula borealis.habitat: gregarious, single to subcespitose, in shallow water, on decaying needles, twigs, cones, or leaves of Abies excelsa, Alnus rugosa, Picea sp., Thuja occidentalis, and Tsuga sp., or decaying vegetation of other unidentified plants and mosses including Sphagnum, July to September

Mitrula elegans.habitat: gregarious, single to cespitose, in shallow water, on decaying wet needles, scales, twigs, leaves, or fruits of Acer saccharinum, Alnus rubra, A. rugosa, Fagus grandifolia, Liquidambar styraciflua, Lysichitum americanum, Osmunda cinnamomea, Pinus monticola, P. strobus, Quercus borealis, Q. prinus, Thuja occidentalis, T. plicata, mats of Calliergonella cuspidatum and Sphagnum recurvum, and logs, mud, algal mats, or other unidentified vegetation, April to September, (Redhead), scattered or in groups in shallow water on decaying leaves, needles, twigs, and debris in woodlands and bogs, April-August, (Bessette for northeastern North America)

Multiclavula coronilla.habitat: gregarious, on "rotting wood and soil, associated with algae", (Petersen), Multiclavula species generally grow on a film of green algae (Coccomyxa) over the substrate, (Brodo(1)).

Multiclavula corynoides.habitat: associated with algae on soil (Petersen), on sandy soil, usually with moss, especially road banks, Multiclavula species generally grow on a film of green algae (Coccomyxa) over the substrate, (Brodo)

Multiclavula mucida.habitat: in groups but not clusters on wet algae-covered wood or occasionally on soil, (Arora), on rotting wood, usually covered with green algae, sometimes also on algae-covered soil, (Lincoff), gregarious, often in large colonies, not bundled, on rotten wood, associated with a film of Chlorococcoid algae (in Corner(3) he corrects this to Coccomyxa) on the surface of the wood, in USA often on Nyssa, (Corner(2)), most often fruiting in late summer and fall (Miller)

Multiclavula sharpii.nameOrigin: after the collector Dr. A.J. Sharp
Multiclavula sharpii.habitat: gregarious, sometimes crowded, associated in BC with algae or moss protonemata, on clay soil, (Petersen(27)), Multiclavula species generally grow on a film of green algae (Coccomyxa) over the substrate, (Brodo(1))

Multiclavula vernalis.habitat: gregarious in extensive colonies on bare earth covered with algae and moss protonemata, (Coker), terrestrial [on the ground], associated with algae or moss protonemata, (Petersen(27)), Multiclavula species generally grow on a film of green algae (Coccomyxa) over the substrate, (Brodo(1)).

Mutinus ravenelii.edibility: eggs of Mutinus spp. have been eaten by some (Arora), [the poisonous Amanitas are also egg-like when young]
Mutinus ravenelii.odour: foul "while the spore slime is present"
Mutinus ravenelii.habitat: saprobic, "growing alone or gregariously in gardens and cultivated areas, or in woods; summer and fall"

Neolecta vitellina.habitat: needle beds and moss carpets usually on ravine or hill slopes, August to October

Onygena corvina.habitat: single to clustered, on owl pellets or animal hair as well as remnants of sheep wool, according to the literature also on feathers, summer to fall, (Breitenbach), on owl pellets, bird carcasses, hair, and wool, (Trudell)

Onygena equina.habitat: single to cespitose [in tufts], also clustered, on rotting horns of cattle and sheep, as well as remains of hooves, spring to fall

Ophiocordyceps gracilis.habitat: on dead buried caterpillars (on larva of Hepialus lupulinus, according to Favre, 1942), summer, (Breitenbach), on buried larva of Lepidoptera, usually Hepialus, "sometimes occurring in numbers in gardens in the spring", (Petch for Britain)

Ophiocordyceps myrmecophila.habitat: scattered to gregarious on mummified, often buried ant carcasses, usually one per ant, usually around ant nests in the woods, (Arora)

Ophiocordyceps ravenelii.nameOrigin: from Ravenel, the collector of the type in South Carolina
Ophiocordyceps ravenelii.habitat: on beetle larvae (Smith), the description here is of fresh collections on June beetle larvae (Mains)

Ophiocordyceps variabilis.habitat: "Parasitic on larvae of Diptera, particularly of wood inhabiting Xylophagidae"

Pachycudonia monticola.habitat: single, gregarious or cespitose [in tufts], on spruce needles and conifer debris, (Seaver), under conifers, usually in spring and summer, (Arora), closely gregarious to cespitose [in tufts], on soil, coniferous debris or rotting wood, (Mains), on spruce needles and conifer debris, late summer and fall, (Castellano), on soil and rotting conifer wood in spring and summer, at times in snow banks, (Tylutki)

Phallus impudicus.edibility: not considered poisonous, but seldom eaten, (Arora), reportedly eaten in egg stage, but not recommended, (Lincoff), young poisonous Amanitas also have egg-like form
Phallus impudicus.habitat: single or in groups or clusters "in lawns, gardens, sandy or cultivated soil, under trees or shrubs, in rich humus, etc.", (Arora), in forests and gardens, and on compost, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), spring, summer, late fall, (Lincoff(1))

Phallus indusiatus.edibility: inedible (Bessette), edible in egg stage but not recommended, (Phillips), eggs could be confused with poisonous Amanita stages
Phallus indusiatus.odour: foul-smelling (Bessette), weak to strong, repulsive, (McKnight), fetid (Lincoff(2))
Phallus indusiatus.habitat: single or in groups on ground in hardwoods or mixed forest, June to October, (Bessette), in rich soil in woods and gardens (Barron)

Pterula gracilis.habitat: "on dead stems and leaves of Juncus, Carex, Cladium, Typha, Eupatorium, grasses &c., in swampy places", (Corner(2)), single or in small +/- trooping groups, densely crowded, on organic debris, old leaves, litter in hardwood woodland and other sites, especially wet habitats, perhaps all year, (Buczacki)

Spathularia flavida.edibility: said to be edible, but rather tough, (Arora)
Spathularia flavida.habitat: "scattered to gregarious or even clustered, sometimes in lines or circles, on humus or rotten wood under conifers (especially pine) or sometimes hardwoods", (Arora), cespitose [in tufts], gregarious, or scattered, sometimes growing in circles, on humus and rotten wood, (Mains)

Tolypocladium capitatum.habitat: single, tufted, or gregarious on ground, arising from underground deer truffles (Elaphomyces species), (Arora), single to clustered, in coniferous forests among moss and needle litter, parasitic on underground Elaphomyces, (Breitenbach)

Tolypocladium ophioglossoides.nameOrigin: from Greek meaning "like a snake's tongue", (Lincoff(1))
Tolypocladium ophioglossoides.habitat: parasitic on various Elaphomyces species, including E. granulatus and E. muricatus, (Castellano), single or a few together (Dennis), late summer and fall (Bacon)

Trichoglossum hirsutum.edibility: supposedly edible but too tough to be worthwhile, (Arora)
Trichoglossum hirsutum.habitat: single or gregarious on rotten wood or on humus among leaves, (Seaver), scattered to gregarious on rotting wood, on soil, in sphagnum, (Mains), single to gregarious in boggy meadows among Sphagnum, (Breitenbach), single, scattered, gregarious or in tufts "in humus, moss, or soil (or occasionally on rotten wood), usually in woods", (Arora), fall (Bacon)

Trichoglossum velutipes.nameOrigin: means 'with velvet foot', referring to stem
Trichoglossum velutipes.habitat: scattered to crowded, on soil and rotting wood, (Mains), single, or gregarious, sometimes cespitose, on soil, humus, or rotten wood, (Seaver)

Typhula abietina.habitat: on twigs of Pinus (pine) and Abies (fir)

Typhula cystidiophora.habitat: somewhat gregarious, on the soil among moss in coniferous forest

Typhula erumpens.nameOrigin: means 'erumpent', referring to the manner of its attachment to wood
Typhula erumpens.habitat: on twigs of Salix (willow) in BC, on twigs of Alnus hirsutum in Russia

Typhula erythropus.habitat: on "petioles and veins of the previous year's fallen leaves of Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Populus (poplar), and other hardwoods", (Breitenbach), on various dead leaves, sticks, stems, Pteris petioles, (Corner), on petioles of fallen leaves of hardwoods such as Acer macrophylla (Bigleaf Maple), (Trudell), single or in small trooping groups; on dead, fallen and rotting leaves, especially sycamore and ash, also occasionally on dead grass leaves, other herbaceous debris, dead twigs and rotting wood; fall, (Buczacki)

Typhula idahoensis.habitat: on leaves and stem of Triticum vulgare and Agropyrum cristatum, parasitic; sclerotia form with the snow melt, fruitbodies grow in fall, (Corner), rarely attacks species other than winter cereals and grasses, (Bruehl(1))

Typhula incarnata.nameOrigin: means 'incarnate' referring to pink color of fruitbody
Typhula incarnata.habitat: on dead culms and leaves of cereals and grasses, and on herbaceous stems and leaves, often parasitic on cereals: sclerotia in spring, fruitbodies in fall, (Corner), rarely attacks species other than winter cereals and grasses, but can attack roots and basal crown tissues even in the absence of conditions required for typical snow mold development (prolonged snow cover), (Bruehl(1))

Typhula ishikariensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Ishikari, a river and area in Japan'
Typhula ishikariensis.habitat: develops only after prolonged snow cover, it is the dominant Typhula species in Washington on winter cereals grown in formerly forested areas, which are usually areas with greater than 40cm of annual precipitation, much of it as snow; it also attacks green foliage of several legumes and broadleaved weeds, in Finland common on clovers, (Bruehl(1)), a pathogen also of turf grasses, (Maloy)

Typhula megasperma.habitat: the type on debris in conifer forest, (Berthier)

Typhula mycophaga.habitat: on several senescent fruitbodies of Lycoperdon pyriforme on moss

Typhula phacorrhiza.habitat: gregarious and cespitose, sometimes 2-3 per sclerotium, on decomposing fallen leaves of various hardwoods, (Breitenbach), single or occasionally 2-3 per sclerotium, on dead leaves, petioles, herbaceous stems and grasses, (Corner)

Typhula sclerotioides.habitat: on dead herbaceous stems and leaves, and on fallen leaves and small twigs of trees, (Corner), growing in rows on dead petioles and stems of Cicerbita alpina (blue sow-thistle), according to Berthier also on Petasites albus (white butterbur), Gentian lutea (great yellow gentian), and Chaerophyllum (chervil), (Breitenbach)

Typhula setipes.habitat: gregarious, scattered, on decomposing fallen leaves of various hardwoods, (Breitenbach), single or in small trooping groups; on decaying leaves of hardwoods, usually by streams, ponds and other wet habitats, (Buczacki)

Typhula thaxteri.nameOrigin: named after Thaxter, the collector of the type
Typhula thaxteri.habitat: gregarious on "woody debris, insect frass, and old perithecia on well decayed hardwood branch in mixed coastal forest", both other world collections on wood, (Redhead), gregarious on rotten wood (Corner for CT)

Typhula umbrina.habitat: on roots of Brassica campestris, and leaves and rhizomes of Iris, (Corner), on turnips in BC, on leaves and rhizomes of iris in ON, (Remsberg)

Xylaria cornu-damae.habitat: on wood, where specified, the collections are from hardwood

Xylaria hypoxylon.nameOrigin: from Greek, meaning "almost ligneous or wooden", because of the texture, (Lincoff(1))
Xylaria hypoxylon.habitat: "scattered to densely gregarious or clustered on rotting logs, stumps, buried sticks, etc.", (Arora), spring and fall, or at other times, (Lincoff(1)), single to cespitose, on hardwood or more rarely conifer wood, conidial stage throughout the year, ascus stage late winter or early spring, (Breitenbach)

Artomyces piperatus.taste: slowly acrid [peppery], (Dodd), a collection iNat 98675889 matched with an Alaska and British Columbia sequence in ITS2 but was mild-tasting
Artomyces piperatus.habitat: gregarious or occasionally cespitose [in tufts], on rotten conifer logs, September to November in North America, (Dodd)

Clavulina amethystina.habitat: on the ground under hardwoods, July to September, (Lincoff), on the ground under hardwoods, at least in Europe, (Corner(2))

Clavulina 'castaneipes'.habitat: on bark or ligneous duff in western North America (var. lignicola), in eastern North America on wet clay soil, often on shady exposed banks covered by moss protonemata or algae (var. castaneipes), (Petersen)

Clavulina cinerea.edibility: highly rated by some authorities, but insipid, (Arora), edible (Corner)
Clavulina cinerea.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups "on ground in mixed woods and under conifers", (Arora), scattered or in groups or clumps in moss on the ground or pine needles in coniferous or mixed woods, August to October, (Phillips)

Clavulina 'coralloides'.edibility: edible (Arora), discard specimens that are parasitized by a blackening fungus (Ammirati)
Clavulina 'coralloides'.habitat: single or scattered on ground in fields or under hardwoods and conifers, June to September, (Phillips), on the ground in fields and coniferous or hardwood woods, (Corner), July to October, (Lincoff), on the ground or dead wood (Courtecuisse), summer, fall, and early winter, (Miller), usually on soil, but at times on well-rotted wood, (Trudell)

Clavulina 'rugosa'.habitat: single, gregarious or subcespitose [somewhat tufted], on the ground in woods and pastures, (Corner), gregarious in woodland and adjacent grassy areas, early summer to late fall, (Lincoff)

Clavulinopsis corniculata.taste: farinaceous to oily-farinaceous (Petersen), mild or bitter (Arora)
Clavulinopsis corniculata.odour: farinaceous to oily-farinaceous (Petersen), mild or farinaceous (Arora)
Clavulinopsis corniculata.habitat: scattered to gregarious, "usually in moist lowland areas with herbaceous or deciduous woody plants", (Petersen(4)), single, scattered, or in groups "on ground or dead wood in forests and at their edges, in grassy areas, etc.", (Arora), fall (Buczacki)

Lentaria albovinacea.taste: mild at first then slowly bitterish, (Leathers), apparently variable from mild to slowly peppery, (Dodd)
Lentaria albovinacea.odour: somewhat fragrant, rather distinctive, (Leathers), fragrant, distinctive, (Dodd)
Lentaria albovinacea.habitat: clustered or single on rotting cottonwood or rotting conifer wood, October in Idaho, September in Arizona, (Dodd), cespitose to single or 3-4 fused at base, on cottonwood logs or on Abies (fir) wood, (Leathers)

Lentaria epichnoa.habitat: densely clustered or cespitose [in tufts] on dead coniferous wood, (Corner(2))

Lentaria pinicola.habitat: usually on rotting coniferous wood, often smaller pieces, fall, (Scates-Barnhart), type on rotten Pinus contorta, (Petersen), growing on small branches, twig litter or cones under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) and Douglas-fir, (Marr)

Phaeoclavulina abietina.spores: ochraceous, but small greenish stains almost always present on paper where fruitbody rested, (Petersen), light brown (Miller)
Phaeoclavulina abietina.taste: mild, agaricoid, sometimes mildly bitter, (Petersen), bitter (Miller)
Phaeoclavulina abietina.odour: mild, when dried of fenugreek, (Petersen), mild, of anise, (Castellano), earthy (Scates-Barnhart), strong (Miller)
Phaeoclavulina abietina.habitat: on conifer debris (Petersen, Castellano), May, and September through November, (Castellano)

Phaeoclavulina argentea.nameOrigin: means 'silvery', probably referring to the silvery or whitish color of the tips on drying
Phaeoclavulina argentea.habitat: on humus and/or woody debris, under Abies (fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), aspen, and Cupressus (cypress), (Petersen), clustered to gregarious among conifer debris in CA and ID, in fall, (Exeter)

Phaeoclavulina curta.habitat: under pines (Scates-Barnhart), under Pinus, Sequoia and Tsuga, (Corner), terrestrial in Pacific coast and inland forests in fall, (Exeter)

Phaeoclavulina eumorpha.nameOrigin: 'eumorpha' from 'eu-' meaning 'agreeable' or 'true, original, typical' and 'morpha' meaning 'shape'; 'invalii' after the town of Inval in Surrey, England, (Lincoff(1))
Phaeoclavulina eumorpha.taste: "musty, mildly bitter, perhaps of tallow", (Petersen), not distinctive (Marr)
Phaeoclavulina eumorpha.odour: "none or mild, fresh, perhaps farinaceous", (Petersen), faintly earthy (Marr)
Phaeoclavulina eumorpha.habitat: in needle duff under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) and other conifers as well as Fagus (beech) and Quercus (oak), (Scates-Barnhart), under conifers - Pinus (pine), Picea (spruce), Abies (true fir) - and hardwoods - Fagus, Quercus, (Petersen), in needle duff under Tsuga heterophylla, fall, (Marr)

Phaeoclavulina glaucoaromatica.nameOrigin: means 'glaucous' [in this case sea-blue-green] and 'aromatic' (fenugreek odor on drying)
Phaeoclavulina glaucoaromatica.odour: "none, on drying moderate to strong of fenugreek"

Phaeoclavulina mutabilis.nameOrigin: means 'changeable', probably referring to the very variable stature
Phaeoclavulina mutabilis.taste: variable, from musty to bitter or acrid [peppery]
Phaeoclavulina mutabilis.odour: mild, in field notes reported as musty disagreeable, farinaceous, fragrant; when dried, either without odor or faintly pleasant, not of fenugreek
Phaeoclavulina mutabilis.habitat: under conifers, "Fruitings on wood or lignous duff seem to produce larger, more complex and congested fruitbodies."

Phaeoclavulina myceliosa.habitat: on conifer litter, (Petersen), in humus under conifers - Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Abies (true fir), Sequoia, (Corner), scattered to densely gregarious in duff under conifers, in parts of California often abundant under redwood in fall, winter, and early spring, (Arora)

Ramaria acrisiccescens.taste: not distinctive or slightly acid when fresh, drying with a pronounced bitterish acid taste, (Marr), mild to +/- acrid [peppery] when fresh, cooking or drying with pronounced bitterish-acid taste, (Scates-Barnhart)
Ramaria acrisiccescens.habitat: on ground in old mixed conifer forests, (Scates-Barnhart), terrestrial under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) (Marr)

Ramaria amyloidea.habitat: under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) or Abies amabilis (Amabilis Fir), (Marr), fruits in humus or soil and matures above the surface of the ground, associated with Abies spp. (fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla, September and October, (Castellano)

Ramaria apiculata.habitat: single, gregarious, or cespitose, common on rotting conifer wood, more rarely on hardwood; late summer through fall; for forma compacta, on very rotten wood or (preferably) sawdust heaps, the form being perhaps due to greater temperature generated by bacterial action or greater substrate surface area

Ramaria armeniaca.habitat: not given, but fruiting in spring

Ramaria aurantiisiccescens.habitat: terrestrial, growing under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Marr), fruits in humus or soil and matures above the ground, associated with Abies spp. (fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla, October, (Castellano)

Ramaria botrytis.nameOrigin: from Greek, meaning "like a bunch of grapes", (Lincoff(1))
Ramaria botrytis.spores: ocher to pale orange (Lincoff(2)), light orange-brown (Miller)
Ramaria botrytis.habitat: terrestrial under conifers, (Marr), on the ground under conifers, especially Picea (spruce) and Abies (fir), August to October, (Lincoff(2))

Ramaria botrytoides.taste: like green pea-hulls (Corner), exceedingly acrid [peppery] taste can linger in mouth for up to 12 hours, (but in his key taste said to be bitter to very bitter), (Arora)
Ramaria botrytoides.habitat: on the ground in woods (Corner), on clay soil, (Petersen)

Ramaria caulifloriformis.taste: negligible to faintly bean-like or slowly musty, (Petersen), mild (Scates-Barnhart)
Ramaria caulifloriformis.odour: negligible to mildly bean-like or weakly agaricoid, (Petersen), slight or musty-sweet (Scates-Barnhart)
Ramaria caulifloriformis.habitat: usually fall, but in California in spring, (Petersen), on ground under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) or Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), fall, (Scates-Barnhart)

Ramaria celerivirescens.nameOrigin: means 'quickly turning green', probably referring to the rapid green reaction of flesh to ferric sulphate
Ramaria celerivirescens.habitat: terrestrial, under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), October and November, (Marr), fruits in humus or soil and matures above the surface, associated with Abies spp. (true fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Castellano)

Ramaria claviramulata.habitat: terrestrial, under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), fall, (Marr)

Ramaria concolor.nameOrigin: after Dr. Currie D. Marr, author of the definitive publication on the genus in Washington
Ramaria concolor.taste: bitter, weakly astringent, not acrid [not peppery], (Petersen)
Ramaria concolor.habitat: on rotting deciduous wood, (Petersen), fruits in humus or soil and matures above the surface of the ground [illustrated on wood], associated with Abies spp. (true fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)

Ramaria conjunctipes.habitat: terrestrial, growing under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), October, (Marr), September to October (Phillips)

Ramaria coulterae.nameOrigin: in honor of Elsie Coulter, longtime collector and mycological enthusiast in northern Idaho and 20-year collecting companion of Kit Scates-Barnhart
Ramaria coulterae.habitat: on coniferous debris in coniferous forest, spring and early summer, (Castellano)

Ramaria cyaneigranosa.habitat: on ground under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), fall, (Marr)

Ramaria distinctissima.habitat: under mixed conifers, with species of Thuja and Tsuga predominant

Ramaria flavigelatinosa.taste: within the range described for var. flavigelatinosa, (Marr), none or faintly fabaceous [bean-like] (Petersen), mild (Scates-Barnhart)
Ramaria flavigelatinosa.odour: within the range described for var. flavigelatinosa, (Marr), mildly fabaceous [bean-like] (Petersen), mildly bean-like to not distinctive (Scates-Barnhart)
Ramaria flavigelatinosa.habitat: terrestrial, growing under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), September and October, (Marr), August-September, coniferous woods in Pacific Northwest and deciduous woods in eastern North America, (Phillips)

Ramaria flavobrunnescens.nameOrigin: 'flavobrunnescens' means 'yellow becoming brown'; 'aromatica' means 'aromatic, fragrant, spicy'
Ramaria flavobrunnescens.odour: sweet, slightly resembling gardenia, curry, or sweet pastries, (Marr)
Ramaria flavobrunnescens.habitat: terrestrial under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), well represented in the fall flora of western Washington and may occur in the spring in less abundance, (Marr)

Ramaria formosa.habitat: terrestrial, growing under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) or (?) Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), October to December, (Marr)

Ramaria gelatiniaurantia.habitat: on the ground under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), fall, (Scates-Barnhart)

Ramaria gelatinosa.spores: 'golden yellow' (Marr), golden yellow (Phillips), light buff to orange-buff (Miller)
Ramaria gelatinosa.edibility: poisonous to some people (causing diarrhea and digestive upset), (Arora)
Ramaria gelatinosa.taste: not distinctive (Marr), often bitter (Arora), mild (Scates-Barnhart, Miller)
Ramaria gelatinosa.habitat: widely scattered to gregarious in duff under conifers - Tsuga (hemlock), Abies (fir) etc., (Arora), terrestrial, under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), September and October, (Marr), on ground in old coniferous forests, often under Tsuga heterophylla, late summer and fall, (Scates-Barnhart), September to November (Phillips)

Ramaria gracilis.odour: distinct, musty to aromatic, but not definitely of anise, when dry faintly of fenugreek, (Petersen)
Ramaria gracilis.habitat: on conifer duff (usually pine), (Petersen), "growing from rotten wood on the ground (?), collected near Western Red Cedar and Douglas Fir", (Marr), fruits in humus or soil and matures above the surface of the ground, associated with Abies spp. (fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), October and November (Castellano)

Ramaria hilaris.nameOrigin: 'hilaris' means 'cheerful, gay'; 'olympiana' probably refers to the Olympic Mountains in Washington
Ramaria hilaris.habitat: not given but type fruiting in fall, (Petersen), on ground, associated with Abies (true fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Scates-Barnhart), fruits in October (Castellano)

Ramaria incognita.nameOrigin: means 'unknown', probably refers to the unknown description of fresh state

Ramaria largentii.edibility: not recommended, easy to confuse with known poisonous species, (McKnight), presumably edible (Scates-Barnhart)
Ramaria largentii.habitat: terrestrial, collected under lowland hemlocks in October, (Marr), scattered or in groups, under conifers (McKnight), fruits in humus or soil and matures above the surface, associated with Abies spp. (fir), Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Castellano)

Ramaria leptoformosa.habitat: terrestrial, growing under Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Taxus brevifolia (Western Yew), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), October and November, (Marr)

Ramaria longispora.habitat: terrestrial, under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), October, (Marr), September-October, (Phillips)

Ramaria maculatipes.habitat: type collected under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), November, (Marr), associated with Abies spp. (fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla, (Castellano)

Ramaria magnipes.edibility: yes, but acts as a strong laxative in some people, (Miller)
Ramaria magnipes.taste: mild when fresh becoming slightly bitter with cooking, (Marr), mild and pleasant (Miller)
Ramaria magnipes.habitat: collected under an understory of Vine Maple, in a mixed coniferous forest of Amabilis Fir, Lowland Hemlock, and Douglas-fir; fruiting in June and July, (Marr), May to August (Phillips), on the ground in mixed coniferous forests, usually with Abies (true fir), spring and summer, (Scates-Barnhart)

Ramaria marrii.nameOrigin: in honor of Dr. Currie D. Marr, author of the definitive publication on the genus in Washington and friend of K. Scates-Barnhart and R. Petersen
Ramaria marrii.habitat: on soil and duff in mixed coniferous forests, including Pinus monticola (Western White Pine) and Abies grandis (Grand Fir), (Petersen)

Ramaria purpurissima.edibility: much too beautiful and rare to eat, (Scates-Barnhart)
Ramaria purpurissima.habitat: under mixed conifers - Abies (fir), Tsuga (hemlock), Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), (Petersen)

Ramaria rainierensis.nameOrigin: means 'from Rainier [National Park]', where type was found
Ramaria rainierensis.habitat: growing among ferns near Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), (Marr), gregarious but not cespitose, September to October, (Petersen), fruits in humus or soil and matures above surface, December and March; associated with Abies spp. (fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Castellano)

Ramaria rasilispora.nameOrigin: 'scatesiana' after Kit Scates-Barnhart "and other members of the Idaho Mycological Society who so generously contributed specimens, notes, and colored slides of ramarias occurring in their 1970 spring flora", (Petersen(3))
Ramaria rasilispora.taste: negligible to weakly musty or krauty [sour] (Petersen(3)), mild, (Scates-Barnhart)
Ramaria rasilispora.odour: negligible to weakly fragrant (Petersen(3)), none or fungoid, (Scates-Barnhart)
Ramaria rasilispora.habitat: on the ground in mixed conifer woods, with Abies (true fir), mainly spring, but also summer and fall, (Scates-Barnhart), May, June, August, (Petersen(3))

Ramaria rasilisporoides.habitat: coniferous forests - Pseudotsuga (Douglas-fir), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), in fall

Ramaria raveneliana.habitat: on poor soil under Tsuga (hemlock) and Rhododendron, (Petersen)

Ramaria rubella.taste: very slowly acrid [peppery] to strongly acrid (Petersen), mild to usually acrid (biting), (Scates-Barnhart), not distinctive, (Marr)
Ramaria rubella.odour: none or faintly of anise (Petersen), not distinctive to musty sweet, (Scates-Barnhart), not distinctive or faintly musty-sweet, (Marr)
Ramaria rubella.habitat: on wood, August to November, (Petersen), growing from decayed conifer wood, collected in a mixed Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) and Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar) forest, September to November, (Marr), on decaying conifer wood or hardwood, fall, (Scates-Barnhart)

Ramaria rubiginosa.habitat: terrestrial, growing under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), October and November, (Marr)

Ramaria rubribrunnescens.habitat: terrestrial, growing under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), October and November, (Marr)

Ramaria rubrievanescens.taste: slightly similar to nuts (Marr), faintly bitter, acrid [peppery] on tongue, (Petersen(12))
