Ramaria rubrievanescens.habitat: terrestrial, in forest of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), September and October, (Marr), on ground in conifer forests, spring or fall, (Scates-Barnhart), fruits in humus or soil and matures above ground, associated with Pinaceae spp., June, September, October, (Castellano), but Petersen(3) reclassifies spring specimens (see SIMILAR)

Ramaria rubripermanens.edibility: edible and choice, especially in juvenile stage, where branches are so short and tips so stiff that the fruitbodies look spiny, (Petersen)
Ramaria rubripermanens.taste: negligible when fresh or very weak of vegetables; when fried in the juvenile stage, a fine, mildly nutty flavor (Petersen), not distinctive, (Marr)
Ramaria rubripermanens.odour: very weakly fragrant, often strong of fenugreek when dried, (Petersen), musty sweet (Marr)
Ramaria rubripermanens.habitat: terrestrial, collected under white pine, June, September, October, (Marr), May, June, (Petersen)

Ramaria sandaracina.nameOrigin: means 'pertaining to realgar [a yellowish mineral]' or 'pertaining to beebread', from Latin 'sandaraca' derived from Greek 'sandarake'
Ramaria sandaracina.habitat: terrestrial, under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), October and November

Ramaria spinulosa.habitat: usually under Pinus spp. (pine), (Petersen), coniferous forests usually under Pinus, fruiting in fall, (Exeter)

Ramaria stricta.edibility: inedible (little flesh and flavor not pleasing), (Arora), edible but a little tough (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Ramaria stricta.taste: bitter, styptic, or mildly astringent-bitter, (Petersen), often somewhat metallic or bitter (Arora), peppery (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), bitter (Miller)
Ramaria stricta.odour: sweet, often pungent, of anise, (Petersen), often faintly sweetish (Arora), slightly resembling anise (Marr), spicy (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), slightly garlic to radish-like (Miller)
Ramaria stricta.habitat: on rotting coniferous wood and (occasionally) hardwood, mostly July to November, (Petersen), single or in groups or tufts on rotting logs and branches (mostly of hardwoods, but also of conifers), (Arora), on conifer wood under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Marr), spring to fall (Bacon)

Ramaria stuntzii.habitat: on ground in old coniferous forest, usually Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), occasionally in fairy rings, fall, (Scates-Barnhart), on ground under Western Hemlock, usually produces a large number of fruitbodies in a fairy ring, (Marr)

Ramaria subviolacea.habitat: deeply buried in needle debris and humus under Abies grandis (grand fir) and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)

Ramaria suecica.habitat: on humus and leaf mold (usually coniferous but sometimes hardwood); August to December, (Petersen)

Ramaria testaceoflava.taste: mildly to moderately bitter, sometimes somewhat astringent, (Petersen), slight to distinctly bitter (Marr), bitter (Scates-Barnhart)
Ramaria testaceoflava.odour: none to mildly pleasant or earthy, (Petersen), not distinctive, or faintly sweet, (Marr)
Ramaria testaceoflava.habitat: terrestrial, under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), September to November, (Marr), single, gregarious or in troops, September to November, (Petersen)

Ramaria thiersii.nameOrigin: in honor of Harry D. Thiers
Ramaria thiersii.habitat: above ground or partly underground: in the normally drier Sierra Nevada, fruitbodies are subhypogeous and therefore pale in color, but in wetter northern Idaho, fruitbodies usually develop above ground and are larger and more brightly colored, fruiting in June, (Petersen), under mixed conifers with true firs, above 2500 feet (760 meters) in Idaho or 5000 feet (1525 meters) in Sierra Nevada of California, (Scates-Barnhart), fruits in humus or soil and matures above the ground, associated with Pinaceae spp., June, (Castellano)

Ramaria tsugina.nameOrigin: 'tsugina' means 'pertaining to Tsuga', referring to its growth on Tsuga canadensis wood
Ramaria tsugina.habitat: on rotting coniferous wood for WA specimen, September, (Marr), on wood of Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock) in New York [also September], (Petersen), single to gregarious, along margins of bogs among mosses or on wet soil under conifers and Alnus (alder) spp., September and October, (Castellano)

Ramaria velocimutans.habitat: terrestrial, under Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) or Taxus brevifolia (Western Yew), September to November, (Marr)

Ramaria verlotensis.habitat: terrestrial, type collected in November, (Marr), fruits in humus or soil and matures above ground, associated with Pinaceae spp., November, (Castellano)

Ramaria vinosimaculans.odour: "fresh, mildly spicy or fragrant, perhaps of tobacco", (Petersen), musty-sweet (Marr)
Ramaria vinosimaculans.habitat: fruiting under mixed coniferous forests, including Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), Abies grandis (Grand Fir), and Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar), in spring and fall, (Petersen), under Tsuga heterophylla (Marr)

Ramaria violaceibrunnea.odour: sometimes weakly fragrant (Petersen), not distinctive or faintly sweet (Marr)
Ramaria violaceibrunnea.habitat: in coniferous woods, under Taxus brevifolia (Western Yew), Abies amabilis (Amabilis Fir), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), or Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Marr)

Ramariopsis crocea.taste: none (Coker), no taste according to Coker and Doty but bad according to Wehm. (Corner)
Ramariopsis crocea.habitat: on the ground among grass in the woods (Corner), single or in small groups, trooping +/- tufted; on soil in woodland, also on rotting wood, woody debris, leaf and needle litter and rotting fern fronds; fall, (Buczacki)

Ramariopsis 'kunzei'.habitat: scattered to densely gregarious "on ground in mixed woods and under conifers, frequently hidden in the duff"; in redwood forests late fall, winter, early spring, (Arora), single, gregarious, or cespitose [in tufts], in woods and pastures, mostly terrestrial, occasionally on decayed wood, (Corner(2)), late summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Sparassis radicata.edibility: edible and exceptional: thorough cooking needed to render it tender, for instance gentle sauting or parboiling followed by baking or stewing, (Arora), leave the base when collecting for food, so that it will fruit the next year, (Ammirati)
Sparassis radicata.odour: spicy-fragrant, (Arora), strong, somewhat disagreeable or like smoked bacon, (Castellano), pleasant (Ammirati)
Sparassis radicata.habitat: usually single at or near the bases of conifer trunks and stumps, fruiting usually in the late fall or winter, (Arora), single, typically within 2 meters of the base of a living coniferous tree (Pseudotsuga, Pinus), fall, (Castellano)

Thelephora americana.habitat: on the ground and on small twigs, probably Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Ginns)

Thelephora anthocephala.odour: "inparticular or none" (var. anthocephala), foetid - ?in all cases - it is not certain whether really foetid or merely so in decay (var. americana)
Thelephora anthocephala.habitat: gregarious on the ground in woods, especially of Fagus (beech) and Quercus (oak), also coniferous

Thelephora caespitulans.habitat: on the ground in mixed or coniferous woods, (Corner), on the ground in mixed woods in Vermont and South Carolina, in dense coniferous woods in Washington, (Burt)

Thelephora caryophyllea.habitat: on sandy ground in coniferous woods, (Corner), single or in groups on soil in coniferous woods, summer and fall, (McKnight)

Thelephora intybacea.habitat: "Ground in pine woods, growing up from the layer of fallen leaves; saprobic on rotten woody material of all kinds; in mixed woods", (Ginns), generally cespitose; in pine woods, (Corner), August to October, (Burt)

Thelephora mollissima.habitat: "in woods", (Corner), BC collection fruiting up from base of old 4 x 4 conifer post, (J. Ginns, pers. comm.)

Thelephora multipartita.habitat: "Soil under deciduous trees, especially oaks; on earth, upland rocky woods (mixed oak and pine), damp woods, in rich humus near base of oak", (Ginns), single, scattered, or in clusters "on soil in mixed woods and hardwoods, especially under oak", July to November, (Bessette)

Thelephora penicillata.habitat: on bare earth and encrusting leaves, twigs, grasses etc., under hardwoods or conifers, (Corner), leaves, including partly decayed Fagus leaves in moist groves, (for var. penicillata), on Pinus contorta var. latifolia (for var. byssoideofimbriata), moist places, encrusting small twigs and moss; encrusting herbaceous plants; encrusting stems, (for f. subfimbriata), (Ginns), fall (Buczacki)

Thelephora regularis.habitat: single or gregarious, in moss in wet places and in humus, (Corner for var. regularis), "in moss in wet places and in humus; damp mossy earth, damp sandy soil; soil among mosses in moist places", (Ginns(5) for var. regularis)

Thelephora scissilis.odour: none in India and Borneo specimens referred here
Thelephora scissilis.habitat: gregarious on ground in woods, (Corner), gregarious on ground, Washington, January, (Burt)

Thelephora terrestris.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "growing on the ground", (Lincoff(1))
Thelephora terrestris.spores: purplish brown (Arora), purplish to purplish brown (Phillips)
Thelephora terrestris.odour: mild or earthy (Arora), none (Corner), like moldy earth (Lincoff(2))
Thelephora terrestris.habitat: occasionally single but more often in confluent masses or clustered or in groups, growing in humus, sandy soil, decaying vegetable matter, on old stumps, climbing up herbaceous stems or tree seedlings, (Arora), year-round, mostly July to December, (Lincoff(2)), July to September, (Phillips), on the ground in coniferous woods, often on roots, stumps and seedlings, rarely in deciduous woods, mainly fall but at all seasons, (Corner)

Tremellodendropsis tuberosa.habitat: single or in groups on ground in woods or clearings, (Arora), single, gregarious, or cespitose [in tufts], on the ground in the forest, "or among grass, moss, or on bare soil in the open", (Corner(2)), late summer to fall (Buczacki)

Abstoma reticulatum.habitat: under or on duff under cypress or fir, January to July, (Zeller for CA)

Abstoma townei.nameOrigin: after Stuart S. Towne, who collected the type
Abstoma townei.habitat: on soil in pastures and waste land, (Smith), the Oregon specimen in dried creek bottom or draw, on decomposed granite soil, (NYBG)

Apioperdon pyriforme.edibility: edible when young, may be bitter if not absolutely white and firm inside, (Arora)
Apioperdon pyriforme.habitat: "scattered to densely gregarious or clustered on stumps, rotting logs, sawdust, and in lignin-rich humus", (Arora), usually "in clusters of up to dozens", more rarely single, on dead, usually rotten wood of hardwoods and conifers, "commonly on stumps and roots, sometimes also on soil, but then always connected to wood by mycelial strands", (Breitenbach), fruits in fall, but spore cases persist throughout year, (McKnight), also on dead Fomes fomentarius (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), summer to fall (Buczacki)

Astraeus hygrometricus.nameOrigin: from Greek, meaning "which measures humidity", because of changing shape with moisture, (Lincoff(1))
Astraeus hygrometricus.habitat: single, scattered, or gregarious "in old fields, sand or sandy soil, pastures, roadsides, waste places, etc.", (Arora), almost any habitat from sandy dunes to high mountains, September to November, but sometimes keeps it shape and condition for a year or more, (Phillips), on "soil surface margins of woodland, open areas" (Phosri(1) for A. smithii)

Astraeus pteridis.habitat: single, widely scattered, or in groups "on ground, usually along roads, railroad tracks, in waste places, old fields, etc., but sometimes in woods", (Arora)

Battarrea phalloides.nameOrigin: 'phalloides' means 'like a phallus (or Phallus)'; "stevenii" after Finnish botanist Christian von Steven, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Battarrea phalloides.odour: spore mass sometimes has unpleasant odor when old (Arora)
Battarrea phalloides.habitat: single, widely scattered, or in groups "in sand, poor soil, and waste places (but often under trees in deep shade)", (Arora), single to scattered on soil in arid regions, (Smith), dry places on sandy soils, sometimes on woody debris or sawdust, (Courtecuisse), fruits in all seasons during wet periods, mature fruitbodies persist a long time, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), spring, summer, winter, fall

Bovista californica.nameOrigin: refers to its range in California
Bovista californica.edibility: unknown, "probably too small to have culinary value", (MykoWeb)
Bovista californica.habitat: often gregarious, often "on the edges of alpine lakes and seeps", (Siegel), single to clustered, "occasionally in broad arcs", "growing in sparse grass, herbs, and mosses of moist montane meadows, especially those adjoining lakes and streams", "fruiting from late spring to early fall", (MykoWeb)

Bovista pila.habitat: single or in groups, in grassy areas, stables, corrals, or open woods, summer and fall; old spore cases can last the winter, (Ammirati), June to October, (Lincoff)

Bovista plumbea.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "lead-like", from the color of the endoperidium, (Lincoff(1))
Bovista plumbea.habitat: single, scattered, or gregarious in grassy places, (Arora), usually gregarious, meadows and pastures, (Breitenbach), spring, summer, fall (Lincoff)

Bovistella utriformis.habitat: on the ground "in fields, lawns and along roadsides", (Zeller), in "waste places, roadsides, and pastures", summer and fall, (Smith)

Calbovista subsculpta.edibility: edible but only when spore mass is white, (Phillips)
Calbovista subsculpta.habitat: single to gregarious, occasionally cespitose [in tufts], in subalpine to alpine habitats, April to August, (Seidl), gregarious, usually single, but occasionally cespitose [in tufts], "in disintegrated rock mixed with soil or in open coniferous forest, 3,000-11,000 feet above sea level", April to August, (Morse), under conifers in the mountains, often under ponderosa pine on the eastern slope of the Cascades, (Ammirati), single to gregarious in subalpine open areas near forest edge, April to August, (Ramsey)

Calvatia booniana.nameOrigin: after Dr. William Judson Boone, first president of the College of Idaho, who was keenly interested in the central Rocky Mountain mushroom flora, and who had some beautiful specimens of this species that A.H. Smith saw in 1935, (Zeller(13))
Calvatia booniana.edibility: edible when firm and white, but has laxative effects on some, do not eat if there is the slightest trace of color (yellow, green, or brown), (Arora)
Calvatia booniana.habitat: on soil under sagebrush or in grassy areas in arid regions, (Zeller), single, widely scattered, or in groups, "under sagebrush or juniper and in other open areas", in arid or semi-arid regions, especially in late spring and summer, (Arora), July to August (Lincoff)

Calvatia candida.habitat: in arid places under sagebrush and in grassy places, summer and fall

Calvatia cyathiformis.edibility: edible when firm and white inside (Arora)
Calvatia cyathiformis.habitat: on ground in grassy places like pastures, often in the prairie and near-desert communities, during the later summer and fall, (Zeller(13)), widely scattered to gregarious or in rings in pastures and other grassy places, (Arora)

Calvatia elata.habitat: "among grass or mosses in low grounds and in shrubby places", summer and fall, (Zeller), on low ground or stabilized sand dunes at the edge of wet areas, (Ramsey), on "low ground in brushy places such as bog edges or on grassy to mossy wet areas", (Smith)

Calvatia fragilis.habitat: grows among sagebrush and other desert shrubs on Great Plains and in Rocky Mountains, (McKnight), "scattered to gregarious on the open prairies or in pasture land", late summer and fall, (Zeller(13))

Calvatia gigantea.edibility: edible [when young] and choice, (Lincoff), edible when young and white all the way through, (Smith)
Calvatia gigantea.odour: none when young, fetid when old, (Miller)
Calvatia gigantea.habitat: single or gregarious "on low ground under brush and often bordering woodland pools, sometimes abundant along drainage ditches, late summer and early fall", (Zeller), occurs in brushy areas, woods, pastures and occasionally in urban surrounding, during late spring, summer, or fall, (Ammirati)

Calvatia lacerata.habitat: type single in a young Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir) area

Calvatia lloydii.nameOrigin: after C.G. Lloyd who recognized the species as undescribed
Calvatia lloydii.habitat: in dry coniferous woods in mountains, (Zeller(13)), May to August in California, (Zeller(3))

Calvatia ochrogleba.habitat: type from meadows near Aurora, Marion County, Oregon

Calvatia owyheensis.habitat: type on soil in Owyhee County, Idaho, late spring

Calvatia pachyderma.habitat: in open places in arid regions, (Zeller)

Calvatia pallida.habitat: open woods and in meadows "in duff and soil at high elevations, summer and fall"

Calvatia paradoxa.nameOrigin: means 'strange, contrary to expectation', presumably because "The species has spores like a Scleroderma, capillitium much like that of C. polygonia and the over-all appearance of Calvatia depressa." [Zeller(13), Latin names in italics]
Calvatia paradoxa.habitat: type on soil in mountain sheep pasture, summer, Colorado, (Zeller), on pastures or range lands in mountainous areas of Idaho, (Ramsey)

Calvatia rubroflava.edibility: edible when young and pure white (Bessette for C. rubroflava)
Calvatia rubroflava.odour: none at first, becoming strong like old ham when old, (Bessette)
Calvatia rubroflava.habitat: usually on cultivated soil (Zeller), "several to gregarious on cultivated soil", (Bessette)

Calvatia sculpta.habitat: in conifer forests at high altitudes (Kreisel), on duff in conifer forests at high altitudes, summer and fall, (Zeller), single or in small groups under conifers or sometimes in the open, late spring, summer, and fall, (Arora)

Calvatia tatrensis.habitat: growing on waste land under sagebrush, summer, (Zeller(13))

Chlamydopus meyenianus.nameOrigin: after the collector of type, P.J.F. Meyen
Chlamydopus meyenianus.habitat: single to scattered or in small groups "in sandy, gravelly, or volcanic soil, sand dunes, gypsum flats, and other barren places, sometimes also in adobe soil", (Arora), originating 3-8cm below soil; usually single; "in sandy, sand-clay, or volcanic soil, on sand dunes, and in gypsum flats; in the open or usually in partial shade of desert vegetation; in arid or semiarid regions", (Long), single to scattered on waste soil in arid regions, (Smith(4))

Disciseda candida.habitat: in pastures and grassy areas, (Smith), single or cespitose, growing in the soil and partly exposed when fully grown, (Coker), single or in groups in pastures or other grassy and open areas, along paths, in barnyards, etc., (Arora), several to gregarious on ground "in open often dry fields, dunes, desert areas or disturbed areas"; spring, summer, fall, (Miller)

Disciseda subterranea.habitat: gregarious to single, on soil in pastures, summer and fall

Gastropila fumosa.odour: often unpleasant, a combination of sour milk, diesel oil and pit toilet, (Ramsey)
Gastropila fumosa.habitat: single to gregarious under spruce and fir in the mountains, summer and early fall, (Zeller), single to gregarious "in duff (sometimes buried) under spruce, fir, and other mountain conifers", (Arora), spring and summer (Trudell)

Gastropila hesperia.habitat: collections in Canyon County on farmland, June and August, collections in Owyhee County in desert country with sagebrush and cheatgrass, December and January, (Ramsey), along a street in sandy soil (Zeller, for California type)

Geastrum campestre.habitat: "in parks and gardens; on calcareous, well-drained soil", (Pegler(4) following Sunhede 1989), gregarious in sandy pasture, September and October (Smith(49))

Geastrum corollinum.habitat: on well-drained soil, usually in hardwood woods or in hedgerows with hardwood shrubs, (Pegler for Britain who say it is reported on juniper in Sweden), on waste land in arid regions (Smith), several to numerous, "on ground among grasses, litter, and duff, often recorded near juniper"; summer and fall, (Miller)

Geastrum coronatum.habitat: various, usually on well-drained soil, often in hedgerows, (Pegler for Britain), usually in small, trooping or +/- tufted groups, fall, (Buczacki)

Geastrum fimbriatum.habitat: in hardwood or conifer woodland, "or in parks or gardens associated with trees, usually on calcareous soil", (Pegler), scattered on rich humus in low woods of hardwood trees, (Smith(49))

Geastrum floriforme.nameOrigin: means 'with the form of a flower'
Geastrum floriforme.habitat: gregarious, usually on well-drained soil, (Pegler), single or in small groups on sandy soil, July to October, (Phillips), single to scattered, on soil, (McKnight)

Geastrum minimum.habitat: on well drained, calcareous soil, sometimes on dunes, (Pegler), usually in small, trooping or +/- tufted groups, fall, (Buczacki)

Geastrum pectinatum.habitat: usually with conifers, "in woods or parks or at roadsides", occasionally with hardwoods, often gregarious, fall (Pegler)

Geastrum quadrifidum.habitat: in Fagus (beech) woodland on calcareous soil in Britain, elsewhere in Europe often in conifer woodland, (Pegler), gregarious, sometimes cespitose, in spruce forests on needle litter, summer and fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), common in conifer woods in Great Lakes area, especially plantations, (Smith(4)), "usually scattered to gregarious with only the top of the mycelial ball visible when immature"; September and early October, (Smith(49)), sagebrush hills, all months except freezing weather, (Ramsey for Idaho)

Geastrum rufescens.odour: unopened and just opened fruitbodies have "a very pleasant and decided fruity fragrance" (Coker)
Geastrum rufescens.habitat: "in woodlands or on heathlands, usually on calcareous, often sandy soil, sometimes in dunes", mature in fall, (Pegler), more or less buried in duff near hardwoods, gregarious to clustered or in gregarious clusters, late summer and fall, (Ramsey), gregarious to clustered or the clusters gregarious, late summer and fall, (Smith(4)), cespitose-gregarious "in debris on light soil around hardwood stumps", (Smith(49)), usually clustered in light soil around decaying hardwood stumps, late summer and fall, (McKnight), usually around the bases of oak stumps in groups (Coker), single or in small to large, trooping or +/- tufted groups, on soil in hardwood woodland or healthland, "also sometimes on unimproved grassland, dunes and other habitats", fall, (Buczacki)

Geastrum saccatum.edibility: inedible "in the mature state in which it is usually found", (Arora)
Geastrum saccatum.habitat: in leaf litter, rich humus, around old stumps, summer and fall, (Ammirati), single, scattered, or in groups in humus under trees, especially conifers, in woods or occasionally in the open, (Arora), July to October (Lincoff), grouped around decaying stumps in hardwood forests or under junipers, late summer, (McKnight)

Geastrum schmidelii.habitat: "on coastal sand dunes, amongst grass and moss in dune slacks, occasionally elsewhere in calcareous, sandy places", (Pegler for Britain), on rich humus in hardwood forest, apparently gregarious (Smith(49)), summer and fall, (Smith(4)), single or in small to large, trooping, +/- tufted groups, (Buczacki)

Geastrum striatum.habitat: usually gregarious; "in woods, gardens and parks, amongst litter, often on rich or calcareous soil", (Pegler for Britain), usually in small to large, trooping +/- tufted groups; on rich soil in woods, parkland, gardens, dunes, cemeteries and other habitats, most often with conifers; late summer and fall, (Buczacki for Britain/Ireland)

Geastrum triplex.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning 'triple', from the peridium, (Lincoff(1))
Geastrum triplex.edibility: supposedly edible when white inside, but rarely found at that stage, and too tough and fibrous to eat later, (Arora), not edible (Phillips)
Geastrum triplex.habitat: "on well-drained, usually calcareous soil, on humus, leaf litter and compost", in hardwood woodland or in more open areas, (Pegler), single or in groups in humus under trees (usually hardwood), (Arora), several to many, in leaves in open deciduous woods, August to October, (Lincoff(2)), gregarious, more rarely single, on soils in hardwood and mixed hardwood-conifer forests, (Breitenbach), woodland and grassland (Lincoff(1)), usually in small to large, trooping or +/- tufted groups; on rich soil and among leaf litter, usually in hardwood woodland, parks, gardens, "also embankments, road-side verges, sand dunes", very occasionally with conifers; summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Geastrum umbilicatum.habitat: closely gregarious "on sand and debris at base of old pine stump in open mixed woods", (Smith(49))

Lycoperdon curtisii.nameOrigin: named after Rev. M.A. Curtis, state botanist of North Carolina, 1808-1872, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
Lycoperdon curtisii.habitat: gregarious to cespitose in pastures and open areas, fall, (Smith(39)), gregarious in grass, late summer and fall, (Ramsey)

Lycoperdon dermoxanthum.habitat: densely gregarious to clustered "on waste soil, pastures, etc.; summer and fall", (Smith), on rich, organic soil "in grassy habitats, road sides, pastures, woodland edges"; usually in small to large trooping groups; late summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Lycoperdon floccosum.nameOrigin: means 'floccose, full of locks of wool'
Lycoperdon floccosum.habitat: reported from sandy soil along river bank, under trees, (Ramsey)

Lycoperdon marginatum.habitat: scattered to numerous, even cespitose [in tufts], on sandy soil; summer and fall, (Ramsey), on sandy soil, summer and fall, (Smith), single, scattered, or in groups, "on the ground, usually on sandy soil, in oak-pine woods, or in nutrient poor habitats; June to October", (Bessette)

Lycoperdon molle.edibility: edible when flesh is completely white (Phillips)
Lycoperdon molle.habitat: on soil and humus in either hardwood or coniferous forests, late summer and fall, (Smith), Oregon collection on ground in logged off land; two Seattle collections in moist virgin forest, (NYBG), usually gregarious, on soil in hardwood and coniferous forests, summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Lycoperdon nettyanum.nameOrigin: after Nettie Laycock who found the type
Lycoperdon nettyanum.habitat: scattered to cespitose on soil in woodland clearings, fall

Lycoperdon nigrescens.odour: not found "to have an odor other than the usual slightly unpleasant smell that all ripening puffballs develop", (Arora), when young unpleasant like Apioperdon pyriforme, (Breitenbach), unpleasant (Miller), strong, gas or metallic, (Buczacki)
Lycoperdon nigrescens.habitat: single, scattered, or in groups "in humus and debris in deep woods", (Arora), usually gregarious, on "soil in hardwood and conifer forests, as well as on heath soils and alpine meadows, prefers acid soils", summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Lycoperdon perlatum.edibility: edible when firm and white inside, not if there is the slightest trace of yellow, "bland at best and bitter at worst", (Arora)
Lycoperdon perlatum.habitat: single, scattered, gregarious, or clustered, "on ground in woods and under trees, along roads, or sometimes in the open", usually fruiting in fall or winter, (Arora), usually gregarious, more rarely single, on soil and needle litter in conifer or mixed forests, more rarely outside forests, summer to fall, (Breitenbach), "on ground in conifer or hardwood forests or on mulch or compost piles" (Bessette), "in woods of various kinds, also in lawns or on cultivated ground", (Ammirati)

Lycoperdon pulcherrimum.edibility: edible when spore mass is white (Bessette)
Lycoperdon pulcherrimum.odour: when maturing distinctly aromatic, somewhat like that of L. marginatum but not nearly as offensive, (Coker)
Lycoperdon pulcherrimum.habitat: on humus under hardwoods in fall, (Ramsey), single to dense clusters, on sandy soil in open hardwood forests, often in clearings for fire lanes or in pastures, (McKnight), single to scattered on soil and humus under conifers or hardwoods, August to October, (Bessette)

Lycoperdon rimulatum.habitat: on "soil and duff in woods and along their borders or on sandy soil on waste land with a few trees present", (Smith(4)), on the ground in fields or pastures; August to October, (Bowerman)

Lycoperdon subcretaceum.habitat: single to widely scattered or in small groups in duff under mountain conifers, especially Picea (spruce) and Abies (fir), late spring through early fall, (Arora), in duff of Abies (fir), Tsuga (hemlock), and Picea (spruce) under alpine conditions from 6000 - 8500 feet, July and August, (Zeller(3)), single to scattered "in forests of spruce and alpine fir, summer and fall", (Zeller(13))

Lycoperdon subincarnatum.habitat: "scattered, in groups, or in clusters on decaying, mossy hardwood logs and stumps; August to October", (Bessette)

Lycoperdon umbrinum.habitat: single to gregarious or subcespitose [somewhat tufted] on leaf mold under conifers, occasionally on wood, September to November, (Ramsey), mainly in dry parts of hardwood or coniferous woods (Lincoff(1)), usually gregarious, in montane spruce forests on soil among needle litter, grasses, and herbs, as well as on burned ground, commonly in clearcuts; summer to fall, (Breitenbach)

Lycoperdon 'vernimontanum'.habitat: open places in coniferous forests, in the duff or occasionally on rotten wood

Mycenastrum corium.edibility: edible (McKnight), presumably edible when firm and white inside (Arora)
Mycenastrum corium.habitat: scattered to gregarious on ground (sometimes partly buried) "in horse corrals, composted areas, and fields where livestock have been grazing", all year round in California, (Arora), single to grouped, "on bare soil in pastures, barnyards, feedlots", summer and fall, (McKnight), several to gregarious "on the ground at low elevations in open sagebrush and saltbush dominated communities, or in grassy or shrubby wet areas in dry prairie"; spring and summer, (Miller)

Phellorinia herculeana.habitat: single or in small groups, "occasionally two or three growing from a common base", "in desert soil, usually near shrubs"

Pisolithus arhizus.odour: "mild to aromatic or unpleasant, depending on the age", (Arora), strong and pleasant mushroomy (Lincoff(1)), mild when young, unpleasant when old (Miller)
Pisolithus arhizus.habitat: single, widely scattered, or in small groups "on or along roads, in waste places, and in hardpacked, poor, sandy, or gravelly soil", mainly late summer and fall, forms mycorrhizal associations with a variety of trees and shrubs, (Arora), "in sandy or well drained soils, old lawns, roadsides, and pine woods, July to October", (Phillips), "frequent in dry pinewoods, beneath juniper in dunes, in grassland, and in the remains of charcoal kilns", spring to late fall, (Lincoff(1))

Scleroderma albidum.habitat: underground in the immature phase, single or gregarious, at times cespitose, in a variety of habitats, (Guzman), mostly single; "occasional under broad-leaved evergreen trees in temperate areas", (Ramsey)

Scleroderma areolatum.taste: slightly sweet, fungous, or not appreciable, (Guzman)
Scleroderma areolatum.odour: slightly sweet, fungous, or not appreciable, (Guzman), strong when cut open, unpleasant, (Phillips)
Scleroderma areolatum.habitat: gregarious to cespitose, sometimes single, developing in soil or humus, occasionally on scraps of wood, in woods and open places, including gardens, in damp shady places, (Guzman), single to gregarious, on soil "at forest edges, as well as in fallow fields and in hardwood forests", summer to fall, (Breitenbach), in deciduous and conifer woods (Ramsey)

Scleroderma bovista.habitat: on or under the ground at maturity, gregarious or sometimes cespitose, on soil or sometimes in sand, (Guzman), mostly gregarious, rare under conifers, (Ramsey), on soil "on dry, free-draining sites, often alongside roads and paths"; single or in small, trooping or +/- tufted groups; summer to fall, (Buczacki)

Scleroderma cepa.habitat: gregarious on humus in hardwood woods, infrequently with conifers, also in sandy soils in arid or semi-arid scrub, (Guzman), single, scattered, or in groups under hardwood and coniferous trees "in woods, in gardens, and along roadsides", July to October, (Phillips), in semi-arid lands and among hardwoods and conifers (Ramsey), fruits year-round (Trappe, M.(3))

Scleroderma citrinum.edibility: poisonous causing nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and even chills and cold sweats, (Arora)
Scleroderma citrinum.taste: rubbery when fresh, without odor or bread-like when mature (Guzman), strong and acrid (Lincoff(1)), bitter (Miller)
Scleroderma citrinum.odour: rubbery when fresh, without odor or bread-like when mature; in dried specimens there is a characteristic odor like decomposed fish (Guzman), strong and pungent when cut open (Phillips), strong and acrid (Lincoff(1))
Scleroderma citrinum.habitat: gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] on soil or on rotten wood, in general in mossy places in the woods, (Guzman), usually in forests but sometimes in gardens or in sandy or disturbed soil, (Arora), July to November (Lincoff(2)), "on the ground or sometimes partly buried, in woods, along paths, also in gardens, flower beds, or under cultivated shrubs", fall, sometimes also in spring, (Ammirati), sometimes rather sunken in the ground, occasionally single but usually gregarious, "in forests, at forest edges, as well as in grassland under shrubs and trees, also among mosses", summer to fall, (Breitenbach), under hardwood and coniferous trees (Ramsey)

Scleroderma floridanum.habitat: gregarious on sand or on soil

Scleroderma laeve.habitat: gregarious or cespitose [in tufts], in soils that are often sandy, in woods or dry scrub with Acacia, Eucalyptus, rarely with conifers, (Guzman), "under conifers and broad-leaved evergreen trees", "also in semi-arid locations", (Ramsey)

Scleroderma meridionale.taste: barely perceptible, like rubber, sometimes a little sweet or disagreeable, (Guzman)
Scleroderma meridionale.habitat: single or sometimes cespitose [in tufts] in sand near conifers, found buried almost completely, showing on the upper part of the peridium above the surface, (Guzman), "in sandy soils and dunes in vicinity of hardwood and coniferous trees", (Ramsey)

Scleroderma polyrhizum.habitat: underground when spherical, above ground when opened, gregarious in pastures, rarely in woods, (Guzman), single or in groups "on or partially buried in sandy soil, often along roads or on hillsides", August-November, (Bessette), forms underground, single to clustered, "on hard clay or sandy soil under hardwoods, in lawns, or on bare soil", late summer and fall, (McKnight), rare under deciduous trees (Ramsey), "on hillsides, along roads, in ditches, poor soil, sand, asphalt, gravel, etc.", (Arora)

Scleroderma verrucosum.habitat: gregarious to cespitose on ground in hardwood woods, gardens, parks, and streets, (Guzman), summer and fall (Bacon), on ground, very occasionally on rotting wood, (Buczacki)

Tulostoma albicans.nameOrigin: refers to the white color of the endoperidium (Wright)
Tulostoma albicans.habitat: sandy soil, February, April to June, August, October to November

Tulostoma albocretaceum.nameOrigin: name applied to the chalky white color of the endoperidium, (Wright)
Tulostoma albocretaceum.habitat: single in clayish soil under shrubs (e.g. Capparis aphylla), February, October

Tulostoma americanum.nameOrigin: means 'of America', refers to its origin and distribution

Tulostoma beccarianum.nameOrigin: refers to fungus being camouflaged as another species, thus simulating it, (Wright)
Tulostoma beccarianum.habitat: "forest soil, among litter, sometimes in dunicolous tree nurseries", January, April to October, December

Tulostoma brumale.habitat: in sand or humus, "but does not grow in truly desertic zones, but rather in areas with vegetational protection, or in sandy soils among herbs, mosses, etc."; mostly October and December

Tulostoma chudaei.nameOrigin: in honor of the collector M. Chudeau
Tulostoma chudaei.habitat: in sand (Trueblood specimen), sandy soil in desertic or very arid regions (Wright)

Tulostoma cretaceum.nameOrigin: refers to the chalky color of the endoperidium (Wright)
Tulostoma cretaceum.habitat: sandy soil in semidesertic regions, March, May, July to October, December

Tulostoma delbustoi.nameOrigin: named after E. del Busto, who found the type
Tulostoma delbustoi.habitat: in sandy soil, Jan 15, (for E. Trueblood collection), in sand in maritime dunes, April 21 and July 8, (for Argentina collection)

Tulostoma excentricum.nameOrigin: probably refers to the eccentric position of the mouth, (Wright)

Tulostoma ferrugineum.nameOrigin: refers to the ferruginous color of the stem, (Oliver)
Tulostoma ferrugineum.habitat: single or gregarious "in semi-stabilized dune areas, in protected hollows", associated with Chrysothamnus (rabbit bush) spp. and other shrubs, late winter and spring, (Oliver), single or gregarious in semi-stabilized dunicolous areas, in protected sites, associated with Chrysothamnus (rabbit bush) spp. and other shrubs, end of winter and spring, (Wright)

Tulostoma fimbriatum.nameOrigin: the name "tuberculatum" probably refers to the spore ornamentation but "does not seem to have been a happy choice since no single feature of the fungus is really tuberculate", (Wright)
Tulostoma fimbriatum.habitat: sandy soil; recorded in March, April, June, and September, (in northern hemisphere), mostly in March

Tulostoma fusipes.nameOrigin: refers to the shape of the stem

Tulostoma giganteum.habitat: in "very humiferous sandy soil in mixed woods", January, November

Tulostoma herteri.nameOrigin: "dedicated to the German botanist who lived most of his life in Uruguay, Dr. Guillermo Herter"
Tulostoma herteri.habitat: "in dry sites with herbaceous vegetation in sandy soils", January, April to July

Tulostoma innermongolicum.nameOrigin: refers to the region of Inner Mongolia where the fungus was found, (Wright)
Tulostoma innermongolicum.habitat: single or gregarious in sandy soil in arid regions

Tulostoma involucratum.nameOrigin: "refers to the involucre-like aspect of the exoperidium in some specimens", (Wright)
Tulostoma involucratum.habitat: sandy soil in arid regions, January, May

Tulostoma jourdani.nameOrigin: in honor of M. Jourdan, the collector of many fungi sent to Patouillard from Africa, (Wright)
Tulostoma jourdani.habitat: sandy soil in desertic zones, April, September

Tulostoma meridionale.nameOrigin: refers to its southern distribution in the United States

Tulostoma meristostoma.nameOrigin: "refers to the slit mouth often appearing in specimens", (Wright)
Tulostoma meristostoma.habitat: single, "typically in sandy soils in arid and gravelly sites", March, April, August

Tulostoma mohavei.nameOrigin: "refers to its having been found in the Mojave Desert, California", (Wright)
Tulostoma mohavei.habitat: sandy soil in desertic areas, March to May

Tulostoma montanum.habitat: in sandy soils in arid regions, sometimes forming large circles; recorded in January, March, April, June, July, September, and October, in northern hemisphere

Tulostoma obesum.nameOrigin: refers to the volva-shaped structure at the base of the stem
Tulostoma obesum.habitat: single, "in sandy soils in exposed desertic or semidesertic areas", March, April, June, August, November

Tulostoma obscurum.nameOrigin: refers to the obscure nature of the spore ornamentation, (Wright)

Tulostoma occidentale.nameOrigin: refers to its western distribution in the United States (Wright)
Tulostoma occidentale.habitat: clayish soil; recorded in January, September, and October, in northern hemisphere

Tulostoma pulchellum.nameOrigin: refers to the color of the endoperidium (Wright)
Tulostoma pulchellum.habitat: February to May, August to December in Northern hemisphere

Tulostoma squamosum.nameOrigin: refers to the very scaly stem (Wright)
Tulostoma squamosum.habitat: calcareous soils among herbaceous vegetation, February to May, July to September, November

Tulostoma striatum.nameOrigin: the name refers to the spore markings, (Wright)
Tulostoma striatum.habitat: typically psammophilous [preferring sand or sandy soil], in exposed or shaded places or in distinctly desertic zones, at sea level or high altitudes; recorded January, March, June, September to December, in northern hemisphere, (Wright), on soil, often in cultivated fields, (Smith)

Tulostoma stuntzii.nameOrigin: in honor of mycologist Dr. Daniel E. Stuntz
Tulostoma stuntzii.habitat: single in sand, semi-stabilized dune areas, growing with Chrysothamnus (rabbit bush) spp., fall, (Oliver), single in sandy soil of semi-stabilized dunicolous zones, growing among Chrysothamnus (rabbit-brush) sp. in fall, (Wright)

Tulostoma thiersii.nameOrigin: dedicated to mycologist Dr. Harry D. Thiers

Tulostoma vulgare.nameOrigin: refers to its being very common (in India), (Wright)
Tulostoma vulgare.habitat: clayish soils probably in flooded areas, May, August

Vascellum lloydianum.nameOrigin: from Latin meaning "of fields", from habitat, (Lincoff(1))
